title: Giants' Injuries Put Rookie In Middle
description: At home this week in Minnesota, Richard and Bridget Engler searched the Internet for news of their son, Derek, an undrafted, free-agent rookie center in the Giants' training camp. He was a long shot to make the team, and the Englers initially did not find any mention of him.

title: A Warning Light Largely Ignored in Thai Currency Crisis
description: The plunge in the Thai baht, followed by a wave of currency depreciations through South and Southeast Asia, illustrates the shortcomings of the international early-warning system set up after the Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95 to head off currency upheavals in emerging economies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC CAHERY, JOSEPH A.
description: Mc CAHERY-Joseph A., 7/30/97, Vice President and General Auditor at Borden Inc., NYC. Devoted father of Joseph A. Jr., James P. and William D.; grandfather of Meagan. The wake will be at the Quinn-Hopping Funeral Home, 145 East Mt. Pleasant Ave, Livingstone NJ, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass, Saturday 9:15AM at St. Teresa of Avila, 306 Morris Ave, Summit, NJ. Interment Holy Sepulchre, East Orange, N.J.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Adolescents'

title: Old Milan, Served Alfresco
description: It is easy to muster good will for the spunky little New York Grand Opera Company and its slightly foolhardy venture of presenting all the Verdi operas in chronological order in Central Park over seven seasons. But good will can be tested, and for one listener it was defeated after only one act of ''Il Corsaro'' last week by a lead tenor who consistently deviated from pitch, unlikable strings and an all but unlistenable male chorus.

title: INSIDE
description: Economy at Slower Pace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, ED
description: POLLACK-Ed. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Phillip Pollack on the loss of his father. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Siebel Marketing Acquired by Grey
description: Grey Advertising in New York has acquired the Siebel Marketing Group, a design and promotion company in New York. Terms were not disclosed. Siebel, with more than 50 employees, will operate as an independent unit. Its clients include several Seagram brands, like Chivas Regal and Captain Morgan rum. Gretchen Siebel, the agency's chairwoman, and Gretchen Mannix, the president, will remain in those posts.

title: Innovations Aid Revival in Hauling Freight by Trains
description: Picture it: A freight train hurtles along at 80 miles an hour, 25 miles an hour faster than most freight trains now travel. An electronic tracking system spots that it is on a collision course with another fast train, still many miles away, and automatically slows one down so they do not cross paths.

title: Human Rights Treaty Deserves Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Charged With Smuggling Deaf Mexicans
description: Federal authorities charged three men today with running an operation based in Southern California through which possibly hundreds of deaf Mexicans were smuggled across the border, kept briefly in a house here, then taken to New York City where they were held in virtual slavery and forced to peddle trinkets.

title: As Bonn Fails at Tax Reform, German Businesses Study U.S.
description: The timing was a coincidence, but no less telling for that: just as United States lawmakers were preening over legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes, German politicians acknowledged failure early today in negotiations to streamline their land's burdensome system of taxation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MISHA DICHTER, the pianist, found himself making a debut yesterday -- on a film set. He was doing a scene for the movie ''Illuminata,'' directed by JOHN TURTURRO, who was a co-author and also acts in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMCHIN, MARK L.
description: TOMCHIN-Mark L. Died July 25 at his home in New York City. He was 56. The cause was Lou Gehrig's disease. During his 30-year career as an executive recruiter, he developed the industry's first specialized practice in the hightechnology arena. Since 1982 he was president of his own firm, Mark L. Tomchin & Associates, Inc. He is survived by his loving wife and companion of 19 years, Barbara Anderson-Tomchin. Memorial service at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam, NYC, Monday, Aug. 4, at 6PM. Memorial gifts, marked ''for research only'' to The ALS Association, 21021 Ventura Blvd., Suite 321, Woodland Hills, CA 91364.

title: Not a Gateway Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: This Man Died, Science Says, Yet Hope Survives
description: The news finally came to the little home on a muddy hill here, to the seven people in a household in which no adult males are left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUFFY, EUGENE H.
description: DUFFY-Eugene H. Of Southold, L.I., (formerly of Forest Hills, N.Y.) on July 30, 1997. Attorney, former Executive Director of the Queens County Division of the American Cancer Society, former member of the Board of Directors of the Queens County Chamber of Commerce and active in many charitable and fraternal organizations. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Grattan). Loving father of Alice Duffy Grant, Eugene O. Duffy, Rosalie Duffy Crabbe, and James H. Duffy. Father-in-law of Philip Grant, Catherine Schmidt Duffy, Robert Crabbe and Mary Ann Harrington Duffy. Cherished grandfather of six. The family will receive friends today from 2 until 9 P.M. at the family residence, 2050 Youngs Avenue, Southold. A Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial will be offered Saturday morning at 11 A.M. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Main Road, Southold. Interment St. Patrick's R.C. Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either, Regis High School, Fordham University or St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, N.Y. DeFriest Funeral Homes, Inc., Directors.

title: WHIRLPOOL CONSIDERS ALLIANCES FOR FINANCIAL UNIT
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that it was exploring ''strategic business options'' for its Whirlpool Financial Corporation unit, including possible alliances or partnerships. Whirlpool said the analysis was part of the company's continuing assessment of how its worldwide businesses can best create value. The company expects to continue a relationship with its financial unit regardless of the study's outcome. Whirlpool Financial, with assets of more than $2.1 billion, provides inventory and consumer financing to the appliance, consumer electronics, lawn and garden, home heating and air-conditioning and music industries.

title: Study Finds Baby Talk Means More Than a Coo
description: When mothers in the United States, Sweden and Russia nuzzle their infants and croon baby talk, they are giving their babies a lot more than tender loving care, scientists have found. The women are producing highly exaggerated speech sounds that provide the basis for all subsequent learning of that language.

title: A Recycled Art Exhibit
description: An art exhibit created by public school students at the Children's Museum of Manhattan that was supposed to close next month has received the ultimate compliment: a longer run at the museum, and a permanent display at a building in the garment district.

title: Living With Terrorism -- and Hope
description: Israelis have lived with terrorism for 30 years, since the Six Day War in 1967. Some years have been better and some have been worse, but none have been completely free of murderous attacks on innocent civilians. One would expect that Israelis would have learned to adapt, but that has not been the case. Each terrorist attack is as shocking as the previous one. Each bloody assault elicits the same outrage.

title: White Sox Are Flying White Flag
description: THEY sure do have a short baseball season in Chicago. As some fans have ruefully suggested, it lasts from the Bulls' celebration to the Bears' first game.

title: A Bargain With Satan And a Devil of a Time
description: From its opening moments, in which a growling narrator thunders out some oracular mumbo jumbo about Armageddon, ''Spawn'' is an incoherent blitz of noise, chintzy special effects and bargain-basement allegory. Based on a popular comic book by Todd McFarlane, the movie has stars like Michael Jai White, John Leguizamo, Martin Sheen, D. B. Sweeney and Theresa Randle. Their apoplectic overacting is more than matched by the special effects in which the movie is garishly gift-wrapped.

title: WESTERN BANCORP TO ACQUIRE SANTA MONICA BANK
description: Western Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Santa Monica Bank for about $198 million in cash or stock. Santa Monica Bank's stock rose 10 percent yesterday, gaining $2.50, to $27. Shares of Western Bancorp were unchanged at $32. Western Bancorp, based in Laguna Niguel, Calif., said it would pay 0.875 of a share, or $28 cash, for each Santa Monica share held. Santa Monica Bank operates eight branches in the Los Angeles area. Western said the deal, expected to close in January, would increase its assets to about $2.1 billion and give it 34 branches in Orange and Los Angeles Counties.

title: Smokers' Tax May Produce A Windfall For Industry
description: In a potential windfall for cigarette producers, new taxes paid by smokers will save the tobacco industry billions of dollars by reducing the amount of money companies would owe if the proposed tobacco settlement plan became law.

title: Amid Hovering Helicopters, a Quick Evacuation of Residents
description: The fear came with a 4 A.M. knock on the door of Lucrecia Ortiz's second-floor apartment, a loud rapping of a police club meant to rouse the sleepy so they could immediately head to safer quarters. Overhead, helicopters hovered, loudly signaling a disturbance on the street below.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH J.
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah J. 8/1/92 Five long, lonely years since we heard your sweet voice call Mom and Dad. Our love and hearts are with you every minute, every day. Hugs, kisses forever. Mom, Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, RONALD H.
description: COHEN-Ronald H. The Board of Trustees, The Men's Club and Sisterhood of The Reform Temple of Forest Hills deeply mourns the passing of their beloved Honorary Trustee Ronald H. Cohen. Our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Roslyn and the entire Cohen family. Funeral services at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, Friday, August 1 at 2:30 P.M. Rabbi Mayer Perelmuter Cantor Cary Schwartz Joel A. Poretz, President Marcia Weinroth, Exec. Dir

title: CAPITAL BANCORP OF MIAMI SAYS IT IS IN ACQUISITION TALKS
description: Shares of Capital Bancorp jumped 9 percent yesterday after the Miami-based bank said it was talking with several companies about a possible acquisition. In Nasdaq trading, the bank's shares rose $3.875, to $44.375, giving the company a market capitalization of $336 million. The announcement comes a month after regulators in Florida said Capital Bancorp could not be controlled by the family of the bank's founder, Abel Holtz. Mr. Holtz founded the bank in 1974 and gave control of the bank to his relatives in 1994 before pleading guilty to Federal perjury charges. His plea permanently bars him from running any federally insured institution.

title: Sun Microsystems to Buy Diba, a Start-Up
description: Seeking to broaden its reach in the consumer market, Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it would acquire Diba Inc., a start-up company that is developing technology for small communications and computing devices called information appliances.

title: Growth Eased To 2.2% Rate In 2d Quarter
description: The economy slowed during the spring as consumers cut back on their spending, Government figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURREN, MARGARET P. (NEE PETERSON)
description: CURREN-Margaret P. (nee Peterson). On July 30, 1997. (Retired teacher, NYC Board of Ed.) Devoted wife of the late John J. (Olympic coach and player, life member NYAC). Beloved mother of John J., Jr. Loving grandmother of Cathleen Byram, Maureen Maksuti, Irene, John, James and Michael. Also survived by six great-grandchildren. Funeral Saturday, 8:45 AM, at Mc Manus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, 9:30 A.M., St. Thomas More R.C. Church, Rockaway Point, N.Y. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Evita

title: I.A.A.F. Reduces Doping Bans
description: Faced with mounting legal challenges in Europe and Asia, the world governing body of track and field today reduced the penalty for its most serious doping violations from a four-year suspension to two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLEETH, CHARLES R.
description: SLEETH-Charles R. The Brooklyn College community mourns the passing of Professor Emeritus of English Charles R. Sleeth. His 22 years of teaching and service will be long remembered. Vernon E. Lattin, President, Brooklyn College

title: Accounts
description: * Borland International Inc., Scotts Valley, Calif., to DNA New Media Group, Chicago, to handle strategic marketing and advertising for the provider of products for software developers, which had been assigned on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Miscellany
description: * TBWA International, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group, acquired an equity stake in Paltemaa Huttunen Santala Oy in Helsinki, Finland. Terms were not disclosed. The agency will be renamed Paltemaa Huttunen Santala/TBWA.

title: In Xanadus of Video, Variety Beyond Dreams
description: IT'S getting to be that time, late on a Saturday afternoon, when you had better have a plan for the evening to avoid being one of New York City's lonely casualties. That's when business picks up at Movie Place, on the second floor of a brownstone on West 105th Street that many New Yorkers call the best video-rental shop on the Upper West Side. At 5:30, a well-fed, athletic-looking young man jogs in and walks up to Gary Dennis, the store's manager, a film scholar without portfolio who affects slicked-back hair and bowling shirts.

title: Oxford to Pay Extra On Late Payments
description: Oxford Health Plans agreed to pay at least $1 million in interest to New York doctors and hospitals on about $238 million in late payments, the New York State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NUGENT, BRENDAN A.
description: NUGENT-Brendan A. One year today. We miss you, and will always. Mom, Dad, Nancy, Chip, Bill and Andy

title: State's Bank Fees Are Highest
description: New Jersey bank customers pay the highest fees in the nation, according to a survey of 29 states conducted by the United States Public Interest Research Group. The consumer advocacy organization found that New Jersey customers pay an average of $234.91 a year in fees for checking accounts and $48 for savings accounts. Among the states surveyed, fees averaged $218.27 for checking accounts and $32.28 for savings accounts.

title: The Puzzle For the U.S.: How to Play Peacemaker
description: Eighteen months ago in his State of the Union address, President Clinton called the United States ''the world's very best peacemaker,'' citing a series of American-brokered agreements in the Middle East.

title: New Alliances and Attitudes on Aid
description: The decision by the President and Congress to restore benefits to half a million elderly and disabled legal immigrants in Tuesday's budget agreement provides a window on the volatile politics of immigration and the way legislators' attitudes toward immigrants can swing from suspicion to sympathy.

title: Military Accountability
description: The Pentagon does not yet know who bombed an Air Force compound in Saudi Arabia last summer. But it long ago identified the officer primarily responsible for security lapses that left American airmen vulnerable to a terrorist attack that killed 19 of them and wounded 500 others. Secretary of Defense William Cohen, in a gutsy and altogether proper decision, has now denied a promotion to that officer, over the vehement objections of the Air Force brass.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: A Weekly Party Glides Through the Night
description: On Wednesday night about 9:30, Mark Anderson, a cabdriver, started pulling into the traffic from the southbound side of Broadway near 66th Street -- and did a double take. Coming up behind him was a blocks-long, fast-moving swarm of bodies in shorts and T-shirts -- swaying, sweating, giggling, flirting, engulfing parked cars and eliciting hoots and hollers from pedestrians on the sidewalk. It may have been the biggest parade of in-line skaters the city has ever seen.

title: Restaurants
description: We could have laid in provisions for the voyage to Greece, but we were far out at sea by the time we discovered we were in the hands of a mad cook.

title: Unexpected Fall In Jobless Claims
description: The number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell last week to the lowest level in more than 23 years, in a sign the United States job market continues to power ahead, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: An Early Blitz of Games Doesn't Faze Syracuse
description: Coaches and top players from the Big East Conference gathered today at Giants Stadium for media day, and in just a few weeks Syracuse Coach Paul Pasqualoni will bring his football team back here to play Wisconsin in the Kickoff Classic on Aug. 24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, DAOK
description: LEE-Daok.The New York Women's Agenda mourns the loss of its distinguished Board member, Doak Lee. Elinor Guggenheimer, Pres.

title: A Flock of Fledglings, Testing Their Wings
description: THE ''Artists in the Marketplace'' program at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, now in its 17th year, is a kind of total-immersion boot camp for artists in the New York region still in an early phase of their careers. Through a 12-week seminar, they are drilled in the arcane skills of grant writing and taxes, briefed on the Byzantine protocols of the art world, and finally earn their stripes in a generously installed group show.

title: Rangers Name a Coach
description: The Rangers yesterday appointed E. J. McGUIRE, a former assistant coach with the old Ottawa Senators of the National Hockey League, to be head coach of their new American Hockey League affiliate when the team begins play this fall in Hartford.

title: A City, a Sound and the Cinema in Mutual Thrall
description: Inspired by sweet, lilting music and a lovely city, Wim Wenders's ''Lisbon Story'' is a dreamy philosophical travelogue made in indulgently poetic style. The word ''story'' in the title is a misnomer, since this wispy film is more gentle meditation than outright tale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUBER, HAROLD A.
description: STRAUBER-Harold A. Beloved husband of Judith. Loving father of Hillary, Meredith and Jocelyn. Dear father-in-law of George and Andrew. Loving grandfather of Stephanie Zilberman and Heather Lewin. Funeral services Friday, August 1, 12:15 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel.

title: Inside Art
description: Big and Contemporary

title: Home Video
description: One reason customers often have trouble finding movies in video stores is that retailers don't think the same way the clientele does, said Ted Engen, president of Video Buyers Group, a Minneapolis company that advises 2,000 retailers across the country. In a recent article in Video Business magazine, Mr. Engen described how a bit of shelf reorganization can lead customers to the smaller independent films, documentaries and higher-grade B movies they want but frequently overlook, can't find or may be unaware of.

title: Inmate Charged With Killing Prison Guard
description: Murder charges were filed today against an inmate accused of fatally stabbing a veteran corrections officer at Bayside State Prison in southern New Jersey on Wednesday, prison officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONLON, MARY ELLEN
description: CONLON-Mary Ellen. Nee O'Connor. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. and Sea Girt, N.J. On July 30, 1997. In her 93rd year. Beloved wife of the late James. Loving mother of Irene Doherty and Mary Sullivan. Mother-in-law of James Doherty and the late Charles Sullivan. Devoted grandmother of Maureen and William Lynch, Kathleen and James Breen, James Sullivan and James Doherty. Dear sister of Edward in Ireland and the late Bea, Joseph, Michael, Thomas and Richard. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Our Lady of Fatima Church, Scarsdale, Saturday, August 2 at 10:30 A.M.

title: Tensions Threaten Angola's 3-Year Peace
description: With Angolan Government officials and rebel leaders trading threats and accusations, Angola's fragile three-year peace process could be headed for a crisis, officials close to the negotiations say.

title: The Spoken Word
description: GALLERY TALK WITH ARTISTS IN RESIDENCE, the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street. A tour and discussion by three artists whose works are in the museum's second-floor gallery: June Clark (''Harlem Quilt''), Gregory Coates (''Riot'') and Vladimir Cybil (''Haiti Meets Harlem''). Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission: $5; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12. Information: (212) 864-4500.

title: Albany School Aid Largesse Faces Harsh Realities in City
description: Though Albany has developed a new generosity toward public education, hundreds of already crowded schools in New York City will be hard pressed to use the money as intended: to reduce class size and begin new preschool programs for the city's 4-year-old children.

title: Mohammed Mahdi al-Jawahri, 97, Iraqi Poet
description: Mohammed Mahdi al-Jawahri, the most famous contemporary Iraqi poet in the Arab world, who was forced to flee his country as an opponent of the Baghdad regime, died in exile in Syria on Sunday. He was 97.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JOHN BARCLAY JR.
description: JONES-John Barclay Jr. On Tuesday, July 29, 1997. Husband of Anita Bills Jones. Father of Katherine Jones Wimmer of Pasadena, CA., Phoebe Jones Schellenberg of Bala Cynwyd, PA., and J. Barclay Jones of Washington, DC. Son of Anna Harvey Jones of Kennett Square, PA. Brother of Curtis Harvey Jones of Winchester, MA., Emily Sander of Cambridge, MA., and Molly Kline of Falls Church, VA. Also survived by six grandchildren. Memorial services will be held at Friends Meeting of Washington, 2111 Florida Avenue NW, Washington, DC, Sunday, August 3 at 2PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Sidwell Friends School, 3825 Wisconsin Avenue N.W., Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Queens Woman Charged In Infant's Death
description: A Queens woman was charged with murder yesterday after the police discovered that she had smothered her newborn baby girl to death, wrapped her in several shopping bags and tucked her in a bedroom closet, just steps away from the room where her two older daughters were sleeping down the hall.

title: Both Sisters Want a Guy Who Just Adores Himself
description: ''Love Serenade'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 21. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Friends With Entangling Alliances
description: Just before Gemma decides to stop speaking, she talks to the audience a little, about ''one of those perfect days that we have in England'' when ''you can see the edge of everything,'' and about a recent trip during which ''Italy was a glass of dark wine, swilled in the mouth.''

title: Corrections
description: The Patents column in Business Day on Monday, about a method registered by Infectech Inc. that seeks to identify the bacteria infecting a patient, rendered a number incorrectly in a quotation from Dr. Mitchell Felder, the chief executive of the company. He said, ''If the pH is 6.95, we can duplicate that,'' not 13.95.

title: Grambling Is Put on Probation
description: For 56 years, Eddie Robinson has been the football coach at Grambling State University in Louisiana, and his 405 victories are the most of any college coach in history. Yesterday, the National Collegiate Athletic Association placed Grambling on two years' probation for violations by Robinson, his son Eddie Robinson Jr. and other coaches at the college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWABER, DAVID
description: SCHWABER-David. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed trustee, past Vice President and Treasurer, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Prof. William Schwartz, Pres.

title: Some big financial guns attack a proposal on derivatives by the accounting standards board.
description: SOME of America's largest financial institutions came out swinging yesterday in a last-ditch effort to block a proposed new accounting rule that would require companies to show derivative securities on their balance sheets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, LEO (LAZAR)
description: BIRNBAUM-Leo (Lazar). Condolences to Sala, Michael and Gail, and his brother, our partner, Arthur Birnbaum. The Families of Willy Apfel, Stanley Katz, Nat Tennenbaum, and all of Learsi

title: Rescuing the District of Columbia
description: The District of Columbia's faltering aspirations to govern itself took a severe blow this week when Congress and the White House agreed to bail out the nation's capital from its financial crisis but at a stiff political price. The agreement would strip Washington D.C.'s Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., and its City Council of many powers and turn them over to a financial control board that was created by Congress two years ago to handle an earlier fiscal debacle. Stripping elected officials of duties is always regrettable. But Congress could not turn over hundreds of millions of dollars to a city administration that is as incompetent as Marion Barry's.

title: Mets Strike Out on Trades for Relievers and for Cubs' McRae
description: Steve Phillips worked aggressively to make his first trade as the Mets' general manager tonight, even proposing a deal that would have sent his star center fielder, Lance Johnson, to the Chicago Cubs. Ultimately, however, Phillips came up empty-handed on that trade and others, and the Mets still do not have the bullpen help they need.

title: ALTERNATIVE LIVING SERVICES TO BUY STERLING HOUSE
description: Alternative Living Services agreed yesterday to buy the Sterling House Corporation, an owner of assisted living residences, for about $170 million in stock. Alternative Living said the combined company would have 178 residences in 19 states and 146 more under construction or development. Annual revenues are expected to exceed $115 million. Under terms of the deal, Alternative Living, based in Brookfield, Wis., said it would issue 1.1 shares for each Sterling share. Sterling House shares surged 22.6 percent yesterday, gaining $4.125, to $22.375. Alternative Living shares slipped 6.25 cents, to $21.5625.

title: No Sign of Trouble, and Then a Fireball on Newark Runway
description: Investigators said tonight that the Federal Express cargo plane that crashed at Newark International Airport early this morning had seemed to land normally, but seconds later began scraping against the runway and turned into a fireball. It ended up on its back, 100 yards from a passenger terminal.

description: FLEISCHNER-Jeannette E. The Teachers College, Columbia University community mourns the loss of its dear friend and colleague, Jeannette E. Fleischner, professor of education. We will miss her greatly. Her more than 25 years of counsel, service, and leadership to the College and her distinguished contributions to the research and teaching of children with disabilities are an enduring legacy that we will celebrate in memorial of her. Arthur Levine, President

title: For Hospitals, a New Prognosis on Fraud-Charge Exposure
description: With the indictment of three executives of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, law enforcement officials are sending a powerful message to administrators and financial executives in the hospital industry: Be very afraid.

title: Chuck Wayne, 74, Guitarist Who Mastered Art of Be-Bop
description: The jazz guitarist Chuck Wayne, who took part in the beginnings of the be-bop movement in the 1940's, played with delicacy and musical wit, and instructed countless young guitarists in the mysteries of the music, died on Tuesday at his home in Jackson, N.J. He was 74.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBLUM, MORGAN ALPERSTEIN
description: GELBLUM-Morgan Alperstein. The Board of Directors of the Canavan Foundation extend their deepest sympathy to the Alperstein and Gelblum families upon the sudden passing of their beloved Morgan. Morgan brought love ito many people's lives and she will always be remembered and cherished.

title: Subway Disruptions and Traffic Jams Inconvenience Hundreds of Thousands
description: More than 300,000 subway riders faced major disruptions during the morning rush yesterday as the Transit Authority scrambled to reroute trains beneath a Brooklyn building where explosives were found.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN TO CLOSE 150 OUTLET STORES
description: The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation said yesterday that it planned to take a $55 million second-quarter charge to close about 150 retail outlet stores and focus more on its branded apparel business. The company, which makes Van Heusen, Izod and Bass clothing and shoes, also said it planned to reposition its Gant brand, which will involve focusing on new and upgraded products and consolidating worldwide design. Phillips-Van Heusen will also leave the sweater-making business, which accounted for an estimated $2 million in losses this year. The company closed about 200 stores in 1995 in a restructuring caused by the decline in popularity of factory outlets.

title: School's Staff Failed to Report Girl's Abuse, Inquiry Charges
description: The little girl arrived at her Coney Island elementary school at least six times last school year displaying telltale signs of abuse: black-and-blue marks on her nose and cheek, an open wound on her head, and, finally, on May 27, a blistering burn mark on her hand.

title: Fraud and Waste in Medicare
description: The Federal agency that oversees Medicare points to the program's tiny overhead as proof it is well administered. But recent reports suggest that Medicare's administrative costs are shockingly low, below 2 percent of costs, because Medicare is shockingly unsupervised. The amount of fraud and waste is huge, and supervision of the quality of medical care provided recipients is largely nonexistent.

title: A Strong First Round Raises Mickelson's Hopes
description: Phil Mickelson and his wife, Amy, have been busy furnishing their new home in Arizona. One day Mickelson hopes to add some major championship trophies to the decor.

description: EISENROD-Solomon. On July 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Sally. Loving father of Michael, Nancy and son-in-law Howard. Dear brother of Barney, Eddie and sister-in-law Mary. Service Friday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment will follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Weld Goes to Washington to Make His Case
description: William F. Weld, the former Governor of Massachusetts, came to Washington today, purportedly to do battle over his nomination as Ambassador to Mexico.

description: BAER-Andrew R., of Armonk, New York, on July 28. Devoted son of Dr. Rudolf L. Baer; loving father of David and Jessica; cherished brother of John R. Baer; uncle of Alexandra and Abigail; and nephew of Eva Baer, Elizabeth and Henry Werner and Virginia and George Grumbach. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Baer Foundation, C/O Dept. of Dermatology, New York University Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, NY 10016-6402.

title: A Pushy Steinbrenner Cannot Sway Watson
description: As the final hours evaporated before the trading deadline at midnight last night, a familiar theme developed in Yankeeland. George Steinbrenner tried to cajole Bob Watson into making a splashy deal for a major player.

title: Former Chief At Aberdeen Is Exonerated
description: The former commanding officer at Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland, which has been rocked by a series of sexual misconduct accusations that have embarrassed the Army, has been exonerated after an investigation, Army officials have reportedly concluded.

title: Former White House Employee Subpoenaed in Harassment Case
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones, who has sued President Clinton on grounds that he sexually harassed her in 1991, have subpoenaed a former White House employee who they contend may have received sexual advances from Mr. Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIES, SAMUEL
description: MARGOLIES-Samuel. On July 31, 1997. Beloved husband of Sally. Devoted father of Paul Margolies and Andrea Sessler. Father-in-law of Dale Margolies and Scott Sessler. Proud Pa, Sam, of Ryan and Jordan Sessler. Funeral services will be held at Parkside Funeral Home, Sunday, 11:30 A.M. Donations to the American Heart Assoc

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Our Better Angels
description: Earl Warren's Supreme Court is long gone, its expansive view of individual rights under the Constitution a distant memory. But some of the ground-breaking opinions written by Justice William J. Brennan Jr. are still fundamentals of our constitutional law, if anything more widely accepted. Why? The question really goes to the Court's role in the American political system.

title: A New Twist on Curfews
description: In recent years, many New Jersey communities have imposed curfews for young people, with varying degrees of success. Last night, officials in Elizabeth began enforcing their own long-neglected curfew, but with a new twist. The curfew bars minors from being out in public without a guardian from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M., except for medical emergencies, work or school, or community or religious events, said Sebastian D'Elia, a spokesman for Mayor J. Christian Bollwage. But rather than simply shooing minors off the streets, the police will take chronic violators to a city-operated ''safe haven'' where three licensed counselors will be on hand, said Patricia Perkins-Auguste, a member of the City Council.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe, That Crazy Little Girl
description: ''IN the springtime some little girls go crazy. Like appletrees sometimes do. I know one such little girl. Guess who she is.'' Alfred Stieglitz sent this riddle to Georgia O'Keeffe in 1922, inscribed under a photograph of an apple tree in blossom. It is one of his oddest equivalences: Georgia O'Keeffe, 35, a crazy little girl. What could he have been thinking?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARETSKY, PROFESSOR BARRY
description: ZARETSKY-Professor Barry. It is with deep sorrow that the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of New York notes the passing of Barry Zaretsky. We shall always be grateful for his invaluable contributions to the interpretation of bankruptcy law as reflected in his many articles and treatises and his participation in bankruptcy panels and seminars throughout the country. We recognize the part he played as a Professor of Bankruptcy in Brooklyn Law School and the sterling example he set as a mentor to his students, many of whom served as our law clerks as well as those who have appeared in our court as competent, able attorneys. We shall miss him. Conrad B. Duberstein Chief Bankruptcy Judge

title: Help Bosnia Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: An Unexpected Spot to Find a Father
description: Duke and Boogie are half-brothers who appear to be your typical orphaned, homeless teen-agers, living by male prostitution and seeking a better life by stealing drugs. Their fraternal devotion would make the Menendez brothers proud.

title: ISRAELIS THREATEN MAJOR CRACKDOWN IN ARAB-RUN AREAS
description: Israeli radio and television reported today that the Government had threatened to send commandos into Palestinian areas and had decreed a series of severe punitive measures against the Palestinian Authority in response to the bombing of the Jerusalem market Wednesday.

title: Spanish Utility Buying A Stake in Brazil
description: A group led by the Spanish utility Iberdrola S.A. won the bidding yesterday for a controlling stake in Cia. de Eletricidade do Estado de Bahia, or Coelba, paying 1.73 billion reais ($1.6 billion), for a slice of Brazil's fast-growing energy market. The Iberdrola group, which also includes the Brazilian pension fund Previ, paid 77 percent more than the minimum price set for the stake by the northeastern state of Bahia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BEBE NEUWIRTH, the Tony Award-winning star of ''Chicago,'' became engaged last month in Paris to MICHAEL DANEK, an actor, singer, dancer and writer, but it was not exactly a whirlwind courtship. They have known each other since 1980.

title: Candidates for Senate Raise $15 Million for the 1998 Race
description: In an early blitz of fund-raising that suggests an expensive and hard-fought contest ahead, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and two Democratic challengers have amassed a combined war chest of $15 million to finance a race that is still more than a year away, according to reports released yesterday.

title: Holders Oust Management Of Sallie Mae
description: Shareholders of the Student Loan Marketing Association ousted the management yesterday by electing a dissident slate of directors to run the company, ending a protracted, bitter struggle over its strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, WILLIAM
description: SIMON-William. August 1, 1992 to August 1, 1997. Dearest Bill, al ways in our hearts and thoughts these past 5 years. Words cannot express the love and respect we shared. We miss that wonderful smile, sense of humor, compassion, class and dignity. A very special person. Remembered forever. Lovingly, Mom and Ellie

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Metro

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages yesterday listing the Oakland hitters who were struck out on Wednesday by the Yankees' David Wells misidentified the one who struck out in the third inning. He was Mark Bellhorn; Ivan Cruz is a Yankee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYLE, JOSEPH D.
description: RYLE-Joseph D. The Board of Managers and staff of East Side House Settlement express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our good friend and benefactor, Mr. Joseph D. Ryle. A member of the Board since 1956 and a dynamic and tireless volunteer of the Winter Antiques Show Committee from 1955 to the present. From 1959 to 1997 he served as Vice President on the Board of Managers, and from 1956 to 1966 as Chairman of the Winter Antiques Show Committee. A founder of the Winter Antiques Show, Mr. Ryle was an integral part of the heart and soul of East Side House-his professionalism, dedication and, especially, his friendship will be deeply missed. David L. Duffy, President Jack McAlinden, Chairman East Side House, Board of Mgrs. John A. Sanchez, Executive Dir. East Side House Settlement

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANAHER CORP., Washington, a tool equipment maker, agreed to acquire Gems Sensors of Plainville, Conn., a maker of level, flow and pressure sensors. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Miss Evers' Boys

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, BELLE
description: BLOCH-Belle. Beloved wife of 61 years of Rabbi Abraham P, devoted mother of Liebe and Zachary Apfel and Raphael and Dorothy Bloch. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear sister of Beatrice Blueweiss and Ruth Neinstein. Services at ''BoulevardRiverside'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, New York, today at 11:30 AM.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The weather has been so wonderful that it seems a shame to eat indoors. So I've been wandering around, looking for gardens in unusual places.

title: BIC TO BUY RIVAL SHEAFFER FOR LESS THAN $50 MILLION
description: Societe Bic S.A., known for its Bic pens and lighters, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the unprofitable pen maker Sheaffer for less than $50 million. Bic, of France, bought Sheaffer from Gefinor S.A., a Geneva-based investment bank, said Thierry Michels, communications director at Bic. Mr. Michels said Bic paid less than the $50 million that Sheaffer has in annual sales. Sheaffer has 550 employees, 450 of whom work in North America. Sheaffer was created in 1913 by Walter A. Sheaffer in Fort Madison, Iowa. Its luxury fountain pens cost between $25 and $5,000. It it also makes cheaper roller pens.

title: Q&A/Hans Ulrich Jost, Swiss historian : Bank Secrecy Was Bern's Wartime 'Weapon'
description: Hans Ulrich Jost is a professor of contemporary Swiss history at the State University of Lausanne who has gained national prominence as a critical chronicler of his country's wartime past. He spoke with Robert Kroon of the International Herald Tribune about the role of the Swiss banking establishment, which is currently under international scrutiny.

title: J. E. Fleischner, 57, Professor of Education
description: Jeannette E. Fleischner, a professor of education at Columbia University Teachers College who devoted her career to the advancement of children with disabilities, died last Saturday at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. She was 57 and lived in Woodstock, N.Y., and on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: RUBIN ORGANIZATION IS BEING SOLD FOR $260 MILLION
description: Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust agreed yesterday to buy the Rubin Organization, the closely held shopping center company, in a transaction valued at about $260 million. The purchase would more than double Pennsylvania Real Estate's shopping centers. Ronald Rubin, founder of the Rubin Organization, is to become chief executive of Pennsylvania Real Estate, based in Fort Washington, Pa., succeeding Sylvan Cohen, who is 83. Pennsylvania Real Estate's shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $25. Pennsylvania Real Estate will pay $154 million in cash, issue as many as one million partnership units worth $23.4 million and pay $8 million in other costs. It also plans to invest about $75 million in properties Rubin has under development.

title: In Russia's Market, Fair Play Is in Winners' Eyes
description: When Russia sold off a 25 percent share of the state's vast telephone and telecommunications monopoly last week, the Government proudly held up the deal as a model of fair play in the free market.

title: E-Z Pass Will Make Some Things Too Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Paradox for Helms on an Abortion Issue
description: In June Senator Jesse Helms struck a bargain with the Clinton Administration to pay off back dues to the United Nations and reorganize the State Department.

title: Prison Labor Grows
description: To the Editor:

title: Mark Twain Is Back in Hartford
description: Somewhere betwixt Tom Sawyer, Huckleberry Finn, Pudd'nhead Wilson and life on the Mississippi, Samuel L. Clemens put down his pen long enough to read a few things -- Shakespeare and Plutarch; the poetry of Longfellow, Shelley and the Brownings; volumes of history and natural science, racy novels, even French erotica.

title: Police Break Up Suspected Bomb Plot in Brooklyn
description: Two men with Jordanian passports were arrested yesterday morning in a Brooklyn apartment, where police officers found components of one or more pipe bombs -- evidence of what the authorities say was a terrorist plot to detonate bombs in the busy Atlantic Avenue subway station and on a commuter bus.

title: Reuters Steps Up Its Talks On Times Square Building
description: Reuters, the British media and information giant, is stepping up its negotiations with Prudential Insurance and New York City to build an 800,000-square-foot office tower in Times Square.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Gain Over All, Though Dow Ends Lower

title: Bills to Balance the Budget And Cut Taxes Pass Senate
description: The House and the Senate today approved the largest tax cut since 1981 in legislation that would offer a net reduction of $96 billion over the next five years through cuts in capital gains and estate taxes, a $500-a-child tax credit to most middle- and lower-income working families, and other measures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, LEO, M.D.
description: STONE-Leo, M.D. Died July 29, 1997, in his 93rd year. Beloved husband and best friend of Marta. A loving brother, father, grandfather and great grandfather. He will be greatly missed. He was a kind and gentle spirit who touched us all. His memory will be cherished by family, friends, colleagues and patients forever. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Friday, August 1st, at 3:30 P.M.

title: Frank Kaufman, 81, Judge And a Bar Leader, Is Dead
description: Frank A. Kaufman, a Federal district judge in Baltimore who presided over many important cases and was a leader in the American Bar Association, died today at his home in Baltimore. He was 81.

title: Kia Executives Put Rescue Plan in Jeopardy
description: Executives of Kia Group refused yesterday to submit resignation letters to creditor banks in exchange for emergency loans, jeopardizing a rescue plan for South Korea's eighth-biggest conglomerate. Kia's creditors withheld 190 billion won ($213 million) of loans on Wednesday, demanding details of the company's cost-cutting plan and resignation letters from top managers.

title: No Headline
description: ''Here's a real op. Look at those flags; I'm going to wrap myself in them.''

title: Judge Weighs Fate of Suit Filed by Jews Against Swiss
description: Batteries of lawyers representing Swiss Banks and Jewish groups faced off in United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday over whether a class-action lawsuit accusing the banks of retaining the assets of Holocaust victims should proceed. Judge Edward R. Korman made no ruling, but his questions and comments led lawyers representing more than 18,000 Jews taking part in the suit to predict the judge would allow crucial portions of it to proceed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMAN, GUIDO
description: ULLMAN-Guido. We mourn the passing of our longtime good friend and associate, Guido Ullman. Guido was always loved and respected by all who knew him. He conducted his business affairs in a highly professional manner and was a good and charming friend who was also a lover and connoisseur of the arts. After retiring from his professional life, Guido devoted much of his time to charitable activities. He was personally and directly involved in helping the elderly and the infirm living in New York. We extend our heartfeld condolences to his wife Annette, his children and his family. Lieber & Solow Ltd.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Jets! Ratings! Sales! It's the Tuna
description: If ''The Jets'' were a television show, it would have been canceled long ago by a merciful network executive. Its survival is no more comprehensible by quality standards than if ''Pink Lady and Jeff'' had lasted a decade.

title: Seven-Building Apartment Project Would End Rental Drought in Fort Lee
description: A 351-unit apartment complex that will begin rising this fall a mile from the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, N.J, will be the first new rental project in the community in 25 years. It is also the latest in a string of upscale rental projects its developer has built in the New York metropolitan area in the last eight years.

title: The Flattery Is Imitation But the Pain Is Real
description: ''In the Company of Men'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 28. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Federal Express to Identify Packages on Cargo Plane
description: It will take at least a day or two for Federal Express to identify all the packages that were aboard the cargo plane that crashed at Newark International Airport early yesterday, company officials said.

title: Not-Guilty Plea in Baby Case
description: A 16-year-old girl who was accused of leaving her newborn baby in a toilet at an Atlantic City bus terminal pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of endangering the welfare of a child and aggravated assault. Prosecutors filed papers in Family Court seeking to try the girl, Vanessa Gomez, who lives in the Dominican Republic, as an adult. The baby was found within a half-hour of his birth on July 13 and was taken to the Atlantic City Medical Center, where he remains in critical condition. Ms. Gomez has been in custody since she was released from the hospital two days after the birth.

title: Hip-Hop Gets Religion
description: At the first concert of his 20-show series at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday night, Kirk Franklin kept insisting he was not there to entertain. He had bigger things in mind: praising Jesus, fighting the devil. He said he didn't want the audience to remember him, but to embrace his beliefs. And although he seemed absolutely sincere, he wasn't entirely truthful. The 26-year-old Mr. Franklin has worked hard and meticulously to make gospel entertaining in up-to-date terms.

title: A List of the Dead
description: Following is a list of 11 people killed in the bombing attack Wednesday in Jerusalem, as drawn up by the Israeli Ministry of Public Security. The list includes the ages or years of birth, and hometown. Two victims have not been officially identified, nor have the suicide bombers.

title: The Coast With the Most
description: America likes to think of itself as a bicoastal country -- or at least the people on the coasts do. The implication is that the coasts are the same and that compared with the vast interior, where the tornadoes are, they share a beach culture. Nothing could be further from the truth, especially when comparing Southern California with the Northeast.

title: Ancient Scroll Carries Clue to Deadly Mold
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLLANSBEE, ANN G.
description: FOLLANSBEE-Ann G. The children, families, staff and Board of Trustees of The League Treatment Center mourn the death, on July 27, 1997, of our beloved friend and colleague Ann G. Follansbee. A brilliant clinician, Ann was our Director of Psychology for over 15 years. She was passionately devoted to the healthy development of our children. Ann saw the best in each child and was a friend to each of us. She leaves a legacy of love and inspiration. Our condolences to her devoted family and friends. A memorial service will be held 4PM Sunday, August 17, 1997 at the Church of the Good Shepherd, 236 E. 31 St, New York City. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made to the Psychomotor Institute Inc., 60 Western Avenue, Cambridge, MA. 02139, for many years a focus of Ann's personal concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLAGER, WALTER L.
description: SCHLAGER-Walter L. Beloved husband of Lore. Father of Rother and Shoi. Died peacefully at home after a long illness, July 31. He was a partner at Peat Marwick in NYC. He is also survived by mother Mary Louise Schlager, two sisters Mary and Susan, and mother-inlaw Buba Deutsch. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: Turner Superstation to Collect Cable TV Fees
description: The Turner Broadcasting System announced yesterday that on Dec. 31 it would complete the transformation of its TBS superstation into what is essentially a basic cable network.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Cohen Details Faults of General in Bombing
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that the Air Force general in charge of the housing complex in Saudi Arabia where 19 airmen were killed in a terrorist blast last year had sufficient warning of a possible attack but failed to safeguard his troops.

title: A Cast of Rich, Poor and Odd
description: IN the early 1930's, as Europe sank into the Depression and photographers began to think about documenting the plight of the poor, Lisette Model picked up a camera for the first time and photographed the upper-middle classes.

title: When a Casino Loses Its Lifeline to Customers
description: The few blackjack dealers still employed at the Lady Luck Casino stand grimly behind their empty tables, nervously tapping the felt with stacks of $5 chips. The one-armed bandits are resting, their slumber broken only occasionally by the whir and clang of a distant machine. The roulette wheel is spinning, but there are no bettors, not for red or black, even or odd, or anything.

title: Officer and Woman Scuffle
description: A veteran Edison police officer was charged yesterday with assaulting a 71-year-old woman on Saturday after she complained that his squad car was blocking her street, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOK, ARTHUR N.
description: BROOK-Arthur N. July 30, 1997. The partners of Mound, Cotton & Wollan mourn the untimely loss of our esteemed partner and friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: Tokyo Stocks Tumble
description: Stocks fell sharply here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 527.05 points -- or two and a half percent -- at 19,804.38. On Thursday, the Nikkei index gained 118.61 points.

title: Brigade of Guards Earns Big Victory In Steeplechase
description: It is an art form that goes back centuries, to the days when men hunted or fought wars on horses that could hurdle obstacles. These days, steeplechase racing is having a revival at tracks like Saratoga, where the featured race today was for jumpers and was won by Brigade of Guards.

title: Public Skepticism on Prosecutors Is Healthy for Justice System
description: To the Editor:

title: In Barbados, Sharpton Criticizes Giuliani on Immigration
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton attacked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's record on immigration issues yesterday, calling it ''reactionary and repulsive.'' Mr. Sharpton said Mr. Giuliani's actions as an Assistant Attorney General a decade ago, when he fought to hold Haitian refugees in detention camps, belied his recent efforts to present himself as a friend of immigrants.

title: Trouble in Cyber City? Cosmo to the Rescue
description: The ODC/San Francisco modern dance troupe clearly spent a great deal of time and money on ''Outawak,'' a spectacular, multimedia computer fable that opened on Tuesday for a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater. Dancers spill out across a set-strewn stage dressed in a variety of costumes whose bright colors give the dancers the look of Liquorice Allsorts. There are scrims and screens galore, on which are projected bridges, a church steeple, clouds and members of the cast. And ''Outawak'' is a noble attempt to create a piece for the entire family, which seems to be one mission of the ODC troupe.

title: Despite Devastation and Fear, Support for Netanyahu Seems Strong
description: In Sammy Ziv's clothing shop at the Mahane Yehuda market today, a picture of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hung behind the counter near a wall blown in by Wednesday's bomb explosions.

title: U.P.S., Workers and Clients Brace for Nationwide Strike
description: Companies around the country searched for alternate ways to ship their packages on Thursday as the United Parcel Service, the nation's largest shipping company, sought to avert a walkout by 185,000 drivers, sorters and loaders, who are members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: 6 Are Hanged By Burundi For Massacres
description: Six people convicted of having taken part in ethnic massacres in this Central African country's four-year-old civil war were hanged early this morning, officials said.

title: Director's Suit Over Rights To Go to Trial
description: A Federal judge in Florida has cleared the way for a trial that may lead to a landmark decision about whether stage directors, like playwrights, must be compensated for their work when it is used in later productions of a show.

title: New Rules Expected For Clearing Firms
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is likely to require Wall Street clearing firms to report suspicious trading involving the brokerage firms they do business with, the commission's chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., said today.

title: $25 and Under
description: Paying Homage to Rice

title: SMARTALK TO BUY RIVAL MAKER OF TELEPHONE CARDS
description: Smartalk Teleservices Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Conquest Telecommunications Services Corporation of Dublin, Ohio. Both companies make prepaid telephone calling cards. Smartalk said it would issue about 4.8 million common shares for the acquisition. Based on Wednesday's stock closing price, the deal is worth about $66.6 million. Smartalk, based in Los Angeles, had 1996 revenues of $15 million. Shares of Smartalk rose almost 28 percent yesterday, gaining $3.875, to $17.75. After the acquisition, which is expected to close in the fourth quarter, the combined companies would have 35,000 retail locations for selling phone cards.

title: Illness Is Turning Into Financial Catastrophe for More of the Uninsured
description: As her three boys were returning from school one Friday in March, Charlene Prowse, who works nights at a convenience store here, awakened from her day's sleep. Mrs. Prowse, 31 and robust despite a battle six years ago with ovarian cancer, stepped into the hallway of the family's home in this working-class suburb of Little Rock. Then she collapsed.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Booty Call

title: A Night of Wholly Mozart
description: Now that the huge, interdisciplinary Lincoln Center Festival is the main focus of Lincoln Center's summer programming, Mostly Mozart loyalists must feel slightly orphaned. Instead of running through July and August, as it once did, Mostly Mozart is now a four-week coda to the larger festival.

title: Senate Panel Unites in Subpoenaing White House Papers
description: The Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses came to bipartisan agreement today to issue a subpoena for White House fund-raising documents.

title: Spitting on the Graves
description: Every time Israeli citizens are murdered by Palestinian terrorism, the world's leaders respond by spitting on their graves.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD TO CLOSE SPECIALTY STORES
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close 44 Lechmere, Home Image and Electric Avenue and More stores and cut 3,900 jobs in the first significant step of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy. The announcement came shortly after a bankruptcy judge in Wilmington, Del., approved a $1 billion financing plan from the majority shareholder, the General Electric Company, designed to fuel the retailer's recovery. The moves will let the company focus on its 356 Montgomery Ward stores in a bid to return to profitability. After years of declining sales and earnings, the Chicago-based company filed for Chapter 11 protection on July 7.

title: That Honey-Loving Bear Cub and His Pals
description: It's not as if Winnie the Pooh has been hard to find in the two decades since his last full-length movie. There have been countless books and toys (seeing Pooh on screen now is like watching a plush stuffed animal come to life), not to mention a television series and its video spinoffs. But throughout Pooh's long and lucrative commercial life, Disney has preserved both the spirit of A. A. Milne's stories about enduring friendship, and the classically simple look of E. H. Shepard's original illustrations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODMAN, SAMUEL H.
description: GRODMAN-Samuel H. Of Pembroke Pines, FL. Formerly of the Bronx, NY. July 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Adeline and father of William of Huntington, NY. Also survived by 3 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Services are at the Menorah Funeral Home, Pembroke Pines, August 1.

title: An Adorable Wardrobe Accessorized by Deceit
description: Separated at birth from ''My Best Friend's Wedding,'' ''Picture Perfect'' is another clotheshorse comedy in which an antic career woman invents a counterfeit Mr. Right. Each film's heroine resorts to elaborate deception to lure a man who doesn't really want her, and in each case there's a subplot about pleasing or annoying the boss. Each film also makes cute use of extras who comment collectively upon the action. In this case, it's the guests at a church wedding who register their opinion of the story's contrived romance.

title: Pete Seeger in the Bronx
description: Pete Seeger and the environmental sloop Clearwater are expected tomorrow at Bronxfest, a free daylong festival with music, dancing and storytelling in Roberto Clemente State Park, along the Harlem River at West Tremont Avenue and Matthewson Road in the South Bronx.

title: Stocks Wrap Up Brisk July, But Dow Slides 32.28 Points
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, capping a spectacular July run that took the main indexes to record highs.

title: He Shoots, He Barks
description: You can lead a dog to the basketball court, but you can't make him do a slam-dunk. Unless that dog is Buddy, the wondrous basket-shooting golden retriever who is the woofy, wagging hero of the pallid little Disney comedy ''Air Bud.''

title: Fire Sales: McGwire Clears Out, Giants Clean Up
description: The San Francisco Giants and Oakland Athletics, once involved in the only World Series disrupted by an earthquake, sent new tremors through four of baseball's six division races yesterday by participating in separate trades involving a couple of outstanding White Sox pitchers and baseball's most prolific home run hitter.

title: Another Madison Avenue independent finds a buyer: Bozell, Jacobs plans to join True North.
description: AFTER months of speculation that a deal was near, True North Communications Inc., the world's seventh-largest agency holding company, said yesterday it had agreed to buy the 14th-largest, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc., in a stock deal valued at about $440 million.

title: Out of Painting, Into Architecture
description: SEVERAL years ago, the Japanese artist Arakawa and his longtime collaborator, the American poet Madeline Gins, abandoned their mind-teasing word-and-diagram paintings for architecture and architectural installation. Judging from ''Reversible Destiny: Arakawa/Gins,'' a grandiose 35-year retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, I would say that painting's gain may turn out to be architecture's loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISEMAN, SAM
description: EISEMAN-Sam. July 30, 1997. A gentle, caring, powerful guiding force has been stilled. De Nieces and De Nephews

title: Flake to Leave Congress To Devote Time to Church
description: Citing the growing weight of his ministerial duties, Representative Floyd H. Flake said yesterday that he would resign from Congress by the end of this year to devote more time to the church in Queens where he has been pastor for 21 years.

title: Enforce Liquor Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobs Is Said to Have Found the Executive Apple of His Eye
description: Steven P. Jobs, who stepped up his role as an adviser at Apple Computer three weeks ago, has been trying -- unsuccessfully so far -- to persuade Eastman Kodak's chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, to come to Apple, according to an executive who knows both men.

title: In Budget Bill, President Wins Welfare Battle
description: When President Clinton signed the welfare bill last year, he said it was ''far from perfect,'' and pledged to ''change what is wrong.''

title: People
description: * Julia Beardwood was named executive director for brand identity at Landor Associates, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., succeeding Bob Fane, who left. Ms. Beardwood was previously senior vice president and management supervisor at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, a unit of MacManus Group.

title: Now, Special Tax Breaks Get Hidden in Plain Sight
description: The tax bill passed by Congress today includes many narrowly focused provisions that benefit just a few individuals or businesses. And this year, for the first time, Congress exposed those tax breaks so President Clinton can veto them if he wants to.

title: Tax Cut Is Passed
description: The House and Senate both approved the nation's largest tax cut in 16 years, voting to give Americans a reduction of $96 billion in their tax bills in the next five years through cuts in capital gains levies and a $500 tax credit for young children.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: TWAIN'S BOOKS ARE BACK HOME -- A rich trove of 271 books from Mark Twain's library, which surfaced last month in California, has finally come home to Hartford. B2.

title: Testing the Waters For Your Used Car
description: What is a car really worth? That's the question that comes up when it is time to trade in the old sedan in the driveway toward a new, often expensive car.

title: A Railroad Man Retires
description: After working on railroads for 45 years, Ken Brown, a New Jersey Transit conductor, ended his career yesterday in familiar surroundings. Accompanied by Shirley DeLibero, the executive director of the transit agency, Mr. Brown, 64, boarded the Raritan Valley Line Train 5900 at the Plainfield Station, where his family had an apartment while his father worked as a ticket agent for the Central Railroad of New Jersey. Mr. Brown, who has worked for New Jersey Transit since 1983, arrived at Newark's Pennsylvania Station -- and began his retirement -- at 8:14 A.M. A third-generation railroad man, Mr. Brown is the father of three daughters, none of whom followed the family career path. ''I'm the end of the line,'' he said.

description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 5.3 percent, as expected, after lower prices stimulated call volumes and overseas investment costs increased. Profit for the three months that ended June 30 at British Telecom, Britain's dominant telephone company, was $:599 million ($981 million), compared with $:569 million a year earlier.

description: In recent years, many New Jersey communities have imposed curfews for young people, with varying degrees of success. Last night, officials in Elizabeth began enforcing their own long-neglected curfew, but with a new twist.

title: Best Month For Treasuries Since May '95
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, rounding out their best month since May 1995, after the Government reported that economic growth slowed in the second quarter while inflation remained subdued.

title: Wielding Words, Not Guns
description: SOMETHING about midsummer turns ray guns and missiles and marauding spaceships into old news. Suddenly the most ferocious weapon on the movie screen is the English language, as deployed so viciously by scheming, Mamet-fueled white-collar workers in Neil LaBute's stunning Sundance prize winner, ''In the Company of Men.'' At this time of year, the big guns are silenced long enough to make way for such sleepers, and they come as the perfect break between early summer's fireworks and the fall's more complex art house fare. What a jolt: we find ourselves surrounded by films by, for and about real people on planet Earth.

title: Little-Known Greene Now Carries America's Hopes in the 100
description: It has been six years since that stunning, humid night in Tokyo when Carl Lewis, Leroy Burrell and Dennis Mitchell led an American sweep of the 100 meters at the world track and field championships. But that sweep represented the peak of American dominance in the event and the beginning of a spiraling decline.

title: Tax Rebates Are in the Mail
description: Homestead rebate checks averaging $243 are being mailed out to 1.2 million New Jersey residents who qualify for the property tax relief program, officials said yesterday. The checks, totaling $300 million, increased an average of $5 over last year and went out to 35,000 additional people this year, said Jack Mozloom, a spokesman for the State Treasurer. Checks of up to $500 are sent to elderly and disabled residents who earn less than $100,000 a year and to other residents whose annual income falls below $40,000.

description: Airbus Industrie won two big contracts today, as Virgin Atlantic Airways of Britain and Air Canada announced plans to buy a stretch version of the European consortium's largest passenger plane, which is intended to compete with the Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADENBURG, VERONICA
description: LADENBURG - Veronica. The Board of Trustees, friends, and former colleagues note with sadness the loss of Hedi Ladenburg, who died on July 25th at the age of 80. Hedi taught at the Fieldston Lower School for twenty-six years. Although she retired in 1985, her connection with the school never ended. Written for teachers, her classic book ''The Living Past in a Modern Classroom'' details the methods and underlying philosophy of her work. Generations of children were touched by her deeply insightful teaching. Hedi's warmth and gentle spirit will be missed. A memorial service will be held on September 20th at 2:00 in the Student/Faculty Center of the Fieldston School. Sara E. Nathan and S. Donald Sussman Frederick C. Calder Helen Halverson Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools

description: Two San Francisco interior designers who were accused of laundering over $30 million in drug money for one of Colombia's most powerful drug traffickers were arraigned in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday. Judge Jack B. Weinstein set total bail for the two men at an unusually high $8.5 million.

description: Gasoline surged after Shell Netherlands B.V., a unit of Royal Dutch/ Shell Group, unexpectedly closed part of Europe's second-largest oil refinery, the latest in a spate of problems for gasoline that pushed prices up 20 percent last month.

(Maureen) Hochberg, Chicago, IL., Bruce R. Hochberg, Portland, OR; daughter Diane (Harold) Gartner, New York; brother Robert (Sondra) Michaels, Forest Hills, New York and 8 grandchildren. Memorials may be made to Sinai Temple and St. Anthony Hospice.

title: Salvadoran Fraud Case Mires Ruling Party
description: Already reeling from losses in congressional elections this spring, El Salvador's governing party and the oligarchy behind it have now been shaken by a messy financial scandal whose central figure is one of the party's most influential leaders.

title: Plane Crash Bodies Found
description: The badly decomposed bodies of two people who were aboard a single-engine plane that crashed on July 13 were identified Thursday.

title: As Lawmakers Slog to Finish, Several Bills Seem Doomed
description: The longest legislative session in New York's history appears to be slogging toward an uneventful close, with state lawmakers so far unable to agree on a host of important issues, from consumer protection to tort and banking reform to ticket scalping.

title: Nomura to Spin Off a U.S. Realty Unit
description: The Nomura Securities Company's United States subsidiary plans to spin off its real estate lending unit, its most profitable businesses, into a private company, paving the way for a possible sale.

title: Big Board Seat Pricier Yet
description: A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold on Thursday for a record $1.475 million, a $125,000 increase from the previous sale on July 17. Owning one of the 1,366 stock exchange seats is an admission ticket to trading. The highest price previously paid for a Big Board seat was $1.45 million in May 1996. The exchange does not release the names of buyers and sellers.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL SELLING BETHFORGE AND CENTEC UNITS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Bethforge and Centec Roll units to the closely held Park Corporation, ending the steelmaker's 10-month effort to shed its secondary businesses. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. The company also said it would close its Bethship Inc. shipyard in Sparrows Point, Md., after failing to reach an agreement with a group of investors led by Peter Angelos, owner of the Baltimore Orioles baseball team. Bethlehem said in October that it would sell or shut down the three units, which generate less than 10 percent of its $4.68 billion annual revenue. Park is based in Cleveland.

title: The Tokyo and Its New Leader Undergo a Schubert Test
description: Schubert told more tales than Mozart at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Thursday evening in Avery Fisher Hall. In the preconcert recital and the concert itself, the Tokyo String Quartet variously shed a violinist, Mikhail Kopelman or Kizuei Ikeda, to join Marina Piccinini in two Mozart flute quartets and John Browning in Beethoven's Opus 16 Piano Quartet, then reassembled for Schubert's ''Death and the Maiden'' Quartet.

title: Equality Is a Given
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day of Spin Follows a Month of Hearings
description: Senators from both parties who are conducting the investigation of campaign financing mostly concurred today that the first month of hearings had produced evidence of abuses, but Republicans and Democrats disagreed on the implications.

title: VLSI TECHNOLOGY SELLING SEMICONDUCTOR DESIGN UNIT
description: The chip maker VLSI Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its semiconductor design unit, Compass Design Automation, to the Avant Corporation for $44 million in cash and stock. VLSI, based in San Jose, Calif., said the deal would allow it to focus on its semiconductor products. The acquisition allows Avant, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., to expand its offering of software design tools and libraries used to create both custom and standard chips. VLSI Technology's shares jumped $3, to $32.625, and Avant shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $29.50. Both companies trade on the Nasdaq.

title: Yeltsin Backs Down in Tiff With Belarussian Over Arrests
description: Even as an international human rights organization met with the Belarussian authorities in Minsk to demand the release of three detained Russian reporters, President Boris N. Yeltsin retracted criticism of the Belarussian President today, and promised that the journalists' detention would not affect their relationship.

title: Measuring Productivity in the 90's: Optimists vs. Skeptics
description: To hear Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, tell it, along with various bulls on Wall Street and assorted chief executives, the United States is entering a period in which the productivity of the American worker is accelerating in ways reminiscent of the best years of the country's economy. And that is why the economy is strong, stock prices are rising and both will continue upward.

title: Madeleine Albright Sings Out
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's belting parody of ''Don't Cry for Me, Argentina'' at this week's meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations drew critical acclaim from her fellow foreign ministers. They were not as happy with her speeches, which some dismissed as patronizing lectures on human rights. Americans, however, would consider her performance a spirited defense of their values, exactly the kind of plain speaking Ms. Albright promised when she took the job, and exactly what Asean needed to hear.

title: Hambletonian (Part I)
description: Twenty-one trotters are ready to chase the winner's share of a $1 million purse in next week's Hambletonian, but only 10 will make it to the Aug. 9 final. This afternoon, the Meadowlands will stage three elimination heats to narrow the field, with the top three finishers in each race plus the top fourth-place finisher making the final cut.

title: Teamsters Let Strike Deadline Slip By at U.P.S.
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters let a 12:01 A.M. strike deadline pass today without ordering a strike against the United Parcel Service as negotiators held intense talks with a Federal mediator in their search for a settlement.

title: Eagles Come to Witness the Jets' Unveiling
description: The team that has undergone a heart and soul makeover is ready for previews. The Jets begin the preseason schedule Saturday night at Giants Stadium against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Police Aide Accused of Arson
description: An administrative aide for the Newark Police Department was suspended without pay yesterday, accused of helping a veteran Newark arson investigator set fire to his rental property to collect the insurance money, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Women's Knockout Team Championship began here yesterday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, with teams captained by Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif., and Kathie Wei-Sender of Nashville, Tenn., fighting for the title.
