title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCER, WILLIAM
description: LINCER-William. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc. notes with sadness the death of William Lincer, Principal Violist of the Orchestra from 1943 to 1972. During a distinguished Philharmonic career, Mr. Lincer played more than 4,000 concerts, including 57 solo appearances. Most memorable among these was Strauss' ''Don Quixote'' on the occasion of Leonard Bernstein's November 14, 1943 conducting debut. Mr. Lincer's lifelong dedication to excellence, and his regard for his colleagues, his students, and his community, will long be a source of inspiration to us. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Mary, and to his sister, Mrs. Janet Bernstein. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec Director

title: Trade Eluded Yankees
description: Yankees General Manager Bob Watson, who was shut out at the nonwaiver trading deadline Thursday night, said yesterday he was not disappointed that a deal never materialized.

title: Report Shows Robust Growth With New Jobs
description: The United States economy entered the summer with fresh strength, as an unexpected number of new jobs reduced the nation's unemployment rate to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed today.

title: Spanish Power Company To Buy Chilean Utilities
description: Empresa Nacional de Electricidad S.A. agreed yesterday to pay $1.5 billion to take control of Enersis S.A. of Chile to gain entry into Latin America's fast-growing market for electric power. Endesa, Spain's largest electric utility, will pay $1.23 billion for control of five Chilean companies known collectively as Chispas that have indirect control over Enersis. The company will buy the rest of Chispas over the next five years, bringing the total price to $1.5 billion.

title: A New Welfare Start in New York
description: The leaders of New York's State Legislature rose a bit above their usual mad-dog partisanship in fashioning the new state welfare program. The plan agreed upon this week is, in concept, a vast improvement from the one presented last winter by Gov. George Pataki. It preserves present levels of benefits, adds incentives for welfare recipients trying to pull themselves out of dependency, protects people who cannot work and stretches a modest safety net for those who still cannot find employment when their benefits are cut off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARKIN, ARTHUR G, JR, MD.

Beloved husband of Marie; father of Arthur, Anne Marie Larkin, M.D., Christine, Jennifer, Thomas; brother of Therese Karsch, Kathy Larkin; uncle of Hank Karsch. Donations to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, New York, New York 10002.

title: A Flip Side to E-Z Pass: East River Tolls and Rush-Hour Prices
description: Most drivers in the New York metropolitan area who have embraced the technology of electronic fare collection probably think about the E-Z Pass stickers on their cars and their little radio transponders only when they are passing through the tollbooths at places like the Tappan Zee or George Washington Bridges. That is when the system pays off for motorists, allowing them to avoid the long lines of people still using old-fashioned money.

title: A Near Thing: Yanks-Mets Blockbuster
description: Ultimately, Steve Phillips ended up with nothing for his binge of trade talks, other than a fast-earned reputation for persistence and imagination. In his first two weeks as Mets general manager, he went so far as to propose a three-way deal with the Yankees and the Phillies involving Curt Schilling, Jeff Nelson and Bernard Gilkey -- among many, many other proposals.

title: ASC HOLDINGS ADDS TO ITS SKI RESORT BUSINESSES
description: ASC Holdings, parent company of the American Skiing Company of Newry, Me., announced yesterday that it had paid $288.3 million for Steamboat Ski Resort in Steamboat Springs, Colo., and Heavenly Ski Resort in Stateline, Nev., near Lake Tahoe. Both resorts were owned by the Kamori International Corporation of Japan. Last April, American Skiing, the largest ski company in the East, expanded into the West for the first time by buying the Wolf Mountain Ski Area, now known as the Canyons Ski Resort, in Park City, Utah. American Skiing owns 11 mountain resorts, which drew 4.9 million skier and snowboarder visits last year, about 9 percent of all visits in the United States.

title: Shares of the Brooke Group Take a Tumble
description: Shares of Brooke Group Ltd. slipped yesterday after the company said its Liggett Group and BGLS Inc. units had postponed making interest payments while they attempted to restructure public debt.

title: Despite Freeing of a Militant, No Letup in Algerian Strife
description: Hopes that Algeria's violent impasse might be broken by the abrupt release from prison last month of a leader of the banned Islamic Salvation Front have been quickly buried in the rubble of renewed carnage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, JEAN WEINER
description: ALTMAN-Jean Weiner. Passed away in her home July 7, 1997 at the age of 69. She was an active member of her condo board and a prolific artist in various mediums. Prior to retirement, she owned a jewelery manufacturing company and was active in the professional organizations. She is survived by 2 daughters Marlene Kutler of Long Beach, New York, Risa Kaparo of Mill Valley, California, a son Mitch Altman of Nesconset, N.Y., two sisters, 2 brothers and six grandchildren, nieces, and nephews. Her warmth and good humor will be remembered and cherished by her family and friends.

title: Why Mexico Wants Weld
description: For years, Senator Jesse Helms has told Mexicans that we are barbarians at the gate, dishonest and disobedient neighbors who should be lectured instead of listened to. No one in Washington has used his pulpit to criticize Mexico as stridently. Perhaps no other American politician is as thoroughly disliked south of the border.

title: A Spy on Radical Right Is Acquitted
description: A Federal District Court jury tonight found Carol Howe, 26, a former debutante who became a neo-Nazi, innocent on charges that she had threatened to blow up buildings in 15 cities.

title: 10th-Inning Outburst Overcomes Bullpen Flop
description: If ever there was a day when Steve Phillips needed somebody to bail him out, it was today, when the Mets' new general manager was widely panned for not acquiring a badly needed reliever Thursday before the trade deadline. In the great tradition that is Murphy's Law, the Mets' bullpen illuminated this tonight, blowing leads in the eighth and ninth innings as Phillips watched from the stands.

title: Cute but Slow, Water Taxis Take Early Retirement
description: It was an idea whose time had come: with visitors flocking to Battery Park, Chelsea Piers and other Manhattan shoreline attractions, why not offer something offbeat -- even a little romantic -- like bright little water taxis, a touch of Venice on the Hudson?

title: John Updike, Impresario Of Fictional Relay Race
description: Remember Snoopy sitting on top of his doghouse and slowly typing, ''It was a dark and stormy night''? Now think of John Updike, breezing in from the golf course to write, ''Miss Tasso Polk at ten-ten alighted from the elevator onto the olive tiles of the nineteenth floor only lightly nagged by a sense of something wrong. The Magazine's crest, that great black M, the thing masculine that had most profoundly penetrated her life, echoed from its inlaid security the thoughtful humming in her mind: 'm.' '' This is the beginning of a new short story, a mystery entitled ''Murder Makes the Magazine,'' which as yet has no middle or ending but will eventually have 44 authors in addition to Mr. Updike.

title: Slapping Backs and Soothing Strains, Giuliani Takes a Tour
description: One minute he was acting as the city's peacemaker, bringing together Jews and Arabs for a hastily arranged handshake a few doors away from an apartment where bombs were found in Brooklyn. The next moment he was the quintessential urban politician, slapping the backs of startled strangers on the street, signing autographs, posing for pictures with giggling customers of a Citibank branch.

title: Inmates Lose Federal Checks
description: Mercer County received $13,400 on Thursday from the Federal Government for becoming the first county in New Jersey, and among the first in the nation, to give officials a computerized roster of inmates housed in the county jail. Using that data, Federal workers were able to determine through a compatible computer program that 34 inmates were collecting Social Security checks while getting their room and board at government expense.

title: G.E. Executives Get New Posts
description: The General Electric Company said today that it had named Eugene F. Murphy as a vice chairman, corporate executive officer and a director, amid executive reshuffling.

title: Budget Deal May Push More Elderly Into Managed Care
description: Older Americans escaped the costly overhaul of their Medicare benefits that some lawmakers in Congress were seeking in Washington's budget negotiations this week. But like younger people with employer-paid or individual health insurance, the elderly are finding it harder to dodge the pressures to sign up for managed care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEENAN, JANET W.

title: Debt Ratings Affirmed On Nomura and Bank
description: The Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank and the Nomura Securities Company, two companies that were penalized on Wednesday for making payoffs to a racketeer, had their debt ratings affirmed yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The affirmation means the two companies are unlikely to have to pay more to borrow money in financial markets. Still, the outlook for both companies remains negative, the rating company said.

title: The Wizard of Taliesin
description: The ribbons were finally cut the other day at Monona Terrace in Madison, Wis., six decades after the convention and civic center was first proposed, and 38 years after the demise of its creator. Yet Frank Lloyd Wright was clearly a presence at the inaugural fete. As if on cue, storm clouds hovered behind the arched lakeside structure as the state's political leaders offered their safely posthumous praises to a rare Wisconsinite known the world over.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Washington, Few Trifle With Jesse Helms
description: Senator Jesse Helms's ability to block William F. Weld's nomination to be Ambassador to Mexico, single-handedly, is only the latest example of a Washington axiom: Everyone is afraid of the Republican from North Carolina.

title: Medicaid Cards in Error
description: The Department of Human Services has accidentally sent out 3,000 Medicaid cards to people who were not eligible for the program, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: School Aide Is Sentenced
description: A lunch monitor at a Paterson elementary school who pleaded guilty to groping nine girls in his first two weeks on the job was sentenced yesterday to a year in the county jail and five years' probation, officials said.

title: Kill an Elephant, Save an Elephant
description: You'd think that after a century's worth of service as the noble Republican symbol, the elephant might enjoy some special conservation status in the party. But it was a Democrat, Senator Barbara Boxer of California, who rose the other day in its defense.

description: LAWRENCE-Scott Andrew. January 15, 1949-August 2, 1985. Forever in our hearts. We love and miss you every day. Mother Sara and Joshua.

description: As local and Federal authorities worked yesterday to determine the scope of a terrorist bomb plot uncovered in Brooklyn, officials tightened security measures at transportation hubs, city landmarks and Jewish institutions and sought to reassure a jittery public.

description: Unilever, the British-Dutch maker of consumer products, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 30 percent as cost-cutting offset sluggish sales growth. Net income rose to $:473 million ($774 million), from $:363 million a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption in The Home Section on Thursday about Jim Spiers, a children's swimming teacher, misstated the surname of two of his students and their mother. The students are Sydney and Jordan Feinstein, and their mother is Maris Feinstein, not Friedman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDROMIDAS, CHARLES JOHN
description: ANDROMIDAS-Charles John, 80, formerly of Manhasset, L.I., in North Palm Beach, FL, surrounded by his immediate family. Charlie is survived by his wife Nancy and was pre-deceased by his first wife Katherine. Also surviving are his sons Charles Jr. (Garland Richard Kyle), Chris and Tom (Kim); his step-children Randy (Paula), Stephen (Susan) and Monica Mills; and his sister Cleoniki Scopas (Stephen) and Soter Andromidas (Mary). In addition, Charlie is survived by his loving grandchildren Katherine and Alexandra Andromidas, Randy, Lynsay, Christopher, Courtney and Jonathan Mills, and extended family in the U.S. and Canada. Private services for immediate family were held in North Palm Beach on August 2nd. A celebration of this extraordinary man and father's life will be held for extended family and friends at Hobe Sound Golf Club, Hobe Sound, FL, on Saturday, August 16th at 4PM. Instead of flowers, donations are suggested to the Ahepa Cooley's Anemia Foundation, 1919 Q St. N.W., Washington, D.C. 20009.

description: Sales results released by auto makers today showed an industry in an old-fashioned price war, with companies offering some of their broadest discounts ever in efforts to increase their market shares.

description: If the First Lady is going to worry about Julia Roberts as a role model, you'd think she would object to ''Pretty Woman,'' in which Ms. Roberts charmingly presented prostitution as another yuppie avenue of upward mobility -- leading to respect, rubies, escargots, good table manners, flossing and Richard Gere.

title: In 25 Years of Flamenco, Fierceness and Applause
description: Pilar Rioja celebrated her 25th season at the Repertorio Espanol theater on Thursday night with a program confirming that she is an artist in full control of her material and her audience, which ended the evening with a deafening roar of approval. Ms. Rioja has also grown with time and all its changes. Unlike many dance forms, flamenco honors its older performers. But Ms. Rioja has learned to use the wisdom of her years of dancing to expand and deepen the theatricality of flamenco. And she has learned to make stillness as vibrant as any motion.

description: Kenneth W. Bilby, an author and journalist, died of leukemia in Dallas yesterday. He was 78.

description: FREED-Roseann. First anniversary in heaven. You're in our hearts and thoughts every moment of every day. Love, George, Cara, David, Jennifer

description: Almost since its founding six years ago, the evangelical Christian men's movement called Promise Keepers has generated strong emotions: enthusiasm among many, apprehension among others.

description: Fallout from nuclear blasts at the Nevada Test Site near Las Vegas may have caused 10,000 to 75,000 thyroid cancers, 70 percent of which have not yet been diagnosed, the National Cancer Institute said today.

description: For weeks, investors have been pushing interest rates lower and stock prices higher on the belief that the economic outlook was a combination of moderate growth and low inflation.

description: Robbers shot and wounded an armored car driver yesterday morning at the Trumbull Shopping Park and got away with between $100,000 and $200,000, the police said.

description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday making it illegal for private clubs to set separate tee-off times for women golfers.

description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was offering workers who are scheduled to be laid off from its car-assembly plant in Lorain, Ohio, bonuses of as much as $45,000 if they agree to move to a truck plant in Louisville, Ky.

description: Secretary General Kofi Annan today named a former president of the Supreme Court of Togo as leader of a team to investigate allegations that Hutu refugees from Rwanda were killed in the eastern part of Zaire, now Congo, over the past year.

We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Naomi and his family. The burial and Shivah are being observed in Israel. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: 2 Office Complexes Sold
description: Brandywine Realty Trust said today that it had acquired two Pennsylvania office complexes for $77.2 million. Brandywine, a real estate investment trust, said that Green Hills Corporate Center, in Reading, consisted of five office properties and that Berwyn Park, in Berwyn, consisted of three office properties. The company said it had bought Green Hills from Salient 3 Communications Inc. of Reading and Berwyn Park from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and LCOR Inc., a New York developer.

title: Rage Against the Dying of the Light
description: On Easter weekend my father started to die. His doctors believed that he started much earlier. His oncologist told us in February that he wasn't going to make it. His internist told us he wouldn't live 24 hours from when he was rushed to the hospital in early January. His pulmonary specialist said when his lung cancer was diagnosed in September that he had six months to live.

title: In French Theater, Horses Are Stars, Russians Heroes
description: It is perhaps a reflection on the state of French Government-subsidized theater that the most sought-after tickets at this year's Avignon Festival were for ''Eclipse,'' the latest show by the French equestrian theater troupe known as Zingaro, which made a splash in New York last year. Not that ''Eclipse'' did not merit the ovation that it received nightly in 18 sold-out performances. But for entertainment and originality, it faced little competition.

title: Bao Dai, 83, of Vietnam; Emperor and Bon Vivant
description: Bao Dai, the last Emperor in a line that held the throne in Vietnam for a century and a half, died on Thursday in France, where he spent nearly half of his life in exile after abdicating in 1945. The French Defense Ministry, which made the announcement yesterday, said he died in a military hospital in Paris at the age of 83.

title: ISRAELIS TIGHTEN CURBS ON ARABS, ARRESTING DOZENS
description: With new arrests and a ban on most movement in the West Bank, Israel kept up its pressure on the Palestinian leadership today in the wake of the suicide bombing that shattered a crowded market in Jerusalem two days before.

title: INTERACTIVE GROUP STOCK SOARS ON ACQUISITION DEAL
description: The stock of Interactive Group Inc. soared 33 percent yesterday after the company agreed late on Thursday to be acquired by the Dataworks Corporation for $57 million in stock. Interactive Group sells business information systems. Dataworks supplies software to midsize manufacturers. The companies, both based in San Diego, had full-year combined revenue of $117 million last year. Dataworks said Thursday after the financial markets closed that it would swap 0.805 share for each Interactive share. Shares of Interactive rose $2.50 yesterday, to $10, on the Nasdaq stock market. Dataworks' shares slipped $1.375, to $13, on the Nasdaq.

title: Celebrate Diversity, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Are Still Baffled by Crash at Newark Airport
description: Federal investigators said tonight that the Federal Express cargo plane that crashed at Newark International Airport on Thursday appeared to approach the runway at a normal speed and height, but that the touchdown was hard, ''like what you'd experience on an airplane that was landing on a stormy day.''

title: A Fast-Track Doctor For Plots in Overdrive
description: Keith Carradine has a knack for bringing laid-back charm and intelligence to projects that run from artistic Robert Altman films to mainstream projects like ''The Will Rogers Follies'' on Broadway. In the new Showtime series ''Fast Track,'' set in the world of stock car racing, he plays an orthopedic surgeon named Richard Beckett, and the film can only lead to the question: What's a nice orthopedic surgeon like him doing in a series like this?

title: Sviatoslav Richter Is Dead; Acclaimed Pianist Was 82
description: The Russian pianist Sviatoslav Richter, one of the most acclaimed keyboard artists of the 20th century, died yesterday in a Moscow hospital. He was 82.

title: Problem: Lose the Debris but Keep the Cormorants
description: Tucked along the Kill van Kull, the busiest channel in New York Harbor, is Shooters Island, a nightmare to navigators and a dream to naturalists.

title: Williams Provides the Spark in His Return
description: At the urging of Yankee Manager Joe Torre, Bernie Williams spent the better part of five innings trying to be cautious.

title: Sex, but Only Along With Love
description: Maxwell knows how to pour on the sweet talk. During his show at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, his third sold-out concert there in July, he offered to paint polish on his lover's toes, to open a joint bank account and to go to the store for tampons; he also proposed marriage. And he did it all in a tender, supplicating voice while his band supplied pop's rhythm of love: a leisurely rolling funk, always insinuating but never pushing too hard. Amid wah-wah guitar ripples and breathy saxophone lines, Maxwell has the assurance to take things slowly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ANTHONY (TONY) C.
description: COOPER-Anthony (Tony) C., a well-known production stage manager and public relations executive, died Thursday, (July 31) at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York City. He was 43 and lived in Athens, New York, and Greenwich Village in Manhattan. The cause was complications related to Aids, his family said. After receiving a Master of Fine Arts in Theater Design from Boston University in 1980, Mr. Cooper joined the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C., where he served as production stage manager for the highly acclaimed production of the Lincoln Story. In 1984, he moved to New York City to work for various production companies including, The New York City Opera, The Elliott Feld Ballet and the modern dance group, The David Gordon Pick-up Company. In the late 80s, Mr. Cooper joined The Rowland Company, a New York based public relations firm. As an Executive Vice President of the firm, he planned and staged large media events for several Fortune 500 clients. He retired from the firm in 1994 to pursue other life-long interests. Mr. Cooper was preceded in death by his father Mr. Hobart Cooper. He is survived by his mother, Shirley J. Cooper; a sister and brotherin-law, Reneda and Allen Baer; his nephew, Jordan Baer, all of Indiana, and his longtime companion, Mr. James Whitmore, of New York City.

Reposing St. John Vianney Parish Center, 140-10 34th Ave., Saturday, Aug. 2, 12-2 PM, 6-8 PM, Sunday, August 3, 4-6 PM. Mass of Transferral Sunday, Aug. 3 at 7:30 P.M., St. John Vianney Church. description: The flowers appear and a few days later they are gone, leaving behind just a few dried blossoms and the shriveled memory of a crime that refuses to let this country rest.

description: BAER-Rudolf L., M.D. of New York City, July 31. Loving father of John R. Baer and the late Andrew R. Baer; cherished brother of Eva Baer; adored grandfather of David, Jessica, Alexandra and Abigail; father-in-law of Sherri Baer; brother-in-law of Elizabeth and Henry Werner and Virginia and George Grumbach. Also survived by special friend, Hilda Seligmann. The family would like to express its sincerest appreciation to the doctors, nurses and others who cared for Dr. Baer during his illness. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to: Rudolf L. Baer Foundation, C/O Department of Dermatology, New York University Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, New York 10016-6402.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about trading in the old stock of the Discovery Zone, misidentified the investor who controls the company and misstated his earlier affiliation. He is Martin S. Davis, not Marvin Davis. Martin Davis is a former chief executive of Paramount Communications, not its Paramount Pictures subsidiary.

title: Ivax, Drug Concern, Chooses President
description: The Ivax Corporation has named David Bethune, who formerly managed the American Cyanamid Company's global drug business, as its president and chief operating officer.

description: A sixth woman has come forward to charge the Army's senior enlisted soldier of misconduct, the Army said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Cancers Tied to Bomb Tests

title: ABM INDUSTRIES REPORTS PURCHASE OF OGDEN BUSINESSES
description: ABM Industries of San Francisco said yesterday that it had bought the Ogden Corporation's building-maintenance and engineering-services operations in New York City for an undisclosed price to expand in the city. ABM Industries, which provides air-conditioning, janitorial, engineering and other building services, said the acquisition would add $150 million to its annual revenue of about $1.2 billion and significantly increase its New York operations.(Bloomberg News)

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES ADDS TO CANADIAN BID
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. of Atlanta increased its takeover offer for the Canadian bottler Coca-Cola Beverages by 13 percent, to $465.8 million (Canadian) and won the support of the company's directors. The higher offer of $22 a share is up from the $19.50 the Atlanta-based company offered in May for the 52 percent of the Canadian bottler it does not already own. Coke Canada's shares rose $1.60, to $21.80, in Toronto trading. While Coca-Cola Enterprises is the only logical bidder for the unit, which bottles 95 percent of the soft drink company's beverages in Canada, analysts said the original offer did not reflect the company's improving profitability. The new offer is equal to about $337 million (United States).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROOK, ARTHUR N.
description: BROOK-Arthur N. Age 64. On July 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Deborah Snyderman Brook; loving father of Doris Jeanne, Saul Joseph, Jessica Arber and Noah Jonathan; devoted grandfather of Nathaniel and Jonah. Funeral services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, Sunday, August 3 at 9:45 A.M. Interment to follow at Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Children's Aid Society, NYC

title: Proposal to Restrict Campaign Contributions by Bond Lawyers Sets Off a Debate
description: New York State has become the focal point of a growing national debate over whether bond lawyers should be prohibited from making more than token campaign contributions to the officials with whom they do business, a move that would for the first time single out a group of lawyers for restrictions on political gifts.

title: $1.2 Million For a Plan On the Future Of a Harbor
description: Hoping to win more than $1 billion in Federal funds to expand shipping in New York Harbor, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has agreed to spend $1.2 million on a plan to revitalize wharves from Brooklyn to Bayonne.

title: Back at Columbus, Irabu Finds His Stuff
description: Here in this Midwestern minor league town, Hideki Irabu was back tonight where his $12.8 million contract would suggest he belongs. Not, that is, in the International League, to which he returned after a melancholy three weeks in the major leagues, but in command of hitters.

title: Little Interest in Politics Or Religion, Families Say
description: The last time Ghazi Abu Maizar called home from the United States, about a week ago, he was bubbling over with plans.

description: Bloomberg News

title: Bomb Suspect Was Detained by U.S. but Released
description: Ghazi Abu Maizar, one of two men arrested in a suspected terrorist plot to detonate bombs in Brooklyn, had been detained by Federal authorities earlier this year but was allowed to stay in the United States temporarily even though he had revealed that Israel considered him a terrorist, officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. LIFTS A BAN ON WEAPON SALES TO LATIN AMERICA
description: Reversing a policy enacted two decades ago because of human rights concerns, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would lift the ban on sales of the most advanced weapons, like fighter jets and tanks, to countries in Latin America.

title: Tunnel Job Delay Is Practical, Official Says
description: A day after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided to delay repairs on the Queens-Midtown Tunnel following a request by the Giuliani administration, a city official said yesterday that the work would not have started on time anyway because the agency had not filed for permits to close nearby streets during the work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABUSH, HARRY
description: BABUSH-Harry. On August 1, 1997. Dearly beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Sydney and Daniel. Devoted brother of Beatrice, Miriam, and Fay. Cherished brother-in-law, uncle, and great-uncle. Service Sunday at 11:30 A.M. at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Women's Tee-Off Times Law
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday making it illegal for private clubs to set separate tee-off times for women golfers or engage in other discriminatory practices.

title: 17th Arrest Made in Case Of Deaf Mexican Peddlers
description: Federal authorities charged yet another person yesterday with being part of the cross-country ring that they say exploited and abused deaf immigrants smuggled from Mexico.

title: Delivering the Power to the People Is Just a First Step in South Africa
description: On cold days, the air in many of South Africa's black townships is so dense with smoke that you can hear the clip-clop of the donkeys pulling the coal carts long before you can see them.

title: Giants to Concentrate On the Little Things
description: On the day before their first exhibition game, the Giants worked on some important things. Like how they were going to run on the field when they left the locker room before the game. How they would line up for pre-game calisthenics. Where the offense and defense would stand on the sideline and where exactly all the players would sit on the bench.

title: Don't Gut Legal Services
description: Despite repeated Republican assaults on its budget and program, the Federal Legal Services Corporation remains an important expression of the nation's commitment to provide equal justice for impoverished Americans. Yet, once again, a Congressional fight threatens its survival.

title: Poetry and Ancient Sounds
description: THE Sunken Garden Poetry Festival began six years ago under the leadership of the poet Rennie McQuilkin. Although the average crowd reaches anywhere from 800 to 1,000, the last reading drew more than 3,500 people. ''This was probably the biggest reading in the country, of its kind,'' Mr. McQuilkin said.

title: Playing College Days Strickly for Laughs
description: AT Texas Christian University, the phrase ''Hey, let's put on a show!'' means much more than cardboard sets and hand-sewn costumes.

title: Approaches To Killing Roaches
description: EARLIER this year, medical researchers in New York and six other cities concluded a five-year study to determine why children in inner cities have a higher incidence of asthma than their suburban counterparts. The study confirmed what many allergy specialists had suspected for years -- that asthmatic children exposed to cockroach infestation in their houses or apartments have more frequent and more severe asthma attacks.

title: Lauren Goldberg, David Wallace
description: Lauren Goldberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Goldberg of Newton Centre, Mass., is to be married today to David J. Wallace, the son of Mimi Stone of New York and Ira M. Wallace of Haledon, N.J. Rabbi Moshe Waldoks is to officiate at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass.

title: Fantasy Worlds, Complete With Sinks and Closets
description: AS MARK BENNETT EXPLAINS it, if he were drowning, the life that would flash before his eyes would be Wally Cleaver's, not his own. Mr. Bennett smiles as he rattles off anecdotes about how television -- particularly 50's and 60's sitcoms, including ''Leave It to Beaver,'' which featured Wally as the Beaver's older brother -- provided his escape, first from an unhappy childhood and later from a troubled adult life.

title: Austria, Circa 1400
description: IT was the middle of March in the mountain town of Lienz, Austria, and the temperature was nearly 70 degrees. Even though this capital of East Tyrol is 2,200 feet above sea level, the sun shines down on it most of the year, separating it from the more famous, crowded and cloudy resorts on the north side of the Alps. I was in the arcaded sidewalk cafe of the Hotel Garni Eck, drinking a melange, an Austrian version of cafe con leche, and watching the passers-by in this city of 15,000 residents crisscross the city's main square, the Hauptplatz.

title: What Is Janet Reno Thinking?
description: I would like to compliment you on your cover photograph of Janet Reno by Ralph Mecke (''What Is Janet Reno Thinking?'' by Jeffrey Goldberg, July 6). Producing a simple and straightforward, yet evocative and powerful, portrait is one of the most difficult things to do in photography. It is similarly difficult to produce a visually striking and resonant magazine cover, particularly with an image of essentially monochromatic tonalities. This wonderful photograph accomplished both. It's a rare thing to see. Attorney General Reno looks strong and dignified, yet retains the essential quality of mystery that, after all, is in some sense the very definition of humanity.

title: Friend of Sinister Torch
description: The 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X, who set a fire that killed his grandmother, Dr. Betty Shabazz, was described in psychiatric testimony in Westchester County Family Court as a mentally ill boy who set his sneakers on fire as a 3-year-old, was institutionalized at 9 because he could not distinguish reality from fantasy, and created an imaginary friend named Sinister Torch. That testimony laid to rest the idea that the boy, Malcolm Shabazz, consciously set out to harm his grandmother. JANE GROSS

title: A Less Burdensome Path to Safeguard the Future
description: AFTER leaving a job of 23 years and the wide range of benefits that went with it, Cecilia Felix found herself shopping not long ago for individual long-term disability income insurance.

title: Bookstore Wanted: Must Be Willing to Locate in the Bronx
description: Let readers in better-stocked boroughs scold Barnes & Noble for driving venerable independent bookstores out of business. Assemblyman Stephen B. Kaufman, a Democrat from Throgs Neck, is begging -- his word -- for a big bookstore in the Bronx. Here he is, in a borough of 1.4 million people, and he has to drive to Westchester to buy a book.

title: Bikini Atoll
description: To the Editor: That Bikini Atoll that is now being developed as a tourist attraction is of somewhat macabre interest to those of us who can still remember the first newsreel scenes of the A-bomb tests there in the 1940's (''Godzilla's Home Opens Its Arms to Scuba Divers,'' June 22).

title: Jennifer Atwater, John R. Anglim
description: Jennifer Snow Atwater, a daughter of Patricia A. Atwater of Columbia, Mo., and the late James D. Atwater, was married yesterday on Block Island, R.I., to John Richard Anglim, a son of Mary Ann and Richard Anglim of Minneapolis. The Rev. Donal R. Kehew performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paradise Not Quite Lost
description: One wall of the dining hall at the twin oaks commune functions as the bulletin board and local news service, with budget notices, letters from former members and handwritten, often fervid opinions posted on clipboards. At the moment, the hot topic on the wall involves a couple who have been seen pushing and hitting each other several times, violating Twin Oaks's strict nonviolent ethos. Members have posted lengthy comments, calling for the community to intervene or to impose sanctions against the couple. The woman involved has put up a typed note saying that she feels the violence remains within her ''personal comfort level.'' Most of the other members angrily disagree. I watch this woman one night before dinner as she studies the responses to her note. Tall and lanky, in a cutoff T-shirt, she gasps as she reads, twisting her body into a defensive posture.

title: Shhh! Some Dormitories Slam Doors on Noise
description: CONSIDERING the excesses of the 1980's, it's small wonder that the film farce ''Animal House,'' with its toga parties and general student mayhem, was considered a reflection of college life. But in the staid 90's, there is a new symbol on some campuses that the party is over.

title: Six Ways of Slicing The Same Speech
description: In one of the most brutal exchanges in all of Chekhov, Olga, the eldest of his ''Three Sisters,'' is chided by her upstart sister-in-law, Natasha, for allowing an aged servant to remain with the family. Here is the way various translators have rendered Natasha's rebuke:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Kiddie City, Israeli Div.

title: Middle Class Shouldn't Be Singing the Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Sufi Muslims Search for the Divine on Lower Broadway
description: It was a Thursday night, hot and steamy, and Masjid al-Farah had no air-conditioning. Still, the three-story building was packed, its 60 or 70 visitors spilling out onto the TriBeCa sidewalks, mingling with the rest of the evening crowd on West Broadway, just below Canal Street, where most of the former warehouse and industrial buildings now house restaurants and bars.

title: Jammed Roads: Guide to Coping
description: FOR roads, as for humans, middle age means constant work to stay in shape. So the Interstate highway system, set in motion in 40 years ago, is under repair, in some cases major repair. Getting good information in advance of a driving trip is important.

title: Next Up in Reinsdorf's Great Chicago Fire Sale: Ventura to Yanks?
description: Jerry Reinsdorf, a general manager was saying the other day, has done two things that have not been good for baseball. Other people in baseball, union officials, for example, would suggest that Reinsdorf, the Chicago White Sox owner, has done many more things that have not been good for baseball, but the general manager was speaking of two specific things.

title: Chautauqua's Quiet Charm
description: AT the Chautauqua Institution, on a long, slender lake about 75 miles southwest of Buffalo, people wear T-shirts that say, ''London, Paris, Rome, Chautauqua.'' In late June, I decided to check out the comparison. To get there reasonably cheaply, I rode Amtrak's Maple Leaf for seven and a half hours from New York to Buffalo ($110 round trip), and caught a shared limousine to the front gate, arriving an hour and a half later. At some point, I realized that I could have reached London, Paris or Rome faster.

title: Following Stone Age Footsteps
description: IN 1991 the Schnals Valley in Italy, in the far northern province of South Tyrol, was the site of one of the century's most sensational archeological discoveries. Two German tourists hiking along the mountainous border with Austria stumbled upon a bleak scene of death: a body, lying face down, was melting out of a deep bed of ice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, ELEANOR TODD MARSHALL PORTER
description: RUSSELL-Eleanor Todd Marshall Porter. Eighty-seven of Summit, NJ died peacefully at home in the presence of her family on August 1, 1997. Mrs. Russell was born in South Orange on July 14, 1910, the daughter of James Marshall and Eleanor Blanche Todd Marshall. She grew up in South Orange and in Somers, NY at the old TurkMarshall homestead. She was graduated from Dearborn-Morgan School, Orange, NJ and Smith College (1931). She married the late Ralph C. Porter, Jr. of Summit in 1931. They had three sons: former State Senator R.C. (Robin) Porter, III, of Wickford, RI; James Marshall Porter of Mendham, NJ, Chairman of Holmes Agency and the late David Stuart Porter, polar explorer. Mrs. Russell was active in Summit civic and service organizations, a life-long Episcopalian she was a member of Calvary Episcopal Church, for sixty-six years. In her senior years her grandchildren and great grandchildren were her life. She is survived by two sons, thirteen grandchildren and fourteen great grandchildren. Yet, as soon as political controls were relaxed in Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary at different moments of the 1960's and 1970's, directors of the stature of Milos Forman and Roman Polanski promptly appeared. Surely, then, with the collapse of Communism, a new New Wave of Eastern European movies would not tarry.

title: Smallest State

Paul Hofmann's ''Glorious Gardens of the Vatican'' (July 6) refers to Vatican City as the world's smallest state. The Vatican is not the world's smallest state, if ''state'' means an independent political entity that has a governmental structure, coins money, issues postal stamps and exchanges ambassadors. By that definition, the world's smallest state is the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, in Rome.

The highest-paid athlete of all time is Mike Tyson, who, despite a jail term for rape and a suspension for ear-biting, has made more than $300 million as a pro. That Oscar-winning documentary about the 1974 George Foreman-Muhammad Ali fight is not titled ''When We Were Champions'' but -- significantly and more accurately -- ''When We Were Kings.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADANES, MILDRED (MILLIE, NEE ROSENBERG)
description: BADANES-Mildred (Millie, nee Rosenberg). Of Oakland, CA., on July 27, 1997 in her seventy-ninth year. She is survived by Elliott, her best friend and husband of fiftyeight years; by her children, Steve, John and Tom; and by John's wife Ella Baff. Millie received her B.A. in languages from Hunter College, New York in 1938, and thirty-six years later earned her MA Degree in Counseling from Roosevelt University, Chicago. She became the Director of Admissions for the non-traditional School for New Learning of DePaul University, also in Chicago, retiring at sixtytwo in 1980. In 1979, with her husband, she was a co-founding member of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI). She was an active member of the Women's Strike for Peace, the Emergency Civil Liberties Committee (ECLC) and the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee (SNCC). As she wished, no formal funeral services will be held, but she will be well remembered by her devoted family and her many good friends. Contributions in her memory would be appreciated either to the California Alliance for the Mentally Ill (CAMI), 1111 Howe Avenue (Suite 475), Sacramento, California 95825, or to the Alameda County Mental Health Association (ACMHA), 1801 Adeline Street, Oakland, CA. 94607.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, GEORGE L.
description: COLEMAN-George L., 85, of Hobe Sound, Florida, died July 23, 1997. He was engaged in mining and oil businesses and was an avid sportsman, who was a close friend of Ben Hogan and Bing Crosby. Born in Miami, OK. on Jan 1, 1912, Mr. Coleman attended Western Academy in Alton, IL., and attended the Univ of Ok. Mr. Coleman was an executive in a lead and zinc mining company and a truck manufacturing company. Later he was chairman of the board and president of the First National Bank in Miami, OK. Mr. Coleman was a director of Flo-Sun Incorporated and a director of Pennzoil Company and its predecessor companies for 33 years. Former corporate directorships included the Detroit Baseball Company, Chris Craft Industries and the Ben Hogan Company. During World War II, Mr. Coleman served in the Army Air Corp Reserves and U.S. Naval Reserve. As an experienced pilot, he served as director of the Spartan School of Aeronautics at Muskogee, OK. and was responsible for training 450 pilots at a time and maintaining a large fleet of aircraft. Later, he was commissioned a Lt. j.g. in the Navy, assigned to the Naval Air Transport Squadron VR-9 and then to the Bureau of Aeronautics. Mr. Coleman won various outboard motor boat (hydroplane) races and held the first recognized national and international records over 60 and 70 m.p.h. He loved golf and excelled in various amateur tournaments, was Oklahoma State Golf Champion in 1946 and played in the British Amateur, French Amateur and Swiss Amateur. Mr. Coleman was a member of the Board of Governors of Seminole Golf Club, Juno Beach, FL. since 1958 and served as President from 1981 to 1992 and then became President Emeritus. Mr. Coleman had the longest membership (60 years) in the Cypress Point Club, Pebble Beach, CA. Other memberships included the Augusta National Golf Club, Augusta, GA, Brook Club, N.Y., N.Y., Castle Pines Golf Club, Castle Rock, CO and Jupiter Island Club, Hobe Sound, FL. He is survived by his wife Dawn Coleman, daughters from a previous marriage, Ann Coleman Carmack of Santa Fe, Sarah Coleman Cecconi of Venice, Italy and Dobbie Bassett de Segur of Middleburg, VA., grandchildren, Frederick Woolworth, Georgina Woolworth Johnson and Caroline Bassett and 4 great grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for late October in Hobe Sound, FL. Memorial contributions may be made to Robert T. Jones, Jr. Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Thomas W. Burke, 555 Fifth Avenue, 8th Floor, New York, New York 10017 or AmeriCares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Connecticut 06840.

description: ''FOX'S MINI-SERIES ''INTENSITY'' begins with Patsy Cline on the radio and Mom's boyfriend's hand in the marijuana Baggie. Then he kills two neighbors just for fun. That scene isn't in Dean Koontz's 1996 novel of the same name, but Mr. Koontz contends that he is thrilled with the adaptation, because the spirit of the book has been retained.

title: Bound for Glory
description: Billie had her gardenia. Chaka Khan has her mane. Patti LaBelle's lacquered coiffures were suggestive, perhaps, of a girlhood on Mars. It is a shrewd diva who finds a signature and sticks with it. As the most recently anointed goddess of the radio airwaves, Erykah Badu has hers.

title: Tribal Colleges Grapple With Challenges of Success
description: Two years ago, Danetta Jane Holds, a Crow Indian, tried to help her 15-year-old son with his algebra homework and discovered to her horror that she couldn't do it. This abrupt affirmation of her educational shortcomings convinced Ms. Holds, who never went beyond high school, that it was time to finally get a college degree.

title: No Small Operas, Only Small Imaginations
description: GRAND opera, by dictionary definition, is one in which the whole text, generally on a serious theme, is set to music. Audiences have come to expect a certain visual grandeur as well. But isn't grandeur hard to come by when the orchestra is half-size, the budget even smaller and the run only one night?

title: The City Becomes a Stage, and Part of the Action
description: WHEN SUMMER COMES, New York dances, sometimes in surprising ways. As always there are outdoor performances on platforms big and small. But at the most unusual events, the city itself is the stage.

title: Swoopes Learns to Juggle Bouncing Ball and Bouncing Boy
description: It is not because she has been away for so long. It is not because she sits at the end of the bench in a flowing dress. Sheryl Swoopes has sat there before. Not often, but enough to have learned to keep her head in the game, to be a student of the thing she loves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CATAPANO, FRANK
description: CATAPANO-Frank. After a long and valiant battle against cancer, died on Saturday, August 2, 1997, at Lenox Hill Hospital with his loving family at his side. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 43 years Joy (nee Franks), three adoring children Joanne, Andrew, and Joy, his cherished grandchildren Jonathan, Taylor and Charles. He was a true gentleman and was admired and respected by everyone who knew him. He will be sorely missed and always remembered. May he rest in peace. As per his wishes, Catholic services and burial will be private. If friends wish, they may make a contribution in Frank's memory to the Department of Medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital, NYC, or the American Cancer Society.

title: Bad Boy, What's He Gonna Do? George Under Raiders' Scrutiny Now
description: If there was ever a player who had just one more chance to prove himself, it is quarterback Jeff George.

title: The Village People
description: ONE MOONLIT NIGHT

title: In Gascony, Avant Garde Weds Medieval
description: A MIX OF AVANT-GARDE ART WITH Romanesque architecture is nearly the proverbial marriage made in heaven. An installation by a much-applauded conceptual artist in an imposing 13th-century chateau is no less a pairing. Both matches have recently been made in southwestern France, in two villages near Condom, in Gascony. In both exhibitions, daring contemporary art thrives in impressive, timeworn settings.

description: Walking Back the Cat

title: In a Higher Realm On the Pop Charts
description: GOD HAS BEEN HAVING A GOOD RUN ON the pop charts. This summer, two Christian-pop albums have lingered in the top 10: ''Butterfly Kisses (Shades of Grace),'' by Bob Carlisle, and ''God's Property From Kirk Franklin's Nu Nation.'' Mr. Carlisle aims for ballad-loving baby boomers, while God's Property reaches toward hip-hop fans. But both carry variations on the same message: that embracing Christ brings comfort.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the playwright Joseph Pintauro misstated the publication date of his novel ''State of Grace.'' It was 1983, not 1963.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. August 7, 1986-1997 Eleven years today. The warmth of his laughter... generous deeds... integrity... kind and loving ways... and ''the memories linger on''. Children, grandchildren and Joyce

title: More Blundering by Swiss Banks
description: Recent disclosures by Swiss banks suggest that their evasive handling of wartime Jewish accounts has not ended. If anything, the banks have again proved themselves incapable of determining whether they looted deposits made by Jews who were later killed in the Holocaust. That makes it all the more important that the independent investigation now promised proceed without delay.

title: Palmer, With 'Army' Ready, to Play in Seniors' Golf Tournament
description: FOR the last 10 years, organizers of the Northville Long Island Classic have brought some of the biggest names in golf to the Meadow Brook Club in Jericho. But the one man most synonymous with the game had always eluded them, until now.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWN, SYLVAN
description: BROWN-Sylvan, July 31, 1989 and Phyllis, August 7, 1996. Always in our hearts. You are missed by so many. Lovingly, Madeline, Howard, Brooke, and Bert.

title: A Talk Show Leads to Burst Of Violence
description: ONE of the few things Lisa Renda and her neighbors at the Spring Heights Family Housing complex can agree on is that she and they did not get along. Another is that after Ms. Renda appeared on the ''Sally Jessy Raphael'' show to tell about it, the situation became much, much worse. Last week, everyone agrees, was the worst ever.

title: Haunted by the Rocks of Ages
description: If 1996 was the year of Jane Austen, 1997 seems to be shaping up as the year of outer space. First ''Asteroid,'' ''Deadly Impact'' and ''Three Minutes to Impact'' dominated the television screen. Then ''Men in Black'' and ''Contact,'' movies offering new perspectives from other galaxies, hit the large screen. Meanwhile Sojourner is making headlines by transmitting data from Mars.

title: In Vineland, a Marketplace Run by Farmers, for Farmers
description: SAM RONCHETTI is still going strong. Six days a week, 35 weeks a year, Mr. Ronchetti calls the prices in his rapid-fire, singsong voice at the Vineland Produce Auction.

description: World Cup 1998

title: Shipwrecks with Wine Inside
description: Reaching half a mile beneath the Mediterranean Sea off the northwest coast of Sicily, oceanographers and archeologists traveling in a once-secret nuclear submarine have discovered the largest concentration of ancient shipwrecks ever found in the deep sea. The 115 artifacts retrieved include clay containers holding wine, olive oil and fish sauce. Five of the eight ships were from Roman times, 100 B. C. to A. D. 400. One was loaded with stone columns and blocks, perhaps material for a prefabricated temple.

title: U.S. Airlines Expand First-Class for Upgrades
description: Some airlines are adding seats to their first-class sections to attract frequent travelers who typically pay full-coach fares.

title: Appeal Says Defense Missed Flaws in Case
description: Nearly two decades after California reinstated capital punishment and more than five years after it resumed putting convicted criminals to death, the state's especially long and anguished fight over the issue finally seemed settled.

title: Deaf Mexicans Are to Remain As Witnesses
description: Some of the deaf Mexicans who were found living in servitude in Queens two weeks ago will be allowed to stay in the United States for at least three years to help investigators pursue criminal cases against the people who have been accused of enslaving them, an immigration official said yesterday.

title: Jamie Tarses' Fall, As Scheduled
description: By arranging her office according to the principles of feng shui, Tarses could have had the benefit of ancient Chinese wisdom in dealing with a modern American power play.

title: Bringing Diversity to the Politics of Distrust
description: DAVID N. DINKINS lost the New York mayoralty four years ago in part because of what some people called his timorous response to a black-led boycott of a Korean-owned grocery store. So it was more than a little noteworthy when the Rev. Al Sharpton -- another black man seeking to be Mayor of New York -- showed up at a dinner of Korean-Americans the other evening to deliver a cordial if awkward talk about race and politics.

title: A Permanent Bond To the America's Cup
description: It was an indelible introduction to the America's Cup for Don Smith, the chief benefactor in the New York Yacht Club's current effort to win back its revered old mug.

title: Combining Public and Private Money Puts Life in a Block
description: During the worst years on West 140th Street, there were things Rolinda Hill always did and things she never did, in order to survive.

title: A Reverse Discrimination Suit Upends Two Teachers' Lives
description: The two women were brought together by a common desire to teach children. But they have been driven apart by race, politics and, paradoxically, a social policy that was supposed to help end such divisiveness.

title: Seeing Green in a Yellow Border
description: NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC has always stood apart from most other magazines, a yellow-bordered aristocrat clinging to its Victorian sense of purpose: ''the increase and diffusion of geographic knowledge.'' No miracle diets or sex tips here, just exhaustive examinations of the Roman Empire or startling pictures of somewhere on the fringes of the galaxy.

title: An 1850 Brick Meeting House of Dramatic Simplicity
description: IN a borough of ornate churches, Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights is an 1850 brick meeting house of dramatic simplicity. The giant theater-style interior is almost unaltered from when the spellbinding antislavery clergyman Henry Ward Beecher conducted his famous slave auctions. Now the congregation has begun a comprehensive restoration.

title: Innocent Posting of Fliers Has Led to Visual Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to 'Who Knew? Estates'
description: ON the wall by Jayson Williams's electric gate, blocking the single-lane concrete drive that he and his father built (less maintenance than asphalt, he explained, it will last 50 years), and near the security phone and the warning about the guard dogs, there is a bronze plaque showing a basketball player, No. 55 on the uniform. He is shrugging, hands upturned, his face in a fatalistic, ''these things happen'' look.

title: Follow the Proffering Duck
description: 'Follow the money. always follow the money.'' That resounding phrase, coined on the analogy of the French cherchez la femme, has become the rallying cry of a generation of reporters investigating corruption in high places. It has echoes, of course, in the pursuit of the Asian connection to Clinton campaign finance; the title of PBS's series on the subject is ''Follow the Money,'' and CNN calls its coverage of the Senate hearings ''The Money Trail.''

title: Fashion Statements, Flapping Their Wings
description: New Yorkers have a tradition of taking exotic pets, from pythons to iguanas, out on the street during warm weather. But from Battery Park to Central Park, it seems that the big crowd-pleasers this summer are parrots. The most popular are white cockatoos, introduced to American servicemen by the people of the Solomon Islands during World War II. One man, far left, deftly managed a baby and a cockatoo. The most exotic parrots are the large scarlet and blue macaws of Mexico and Brazil. In the 1970's, two macaws, Napoleon and Josephine, became a familiar sight in Central Park, riding on a bicyclist's handlebars. Recently, another Napoleon, left, a 37-year-old yellow-naped Amazon parrot, was seen happily perched on a stylish woman with a scarf around her shoulders to protect her dress. Although a macaw is on display under a sign that reads OVEREXPLOITATION at the American Museum of Natural History, the designers Jean-Paul Gaultier and John Galliano were still lavishing macaw feathers on fantasy wraps in their recent Paris shows. The designer John Bartlett ended his New York men's fashion show on July 24 with a bird of a different color: a rooster, carried by a model. Could roosters be the new parrots?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, SALLY
description: PAUL-Sally, July 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Sherry and son-in-law Joel. Loving sister of Dorothy Light. Cherished grandmother of Mason and Travis. Services Wed., 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Why I Took A Chance On Learning
description: During my first semester at Santa Barbara City College in 1993, my classes included aerobics, typing and remedial math. Who would have guessed that after spending three years there, I would be attending Harvard University?

title: From Doctors' Offices To a Minimalist Duplex
description: THE couple who own the exquisite minimalist duplex were at their house in Connecticut. So the architect's assistant filled in, rushing down West 78th Street in the rain, wearing only T-shirt, khakis and sneakers and clutching the keys.

title: Where a Garden Blooms, Children With AIDS Are Remembered
description: In 1989, Countess Albina du Boisrouvray was searching for ways to assist children with AIDS when she found Dr. James Oleske, a pediatric immunologist at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey-New Jersey Medical School in Newark, who had helped establish that AIDS can be passed from parent to child before birth. Since then, through a foundation named for her son, Francois-Xavier Bagnoud, who died in a helicopter crash, Countess Boisrouvray has given the university $2.25 million toward further research and a center that trains AIDS workers from around the world.

title: Jamie Tarses' Fall, As Scheduled
description: Lynn Hirschberg's article ''Jamie Tarses' Fall, as Scheduled'' (July 13) is a perfect example of why ABC is in third place. ABC takes someone like Tarses, with refreshing, sharp ideas, and bashes her down with network politics. Once that's done, she doesn't appear ''fresh'' anymore, so out the door she goes.

title: A Sportsman Above and Below the Surface
description: ON a trip to Florida this winter I discovered a troubling conflict in my relationship with the underwater world. One way or another, the water and what lives in it has always been a source of pleasure and fascination for me. I've fished since I was a child, in ponds, lakes, streams and drainage ditches. I'm sure when I was very young I fished in puddles. On summer vacations at the Connecticut shore, I went crabbing and dragged a small hand seine with my cousins, catching dogfish, sea horses and minnows.

title: Ready to Lift That Copter (And Don't Call Her 'Doll')
description: WHAT -- The first female G.I. Joe, or as Hasbro puts it, its first female action figure ''portrayed in authentic military gear.'' (Hasbro's G.I. Joe Nurse, a 1967 model, was quickly discontinued when the toy company found that ''boys didn't want to play with a nurse,'' said Karen Lehman, the brand manager.)

description: To the Editor:

title: A Sight of the Infant Universe
description: The farther out a telescope peers into space the farther back in time are the events it sees. Light traveling from the outermost reaches of the universe would take 14 billion years to get here.

title: Medicare Crisis Is Nearly On Hold
description: For the last few days Washington has been indulging in a well-deserved round of self-congratulation over passage of the first balanced budget in three decades. After 10 years of failed deficit reduction efforts, the bill passed last week stands out as a significant bipartisan accomplishment. So why are we applauding with only one hand?

description: Maria Jeanette Capone and Paul Brower Thompson Jr. were married yesterday in West Orange, N.J. The Rev. Abigail W. Hamilton performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Innocents.

description: GRANSTON-David W., 60, formerly of Locust Valley, NY and Northeast Harbor, ME. Died July 31, 1997. He is survived by his wife Priscilla (nee Day), son David W. Jr and grandson David ''Willie'' III, all of Northeast Harbor, ME.

description: For generations of New Yorkers, it has been the poor man's taste of summer. It is a frozen concoction that comes in a crayon-box assortment of flavors served in a pleated paper cup, and it costs about $1. It is Italian ice, of course. The kind made for three decades by Marino's Real Italian Ices, the largest purveyor of the ices in the metropolitan region.

title: Charlotte Loomis and James Heaton
description: Charlotte Earle Loomis, a daughter of Dr. Louise Earle Loomis and A. Worthington Loomis of Hartford, was married yesterday to James Joseph Heaton, the son of Joan S. Heaton of Tipton, Ind., and the late L. Joe Heaton. The Rev. William J. Eakins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Hartford Golf Club in West Hartford, Conn.

title: J. David Jones, 61, a Master of Aerial Camera Work, Dies
description: J. David Jones, an airborne Balanchine who used the sky as his stage and helicopters as his corps de ballet, died on July 14 at his home in Redway, Calif. He was 61 and had been Hollywood's premier helicopter pilot and an accomplished aerial coordinator.

title: Crime in New Jersey: Charting the Decline County by County
description: The downturn in crime across the state continues a trend that began at the start of the decade. By 1995, for example, violent crime was down 7 percent, and in 1996, it dropped 11 percent. Nationwide, violent crime dropped 7 percent. New Jersey's overall crime rate, which calculates crimes in the seven categories listed in this chart, dropped 7 percent.

title: Corrections
description: The International Datebook listing on page 15 of the Travel section today carries an outdated entry in some copies for the Otello Festival in Pafos, Cyprus. The cancellation of the festival was reported to The Times after printing of the section had begun.

title: In a Master Class, a Diva, 82, Teaches the Essence of Feeling
description: THE doorbell chimes played a lilting tune. ''One of them is flat,'' Vivian della Chiesa said as she answered their call and headed for the door. ''I really should get that fixed.''

title: Casinos' Ripple Effect Attracts Bets on Real Estate
description: A RECENT tour of commercial property in southeastern Connecticut -- an area once known mostly for making submarines -- drew 55 real estate brokers and investors from all over the state who were looking for hotel, restaurant and golf course sites, rather than industrial properties.

title: Unbalanced
description: BOTH houses of Congress this week agreed to sweeping health care changes to balance the Federal budget -- changes that affect New Jersey more than most other states. With more than one million senior citizens in the Garden State on Medicare and 700,000 poor residents receiving Medicaid, the proposed reduction in those two programs -- some $1.5 billion from Medicare and hundreds of millions of dollars in Medicaid in the next five years -- will negatively affect the financial health of every hospital in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANKEL, BERTHA
description: FRANKEL-Bertha, Dearest Mom. Five years have gone by. Miss you and think of you always. Your loving daughter.

title: From North Gate, a Vision of Paradise
description: ON a warm, sunny day, arriving on the tented patio of this restaurant feels like arrival in paradise. Across North Gate's broad lawn sloping to the Hudson River's edge lies the beautiful broad northward sweep of water and mountains. There is not a serpent in sight, and the apple is candied and served with red snapper. Summer evenings settle in slowly, turning the river to shimmering silver, which makes silhouettes of trees and, on one occasion, of branches arching over a painter in a long flowing skirt and wide-brim straw hat, her brush to easel. For a moment we are transported back into the 19th century.

title: Informer on Radical Right Is Acquitted
description: A Federal District Court jury on Friday night found Carol Howe, 26, a former debutante who became a neo-Nazi, not guilty of charges that she had threatened to blow up buildings in 15 cities.

title: King Emeritus
description: GEORGE A. HAMID Jr. used to love the rain. ''On a hot summer day on the Boardwalk, when it rained, you had to go inside,'' said Mr. Hamid, who once owned so much of Atlantic City's great indoors that he was called the king of the Boardwalk.

title: Target of Twin Broadsides on Corruption and Bombing, Arafat Goes to See Mubarak
description: Under fire from other Palestinians as well as from the Israeli Government, Yasir Arafat traveled to Egypt today to seek Arab backing against what he called ''the dangerous measures'' taken by Israel since a devastating suicide bombing Wednesday.

title: The Blue Water and the Green Service
description: THE Lobster Bar and Grill in Hampton Bays is the quintessential summer spot. The approach along a ''can this possibly be it?'' road, past boatyards and marinas, prepares diners for this laid-back, carefree destination. A boardwalk, flanked by willow trees and wooden barrels filled with petunias and geraniums, leads to an oversize A-frame ski house look-alike.

title: The Making of E. B. White
description: Modest in its size and presumptions, engaging in tone, E. B. White's ''One Man's Meat'' has resisted becoming historic, even after a nonstop run of 55 years in print. First published in 1942 and reissued in expanded form two years later, the book was unweighty by design, being not a sustained single work but a compilation of the writer's monthly columns for Harper's Magazine (which he had begun writing in 1938), along with three casual essays first published in The New Yorker. Because of this format and the format of the author's mind, the book has always had the heft, the light usefulness, of a bushel basket, carrying a raking of daily or seasonal notions, and, on the next short trip, the heavier burden of an idea. (The image owes much to White himself, whose remembered easy, unstriding walk across a pasture or down the shore road of his Maine farm remains unique, as does his touch with the homely utensils of prose.) Strewn with errands and asterisks, farming tips and changes of weather, notes on animals and neighbors and statesmen, ''One Man's Meat'' is too personal for an almanac, too sophisticated for a domestic history, too funny and self-doubting for a literary journal. Perhaps it's a primer: a countryman's lessons that convey, at each reading, a sense of early morning clarity and possibility.

title: Festival at Bard Highlights Haydn's Career
description: FOR seven summers, the Bard Music Festival in Annandale-on-Hudson has chosen a major composer of the Romantic or modern era, showcasing the composer's works in the context of the world in which he lived. His music, in other words, was juxtaposed with pieces by predecessors, followers and contemporaries. This season, the artistic directors, Leon Botstein and Robert Martin, are piloting their ''Rediscoveries'' project in two directions: first, going back to the classical period and then putting all their eggs in one basket: each of the dozen concerts will be devoted to Haydn.

title: In Berlin, Charting Gay Art's Struggle to Emerge
description: AT FIRST SIGHT, DAVID HOCKNEY'S large, formal painting of Christopher Isherwood and his lover, Don Bachardy sails in stylish triumph above an exhibition at the Academy of Arts here, celebrating 100 years of the international gay movement. Look, it appears to say, amid all the evidence of scandal, struggle and concealment in the show around it, we have come far. We can be painted together. There is no more to hide.

title: Athlete Wins Gold With U.S. in Israel
description: RUGBY has been a sport in the Maccabiah Games, the quadrennial Jewish Olympics in Israel, since 1981. Going into the recently completed Games, South Africa had never lost a match, much less the gold medal. And its powerful team was overwhelmingly favored again this year.

title: About Early Editions
description: Starting tomorrow, The Times is changing its printing schedules to provide late news coverage for all readers in the metropolitan area.

title: East Hampton Seeks Time Ban on Music
description: A PROPOSAL to limit the hours for live music is upsetting bar and restaurant owners in East Hampton.

title: Trading Rose Frustrations for Clematis Delights
description: Gardeners are a fickle breed. A few years ago, people were planting roses with a fervor usually reserved for more active outdoor sports. They were cheerfully plucking bugs, battling blight, combating mildew and applying rather potent chemicals for rose-related problems. They grumbled only when half their roses succumbed to winter kill, and seemed resigned to treating rosebushes as expensive annuals. But it seems as if the rose craze may be on the wane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLAN, DAVID LLOYD
description: GOLAN-David Lloyd. Died at his home in Weston, CT. Born in N.Y.C. on June 22, 1919 to Anna and Joseph Golan. Survived by his wife Nancy, daughter Lisa, son Mark, and three grandchildren.

title: Athens Pins Olympic Bid to World Meet
description: The most important race at the world track and field championships is not the 100 meters or the marathon, but the city of Athens' final dash to convince members of the International Olympic Committee that it deserves to be the host of the 2004 Summer Games.

description: MAKING WAVES

description: AN I.G.A. supermarket is scheduled to open this fall on the site of the former Gristede's store here on East Hartsdale Avenue, restoring an anchor for the downtown shopping district, a convenience for residents and a boost to other businesses.

description: FIRST I heard a crack. Then utter pandemonium broke out.''

description: Life as a community college professor sometimes turns Sheri David churlish. At a barbecue this summer, she snapped at a professor from a prestigious four-year college who was complaining about being forced to teach three classes in the coming term. She usually teaches five.

title: EAT WISELY
description: You can now snack your way to smoother mental functioning, according to Personal Health Development, a California company that sells Think!, an ''interactive''candy bar that contains alleged brain food like gingko biloba, vitamin B-12 (with 4,166 percent of the recommended daily allowance!) and a secretive ''Advanced Protein Blend''.Think! is part of a new brain-bar wave. Intellect, produced in Minneapolis, offers more esoteric additives like kava kava root and gotu kola leaves, while Aunt Sue Productions in Montreal sells Anxiety, which supposedly alleviates that efficiency-robbing state. On the assumption that customers are mentally drained before each chew, idiot-proof instructions on Think!'s label suggest a Think! bar and fresh water ''30 minutes before using your brain.''

title: Conventionally Unconventional
description: RARELY has a movie villain emerged as triumphant and as smugly self-satisfied in his malevolence as he does in the form of Chad in the film, ''In the Company of Men.'' Like Iago in Shakespeare's ''Othello,'' Chad comes across less as a flawed man than as an embodiment of pure evil, updated as a sinister corporate climber, racist and misogynist who destroys souls for sport. The film won an award at the Sundance Film Festival, and many critics have applauded its raw, if unappealing, ferocity.

title: Save Sigmund Freud
description: People who get an ''amphetamine-style buzz'' from Prozac are the lucky ones. Many get hostile, irritable, agitated and have to quit the medication.

description: A vacant 138,000-square-foot retail building at the Newport mixed-use center on Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront that used to house a Bradlees department store is being converted to an international food market.

description: WHEN Affymetrix, a gene research company, went public last summer, investors opened their arms wide. Not only did they help the company raise $85 million, but they have sent its stock from an initial $15 a share to more than double that amount -- $31.9375 -- today.

Taylor of Boston, was married yesterday to Samuel Bradford Davol, a son of Dr. Anna Lo Davol and Dr. Peter Bradford Davol of Concord, Mass. The Rev. Carl Scovel, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Old Meeting House in Francestown, N.H.

title: Renovated, San Francisco Opera House to Reopen
description: San Francisco's War Memorial Opera House, a 1932 Beaux-Arts landmark in the Civic Center, is scheduled to reopen next month after a two-year, $84.5 million renovation. The 3,176-seat auditorium will once again be the home of the San Francisco Opera and the San Francisco Ballet, both of which performed elsewhere during the renovation. The Opera House and its sister building, Veterans Auditorium, were the setting for the founding of the United Nations in 1945.

title: Suspects in Bomb Plot Took Two Paths From the West Bank
description: A few years ago, they were just a couple of teen-agers in dusty Palestinian towns 30 miles apart in Israel's troubled West Bank. There are no indications that they knew each other. Indeed, as relatives and friends tell it, they were not much alike: one caught up in the stone-throwing crowds of the Palestinian uprising known as the Intifada, the other an honor student never in trouble.

title: Lonely Song of a Chinese Minstrel Bares a Migrant's Lament
description: Over the clatter of Chinese meal-making in the outdoor food stalls that overflow with diners on a hot summer evening, Shen Ping sings with a lonely voice.

description: Thanks to Davida Rosenblum for creating the euphemism for older romance: Would I like ''bagels for breakfast?'' Yes.

Law enforcement officials say that Lafi Khalil and Ghazi Abu Maizar planned to detonate bombs in a crowded subway station and a commuter bus, possibly as part of a suicide mission. Acting on a tip from a friend of the suspects, the police burst into a darkened Brooklyn apartment Thursday and shot the two men, authorities said, just as one of them was reaching for an explosive device.

title: Crime and Too Much Punishment
description: The bungled electrocution of a convicted murderer in Florida in March has revived the debate about the cruelty of capital punishment. It's probably cold comfort to opponents, but things used to be far worse, as demonstrated all too clearly at the Museo di Criminologia Medioevale in San Gimignano, Italy, which features medieval- and Inquisition-era torture devices. In the past, a death sentence wasn't about quickness and efficiency; instead, the goal was to make the deaths of convicts and coerced confessors as slow and agonizing as possible. Tucked away in a small, scenic Tuscan hill town, the museum's cavernous maze of rooms enlightens visitors about the miserable effects of thumbscrews, branding irons, skull crushers and tongue clamps, among greater horrors. Here's a look.

title: Poland's New Jewish Question
description: Plonsk, an average small town in poland: 23,000 inhabitants; brand-new Ford and Pepsico plants in the suburbs; a dilapidated market square; dismal Communist housing; billboards of women in sexy underwear, and a supermarket where there once was a synagogue. Plonsk is fairly typical also in that before 1939 more than half of its inhabitants were Jewish. At one point, Jews made up 80 percent of the population. There had been Jews living in Plonsk since 1446. David Ben-Gurion, the first Prime Minister of Israel, was born there. After Dec. 16, 1942, when the last train left for Auschwitz, barely a handful came back. Now there is said to be one old lady left of Jewish origin, and she is a Catholic.

title: Steps to Repair Your Wooden Fence
description: MANY homeowners have wooden fences around their homes. Fences take a lot of abuse and, sooner or later, they need repair work. Before starting any repair, it's a good idea to look over the entire fence and evaluate the extent of damage. What seems like a minor problem may in fact be more extensive. For example, a rotted picket may be an isolated problem or the wood rot may extend to neighboring pickets or even the support members. Careful investigation may reveal that it would be better to rebuild the fence rather than to attempt repairing a section at a time.

title: A Judge Tells Newark Officers They Can Keep Their Beards

''They all had bushy mustaches or bushy beards,'' said Detective McEntee, president of the local Fraternal Order of Police. But the accepted image for members of police organizations seems to have changed, and a departmental rule in effect for several years has barred Newark police officers without medical exemptions from having beards. Until last week, that is. On Monday, Judge John W. Bissell of Federal District Court in Newark granted another exemption to the rule, this time for religious reasons.
