title: Hey, Things Fall Apart
description: The specters of failed relationships and echoing catastrophes haunt DANGER WALL MAY FALL (Zoland, paper, $13.95), a collection of seven short stories by Lynn Luria-Sukenick, a poet who died of cancer in 1995. Typically, a protagonist (all are women) with her ''marriage gone, jobs hard to come by, bad luck,'' assesses her isolated state in sophisticated accents of mingled rapture and resignation. Thus in ''Still Life With Bath,'' an older woman puzzles over her younger lover's incomprehensible devotion and decency. ''What Is Lost, What Is Missing, What Is Gone: Scenes After the Earthquake'' draws disturbing and oddly exhilarating parallels among love lost, ''the sound of California breaking'' and the heroine's intuitive understanding of her Jewish grandmother's sufferings during World War II. And ''Do You Know the Facts of Life? (Quiz)'' offers in question-and-answer form hilarious capsule descriptions of such amusing romantic-erotic arcana as ''a state of sexual dyslexia'' and ''the opposite of an obscene phone call.'' If little happens in these stories, their elegant tone and clever imagery nevertheless give them a beguiling density; Luria-Sukenick's fiction amply compensates in intensity for what it lacks in range. Watching landscapes where ''blank-faced condos bite into the hillsides'' and observing ''the citrus slice of the Ferris wheel motionless in the morning light,'' we slip willingly inside her characters' thin skins. Bruce Allen

title: Save Sigmund Freud
description: Edmundson is right that much of our thinking about literature and contemporary culture would be impoverished by an absence of Freud's ideas. But while we're in the business of saving the baby from the bath water, it's worth noting a few points. Many of Freud's conclusions about women were misogynistic, products, as they were, of his misogynistic culture and his own limitations. Contemporary Freudian psychoanalytic theory about female psychology is quite another matter. The days of fixation on penis envy as bedrock in understanding a woman's sexuality are long over. Gone is any notion that women have deficient morality. Instead, Freudian psychoanalysts focus on ways in which women's primary femininity is experienced and expressed.

title: A Head Start
description: Accompanied by both well-known and unfamiliar reproductions of the artist's work, the essays in PICASSO: The Early Years, 1892-1906 (National Gallery of Art/Yale University, $60) were chosen to reflect new areas of scholarly research. Perhaps the most fascinating of these (and the most needed) pertains to Picasso's earliest training, as well as to the importance of drawing. ''The practice of drawing was at the root of everything Picasso did,'' the art historian Marilyn McCully, the book's editor, writes. Several essays consider the famous Blue and Rose periods, but from unexpected perspectives. ''Barcelona Blues,'' by Robert S. Lubar, for example, describes socioeconomic conditions in Barcelona, where the vast majority of the Blue period paintings were executed; an essay on the Rose period examines the influence of French poetry and theater. And in ''Picasso in Gosol: The Calm Before the Storm,'' Robert Rosenblum discusses the paintings done in the remote Pyrenean village the summer before Picasso painted the revolutionary ''Demoiselles d'Avignon'' (1907). McCully, who serves as a collaborating author with John Richardson on his continuing biography of Picasso, also provides a helpful chronology of the painter's life, which reminds us that the book covers him only from the age of 11 to 24. In the essay ''Gods of Art: Picasso's Academic Education and Its Legacy,'' Natasha Staller writes: ''His nascent mastery is thrilling to witness.'' Robin Lippincott

Since the ads began running a decade ago, adult smoking has dropped from 26 percent to 18 percent.

title: Caspian Oil and Quicksand
description: The Caspian region nowadays is best defined as a large body of undersea oil surrounded by nations anxious to tap it. The industry reckons that the Caspian reserves contain up to 200 billion barrels of oil worth as much as $4 trillion at current prices, plus comparable reserves of natural gas. Little wonder two potentates from the Caspian and Caucasus area, Presidents Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan and Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia, journeyed to Washington this summer seeking to improve diplomatic and commercial relations. The danger is that American political concerns will be overwhelmed by the petroleum juggernaut.

Porter, Jr. of Summit in 1931. They had three sons: former State Senator R.C. (Robin) Porter, III, of Wickford, RI; James Marshall Porter of Mendham, NJ, Chairman of Holmes Agency and the late David Stuart Porter, polar explorer. In 1954, Mrs. Russell began a career in book sales with the Baker and Taylor Company. She married the late George F. Russell in 1955. Together they traveled the world. Mrs. Russell was active in Summit civic and service organizations, a life-long Episcopalian she was a member of Calvary Episcopal Church, for sixty-six years. In her senior years her grandchildren and great grandchildren were her life. She is survived by two sons, thirteen grandchildren and fourteen great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Episcopal Church, Summit on Tuesday, August 5 at 10 AM. Burial will be in the Todd Family plot, Ivandell Cemetery, Somers, NY. Fletcher of Ashland, OR; two sisters, Marjorie Balboni, of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts, and Ann Robinson, of London, England, and New York City. Mr. Fletcher was a graduate of The Hill School in Pottstown, PA, and later attended Yale University. During World War II, he joined the United States Navy and was a member of the Naval Intelligence Corps. He was employed by both the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the U.S. Salvage Company before joining the American Hull Shipping Syndicate, of which he eventually became Vice President, and from which he retired in 1985. Mr. Fletcher was a member of the Spouting Rock Beach Association of Newport, RI; of the Masonic Order Holland Lodge of New York; The Brook Club of New York; the Union Club of New York; The Meadow Club of Southampton; the Southampton Bathing Corporation; and the Southampton Club. title: DOW PLANS TO ACQUIRE SOUTH AFRICAN CHEMICAL COMPANY
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would acquire Sentrachem Ltd., an ailing South African chemical and plastics company, for 2.07 billion rand, or about $447 million. Dow Chemical plans to offer 10.50 rand for each of the 197.5 million shares of Sentrachem. Sentrachem's biggest shareholder, Sankorp Ltd., has agreed to throw its 39 percent stake behind the bid, Dow Chemical said. Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., established itself in South Africa in 1959 but withdrew in 1987 amid economic sanctions designed to pressure the ruling apartheid regime. The company returned in 1995 and now operates a polyurethane plant there. Sentrachem lost 217 million rand in the six months ended Feb. 28, compared with a profit of 101 million rand a year earlier.

Before retirement in 1984, Mr. Bilby served as Executive VP at RCA for a number of years. Prior to that, he worked for NBC. Upon retirement, Mr. Bilby was appointed Executive in Residence at Harvard Business School. Mr. Bilby attended Columbia Univ. and graduated with a B.A. from the Univ of Arizona. During World War II he was awarded The Legion of Honor, The Bronze Star and The Silver Star. Following the war he covered the Arab-Israeli War and wrote a book about that experience called ''New Star in the Near East''. He also authored a biography of RCA founder, General David Sarnoff, called ''The General.'' Survived by his wife, Dr. Joanne Stroud Bilby, four children, Winne Kenneth, Jr., Margot and Bryan, one brother, Judge Richard Bilby, five grandchildren, Ben, Hallie, Taylor, Leigh and Harrison, and three stepchildren, Ethan, Eric and Natasha Stroud. description: Acordia Inc. said yesterday that its managers had agreed to buy the closely held insurance brokerage firm for about $330 million. Anthem formed Acordia in 1989 and took it public in 1992. Then, last month, Anthem took the company private to prepare it for sale. The deal includes $270 million in cash, $40 million in assumed debt and a $10 million contingency payment based upon future operating earnings.

title: Chess

title: POST PROPERTIES-COLUMBUS IN $600 MILLION DEAL
description: Post Properties Inc. has agreed to acquire the Dallas-based residential property developer Columbus Realty Trust for about $600 million, including debt, the companies said yesterday. Post Properties, also a real estate investment trust, said each Columbus share would be exchanged for 0.615 Post Properties share. The deal, which is expected to be completed in November, would combine the 7,526 Columbus apartment homes, mainly in Dallas, with Post Properties' 21,673 apartment homes. After completion of the deal, the Atlanta-based Post Properties would have total market capitalization of about $2.2 billion. Columbus would operate under the Post Properties name.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY GYNECARE FOR $79 MILLION
description: Johnson & Johnson agreed yesterday to buy Gynecare Inc. for stock valued at about $79 million, or $8.46 a share, entering the market for products to treat uterine disorders. The maker of medical devices, drugs and consumer-health products said buying Gynecare, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif., would expand its line of women's health products. Shares of Gynecare fell 37.5 cents, to $8.125. Gynecare, which develops devices to treat uterine bleeding, will become part of Johnson's Ethicon Inc. division, which sells wound-closing and other surgical products. Johnson & Johnson's stock fell 12.50 cents, to $60.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZKI, HERBERT
description: KATZKI-Herbert. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) deeply mourn the passing of Herbert Katzki, a giant in the history of JDC since 1936. He served overseas for 30 years. One day before Nazi troops entered Paris in 1940, he fled to Lisbon where he helped direct JDC rescue programs during the Holocaust. As representative of the U.S. War Refugee Board, he served as special attache to the American Embassy in Ankara, Turkey and, subsequently, to the U.S. Legation in Berne, Switzerland. After the war, he played a key role in the relief and reconstruction of Jewish communities in Europe and helped develop programs for Jews in Israel and Moslem countries. A man of compassion and integrity, his dignity, kindness and humility inspired all who knew him. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife, Kate, his companion and partner in healing and public service. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Amb. Milton A. Wolf, Bd Chairman Michael Schneider, Exec. V.P. Ralph Goldman, Hon. Exec. V.P. Honorary Presidents: Heinz Eppler Sylvia Hassenfeld Donald M. Robinson Henry Taub

title: 2 in Bomb Case Appear More Aimless Than Ardent

title: Qualities of an Animal Scientist: Cow's Eye View and Autism

title: History That Remains Hidden
description: Last week in Guatemala, a truth commission began sifting through the rubble of that country's 36-year civil war. Commissions to investigate the human rights abuses of the past have become a standard part of the healing process in Latin America as guerrilla wars and military dictatorships recede into history. Like the other commissions, Guatemala's will be constrained by penury and political realities. Cooperation from the military will be scant. The United States, which backed that military for long periods, is giving $1 million for Guatemala's commission. But Washington has declined to provide something more important, its own files on Guatemala's crimes.

title: American Topics

Mr. Saban owns A-Aaable Rentals, a name he chose 27 years ago to keep his business in Phoenix, Arizona, high in the phone-book listings. But the regional phone company, US West, recently said that so many A's created dishonest competition. So Mr. Saban filed suit and won an injunction ordering the inclusion of A-Aaable Rentals in the next edition of the Yellow Pages. Said Mr. Saban: "Their regional manager comes to my office and says, 'What are you going to do, sue the phone company?' So that's what I did."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SIDNEY

The Boards of Trustees and Governors and the staff of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture mourn the passing of the School's last surviving founder and its long-time friend, Sidney Simon. Sidney and three fellow artists founded the School in 1946. Sidney was a faculty member through the 1950's, served as the Director of the School from 1980-1983, and was an active member of Skowhegan's Board of Governors from 1962 to the present. Sidney's talent, wit, and dedication have helped shape Skowhegan's history. He will be deeply missed by everyone at the Skowhegan School. We send our condolences to his family.

title: A Who Tour, This One To Honor, uh, Whatever
description: It can be an amusing pastime watching classic rock bands that are good but no longer relevant invent new reasons to tour every few years. Pink Floyd likes to offer increasingly grandiose spectacle, which last time out involved blimps, the Empire State Building, a stadium tour and a new album complete with an Internet riddle. The Rolling Stones like to act as if they are a torch that must never be extinguished, and every few years they burn as brightly as they are still able to with a new album, tour and publicity campaign. The surviving members of Led Zeppelin perform their songs acoustically or with new arrangements and pretend they're breaking new ground. But the Who, most likely because of Pete Townshend's need for intellectual justification for his every move, always come up with the most elaborate excuses: farewell tours, silver anniversaries, performances of the rock opera ''Tommy.'' The excuse this time is that until now it has never been able to perform Mr. Townshend's 1973 rock opera, ''Quadrophenia,'' properly.

There is a resemblance to a funhouse in his work, except that his shockers are real and aimed to destroy, not amuse, his opponent.

title: Personal Health
description: MELANOMA, the least common but most feared form of skin cancer, does not just happen out of the blue. Because of changes in fashion and behavior that occurred more than a half-century ago, someone born today is more than 12 times as likely to develop melanoma as someone born in midcentury. The main reason for this explosive growth, as you may have guessed, is overexposure to sunshine. The body parts on which melanomas now develop most often -- the legs and the back, for example -- are those that in years past were covered when people ventured outdoors.

title: A Chance for Stewardship

Mrs. Whitney, the heir to one of America's legendary fortunes, proposes to chop up 15,000 of the most valuable and environmentally sensitive acres into more than 40 ''estates'' around Little Tupper Lake. Since this would threaten an unspoiled wilderness and thwart larger plans to preserve the integrity of the entire Adirondack Park, Gov. George Pataki has made a serious effort to buy the property and add it to the state forest preserve. The talks collapsed about 10 days ago. Then late last week the Nature Conservancy, a private group, stepped in with an offer that has persuaded the Whitney interests to return to the bargaining table.

title: BASF UNIT TO PAY $98 MILLION TO SETTLE SYNTHROID SUIT
description: BASF A.G. of Germany said yesterday that its United States-based Knoll Pharmaceutical unit had agreed to pay $98 million to settle a class action lawsuit by thyroid patients who said the company suppressed a study saying its best-selling Synthroid drug was no better than generic versions. The suit, in United States District Court in San Francisco, accused BASF, Knoll and Knoll's previous owner, the Boots Company, with consumer fraud and misrepresentation. Boots and Knoll contended that the study, by University of California researchers, was flawed. BASF said the settlement was ''in no way an admission of guilt.'' It said the $98 million would go into a fund to pay Synthroid users and their legal costs. Each one who took Synthroid between Jan. 1, 1990, and Aug. 1, 1997, would be eligible for a payment of $19.60.

title: Idea of Apologizing for Slavery Loses Steam, at Least for Now
description: The idea of a national apology to blacks for slavery seemed to fade today as its originator acknowledged that it was unlikely to happen soon, and President Clinton backed away from it -- at least for now.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Creditors' Plan Stirs Concern Over Kia
description: Kia Group creditors said yesterday that they would control the proceeds from recent asset sales, raising concern that banks will stop the South Korean auto manufacturer from pumping cash into its ailing business. Four creditors will set up separate bank accounts to manage an estimated 2.4 trillion won ($2.68 billion) generated from asset sales by Kia, the group's prime creditor, Korea First Bank, said.

title: The Unpredictable Cornucopia Arrives
description: SUMMER finally arrived at 93d Street and Broadway last week. It was the first time this season that tomatoes were spread on the tables of produce at Advent Lutheran Church, the drop-off site of one of New York City's eight Community Supported Agriculture programs, or C.S.A.'s.

title: GEC ALSTHOM WANTS ROLE IN BID FOR WESTINGHOUSE UNITS
description: GEC Alsthom said yesterday that it wanted to join with Framatome Connectors France S.A., a state-controlled nuclear-energy company, to bid for the energy operations of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. GEC Alsthom, an equal joint venture of Alcatel Alsthom S.A. of France and General Electric P.L.C. of Britain, made the statement after the French daily newspaper Liberation said GEC Alsthom and Framatome planned to bid up to $300 million for Westinghouse's power-generation activities and assume nuclear-related legal liabilities and $500 million of debt. Westinghouse, based in Pittsburgh, plans to spin off most of its industrial units this year to focus on broadcasting. It owns CBS Inc. and runs a number of radio and television stations.

title: Electric Cars Get a Big Push In New York
description: In a decision that environmentalists contend will provide a major boost to the nation's tiny market in electric cars, a Federal judge ruled today that New York State can order automobile manufacturers to sell thousands of electrically powered vehicles in the state beginning this fall.

title: In Kitchen Tools, Old Friends Are Best Friends
description: ALICE WATERS can certainly afford the latest in kitchen equipment, but sometimes, she says, the best tool is two pieces of stone.

title: In Straits, Nation's Capital Shifts Power Center
description: Just a couple of hours after President Clinton signed a sweeping Congressional measure today that shifted control of Washington's major city agencies from the Mayor and City Council to the city's financial control board, the board replaced four top department heads and said it would review whether to keep five others.

title: 14 Children in North Carolina Sue a District Over Testing Policy
description: In one of the nation's first court challenges involving the new wave of higher state education standards, 14 students and their parents have sued a North Carolina school district over its policy automatically denying students promotion unless they pass statewide reading and mathematics tests.

title: Stoudamire Postpones Deal
description: DAMON STOUDAMIRE, the Toronto Raptors' point guard who led the team in scoring last year, will wait until after next season to sign a lucrative long-term deal with the team.

title: Love Flaunts Her Conquests In Paris
description: It is a catchy idea, perhaps too catchy for some curators, but why not an art exhibition dedicated to love? And where better to hold it than Paris? After all, theme shows are in vogue in Europe, and nothing has greater popular appeal than love. (All right, sex does, but the Georges Pompidou Center's ''Feminin-Masculin'' covered that more than a year ago.)

title: State Dept. Got Bomb Note, but Doesn't Know Why
description: A copy of a threatening note found last Thursday in the Brooklyn apartment of two men accused of planning bomb attacks had been mailed two days earlier to a Federal program that offers rewards for information on terrorists, State Department and law enforcement officials said last night.

title: Illusions of Nigerian Democracy
description: With the United States and France losing interest in military and political intervention in Africa, local powers are taking their place. South Africa, Uganda and Rwanda, among others, have all plunged into their neighbors' conflicts, with motives ranging from noble to murderous. The prize for hypocrisy, however, must go to Nigeria, which is ostensibly defending democracy in Sierra Leone and Liberia while still crushing it at home.

title: In Bipartisan Show, Clinton Signs 2 Bills
description: In a truce gathering on the South Lawn of the White House with Speaker Newt Gingrich at his side, President Clinton signed bills to balance the budget by 2002 and to cut Federal income taxes for the first time since 1981. Mr. Clinton called the signing a ''true milestone for our nation,'' and it was also one for Republicans and Democrats, who had engaged in two and a half years of partisan struggle over such fiscal issues, leading to the acrimonious Government shutdowns and veto fights of 1995.

title: Labor Backs McGreevey, Pledging Strong Support
description: James E. McGreevey, the Mayor of Woodbridge and a Democratic State Senator, who is attempting to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, won major campaign support today when the New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced it would endorse his candidacy.

title: Sheriff Orders Temporary Retreat from Brooklyn Neighborhood Where Towing Led to Melee
description: In the aftermath of a dispute with a motorist that led to a street disturbance involving thousands of Orthodox Jews, city sheriff's deputies have been temporarily ordered not to tow the cars of ticket scofflaws in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

title: People Soft Names A New Agency
description: People Soft Inc., the software company in Pleasanton, Calif., has named the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising to handle its account, which had been at W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore since April 1995. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. The decision came after a two-month review that included Saatchi & Saatchi San Francisco, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.; Doner, and the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Sales Increase More Than Expected

title: Redemption Plus a World Title In the 400 Meters for Johnson
description: The Superman T-shirt was a bit much. A fan tossed it to Michael Johnson tonight after he won his third world championship in the 400 meters. Not that Johnson had run superhero fast. His winning time, 44.12 seconds, was slowed by a leg cramp that must have felt like Kryptonite and led to a moment of panic.

title: Wait Over, Harnisch A Pitcher Once Again
description: Pete Harnisch bounced around the Mets' clubhouse before last night's game with St. Louis with the enthusiasm of a child on Christmas Eve. His poster-sized smile, his body language -- they screamed that he could not wait to take the mound for the first time since going on the disabled list with depression four months ago. And, naturally, a late-afternoon shower was drenching the field.

title: U.S. Sales at Ford Rose 5.1% In July, Outpacing Estimates
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that its United States sales rose more than expected in July, led by continued gains by its pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.

title: Clarence M. Kelley, Director of F.B.I. in the 70's, Dies at 85
description: Clarence M. Kelley, the square-jawed former police chief who headed the Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1973 to 1978, steering it away from its campaign against Communism, out of its Watergate-era miasma and into a new battle against white-collar and organized crime, died today at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 85.

title: Oxford Founder Resigns Job; Company Posts Large Profits
description: The 40-year-old entrepreneur who built Oxford Health Plans into a $4 billion giant of managed health care in metropolitan New York resigned yesterday as chief executive.

title: An Officer Shoots A Robbery Suspect
description: An off-duty transit officer shot a man who tried to rob him as he was entering an apartment building in Brooklyn early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Checkers Chooses Crispin Porter
description: Checkers Drive-In Restaurants in Clearwater, Fla., has selected Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami to handle the creative and media portions of its account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The creative portion had been handled for seven months by Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising in Los Angeles, while media had been handled by the Western International Media Corporation unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Los Angeles.

title: South Korean Plane Crashes On Guam With 254 on Board
description: A South Korean jumbo jet slogging through a late-night downpour crashed yesterday in the jungle hills a few miles from a runway on Guam after the pilot reported trouble. Most of the 254 passengers were presumed dead, officials on Guam said.

title: Belgrade's Soccer Team Is Above Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: ''It's So Hard to Find a Good Guy to Hate Now'' That the Red Menace Is Back
description: The commies are back!

title: Principal Oxygen System Fails Aboard Calamity-Plagued Mir
description: As a giant Soyuz rocket thundered toward the badly damaged Mir space station, carrying a crew to undertake crucial repairs, the three astronauts aboard Mir struggled tonight with the latest in its seemingly endless string of calamities.

title: Budget Offers Cornucopia of Tax Breaks For Everyone
description: Alongside large tax cuts with mass appeal, like reductions in property taxes and the sales tax on clothing, New York's new state budget is sprinkled with smaller cuts tailored for particular industries, some reflecting the lobbying of particular companies like International Business Machines and the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus.

title: Michael J. Tully Jr., 64, Senator Who Fought for a Smoking Ban
description: Michael J. Tully Jr., a Republican State Senator from Long Island who was instrumental in passing New York's ban on smoking in public buildings, died early yesterday at his home in Flower Hill. He was 64.

title: Firing on Music Videos With a Satiric Pop Gun
description: There they sat: 20-something, cross-legged and jean clad, upon comfortable couches that encircled a coffee table strewn with soda pop, Blow Pops and popcorn. They are the 12 trivia-clogged masterminds behind ''Pop-Up Video,'' VH1's most popular show. And as soon as someone popped Lisa Stanfield's 1997 music video ''Never, Never Gonna Give You Up'' into the VCR, things got a little ugly:

title: New Land Rush: Garth Brooks in the Park
description: Sixty feet above the North Meadow of Central Park, a 100-foot-wide circular array of stage lights hovers like one of the invading spaceships in the movie ''Independence Day.''

title: Mexico Post Nominee Is Short on Credentials
description: To the Editor:

title: MEASURE TO ALLOW EARLY RETIREMENT BY CITY TEACHERS
description: The New York State Legislature has approved a last-minute state budget item permitting thousands of New York City's most experienced teachers to retire early, a measure that runs counter to a legislative initiative announced with fanfare last week -- one that would reduce class size by hiring more teachers.

title: Technology Stocks Buoy Nasdaq Index
description: Technology stocks continued to roll yesterday, with semiconductor issues buoyed by anticipation of strong fourth-quarter demand for personal computers and other microprocessor-based products. But over all, stocks only managed modest gains and the Dow Jones industrial average declined.

title: Alarm Is Merited
description: To the Editor:

title: Safari Skills: How to Get Elephants Drunk
description: MANY tourists won't admit it, but what they really want to see on an African safari isn't just elephants or lions. It's a kill. I almost saw one in Pilanesberg Park last year. But it wasn't a poor kudu or springbok that nearly bit the dust. It was our game ranger, Mark.

title: Beth Israel Unit Acquired
description: A division of Beth Israel Medical Center that helps manage physicians' offices has been acquired by a Florida company that does the same thing on a larger, national scale, the companies have announced.

title: BAA Profits Rose 7.1% in First Quarter
description: BAA P.L.C., the operator of seven British airports, said profit rose 7.1 percent in the first quarter before a one-time charge to pay for Britain's ''windfall'' tax on former state utilities. Net income for the three months ended June 30 rose to $:105 million ($172 million), or 10.1 pence a share, from $:98 million, or 9.5 pence. The figure excluded a $:102 million one-time charge that BAA said it would take to pay the tax, levied by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, last month.

title: Top Freshman Fund-Raiser
description: With the next election more than a year away, United States Representative William J. Pascrell, of Paterson, has raised more money than any of the other 41 freshmen Democratic House members in his first six months in office, the party's Congressional campaign committee said yesterday.

title: Parcells Plays the Teacher, And Douglas Is His Student
description: The Jets tinker with their defense and worry about it and still have a one-man pass rush, with no prospects for significant and immediate improvement.

title: OIL COMPANY'S STOCK LOSES 18% ON RESERVES NEWS
description: A day after it slashed its estimate of its oil and natural gas reserves, Enserch Exploration Inc. was spun off from its parent company and its shares fell 18 percent yesterday, closing at $8. Enserch Exploration, which is based in Dallas, issued a release after the market had closed on Monday that said it expected to cut its reserve estimates by as much as 45 percent. Texas Utilities closed its $1.7 billion acquisition of Enserch Exploration's parent, the Enserch Corporation of Houston, early yesterday, a company spokesman said. Just before the transaction was completed, the corporation spun off its 83 percent stake in Enserch Exploration to shareholders.

title: Grace's Marketplace Adds a Trattoria
description: GRACE DORIA and her husband, Joseph, the owners of Grace's Marketplace, at Third Avenue and 71st Street, have turned a former chiropractor's office next door into a restaurant. On Tuesday, they will open Grace's Trattoria, at 201 East 71st Street, a handsome brick-walled space with a pizza oven and an open kitchen.

title: Eugene Fubini, 84; Helped Jam Nazi Radar
description: Eugene G. Fubini, a physicist and electronics engineer who was active in Allied efforts to hamstring Axis radar operations in Europe in World War II and became an Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died yesterday at his son's home in Brookline, Mass. He was 84 and lived with his son.

title: Horsing Around With Balletic Warhorses
description: The Trocks are looking better than ever. Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, as the lovable all-male ballet company is more formally known, presented a typical program of Russian warhorses of the 19th and early 20th centuries, danced by performers with silly Russianized names, on Tuesday in the opening-night performance of a weeklong season at the Joyce Theater. It was ballet that would probably delight all who miss ballet as it once was. There was nary a modern-dance step or gesture in sight, in dancing filled with the kind of infectious passion and triumph the Bolshoi Ballet once brought to the stage.

title: No Talks, and Very Few Deliveries, in United Parcel Strike
description: The strike by drivers, loaders and sorters at the United Parcel Service slowed the company's business to a near standstill yesterday, and for the second straight day there were no negotiations between management and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Poetic Allusions Floating Into Finity
description: The Bottom Line was filled with worshipers at the altar of the perfect pop song on Thursday night, but Freedy Johnston wasn't pretending to be the man with the answers; for 10 years, he has been bending toward that same altar himself.

title: 4 Hurt by Gas-Main Blast
description: A firefighter and three gas company workers were injured yesterday afternoon and four stores were damaged by smoke after a natural gas main under the Atlantic City Boardwalk leaked and burst into flames, the authorities said.

title: New Tax Law Takes Aim at Estee Lauder
description: In 1995, Wall Street was impressed by the successful initial public offering of the Estee Lauder Companies, a stock that leaped 25 percent in price when it began trading.

title: A Taint That Won't Go Away
description: I AM sure that there is an array of complex psychological explanations for why an increasing number of athletes have taken to carrying weapons. Guns seem to be the new fad, like earrings and tattoos.

title: Canned Tuna: In Search Of Flavor And Texture
description: AS always in the too-hot-to-cook months, this is prime time for canned tuna, that quick, high-protein meal that needs only minimal wrist action to liberate it for eating.

title: Herb Friedwald, 62, Jazz Record Producer
description: Herb Friedwald, a jazz producer, jazz historian and lawyer whose interests ranged from the most traditional New Orleans music to the most abstract free-jazz, died on Thursday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 62 years old.

title: Suspect's Confession Cited As Bombing Trial Opens
description: It was Friday, Feb. 26, 1993, at 12:17 in the afternoon, a Federal prosecutor, Lev L. Dassin, told a jury yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan. ''A light snow had begun to fall in the city,'' he said. ''At the World Trade Center complex here in lower Manhattan, tens of thousands of people went about their business as they did on any other day.''

title: Storms Bring Floods and a Cooler Forecast
description: A brisk stream of cool air blew across the metropolitan region yesterday, bringing scattered hail and thunderstorms that caused flooding in parts of New Jersey and downed power lines in Queens.

title: Focus Is on Diagnosis As Melanoma Rates Soar
description: COULD the incredibly rapid rise in cases of melanoma be caused by an overdiagnosis of malignant lesions that, if left alone, would never grow to threaten life?

title: With Tomatoes, There Is Never Too Much of a Good Thing
description: A friend recently served turkey burgers stuffed with salsa. She made them with bottled salsa and fat-free cheese, and they were very good.

title: In a twist on the consolidation trend, a direct-marketing concern is acquiring a general agency.
description: DRAFT DIRECT WORLDWIDE, a prominent direct marketing agency, is diversifying into the general advertising arena by agreeing to acquire Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners in New York, which specializes in accounts in fields such as financial services, entertainment, fashion and publishing.

title: Macerating Fruit for Cool Desserts
description: THIS is the time of year when the bounty of summer's fruit is matched by the steaminess of summer weather, a combination that makes turning on the oven for a fruit crisp or pie feel like a mistake.

title: Angry Griffin Is Out to Clear His Tainted Title
description: Montell Griffin went to Big Bear, a southern California resort area noted for skiing, fishing and camping, for 10 weeks to train for his title defense against the former champion Roy Jones, Jr.

title: David A. Prager, 84, Protector Of the Architectural Landscape
description: David A. Prager, a lawyer who became an outspoken and forceful advocate for urban architectural preservation and an influential figure in the arts in New York City, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Lawyers wrangle over the move by Ritz-Carlton to strip its imprimatur from four U.S. hotels.
description: ALTHOUGH the Ritz-Carlton name was stripped last weekend from hotels in New York, Washington, Houston and Aspen, Colo., as of yesterday afternoon only the Aspen property appeared resigned to its fate. Its operator answered the telephone: ''Good afternoon, this is Kathy. How may I assist you?'' and when asked if this was the number for the Ritz-Carlton, replied, ''Formerly.'' But operators at the other three properties all answered, ''Thank you for calling the Ritz-Carlton,'' followed by the name of the city.

title: Executives Leave Paging Network
description: The chairman of Paging Network Inc., George Perrin, and the chief executive, Glenn Marschel, resigned today. The company named a former Sprint Corporation executive, Jack Frazee, to their posts.

title: New York Penalizes Agencies That Care For Foster Children
description: After taking little strong action against troubled foster care agencies for nearly a decade, New York City has begun to punish agencies that fail to place foster children into permanent adoptive homes and neglect to file reports documenting the monitoring of foster homes, city officials said yesterday.

title: Pol Pot's Siblings Remember The Polite Boy and the Killer
description: Rocking slowly in his hammock, an old farmer named Saloth Seng remembered the sunny holidays when a much-loved schoolboy dressed all in white came home to this tiny village by the river.

title: Israel Is Urged to Ease Siege of Palestinian Authority
description: Israel came under international pressure today to ease the siege it has imposed on the Palestinian Authority in the six days since a suicide bombing attack reinforced Israeli concerns that the Palestinians have done too little to root out terrorism.

title: Thais Agree to Raise Taxes And Shake Up Finance
description: The Thai Cabinet agreed today to increase taxes and reorganize the nation's financial industry in return for a rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund that would pump as much as $15 billion into the battered economy.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS OFFERS $119 MILLION FOR SANTECH MICRO
description: CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Santech Micro Group A.S.A., a computer distributor in Norway, for $119 million and that Santech's board was recommending that shareholders accept the offer. It said Santech had sales of $610 million in 1996 and has reported sales growth over the last three years at a compounded annual rate of 51 percent. CHS Electronics, based in Miami, is a distributor of microcomputers, peripherals and software products.

title: Ignorance of Judaism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Restaurant May Once Again Fill Delmonico's
description: It is a New York City landmark -- the home of Delmonico's, the restaurant credited with introducing haute cuisine to the United States in the mid-19th century. It was a gathering place for New York society, where visiting dignitaries like Charles Dickens dined on fare like the stuffed lamb dish agneau farci a la Walter Scott. One of its chefs, Charles Ranhofer, was the creator of baked Alaska and lobster Newburg.

title: DII GROUP TO ACQUIRE I.B.M. PLANT FOR $47 MILLION
description: DII Group Inc. said yesterday that its Multilayer Technology Inc. unit had agreed to acquire I.B.M.'s printed-circuit-board plant in Austin, Tex., for $47 million. DII Group, based in Niwot, Colo., supplies electronic manufacturing products and related services. It said the acquisition of the 700,000-square-foot plant was expected to add more than $80 million in revenue and about 15 cents to 20 cents to its presplit per-share earnings next year. It said Multilayer Technology would add the plant's 770 employees to its work force. Shares of DII rose $2.0625, to $57.0625.

title: CEI CITICORP TO SELL STAKE IN ARGENTINE CABLE TV OUTFIT
description: CEI Citicorp Holdings S.A. agreed to sell all its shares in Multicanal S.A., Argentina's largest cable television provider, to Telefonica de Espana S.A. for $239 million. Telefonica agreed to buy the 22.5 percent stake in Multicanal, increasing its holdings to 47.5 percent. CEI Citicorp is 40 percent owned by Citicorp, of New York. The Argentine multimedia group Grupo Clarin holds the remaining 52.5 percent of Multicanal and could exercise its right to buy a portion of the CEI shares. Multicanal, formed in 1991, has about one million subscribers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MID-AMERICA BANCORP, Louisville, Ky., a bank holding company, said it would sell its money order business to Moneygram Payment Systems Inc., of Lakewood, Colo., for about $15 million in cash.

title: On Germany's Mind: Floods, Taxes and Votes
description: The connection between tax reform and menacing floods may not seem all that evident, but in this unsettled, waterlogged German summer, they are linked by an overriding priority -- elections that are not even due for more than a year.

title: Aetna Stock Plunges 12% On Cost News
description: Shares of Aetna tumbled more than 12 percent yesterday after the company, one of the nation's largest managed health care concerns, said that costs were rising faster than premiums, especially in its Medicare health maintenance organizations.

title: Dismissed Manager at Lab Calls Energy Dept. Unfair
description: The ousted manager of the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, Associated Universities Inc., charged yesterday that it had been unfairly blamed by the United States Energy Department for environmental and management problems at the laboratory.

title: Measure Seeks Campus Workfare Jobs, but City Balks
description: Fearing that workfare rules were forcing college students on welfare to drop out of school, the State Legislature adopted legislation this week that sponsors said would require officials to place students in workfare jobs on college campuses so they can continue their studies.

title: Mario Pittoni, 90, Justice for 25 Years In New York State
description: Mario Pittoni, who served for 25 years as a justice of New York State Supreme Court, the first Democrat to be elected to that post on Long Island, died on Sunday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 90 and lived in Lynbrook, N.Y.

title: EQUITY OFFICE TO BUY 13 BUILDINGS AND A PARKING GARAGE
description: Equity Office Properties Trust said it had agreed to buy 13 office buildings, including the headquarters of Texaco Inc.'s production operations, and a parking garage for $284.7 million in cash, securities and assumed debt. The Chicago-based company, headed by the financier Sam Zell, said 11 buildings in the Philadelphia area would be bought for $144.7 million from the Acorn Development Corporation. Two buildings -- the 32-story Texaco Center and a 36-story office tower -- and the garage are in New Orleans and are to be bought for $140 million from Columbus American Properties L.L.C. With these deals, Equity Office will own 103 properties from San Francisco to Boston and 15 parking garages. Its shares were up $1 yesterday, to $30.125.

title: No Shills for the Right
description: To the Editor:

title: The Parties Talk of Reform, And Bring In Record Money
description: For all the talk about campaign finance reform, Republicans and Democrats alike have raised record amounts of money in the first half of 1997, with fund-raisers saying that the financial scandals of the last election are apparently having little effect on the flow of donations.

title: Barbie Pulls Teeth
description: So I think about writing about the Mayor and sex. Then I think, nah.

title: Liberty Topples Under Pressure
description: The steals, the rebounds and the breaks that usually feature the Liberty's relentless play went the way of the Los Angeles Sparks last night as New York fell, 67-50, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Can Cambodia Hold Its Own?
description: As the era of post-colonial wars and superpower rivalry recedes, Southeast Asia is subtly reverting to the balance of power that existed before the arrival of Europeans in the mid-19th century. Cambodia and Laos had been kingdoms that easily could have been subsumed into Vietnam or Thailand. Now, once again, they are weak and beguiling pieces of real estate that Thailand and Vietnam are ready to dominate.

title: A Spicy Take on a Cuban Master
description: Given all the awe-inspiring Cuban bands that have reached New York over the past few years, it stood to reason that downtown jazz musicians would eventually begin exploring the rhythms and the stylistic masters of Afro-Cuban music. The guitarist Marc Ribot looks to be first in line.

title: Police Study Possible Affair In the Shooting Of 2 Officers
description: Detectives trying to untangle the chain of events that led to the shooting late Monday night of two off-duty police officers are focusing on the possibility that the shooting was a murder-suicide attempt that stemmed from a broken love affair, the police said.

title: Another Top Nynex Executive Is Reported Quitting
description: Days before it is expected to win Federal approval of its merger with Bell Atlantic, the Nynex Corporation is losing another top manager, executives at the companies said yesterday.

title: Bicoastal Blading Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: For Brides and Businesses, Thinly Veiled Frustration
description: The walkout against the United Parcel Service forced Norman Toline, the president of Betty Wales Bridal Veils, to use the Long Island Railroad as his own pony express. On his commute home, Mr. Toline personally delivered a headpiece and veil to a bridal salon in Huntington late Monday night. An anxious bride-to-be picked it up yesterday.

title: Hearing on Casino Donations
description: State Senator William L. Gormley, a Democrat from Margate, faced a tough battle in the June primary against an opponent whose campaign contributors included lobbyists and others who do business with Donald J. Trump.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article on Wednesday about the resurgence of Slobodan Milosevic, now President of Yugoslavia, referred incorrectly to the aftermath of the beating of a lawyer who challenged the eviction of a Croatian family from its Belgrade home. The victim, Nikola Barovic, indeed acknowledges that the attack occurred; it was denied by Vojislav Seselj, the Serbian ultranationalist who is the municipal leader in the neighborhood where the eviction order was issued, and whose bodyguard administered the beating.

title: Injustice on Death Row
description: Thomas Thompson, a former boat repairman convicted 14 years ago of the rape and murder of a woman in Laguna Beach, Calif., was scheduled to be killed by a lethal injection of potassium chloride at 12:01 A.M. yesterday. But with less than 36 hours to go, an 11-member Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals panel in San Francisco blocked the execution because it was troubled by the rape conviction. Under California law, it was the alleged rape that made the murder a capital case.

title: President and Allies Hail 'Milestone'
description: With Speaker Newt Gingrich by his side, President Clinton today signed two bills he called a ''true milestone for our nation'' that put into place a plan to balance the Federal budget and to cut taxes for the first time since the Reagan era.

title: Dolphins as Therapy?
description: To the Editor:

title: From His Olympian Heights, Deaf to the Alarm Below
description: Great authors can also be colossal fools. Witness the case of Knut Hamsun, the Nobel Prize-winning Norwegian novelist and starry-eyed nationalist, who was regarded as a god in his homeland until he took up the Nazi cause during World War II.

title: Rangers' Langdon Gets New Contract
description: The Rangers yesterday announced the signing of left wing Darren Langdon to a new contract. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Angry Voices of Pickets Reflect Sense of Concern
description: The pickets signs bobbed like kites in the wind. Clenched-fisted truckers along 79th Street blared horns of solidarity. The striking workers chanted, vowing never to surrender.

title: STAAR SURGICAL GETS F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR LENS TESTS
description: The Staar Surgical Company said yesterday that it had received Food and Drug Administration approval to begin the second phase of clinical trials of its implantable contact lenses to correct nearsightedness. The F.D.A. said the company, of Monrovia, Calif., would be permitted to implant 62 of the lenses. In the first phase of the trials, seven of the 10 patients tested improved their vision to 20/20, or perfect, from being legally blind without glasses. The company already sells the lenses in Europe, South America and the Middle East, as well as South Africa and China. Staar shares rose $1.125, to $14.50.

title: Once More, Lower East Side Is the Focus of Drug Arrests
description: For the fourth time in less than a year, prosecutors and the police have broken up a heroin gang that used murder and violence to stake out its territory on Manhattan's Lower East Side, the authorities said yesterday.

title: High-Tech Travel Gets a Road Test
description: For nine minutes this morning, H. E. Edmonson, last year's runner-up for Houston Metro bus driver of the year, went barreling down a stretch of Interstate 15 here at 45 miles an hour, comfortably ensconced in 20,000 pounds of rolling steel and rubber. His bus sped up and changed lanes to pass, swerved to avoid an orange construction barrel, then slowed to a gentle stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENAUER, RABBI SAM
description: GENAUER-Rabbi Sam. On August 5, 1997. In his 91st year, after a life of goodness, devotion to family and community, and learning and teaching Torah. Beloved husband of Sylvia Genauer. Loving father of Judy and Irv Brickman, Blu and Yitz Greenberg, Rena and Shelly Schlaff. Devoted brother of Ben, Mendel and Jack Genauer and the late Isaac and Zvi Hirsch Genauer. Cherished grandfather of Sandy and Mark, Ellen, Nachy and Helene, Moshe, David and Mindy, Deborah and Jonathan, J.J., Goody and Eric, Lisa and Shira. Adored greatgrandfather of sixteen, esteemed patriarch and uncle of the extended family. Funeral at Riverdale Jewish Center, 3700 Independence Avenue, on Thursday, 9 A.M.

title: An Olympic Fall Lifts Moroccan
description: Hicham el-Guerrouj of Morocco was inconsolable, sobbing at Olympic Stadium in Atlanta last summer after falling in the 1,500-meter final, when a conciliatory call came from his king. At that moment, a layer of his pain and his immaturity was scraped away like paint.

title: Giants' Turnabout: A Winning Practice
description: The Giants did not practice well this morning, and when that two-hour session was over, Coach Jim Fassel gathered his team before him and said: ''That was a 6-10 practice. You keep practicing like that and you'll be 6-10 again.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONAHAN, URBAN
description: MONAHAN-Urban, 72, of New Canaan, Connecticut, a labor relations executive, died August 1. Beloved husband of Mary Keenon Hannon, father of Mari, Michael, Kathleen, John and Edmund, and brother of Mary and Dorothy. A funeral mass was held yesterday at St. Augustine's Church in Larchmont, New York.

title: Deficit to Drop To $37 Billion, President Says
description: A day after signing laws to balance the Federal budget and cut taxes, President Clinton announced today that the Federal deficit was expected to drop to $37 billion this year, its lowest level in 23 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EIDELMAN WACHS, DR. BARBARA
description: EIDELMAN WACHS-Dr. Barbara. We express our deepest sympathy on the untimely passing of Dr. Barbara Eidelman Wachs in Israel while attempting to rescue a drowning child. Dr. Wachs was a source of great pride to her family and will be sorely missed. We extend sincerest condolences to her husband, Saul, children, parents, brothers and their families, Aaron and Sherry Eidelman, supporters of Shaare Zedek medical Center and Prof. Arthur Eidelman, Director of the Neonatology Department at Shaare Zedek Medical Center and his wife Arleen. May the family be comforted amongst the the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may her memory be a blessing. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Menno Ratzker, President

title: New York Judge Rejects Death Penalty Plea Deal
description: The defendant in the first death penalty case brought by a New York City prosecutor since the state reimposed capital punishment has agreed to plead guilty to murder and serve at least 50 years in prison. But a judge has rejected the deal, saying that the plea bargain provisions of the state's death penalty law are unconstitutional.

description: In many ways, the strike against the United Parcel Service is the fight that Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president who began as a U.P.S. deliveryman in Queens, has been preparing for in his three decades as a union leader.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference at the White House
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference today on the South Lawn of the White House, from a transcript provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: NORTHERN TELECOM WINS GERMAN WIRELESS CONTRACT
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. yesterday beat out European rivals to win a contract valued at as much as $290 million from Viag Interkom, a joint venture between Viag A.G. of Germany, British Telecommunications P.L.C. and Norway's Telenor, to supply wireless networking equipment for a new system being built in Germany. Northern Telecom said the agreement would involve the sale of its radio base station and mobile switching products. The contract represented the Toronto-based company's first wireless deal in Germany.

title: Silver Charm's Owners Land $1 Million Horse at Saratoga Auction
description: For the first time in seven years, a yearling commanded a purchase price of $1 million at the opening session of the annual Saratoga horse auction as the sales market continued its upswing from the steep decline of the early 1990's.

title: Interpublic Buys Into Talent Agency
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that it had acquired a majority interest in Addis-Wechsler & Associates, a talent management and production company in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paul W. Williams, 94, U.S. Attorney, Is Dead
description: Paul W. Williams, who served as a United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York in the 1950's and also as a Special Assistant Attorney General of New York, died on Monday at his home in North Plain Beach, Fla. He was 94.

title: A Sequel Too Far
description: The movie ''Air Force One'' has been so successful in its first two weeks -- No. 1 at the box office, $81 million in ticket sales -- that a sequel is already in the works. Which means, of course, that a contraband script has already surfaced. Below are exclusive excerpts from the screenplay of ''Air Force Two.''

title: Though many investors find that the new tax law helps, some strategies will quietly lose out.
description: INVESTORS are broadly viewed as winning with the new tax law. They get lower capital gains taxes and a variety of savings plans that can let them defer or even escape taxes on some retirement accounts.

title: For Pettitte, Texas Hex Lives On
description: Andy Pettitte enjoys pitching at the Ballpark in Arlington as much as he likes undergoing root-canal surgery. Even if Pettitte had pitched here only twice in two and a half seasons, it had been incredibly painful. It hurts if it happens even once a year.

title: NATO Expansion Forces Russia to Reform
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: CARR-GOTTSTEIN HAS LOSS AFTER CHARGE TO CLOSE UNITS
description: The Carr-Gottstein Foods Company took a charge to close two businesses, resulting in a second-quarter loss. The company, Alaska's largest food and drug retailer, said yesterday that it had closed its Yes Foods institutional food-service operation and discontinued wholesale services to a Russian exporter. Before the charge, it had profit for the quarter of $200,000, or 2 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $400,000, or 5 cents, a year earlier. After the pretax charge of $8.9 million, or 66 cents after taxes, it had a loss of $5.1 million, or 64 cents. Sales dropped 5.6 percent, to $152 million from $161 million. Shares of the Anchorage-based company fell 18.75 cents, to $5.

title: 4 Intertwined Lives, Shattered by Bombing
description: The fruit stand that wrapped around the corner of Chaim Street and Apple Alley in Jerusalem's bustling produce market was a family venture, watched over by two Jewish brothers, their brother-in-law and the Arab worker who helped shift around the crates of whatever was in season. When two suicide bombers detonated their briefcases seven days ago among the jostling shoppers, the four men were standing in a rough line outside the stall.

title: SUNSTONE AGREES TO ACQUIRE KAHLER REALTY
description: Sunstone Hotel Investors Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Kahler Realty Corporation from affiliates of Westbrook Partners L.L.C. for $322 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. Kahler Realty, based in Rochester, Minn., owns and operates 17 hotels. Its 4,255 rooms are mainly in Utah, Idaho, Montana, Arizona and Minnesota. Sunstone, of San Clemente, Calif., is a real estate investment trust. Upon completion of the deal, expected late this year, Westbrook Partners, a real estate investment fund, will own up to 13 percent of Sunstone. The purchase price includes $95 million in cash; $57 million in stock, and assumed debt of $170 million.

title: A Don Juan, but Maybe Not for Long
description: To paraphrase the medieval bard, sumer is igoing out, lhude sing whoopee.

title: The Commotion Over Clap Skates
description: At the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, constant clapping is guaranteed when the speed skaters take to the ice. But the fans will be responsible for only some of the noise. The rest is bound to come from the athletes' controversial new equipment.

title: Housing Authority Seized
description: At the request of Mayor Milton Milan, the Federal Government plans to take control of Camden's problem-plagued housing authority for one year, officials said yesterday.

title: Giuliani Rival Proposes Force To Fight Crimes by Teen-Agers
description: In a bristling attack on the Giuliani administration's record on youth violence, Sal F. Albanese outlined a plan yesterday to develop a unit within the New York Police Department that would deal specifically with violent crimes that teen-agers commit against one another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, MAXINE COOLEY
description: MONTGOMERY-Maxine Cooley. On July 29 at Silver Spring, MD. Wife of Royal M. Montgomery, M.D. Fifty years resident of Forest Hills, NY. Also survived by three children, twelve grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARB, JACOB S., M.D.
description: BARB-Jacob S., M.D. on August 6, 1997. Columbia College Class of 1928, Columbia P&S 1931. Beloved husband of Bernice (Bunny). Devoted father of Madeleine Haley. Dear brother of Dr. Julius Barb and Dorothy Budd. Shiva at home. Contributions may be made to Columbia P&S, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, New York City or the Visiting Nurse Service.

title: Fortuitous Ad Hails On-the-Scene Mayor
description: Radio listeners who woke up yesterday to a news report about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani at an early-morning building collapse in Brooklyn heard something extraordinary a few seconds later: a political advertisement by the Mayor's campaign boasting that he is always there at a building collapse.

title: Sergeant Is Dismissed For Handling of Call
description: A veteran New York City police sergeant has been dismissed for mishandling an emergency call from a woman who later was killed by her ex-boyfriend, a transit police officer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. August 7, 1986-1997 Eleven years today. The warmth of his laughter... generous deeds... integrity... kind and loving ways... and ''the memories linger on''. Children, grandchildren and Joyce

title: Woman Calling 911 Is Killed
description: A cocktail waitress at Harrah's Marina Casino Hotel in Atlantic City was shot to death by her former boyfriend yesterday while she was calling 911 from the employee parking lot, the authorities said. The woman, Peggy Selvaggio of West Berlin, called the police at 3:58 A.M., saying that her estranged lover, Donald Burris, 45, of Voorhees, had accosted her, said the Atlantic County Prosecutor, Jeffrey S. Blitz.

title: Whitman Forms Panel to Expedite Death Penalty Cases
description: No one has been executed in New Jersey since the state reinstated the death penalty 15 years ago today, which Gov. Christine Todd Whitman noted as she announced that she would set up a 15-member commission to recommend how to speed death penalty cases through the court system.

title: Dance Event Benefits An Emergency Fund
description: The Emergency Fund for Student Dancers is to present a program of new and repertory dance tonight through Saturday at 9 P.M. at the Cunningham Dance Studio, 55 Bethune Street, in the West Village.

title: True Believers Seem Resigned To Alliance
description: This year's Boston Macworld Exhibition is running true to form: a cacophonous mix of sideshow hucksterism, computer geek convocation and religious revival.

title: Teamsters and U.P.S. Agree to Resume Talks
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the United Parcel Service have agreed to resume talks today in an effort to end the three-day-old walkout by 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters, Federal mediators announced yesterday.

title: Showing Girls The Virtue Of Abstinence
description: AT the first meeting of the Snyder High School abstinence group in almost three weeks, Leslie Morris is quickly finding out what a long, dangerous time has elapsed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARKEY, ELIZABETH
description: SHARKEY-Elizabeth. We mourn with our dear friends Barbara and Allan on the loss of their beloved Elizabeth, affectionately known to us as ''Lizbo''. We will always remember her sweetness and beauty. Gary, Lynn, Robert, Amy, Andrew, Michael

title: Cabletron's Chief Executive Plans to Step Down Sept. 1
description: Cabletron Systems Inc., a computer networking company, said yesterday that S. Robert Levine, its president, chief executive and co-founder, would resign effective Sept. 1. He will be succeeded by Donald B. Reed, 53, whose departure as president and group executive for external affairs at the Nynex Corporation was expected.

title: Microsoft Comes to the Aid of a Struggling Apple
description: In a stunning alliance that could alter the map of the computer industry and help insure the survival of Apple Computer Inc., the company announced a financial and business partnership today with its archrival, the Microsoft Corporation.

title: WORRIES OVER BILL BLASS LICENSE HURT DESIGNER HOLDINGS
description: The stock of Designer Holdings Ltd. fell 19 percent yesterday after the sportswear manufacturer said restructuring measures and the possible failure to renew its Bill Blass jeanswear license could cut its second-half earnings by 56 cents a share. Designer Holdings of New York, which also sells apparel under the Calvin Klein label, said it was negotiating renewal of the Blass license, which expires at the end of 1997. It reported that second-quarter net income rose 64 percent, to $3.6 million, or 11 cents a share, but forecast that operating profit for the full year would be about half of analysts' current estimates of 90 cents to 95 cents. The restructuring measures will be taken to offset sluggish sales, which slowed to $104.3 million in the latest quarter from $104.9 million in the period a year earlier. Shares of Designer Holdings fell $1.4375 yesterday, to $5.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIFT, ISABEL
description: SWIFT-Isabel, of Manhattan, died on July 24. A memorial mass will be held at St. Monica's Church at 413 E. 79th St., August 9 at 10 am.

title: Growing A Pie In the Sky
description: JAY HERMAN made his fortune on Wall Street as a floor trader for the Commodity Exchange and then retired to his farm -- a garden in the sky in midtown Manhattan.

title: A Workers' Rebellion
description: It is more a rebellion than a strike. The walkout by 185,000 drivers, loaders and sorters of the United Parcel Service is best seen as the angry, fist-waving response of the frustrated American worker, a revolt against the ruthless treatment of workers by so many powerful corporations.

title: Head of U S West's Cable Unit Resigns Abruptly
description: Amos B. Hostetter, one of the cable industry's most respected executives, resigned abruptly yesterday after U S West Inc. announced plans to move his company's headquarters to Denver from Boston.

title: No Headline
description: ''We want to let go of this notion that for Apple to win, Microsoft has to lose. We better treat Microsoft with a little gratitude.''

title: Truancy in Newark Is Down
description: When state officials seized control of Newark's school system in 1995, chronic truancy was one of the most daunting problems. But the number of truants dropped by 38 percent last year, a change the officials attribute to new programs and incentives to keep children in school.

title: Bankers Trust to Sell Site
description: Boston Properties, a real estate investment trust, has agreed to buy the Bankers Trust Building in Manhattan for $320 million, according to brokers familiar with the deal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Amex Halts Trading in Shares of Equisure, a Reinsurer
description: Equisure Inc., a reinsurance company whose shares have more than doubled since they were listed on the American Stock Exchange last December, has had trading halted amid an investigation by the exchange into both its accounting and the trading in its stock.

title: A Strong Mideast Message
description: Madeleine Albright has been too little engaged with the Middle East since becoming Secretary of State, clearly fearing entanglement with the slow, frustrating and recently unraveling peace effort. But Ms. Albright overcame her hesitations yesterday, delivering a blunt assessment of Israeli and Palestinian conduct and declaring her intention to push both parties hard to resume and then accelerate negotiations. President Clinton pointedly endorsed her comments at his news conference. Later this month Ms. Albright will most likely make her first trip to the region as Secretary of State.

title: Clinton Isn't Selling Out
description: To the Editor:

title: For Tuscans, How Can You Copyright Paradise?
description: The ocher hills, patchwork vineyards and olive groves of Tuscany, lorded over by medieval towns and elegant villas shielded by clumps of pine, are probably among the most familiar of the world's backdrops, used to felicitous effect in Renaissance paintings, 19th-century novels and innumerable Italian movies.

title: SULLIVAN BROADCASTING TO BUY TV STATION FOR $60 MILLION
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. agreed yesterday to sell KOKH-TV, an Oklahoma City station, to Sullivan Broadcasting for $60 million in cash, eliminating an obstacle to its planned $630 million acquisition of the Heritage Media Corporation's television and radio stations. Sinclair said last month that it planned to buy the stations from the News Corporation, which agreed to acquire Heritage in March for $1.35 billion and then sell the stations, keeping the company's supermarket coupon and promotion operation. The KOKH-TV sale was conditioned on the News Corporation's acquisition of Heritage.

title: 2,001 Degrees of Security
description: No one, it seems, wants to talk about Stanley Kubrick's forthcoming film, ''Eyes Wide Shut.'' Not Warner Brothers, which is producing it. Not Nicole Kidman and Tom Cruise, who are starring in it. And not the security guard at Pinewood Studios outside London, where ''Eyes Wide Shut'' finally wrapped on Tuesday. ''I've been instructed not to let you in,'' he said curtly to a reporter and a photographer the other day, flatly refusing to say anything about anything. (''My name is I'm a Security Officer.'')

title: Hartford Children's Agency To Be Run by a Harsh Critic
description: The head of the state's troubled Department of Children and Families resigned today, and was immediately replaced by one of the department's harshest critics.

title: Cadbury Reports A 25% Rise in Earnings
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British candy and beverage maker, said net income before a one-time gain rose 25 percent in the first six months as Dr Pepper continued to post strong United States sales and interest charges fell. Net income, before a one-time gain from the sale of its 51 percent stake in the Coca-Cola and Schweppes Beverage Ltd. bottling venture, rose to $:150 million ($244 million), from $:120 million a year ago. Earnings per share rose to 14.9 pence from 12.1 pence. Analysts had expected 14.6 pence, on average.

title: Herders Routing Geese On Links
description: ''WAY to me!'' Jim Weyland, the superintendent of the Shorehaven Golf Club in East Norwalk, Conn., said firmly to his border collie, Skip, as they rode on a golf cart toward a pond on the course. That command sent the black and white dog racing off the cart and after a gaggle of 20 Canada geese near the 18th fairway.

title: Like It or Not, It's Tennis. So, Cheer On!
description: THOSE impudent geezers, Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe, are up at Manhattanville College this week, just north of New York City, doing their 35-and-over thing, with Bjorn Borg and some of the men who routinely chased the former headliners around the world. It's classic sports, live on stage, though not quite looking and sounding as slickly produced as the genuine golden oldies.

title: A Movie at $6.75? Not in This Town
description: To the Editor:

title: The new tax law encourages savings, but there's a catch.
description: AMONG other virtues, the new Federal tax package is supposed to stimulate savings by encouraging families to set aside more for retirement, college and first-time house purchases. And according to some experts, the incentives could make a real difference. ''The data are pretty persuasive,'' argued Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: PG&E Will Buy 18 Power Plants In New England
description: The PG&E Corporation announced yesterday that it would buy 18 fossil-fuel and hydroelectric power plants from New England Electric System for $1.59 billion in the first major sale of a utility company's generating operations as the industry undergoes sweeping changes.

title: Dickson Concepts In Two Long-Term Deals
description: Dickson Concepts International Ltd. said it had entered into a 10-year agreement with Marks & Spencer P.L.C., giving it exclusive rights to operate Brooks Brothers stores in Southeast Asia. Dickson also said it had entered into a long-term deal with Coach, a division of the Sara Lee Corporation that makes shoes, purses and other leather goods, to distribute its products in Southeast Asia.

title: Corrections
description: American Stock Exchange tables from The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday misstated the change on Tuesday in the shares of IMH Commercial Holdings Inc. The price was unchanged, at 177/16, after the shares' first day of trading; it did not fall 85/16.

title: Fehr Urges a Slowdown on Realignment
description: Baseball owners are working on a plan that would radically realign the major leagues, but the players are not ready to obliterate the centurylong existence of the National and American Leagues.

description: Managers who beg for patience often liken baseball seasons to a marathon. If that's so, then the Mets are on about Mile 18 right now and they're gradually falling out of the lead pack.

description: David Benoit signed a one-year, $600,000 deal with the Nets yesterday, giving the 6-foot-8-inch small forward another chance to implement a plan that fell through last October when an injury in training camp ended his season.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on July 23 described historical research on papers detailing a 1940 Nazi plan to finance a propaganda campaign in the United States. The article, headlined ''How Nazis Tried to Steer U.S. Politics,'' appeared with a photograph of Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican of New York, who was chairman of the National Committee to Keep America Out of Foreign Wars.

title: So a Sound Unheard Can Still Be Sensed
description: HEARING loss frequently creeps up on people, especially as they age. In addition to the increasing frustration and isolation of half-missed conversations, many of the mechanics of living become difficult as well: how to tell if the doorbell is ringing, especially since the higher frequencies are often the first to go. Or for that matter, how to be forewarned of a fire if the smoke alarm screams in solitude.

title: 3-Day Slide In Treasury Prices Ended
description: The Treasury market ended a three-day slide yesterday as the Government's quarterly debt refunding proceeded without stumbling and the latest business survey by the Federal Reserve showed the economy growing but with few traces of inflation.

description: MIFFLIN-John W. Died August 5, 1997 in Cincinnati, OH at age 79. Grandfather of Jacqueline and uncle of Lawrence, Eileen and David. A loyal friend and wise counselor. title: Man Is Killed When a Sting Goes Awry
description: Federal agents and suspected drug dealers exchanged gunfire yesterday afternoon in the parking lot of a McDonald's, in what investigators described as a sting operation gone awry on a busy Manhattan street. When the shooting was over, a Federal agent had been injured and the suspect who had shot him was dead, officials said.

Lidback, Geoffrey Gardner and Pamela Spano; devoted grandmother of Kathryn and Rebecca Gardner and Marion Devlin; great grandmother of Nicholas & Kevin Devlin.
