For information call the Howard E. Williams, Inc. Funeral Home, Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Irabu's Return Is Not Yet Set
description: Even before Hideki Irabu uncorked his first pitch for Class AAA Columbus tonight, Joe Torre said the Japanese pitcher would probably not be promoted to the Yankees to start against Minnesota on Sunday.

title: Slum Decor Is Costly
description: WHAT does it cost to recreate the look of a Los Angeles slum apartment? For ''Nothing to Lose,'' one of this summer's comedies, decking out the living room inhabited by Martin Lawrence, his movie wife, children and mother cost $9,000 for one week, enough to rent a full apartment in some neighborhoods for two years.

title: Bridge
description: Since the dawn of the game seven decades ago, American bridge players, unlike the tennis and golfing worlds, have kept foreign invaders at bay. For a time, they kept them at bay by refusing to allow them to compete. But that all ended Sunday, when four Polish stars, Adam Zmudzinski, Marek Szymanowski, Marcin Lesniewski and Cezary Balicki, won the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Bomb Plot Investigators Are Puzzled by New View of Suspects
description: In the weeks before they were shot and captured in a predawn police raid in Brooklyn, the two men accused of plotting suicide bombings in the city's subways seemed interested only in chasing women and fast-buck schemes, people who encountered them say, and not in becoming martyrs for Islam.

title: U.S. SHIFTS STAND ON MIDEAST TALKS, TO ISRAELI PLAN
description: The Clinton Administration today announced a shift in the American strategy toward the Middle East, in which it will press Israel and the Palestinians to negotiate much more quickly on the shape of a final peace settlement in an effort to restore the confidence lost in bitter disputes over interim measures.

title: Apple's Worst Enemy No More
description: Formerly a contender, but lately on the ropes, Apple Computer Inc. had to do something to reassure customers and investors alike that things are improving for the personal computer pioneer. The big push came yesterday as Steven P. Jobs, once and future chairman, announced an almost entirely new board of directors and a strategic $150 million investment by Microsoft. While this is good news for Apple, the details of what happened and their long-term implications are far from clear.

title: Easy Illegal U.S. Entry in Northwest
description: The first time Ghazi Ibrahim Abu Maizar crossed the world's longest undefended border, he followed a typical pattern for illegal entrants at the far western edge of the boundary. He hiked into the Cascade Mountain woods from Canada last year and simply walked into the United States.

title: KPMG Venture With Microsoft
description: KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. plans today to announce the formation of a 500-member consulting group dedicated to the Microsoft Windows NT operating system and business-oriented applications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ROBERT
description: SMITH-Robert, of Lenox, MA., died on a fishing trip in Coburn Gore, Maine on August 4, 1997 at the age of 91. Distinguished author of fiction and non-fiction. Beloved husband of Jean (nee Kelly) Smith, father of Anvil, Pam, Bob and Nora, father-in-law of Deejay and Dian, grandfather of Ben, Emlen and Rosie. A memorial service will be held at the Roche Funeral Home, 120 Main Street, Lenox, MA., 10 A.M. on Saturday, August 9. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the Robert Smith Memorial Scholarship Fund, 17 West Street, Lenox, MA. 01240.

title: Hilton Hotels Increases Its Offer For ITT to $70 a Share From $55
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation renewed its attempted hostile takeover of the ITT Corporation yesterday, increasing its offer to $70 a share from $55.

title: Invasion of Cuba Revisited
description: In tonight's brisk account, the failed 1961 invasion of Cuba by an anti-Castro force of Cubans recruited, trained and equipped by the Central Intelligence Agency is variously called a defeat, a fiasco, a tragedy, but no one argues that it was a glorious episode of American statecraft.

title: Serbia's Last Ally in the Yugoslav Breakup Is Restive
description: From the secluded medieval fort of St. Stefan on the Adriatic Sea to the mountainous ancient capital of Cetinje, Montenegro was once independent. Annexed by Serbia in 1918, it went on to become an aquatic playground for the rich and famous, attracting valuable foreign currency to Tito's Yugoslavia.

title: Airline's List Of Survivors
description: Following is a list of survivors of Korean Air Flight 801, which crashed at Agana, Guam, on Tuesday. The list, including nationality, was compiled by the airline.

title: For Foss, Probably 75, Definitely a Celebration
description: Lukas Foss has spent the last eight months conducting, playing the piano and listening to performances of his own works at concerts celebrating his 75th birthday, and as the actual date approaches -- Aug. 15 -- he has been preparing for a pair of concerts at Tanglewood, where he was a student in the early 1940's.

title: Families Go to Guam To Claim Their Dead
description: Grieving family members rushed to Guam to claim the remains of relatives killed in the Korean Air crash early Wednesday that left 225 people dead.

description: SPIEWAK-Shirley (nee Bell), 67, Monroe Township, NJ (form. of Valley Stream), August 6, 1997. Wife of Gerald, mother of Alan, Michael, and Rosanne Ebner. Sister of Herman Bell. Grandmother of 7. Funeral Friday 11:15AM, Mt. Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, New Jersey. Burial Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. Memorial gifts to the American Cancer Society.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC., Palm Beach, Fla., a discount brokerage firm, acquired Financial Systemware Inc., Jersey City, a maker of stock-trading software, for undisclosed terms.

title: Major Indexes Reach Highs, With Dow Soaring 71.77
description: Wall Street's major stock market indexes reached new highs yesterday, as investors sought to participate in the continuing price climb despite a recent jump in interest rates.

title: U.S. Women's Team Selected
description: Connecticut, Stanford and Georgia placed two players each yesterday on the women's basketball team that will represent the United States in the World University Games Aug. 21 to Aug. 29 in Palermo, Italy.

title: Words Fly As Division Becomes Ever Wider
description: Even as Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan arrived here to appeal for renewed Israeli-Palestinian cooperation, verbal exchanges between the two sides turned as confrontational today as at any time since the Palestinian uprising ended four years ago.

description: BASEBALL

title: Jobs's Team And Name Are on the Line
description: Little more than a week ago, as Steven P. Jobs was becoming more and more involved in running Apple Computer Inc., the Silicon Valley rumor mill had him ready to step in as chairman and chief executive of the company he had co-founded.

title: Greenspan Opposes Accounting Change on Derivatives
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has come out against proposed new accounting rules that would change the way companies account for derivatives and possibly discourage some from using them.

title: TRANSACTIONS

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

description: ROSENWASSER - SCHALL - Han nah (nee Taub), of Yonkers, New York, suddenly on August 5, 1997. Devoted mother of Caryl (Leo Meltzer), Nancy (Howard Levine) and Franklin Schall (Susan Ecker). Cherished grandmother of Steven, Alan, Allan, Harold (Michal), Richard, Gary, Laura (Tom). Caring great-grandmother of Dana and Todd. Services Friday, August 8, 10AM, Temple Emanuel, Rumsey Road and Parkway, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Temple Emanuel, Yonkers, would be appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: One year after a suffering a debilitating stroke, MEL TORME is getting stronger and wants to sing again.

title: Gannett Chain Strengthens Its Presence In New Jersey by Buying 2 Newspapers
description: The Gannett Company, the nation's largest newspaper company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy The Asbury Park Press and The Home News and Tribune of East Brunswick, putting the media chain in a position to dominate the southern two-thirds of New Jersey and turning central New Jersey into a battleground with The Star-Ledger of Newark, the state's largest daily.

title: Safir Plans to Add 400 Detectives To Narcotics Units
description: Saying that he does not want political battles with Albany to hobble the city's fight against crime, Police Commissioner Howard Safir indicated yesterday that he would add 400 new narcotics detectives in the coming months, including 120 drug investigators who were transferred to patrol duty last fall during a dispute with the State Legislature and the detectives' union.

title: Horace Bristol, 88; Depicted War and Poverty
description: Horace Bristol, a giant of photo-journalism, a man whose images of Depression-era despair in the United States, wartime heroism in the Pacific and postwar poverty and hope in rural Korea have been ranked with the great pictures of the century, died on Monday at a hospital in Ojai, Calif. A resident of Ojai, a small town south of Santa Barbara, he was 88.

title: Executive Changes
description: MERRILL LYNCH & CO., New York, promoted Peter Hoffman and Phil Jones, managing directors, to head the group that arranges sales of convertible securities and derivatives for corporate clients. They will lead Merrill's equity-linked origination group, succeeding Lee Cole, who left last month to help rival Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. build its convertibles business.

title: Fewer Youths Report Smoking Marijuana
description: Marijuana use by younger teen-agers declined slightly last year for the first time in five years, but overall use of illegal drugs showed no change, according to an annual Government survey released today.

title: Hospital Giant, Under Attack, Sets Shake-Up
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, responding to a wide-ranging criminal investigation, plans to drastically alter or abandon many of the business practices that helped make it the world's largest health care company and a leading advocate of medical care for profit.

title: Debt
description: * City of Austin, Tex., is selling $226.9 million of tax-exempt combined utility systems revenue refunding bonds through Smith Barney. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.43 percent for an issue due in 2020. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yield ranges from 4.10 percent in 1999 to 5.40 percent in 2017. The bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

title: Police Lieutenant Charged With Mail Fraud
description: Three years ago Lieut. Charles Luisi Jr. of the New York Police Department reported a burglary at his home in Pound Ridge and collected $26,700 from his insurance company for stolen items, including his wife's diamond ring.

title: Mayor Assails Bill for Easing Retirement Of Teachers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday criticized a bill passed in the last moments of the Albany legislative session that would permit thousands of New York City teachers to retire early, saying it was a gift to those teachers that provided no benefit to the public school system.

title: Disney Hall and Gehry in Deal
description: THE true princess in the extended family of Disney princesses may be Diane Disney Miller, a daughter of Walt and Lillian -- although she is a Cinderella in reverse. Years ago she cast off her glass slippers and Hollywood for the earthier pursuits of the annual crush in Napa Valley: she and her husband, Ronald Miller, a former president of Walt Disney Productions, own and run Silverado Vineyard, where they live in a modest 1906 Craftsman bungalow. ''It's a typical little house that was brown when we got it, and we painted it off-white,'' she said. ''This year, I discovered dahlias and filled the garden. I love living here. All around, it's just country.''

title: Garth At a Glance
description: Garth Brooks will be appearing tonight in a free concert in Central Park that will be simultaneously broadcast on HBO. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office estimates that 300,000 people are likely to attend the event. Other artists who have given similar performances in the park include Placido Domingo, Paul Simon, Barbra Streisand, Simon and Garfunkel, Elton John, Luciano Pavarotti and Diana Ross.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, PAUL V.
description: FARRELL-Paul V., at age 81 on August 6th. A resident of Barre, MA., and formerly of Oceanside, NY. He was predeceased by his wife, Maude Whitbread Farrell. He is survived by his wife, Theodora Cogley Farrell; his children: Barbara McTiernan, Paul, Mary, Rita and Peter Farrell; his sons and daughters-in-law Charles E. McTiernan, Jr., Denise Rinaldo, Michael Broad and Gene Harkless, and eight grandchildren. He also leaves five stepchildren and many other relatives and friends who loved and cherished him. During World War II, he served in the U.S. 3rd Army in England, France and Germany. After the War, he became a busines journalist. He was Editor of Purchasing magazine until 1968 and was associated with the National Association of Purchasing Management until his retirement in 1980. He served on the Boards of Directors of Commonweal magazine and of the Oceanside Free Public Library. He will always be remembered for his vast knowledge, his loyalty to friends and family, and his keen sense of humor. Friends may call at Macken's Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, NY Friday, 2 to 4 PM and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Martyr Church, Long Beach, NY, Saturday, Aug 9, 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Commonweal Endowment, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, N.Y. 10115.

title: Woman Shot to Death While Dialing for Help
description: A cocktail waitress at Harrah's Marina Casino Hotel was shot to death by her former boyfriend yesterday while she was calling 911 from the employee parking lot, the authorities said.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BUILDING COLLAPSE -- A five-story apartment building in Brooklyn collapsed, raining tons of debris into the street. B3.

title: For Relatives Of Victims, Anger Adds To Anguish
description: In homes and offices, in taxis and restaurants, South Korea stopped today, riveted by the news that more than 200 people -- many of them young couples on romantic getaways -- had been killed in the crash of a Korean Air jetliner in Guam this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, DR. ROBERT LEWIS
description: BECKER-Dr. Robert Lewis, 79, died on August 4th, 1997. Loving husband of Naomi Lynn Becker and father of Jane Becker and Caryn Faure Walker, and brother of Beth Becker Pollock. Private Graveside service, Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, New York. The family may be reached at the home in Hendersonville, N.C., at area code 704-696-8736, address 170 Ridgeview Drive, Hendersonville, N.C. 28739. In place of flowers charitable donations may be made to the National Kidney Foundation, Western North Carolina Chapter, 2 McDowell Street, Asheville, N.C. 28801.

title: Terrorism, at a Fruit Stand
description: Last week's suicide bombings bound Jews and Arabs together at a bustling fruit stand, but not enough to bridge the vast differences in their politics and status. Page A6.

title: Tobacco Lawyers' Papers Are Made Public
description: A state judge here today released decades of secret tobacco industry documents that reflect discussions among cigarette company lawyers to suppress scientific research, potentially destroy documents and mislead the public about the health effects of smoking.

title: Congress Cuts $8.3 Million for Governors Island Maintenance
description: The fate of Governors Island has become more unsettled because of little-known Federal budget provisions that eliminate funds to maintain the island and to keep its 19th century village from crumbling.

title: Computer Industry In the Apple Camp
description: If Apple Computer fails now, it won't be from lack of industry support.

title: CHRONICLE
description: On Sunday afternoon, Mr. Corman will redeem himself by attending a book party. This party, a luncheon, will also be given by Ms. Sherr, but this time with Catherine O'Neill at the Sag Harbor home of Ms. O'Neill and her husband, Richard Reeves. It will honor PATRICIA O'BRIEN for her third novel, ''Good Intentions''(Simon & Schuster).

title: Behind the Teamsters Strike
description: To listen to the teamsters' union, its strike of United Parcel Service, idling 185,000 workers, is a battle on behalf of part-time workers who have been shoved into ''throwaway'' jobs not only at U.P.S. but all across the country. To listen to U.P.S., its part-time workers are a business necessity that allow it to compete against non-union rivals. Outsiders to this struggle may want to root for the union both on the merits of its position and because organized labor can ill afford another conspicuous defeat. But what is right for part-time workers at U.P.S. says little about what is right anywhere else.

title: Railroad Tunnel Is Criticized
description: An official of the Federal Railroad Administration has drawn the wrath of New Jersey transportation officials for publicly criticizing a plan that would create a new railroad crossing in Atlantic City as part of a proposed $330 million tunnel project.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WERFEL, ZACHARYA
description: WERFEL-Zacharya. Forty years since your passing. Always remembered with love and respect. Each day brings us closer to thee. Velvil

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINKMANN, ANNA K. (NEE ALBUS)
description: BRINKMANN-Anna K. (nee Albus). Co-founder and long-time treasurer of Brinkmann Instruments, Inc. died in Delray Beach, Florida on August 5, 1997 after a prolonged illness. Born in Mannheim, Germany in 1907, she emigrated to the United States in 1939. A loyal and devoted wife and mother, she was admired for her personal integrity as well as her cooking skills and business acumen. Her daughter, Ruth, died earlier this year and she is survived by her son, Klaus, and daughter, Karin, both of Manhattan, seven grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren.

title: After Microsoft, Apple Computer plans a second reunion, with an ally from '1984' fame.
description: FIRST, Apple Computer Inc. united with an old enemy by agreeing to cooperate with the Microsoft Corporation. Next, the troubled maker of Apple computers plans to reunite with an old ally.

description: GROSSMAN - George. Beloved husband of the late Rose Barkin Grossman and Florence Dutko Grossman. Loving stepfather of Marshal Dutko and Julie Osborn. Retired Director of Mathematics and Science for the New York City Board of Education. Services on Friday 12 Noon at Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

description: LONDON

title: Dozens Narrowly Escape as Apartment Building Falls
description: The corner of a five-story apartment building in Brooklyn collapsed early yesterday, raining tons of debris into the street and sending firefighters and police officers racing through the halls to warn scores of sleeping residents to get out.

title: For Jones, Little Time for Fun and Games
description: There was no joking around for Roy Jones Jr. at the weigh-in this afternoon for his bout against Montell Griffin at the Foxwood Resort Casino on Thursday night. No smiling. No laughing. Just hop on the scale, get weighed and get out. All business.

title: Scientists Map a Bacterium's Genetic Code
description: In a tour de force of computer-aided biology, scientists have decoded the full genetic instructions of the bacterium that causes ulcers and other stomach disease and have figured out many of its cunning strategies.

Gormley, the State Senator whose complaint prompted the proposal. Mr. Gormley, of Margate, is a Republican, not a Democrat.

title: Sakic Signs Offer From Rangers
description: In a bold move to replace Mark Messier as their first-line center, the Rangers announced last night that they have signed Joe Sakic of the Colorado Avalanche to a contract offer sheet of $21 million over three seasons.

title: Gunmen Shoot Worker At a Housing Project
description: A Housing Authority worker helping to fix pipes at a housing project in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn was shot in the back yesterday afternoon after he encountered three masked robbers, the police said.

title: Mets' Bullpen Is in Need of Saving
description: The Phillies' Ricky Bottalico, the Cardinals' Dennis Eckersley, the Astros' Billy Wagner, front-line relievers all, blew save opportunities Tuesday night.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Hamptons frenzy may be reaching its summer peak, but there is one event that party goers need not feel compelled to attend this year: the annual benefit given by the Friends of the Hampton Library in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHARNO, EDMUND
description: CHARNO-Edmund. On August 5, 1997. Of Jericho, L.I. Beloved husband of Wendy; devoted father of Randi Levine and Steven Charno; loving father-in-law of Jeff and Lilia; adored son of Esther; dear brother of Lawrence and brotherin-law of Ellen; cherished grandfather of Benjamin, Jessica and Dara. Janse-Vreeling of Appleton, WI., Janet C. Bryars of Papillion, NE and Charles Comer of Port Washington, NY. Also survived by 13 nieces and nephews. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main Street, Port Washington. Visiting Hours Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. and Saturday 9-10 AM. Funeral service Saturday 10 A.M. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, HELEN GOLDING
description: BRODY-Helen Golding. Camp Dora Golding expresses its heartfelt sympathy to the family of Helen Golding Brody upon her passing. The Golding name is borne proudly by this camp which testifies to the many deeds of merit of the Golding family. May her memory be blessed and her family comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mendy Bauman, President Jon Herbitter, Chairman of the Board

title: Stable Prices and Low Wage Pressures Seen
description: The economy is continuing to expand moderately with subdued wage pressures and stable prices over all, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic survey.

title: Chrebet, No Mascot, Knows His Role
description: Wayne Chrebet had paid his dues and emerged as the most compelling of the the Jets in the worst two-year stretch in their history. Coming out of Hofstra in 1995, and so small at 5 feet 10 inches that a security guard once refused him admission at the gate, he merely caught more passes his first two seasons than any other player in National Football League history.

title: Law Firm Expands Offices
description: The law firm of Thacher Proffitt & Wood has expanded its offices at 2 World Trade Center in a new lease from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that is worth about $65 million over the 15-year term.

title: Budget Deal, for Now, Takes Back Seat to the Economy
description: In announcing his estimate that the Federal budget deficit this year would fall to $37 billion, its lowest level since 1974, President Clinton acknowledged today that the strong economy and resulting unexpectedly high tax receipts had restored the Government's fiscal health even before the balanced-budget agreement he signed into law this week has had a chance to take effect.

title: Firms Face Charges Over Phone Cards
description: Federal and state law enforcement authorities have charged three New York companies with using deceptive practices to sell prepaid telephone cards, resulting in losses for consumers and distributors.

title: Nuclear Plant Is to Reopen
description: Federal regulators announced yesterday that the Salem II nuclear power plant was ready to reopen.

title: One Oregon Agency Acquires Another
description: Karakas VanSickle Ouellette Advertising and Public Relations in Portland, Ore., has agreed to acquire AKA Inc. Advertising & Sass, also in Portland. Terms of the deal, expected to be completed on Sept. 1, were not disclosed.

title: Dividing the Audience For a Hipper Talk Show
description: The new late-night talk show ''Vibe'' knows how to make a splashy entrance. One of two competing shows that had their debuts on Monday, ''Vibe'' didn't begin by bringing out its little-known host, the comedian Chris Spencer. Instead, the show's big-name producer, Quincy Jones, chatted with President Clinton in a brief appearance taped last week at the White House. When the President talked about the need for cooperation among young people of all ethnic groups, pointing out that within a decade California will have no majority race, he might as well have been defining both shows' dream audience.

title: Capital Punishment Cases in New York
description: Following is a list of the defendants in cases in New York State in which prosecutors are seeking the death penalty, according to the Capital Defender Office.

title: An Appalling Finale
description: In the final days of its session, the New York State Legislature passed a budget that was 126 days late, a series of major changes in regulation of insurance and banking that virtually no one had read, and a crop of special-interest bills that seemed to pop out of nowhere and then zoom through the Assembly and Senate by near-unanimous votes. Two of the most egregious of these bills grant favors to teachers and police that can only weaken the education system and undermine police discipline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISHMAN, ROSE S.
description: TISHMAN-Rose S. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Jerry A. of Westport, CT., and N.Y.C. Died peacefully in her 96th year on August 4. Mrs. Tishman was born on June 26, 1902 in N.Y.C. where she resided her entire life. During World War II, she was one of the leaders of the New York Division of the American Women's Volunteer Service. She was also a founding member and Secretary of the Lila Motley League which was a forerunner of volunteer cancer care organizations. Interment will be private.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New York City's plan to impose sanctions on private foster care agencies for poor performance included an incorrect identification from city officials for one agency facing sanctions. The agency, described by the city as among the seven worst performers, is Edwin Gould Academy in Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., not Edwin Gould Services for Children in Manhattan. The Manhattan agency, a separate organization that has its own city contract, remains in good standing with the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULLY, SENATOR MICHAEL J. JR.
description: TULLY-Senator Michael J. Jr. The Board of Governors, members and staff of Greater New York Hospital Association deeply regret the passing of New York State Senator Michael J. Tully, Jr. As Chairman of the Senate Health Committee and Chairman of the Council on Health Care Financing, Senator Tully worked tirelessly on behalf of the New York health care community to improve the health of all New Yorkers. At this difficult time, we extend our most sincere condolences to Senator Tully's family and many friends. Barry R. Freedman, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President Greater New York Hospital Association

title: New Premier In Cambodia, Bringing Total To 3? 2? 1?
description: An obedient Parliament ignored a series of constitutional and procedural roadblocks today and elected a new Co-Prime Minister, giving Cambodia, by various counts, one, two or three Prime Ministers.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Chooses an Insider To Head the Police
description: Mayor Richard J. Riordan selected a 32-year veteran of the Los Angeles Police Department today to lead the force.

title: GTECH AND NTN COMMUNICATIONS CANCEL MERGER DEAL
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation said yesterday that it had ended its plan to buy NTN Communications Inc., a money-losing maker of interactive games, for $140 million. Gtech, of West Greenwich, R.I., and NTN had reached a tentative agreement in June for the purchase of NTN at $5.125 a share in cash. Gtech shares rose $3.6875, to $33.5625, while NTN fell 37.5 cents, to $3.625, before trading in the shares was halted. NTN is an interactive television and Internet entertainment company in Carlsbad, Calif.

title: Writers' Workshops Thrive on Dreams of Fame
description: As long as she can remember, Ivonne Lamazares has yearned to be a writer. Three times in the last four years (with one year off to have a baby), Ms. Lamazares has come to the Sewanee Writers' Conference, along with some 100 other hopeful, dreaming souls. She has come to ''workshop'' her writing, in the parlance of such gatherings, to sit at the feet of well-known writers like Russell Banks and Anthony Hecht, to hear lectures and readings that enhance the mind and elevate the spirit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABRAL, VINOD
description: DABRAL-Vinod, of Hastings-onHudson, NY, died suddenly on Wednesday, at age 45. Beloved husband of Sharad, loving father of Siddharth, and a simply wonderful human being. Memorial service and funeral Sunday 1 PM, at Ferncliffe Cemetery, 280 Secor Road, Hartsdale, NY (Tel 914693-4700). Memorial gifts to American Diabetes Association.

title: Sleepless And Worried For a Family
description: NOON games come up fast after night games. Bobby Valentine had no sleep at all, and it had little to do with runs or hits or errors.

title: NORTHEAST STATES PRESSURING E.P.A. TO MOVE ON SMOG
description: As the Northeast suffers through one of the worst smog seasons of the decade, most state governments in the region are about to petition the Environmental Protection Agency to crack down on Midwestern utilities, where much of the pollution originates.

title: CHOICEPOINT SAYS IT HAS CALLED OFF ACQUISITION OF KROLL
description: Choicepoint Inc., the insurance services company to be spun off by Equifax Inc., said yesterday that its acquisition of Kroll Associates had been called off after the two companies could not reach a final agreement. Kroll is based in New York and provides detective work to corporate clients. Choicepoint is based in Alpharetta, Ga., and provides risk management information and services like employee drug testing. The companies said they would continue to cooperate. The plans to acquire Kroll were announced in April, but no terms were announced. Choicepoint generated $366.5 million in revenue last year. The closely held Kroll had 1996 revenue of more than $70 million.

title: $25 and Under
description: At Swan Oyster Depot in San Francisco, paradise is a platter of Pacific oysters on the half shell, a bowl of chowder, a length of French bread and a cold beer, served at a long marble counter. Rebecca Charles and Mary Redding, two cooks from New York City, discovered Swan for themselves on a vacation last year and decided that New York needed what San Francisco had. Taking Swan as their model, they opened Pearl Oyster Bar this summer on Cornelia Street in Greenwich Village.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, GEORGE
description: GROSSMAN-George. Died on August 6, 1997. Survived by his loving companion Mildred whose devotion warmed his life; the spirit of beloved wives Rose and Florence; father Nathan, mother Lena, brother Sidney; grieving cousins Rebecca, Isadore, Blanche, Elaine, Julie, Esther, Adele. title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the collapse of a building in Brooklyn misspelled the given name of a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Buildings. She is Ilyse Fink, not Elise.

title: White House Excuses
description: This week's news from Washington, including President Clinton's press conference yesterday, showed once again that the Democrats have no real credibility on campaign fund-raising. The Republicans can also be maddeningly disingenuous, as demonstrated by Haley Barbour's slippery testimony before the Senate committee investigating the flow of foreign soft money into the 1996 campaign. But when it comes to devising audacious and creative defenses, nobody matches the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNITZLER, PAULA
description: SCHNITZLER-Paula. Congregation Ohab Zedek of Belle Harbor, New York, mourns the passing of the mother of our esteemed member Dr. Irving Schnitzler. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, REV. ARTHUR
description: WELLS-Rev. Arthur. On August 6, 1997, loving husband of Marion, father of Dorothy Whitehouse and Jane Schneider. Grandfather of Melanie, Casey, Jean Schneider, Eric Whitehouse and Scott Schneider. Also survived by two great-grandchildren. Reposing at Howard L. Hallett, Inc (Gleason Bldg), 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY Friday 2-4PM and 79PM. Services at the Bowne St. Community Church, Saturday 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Bowne St. Community Church 143-11 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, NY or The New York Congregational Nursing Center 135 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Card Holders' Credit Improved in June
description: The credit quality of United States credit card holders improved in June as banks wrote off less debt and consumers paid more of their bills, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: Arafat Aides Say Israel Prevents Security Ties
description: By almost any measure, Col. Sameh Kanan is exactly the sort of Palestinian on whom the Israeli authorities would have to depend to carry out any new wave of arrests of Islamic militants.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the resignation of the chief executive of Oxford Health Plans misspelled his given name. He is Stephen F. Wiggins, not Steven.

title: Risks of Electric Cars Are Still Under Debate
description: As the number of electric cars grows and their durability and performance are measured, experts are quietly waiting for the events that will settle another question: how safe are electric vehicles in highway accidents?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARB, JACOB S., M.D.
description: BARB-Jacob S., M.D. on August 6, 1997. Columbia College Class of 1928, Columbia P&S 1931. Beloved husband of Bernice (Bunny). Devoted father of Madeleine Haley. Dear brother of Dr. Julius Barb and Dorothy Budd. Shiva at home. Contributions may be made to Columbia P&S, Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, New York City or the Visiting Nurse Service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.C.C. Moves to Cut Costs Of Phone Calls Overseas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARGEVER, IDA (HAIMOWITZ)
description: LARGEVER - Ida (Haimowitz). June 20th, 1902 to August 3, 1997, age 95. We mourn the loss of our dearly loved ''Nanny,'' a lifetime member of Hadassah, who now joins her beloved husband Mac; her brothers Henry, Sam & Irving Haimes; and her daughter Gladyce Begelman. She is survived by her sister Ethel Schissel; her son and daughter-in-law Arnold & Barbara Largever; her grandchildren Beth Rudin DeWoody, William Rudin and Jason and Andrea Largever; her great-grandchildren Carlton & Kyle DeWoody, and Samantha and Michael Rudin; her nephew Howard Schissel and sisters-in-law Edyth Berg and Ruth Haimes. The funeral services will take place Monday, August 11, 1997 at 11:30AM, The BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island. Interment immediately following at Mount Ararat Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the Leukemia Research Fund, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTINER, DAVID
description: TROTINER-David. Beloved husband of Sylvia, loving father of Alan, Mark and Laurie. Cherished grandfather of Melissa, Susan, and Rose Mary. Dear brother of Murray and Perry. ''Sinai Chapels'' 800446-0406.

title: Rangers Revel In Bold Move To Get Sakic
description: So what if the Rangers boosted the pay scale for hockey players by signing Joe Sakic to an offer sheet of $21 million for three seasons. Who cares if other general managers resent the Rangers' bid for this elite Group 2 free agent, the kind of restricted free agent who rarely changes teams.

title: Informix to Restate Financial Results
description: The Informix Corporation said today that it planned to restate its 1996 financial results because of errors in the recording of revenue.

title: The Apple of Microsoft's Eye
description: Even in cyberspace, the moment can only be described as surreal. Two thousand Apple computer loyalists greet the return of their hero and Apple co-founder, Steven Jobs, at a Boston trade show, only to gasp as the looming picture of Apple's archenemy, Bill Gates of Microsoft, appears on a huge on-stage screen. It was Mr. Gates, after all, who copied Apple's visionary point-and-click system of computer commands, marketed it far more aggressively and successfully, and drove Apple to near-collapse.

title: Soybean and Corn Prices Fall On Forecast of Midwest Rain
description: Soybean and corn prices fell sharply yesterday as a private forecaster predicted a surprisingly large United States soybean crop and the market anticipated much-needed rain this weekend in grain states.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLE NATIONAL CORP., Cleveland, an operator of specialty service retail stores, acquired American Vision Centers Inc., New York, a retail optical chain, for $28.9 million in cash.

title: America Online Reports Operating Profit in Quarter
description: Exploiting its growing bases of customers and advertising, America Online Inc. announced earnings from operations for its fourth quarter yesterday that slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: Songs of Love and Many Permutations
description: A jealous trucker kills his wife by driving his rig through a hotel window. A drunk disrupts his ex-girlfriend's wedding. A widow seduces a teen-age boy in a wheatfield. The ghost of a suicide haunts a beach. Just another night of programming on HBO? Yes and no. They were the storylines for some of the more striking songs that Garth Brooks sang during his concert on Thursday night in the North Meadow of Central Park, which was telecast live on HBO. And those songs stuck out in Mr. Brooks's set like peppercorns in a cheese.

title: 2 Held in Smuggling Of Deaf Mexicans
description: Ending a manhunt that stretched from the subways of New York to the barrios of Mexico City, United States immigration agents arrested a father and son accused of leading an operation that smuggled deaf Mexicans into the United States and forced them to live in virtual slavery peddling trinkets. Both were taken into custody in Mexico City.

title: Looking Backward
description: Stereo Total, Brownie's, 169 Avenue A, between 10th and 11th Streets, East Village, (212) 420-8392. Behind nearly every word and note the European lounge-pop band Stereo Total plays, there is an antecedent (and usually a sly, winking joke as well). It's not just in its hilariously plastic version of Salt-n-Pepa's ''Push It,'' but the melodies borrowed from the Beach Boys, Serge Gainsbourg and K. C. and the Sunshine Band. Though the band's primary influence seems to be French chansons, Stereo Total doesn't shy away from incorporating clattering punk rock, portentous progressive rock, cheap drum machines, even typewriters. The band plays with Hooked on Sonics, B. Blush and St. Christopher and the Sleeping Doormen tomorrow night at 9; admission is $6. N. S.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, PAULINE
description: FISCHER-Pauline, 98. Devoted wife of the late Jack; loving mother of Bill and Stuart, Iris (Stanley) Aronson and Carol and Howard Schleien; loving sister of Esther Nathanson; adoring grandmother of ten grandchildren and fifteen great grandchildren. Pauline Fischer, along with her husband Jack, ran the famous Little Oriental Restaurant in Brooklyn. Services on Sunday, 12 Noon, ''Parkside'' Chapels, at 66th Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: First the Spano Debacle, Then a Bidding Frenzy
description: John O. Pickett is chuckling these days. He has discovered the joys of bad publicity. Despite a month of prominent national reports about John Spano's allegedly fradulent attempt to buy the Islanders, a dozen or so suitors have emerged, apparently willing to pay more than the $165 million Spano promised.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Everyone Says I Love You

title: G.E. to Sell Back Shares to Broker
description: The General Electric Company's Capital Services unit said yesterday that it had agreed to sell six million Paine Webber Group Inc. shares back to the brokerage firm for $219 million. The agreement would cut G.E.'s stake in Paine Webber to 23 percent from 31 percent.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Against the Tide'

title: Israel and Arabs Welcome U.S. Push but With Different Agendas
description: Both the Israelis and the Palestinians said today that they welcomed a new American initiative aimed at pushing the two sides more swiftly toward peace, but they also presented rival views about what should receive the highest priority under the reinvigorated diplomacy.

title: Parents of Invention
description: Homemade Instrument Day, Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors, (212) 875-5108. Forget the cellos and clarinets; for one day at Lincoln Center, sounds will be made and controlled by one-of-a-kind gadgets built or envisioned by composers who are not content to use anyone else's instruments. Some harness electronics to trigger sounds in unlikely ways, like pointing with a glove (as Laeticia Sonami does) or tapping on shoes (Joshua Fried); others use steel pans (Bakra Bata) and boomboxes (Kathy Kennedy). Workshops and performances begin on Sunday at 2 P.M. in the North, South and Fountain Plazas. At 6:30 P.M. in Damrosch Park, Pauline Oliveros's meditative Deep Listening Band and the violinist Leroy Jenkins perform. Admission is free. J. P.

title: Family Values Void
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHER, IRVING E., M.D.
description: BLECHER-Irving E., M.D. Dearly beloved and never to be forgotten husband of Rhoda, devoted father of Louise Rose Gutstein and Lillian Steinmann, adoring grandfather of Jacob Steinmann, proud father-in-law of Dr. Sidney Gutstein. We shall miss him forever. Services today, 11:15, Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City.

title: Tenet Healthcare Tries to Settle Some Old Accounts
description: A decade has passed since Kelly Stafford walked through the doors of the Brookhaven Psychiatric Pavillion here. But for her, the nightmarish days that followed are fixed forever.

title: Older Horses Are Running Into Spotlight
description: While the best of this season's 3-year-old colts were preparing for their next test in the Travers Stakes here in two weeks, the premier senior horses on both the East and the West coasts were primed for two major stakes this weekend: the $1 million Pacific Classic at Del Mar and the $250,000 Sword Dancer Invitational at Saratoga.

title: A Night of Garth Fever and Country Cool
description: They missed their train, so they caught a bus. The ride to New York took five long hours, and when they finally arrived in Central Park, the public address was blaring that the time was ''G minus five'' -- five minutes until Garth Brooks would dash across the stage. But as soon as Peggy Graham of Worcester, Mass., heard the opening beat of the opening song -- ''Rodeo,'' one of her favorites -- she was lip-syncing every word.

title: E.D.S. to Buy Control of Neodata
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation in Plano, Tex., said yesterday that it would acquire the remaining 52 percent stake in Neodata Services, an integrated marketing communications services company, from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. E.D.S., which has owned 48 percent of Neodata since 1993, will pay Hicks, Muse about $67 million and will assume about $210 million in debt.

title: Accused of Groping a Patient
description: A dentist from Cedar Grove whose office is on the Upper East Side of Manhattan was arrested yesterday after a patient reported that she awoke from anesthesia to find him clad only in a pair of high black socks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, ROY W. JR.
description: MOORE-Roy W. Jr., 77, of Southport, CT. Husband of Helen Starbuck Moore, retired Chief Executive Officer of the Canada Dry Corporation, New York City, and former Trustee of Roosevelt Hospital, died on Monday, August 4, 1997. Funeral Services will be held on Saturday, August 9, at 11 A.M. at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT. Spear Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT. for information.

title: CHRONICLE
description: L. JAY OLIVA, the president of New York University, is accustomed to lecturing in classrooms, but rarely in theatrical settings. On Monday, he went to Lincoln Center to brief the cast and crew of ''The Scarlet Pimpernel,'' the musical that is to open on Broadway in November. It is based on Baroness Orczy's novel about a British aristocrat who smuggles French aristocrats out of prison and saves them from the guillotines of the French Revolution.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: WORKFARE AGREEMENT -- Mayor Giuliani has reached an agreement with municipal unions pledging to provide adequate safety protections for workfare participants and asserting that they are not intended to displace city workers. B2.

title: The Forbidden Fruit
description: To the Editor:

title: Don Steele, 61, Disk Jockey Known for His Patter
description: Don Steele, one of the pioneering disk jockeys of top 40 radio in the 60's, died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 61.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower here at midday, with the Nikkei average of 225 stocks down 216.42 points, or 1.11 percent, to 19,259.43. On Thursday, the Nikkei was down 226.22 points.

title: They Still Don't Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoken Word
description: OPEN READING, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village. Sponsored by the Italian-American Writers Association. Tomorrow, 6 P.M. Admission: $5, which includes one drink. Information: (212) 989-9319.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, PAUL V.
description: FARRELL-Paul V. You were the best. Mike Stimson

title: For Stock Mutual Funds in '97, A Great Year in Just 7 Months
description: Seven months into the year, mutual fund investors have already made this the second-best year ever for stock funds. Nor have they forgotten about bonds in their rush to buy stocks; bond funds have already recorded their best year since 1993.

title: Legitimizing a Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Parents Are Subpoenaed
description: Prosecutors have subpoenaed the parents of a Wyckoff teen-ager who is accused of killing her newborn son, The Associated Press reported, so that the prosecutors can compel them to disclose why their daughter hid her pregnancy.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's Man Against Whale, With a Boy in Between
description: A lot of water has flowed past the Pacific Northwest coastline since Jesse met Willy, a lovable killer whale who became his best friend, in 1993. That year, ''Free Willy'' introduced moviegoers to Jesse (Jason James Richter), an angry, streetwise little boy who was exhilarated and transformed by his friendship with the whale. He eventually saved Willy from evil amusement park owners and set him free.

title: Indicted Assemblyman Was a Fighter, and Still Is
description: When Assemblyman Dov Hikind, the onetime Jewish militant turned political kingmaker, called a news conference yesterday to denounce his indictment on Federal corruption charges, he picked a telling location: the same spot in front of Amnon's kosher pizzeria in Borough Park, Brooklyn, where in recent years he has presented his coveted endorsement to some of the state's most powerful elected officials.

title: For Children
description: 'Chill Out Weekend'

title: Managed-Care Bill Signed
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation yesterday giving users of managed-care programs certain protections that consumer organizations described as the strongest in the nation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Christian Mortensen, who, with the death of a 122-year-old woman in France, may now be the oldest person in the world, misstated a demographer's comment about him. John R. Wilmoth, a professor of demography at the University of California at Berkeley, wrote two years ago that even before his 113th birthday, Mr. Mortensen might have been close to the record as the oldest reliably documented man who ever lived, not the oldest person.

title: Refugee Fusion
description: Wyclef Jean and the Refugee All-Stars, Tramps, 51 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-7788. Wyclef Jean of the Fugees is after a pan-Caribbean-New York City fusion, combining hip-hop with reggae, Haitian compas and Trinidadian soca on his album ''Carnival.'' Even when his ambitions outrun his music, his coalition-building is intelligent and good-hearted. Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $20. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVE, CURTIS
description: SOLOVE-Curtis. On August 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Jean, father of Richard and Stephanie, grandfather of Daniel and Jacqueline. Services on Friday 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Sargent, a Canny Traveler on the Road to Fame
description: American taste, puritanical by inclination, turned in embarrassment from John Singer Sargent after World War I, then embraced him when it became all right to be rich again, in the 1980's. Such is the serpentine fate of a virtuoso who courts fame.

title: Walker Cup Competitor Juggles Work and Sport
description: After playing his second match in the Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur Championship in Springfield, N.J., last Friday, Jerry Courville drove to his job as a projects coordinator in Shelton, Conn., a two-and-a-half-hour trip.

title: Welfare Bill Denies Benefits To Immigrants in First Year
description: The welfare bill awaiting Gov. George E. Pataki's signature contains a provision that would deny state-financed benefits to legal immigrants in their first year in this country. Immigrants are allowed to enter the country only if sponsors promise financial support, but New York State now provides benefits to immigrants when sponsors are unable or unwilling to support them.

title: Everett Cleared In Inquiry Into Abuse
description: The 4-year-old son and 5-year-old daughter of Carl Everett, the Mets' right fielder, were placed in foster care early yesterday morning after a child-care worker at a Shea Stadium playroom noticed bruises on the girl, police and city officials said.

title: Music Label Sale Planned
description: The Alliance Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell back most of Red Ant Records to Wasserstein Perella & Company, which helped finance the ailing record label. The deal will give Alliance, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, $625,000 in cash and a 10 percent interest in the record label. Wasserstein Perella will provide $11 million to $19 million in financing for the Red Ant label, Alliance said.

title: Merger Proposed For Exchanges
description: With the futures industry facing increased competition from the over-the-counter markets and pressure to trim costs, the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Jack Sandner, is promoting the idea of merging his exchange with its longtime crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What the Princess did on her summer vacation: London newspapers have been filled with articles about the PRINCESS OF WALES on a six-day Mediterranean cruise off the coast of Italy with DODI FAYED, a Hollywood film producer and son of Mohamed al-Fayed, the owner of Harrods. The Evening Standard reported that they met 10 years ago when he played polo against Prince Charles's team.

title: A Contrast of Elegance And Rambunctiousness
description: Because of the nature of its repertory, Mostly Mozart concerts often visit extremes of courtly elegance and backstairs rambunctiousness, often within single works. How much is made of this contrast depends on whether the conductor, the soloists and the musicians care to paint in vivid hues or more subtle ones.

title: Landmark Settlement Ends Hispanic Housing Bias Suit
description: When a job in the press room of a printing company lured Francisco Hernandez to Addison, Ill., a dozen years ago, he was one of only a few Mexican-Americans in town.

title: In Balanced-Budget Deal, Bush Is Off the Seesaw
description: While President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich are grandly congratulating themselves and each other over the balanced-budget deal they wrought, George Bush, the man who risked the most and paid the biggest price for cutting the deficit, is off in Maine, feeling unappreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIM, EDITH
description: WERTHEIM-Edith. ''Edzia'' to those who knew and loved her. Beloved wife of Samuel. Devoted mother of Elliot, and mother-inlaw of Ellen. Loving grandmother of Aaron. On August 6, 1997. A survivor of the Holocaust and one of the first women on ''Schindler's List,'' her generosity of spirit, strength of character and unyielding will to survive was, and always will be, an inspiration to all whose lives she touched. The family would like to express its sincerest appreciation to Dr. Mary Ann McLoughlin of Mt. Sinai Hospital in NY for her extraordinary care and concern. She was a friend and a true humanitarian and for that we will always be grateful. Edzia, Mom, Grandma-you will always be with us. Funeral services Friday, August 8, Schwartz Bros., 11403 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, 11AM

title: Stocks Fall From Records, With Dow Retreating 71.31
description: Stocks retreated from records yesterday, hurt by a slump in the Treasury market.

title: Assemblyman Indicted
description: State Assemblyman Dov Hikind, whose success in bringing home government dollars to his Brooklyn neighborhood won him popularity and political influence, was indicted yesterday on Federal corruption charges. Mr. Hikind denounced the charges as ''scurrilous.''

title: Cone Discovers Success By Shortening Windup
description: David Cone is renowned for going into his personal pitching laboratory to tinker with his repertory, his motion or his approach to hitters. Cone loves to experiment and stay one stride ahead of the opposition, which is what he did by altering his windup against the Rangers tonight and baffling them.

title: Beyond 'The Thinker': Hands Reveal Rodin's Impact
description: Many people, it seems, first fall under the spell of Auguste Rodin's art in adolescence, when a dawning sense of the world's tormented grandeur finds a sympathetic echo in his overwrought, romantic sculptures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, FREDERICK, REVEREND
description: HILL-Frederick, Reverend. Retired Rector of St. Michael's Church, New York City. Longtime Associate at St. James, Madison Avenue, suddenly and peacefully at home in Goshen, N.Y., August 2, 1997. He was 67. Survived by James Kennedy, many relatives and friends. Services Saturday, August 9, at 1 PM at St. Michael's, 225 W. 99 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Michael's Church would be appreciated.

title: From Shtetl to Village
description: The Klezmatics and Brave Combo, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. A double bill of music with ethnic roots and plenty of twists. The Klezmatics carry klezmer music's freylachs and horas to the Lower East Side, where they collide happily with jazz and noise. Brave Combo finds endless, lighthearted variations in the polka. Saturday at 8 and 11 P.M. Admission is $17.50. J. P.

title: INVESTOR GROUP OFFERS $1.4 BILLION FOR FISHER
description: An investor group led by the Thomas H. Lee Companies agreed yesterday to buy Fisher Scientific International for $1.4 billion, or $51 a share, thwarting an unsolicited offer of $1 billion, or $48 a share, by the Bass Group. Fisher, a maker of test tubes, rubber gloves, beakers and other scientific equipment based in Hampton, N.H., agreed to the friendly offer by investors including Lee, which is a Boston buyout firm, DLJ Merchant Banking Partners and Chase Capital Partners. Fisher shares fell $1.375 yesterday, to $49.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLIVET, JULIEN REMY
description: JOLIVET-Julien Remy. Age 3, on August 6, 1997. Beloved son of Arnaud and Melissa. Dear twin brother of the late Ethan. Loving grandson of Maggie and Joe DelRosario and Manline and JeanPaul Jolivet. Adored nephew of Caress and Ali DelRosario. Special grandson of Donald Fine and cherished great grandson of Felix Ledda Jr., Roberto and Claring DelRosario. Friends may call at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday 2-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84 Street, on Saturday 10 A.M. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Stoop Dreams: Skipping College for the Streets
description: That old saw about being able to take the boy out of Brooklyn but not Brooklyn out of the boy is given a poignant new twist in ''Soul in the Hole,'' Danielle Gardner's pulsating documentary about street basketball on the outdoor courts of New York City. The film, which suggests a casual, scorched-sidewalk answer to ''Hoop Dreams,'' follows Kenny's Kings, a talented team from Bedford-Stuyvesant, through the local tournament season during the summer of 1993.

title: Great Trek Inspired By Faith
description: ''Trail of Hope'' is a moving, but slow-moving, account of the great migration that brought tens of thousands of Mormons to Salt Lake Valley, their New Zion, about 150 years ago. After meeting hostility and violence in Missouri and Illinois, the ''Latter-day Saints,'' led by Brigham Young, trekked across 1,400 hard-traveling miles in an astounding demonstration of determination, organization, discipline and faith that has won comparison with the children of Israel making it out of Egypt. ''This is the right place,'' Young said as he entered the valley.

title: Jones's Jarring Left Hook Knocks Griffin Out of the Title
description: The fight between Montell Griffin and Roy Jones Jr. was called Unfinished Business, and it didn't take Jones long to bring it to a quick conclusion.

title: Sidney Simon, Sculptor, 80; Founded School
description: Sidney Simon, a sculptor and a founder of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture in Maine, died on Monday at his summer home in Truro, Mass. He was 80 and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Lugar Vows Trouble for Helms If He Balks on Hearing for Weld
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar raised the stakes today in the battle over William F. Weld's nomination to be Ambassador to Mexico, threatening to make trouble for Senator Jesse Helms's tobacco interests if Mr. Helms did not call a committee hearing and permit a vote on the nomination.

title: Retailers Had Especially Strong July Sales
description: American retailers in July enjoyed one of the strongest months of sales in two years, according to figures released yesterday by the industry.

title: Agents Arrest a Sixth Suspect As Details Unfold on Shootout
description: A sixth suspect was arrested yesterday morning in a bloody shootout that erupted outside a McDonald's in mid-Manhattan Wednesday evening, as investigators tried to sort out how a Federal sting operation went awry and left an undercover agent wounded and a suspected drug dealer dead.

title: Art in Review
description: Group Show

title: Sculpture Adorns the Urban Terrain
description: ABOUT 30 years ago, a sculpture revolution broke out in New York City that led many artists to abandon galleries and museums for points unknown, most of them outdoors. Artists like Michael Heizer, Robert Smithson and Walter De Maria ended up in the Southwest, while others, like Richard Serra, Donald Judd and Gordon Matta-Clark, executed various site-specific works in more urban settings. Still others reinterpreted site-specific to mean functional. Scott Burton, Siah Armajani and Mary Miss, for example, began to design outdoor chairs and benches, gazebos and even footbridges for squares and parks, some of which are permanent parts of places like Battery Park City in lower Manhattan and North Shore Park on Staten Island.

title: Nature's Own Tax Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Sculpture

title: CBS Executive Is Promoted To Television Unit President
description: CBS elevated Leslie Moonves, the president of CBS Entertainment, to president of CBS Television yesterday, putting more authority in the hands of the man widely credited with rebuilding the programming base of the network.

title: India's Odd, Enduring Patchwork
description: A year ago, when India celebrated the 49th anniversary of its independence from British rule, H. D. Deve Gowda, then the Prime Minister, stood at the ramparts of New Delhi's 16th-century Red Fort and delivered the traditional Independence Day address to the nation in Hindi, India's ''national language.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZKI, HERBERT
description: KATZKI-Herbert. HIAS mourns the passing of Herbert Katzki, a force in rescue programs of WWII and reconstruction of the Jewish community in Europe. His lifelong Commitment to the dignity of humanity inspired all. HIAS extends condolences to his wife, Kate and to JDC. Norman D. Tilles, President Martin A. Wenick, Executive VP

title: Baerga Helps Resilient Mets Come Alive
description: Every excuse, name it, the Mets have had it. They could have crumbled long ago.

title: E.D.S. Posts Decline in 2d-Quarter Earnings
description: Electronic Data Systems, buffeted by tougher competition and shrinking margins in the computer services industry, reported declining earnings today and said the poor results would continue for the rest of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCER, WILLIAM
description: LINCER-William. The Juilliard School mourns the death of William Lincer distinguished member of the faculty since 1969 and one of the most prominent and respected violists of this century. At Juilliard he developed an extraordinarily strong class of violists who went on to become professionally active in solo, chamber and orchestral settings. All the members of the Juilliard community extend deepest condolences to his family. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman of the Board Joseph W. Polisi President The Juilliard School

title: U.S. Indicts 12 In $15 Million Medicare Ring
description: In what the authorities called the largest case of home health care fraud ever uncovered in the country, 12 people here, including five doctors, were charged today with defrauding the Medicare system of $15 million by submitting false claims and inventing patients and treatments to collect fees.

title: Underneath the Veneer of Adulthood
description: Dressed for success, two 30-ish women and a man tour a London flat. He is the smug real estate agent selling the place; one of the women, Hannah (Katrin Cartlidge), is a sharp-tongued potential customer, accompanied by an old friend, Annie (Lynda Steadman), on a visit from out of town.

title: Adoption Rate In Foster Care Varies Widely Among States
description: The number of foster children who are ultimately adopted varies widely from state to state -- from 96 percent in North Dakota last year to less than 10 percent in Hawaii, according to a study by two groups that specialize in advocacy on children's issues.

title: Job Hunting to Be Harder for Errant Brokers
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers adopted a rule yesterday that will make it much harder for brokers from firms that violate securities laws to move on to other firms after theirs have been shut down.

title: Space Shuttle Blasts Off and Deploys a Scientific Satellite
description: The space shuttle Discovery and a crew of six astronauts blasted off today on a mission to deploy a scientific satellite that tracks atmospheric pollution and to test a new kind of robotic arm that one day might aid experimenters on the international space station.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Nullifying Anti-Terrorism
description: Congress passes legislation instructing the State Department to take a critical step against foreign terrorism in America. Naturally, State carries out the law -- when it is good and ready.

title: Parcells Gives Farrior A Chance to Be a Factor
description: On the eve of the Jets' second preseason game, Coach Bill Parcells today tightened the pressure on rookies, elevating his most noted newcomer as well as one of the least heralded.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, EDWIN MCMAHON
description: SINGER-Edwin McMahon. On August 6, 1997. Attorney for over 60 years in New York City. Survived by wife Rita, daughter Patricia Hamilton and grandson Todd Hamil ton. Reposing at The Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Friday 35PM and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 11AM, St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street. In lieu of flowers a contribution in his memory to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Korean Peace Talks Falter Before They Begin
description: The effort by the United States, China and the two Koreas to set up peace talks aimed at formally ending the Korean War broke off unexpectedly this evening after failing to resolve differences over which topics those talks would cover, including the future of 37,000 American troops in South Korea.

description: Sonny Skinner's grandmother gave him his nickname because of his pleasant disposition.

title: Brest, French Home Port, Sees Future of Mothballs
description: Cardinal Richelieu selected this city at the tip of Brittany to give France a first-class navy. He succeeded so well that over 360 years later, one out of every two jobs here now depends on the military.

title: Mortgage Rates Increase
description: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages climbed in the last week, following yields on benchmark Treasury securities. The average commitment rate on 30-year fixed-rate conforming mortgage loans rose 13-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.64 percent in the last week, according to a weekly primary mortgage market index released yesterday by Banxquote Inc. The average rate on 15-year fixed-rate conforming mortgage loans rose 11-hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.23 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, STEVEN
description: KAPLAN-Steven. The Board of Governors and Members of Cold Spring Country Club deeply mourn the recent passing of our member of forty years. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Judith, and his children, Randall, Karin and Eric Greenberg, and Jillian, and grandchild, Drew. Steven Kaplan is the son of Harvey and the late Fritzie Kaplan.

title: Island Fling
description: David Rudder and Charlie's Roots/Krosfyah, Central Park Summerstage, Rumsey Playfield, mid-park at 72d Street, (212) 360-2777. David Rudder holds onto calypso tradition -- singing sly but pointed songs about current events and ideas -- while reaching back to resonant Afro-Trinidadian drumming. Krosfyah, from Barbados, plays speedy, exhilarating soca, calypso's uptempo party-music descendant. Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission is free. J. P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUBBARD, CRESCENS GARMAN
description: HUBBARD-Crescens Garman, of White Plains, NY. Husband of Jean N. Hubbard. Father of Julie Hubbard Lull, Carol and David Hubbard. Brother of Helen Baird. Grandfather of nine. Private funeral services will be conducted. Memorial contributions to CCHR, 6362 Hollywood Boulevard, Suite B, Los Angeles, CA. 90028.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINAMAN, HENRIETTA
description: ZINAMAN - Henrietta. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Jules and Lawrence (Dick). Cherished grandmother of Joanne Bross, James, Steven and Dr. Michael Zinaman. Adored great grandmother. Services Fri. 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mt Vernon.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Choose your seat carefully when you go to Gertrude's, in an Upper Side town house. In fact, you would be wise to ask for a specific dining room when you reserve a table.

title: Woman Slashed Baby To Death, Police Say
description: A Queens woman slashed her infant daughter to death yesterday evening and then critically injured herself with the knife, the police said.

title: VENTURE STORES IS SELLING STAKES IN 49 STORES TO KIMCO
description: Venture Stores Inc. sold stakes yesterday in 49 stores to the Kimco Realty Corporation for $135 million. Kimco is to pay $75 million cash and assume $60 million of debt on the properties, which contain 5.9 million square feet of space in seven states. Kimco, based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., also received the right to buy 21 more properties within the next five years. The moves are part of a plan by Venture to transform itself from a discount retailer to a seller of more profitable items like apparel, home furnishings and leisure goods. Shares of Venture rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $2.375, while Kimco's shares climbed 43.75 cents, to $35.125.
