description: To the Editor:

title: Mother of 3 Is Accused of Child Endangerment
description: They were young brothers well known in the playground behind their East Harlem apartment building, a 9-year-old and a 6-year-old who hardly ever appeared to leave the slide, the benches or the crawlable caterpillar, even after midnight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNARD, PETER
description: BERNARD-Peter. Age 87. On Aug. 6, 1997, of lung cancer. Loving husband of Susan Deutscher. Loving father and father-in-law of Laura B. and Frank Damone; cherished step-father of Lisa and Maria Deutscher, and Jonathan and Judy Poole; step-father-in-law of Robert Garber and Janet Poole; affectionate step-grandfather of Neal and Bobby Poole, and Laurel and Nicholas Garber. Services Sun. 12 noon, at The Riverside, 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made to Amer. Cancer Soc. or VNS or East End Hospices.

title: Two Luxury Projects May Cast Shadows on the West Village
description: Plans for two luxury condominium buildings are reflecting the increased interest of developers in the western fringe of Greenwich Village, raising community concerns that an area known for its quaint brownstones, loft warehouses and river views will soon be crowded with high-rise buildings that could change the character of the neighborhood.

title: Scientists Find Cause of Death Of Brain Cells
description: In a major medical advance, scientists have discovered what causes brain cells to die in people with Huntington's disease and six related disorders.

title: When Tenure Is Given To Incompetent Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuela and Trinidad Square Off Over Oil Treasure
description: A long-simmering boundary dispute over the petroleum-rich straits and gulf that separate Trinidad and Venezuela is flaring up again, with American oil companies caught squarely in the middle.

title: After One More Mishap, Relief Craft Links to Mir
description: The epic woes of the Mir deepened tonight when the system guiding a spaceship carrying a relief crew sent to repair the damaged space station failed. The spacecraft docked successfully, but only after the crew in the space station was forced to take the controls and bring it in manually.

title: Kipketer Best in World In Evasiveness and 800
description: The public address announcer was introducing an early heat of the 800 meters the other night, when he came to the man who is a co-owner of the world record. ''This is Wilson Kipketer of Kenya,'' the announcer said before he caught himself. ''Uh, Denmark, excuse me.''

title: Art in Review
description: 'Old-Time Favorites, New-Time Fashions'

title: CALLING OVERSEAS MAY GET CHEAPER
description: In a move that could sharply reduce the cost of calling from the United States to many places overseas, the Federal Communications Commission issued tough new rules yesterday to cut the $5.4 billion that American telephone companies pay to foreign carriers to complete their calls.

title: Country House Chatter So Rudely Interrupted
description: ZAK ORTH. The actor's name sounds as if it belongs to a visitor from another planet. Appropriately enough, in ''Misalliance,'' Mr. Orth plays one, to hilarious effect. He is Julius Baker, a dissembling wreck of an office clerk who, armed and angry, bursts in on the Edwardian swells of George Bernard Shaw's dizzy country house comedy of ideas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, NORMA H.
description: REID-Norma H. Died on August 3, 1997. Beloved mother of Jordanna, caring daughter of Roderick and Eileen Reid, devoted sister of Franklin Reid, Bertram Reid, Carmen Gray, Irma Reid, Carlton Reid, Yvonne Reid, Ruby Reid, Colleen Reid, Sandra Yearwood, Wayne Reid, Francis Reid. Cherished friend. Visiting on Thursday August 7, 7-9PM and Friday, Aug 8, 2-5PM, 7-9PM at John J. McManus & Sons, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. Funeral Saturday, August 9, 9AM at Vanderveer Park Methodist Church, 3114 Glenwood Rd, Bklyn.

title: NEWCOURT CREDIT AGREES TO BUY COMMCORP FINANCIAL
description: Newcourt Credit Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Commcorp Financial Services, a Burlington, Ontario, asset management company, for about $361 million (Canadian), or $260 million (United States). The purchase price consists of about $89 million (Canadian) cash and about 8.1 million Newcourt common shares. Newcourt is a Toronto-based financial services company. As part of the deal, Newcourt would also acquire a minority interest in a Commcorp affiliate, CIBC Equipment Finance Ltd. In October, Commcorp had managed assets of about $1.9 billion (Canadian), or $1.36 billion (United States). Newcourt had 1996 revenues of $171.6 million (Canadian).

title: Ford to Sell Its Stake in British Venture
description: Siemens A.G. said today that it would buy the Ford Motor Company's 49 percent stake in their British car-components venture, Siemens Automotive Systems Ltd., for an undisclosed price.

title: Military Chic, Circa 1815
description: To the Editor:

title: Citibank Consolidates, Stunning Madison Ave.
description: In what is probably the largest shift in the history of Madison Avenue, Citibank unexpectedly announced yesterday that it would consolidate virtually all its worldwide advertising and direct marketing assignments at a single agency company, Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Vamping the Vampire
description: Alloy Orchestra, Prospect Park Band Shell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-8954. Perhaps more than any other silent film, F. W. Murnau's 1929 Expressionist classic ''Nosferatu'' has inspired dozens of composers and interpreters to try their hand at a live score in New York City in the last decade. From Liminal's modern ambient soundtrack incorporating turntables at the Knitting Factory to the chilling renditions Lee Erwin used to perform on the massive organ at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, every score has opened up new ways of understanding the film. The Alloy Orchestra from Boston, fast becoming the country's leading avant-garde interpreter of silent films, is a half-quirky, half-serious outfit more than capable of adding extra menace to the long bony hands and slow, malevolent gait of Murnau's vampire. The performance is tonight at 7:30; admission is free. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERTZ, ALISON
description: GERTZ-Alison. Feb. 27, 1966 to Aug. 8, 1992. ''...Do not stand at my grave and cry, I am not there, I did not die.''

title: Home Video
description: Just 139 Shopping Days Left

title: Suspect Is Sought In Rapes in Queens
description: Queens detectives were searching yesterday for a man believed to be responsible for a series of rapes in Sunnyside and Long Island City.

title: Ripple Effect Likely From Citibank Move
description: The decision yesterday by the Citibank unit of Citicorp to consolidate almost all advertising and direct marketing tasks at Young & Rubicam Inc. may affect other Y.& R. accounts.

title: Frantic Poetry on Piano
description: Cecil Taylor began his annual stay at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night, and played an unbroken novella, emphatically proceeding chapter by chapter. The first set was standard-issue Taylor, not one of the breathtaking highs he can provide (and often does), but a perfect primer for those who haven't heard him before.

title: Johnson's The Name; His Gold Is In Hurdles
description: If he is destined to remain the ''other'' Johnson, so be it. At the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, Allen Johnson happened to win the 110-meter hurdles the same night that Michael Johnson won the 400 meters and Carl Lewis won the long jump. Few noticed, but in his own way, Allen Johnson is becoming as dominant as Michael Johnson at major championships.

title: Utility Sued Over Millstone 3 Closing
description: In an unusual battle between Connecticut utilities, the United Illuminating Company filed suit today against the troubled Northeast Utilities over its management of the Millstone 3 nuclear power plant, which the two companies own together.

title: 2 Held as Leaders of Ring Involving Deaf Immigrants
description: Ending a manhunt that had stretched from the subways of Queens to the barrios of Mexico City, United States and Mexican law enforcement officials arrested two men yesterday on charges of leading an operation that smuggled dozens of deaf Mexicans across the border and forced them to live in virtual slavery by peddling trinkets in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago.

title: PACIFIC ENTERPRISES AND ENOVA TO BUY AIG TRADING
description: The Enova Corporation and Pacific Enterprises said yesterday that they had agreed to buy the AIG Trading Corporation, a natural gas and electricity marketer, for $190 million in cash. AIG Trading, based in Greenwich, Conn., is a subsidiary of the American International Group, the New York-based insurance company. Enova, parent of San Diego Gas and Electric, and Pacific Enterprises, parent of the Southern California Gas Company, said they would split the cost of the acquisition. Enova announced in October that it planned to buy Pacific Enterprises.

title: Supermarket Expansion
description: Jeffrey Wu, an entrepreneur, has bought the former administration building of the Green Point Financial Corporation at 41-60 Main Street in Flushing, Queens, for $8.7 million and plans to open a unit of his supermarket chain, Hong Kong Supermarkets, catering to the heavily Asian community there, executives involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Joan Erikson Is Dead at 95; Shaped Thought on Life Cycles
description: Joan Mowat Erikson, who helped reshape the prevailing psychological view of human development through a six-decade, all-senses collaboration with her husband, Erik Erikson, and still found time to pursue her own interests in arts and crafts, education and dance, died on Sunday at a nursing home in Brewster, Mass. She was 95.

title: Little Flexibility Seen in Talks Between Teamsters and U.P.S.
description: Leaders of the teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to end the four-day-old strike, but their public statements indicated little flexibility from either side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, HENRY B.
description: ROTH-Henry B. Born Brooklyn, New York, on June 10, 1908. Previously resided in New York City, Mamaroneck, NY, Los Angeles, CA, La Quinta, CA. Died August 4, 1997 at his residence in Montecito, California. Survived by his wife Babette Langdon Roth.

title: Diplomat to Make Trip to Urge Reduction of U.S. Dues to U.N.
description: Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that he would make a round-the-world trip beginning on Monday to persuade key countries to support reduced American payments to the organization.

title: Dispute Emerges on Cause of Brooklyn Building Collapse
description: Engineers for the city and the landlords of a five-story building in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn yesterday offered starkly different explanations for the building's collapse, as tenants claimed belongings rescued from debris by the police.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKEMORE, FRANCES L.
description: BLAKEMORE-Frances L. Age 91, died August 1 in Seattle, Washington. Born June 19, 1906 in Pana, Illinois. Well-known artist who lived and worked in Tokyo from 1935 to 1989. Author of Modern Japanese Prints, Japanese Design and other works. Her paintings and prints have been exhibited in Japan and the United States. Owner of Franell Gallery in Okura Hotel in Tokyo. In W.W. II she was with Office of War Information and during subsequent occupation of Japan was Chief of Exhibits at the American Embassy, Tokyo. She and her husband, Thomas L. Blakemore, who predeceased her in 1994, established the Blakemore Foundation in 1990 to promote Asian language study and create a better understanding of Asian art. Memorial services at 10:00 a.m. Wednesday, August 20, at Columbia Lutheran Home, 4700 Phinney Ave. North, Seattle. Remembrances are suggested to the Seattle Asian Art Museum, P.O. Box 22000, Seattle, WA 98122-9700.

title: Sure He's Paranoid, And With Good Reason
description: AT last we have a summer movie hero who likes a good book. Unfortunately, he likes only one book (''The Catcher in the Rye,'' so popular with dangerous crackpots). And he happens to be halfway out of his mind. Jerry Fletcher (Mel Gibson) keeps a beer bottle balanced on his doorknob, not to mention a lock and label on his tapioca pudding supply. He thinks that Jerry Garcia is still alive, that Oliver Stone is in cahoots with George Bush, and that water main breaks in New York City are not the accidents they seem. He thinks strange forces are everywhere.

title: No Headline
description: ''I was trying to make a point that I am chairman of the Agriculture Committee. That may have limited jurisdiction. The one thing it does talk about from time to time is tobacco.''

description: Crash

title: Fear and Famine in North Korea
description: Two months of drought and scorching heat has turned North Korea into a veritable oven enclosing 24 million people. The normally green fields squeezed onto and around the mountains of this reclusive country are now a sickly brown. Visitors report that undernourished people walk listlessly on the streets of Pyongyang, and relief agencies fear that a looming famine, following two years of floods and economic dislocation, will scythe down the very young and old. It is not the doctrines of Marx but of Malthus that now shape this isolated and fanatical Communist fortress.

title: WDBZ Is Optioned To 2 Broadcasters
description: The Chancellor Broadcasting Company and the Evergreen Media Corporation have bought an option to acquire WDBZ-FM in New York from Bonneville International as part of a transaction that includes the companies swapping several stations in Washington, Houston and Los Angeles.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: A Saint Besieged: Heaven Knows, Many Need Help
description: Unable to feed his family after losing his job as a welder last year, Roberto Fuentes went to church on Wednesday afternoon to petition St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASENCIO, MARIA
description: ASENCIO-Maria. 9/6/39 to 8/6/97. Passed away Wednesday. Loving and devoted wife to Alfredo. Proud and adoring mother to Arlene, Deborah and Paul. Doting grandmother to Conor and Nina. She will be remembered for her generous spirit, caring soul and her love of laughter. Wake at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, 2-5 and 7-10, Saturday and Sunday. Mass at 10 A.M., Monday, at St. Peter's and St. Paul's, 190 Court Street.

title: Big Lies and Little Green Men
description: The Central Intelligence Agency's admission that the Air Force lied about supposed sightings of unidentified flying objects three decades ago to conceal the Government's secret high-altitude spy planes comes as wonderful news to the flying saucer crowd. They are already hailing the agency's disclosure as proof that aliens must have landed in Roswell, N.M.

title: Williams Likely to Stay a Net
description: Coach John Calipari has yet to sit down for a peace summit with Jayson Williams, but it is looking more likely that the two will find a way to coexist next season on the Nets.

title: Frank F. Furstenberg, Doctor, 92
description: Dr. Frank Folke Furstenberg, a Baltimore physician and an advocate of national health care legislation in the 1940's, died on Tuesday at his home. He was 92 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHER, ETTA
description: SCHACHER-Etta. We mourn the passing of the mother of our esteemed member, Henry Schachar, and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Compromise With Unions On Workfare
description: Responding to union complaints about his workfare program, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has reached an agreement with several municipal unions, pledging to provide adequate health and safety protections for workfare participants and asserting that they are not intended to displace regular city employees.

title: Tug-of-War Over Airbus Restructuring Heats Up
description: PARIS  When Airbus complains about Boeing's competitive advantages, the European manufacturer knows what it is talking about: More than anything else, industry executives say in Europe, Airbus needs and wants to become more like its U.S. rival.

title: Airport to Be Discussed
description: One week after a Federal Express cargo plane flipped over and caught fire while landing at Newark International Airport, Federal officials and transportation experts will meet today to discuss the future of the airport.

title: Computer Wins at Othello
description: Could Monopoly be next? Only months after the reigning chess champion was brought down by a computer, the world's best Othello player lost a six-game series yesterday to another machine.

title: Gulf War Data on Internet Harmed U.S. Spy Efforts, Report Says
description: An internal investigation by the Central Intelligence Agency has found that the release of hundreds of intelligence reports on the Pentagon's Internet site for veterans of the Persian Gulf war did ''serious damage to intelligence sources and methods,'' a new Congressional report says.

title: Housing Group Is Called Victim Of Embezzler
description: The former office manager of a real estate company has been charged with embezzling $119,000 from the Grand Street Housing Guild, a nonprofit organization that receives Federal housing funds for a low-income housing development on the Lower East Side.

title: DuPont to Invest $1.7 Billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it would invest $1.7 billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., creating a powerful rival to the Monsanto Company and others in the fast-growing business of genetically engineered agriculture.

title: 10 Cloned Cows Soon to Be Born, Company Reports, Duplicating a Lamb Experiment
description: A small company in Wisconsin has developed a highly efficient cloning method and has used it to make genetic replicas of more than 10 adult cows, the company's research director disclosed yesterday in an interview.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What's a Hollywood star to do between projects? GWYNETH PALTROW, who has three movies ready for release and who is contemplating what to do next, has moved into a new field: magazine editing.

title: Moral Censorship?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Mongolia, Lunging Toward Enlightenment
description: If you're looking to flee the vexations of modern urban life, try Mongolia as it is revealed in Marie Jaoul de Poncheville's film ''Molom: A Legend of Mongolia.'' To visit this world of yert-dwelling nomadic herders, shamans and Buddhist monks is almost to step out of time, entering a region where names like Madonna or the two Bills (Gates and Clinton) mean nothing and the rolling prairie once ruled by Genghis Khan evokes stupendous distances of time and space.

title: The Bauhaus: Utopian Ideas and Constant Uproar
description: BAUHAUS

title: A Bear Confronts a Bird
description: For a thoroughly entertaining lesson in the fine art of theatrical finesse, few New York productions at the moment can match the National Actors Theater revival of ''The Gin Game.'' Each night at the Lyceum Theater, two wonderful old pros, Julie Harris and Charles Durning, reassuringly demonstrate that the smallest of gestures on a Broadway stage still have the power to surprise and to move.

title: Strike Points to Inequality in 2-Tier Job Market
description: In 1982, when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters first agreed to a lower pay scale for part-time workers at United Parcel Service, recently hired part-timers earned $9 an hour, or just $4 less than a full-timer with the same tenure. Today, the part-timers, mostly people who sort packages, still earn $9 an hour while full-timers, mainly the men and women in brown who drive U.P.S. delivery trucks, earn nearly $20.

title: Stockholders of Lilco and Brooklyn Union Ratify Merger of Companies
description: At their final annual meetings of the Long Island Lighting Company and Brooklyn Union Gas as separate companies, stockholders of both utilities overwhelmingly ratified a merger today that is expected to be completed next year.

title: Blunt Words By Albright To Players In Mideast
description: Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on Middle East policy, delivered on Wednesday at the National Press Club and transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: Treasury Issues Slip After Government Sale
description: Treasury securities stumbled yesterday after the final leg of the Government's quarterly debt refunding disappointed traders and a surge of new corporate debt came to market.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Time Stands Still
description: Arthur Doyle Quartet, Alterknit Theater, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. On a good night, Arthur Doyle, one of the unsung free-jazz saxophonists of the late 60's, can make time stand still: huffing, puffing, honking, bleating and making all kinds of vocal intonations through the saxophone. On a bad night, he just sounds as if he needs to be oiled. He performs tomorrow night at 9; admission is $8. N. S.

title: Peter Carruthers, 61, Physicist
description: Peter Ambler Carruthers, a physicist at the University of Arizona and former head of the theoretical division at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, died on Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 61.

title: 3 Are Killed as Cargo Plane Crashes in Miami
description: A cargo plane crashed today during takeoff near Miami International Airport, killing at least three people but narrowly averting a potentially higher death toll in the busy commercial area of small warehouses and businesses where it fell.

title: Second Prominent Democrat Forgoes Race Against Pataki
description: In what many Democrats view as a dismaying new sign of their struggling party's inability to regain power, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the highest ranking Democrat in state government, announced today that he would not seek his party's nomination for governor next year.

title: A Union Is Criticized for a Message of Solidarity
description: In a sideshow skirmish to the United Parcel Service strike, Houston officials today denounced an apparent suggestion by an official for a local police union that city police officers harass people driving U.P.S. trucks.

title: A Protest Threat, Then a Plan to Ease River Access
description: For decades, anglers along the Hudson River have been drawn to the wrong side of the tracks -- the side with the water on it. They've risked fines and arrest for unlawfully crossing the railroad tracks, just to get to the best fishing spots.

title: Healing The Wounds
description: How can a society torn apart by racial or ethnic conflict be made whole again? We know about the effort at healing in post-apartheid South Africa. But not many Americans are aware of the example in our own hemisphere: Guatemala. Or aware of our responsibility there.

title: Dentist Is Charged In Sex Abuse of Patient
description: An Upper East Side dentist was arrested yesterday after a patient reported that she awoke from anesthesia to find him clad only in a pair of high black socks.

title: A Makeover May Change More Than Columbia
description: Adopting drastic changes in the way it does business, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has begun transforming itself into a company far different from the one that upended the once-sleepy hospital world over the last nine years.

title: Europe and U.S. In Accord on Textiles
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it was dropping a case with the World Trade Organization over American import regulations on textiles, after a decision by the United States to accommodate European demands. The Commission said the United States had agreed to amend rules that designate the origin of a textile product based on the source of the raw materials used rather than the place where the raw materials are processed. Under the rules, a scarf made of Chinese silk but dyed and printed in Italy would have had to carry a ''made in China'' label in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUBINI, EUGENE G.
description: FUBINI-Eugene G., of Brookline, MA., Tuesday, August 5, formerly of Washington, DC. Beloved husband of the late Jane Elizabeth. Devoted father of David G. Fubini, Dr. Susan Todd Hunter, Carol Fubini, Laurie Jacobs, Dr. Sandra Willwerth and Dr. Sylvia Fubini. He is also survived by sixteen grandchildren. Memorial service at The Cosmos Club, Washington, DC, Fri., September 5 at 3:00PM. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the California Institute of Technology, Office of Stewardship, Mail Code: 105-40, Pasadena, CA. 91125.

description: To the Editor:

title: PIZZA HUT PLANS TO SELL 148 RESTAURANTS TO PACPIZZA
description: Pepsico Inc.'s Pizza Hut unit said yesterday that it would sell 148 Pizza Hut restaurants in California, Oregon and Nevada to Pacpizza L.L.C. for an undisclosed amount. The deal would make Pacpizza, based in San Ramon, Calif., the company's second-largest franchisee, after NPC International of Pittsburg, Kan. The sale is part of a Pepsico strategy to spin off its Taco Bell, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut restaurant chains by the end of the year and focus on selling salty snacks through its Frito-Lay division and on selling soft drinks. Pacpizza is a new company formed by Provender Capital Group L.L.C., a New York-based merchant banking firm. Pepsico shares fell 68.75 cents yesterday, to $39.

title: Second Avenue Fair
description: Strollers along Second Avenue in Manhattan can eat, dance and shop their way from 46th to 56th Streets on Sunday during the avenue's Third Summerfest. The street fair, sponsored by the East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue, runs from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. and features over 200 vendors. Stages offering performances of music magic and mime will be at 48th and 55th Streets. Admission is free. Information: (212) 809-4900.

title: Hikind Faces U.S. Charges In Payoff Case
description: Assemblyman Dov Hikind, whose success in bringing home government dollars to his Brooklyn neighborhood won him both popularity and political influence, was indicted yesterday on charges of receiving at least $40,000 in payoffs from officials of a social-service group for which he had obtained public grants.

title: Fight Teen-Age Smoking With Facts, Not Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: The lobby of the SoHo Grand Hotel, with its faux subway gratings and realistic-looking fake dogs, is as severe and self-conscious as an art gallery. It has such a seriously Magritte air that you find yourself searching for the sign saying ''Ceci n'est pas un hotel.''

title: Chief Resigns At Kodak's Imaging Unit
description: After struggling without success for a year and a half to get the Eastman Kodak Company's troubled digital imaging business on track, Robert M. Unterberger resigned yesterday as the division's president. He was immediately replaced by Willy C. Shih, who left Silicon Graphics Inc. just a month ago to be the unit's No. 2 executive.

title: Consumer Credit Growth Stalls As Demand for Car Loans Drops
description: Borrowing by American consumers unexpectedly stalled in June, as demand for auto financing and other personal loans declined. It was the first month without an increase in consumer borrowing in more than four years.

title: INSIDE
description: Backlash Against Israel

title: Even If City Doesn't Sleep, Mayor Should
description: WHEN you think about it, the most interesting part of this flapdoodle over the state of the union at Gracie Mansion is what it tells us about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's frenetic work habits. This is an issue that surfaces from time to time, and it is back once again, with the Mayor trying to use it to advantage in his re-election campaign.

title: Petersen Plans Stock Offering

title: Brazil's Violent Police

Police in that country are the most brutal in the hemisphere, as feared in poor neighborhoods as any criminal gang. This summer, police in a dozen states have gone on strike for higher pay. They deserve raises, but increases should come with new policies that discourage violence and prosecute policemen who kill.

title: KROLL ASSOCIATES AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED FOR $89 MILLION
description: Kroll Associates, the closely held international detective agency, has agreed to be acquired for $89 million by the O'Gara Company, a publicly traded security services company. Shares of O'Gara soared on the news as much as 31 percent. They closed at $15, up $2.875. Under the terms of the deal, O'Gara will issue 6.75 million shares to acquire all of Kroll's outstanding stock and options, and will assume its debt. Jules Kroll, the founder of the detective agency, will be chairman and chief executive of the new company, which will be called the Kroll-O'Gara Company.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS GAINS FROM CABLE OPERATIONS
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said operating cash flow from its United States cable operations rose 16 percent in the second quarter, even as it lost cable subscribers. Tele-Communications will release full results on Wednesday. The nation's largest cable television operator said cash flow rose to $706 million, from $609 million in the second quarter of the year earlier. Results for the 1996 quarter are pro forma to include cable systems bought and sold since that quarter, and to exclude its Primestar unit, which was spun off to shareholders in December, and its telephone business, which is no longer counted as part of the cable operations. Leo Hindery, president and chief operating officer, attributed the cash flow improvement to lower costs and operating margins that increased to 44 percent from 40.6 percent.

title: STARWOOD LODGING TO BUY 15 HOTELS FOR $470 MILLION
description: Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 15 hotels from the closely held Flatley Company for $470 million. The hotels, with more than 4,000 rooms, are in the Northeastern United States. The largest of the hotels are the 442-room Tara Stamford Hotel in Stamford, Conn., and the 383-room Sheraton Tara Hotel in Parsippany, N.J. The deal also includes four golf courses. Starwood, a Phoenix-based real estate investment trust, said it expects to close the deal in mid-September. Eight of the properties are operated under the Sheraton name, one is a Hilton and six are operated independently under the Tara name, the company said. Tara Hotels is a unit of the Boston-based Flatley Company.

title: Casting Call for Candidates

Mr. McCall had been regarded as Mr. Pataki's toughest potential challenger ever since Representative Charles Schumer, the previous toughest potential challenger, backed out of the race. Someone has to run against Mr. Pataki. Mr. McCall has one of the strongest political resumes in the state. His analyses of the precarious economics of Mr. Pataki's budgets are compelling, and a McCall-Pataki campaign might have provided a useful education for the voters.

Shares of Omnicare slipped 62.5 cents, to $30. Omnicare, based in Cincinnati, provides pharmacy and consulting services at about 4,400 long-term- care facilities. description: The vitamin maker NBTY Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Holland & Barrett, a British health-food retailer, from Germany's GEHE A.G. for $168.8 million. The acquisition will nearly double the annual sales of the company, to $430 million a year, the company said. The addition of the 410 Holland & Barrett stores will quintuple the number of retail outlets controlled by NBTY, maker of Nature's Bounty and Vitamin World brands.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COGNIZANT CORP., Westport, Conn., agreed to sell Pilot Software Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a supplier of customer and market analysis software, to Platinum Equity Holdings of Los Angeles, for undisclosed terms.

title: Zulu-Based Party Quits Talks in South Africa
description: Angry over testimony before South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission that linked the Inkatha Freedom Party to assassination squads, Inkatha leaders said today that they would break off negotiations with the African National Congress to end political violence in the troubled province of KwaZulu/Natal.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELIAS, RALPH
description: ELIAS-Ralph. Dear Pope. Loving thoughts on your birthday. From Doris, Ralph, Maggie, Mary, Peter, Mark, Julie and John

title: After a Steady Climb in Europe, She's at Home With Her Lieder
description: It was impossible to enter Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night without being stopped by someone trying to get a ticket for the sold-out recital by the American soprano Barbara Bonney, presented by the Mostly Mozart Festival. This was her Lincoln Center recital debut, and the recognition must have been gratifying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SIDNEY
description: SIMON-Sidney. The Sculptors Guild deeply mourns the passing of its longtime member, Sidney Simon. His wisdom, charm and many diverse contributions to the Guild will be long remembered and his fine sculpture creates a living memorial. We wish to extend our sympathy to his family.

title: Ban Land Mines
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBLATT, IRA
description: WEINBLATT-Ira, on August 6, 1997. Lovingly remembered for his heart & laughter by wife Judy, daughters Amy, Jennifer, Emily, brother Jules, sister-in-law Elaine, niece Margery, nephew Michael, granddaughter Lucy, son-in-law Phillip, and close circle of friends. Memorial services Sunday 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Remembrances may be made to the New York Public Library, Room 67.

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH SYSTEMS EXPECTS 2D-QUARTER LOSS
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would have a second-quarter loss after taking pretax charges of $405.9 million, more than expected, to cover costs from the April merger that formed the company. The nation's fourth-largest managed-care company was created through the $1.34 billion combination of the Foundation Health Corporation and Health Systems International Inc. In filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the companies originally estimated charges of $175 million to $225 million. Excluding the effect of the charges, Foundation Health, of Woodland Hills, Calif., said it expects to report earnings Tuesday of 49 cents to 51 cents a share.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about job cuts at Fruit of the Loom factories overstated the extent of the cuts. The company plans to eliminate 4,800 jobs at six plants, not 5,100 at seven plants.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIRARDOT, CLAIRE LILY
description: GIRARDOT-Claire Lily. Her son Christopher, her mother Mamie are inconsolable over their loss of Claire Lily Girardot on August 9, 1996. She was the niece of Lily Pons. Please think of her affectionately. Once again, we would like to express our thanks and appreciation to her doctor and the entire staff at Lenox Hill Hospital, Park Avenue, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, BERKLEY
description: MATTHEWS-Berkley. You were the light of our lives. We will so miss your extraordinary friendship-your calm wisdom, your intense loyalty, your reliable sense of values, your outstanding creativity-not only in art, but in life as well, your wonderfully quirky sense of humor, your ability to overlook your own undeniable angelic beauty, and so very much more. We treasure our memories of you, Berkley, and send our deepest sympathy to your family. May they know that you will exist in our hearts and minds forever. All our love, all our lives, all the time. Emily I., Lindsay, Sarah, Dixie, Alison, Emily M., Dave, Brian, Cuyler, Roo, Matt and all of your Taft friends.

title: Nomura Securities Fined For Racketeer Dealings
description: The Nomura Securities Company will be fined a total of 200 million yen, or $1.7 million, by the Tokyo Stock Exchange and the Japan Securities Dealers Association for illegally channeling funds to a racketeer, the organizations said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUGHNEY, SR. CECILIA
description: HAUGHNEY-Sr. Cecilia Mary on August 8, 1997. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and Pharmacist at St. Vincent's Hospital, Staten Island for many years. Survived by several cousins. Reposing at Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, New York, Sunday 1-8 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10 A.M. at the Convent. Interment following at St. Joseph's Cemetery.

title: A Month on Mars and the Pathfinder Is Declared a Total Success
description: The Pathfinder spacecraft has transmitted almost 10,000 pictures from Mars. Its roving companion Sojourner has traversed some 165 feet of Martian surface, closing in on a circumnavigation of the landing site. And still both are going strong after more than a month exploring the rocky flood plain of Ares Vallis.

title: MCI Enters Local Call Market in New York Area
description: The MCI Communications Corporation began offering local residential telephone service in New York City and its nearby suburbs yesterday, becoming the first major competitor for Nynex's four million customers in the region.

title: A Meeting That Transformed The U.S. Stance in the Mideast
description: On June 19, after one more trip to the Middle East by a special Presidential envoy had ended in failure, President Clinton gathered his Vice President and senior foreign policy advisers in the Oval Office for a basic rethinking of their strategy in the region.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHENKIN, BEATRICE G.
description: CHENKIN-Beatrice G. 1920-1988. Nine years have passed but your memory still fills my days. Alvin.

title: Survey of American Jews Didn't Exaggerate Interfaith Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REID, NORMA H.
description: REID-Norma H. Died on August 3, 1997. Beloved mother of Jordanna, caring daughter of Roderick and Eileen Reid, devoted sister of Franklin Reid, Bertram Reid, Carmen Gray, Irma Reid, Carlton Reid, Yvonne Reid, Ruby Reid, Colleen Reid, Sandra Yearwood, Wayne Reid, Francis Reid. Cherished friend. Visiting on Thursday August 7, 7-9PM and Friday, Aug 8, 2-5PM, 7-9PM at John J. McManus & Sons, 2001 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn. Funeral Saturday, August 9, 9AM at Vanderveer Park Methodist Church, 3114 Glenwood Rd, Bklyn.

title: Blood Center Workers Guilty in Tampering
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan convicted two former supervisors of the New York Blood Center Thursday on charges of conspiring to tamper with tests to screen blood for the AIDS virus and other infectious diseases as a way of taking short cuts.

title: Brazil Auctions Mobile Phone Rights
description: Brazil raised $1.74 billion yesterday through the sale of mobile telephone licenses, as groups led by Telia A.B. of Sweden and the BellSouth Corporation bid handsomely for entry into one of the last big emerging telephone markets. The auctions -- more than double the Government-set floor prices -- bring to 5.11 billion reais the amount Brazil has raised by selling rights to offer cellular service on a new bandwidth.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about four victims of the terrorist bombing in a Jerusalem market on July 30 referred incorrectly to shiva, the seven-day Jewish mourning period. It should not have been described as a wake, which is a watch over the corpse; by Jewish custom the dead are buried within 24 hours. Visitors paying condolence calls should not have been described as ''sitting shiva,'' which describes the weeklong vigil performed only by the bereaved family.

title: Els, Who Refuses to Be Unnerved, Shoots a 63
description: One of the traits that make Ernie Els a great golfer is his unflappable nature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABEL, REUBEN
description: ABEL-Reuben. The New School and its Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science have lost a deeply beloved and respected member on the passing of Reuben Abel. The University extends its heartfelt condolences to his wife, Marion; their children, Richard and Elizabeth; and their four grandchildren. Reuben Abel has been part of our community since 1938. After receiving the Ph.D. in Philosophy at the New School in 1952, he taught for four decades in the Graduate Faculty and other academic divisions. His gifted teaching, animated conversation, and uplifting disposition will be greatly missed. Jonathan F. Fanton, President, New School Judith N. Friedlander, Dean of the Graduate Faculty

title: Everett Fails to Get Custody
description: Carl Everett rejoined the Mets yesterday after failing to regain custody of the two children who are being held by the New York City Administration for Children's Services. The next action in the case is expected Monday, with the children to remain in foster care through the weekend.

title: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE ADDING DESERT MOUNTAIN
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company said yesterday that it had bought Arizona's Desert Mountain residential development for $229 million from the Mobil Corporation and the investor Lyle Anderson, marking the end of the oil company's foray into the real estate business. The property includes 8,300 acres in the high Sonoran desert that is zoned for the development of more than 4,500 lots, as well as the Desert Mountain Club, a private golf, tennis and fitness club with 1,600 members. Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., in December sold 18 planned communities to Westbrook Partners L.L.C. for $324 million.

title: In Quitting, Scientists Say Beach Repair Is Foolhardy
description: Accusing the Army Corps of Engineers of ignoring Federal environmental law in a rush to begin a $60 million dune- and beach-rebuilding project on Fire Island, two biologists resigned their Government jobs yesterday in protest.

title: John B. Elliott, 69, Art Collector
description: John Brailsford Elliott, a former chairman of the National Data Corporation who was a leading collector of Chinese art, died on July 25 at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. He lived in Princeton, N.J., and was 69.

title: Evidence in Crash on Guam Is Reported to Indicate Pilot Error
description: Newly gathered evidence points to pilot error rather than mechanical failure as the cause of the Korean Air Lines jumbo jet crash here that killed 225 of the 254 people on board, United States officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZINAMAN, HENRIETTA
description: ZINAMAN - Henrietta. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of Jules and Lawrence (Dick). Dear mother-in-law of Lynn. Cherished grandmother of Joanne Bross, James, Steven and Dr. Michael Zinaman. Dear greatgrandmother. Services were held.

title: Grandson of Betty Shabazz Is Sentenced to a Juvenile Center
description: Malcolm Shabazz, the 12-year-old grandson of Malcolm X and Dr. Betty Shabazz who set a fire that killed his grandmother, was sentenced today to one of the few juvenile detention centers in the nation that accepts arsonists, the Hillcrest Center in Lenox, Mass.

title: Appeals Court to Review Blades Acquittal
description: An appeals court in West Palm Beach, Fla., will review whether a trial judge was justified in overturning the verdict of a jury that convicted the Seattle Seahawks receiver BRIAN BLADES of manslaughter.

title: Rape-Drug Bill Is Signed
description: A rape conviction could result in a 20-year prison sentence if the victim was incapacitated by a so-called date rape drug, under legislation that was signed yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Parcel Strike Could Be Long, Union Says

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOVE, CURTIS
description: SOLOVE-Curtis. On Aug. 6, 1997. Rest in peace. I miss you. Until we meet again, Lester E. Brody

title: Clinton Unveils Plan to Battle Diabetes
description: President Clinton today announced an effort to combat diabetes.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword on Thursday gave an incorrect clue for 13 Across. Referring to the answer ''USOC,'' it should have said, ''Sports org. based in Colorado Springs,'' not in Boulder.

title: Boldon Wins Gold At Last, Taking 200
description: When he finished fifth at 100 meters last Sunday, Ato Boldon of Trinidad had to live with the world champion being a close friend and training partner, Maurice Greene.

title: Minister Is Found Stabbed to Death
description: An elderly woman who only two years ago became an ordained Baptist minister was found stabbed to death yesterday in the living room of her Brooklyn home.

title: Babies and Methadone
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall St.'s Dark Day: 3 Markets in a Slump
description: Stock and bond prices and the value of the dollar all fell sharply yesterday. Many analysts said the selloffs might have come simply because all three markets had recently moved too far, too fast and were susceptible to falling.

title: Garth, Nice Guy, Balancing Lust and Love
description: A jealous trucker kills his wife by driving his rig through a hotel window. A drunk disrupts his ex-girlfriend's wedding. A widow seduces a teen-age boy in a wheatfield. The ghost of a suicide haunts a beach. Just another night of programming on HBO? Yes and no. They were the story lines for some of the more striking songs that Garth Brooks sang during his concert on Thursday night in the North Meadow of Central Park, which was broadcast live on HBO. And those songs stuck out in Mr. Brooks's set like peppercorns in a cheese.

title: Homeless Site Is Raided Beneath the Boardwalk
description: For decades, the homeless have slept in makeshift shelters underneath the Atlantic City Boardwalk, disturbing tourists and occasionally snatching bags from unattended blankets on the beach, the police say. But this summer, the Atlantic City Police Department began a new effort to make the beaches safer with a series of intensive, unannounced sweeps.

title: The Chandlers' Investment In Times Mirror Will Be Cut
description: The Chandler family, which founded and controls the Times Mirror Company, reached a deal with the company yesterday that will give the family more current income and diversify its investments, at the cost of cutting its stake in the company. Times Mirror publishes such newspapers as The Los Angeles Times, Newsday, The Baltimore Sun and The Hartford Courant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, PAULINE
description: FISCHER-Pauline, 98. Devoted wife of the late Jack; loving mother of Bill and Stuart, Iris (Stanley) Aronson and Carol and Howard Schleien; loving sister of Esther Nathanson; adoring grandmother of ten grandchildren and fifteen great grandchildren. Pauline Fischer, along with her husband Jack, ran the famous Little Oriental Restaurant in Brooklyn. Services on Sunday, 12 Noon, ''Parkside'' Chapels, at 66th Avenue and Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Woman Who Killed Baby Called Her Mother First
description: Before Debra Barnes slashed her baby's throat and then turned the knife on herself Thursday evening, she called her mother and told her what she was about to do, neighbors said: kill herself and the baby. Then she hung up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBERT, HARRIS
description: GILBERT-Harris, Friday, August 8th, 1997, of Westfield. Beloved husband of Sally (nee Klein). Devoted father of Carol and Jeffrey Singer and Bruce and Beth Gilbert. Loving grandfather of Matthew, Michael, Ryan, Jamie and Tori. Funeral services conducted 10:00 A.M. Sunday, August 10, 1997 from Temple Emanu-el, 756 East Broad Street, Westfield, N.J. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Harris Gilbert Fund For Social Justice at Temple Emanu-el, Westfield, N.J. Information: the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: 4 Days in a Life Where the Grass Was Greener
description: Back when she was a municipal judge in Ohio, draped in bland but comforting black robes and following a daily timetable more or less of her own design, Deborah Pryce thought life on Capitol Hill must be all ''chandeliers and limousines.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, MAX D.
description: BLUESTONE-Max D. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Devoted father of Carol & Martin McClain, Stewart and Fran Bluestone and Ellen and Jay Shillman. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Judith, Sarah, Michael, Jenny and Jacob. Dear brother of Irving Bluestone and the late Sybil Silverberg. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, Sunday at 1:30 P.M.

title: Petroleum Chief Resigns At Broken Hill
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company, an Australian mining, steel and energy group, said yesterday that the chief executive of its petroleum unit had resigned after the board of directors blocked his attempt to split off the division. The Broken Hill chairman, Jerry Ellis, said that the resignation of the petroleum chief, John O'Connor, ''was essentially to do with the ownership of the company's assets.''

title: Democrat Denies Intent to Delay Evidence
description: In the continued bickering between the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses and the Democratic Party, the party chairman said today that there was ''no intention to withhold or delay'' the handing over of Democratic documents and that a recent failure to do so was ''an innocent mistake.''

title: The Brain Drain
description: My male friends tell me that I generalize too much about men. That's so true. It's one of the flaws of women generally.

title: Disrupting Sales at Greyhound, Disabled Protest Bus Access
description: More than a dozen handicapped demonstrators rolled their wheelchairs in front of a Greyhound bus and disrupted ticket sales for four hours yesterday afternoon at the Port Authority terminal in Manhattan to protest what they said was their lack of access to the largest interstate bus company's buses.

title: Purple in the Oval Office: You Can't Make This Up
description: Separately, Elvis Presley and Richard Nixon had enough power, paranoia and megalomania to fill several shelves of history and psychology books. Think what they might have done together. The product of their only meeting is now a popular item at the Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif.: a photograph taken in the Oval Office of the President and the drug-addicted pop idol, who had a fancy to become a Federal marshal in the war against drugs.

title: Microsoft Monopoly? Not So Fast
description: Many Macintosh devotees contend that Bill Gates's $150 million investment in Apple Computers will emasculate this last outpost of opposition to Microsoft's implacable operating system. Nonsense. Microsoft's involvement gives Apple a chance to regain its lost footing in the personal computer marketplace. Whether Apple succeeds will be determined by its willingness and resolve to reinvent itself and change the P.C. market as dramatically as it did 15 years ago.

title: China's Growth Slowed in July
description: China's benchmark measure of industrial output grew 8.4 percent in July, the slowest rate in more than three years. The State Statistics Bureau said value-added industrial output for the month totaled 162.5 billion yuan, or $19.5 billion, blaming an extra holiday and the summer heat wave for the dip.

title: As Slopes Warm Up, the Sound of Festivals
description: From a musical kernel planted here half a century ago, summer arts festivals have taken root in the Rockies, spreading this year like alpine wildflowers to 13 Colorado ski towns.

title: Race Wasn't Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeing the Kennebec River
description: A small Federal agency that few Americans pay attention to is about to do something that deserves not only attention but applause. For the first time in its history, the staff of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has recommended that an operating hydroelectric dam, the privately owned Edwards Dam on Maine's Kennebec River, be dismantled. If the full commission approves, as expected, nine species of Atlantic fish will soon have access to their traditional spawning grounds upriver from the dam, and with any luck will multiply.

title: USF&G IN AGREEMENT TO BUY TITAN HOLDINGS
description: The USF&G Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Titan Holdings Inc., an insurance company, for $234 million in cash and stock, plus the assumption of debt. USF&G, based in Baltimore, is also an insurance company. Titan Holdings, based in San Antonio, operates Titan Auto, which writes nonstandard auto insurance, and Titan Public Entity, which insures small-to-medium-size towns and counties. For the year ended Dec. 31, 1996, Titan reported net income of $14.2 million, or $1.48 a share. Under the agreement, Titan shareholders will receive $11.60 in cash plus 0.46516 share of USF&G common stock for each Titan share held, for a total of $23.20 per Titan share.

title: Honor Athletes on the Field, Not in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Five Decades of Care and Caring
description: One thing Irving Gorin knows is that time flies when you're having fun.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and a picture caption about the Beat writer William S. Burroughs on Monday, and in some late editions on Sunday, referred incompletely to the origin of his title for the novel ''Naked Lunch.'' Although it was Allen Ginsberg who misread part of a manuscript by Burroughs as ''naked lunch'' -- rather than ''naked lust'' -- it was Jack Kerouac who said the phrase would make a good title.

title: Bringing Some Water To the Desert
description: THE first thing that struck Tony Samuel about New Mexico was the sharp contrast between this desert spot and Lincoln, Neb. Lincoln had been home for 14 years, three as a player at Nebraska, 11 as an assistant coach. Midwest. Bitter cold and snow in the winter. Hot summers. Flat, endless plains.

title: Mets Boost Bullpen In Deal With Cubs
description: Steve Phillips and Ed Lynch traded more than a dozen proposals over the last few weeks, but never any players. Late Thursday night, the general managers of the Mets and Cubs haggled over a blockbuster six-player deal: center fielder Lance Johnson, pitcher Mark Clark and shortstop Manny Alexander to the Cubs for relievers Mel Rojas and Turk Wendell and center fielder Brian McRae.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATZKY, BESS
description: SHATZKY-Bess. Passed away on August 7, 1997. Beloved mother of Joel and Dorothy, beloved grandmother of Ben and Judy, beloved aunt. She has done her work. Funeral services Sunday at noon at Gutterman-Musicant, corner of Passaic and Park St, Hackensack, NJ. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI, 1:45PM

title: Final Front in Crusade For Corporate Reform
description: AMERICA'S economy and America's corporations are in the midst of the most dynamic resurgence in our lifetimes. After a wave of corporate reorganizing, our companies are more efficient, our workers more productive and we employ capital far more effectively than the rest of the world.

title: Taking Flight Together
description: Our flight to Turkey is leaving in less than a week, and I desperately want to cancel. I know, of course, that I can't. Our tickets were purchased months ago and are nonrefundable. There is, however, a more serious snag. My name not only appears on all the program notes of the convention we're attending in Turkey, I am the keynote speaker. Forget the fact that I committed to this speech nine months ago and that the organizers of the convention have already booked, no doubt, a room with a breathtaking view of the Bosporus. Forget even that my mother-in-law has herself purchased nonrefundable tickets to come from out of town and baby-sit for our three sons while we're abroad. A cancellation would spell disaster for everyone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENAUER, RABBI SAM
description: GENAUER-Rabbi Sam. The Board of Directors, Faculty and Staff of CLAL -The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extend deepest condolences to Blu Greenberg, our esteemed associate faculty member, her husband Rabbi Irving Greenberg, our president and founder, and their entire family, on the passing of Rabbi Sam Genauer, beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Rabbi Genauer was a great scholar, a warm, generous and caring person who deeply touched the lives of everyone. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Radine Abramson Spier Chairman Rabbi Irwin Kula President-Elect Donna M. Rosenthal Executive Vice Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIOIA, SANDY
description: GIOIA-Sandy. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Sandy Gioia. Wife of our colleague Guy Gioia. We will always respect her as a wonderful wife and mother of Dana and Lisa. We wish to express our deepest regrets to the rest of her family. In her memory contributions may be made to the Sandy Gioia Memorial Fund c/o Bloomberg L.P., 499 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10022.

title: When the Going Gets Tough, Some Go to the Gavel
description: SHEILA AND ALEX SHAPIRO, who have six grown children, hurl enough endearments around to last many couples the length of their marriage. But when it comes to the problems of trying to sell their home -- a contemporary white mansion on the top of a mountain in Pomona, N.Y. -- he becomes choked up and she becomes unnaturally quiet.

description: There is a $150,000 check awaiting the winner of the Northville Long Island Classic on Sunday. But that is not the prize the current leaders are chasing.

Your great-grandfather's Oldsmobile was born on Aug. 21, 1897, when Ransom E. Olds and a group of investors formed the Olds Motor Vehicle Company in Lansing, Mich.

description: NINETY YEARS AGO, THE ABBEY theater in Dublin presented a play in which a young vagrant called Christy Mahon was feted as a hero by Irish villagers because they believed he had bashed in his father's brains with a hoe.

description: Only five years old, the Stuyvesant High School Plaza is already favored by students and neighborhood residents as an oasis for contemplation amid the bustle of downtown traffic.

title: Summary of Major Actions in the 220th Session of the Legislature
description: As the New York State Legislature sleepily stumbled to the close of its 220th session at 3:40 P.M. on Aug. 4, party leaders in both houses rose to give valedictories expressing their abiding affection for their staffs, their colleagues, even their opponents.

title: Artists, Birds and the Need for a Nest to Call Home
description: WHETHER they move about on two legs or two wings, most living creatures want a roof over their heads at the end of the day. A new exhibition shows how human and avian beings share that basic need.

description: The amateur driver Malvern Burroughs, who 22 years ago operated a backhoe in excavating for the Meadowlands race track, drove his home-bred Malabar Man to victory today in the $1 million Hambletonian for 3-year-old trotters.

Its inent is to heighten public awareness of various threats to the nation's heritage, from the dilapidation of hospital wards on Ellis Island to termite infestations of historic buildings in the South to the construction of a superhighway near Montana's Flathead Indian reservation. description: MASIN-Beatrice. Loving mother of Dr. Martin Aronauer and Linda and Arnold Bernstein, Ruth and Irwin Levine, Lois and Martin Lutwin. Dear sister of Irving Bottner. Cherished grandmother. Service today, 12:15 P.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York.

title: As U.S. Mediator Arrives, Arafat Calls for Confrontation
description: As an American special envoy arrived here in hopes of healing a widening crisis, Yasir Arafat told an emergency meeting of the Palestinian legislature today that the Israelis were seeking to humiliate the Palestinian people and that ''we must confront them, in every sense of the word.''

description: ''I AM absolutely a muck nut,'' Mary Parker Buckles said as she picked her way through grasses, sand and rock near Long Island Sound.

title: U.P.S. and Union Break Off Negotiations
description: Negotiators for the teamsters' union and the United Parcel Service broke off talks yesterday just two hours after returning to the bargaining table, with both sides signaling that they might be digging in for a long strike.

title: Giacometti, Haiti in Norwalk
description: WHEN reviewing two shows in the same article, art writers will usually try to cleverly make the transition from one to the other. Sometimes the best transition is no transition, for there is little linking the graphic work of Alberto Giacometti and a raft of paintings from Haiti. The bond between them is that they are complete opposites, but the city of Norwalk is big enough to hold them both.

title: Cheaper Air Fares For Older Travelers

For others it is a hairstyle suggesting that they don't care, when in fact they care very much about appearances in the realm of being cool. title: Missing Worker Mysteries
description: They are phantom employees; they saunter in late, flip on the computer, drape a jacket over the back of the chair, perhaps read the newspaper or the E-mail, linger over a cup of cappuccino, and then they vanish, sometimes leaving others to take up the slack. Or maybe they don't disappear, but somehow little or no work seems to emerge from their cubicles, just a hushed voice making weekend plans, detailing erotic encounters or negotiating with Mastercard. Is life in the workplace fair? Do these shirkers ever get their comeuppance? Or is life on the job, to paraphrase Woody Allen, mostly just about showing up? (And if you are reading this column while sitting at your desk at the office, get to work!)

title: Books From The Times
description: For two decades, this newspaper's readers have reported to its Metropolitan Diary column thousands of modest epiphanies that suddenly penetrated the New York area's absurdity overload: a travel agency door bearing the sign ''please go away''; a cemetery's phone machine that says ''If you know your party's extension . . .''; one dog walker demanding, about another's pet, ''Does he get enough exercise emotionally?'' Ron Alexander, the column's editor since 1984, is now the author of METROPOLITAN DIARY: The Best Selections From the New York Times Column (Morrow, $20), a collection of the region's sensibility as perceived by its inhabitants. They ought to know.

If McDonald's makes another go at serving all its customers in 55 seconds or less, it would do well to study the White Rose System, a hamburger joint in Highland Park that manages to deliver orders in about half that time. But unlike a fast-food establishment, White Rose System cooks to order. The burgers are large, tasty and inexpensive: the California burger, the White Rose version of a ''works,'' costs $2.30.

title: Deeper Shade of Blue Collar
description: Until now, almost every strike that has commanded the nation's attention has involved organized labor's high-paid elite: the four-month steel strike in 1959 involving 650,000 workers, the two-month General Motors walkout of 1970, the air controllers' strike of 1981 and the unpopular baseball players' strike of 1994. But the week-old walkout at the United Parcel Service is the first strike to capture the national spotlight that involves labor's lower castes, in this case part-time parcel sorters and truck loaders who earn about $10,000 a year.

But to those drawn also by the labyrinthine mysteries within, there is bad news: One by one, their cramped passageways are being closed, at least temporarily, to tourists.

title: Before an Election, Prisons Are Good. The Bills Come Later.
description: This is an election year in New Jersey, and it is not a good time to be a criminal.

title: A Fair and Straightforward Test of Golf
description: Winged Foot Golf Club opened for play in June of 1923 on 280 acres of rolling Westchester County terrain. It was built by the famed Scottish architect A.W. Tillinghast, who considered it his masterpiece. He loved the natural contours of the land, and built a course tailored to those contours. Even today, there are tee boxes not built or elevated but rather cut right out of the landscape. The bunkers are deep and sweep sharply upward, and the greens are undulating and steeply sloped. Every hole presents problems to solve with strategy and shotmaking, and the winner next Sunday will be the golfer who best meets those challenges.

And the material for this second chapter seems to be falling into place now.

If the same thing happens to him this week during the P.G.A Championship at Winged Foot Golf Club, his wish would be heard by more sympathetic ears, albeit ghostly ones.

title: I Know It's Broke, Why Fix It?
description: IT'S always a treat to watch my father-in-law open the door between his house and his garage. He approaches sideways, arms outstretched, like a karate black belt about to deliver a death blow. Then, taking the door by surprise, he grabs the handle and pulls it inward, at the same time giving the bottom of the door a violent kick outward. In one smooth movement, he rams his shoulder against the upper part, and the door bursts open. I'm sure it is this vigorous daily exercise that keeps him young.

title: It's the Government Way

Practicing at an Indian health center in Winslow, Ariz., Benally, a Navajo, treats patients with herbal potions and prescribes religious ceremonies. Since putting up a shingle in September, he has often ignored conventional medical wisdom, but clinic physicians seem O.K. I think the concept should be extended,says Dr. Raymond Andrews. Not because Jones is a magician, but because he understands what these people need. He often understands it better than I do. Here's a look at the Benally technique.

For him, conditioning was paramount, as he promises it will be for the Indiana Pacers, for whom he has recently become the rookie head coach. Larry Joe Bird ran and ran and ran. He even ran in races, some having as many as 12,000 competitors. He once won a five-mile race in Boston in the heavyweight division -- at 6 feet 9 inches, he tipped the scales at about 220 pounds -- running it in 33 minutes.

title: A Holiday in Bali
description: Living in Kenya, my husband and I turned into the expatriates Rebecca Chace described in her Lives column ''A Holiday in Bali'' (July 20). At first, I did not want to hire servants, but the continual stream of people asking for work made it difficult to resist. When we moved into a house in Nairobi, the line seeking employment outside our front gate was long. One woman begged me to hire her as a nanny. When I said we did not have children, it did not dissuade her: ''You are in your early 30's. You will have a child soon, so you must hire me now until the baby comes.'' Hire her on a retainer?

title: Cloud Town

title: English in India: Still All the Raj
description: THE assault began, really, as soon as I set foot in Bombay a few months before the golden jubilee of Indian independence. ''If Aggrieved,'' advised the sign in the airport arrival hall, ''Please Consult Asstt. Commissioner Customs.'' At the counter where I went to change my money, a notice told me, ''PLEASE ENSURE THAT YOUR DRAWERS ARE LOCKED PROPERLY,'' and after I'd done so, looking down demurely, I stepped into a wheezing old knock-off of a Morris Oxford to lurch through streets that said ''Free Left Turn'' on one side and ''Passenger Alighting Point'' on the other. The crazy Indian dialectic was in full swing all around, buses demanding ''SILENCE PLEASE'' on their exteriors, a few truck mudguards responding, ''HORN O.K. PLEASE,'' and my own little car making its own small contribution to democracy with a sticker that read: ''Blow Your Horn / Pay a Fine.''

title: The Sympathy Vote
description: There is no question that Gianni Versace's murder was tragic and horrific, that his career was cut short at its height. But in their distress and in sympathy, it seems, many of his colleagues, friends and admirers have been moved to overstate his place in history. During the past few weeks, it has been claimed that no designer before Versace had mounted fashion shows as large-scale theatrical productions (in fact, Kenzo, Claude Montana and Thierry Mugler got there before him); that Versace was the first to stock his front row with celebrities (although some 50 years ago, Christian Dior commanded the likes of the Duchess of Windsor, Rita Hayworth, Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart); that Versace's death is to the 90's what John Lennon's was to the 70's (and yet Lennon embodied the idealism of an entire generation, while Versace stood for the cynicism that is rampant in our culture, for the money and the hype that have become the chief criteria for greatness). In the midst of all this, Versace's true contribution -- which is both less sensational and more complicated -- has gone largely unremarked. His talent, a gift for innovative cut, was eclipsed by his celebrity: by the time of his death, he was more famous for the company he kept than for the clothes he designed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, GERARD E., DR.

He practiced obstetrics and gynecology in Brooklyn for thirty years until his retirement in 1982. An attending on the staffs of St. John's Episcopal Hospital and Caledonian Hospital where he was director of the department of obstretics and gynecology for ten years. Survived by his wife, Adrienne; two daughters, Lisa Evans Priskie of Pembroke Pines, FL, and Stacey Ann Evans of Ogunquit, ME.; and one grandchild, Chase Priskie. A devoted husband, a loving father and grandfather, a dedicated and caring physician. Services were held August 8, 1997 in Portland, Maine.

title: A Sailor's Murder and a Mother's Crusade
description: FOR some months in 1992 and 1993, the death of Allen R. Schindler, a radioman aboard the Navy's amphibious assault ship Belleau Wood, was news. He was trailed to a park near his base in Sasebo, Japan, on Oct. 27, 1992, and killed. The pathologist who performed the autopsy said Mr. Schindler, who had been stomped with shoe heels, looked as if he had been in a high-speed car crash or trampled by a horse.

title: End of Greed or Doing Good?

title: EEZ HYPER
description: The Government can't tell us what to do, scoffs Marc Silverman. His Montreal computer store, Micro-Bytes, recently received a ding from Quebec's Office de la Langue Francaise, ordering the retailer to change its predominantly English Web site to at least equal parts French and English. Provincial law allows English translations in commercial publications, but requires that French retain equal prominence. Silverman pointed out that the law does not mention cyberspace, but compromised anyway -- Micro-Bytes Web pages are now available in both tongues. As a protest, he has left one English-only page that rails against the O.L.F. For its part, the O.L.F., ever vigilant, now wants to expand its charter to cover the Web.

title: Op-Art

It went up last spring on the north side of 388 Greenwich St. in Tribeca, and people in the neighborhood and Greenwich Village complained. They said the neon umbrella ruined their views of downtown Manhattan.

title: Swaying to the Rhythm of a Blues Club

title: Crime
description: It's a long, hard ride from the swampy bogs of Bayou Teche, La., to the heat-cracked soil of Deaf Smith, Tex., but James Lee Burke makes the trek without falling out of the saddle. CIMARRON ROSE (Hyperion, $24.95), the first book in a projected series about a country lawyer named Billy Bob Holland, imposes the same strict honor code that made Dave Robicheaux such a stand-up guy in Burke's Louisiana bayou series. (With or without his guns, a man's a man when he sticks up for the young and the weak, the defenseless and the just plain loco.) But set in a new context, in a world as richly detailed and closely studied as the one back yonder, the old battles between good and no-good take on a crack-of-dawn freshness.

title: Dense, Complex Calcutta
description: EVERYTHING happens in Calcutta. On my first visit, in 1990, I was accidentally baptized in sacrificial goat's blood. On my fourth, most recent, trip, in November 1996, I had a near-death experience. Sinking to the gutter in a faint, I let go of life all at once. This was unexpectedly blissful, but it turned out to be just a 24-hour stomach bug.

title: Sky Wars
description: Col. Mikhail Botvinko attracted little national attention last month when he and several fellow Russian airmen flew a Soviet-era cargo jet across a large swath of the Eastern United States, taking photographs of American military bases as they went. That is a pity, because the flight of Colonel Botvinko, though a trial run, was rich with history and irony. It came more than four decades after it was first proposed, and followed the expenditure of billions of dollars by Washington and Moscow on other, more exotic ways to monitor each other's military forces. What would have been a great diplomatic breakthrough during the cold war seemed this summer merely another symbol of changed times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSAY, ALAN W.
description: LIPSAY-Alan W. Family and friends mourn his death, of cancer, on August 1, 1997 in San Jose, Costa Rica. Mr. Lipsay was born in Brooklyn, N.Y. in 1930, graduated from Lincoln High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia Law School. He raised his family in Manhasset Hills and was active in major New York area real estate projects for over 25 years. He later led an adventurous life in Costa Rica and in Sarasota, Florida while also engaged in real estate and vehicle financing businesses. An avid reader and crossword aficionado, he had great appreciation for the stylish use of the English language. He is survived by his sons, Seth and Craig, his granddaughters, Lauren and Allison, his sister, Ciceil L. Gross and his ex-wife, Florine Lipsay. The funeral was private. Donations may be made to Dorot, 171 West 85th Street, New York 10024, a charity benefiting the elderly and homeless.

title: Summering, Colonial Style
description: A CENTURY or two ago, there was not much glamour or fun in running the British empire in India, with its sweltering cities and small towns baking on the plains. Men, women and children were struck down by cholera, malaria and other fevers with no names or cures. Overdressed and overfed in a foolish attempt to keep up the habits of Home -- the word was usually capitalized -- these servants of the Raj fretted and fainted away, their tempers and lives shortened. Some sank into depression, some went mad.

title: Why Phone Numbers Don't Add Up
description: NO, it's not your imagination: the number of area codes is growing faster than ever. There is on average one new area code somewhere in the United States every month. Three years ago, there were 127 area codes and today there are 164, unmemorable ones like 954 for Miami and, as of next month, 781 for Boston. That doesn't include the third and possibly the fourth area code that state regulators say will be needed for Connecticut, less than a year after 860 went into effect.

title: The Real-Estate Royals. End of the Line?
description: It is not a sight for the faint of heart: a ballroom full of tuxedo-wearing owners, builders and managers of the city's prime real estate shouting at the top of their lungs at lenders, lawyers and assorted factotums as white-jacketed waiters stagger by beneath silver trays of salmon roulade. If the 101st annual banquet of the Real Estate Board of New York lacks the laid-back charm of dinner for two at the Rainbow Room -- there are few spouses, no dancing, and only a handful of the guests bother to sit down -- the importance of tonight's event can be seen from even a quick glance at the dais. Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani are here, along with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Senate Majority Leader Joseph Bruno, various City Council members and a youthful-looking official in a sharp blue suit whose game but puzzled expression indicates that he is happy to honor his distinguished constituents in the real-estate business but has never seen anything quite like this before in his life.

title: Robert McNamara and the Ghosts of Vietnam
description: Not long after dawn, Robert S. McNamara set out on a rapid walk through the half-light of Hanoi. A steamy drizzle soon soaked his dark blue jogging shorts and shirt. He stared intently ahead, barely glancing at the Vietnamese along the way as he marched in a loping stride through the city he ordered bombed some 30 years ago. He walked too quickly for the beggars or the barefoot children selling postcards to keep up with him. He did not seem to notice a boy hawking copies of ''The Quiet American.'' He raced across currents of whizzing motorbikes and bicycles laden with impossibly huge bundles of fruit and shoes and large tin boxes, balanced as ingeniously as weapons had once been on the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

title: Smiles of a Summer Audience, Italian Style
description: For the regulars at the DeSalvia Playground at Mulberry and Spring Streets, it was just another summer night. But on the basketball court there was heartbreak in the air. Women in short dresses and platform sandals and men in vintage shirts watched the bare-shouldered Jeanne Moreau wander sadly across the golf course, past Marcello Mastroiani and right out of the frame of Michelangelo Antonioni's 1960 film ''La Notte.''

title: Parcells and Young Start the New Season With Something to Prove
description: The New England Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft, is relatively new to the National Football League, but since he is a smart man he has adapted quickly. He has figured out one thing: Coaches, general managers and even owners always have something to prove. No matter how many Super Bowls they go to, no matter how many trophies are in the case, there is always someone who says, ''That was good; what's next?''

title: In Sicily, Exotic, Pungent Tastes of The Sea
description: MOST people go to Sicily either for the Greek temples or for the beach. Both groups, however, can take advantage of a third excellent reason, which is the food. Gastronomically, Sicily is the meeting place of at least two major traditions, the Arab and the southern Italian, and the result is not merely an imposition of spices and exotic flavorings on the home-grown; the Eastern influence can be seen, too, in the elaborateness of the many labor-intensive Sicilian dishes in which foods are not simply grilled, but first stuffed, if possible with something expensive. The recurring pleasant sensations involve the tart (capers), the sweet (raisins where you least expect them), the hearty (rich tomato sauces that taste of the sun) and the luxurious (marzipan and ricotta-filled pastries). And, in addition, the red (the showy scorpion fish), the blue (tuna, swordfish, fresh anchovies and sardines) and the silver (the exotic scabbard fish).
