Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules.

title: Blood Supply Is Low, Even for Summer
description: Officials warned last week that blood donations, normally slow in summer, have practically dried up in the region. The Central Jersey Blood Center in Shrewsbury, (732) 842-5750, which provides blood to Monmouth, Middlesex and Ocean counties, had about 250 units of blood -- one day's supply -- on hand Wednesday, compared with the 700 or so units that is normal for this time of year, said Lydia Blancato, the center's executive director. Linda Levi, a spokeswoman for the New York Blood Center, (800) 933-2566, which serves 250 hospitals in New York and northern and central New Jersey, said her bank's reserves were similarly drained.

For 30 years he lead Newmont Mining Corp as President and CEO and held many directorships. A man of high principles and steadfast dedication to his friends and family, he is survived by his loving wife Alexandra and children Alex and Irene, one granddaughter and 4 grandsons. The funeral service will be held at St. Sergius Russian Orthodox Church at the Tolstoy Foundation Center in Nyack, NY on Sunday Aug. 10 at 1PM. Driving directions can be obtained by calling 212986-7570. title: Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital Stops Admitting Local Patients
description: Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital stopped taking new admissions from its home county, Monmouth, last week, the latest step in a three-year plan to close the state-run institution. New admissions from Union and Middlesex Counties were already being diverted to Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, a 45-minute drive away. Only patients from Somerset and Essex counties will enter the hospital from among the five counties originally within its area of service. The 855-bed hospital, now with 360 patients, is scheduled to close June 30, 1998, under a plan to put greater emphasis on community-based care. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: A Month in Shaker Country
description: LAST SUMMER, THE ARTIST Mona Hatoum gave a tour of the dark Shaker attic in Sabbathday Lake, Me., that had been her studio for a month. In it were fragile, small things. Green and yellow noodles had been woven together into a swatch of edible homespun. Dots of shimmering jelly gathered weblike on a tiny window, the result of squeezing Vaseline through the holes in an old metal pie plate. A sifting of powdered sugar over the springs of a wooden baby's crib left delicate diamond shadows on the white-filmed floorboards: vanished childhood limned in pixie dust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEWAK, SHIRLEY
description: SPIEWAK-Shirley. On August 6th, after a year of struggling against cancer. Shirley Spiewak passed away peacefully at her home with her loving family at her side. She was grateful for her wonderful life with her beloved husband of 49 years, Gerald (Jerry) and loving children Alan, Michael and Rosanne (Ebner). She was blessed with seven grandchildren: Aaron, Meryl, Jason, David, Matthew, Jonathan, and Daniel. A truly elegant woman, Shirley was admired and respected by all who knew her. Born in Philadelphia (nee Bell) on January 19, 1930, she lived in Valley Stream, NY for 43 years. She also enjoyed residences and many friends in Copake, NY and Boca Raton, Fla. Most recently Shirley resided with Jerry at the Greenbriar Community in Jamesburg, NJ. An avid golfer, an accomplished painter, and skilled bridge player, Shirley was the consummate hostess for all of the family's business and social functions, (I. Spiewak & Sons, Inc.,). She was a good friend to all who knew her and she sincerely cared about everyone she knew. Always worrying about others before herself, she had a unique way of making everyone around her feel comfortable and special. We will all miss her very much. The funeral was held on Friday, August 8, 1997. Donations may be made to Cancer research in her memory.

title: Mistakes Plague Giants In Loss
description: In a thoroughly uneven performance marked by penalties and shoddy execution, the Giants chose the home opener of their exhibition season to display many of the problems that plagued last year's Giants. Offensively and defensively, the Giants looked bewildered in tonight's 38-16 defeat to the Jacksonville Jaguars, an effort that moved Coach Jim Fassel to sternly lecture his team both at halftime and after the loss.

It's not that he doesn't like to talk -- he does, and at great length -- it's just that he is not his favorite topic. Which, for an actor, is news right there.

title: An Industry and Its Founders Grow Up
description: THE personal computer industry was created in the mid-1970's by a few hundred fiercely competitive, idealistic young men barely out of their teens. Their mission was to change the world by democratizing digital technology (and, yes, to get rich too). They pursued their goals with the energy and passion of youth. Disagreements had a way of escalating into shouting matches, and conflicts became holy wars.

title: Serbian Media Is a One-Man Show
description: THE Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the propaganda maestro of the Balkans, rarely appears on state television. When he does, he insures that it is in grand style. At his swearing-in as President of the Yugoslav federation last month, the camera showed him seated in the front row of the federal Parliament, pug faced and steely gazed. Supplicants lined up to shake his hand. title: Picture This!
description: That carefully posed studio portrait of a stiffly smiling bride and groom might look nice on Aunt Margaret's mantelpiece, but to get the real story of a wedding, you have to go behind the scenes. WEDDING PICTURES (Chronicle, $22.95), a novel with text by Jacqueline Carey and illustrations by Kathy Osborn, gets right to the quirky, complicated heart of matrimony, offering up the nuptial saga of Kip and Bonnie. Never mind that he lives in New York and she lives in Washington, and neither one wants to move. Forget that Kip's roguish older brother, George, is on his fourth wife and he's having an illicit affair with Bonnie's childhood friend Fay, or that to save money the bridesmaids have to wear fishnet dresses borrowed from a singing group called the Five Flavors. Never mind the bickering in-laws, or all that unwanted advice. Kip and Bonnie are madly in love and that's all that matters. Right? Told completely in dialogue, Carey's witty story sprints along with plenty of unexpected twists and turns, a deftly traced map of preconjugal pitfalls. And Osborn, whose artwork has appeared on many New Yorker covers, brings the chattering chorus of voices vividly to life. Will Kip and Bonnie live happily ever after? It's anyone's guess, but one thing's for sure: they'll always have their wedding pictures. Sarah Ferguson

title: A Fisher Miscellany
description: So skillfully did M. F .K. Fisher stripmine her biography for her essays and books that even her most faithful readers may be surprised at the gaps in their knowledge of her life. The outline is clear -- the childhood in Whittier, Calif., the young married life in Europe, the doomed romantic years in Switzerland with Dillwyn Parrish, the stint in Hollywood, the return to Europe, the graceful slide into old age in northern California -- and so is the cast of characters: the newspaperman father, the formidable grandmother, the scholarly first husband, the many unnamed lovers. But Fisher (1908-92) was an artist, not a mere memoirist, and she did not linger over facts in her quest to tell the truth. A WELCOMING LIFE: The M. F. K. Fisher Scrapbook (Counterpoint, $35) is a guide to her life that will be welcomed by her devotees; sensuous, witty and quick in pace, this collection of photographs and excerpts from Fisher's writings is at one with the spirit of its subject. Dominique Gioia, a freelance editor in San Francisco, provides a connecting narrative for her assemblage of memorabilia, which follows Fisher from cradle to grave. Gioia's prose suffers in comparison with Fisher's (whose would not?), but she is to be congratulated for her conscientious attention to biographical detail. And even her slippages in tone prove useful. Calling Fisher a single mother is accurate enough but rings oddly false for a woman who, as Gioia says, ''shunned the categorical, the reductive.'' Michael Anderson

title: The Fall and Rise Of Kilmer McCully
description: In 1981, when kilmer mccully started commuting from his home in a boston suburb to a new job in Providence, R.I., he would drive past the domed Rhode Island Capitol. High atop the dome stands a statue called ''The Independent Man'' -- a representation of Roger Williams, the Puritan founder of Providence. ''Because of Williams's religious beliefs, he was thrown out of Boston,'' McCully says now. ''It sounded familiar.'' McCully, too, felt like an outcast when he went to Providence from Boston, though he was a scientific rather than a religious infidel. He had left appointments at Harvard Medical School and Massachusetts General Hospital under a cloud, told that his research had dead-ended. He had been denounced by some fellow scientists and ignored by others. His research grants had withered away. He took refuge in a pathology job far from the fast track at the Providence Veterans Administration Medical Center.

The event helps park employees raise money for incidental expenses; it's also positive bat P.R. I could get into a long dissertation about the benefits of bats, says Dale Pate, a park resource specialist. He's referring to things like bats' amazing appetite for insects and aerial acrobatics. Any other selling points? I'll just say this, he says. Bats are closer in body physiology to humans than they are to rodents.

The move is an attempt to increase their influence against what the doctors see as restrictive rules imposed by managed care associations. Dr. Chirel, 66, was a president and board member of the medical association before becoming its executive director. He received his Doctor of Podiatric Medicine degree in 1956 from the New York College of Podiatric Medicine, and served on the faculty there as well as at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. description: Marjory Joan Koliski and Jun Sochi were married yesterday at the Holy Rosary Chapel in Cascade, Colo. Msgr. John Zay performed the ceremony.

title: American Men Blunder, but Women Salvage a Relay Gold
description: The United States women won a gold medal tonight in the 4 x 100-meter relay at the world track and field championships, delivering the second-fastest time ever run, 41.47 seconds. But the feeling was as much relief as celebration. The rest of the evening produced more startling failure than success for the Americans.

title: In Fair August, Work Is but a Midsummer Daydream
description: IT seems T. S. Eliot was wrong. August, not April, is the cruelest month, at least for trying to conduct business. Just try setting up a meeting this month. Or arranging a job interview. Or getting a telephone call returned.

title: A Mere 50 Years of Freedom
description: THE 50th anniversary of India's independence in August 1947 was still a couple of years away when the American Ambassador to India, Frank G. Wisner, hit on an idea he took to P. V. Narasimha Rao, who was then the country's Prime Minister. If India were to use the occasion as a vehicle for celebrating democracy, Mr. Wisner suggested, the United States would lend its support, and organize events of its own that would hail India's tradition of electing its Governments.

title: Pets' Pampering Depends On Readers' Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Adams Discusses His Agenda for Ulster Talks
description: The British military helicopter circled noisily high above the West Belfast office where Gerry Adams, president of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, discussed the Northern Ireland peace talks he expects to attend next month.

title: A Bigger Tax Break On Sales
description: THE Federal tax changes that became law last week will virtually eliminate capital-gains taxes on the sale of most middle-class homes, and could save average homeowners tens of thousands of dollars, real estate and tax specialists say.

title: Christo Would Be Jealous: How to Hide a 140-Foot Cellular Tower
description: Drive to the St. John Baptist convent in Mendham where eight Sisters of Mercy of the United States maintain a ministry of hospitality and you can't help but notice the new bell tower on a hill, 140 feet tall with a gold cross on each side. Although the Episcopal sisters welcomed the addition to their property last month, the tower is not what it seems to be. For one thing, it doesn't have a bell.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Good Intentions

title: Socking It Away for College, With Uncle Sam's Help
description: For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules.

title: At Home on the Range: McNair Leads the Oilers
description: He came from rural Mount Olive, Miss., and from tiny Alcorn State University, but now the bright lights of the National Football League and the blinding glare of being one of only 30 starting quarterbacks in the league are testing his foothold in his solid roots.

title: For Cleaner Air, Try Electric Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Plane Crash on Guam After Problem on Approach
description: The late-night Korean Air flight had been cleared to land in a downpour at Guam's main airport, where a navigational system that directs pilots toward the runway had been out of service for more than a month. No one knows whether it could have made a difference, but the plane crashed Wednesday in the jungle a few miles short of the runway, killing 225 people. There were 29 survivors.

title: P.G.A. Scrapbook: Surprising Starts, Startling Finishes
description: The tone for what has been 78 unpredictable and fateful P.G.A. Championships was set in the very last moments of the very first event. In 1916, after three days of play at the Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville, N.Y., a championship was settled on the outcome of dueling 4-foot putts.

title: Covering Tiles With Stucco
description: To the Editor:

title: Standouts in the Cash-Flow Sweepstakes
description: Almost all mutual funds are raking in the cash this year, but some fund companies are growing particularly big, particularly fast.

title: Alexander Cordell, 82, Novelist
description: Alexander Cordell, the author of the best-selling 1959 novel ''Rape of the Fair Country,'' about Welsh iron-workers and their struggle for union rights at the turn of the century, was found dead on July 9 near Llangollen, Denbighshire, in Wales, The Independent, the British newspaper, reported. Mr. Cordell who lived in Wrexham, Wales, was 82.

title: Blacks Seeing Economic Growth
description: AS a successful black architect and political leader, Ernest D. Davis relishes the trappings of the upper-middle-class status he has worked so diligently to achieve: his five-bedroom house with manicured grounds here, an extensive art collection acquired over the years, membership in the same college fraternity as the television star Bill Cosby and acceptance in social circles where other prominent political and business leaders congregate.

title: Salvaging the I.N.S.
description: Few students of America's immigration policy would contest the notion that the Federal agency in charge of it has been a calamity. No organization could successfully seal the border, but the Immigration and Naturalization Service has proved exceptionally inept at its most essential tasks. It has done a poor job of keeping out illegal aliens, deporting criminals, processing requests for asylum, visas or citizenship in a reasonable amount of time and even maintaining basic courtesy in the district offices that serve legal immigrants.

title: Jennifer Diamond And Brett Haber
description: Jennifer Anne Diamond, a television news producer, was married last evening to Brett Alan Haber, a television sports announcer. Rabbi Jay Rosenbaum performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridian in New York.

title: How Can We Save the Next Victim?
description: In the Digoxin episode described by Lisa Belkin, not a single individual (doctor, nurse or pharmacist) felt a personal responsibility for the patient who was accidentally given an overdose of medication (''How Can We Save the Next Victim?'' June 15). This is unprecedented and catastrophic. We are witnessing nothing less than the dismantling of the Hippocratic oath -- the loss of the one-to-one patient-doctor relationship. Hospitals are in survival mode. Business practices are destroying our medical system; volume is now a necessity in order to pay the bills. At my hospital, patients are referred to as customers.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: A seasoned traveler and a Tuscan at heart, I am usually skeptical about the somewhat idealized descriptions and recommendations of hotels and restaurants found in newspapers and guides. With a copy of your Oct. 14, 1996, article ''Florence From the Hilltop'' under my arm, I recently left my Florence hotel room one evening and ventured into the Florentine hills in search of La Panacea del Bartolini, the restaurant that intrigued me most in Glenn Collins's article.

title: Ms. Silverstein, Mr. Migdon
description: Michelle Rose Silverstein, the daughter of Elaine S. and Lee Silverstein of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married there last evening to Andrew Harris Migdon, the son of Hermine R. and Sidney A. Migdon of New York. Rabbi Jerome P. David performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel.

title: Fair Housing Settlement
description: Fair housing experts and Justice Department officials say a troubling pattern is emerging as Hispanic people begin to move from city to suburb and some suburban communities appear to try to keep them out, or limit their numbers.

title: A Man Who's True To His Convictions
description: ANYONE WHO HAS SEEN Robert Carlyle only in ''Trainspotting,'' the unsettling 1996 film about junkies in Scotland, might well wonder about his sanity. In that movie, Mr. Carlyle, a 36-year-old Glaswegian, plays the psychotic Begbie with such conviction that the actor himself seems possessed by demons. But, be assured, in the handful of roles that have won him recognition as one of Britain's new acting talents, he has also been gentle and loving. Indeed, Mr. Carlyle is all too wary of being typecast as a ''Glasgow hard man.''

title: University Forced to Pay $1.6 Million To Researcher
description: Ending seven years of court action and appeals, the University of Michigan has paid $1.67 million in damages to a scientist who said her work had been stolen by her supervisor.

title: They're Reading the Letterland Way
description: ROBERT THOMAS, age 6, grinned widely as he moved an index card along the page to keep his place. The book was a beginning phonics text, but it could have been ''War and Peace'' for all the pride he felt at being able to read it.

title: In Mahopac, Where View Is Spectacular
description: BUILT at the edge of Mahopac Lake, this restaurant offers diners an unparalleled view, reason enough for a visit. Those seated at the ribbon of windows in the dining room or on the broad dining deck will find the prospect of the huge silvery lake, smooth water crafts and companionable geese that drift by inspiring at the very least.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Bad, Period
description: To the Editor:

title: Flogging Freud
description: Never mind whether Freud should be judged as a scientist or a therapist or a sexist or a social force. If nothing else, Freud has proved to be a great whipping boy for our time. He has been blamed for turning children against their parents (Frederick Crews) and for excusing parents who seduce their children (Jeffrey Masson), for being a crypto-biologist (Frank Sulloway) and a crypto-priest (Richard Webster), for believing patients too little (Jeffrey Masson) and too much (Mikkel Borch-Jacobsen), for hiding his faults (Henri Ellenberger) and flaunting them (John Farrell).

title: Correction
description: The front-page article last Sunday about a Queens developer, Thomas J. Huang, referred incorrectly to an award by the Queens Chamber of Commerce in 1984. Mr Huang's house in Queens received the chamber's Annual Building Award in the residential category; Mr. Huang was not named the group's Man of the Year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, SIDNEY
description: SIMON-Sidney. We deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend whose inspired artistry contributed so much to the dignity and beauty of the Jewish Chapel at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, New York. Visitors are tremendously impressed with his creation of the tablets and the ark doors and curtain. His memory will live on in his magnificent work. Herbert M. Ames, Chairman Louis Gross, President West Point Jewish Chapel Fund

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Landscapes That Celebrate Their Makers
description: THE vista of sand dunes and rocks hanging in the Curatorial Studies Museum at Bard College here is not a mirage but a black-and-white photo mural by Hannah Collins. Having made a dramatic impact, the image becomes no more than a backdrop or at best a Conceptualist record of aridity, that is, until the viewer notices the vague pyramidal forms on the horizon. Then the mystery returns, to be compounded by the title of the print, ''Heart and Soul.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about a disk jockey in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., who relentlessly ridicules a neighboring town included a duplicated passage in some copies in place of its third column on the front page of the Metro Section. The complete article, including the missing third column, is reprinted today on page 36.

title: Charitable Giving Taps New Donors
description: TWO new funds at the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven have captured the imaginations of a new breed of philanthropists who want to become more involved in the decision making.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANIERMAN, JONATHAN
description: SPANIERMAN-Jonathan, age 34, died on August 1, 1997 of AIDS at his home in East Hampton with his beloved wife Cheryl and his adoring mother and father Helen and Ira after a long and valiant battle. He was a musician and a composer of beautiful music that will live in our hearts forever. He is survived by his brothers David and Gavin, and his aunt Dorothy Lautman. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the East End AIDS Wellness Project in Sag Harbor, New York 11963.

title: Where It's Sit-Up-and-Take-Notice Fare
description: THERE is a quaint 78-year-old cottage beside the railroad tracks in Glen Head. It is now a contemporary American restaurant with a French name and sit-up-and-take-notice food. Cooks will recognize Mirepoix as the culinary term for the mixture of minced carrots, onions and celery that is the foundation of so many classic French dishes. But the food at this new Glen Head spot is au courant American with forays to Italy, France, Japan and China.

title: Barbara Walters's Foursome
description: ''HOW many parties have their own rainbow?'' Barbara Walters asked at the celebration Tuesday night for her new daytime show, ''The View.'' As if on cue, a brilliant rainbow had appeared in the sky just in time to be glimpsed from a room with a wraparound view on the 22d floor of ABC on West 66th Street.

title: Mischief on the Net
description: It seemed real enough, but then again, why would anyone question whether Kurt Vonnegut was the author of a quirky graduation speech given this year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology? The answer: Truth on the Internet is a slippery thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, JOHN B.
description: ELLIOTT-John B. With great sadness, The Art Museum, Princeton University, mourns the loss of John B. Elliott, dear friend and generous benefactor, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to his family. Allen Rosenbaum, Director

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARGARET
description: DAVIS-Margaret. Great Neck Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of its member and friend. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire bereaved family. Dale Polakoff, Rabbi Dr. Ephraim Wolf, Rabbi Emeritus David Werber, President

title: Governor to Urge Cuts In Automobile Insurance
description: Reversing her position on one of the most contentious political issues in the state, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will propose mandatory reductions in automobile insurance rates, cutting some drivers' costs by 25 percent or more, her spokeswoman, Becky Taylor, said yesterday.

title: Digital-Age Wiretapping Plan By F.B.I. Draws Opposition
description: Privacy advocates plan to challenge the F.B.I.'s proposal for high-technology wiretapping today, contending that the agency is seeking powers never intended by Congress when it enacted a 1994 law to bring wiretapping into the digital age.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOND, LILIAN
description: MOND-Lilian. Age 94, on August 7, in Bloomfield, CT. Wife of the late Morris Mond. Survived by daughter Joan Lebovitz, West Hartford, CT; son-in-law Walter Freedman, Delray Beach, FL; grandchildren Cathy and Gerald Gollub, NYC, Samuel Lebovitz, Brooklyn, NY, Joseph and Suzanne Lebovitz, Columbus, OH, and Alisa and James Keane, West Hartford, CT; great-grandchildren Allison, Matthew, Robert and Kaitlyn. Predeceased by daughter Jacqueline Mond Freedman and sonin-law Robert Lebovitz.

title: R. E. Pike, 92, Author of 'Spiked Boots,' Dies
description: Robert E. Pike, who grew up in northern Vermont enchanted by the tales of the imposing, spiked-booted loggers who swaggered down the Connecticut River and camped on his uncle's farm, tousling his hair and feeding him sugar cookies from the cook tent before pushing off for the pulp mills downstream, died on Thursday, satisfied that he had taken precautions against being remembered as the pre-eminent authority on the history of logging in New England.

title: E-mail's personal impact makes it a fertile medium for perpetrating hoaxes.
description: THE ability of E-mail to zap messages to and from anyone, anywhere in the world -- into your face, whether you like it or not -- is inspiring some distinctly unpleasant conduct in the infosphere.

title: A South African Killer Goes Free
description: Unlike other apartheid officials who have asked for amnesty from South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Dirk Coetzee did not need to be persuaded to confess to killing Griffiths Mxenge. For eight years, Mr. Coetzee has been confessing his crime to anyone who would listen. The decision last week to grant him amnesty ended a saga that has tested some of the commission's most basic premises. The commission, which offers amnesty in exchange for full confession, has indeed gotten truth from Mr. Coetzee. But whether its verdict will contribute to reconciliation is unclear.

title: Cable Chief Tries to Bring Cool Into Disney Children's TV
description: When Geraldine Laybourne ran Nickelodeon, merrily building it into a $300-million-a-year revenue generator for its corporate parent, Viacom Inc., she and her mostly young staff thrived on being known as the anti-Disney.

title: Mayor Extols the Benefits Of Tax-Free Shopping Week
description: Making the most of an election-year gift from the Legislature, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ventured into the Manhattan Mall in Herald Square yesterday to announce the suspension of the sales tax on clothing purchases during the first week in September -- just in time for back-to-school shopping.

title: Preseason Or Not, Fassel Rips Two Giants
description: When the Giants named Jim Fassel their head coach seven months ago, people wondered if this mild-mannered longtime assistant coach was tough enough to lead and motivate National Football League players. After the Giants' first loss of the 1997 preseason schedule Saturday night, it is unlikely his players are still questioning Fassel's mettle, or his willingness to lash into his team when things have gone poorly on the field.

title: The Man Who Invented American Efficiency
description: THE ONE BEST WAY

title: 4 Shoes And Then 2 Concerts
description: By its nature, the Out of Doors festival is the most populist and in some ways the quirkiest of Lincoln Center's handful of summer programs. The festival, which began its 27th season on Thursday and runs through Aug. 23, offers ethnic music and dance of all sorts, as well as many varieties of folk, jazz, country and chamber music, all free of charge. The festival also has some traditions, among them an annual Homemade Instrument Day.

title: Can Museums Put Art On Virtual Walls?
description: Georgia O'Keeffe's red hills, bleached bones and poppies populate countless sites on the World Wide Web. But nary a landscape, skull nor flower can be found on the cyberspot belonging to the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M. This simple paradox illustrates the quandary in which museums find themselves as they assess the opportunities and threats presented by the Internet.

title: For Jets' Rookies, Real Test Is Coming
description: They are young, they have been promised work and they have one great advantage over Jets rookies from previous years: Coach Bill Parcells owes the veterans nothing.

title: Rivals for Olympics Feel Effect in Athens : Stockholm Bomb's Shock Travels Far
description: ATHENS  So powerful was a small bomb detonated in Stockholm last week that it set off a chain reaction 1,500 miles away in Athens, where officials of three European cities seemed to be using the attack to propel their own campaigns to host the 2004 Olympic Games.

title: Fitch Ratings Agency in Merger Talks
description: Fitch Investors Service L.P. said yesterday that it was in merger talks with IBCA Ltd. of London in hopes of creating a credit-rating agency to challenge the industry leaders, the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service.

title: For Quigley, The Triumph Of a Lifetime, A Moment Late
description: Dana Quigley was celebrating as joyously as any winner of a golf tournament has, and deservedly so, after working his whole life toward this moment.

title: United Parcel Asks Clinton To Intervene In Walkout
description: Officials at the United Parcel Service stepped up their calls yesterday for President Clinton to intervene to end the week-old teamsters' strike, but Administration officials said Mr. Clinton was leaning strongly against such action.

title: Island Was No Fort
description: To the Editor:

title: Answers and 'Solution Techniques'
description: The ''standards-based'' mathematics curriculum, as its proponents call it, or ''whole math,'' as its critics describe it, encourages students to invent their own ways to solve problems.

title: U.S. to Put a Civilian Reactor to Military Use
description: The Energy Department, its own big nuclear reactors broken down irreparably, is preparing to borrow space in a civilian power plant to manufacture tritium for nuclear weapons, in effect beating a plowshare into a sword.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIDAS, CONSTANTINE V.
description: HAIDAS-Constantine V., 68, of Centerville, MA, August 7, 1997, in La Jolla, CA. Husband of Anne (Goussias) Haidas. Father of Katherine and Despina of Greece; brother of James G. Haidas of Osterville, MA. Funeral service 10:30 AM, Wednesday, in St. George Greek Orthodox Church, 1130 Falmouth Road, Centerville, MA. Mr. Haidas was a graduate of the School of Business, Cornell University. He initiated the Corporate Finance Department at Tucker Anthony & R.L. Day in Boston, MA, was a principal in Ungerleider Haidas & Co., NYC, a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. On Cape Cod he was a founding partner with his brother of Cooke's Seafood Restaurants. Calling hours Tuesday, 7-9 PM, at the Doane, Beal & Ames Funeral Home, 160 West Main Street, Hyannis, MA.

title: Medicine Is Altering Tie To Government
description: When New York State announced last month that it had negotiated a $1.25 billion Federal aid package to help its hospitals and clinics make the adjustment to managed care, critics said an industry with intimate connections to the highest levels of state and local politics was being coddled once again.

title: Mediocre Is Not Good Enough
description: For the past quarter-century it has been obvious that Americans need a better understanding of mathematics, science and technology if our society is to prosper.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Don't Dismantle I.N.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: To Hollywood, Britain Is a Land of Villains
description: To the Editor:

title: Missing Toddler's Mother, 16, Charged With Endangerment
description: A 16-year-old girl was arrested yesterday and charged with endangering the welfare of her 20-month-old daughter, who has been missing since Tuesday. The police said that they believe the teen-ager, Robine Blue, removed the toddler from the foster home they shared in Brooklyn and took her to her own mother, who has an extensive history of prostitution and drug convictions.

title: Now New York, Too, Has a Fringe Festival (No Chandeliers Need Apply)
description: Which is more dramatic: ''a monstrous hellfire'' in ancient Scotland or a ''woman's desperate search for a livable New York apartment''? Theatergoers can make their choice at the first New York International Fringe Festival, or Fringe N.Y.C.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about furnishing college dormitory rooms misspelled the surname of the dean of Barnard College. She is Dorothy Denburg, not Denberg.

title: Single-Minded In Seeking A Constitution
description: WHEN it comes to far-out political thinking, Bob Schulz, chairman pro tem of the We the People Congress, is a pretty open-minded guy. He is, after all, the man who agreed to run for governor on the Libertarian line after Howard Stern dropped out.

title: Wrong Place for a Prison
description: The $68 billion budget approved by the New York State Legislature last week is crammed with special-interest items benefiting one regional interest or another at the expense of broader considerations. One such item authorizes $130 million for the design and construction of a new 1,500-bed maximum-security prison for violent offenders, smack dab in a valuable wilderness area of the Adirondacks.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Neil Young Proves Himself to Himself
description: Neil Young stands behind a shoulder-high mountain, holding the remote control for an electric train that's looping through a landscape of canyon and river, tunnels and bridges. He's not in his basement; he's in a tent at the Horde (for Horizons of Rock Developing Everywhere) Festival tour, which he is headlining this summer. Headliners get an indulgence or two, and this is Mr. Young's: a Lionel setup no 1950's child ever had.

title: Last Round Proves Best For Singh At Buick
description: Like a predator waiting for the perfect time to strike, Vijay Singh saved his best for last.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARSHAK, BEN
description: MARSHAK-Ben. On this day, your birthday, we love and think of you as we do each day. Janet, Edward and Alma

title: Exhibit Hall Added to Plan For Coliseum
description: Trying to resuscitate its bid to develop the New York Coliseum site in Columbus Circle, Tishman Speyer Properties secured an endorsement yesterday by the New York City Central Labor Council, an umbrella group for the city's labor unions, by adding plans for an exhibition hall.

title: CLINTON PLANNING TO KILL SOME ITEMS IN NEW LEGISLATION
description: After a week of high-level White House deliberations, President Clinton has decided to exercise his line item veto authority on Monday for the first time by deleting at least one narrow tax break and one spending measure from the balanced-budget and tax-cut legislation he signed last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEA, PETER LANE
description: SHEA-Peter Lane, of Locust Valley, LI, died suddenly and peacefully at his home in Northeast Harbor, ME, on August 9th. He was 64. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Sage Shea, his sisters, Edwina Millington and Betty Rouss, and his four sons, Chris, Andy, Ed and Jamie Shea. He is the grandfather of Phelan, Nicholas, Elyssa, Brody, Spencer, Reid and Natalie Shea. A private family service will be held on Tuesday. A memorial service will be held later in September.

title: Bill Sale Today By Treasury Is All for Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: School Official in Limbo
description: The Bridgeton school board is expected to decide tomorrow night the fate of its business manager, who was accused last week of stealing money from another school district.

title: Walter I. Farmer, 86 Architect; Protected German Art After War
description: Walter I. Farmer, who was awarded a high German medal last year for having protested, as an American Army captain in Germany in the months after World War II, his superiors' decision to ship artworks including paintings by Rembrandt and Rubens to the United States, died on Saturday at Christ Hospital in Cincinnati. He was 86 and lived in Cincinnati.

title: Philosophies Differ on Future of Socrates Sculpture Park
description: In a Queens neighborhood of abandoned warehouses and scampering rats, Socrates Sculpture Park rises as a kind of crazy vision, a surreal space where gigantic contortions of steel, stone, wood and plastic sprout.

title: For Athletes With Guns, There Are Few Controls
description: When the Dallas Cowboys' coach, Barry Switzer, was found carrying a handgun in his luggage at an airport last Monday, a day after the Philadelphia 76ers' point guard, Allen Iverson, was found with a gun in his car, it underscored a problem that professional sports leagues have been powerless to solve.

title: Fears of Shadowy Force Return to South Africa
description: In the cold, dewy morning, the women of this village had gathered around the mud house, just outside the red-and-white police tape demarcating the crime scene. They watched, whispering softly to each other under their hands, as the officers picked up used rifle shells and took pictures.

title: U.S. MIDEAST ENVOY HITS SNAG IN TALKS ON SECURITY ISSUES
description: President Clinton's special envoy to the Middle East ran into obstacles today as he began a quest to restore what he called ''the security underpinnings'' of Israeli-Palestinian ties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESSO, DAVID V.
description: BESSO-David V. On August 9, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Yetta Besso; beloved father of Vida Lapins; cherished grandfather of Ruth Resciniti; adored greatgrandfather of Chandler Paige. Loved and mourned by all who knew him. Services, Robert Schoem Chapel, Rte 4, Paramus, NJ, Monday, August 11, at 10:30 AM. Shiva, Monday through Thursday AM, 15 Wagon Wheel Drive, New City, NY.

title: Top Executives at Yamaichi to Step Down
description: The Yamaichi Securities Company said today it would appoint a new president and chairman as part of a sweeping leadership change as authorities investigate the brokerage in a widening racketeer payoff scandal.

title: No Headline
description: ''What annoys me most is that just a couple of weeks ago, I got a tax bill for land and property I can't even see. Everything I have is gone, so I tell the Government to please send the bill to the volcano.''

title: New Petersen Owners Take Aggressive Stance in Magazine World
description: Less than a year after taking control, the new owners of the Petersen Companies are preparing to seek the rewards of reshaping the company that publishes Motor Trend, Hot Rod, Teen and 70 other special-interest magazines.

title: CUNY's Bad Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor's Home Auctioned
description: The home of the former Somerset County Prosecutor who killed himself in a Nevada casino hotel last November is scheduled to be auctioned by the Somerset County sheriff's office tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAGLIEN, TOM
description: BAGLIEN-Tom. It's not the same without you. Your friends in Nous Allons au Cinema

title: Stocks Decline in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 351.23 points, or 1.79 percent, at 19,253.23. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 128.61 points.

title: The Makeover at Columbia/HCA
description: The new management of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the largest for-profit hospital chain in the country, vowed last week to drop business practices that have led to criminal indictments, conflict-of-interest charges and a sullied reputation. But as the company changes its personality, it is important that Columbia/HCA and its critics draw the proper lessons about what did and did not go wrong.

title: Immigrants Thrive as Tour Guides for a Surge of Visitors
description: Tourists who take the advice of Lorenzo Regalado, a tour guide, and walk across the Brooklyn Bridge to and from Manhattan this summer will undoubtedly enjoy the sights he describes in florid detail: ''fantastic views, stupendous skyline, tremendous sunsets.''

title: Jittery Volcano Is Transforming Caribbean Gem Into Isle of Ash
description: The long-abandoned capital lies in ruins, destroyed a week ago by a tide of volcanic ash and superheated gas. Nearly two-thirds of the island's population has been evacuated, and the 4,000 people who remain now worry that all of their tiny Caribbean island may soon be unfit for human habitation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLMAN, JESSIE (NEE ROSEN)
description: PEARLMAN-Jessie (nee Rosen). Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Robert. Dearest sister of Ceil Bauer. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Services Monday, 1 PM, at Temple Beth-El, Jersey City. For information ''Wien & Wien,'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Star Light Not Too Bright
description: The glare from malls, highways and other urban flotsam is polluting the skies over New Jersey and making stargazing difficult, experts say.

title: TBWA Chiat/Day Gets Apple Account
description: Apple Computer Inc., as expected, has named TBWA Chiat/Day in Venice, Calif., to handle its domestic account, with billings estimated at $60 million to $80 million. The account had been handled by the BBDO West unit of BBDO Worldwide in Los Angeles until that agency resigned in June rather than participate in a review.

title: After Crime, She Made a New Life, but Now Faces Deportation
description: If Xuan Wilson, 32, is de ported to Vietnam a country she has not seen since she was 4 -- she will be exiled from her three young children, her husband and her parents, all of them American citizens. The child of a Vietnamese woman and an American soldier, she speaks no Vietnamese and would probably be a racial pariah in her native land.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : California Group Seeks to Outlaw Slaughtering of Horses for Food

But a group of horse lovers, the California Equine Council, is out to end the practice in that state. The group hopes to put a "Save the Horses" initiative, which would make it a felony to sell horses to be slaughtered for food, on the November 1998 ballot. No state now has such a law, which effectively would put horses in the same category as pet dogs and cats.

Digital's printing systems unit has annual revenue of about $100 million. Shares of Genicom, which is based in Chantilly, Va., rose 18.75 cents, to $11.3125. title: 29 Held in Ring's Drug Smuggling From Mexico to New York

description: ON AUTO INSURANCE -- Responding to polls that show New Jersey voters remain unhappy with high auto insurance rates, Governor Whitman has revived her plan to cut rates for consumers who give up their right to file lawsuits for pain and suffering. B5.

description: State investment in private building projects increased 79 percent during the first half of 1997, indicating continued growth in New Jersey's economy, state officials said yesterday.

description: Assemblyman Dov Hikind was formally charged yesterday with taking at least $40,000 in payoffs, and the politically influential legislator repeated his intention to fight the accusation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHECHTER, NOAH MOROWITZ
description: SCHECHTER-Noah Morowitz. 8/12/96. All the beats of our hearts ring with love for you, our cherished son. Hugs, kisses, all our love. Mom and Dad.

title: Peter Braestrup, 68, Library of Congress Editor
description: Peter Braestrup, a former war correspondent for The New York Times and The Washington Post who became an authority on the relationship between the press and the military, died on Sunday at Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Rockport, Me., where he had been on vacation. He was 68 and lived in Washington, where he was senior editor and director of communications for the Library of Congress.

description: You may wear your skirt long or short or in between, but if you want the look of the moment, your new fall skirt will have a slit on one side or possibly both sides.

description: WEBER-Sylvia. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of its esteemed member, Dr. Samuel P. Weber. description: REMS-Sarah on August 11, 1997, in her 90th year. Born in Miedzyrzec Podlaski, Poland. Daughter of the late Chaye Mindl and Yudel Furman. Beloved wife of the late William Rems. Loving sister of Marsha Siegel, and of the late Donne Furman, Malke Lewin, Nathan Furman, Shayndl Trusz, and Paul Furman. Devoted mother of Beverly Katzman and Alan Rems; loving grandmother of Lois Sheinfeld, Jay Katzman, Emily Rems, Daniel Rems; great-grandmother of Daniel Sheinfeld and Leora Katzman. Contributions may be made to the General Israel Orphans Home for Girls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, DEMING STEDMAN, JR.
description: CROSS-Deming Stedman, Jr., 49, of NYC. A banker at Barclay's Bank of New York, he died August 11 at the New York University Hospital after an extended illness. He was born in Providence, RI, April 28, 1948, the son of Deming and Dorothy Cross of Wakefield, R.I. and Beaufort, S.C. He leaves a friend, Dante Bini of NYC, a sister, Dana Coes, and was predeceased by another sister, Lacy Cross. He also leaves 3 nieces and 2 nephews. He was a graduate of Pomfret School, Washington University in St. Louis, and received his law degree from St. Louis University Law School.

title: PENNEY TO OFFER EARLY RETIREMENT TO MANAGERS
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would offer voluntary early retirement to 1,500, or about 5 percent, of its management employees and that it expected to take a $200 million pretax charge against earnings later this year to pay for the program. The retailer said it would save about $120 million annually if all 1,500 people accepted. Penney, which is based in Plano, Tex., has struggled lately under the weight of weak sales and excess inventories. It is expected to post flat earnings when it reports its second-quarter results today. Yesterday, its shares rose 50 cents to close at $58.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIROTA, ROSLYNNE
description: SIROTA-Roslynne. Died suddenly and peacefully in bed on August 6 of natural causes eight months after suffering a stroke. She is survived by her loving husband, Milton, her daughter Nancy and her three grandchildren, Kenji, Mina and Rena. Funeral services were held on August 8.

title: German Tire Maker Posts 73% Rise in Profit
description: Continental A.G. of Germany, the world's fourth-largest tire maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit in the year's first half rose 73 percent as it cut jobs and costs, in part by getting unions to accept a longer workweek. Continental shares rose as much as 5.2 percent after the company reported earning 208 million marks ($112 million), compared with 120 million in the period a year earlier. At the close of trading, Continental shares were up 2 marks, or 4.2 percent, at 50 marks ($26.92).

title: Swedish Dancers Out of Step With Tradition
description: The Royal Swedish Ballet gave its first performance in 1773. Two hundred and twenty-two years later, in 1995, a spunky Swedish principal dancer named Madeleine Onne approached Frank Andersen, the new director of the company, on his first day on the job. Wasn't it about time, she asked, for the company to create a smaller, less traditional troupe? Mr. Andersen said it was, and the group that Ms. Onne began, called Stockholm 590 North (after Stockholm's latitude), makes its American debut tonight at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.

title: Beauty Tops the List
description: When it comes to dating, beauty is only skin deep, a researcher in Indiana has found.

title: Tracing Mozart in Prague, Escaping From Viennese Politics
description: To better understand the Prague-Vienna connection, pick up a Viennese telephone book, in which Vuklacecs threaten to outnumber Seidlhofers or Hoffmanns by a considerable margin. Prewar Prague claimed the purest German spoken in the world, although after Hitler's demise that prize may have shifted to Montevideo and Buenos Aires.

title: Doctor Finds That Working Too Long Costs Him Social Security Payments
description: On June 2, 1995, Luis Caplan closed the door to his medical office in the South Bronx for the last time.

title: Mexico's Recovery Just Bypasses the Poor
description: There is no school in this wasted hillside village, no doctor, no drug store. When the pump works, a central faucet spurts grayish water for about three hours a day, and Paula Hernandez and the other village women scamper up the steep stony paths with buckets before it shuts off again.

title: Rebates by Brokers Under S.E.C. Review
description: It is not just Washington politicians who quarrel about ''soft money,'' and how it should or should not be used. Wall Street has its own ''soft dollars'' debate, much of it between powerful vested interests, about their proper use.

title: Inquiry Takes Up Killing of Mandela Aide
description: With liberation celebrities in the front row and crowds of demonstrators outside, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission began work today on one of its toughest cases: determining whether to free the men who, on the eve of South Africa's transition to a multiracial democracy, assassinated one of its most popular black leaders, Chris Hani.

title: CGI TO BUY TELEGLOBE'S INSURANCE SERVICES UNIT
description: The Montreal-based CGI Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the insurance systems unit of Teleglobe Inc., also of Montreal, for $140 million (Canadian), or $100 million (United States), in cash and preferred shares. The unit is the third-largest supplier of computer processing services to the property and casualty insurance industry in North America and the largest in Canada, with annual revenue of $163.5 million (Canadian). CGI's shares rose $2.75 (Canadian), to $27.90 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, PAUL W.
description: WILLIAMS-Paul W. The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York regrets the passing of its former Governor on August 4. John Badman III, Governor James B. Gardiner II, Secretary

title: Woman Falls From a Ride
description: A 47-year-old woman fell to the Boardwalk from an amusement park ride on the Steel Pier Sunday night and remained hospitalized yesterday.

title: With Prices on the Rise, Private Advisers Help Collectors Decide What to Buy
description: ''Who is she?,'' whispered a woman to her friend. The two were at Sotheby's during an evening sale of important Impressionist and modern art last May. All eyes were fixed on a woman in her 30's, with a brown mane in a style made fashionable by Jennifer Aniston, who persisted in raising her paddle, determined to snag Picasso's 1939 ''Standing Nude and Seated Woman.''

title: Summer of '97 Frolics On, Hardly Breaking a Sweat
description: As Goldilocks might say, this summer in New York has been neither too hot nor too cold but just right. Ice cream has been floating out of the barrel; novice sailors have discovered the pleasures of the Manhattan skyline seen from the Hudson at night; mounting garbage in city parks betrays not poor sanitation but avid attendance at concerts, zoos, city pools, impromptu touch football games and picnics.

title: Chess
description: Vladimir Kramnik, who is the No. 2 player in the world behind Garry Kasparov, according to the June 30 International Chess Federation rankings, brilliantly confirmed his status by winning the elite Dortmund International Tournament in Germany in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIM, EDITH
description: WERTHEIM-Edith. You will be truly missed by your Friends of Akim. Our condolences to your husband, Samuel, and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBELL, DORA
description: ABBELL-Dora. The administration, faculty, students and boards of the Jewish Theological Seminary record with sorrow the passing of Dora Abbell, whose generosity and that of her family have benefitted the Seminary for decades. Along with her beloved husband, Joseph, a Chicago businessman, Mrs. Abbell has been a prime supporter of the Seminary's worldclass library. A lively individual whose guiding principle was helping others in need, Mrs. Abbell created a home in which Jewish traditions played a central role. She will be deeply missed by her husband, daughter, Louise A. Holland and grandchildren, Elizabeth and Ethan. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: Order Bars Ward Raids by Sears
description: Montgomery Ward, the Chicago-based retail chain that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, has obtained a temporary restraining order against Sears, Roebuck & Company to prevent the rival retailer from trying to attract executives from Ward.

title: Spirits Soar As Shuttle Prepares For New Era
description: After 16 years of flight, more than $68 billion and a stretch of lassitude, the space shuttles are facing their hardest and most dangerous job: transporting into orbit and assembling the components of the international space station.

title: Where Tribe Saw Promise, Democrats Saw Pledge
description: In June 1996, Charles Surveyor, an American Indian leader from Oklahoma, found himself in heady company at a White House luncheon. Along with top executives of a handful of big companies, he was getting to make his case to the President, and this was his best chance, Mr. Surveyor thought, to win the return of 7,500 acres taken by the Government more than a century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, BERNARD
description: HIRSCHHORN-Bernard. 39 years since that fateful and tragic day and yet not a day goes by that I am not reminded of your inspirational guidance in my youth, that education and not gold is the human's best adornment. Once again I express my gratitude for your and mother's salutary wisdom. Herbert

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELD, EDWARD, SR.
description: FIELD-Edward, Sr., 96, passed away August 7, 1997 at his home in Newport Beach, CA. He was born in Rye, New York in Westchester County, on April 29, 1901. He met and married Emogene Lewis, his wife of 61 years, in Olathe, Kansas, in October of 1935. He was formerly the president of Childs Restaurant chain, based in Manhattan, during the 1930's and 40's. In 1958, after moving to California, he cofounded the Denny's Restaurant chain, formerly Danny's Donuts of Anaheim, CA and remained actively involved until its sale in 1978. He is survived by his wife, Emogene, son, Dr. Edward C. Field, Jr., granddaughters, Holly Field and Kimberly Light Knight, greatgrandsons, John Benjamin Knight IV and Clifton James Robert Knight. Funeral services were held Saturday, August 9, 1997 at Pacific View Mortuary, 3500 Pacific View Drive, Newport Beach, CA. Following cremation, inurnment will take place on Wednesday, August 13 at 3:00 p.m. at Pacific View Memorial Park. Donations in Edward's memory may be made to St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church, 600 St. Andrews Road, Newport Beach, CA 92663.

title: Jones Aims to Be Fastest Of All Female Runners
description: When the world track and field championships ended on Sunday, Marion Jones of Los Angeles had distinguished herself as the only winner of two gold medals.

title: For Brooks, Life at Top No Confidence Builder
description: The defending P.G.A. champion has not won a tour event in 12 months. He missed the cut at the Masters. He missed the cut at the United States Open. He missed the cut at the British Open. And he has managed just one top-10 finish in 23 tournaments this year.

description: The governors of several Northeastern states recently agreed to ask the Environmental Protection Agency to impose new air pollution controls on utilities and industries in the Midwest. They claim the controls are needed to help their states meet stricter national clean air standards.

description: The chief executive and chairman of the Reader's Digest Association resigned yesterday after his efforts to expand the company beyond its pint-sized flagship magazine had been met with sluggish profits and a sliding stock price.

description: The Quick & Reilly Group, the nation's third-largest discount brokerage firm, after the Charles Schwab Corporation and Fidelity Brokerage Services, gave about a dozen potential buyers a chance to submit preliminary bids today, people familiar with the planned sale said.

title: Paw-Tapping Music
description: FOR those who have held the esthetic sensibilities of rats in low esteem, it may be time to reconsider. Scientists have found that rats can tell the difference between classical and jazz music, sorting out strains of Schubert from Coltrane, Vivaldi from Miles Davis.

title: Neighbor Held In Killing Of Woman, 81
description: An 81-year-old woman was bludgeoned to death inside her apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Sunday morning shortly after she returned from church. The police arrested an upstairs neighbor yesterday and charged her with the woman's murder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESAPIO, WILLIAM J. (BILLY)
description: DeSAPIO-William J. (Billy) Suddenly at age 26 on August 10, 1997. Beloved son of Joseph and Barbara (nee Carroll), wonderful brother to Joseph, Martin and Mary Carroll. Loving grandson of Mary DeSapio and the late Marty DeSapio and the late Mary and William J. Carroll. Leaves behind many heartbroken aunts, uncles and cousins. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E 28th St, NYC. Please call 212-532-6579 for funeral arrangements.

title: Swedish Jobless Rate Fell to 10.8% in July
description: Sweden's unemployment rate fell to 10.8 percent of the labor force in July from 11.3 percent in July 1996, the country's labor board said yesterday. The decline reflects an increase in jobs in the education and health care industries.

title: Major Says Top Enlisted Man Propositioned Her
description: The only officer among six women to accuse the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier of sexual misconduct testified today that he propositioned her on two separate occasions and later grabbed her in a hallway, apparently seeking a kiss.

title: A Mixed Day As Stocks Try To Rebound
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday, as the market's two main indexes were the only ones that managed to regain some ground after Friday's sharp losses.

title: Amscan Is Acquired
description: Amscan Holdings of Elmsford, N.Y., said yesterday that it agreed to be acquired by Confetti Acquisition Inc., a corporation affiliated with the investment fund GS Capital Partners II L.P., for $315 million.

title: Cable Networks Back Nielsen Rival
description: Four cable television networks have become the first to say they will support a national television audience measurement system that is meant to compete against Nielsen Media Research.

title: Young Fillies Perform For New Connections
description: They are two of the fastest young fillies pursuing their careers at Saratoga. Brac Drifter won by 8 lengths after she was bought by Team Valor, the syndicate that took Captain Bodgit to the Kentucky Derby. Salty Perfume won by 16 lengths in her second start and then was bought by Beverly and Bob Lewis, the owners of the Kentucky Derby winner, Silver Charm.

title: Big Gas Disk May Form A New Planet System
description: ASTRONOMERS have detected not only planets orbiting stars other than the Sun. Over the last 15 years they have also observed disks of gas and dust around distant stars, the residue of stellar creation that could be the makings of even more planets.

title: Giuliani Opposes Bill to Deny Benefits to New Immigrants
description: With the historic portal of Ellis Island as a backdrop, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that legal immigrants should be eligible for state-financed welfare benefits in their first year of residence.

title: Bicyclist in Queens Shot To Death by Bike Thief
description: A man riding his bicycle in Springfield Gardens, Queens, was shot to death yesterday afternoon by a man who then fled with the bicycle, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APFEL, SADYE
description: APFEL-Sadye. ''Honey'' to her grandchildren, wife of the late Murray D. Apfel, matriarch of the family, took ill while vacationing and died in Southampton Hospital, four months shy of her 100th birthday. After an automobile accident 14 years ago, she defied all odds and lived with a spinal cord injury, while her devoted Blossom and Stanley and Christy gave her life. She never ever made demands, but earned the love and devotion of all her great grandchildren: Morgan Van Dorn, Lindsay, Andrew and Matthew Schaeffer; and her grandchildren who worshiped and adored her: Cindy and Del Van Dorn, Todd and Jeri Schaeffer, Christy and Tyler Schaefferwhose love and affection sustained her. Sadye's remarkably strong spirit and will to live, just so she could be with all her children, will be remembered deep in the hearts of her family. Sadye was an angel, a saint.

title: Maddux's Arm, and a Fly, Lift Braves
description: Having just signed a contract that makes him the highest-paid player in baseball, Atlanta pitcher Greg Maddux went right back to work as usual tonight. He held his weak-hitting team in contention through eight innings as the Atlanta Braves scratched their way to a 2-1 victory over the Florida Marlins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEL, ROBERT L.
description: BAEL-Robert L. On August 10, 1997 at his home in Stamford, Conn. Loving husband of Alice Minton Bael. Loving father of Dr. Nancy Bael, Lisa Bael Aman and Timothy Bael. Brother of Howard Bael and Martin Bael. Also pre-deceased by son Jonathan Bael. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, August 12, at 12 noon in the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford, Conn. with Rabbi Mark Golub officiating. Burial Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, N.Y. Memorial contributions to Preventive Medicine Institute, Berkeley, California.

title: Martinez Clouts 38th To Support Pettitte
description: The scorched baseball sailed off Paul Molitor's bat toward the left-field seats and virtually everyone at the Metrodome figured that the Twins would have no trouble scoring off Andy Pettitte in the third inning. But it turned very quiet after Chad Curtis raced to the warning track, backed up against the fence and gloved the ball. It was quiet and Pettitte kept it that way.

title: E.P.A. IS PRESSING PLAN TO PUBLICIZE POLLUTION DATA
description: If the Environmental Protection Agency has its way, people who live near hundreds of factories in five major industries will soon gain easy on-line access to mountains of data about the pollution given off by the plants.

Joan Rosenbaum, Director Robert J. Hurst, Chairman Charlotte Schwartz, President, Volunteer Association

description: HAHN-Peter. On August 8, 1997, former employee NYC Office of Labor Relations. Son of the late Hilda and Ludwig. Graveside Services Tuesday 1:30 P.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery.

description: The International Monetary Fund and a group of Asian nations led by Japan agreed today to a $16 billion rescue of Thailand's troubled financial system, which has been jolted by a currency crisis that has spread through South and Southeast Asia, threatening the region's rapid growth.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES IN STOCK DEAL FOR VACATION BREAK
description: Fairfield Communities Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the resort operator Vacation Break U.S.A. Inc. for $190.2 million in stock, increasing its resort holdings in South Florida. Fairfield, which is based in Little Rock, Ark., and operates resorts in 11 states, will issue 0.6075 share for each Vacation Break share. Shares of Vacation Break rose $3.375 yesterday, to $17.375, while Fairfield Communities shares fell $1.625, to $31. Vacation Break, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., operates and sells time share rights in the Sea Gardens Beach and Tennis Resort, the Fairways of Palm Aire and the Royal Vista Resort, all in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: Police to Be Sued Over Melee
description: It began as a parade through downtown Paterson last month to celebrate Peruvian independence and ended in a melee that officials said left four Paterson police officers and several civilians injured. This morning, a civil rights suit will be filed in Federal District Court in Newark on behalf of 17 people who attended the July 27 parade, alleging that the police used excessive force to subdue the largely Hispanic crowd, said Richard Winograd, the lawyer handling the suit.

title: French Utility Weighs Bid for British Concern
description: Compagnie Generale des Eaux S.A., a French company with interests in construction, water and telecommunications services, said yesterday that it might bid for Leigh Interests P.L.C, a British environmental services company.

title: 2d, and Wider, Chance to See Brooks on TV
description: Buoyed by the popularity of the free Garth Brooks concert in Central Park last week, HBO said yesterday that it would repeat the show next month and make it available to all homes in the country with cable television, not just those that subscribe to HBO.

title: Performers Keep Going Despite Pain
description: UNDER the best of conditions, it is hard to keep the hands from trembling while driving or chipping or putting a golf ball. On Sunday, Dana Quigley performed these complicated maneuvers in public, knowing that his father was gravely ill with cancer.

title: A Settlement With P.L.O. Over Terror On a Cruise
description: Nearly 12 years after Palestinian terrorists killed a disabled passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, aboard the hijacked Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and threw his body into the Mediterranean Sea, the Palestine Liberation Organization has agreed to settle a lawsuit by the Klinghoffer family for an undisclosed sum.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the United Parcel Service strike misstated the benefits policy of Federal Express. Part-time workers there become eligible for company-paid health insurance after 90 days on the job.

title: Israeli Melee as Women Pray With Men at the Western Wall
description: Jeered by strictly Orthodox Jews who called them ''Hamas,'' ''terrorists'' and ''Christians,'' about 150 Conservative and Reform Jewish men and women were shoved away from the Western Wall by the police tonight after they prayed together, contrary to Orthodox custom.

title: Banishing Land Mines
description: In 1991 the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation opened a shop in Phnom Penh to make and fit artificial limbs for Cambodians. The veterans, who had always considered land mines just one more weapon of war, began to see their special cruelty. ''Every other weapon got put away after the war,'' says Bobby Muller, the group's president. ''But land mines were still causing horribly debilitating and painful injuries. And the victims were the poorest of the poor. Many knew the area where they were gathering firewood was mined, but they had no choice.'' Now the group is one of the leaders of the American effort to ban land mines, which kill or injure 2,000 people around the world every month, the majority civilians, many of them children.

title: Unions Plan To Borrow Business Tool: Ad Campaign
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has come up with a new capitalist wrinkle to woo workers to the union banner: slick television spots.

title: Camden Payments Approved
description: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development will authorize payment to Camden Housing Authority employees this week, despite a standoff with local officials over control of the public housing agency, a spokesman told The Associated Press yesterday.

title: Report Says Errors, Not Fraud, Are the Biggest Reason New York City Cuts Off Welfare
description: New York City's procedures to weed out fraudulent welfare claims are so rigorous that thousands of eligible people have been denied benefits, a report released yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission said.

title: Housing Construction Up in July in Canada
description: Housing starts in Canada rose 2.7 percent in July from June because of a rise in new multiple-unit construction, the national housing agency said yesterday. Starts in July totaled 144,700 units, up from 140,900 in June. All figures from the agency, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation, are seasonally adjusted at an annual rate.

title: Book Chains' New Role: Soothsayers for Publishers
description: ''Love Potion No. 9'' is music you can dance to, but could an old rock-and-roll beat drive a memoir into a best seller for the songsmith Jerry Leiber? For such nagging literary questions, the publishing house of Grove Press turned to Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest chain of bookstores.

title: Debating Union Power, Drifting From the Point
description: If you sense something anachronistic about tonight's ''Firing Line'' debate -- ''Resolved: Labor Unions Are Too Powerful'' -- it is probably that unions are plainly not as powerful as they once were, despite a recent resurgence. So the encounter turns out to be more about issues like the North American Free Trade Agreement, tax cuts, Medicare, affirmative action and other subjects that deserve (and often receive) debates of their own.

title: Prices Flat For Treasury Securities
description: Treasury securities were flat yesterday, with investors concerned that forthcoming sales and inflation data would point to a more rapid rate of economic growth for the third quarter, leading the Fed to raise rates next week to keep growth and inflation contained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, MARJORIE
description: POSNER-Marjorie. Died August 11, 1997. Survived by her husband of 53 years, William, and her children, Nancy and Martin Becker of Kettering, MD, Judge Charles A. Posner and Lynn of Brooklyn, NY, and Ira P. Posner, MD and Sheila of Hollywood, FL, and the grandchildren she adored, Michael and Hilary, Aaron and Karen, Beth, Mark, Amy and Deborah, her brother, Howard Wilde, and sisterin-law, Rita. Founding member of the Glenwood Jewish Center; member of Hadassah, Amit and JWVA Auxiliary. Graduate of Brooklyn Jewish School of Nursing, 1944; a proud registered nurse for more than 50 years. title: METROCALL TO BUY PRONET FOR $73.8 MILLION PLUS DEBT

The combined company would control more than 15 percent of the paging market in New York, Washington, Los Angeles and other major cities. Shares of Metrocall, which is based in Alexandria, Va., fell 6.25 cents, to $5.9375, while shares of Dallas-based Pronet fell $1, to $5.

title: Naked Kennedy Truth
description: When one of the most prominent members of the Kennedy family chides another in print, attention will inevitably be paid -- particularly if it happens in the August news doldrums. John Kennedy Jr.'s reference to his cousins Joseph and Michael as ''poster boys for bad behavior'' in the latest issue of George magazine is a transparent marketing ploy. But it may also further the fracturing of an unhealthy public fantasy. In a nation of small, scattered family units, the idea of belonging to a close-knit clan that always sticks together has great appeal. That was why Americans loved ''The Waltons,'' Mafia movies and multi-generational novels. It was also one of the reasons the Kennedys continued to fascinate.

title: A Delicate Creature Yields Its Secrets

Just try to catch one, even with a net, and you'll soon discover the 300-million-year-old advantage of having evolved with 360-degree vision and the ability to weave, dodge, hover, fly backwards and change directions in a fraction of a second, then take off at 35 miles an hour.

And in doing so, Mr. Clinton highlighted the sort of special benefits that have long found their way into the nation's tax laws, often to the benefit of only a handful of wealthy or influential people.

title: New York Stripped of Tax Setup That Aided Health-Care Services

title: In Society of Female Chimps, Subtle Signs of Vital Status
description: MUCH to the surprise of primatologists, a dominant female chimpanzee turns out to be a lot like Alan Greenspan, the all-mighty czar of the Federal Reserve. He clears his throat, and stock markets tumble. She twitches an ear, and her underlings tremble. He controls the economy without so much as passing a law. She affects her group's fecundity without so much as raising a paw. Both man and ape offer proof that you don't have to speak much, you don't even have to carry a big stick, and still you can rule the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWAIM, J. CARTER, PH.D.
description: SWAIM-J. Carter, Ph.D., D.D., a Presbyterian minister and former professor at the Pittsburgh Theological Seminary, died on Thursday, August 7th, at the age of 93, in Washington, PA. Dr. Swaim was a graduate of Washington & Jefferson College in Washington, PA and the Western Theological Seminary, now Pittsburgh Theological Seminary, in Pittsburgh, PA. Dr. Swaim earned his Doctor of Philosophy degree from the University of Edinburgh, Scotland. Dr. Swaim served pastorates at the First Presbyterian Church in Staten Island, NY; Kingshighway Presbyterian Church in St. Louis, MO; and the Church of the Covenant in New York City, which included a ministry to the United Nations. Before becoming a minister of the Church of the Covenant in New York City, Dr. Swaim was the Executive Director of the Department of English Bible at the National Council of Churches in New York City. Prior to his service with the National Council of Churches, Dr. Swaim was the professor of New Testament Literature and Exegesis at Western Theological Seminary in Pittsburgh. Dr. Swaim was the oldest living Professor Emeritus of the Pittsburgh Theological Seminary. Dr. Swaim had written more than a dozen published books, two of which were selections of the Book-of-theMonth Club. He was a co-author of the widely publicized The Bible Reader. Dr. Swaim's wife of over sixty years, Charlotte Klein Swaim, died several years ago. Dr. Swaim is survived by two sons, Joseph C. Swaim, Jr. of Mt. Lebanon, PA, and Stephen C. Swaim of Arlington, VA, as well as six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Dr. Swaim is also survived by a brother, the Reverend William T. Swaim of Newville, PA. A Memorial Service will be held at 1:00 P.M. on Saturday, August 23rd, at the First Presbyterian Church, 100 East Wheeling Street, Washington, PA 15301. Memorial Gifts may be made to the First Presbyterian Church.

title: AMGEN SHARES FALL ON PROJECTIONS OF SLOW DRUG SALES
description: The stock of Amgen Inc. slipped 12 percent yesterday after the company said it expects sales of its Neupogen and Epogen drugs to slow during the rest of this year. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Amgen, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said worldwide Neupogen sales would grow more slowly this year than in 1996. Also, Epogen is expected to grow more slowly in the second half of the year than the first. Neupogen is used to increase white blood cell counts in cancer and AIDS patients. Epogen is used to raise red blood cell levels in kidney dialysis patients. Amgen also said it was no longer comfortable with analysts' earnings estimates of $2.83 a share for 1997. Amgen earned $2.42 a share in the last fiscal year. Amgen said that changes in AIDS therapies had hurt sales of Neupogen and would continue to do so. Shares of Amgen fell $6.9375, to $50.1875 yesterday.

Some 25 researchers, managers and scientists gathered discreetly in Tampere, a bastion of high-technology research in Finland, and were given this broad mission: ''Look at the next challenge'' in tapping the exploding world of wireless communications.

title: Partial Justice for the Klinghoffers
description: On Oct. 7, 1985, four Palestinian gunmen hijacked the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro as it steamed off the Egyptian coast with 400 people on board. When the terrorists received no response to their demands they executed Leon Klinghoffer, a 69-year-old Jewish passenger from New York City. The youngest of the hijackers shot Mr. Klinghoffer in the head and back as the American, who had suffered two earlier strokes, sat in his wheelchair. Mr. Klinghoffer and his wheelchair were then shoved into the sea.

description: The Treasury market, after being pummeled by dealers and investors for four sessions because of a poor quarterly refunding and concern that a strong economy would lead the Fed to raise interest rates, enjoyed a brief respite yesterday morning, only to reverse course and chalk up its fifth loss in a row.

description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said yesterday that net income rose nearly 13 percent in its fiscal second quarter as each of its divisions recorded a sales increase and a profit.

title: Rex Barney, 72, Dodger Pitcher; Threw a No-Hitter for Brooklyn
description: Rex Barney, whose no-hitter for the Brooklyn Dodgers against the New York Giants in 1948 was the crowning point of a baseball career shackled by his inability to get the ball over the plate consistently, died yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 72.
