title: Cartoons About Children Feature Grown-Up Jokes
description: Like most 8-year-old boys who spend a lot of time together, the friends in the animated series ''South Park'' have a phrase they repeat endlessly. ''Oh, my God, they killed Kenny,'' the boys are always yelling, and they're not joking. Each week, Kenny, the one muffled in a cheery red ski parka, is wiped out while his three pals look on: he is smashed by a U.F.O., stampeded by cows, impaled on a flagpole. In the best cartoon tradition, Kenny bounces back as easily as Wile E. Coyote.

title: Steris to Acquire Medical Concern
description: The Steris Corporation, a provider of infection prevention products and a variety of health care services, agreed yesterday to buy Isomedix Inc., which provides sterilization services, for about $142 million in cash.

title: Discoverer Of Cunanan Gains Reward
description: Surrounded by newspaper reporters and squinting in the glare of television lights, Fernando Carreira smiled broadly as he held the $45,000 in reward money he collected today, nearly three weeks after he inadvertently discovered the hideout of the suspected serial killer Andrew P. Cunanan.

title: Mexico's Opposition Parties Plan Control of Congress
description: Setting aside for the moment their broad ideological differences, the four Mexican opposition parties have formed a voting bloc that will allow them to elect the Speaker of Mexico's House and to control its powerful rules committee.

title: BROOKFIELD PROPERTIES PLANS TO BUY GENTRA FROM TRILON
description: The Brookfield Properties Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 43 percent interest in Gentra Inc. from the Trilon Financial Corporation for $262.4 million (Canadian), or $188.2 million (United States) in cash and stock. Gentra, which manages a portfolio of loans and real estate investments, would add six million square feet of commercial properties to Brookfield's portfolio, increasing its holdings to about 32 million square feet. Brookfield, which is based in Toronto, had 1996 revenues of $950.7 million (Canadian). Trilon Financial, a Toronto-based financial services company, had 1996 revenues of $6.21 billion (Canadian).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCE, JOAN L.

France on April 25, 1951, and they resided together in New Jersey until moving to Babylon Village in 1970. Beloved wife of William P. France. Devoted mother of William E. description: President Clinton will order changes in the testing of prescription drugs to insure that manufacturers specifically examine the drugs' effects on children if the medications are to be used by any significant number of young patients, White House officials said today.

title: Personal Health
description: A 73-YEAR-OLD Memphis woman was discharged from the hospital with a prescription for medication that was not covered by her Medicare managed-care health plan. Because she could not afford to pay for it herself, she did without it, suffered a relapse and had to be readmitted to the hospital, where she was able to get the drug she needed.

description: VERNAY-Jean-Pierre. December 5, 1938-August 13, 1988. Remembered always with love and joy and gratitude. Bill and Lenny

Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, announced yesterday that the nation's labor unions would lend the International Brotherhood of Teamsters $10 million a week for ''many, many weeks'' to sustain members during the strike.

title: Sweet Songs, With a Bounce and a Grin
description: When the Texan rockabilly singer Ronnie Dawson revived his career in the early 90's, he was a curiosity in good performing shape. He knew a lot of old proto-rock-and-roll songs and had a bunch of his own, some dating back to the late 1950's, when he was the teen-age ''Blond Bomber,'' recording songs like ''Action Packed'' and ''Rockin' Bones.'' He scratched out his sets with luck-of-the-draw sidemen back then and took requests from thin audiences of record collectors.

title: Officers Investigated In a Suspect's Injuries
description: Prosecutors are investigating allegations that police officers beat and tortured a man while he was in custody at a Brooklyn station house, officials said.

title: A Chef Tells All, With Sorbet In Hand
description: DESIGNER sorbets, in flavors like grapefruit-Campari and passion fruit, have become so mainstream that supermarkets sell them. So, John Dudek, the pastry chef at Duane Park Cafe, 157 Duane Street (at West Broadway), in TriBeCa, has to work harder to come up with his flavors for the dozens of sorbets and granitas that he concocts every summer. This month, he is featuring 29 of them on a rotating basis, like blueberry-kirsch sorbet, orange-Armagnac sorbet and chocolate granita with mint zabaglione. The sorbets, $6 for three flavors, are served at lunch and dinner, or without a meal at the bar.

title: Taiwan Youths, So Versatile
description: The program for Saturday night's Alice Tully Hall concert described the ''most distinguishing features'' of Double Tenth Junior High School in Taichung, Taiwan, as ''the experimental music class and female volleyball team.'' The place must therefore be positively jumping with experimental music, and has to be a major force on the Taiwan volleyball circuit, since its orchestras -- which by implication are among its less distinguishing features, and which were the point of this concert -- are engaging and proficient.

title: Again, Farrakhan Rallies Faithful
description: It was the 15th city in a 90-city, 2-month cross-country tour in preparation for the big day in the fall. By the time he stopped in this town today, he had already visited Boston, Providence, Hartford and Harlem, raising money, rousing the party faithful, trying to build ties with religious, business and political leaders outside his group.

title: On the Web, Where Eros Wears Glasses
description: IT is nice to have a job that combines your interests, and Rufus Griscom and Genevieve Field have no doubt about what moves them: good writing and, to put it plainly, sex. The other day, this ambitious young couple were holed up, as usual, in their book-cramped apartment on Third Avenue in Manhattan that now serves as an office. Calls came in from a photographer with arty shots of naked people -- what else? -- and from a sex columnist who wanted to propose a story about a day her boyfriend Ben spent with an Eskimo supermodel. The theme: jealousy.

title: Federal Inquiry Widens in Testing Scheme
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan unsealed court records yesterday that showed for the first time the extent of what they called a nationwide scheme to sell answers to standardized graduate school exams. And they suggested in court papers that hundreds of students were admitted to schools with fraudulent test scores.

title: A Continuous Role
description: Senior American officials said today that an American intelligence official would play a continuing role between Palestinian and Israeli intelligence officers to insure that security cooperation continues beyond the investigation into the Jerusalem bombings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEINKER, MYRA R.
description: SHEINKER-Myra R., age 61, 37year resident of Roslyn, LI, NY, on August 11, 1997, after a courageous and valiant struggle against illness. Commissioner of the Garden City Park Water/Fire District for the past 24 years; senior commissioner and Chairperson of the Board. First woman ever elected as a water or fire commissioner in New York State. Founder and President of Harmony Travel, Inc, a leader in corporate, governmental and institutional travel. Past President, Hamilton Park (Roslyn, LI) Civic Association. Executive Board Member, Nassau County Association of Fire Districts. Former First Vice-Chairperson, LI Water Conference. Affiliated with American Water Works Association, Water Environment Federation, Society of Women Engineers, International Association of Fire Chiefs, National Fire Prevention Association. Born in Brooklyn, New York, Commissioner Sheinker received a BS degree from Adelphi University and did graduate work at Michigan State University in the field of water and wastewater utility management. She was an acknowledged leader and innovator in all her professional and community endeavors, and a warm and caring friend to many. Survived by her husband of 41 years William, three loving children, Taran Chernin, Craig and Kerrie, devoted son-in-law Howard Chernin, adoring grandchildren Amanda, Cara and Jenna, cherished brother and sister-in-law Seymour and Eleanor Krinsky, and dear nephews Scott and Glen Krinsky. Predeceased by her beloved parents, Fay and George Krinsky. Services Wednesday, August 13, 1997, 1:00 PM, at Sunset Chapels, Inc, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, LI, NY. Burial immediately following at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI. Memorial gifts to Garden City Park Fire Department-Subscription Fund, 333 Marcus Avenue, Garden City Park, NY 11040 would be appreciated.

title: For Hockey in Trenton
description: Mercer County officials have long dreamed of building a hockey arena and making Trenton the home to the state's first minor league hockey team. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that the state would lend $5 million toward the construction of a 10,000-seat arena.

title: Roy Gerrard, 62, an Illustrator And Author of Children's Books
description: Roy Gerrard, an author and illustrator who charmed children with his bouncy rhymes and thumb-shaped characters acting out their adventures -- and misadventures -- in sumptuous period settings, died on Aug. 5 in his native England. He was 62 and lived in Stockport, Cheshire.

description: SIX years ago, Bob Stafford of Teegarden, Ind., was buying a car. He joked to the salesman that he should be able to pay for the sky-blue Chevrolet Corsica before he died of cancer.

description: Striking back in what could turn into a lengthy legal battle, the Intel Corporation filed a counterclaim against the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday, accusing the company of violating 14 Intel patents that appear to affect virtually every aspect of Digital's business.

description: Encouraged by relatively low interest rates and the swelling value of their stock portfolio, Bruce and Alexis Goria plunged into the home buying whirl last spring. They tramped through dozens of houses in Bergen County, N.J., just west of New York City, before finding one they liked.

description: The starting pitchers are the stars of the Mets' magic act. Stick them in a box, hack the box into sections, and somehow a piecemeal rotation turns up intact and even thrives. Abracadabra.

title: CHRONICLE

Ablow, M.D., President

title: Jobless? Broke? Men, You Can Always Strip
description: Improbable smiles dot the ads for non-comedies from ''Mrs. Brown'' to ''In the Company of Men,'' but in fact this summer at the movies has been no laughing matter. Not until ''The Full Monty,'' the irresistible tale of unemployed steelworkers in Sheffield, England, who contrive a bold moneymaking scheme. Shy, gruff or paunchy as they are, these middle-aged men are persuaded to try stripping to raise funds and bolster damaged self-esteem. Brightly acted and casually hilarious, ''The Full Monty'' exploits this gimmick in witty, trenchant ways that are always generous, never cruel.

title: Excerpts From the Report On Abuses at City Shelter
description: Following is an excerpt from a report by Commissioner Edward J. Kuriansky of the Department of Investigation on the allegations of rape and sexual assault at the New Day Shelter in the Bronx.

title: Money Gains Access. So What?
description: The issue of access to politicians who should have it and how much they should have -- has gotten mixed up in the debate about political money. Access is what contributions are supposed to buy for individuals who wish to influence politicians. This is giving access a bad name, even though the term refers only to a claim on the attention of politicians, not to the delivery of any particular outcome.

title: Gingrich in '98: Money Gushing Both In and Out
description: In the first six months of this year, Speaker Newt Gingrich raised more money for his 1998 re-election race than anyone else in Congress -- and promptly spent it all.

title: Mutual Fund Manager Abruptly Leaves Janus
description: Thomas F. Marsico, the portfolio manager of two top-performing mutual funds of the Janus Funds, a Denver-based mutual fund company, left the company abruptly on Monday.

description: Living in this wilderness outpost, bounded by the Salmon River and the Lost River Range, Jackie Matson always thought she was a world away from big-city carcinogens.

title: Obstacle to Unifying Bosnia: Politicians Who Have Their Hands in the Till
description: The latest obstacle to unifying Bosnia, Western diplomats say, is not ethnic hatred or unpunished war criminals, or refugees. It is money: millions of dollars that political leaders get from smuggling goods into the three mini-states they control and from skimming their own treasuries.

title: Executive Changes
description: THE LIMITED INC., Columbus, Ohio, named Robert Bernard president and chief executive of Limited Stores, a chain of women's clothing stores.

title: SUN CUTS PRICES AND ADDS FEATURES ON MIDRANGE SERVER
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. cut prices as much as 27 percent yesterday and added features to its midrange computer server in a bid to win market share from competitors like the Hewlett-Packard Company. The Ultra Enterprise 3000 server now starts at $43,250. Sun, based in Mountain View, Calif., introduced the Ultra Enterprise line in April 1996 and revenue from the midrange models has nearly quadrupled, according to the market research firm International Data Corporation. Shares of Sun fell 50 cents, to $47.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, LEAH
description: EPSTEIN-Leah. Passed away Tuesday, Aug 12, 1997 at age 95. Sister-in-law of Sir Jacob Epstein, famed Anglo-American sculptor, who in appreciation of her homemaking and culinary abilities, deemed her a ''genius.'' Devoted mother of Professor Emeritus Howard Evans, Naturalist and Anatomist of the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell and Martin Evans MD, retired pediatrician, a founding member of the Dept of Pediatrics at Schneider Children's Hospital. She is survived by loving sister Beatrice Travis Linder.

title: Mr. Pataki's Veto List
description: New York's Governor, George Pataki, has the unenviable job of winnowing through 374 newly passed pieces of legislation. Thanks to the chaos of the Albany political process, some are bound to be flawed due to accidental drafting errors. But the lawmakers also passed some very bad bills on purpose, opting to please special interests at the expense of the state's welfare. It is left to Mr. Pataki to show his leadership and veto them.

title: Giving In to Rich Temptation
description: RICKIE TAMAYO, the size-6 co-owner of Cafe Tamayo in Saugerties, N.Y., freely admits that she must have a pint of ice cream a day. ''That's just the minimum daily requirement,'' Ms. Tamayo said. And not the low-fat stuff, either. Her favorites are Haagen-Dazs coffee or Vanilla Swiss Almond. ''I'm happiest when I have a quart all to myself,'' she added.

title: CROWN CORK AND SEAL TO REVAMP ITS CONSTAR UNIT
description: The Crown Cork and Seal Company said yesterday that it would close six United States plastic beverage container plants and lay off 430 workers in a restructuring of its Constar unit. The closings will result in a third-quarter after-tax charge of $43.3 million, or 31 cents a fully diluted share. First Call projected third-quarter earnings of $1.11 a share. For the third quarter a year ago, the company reported earnings of $109.4 million, or 81 cents a share, on sales of $2.5 billion. The company said it expected the restructuring to save $20 million a year.

title: Mild-Mannered Sakic Is a Small-Town Guy
description: Until his team moved to Denver two years ago, Joe Sakic was not a big city sort of guy. He grew up in Burnaby, British Columbia, near Vancouver. He played junior hockey in Swift Current, Saskatchewan. And he spent seven seasons in Quebec, playing for the Nordiques. Even when that team became the Colorado Avalanche and won the Stanley Cup in 1996, Sakic, the high-scoring star of the team, seemed to be a shy sort of captain with little to say.

title: MIDCOM IN $75 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR PHOENIX NETWORK
description: Midcom Communications Inc., a struggling reseller of long-distance services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Phoenix Network Inc. for $75 million in stock. Midcom, based in Southfield, Mich., will pay 9.1 million common shares for Phoenix, which is based in Golden, Colo. It will also provide 1.5 million more shares and assume $15.7 million of debt if Phoenix closes a planned acquisition of Trans National Communications Inc., a long-distance reseller in Boston. Phoenix lost $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, compared with a loss of $1.9 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: APS HOLDING TO CLOSE 15 STORES AND ELIMINATE SOME JOBS
description: The APS Holding Corporation, an auto parts distributor in Houston, said yesterday that it would close 15 stores and 50 warehouses in an effort to return to profitability. The company said it would cut a substantial number of jobs but did not provide details. The company said it would post a second-quarter loss of 11 cents to 13 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had expected a profit of 25 cents a share. The company's 1998 earnings are expected to fall below analysts' estimates of 75 cents to $1.40 a share.

title: Panel Faults Caseworkers In Child Abuse
description: One year after a major overhaul of New York City's child welfare system, a judicially appointed panel of specialists has found that child abuse investigators continue to endanger the lives of thousands of children with the same missteps and sloppy casework that led to the death of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo.

title: Visa Reduces Liability on Lost or Stolen Debit Cards
description: Responding to growing consumer unease about potential problems with debit cards, the Visa U.S.A. division of Visa International said yesterday that customers would not be liable for unauthorized charges if they reported a lost or stolen card within two days.

title: Accomplices In Killing Of Policeman Are Sentenced
description: Two gang members involved in the murder of a Bronx police officer, Kevin Gillespie, were sentenced yesterday to life in Federal prison without parole.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS SAID TO HAVE HIGH UNITED DEFENSE BID
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has reportedly bid $1 billion for United Defense L.P., an armored-vehicle business owned by the FMC Corporation and the Harsco Corporation. General Dynamics was the highest bidder, offering more than Carlyle Group in Washington, people familiar with the offers said. A final decision on the winning bidder has not been announced. The bids were disclosed yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. The acquisition would make General Dynamics the only United States armored-combat-vehicle maker and could face antitrust scrutiny. It is the only United States tank producer and one of two makers of Navy submarines and destroyers.

title: Money Manager for Colleges Is Told to Return $2.6 Million
description: Federal regulators ordered First Capital Strategists and its four partners today to return $2.6 million to colleges and universities that lost more than $137 million on unauthorized investments by a former First Capital trader.

description: A company that operated the city's largest helicopter service for tourists was evicted from the East 34th Street Heliport yesterday, losing its final skirmish in a long legal battle with the city over back rent and the number of flights it sent daily over the Statue of Liberty, Central Park and Yankee Stadium.

description: Competitors of the United Parcel Service are doing about as much business as they can possibly handle, but not one said it was thrilled about the strike against the nation's biggest package-delivery company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENITE, BOBBY S.
description: GENITE-Bobby S. on August 12, 1997 after a long illness. A Philippino-American, Bobby came to New York in 1975, loved it here and stayed. He got work as an accountant and was soon able to lead the life he wanted. He loved dance and danced for the Philippine Dance Company in the late 70's. He made friends easily. They loved him for his sweet smile and his quiet and easy-going personality. He also became the one to whom questions were directed about ballet, theater, movies, travel, names, etc. He loved attending and giving parties, and many of his friends will remember him as an excellent host. He is survived by his father, Juanito Genite of the Philippines, his mother Eufemia Genite, a sister Edna S. Arellano, a brother Conrado Silpao all of Guam and his companion of eight years, Ronald Taylor of Brooklyn and Greenwich Village. Viewing at Peter C. DeLuca Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, Thurs and Fri, 2-5 and 7-9:30 pm. Memorial Mass will be held St. Malachy's, 239 W 49th St 10am Saturday.

title: If There's Heaven, It Should Expect Changes
description: IN the 1960's, Paul Rudolph sneaked a triplex rooftop addition onto a brownstone on Beekman Place, just before the historic-preservation police would have stopped him. Embarking on the New York phase of his brilliant career, Mr. Rudolph -- often called the most fertile architectural imagination of the postwar generation -- piled a hanging architectural garden on the rather plain building: the fragile steel-and-glass superstructure cantilevered over the street and spilled off the back in an interlocking succession of landscaped terraces overlooking the East River.

She leaves her husband of 56 years, Gardner, her daughters Deborah D. Landon, Joan L. Gignoux and Judith A. Landon, and four grandchildren. Her sister, Catherine Granger, predeceased her. description: The Quaker Oats Company is passing the spoon to a new child to replace ''Mikey.''

title: LUCENT EXPECTS TO TAKE $950 MILLION CHARGE
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it expected to take a fourth-quarter charge of $950 million, or $1.47 a share, related to the purchase of the Octel Communications Corporation, resulting in a loss. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Lucent said the charge was related to research and development. Lucent said it expected to take the charge when the acquisition is completed, probably in the quarter ending Sept. 30. Lucent is expected to earn 50 cents a share in the quarter, based on a survey of 13 analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. On July 17, Lucent said it would buy Octel, a leading voice-mail company, for $31 a share, or $1.8 billion, in cash.

title: Station House Horror
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was right when he called the story that Abner Louima told about his ordeal at the hands of New York City police officers ''shocking to any decent human being.'' It is the kind of account that is usually reserved for political prisoners in dictatorships. A man says he is beaten and dragged into a bathroom in the police station house, where officers assault him with a toilet plunger, sticking the handle into his rectum and mouth while screaming racial epithets.

title: Questionable Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: PIZZA HUT TO SELL ITS D'ANGELO'S SANDWICH SHOP CHAIN
description: Pepsico Inc.'s Pizza Hut unit said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its D'Angelo's Sandwich Shops chain to the Papa Gino's Holdings Corporation. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. After the purchase, Papa Gino's, which is based in Dedham, Mass., will have 378 units and more than $200 million in sales. Tom Galligan, the chairman of Papa Gino's, said that the company would continue to operate the 203 D'Angelo's shops and 175 Papa Gino's outlets as separate chains. Pepsico, based in Purchase, N.Y., has been selling its casual dining chains and company-owned restaurants in preparation for the spinoff of its restaurant businesses, including Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut, as Tricon Global Restaurants Inc. by the end of the year.

title: A Few Rays Of Sunlight For Irabu
description: THE weather yesterday was inconsistent -- hard showers, clearing, soft showers -- and that was about right for Hideki Irabu.

title: Mitsui Members to Aid Construction Entity
description: Sakura Bank and three other members of the Mitsui & Company conglomerate -- Mitsui Trust and Banking, Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance and Mitsui Mutual Life Insurance -- stepped in to rescue the Mitsui Construction Company, another member of the group. Mitsui Construction is the latest contractor overwhelmed by debts that piled up after Japan's real estate boom collapsed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIN, LILLIAN
description: FEIN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Fred Fein and Bernard Shiller. Devoted mother of Stephen and mother-in-law of Sandy. Adored grandmother of Barrie Fein. Loving aunt of Beverly and Ted Gursky, Naomi and Stan Zarinsky, Sharon and Loren Malamud, Barbara Silverman, George and Judy Kessman, Marilyn and Donald Livsky, Natalie and Milton Kranitz, Ruth Fein, and Loretta Fein. Cherished great-aunt to many. Past President of Ladies Pythians, active in The City of Hope. Services today 12 noon at ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Blvd and 66th Ave, Forest Hills.

title: Satellites Of a Prague Superstar
description: For the last five years, Mostly Mozart's planners have been searching for ways to liven up the festival, to capture the excitement that surrounded it in its early days, when it was fresh and trendy, in its dressed-down way. Lincoln Center's solution so far has been to hop onto the thematic-presentation bandwagon, and this year that approach has yielded a mini-series within the festival in which Mozart's relationship with Prague and its musicians is examined.

title: Margaret Peet, 90, Ex-Advertising Executive
description: Margaret Sherman Peet, a former advertising executive, died Aug. 6 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after a fall, her son, Charles D. Peet Jr., said. She was 90 and a longtime resident of Bronxville.

title: Jets Rookie Running Back Changes Parcells's Mind-Set
description: Back home in Morganton, N.C., Leon Johnson is a figure of heroic proportions. He has been since high school.

title: Early Gains In Treasury Prices Wane
description: Relieved that reports on retail sales and producer prices were less alarming than some investors had feared, the Treasury market rallied sharply yesterday before giving up some of the gains because of worries about the dollar.

title: One More Police Victim
description: At what point will Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir decide that things have gone too far, that it is time to put a stop to the barbaric behavior of so many New York City police officers?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOCUM, JOHN JERMAIN
description: SLOCUM-John Jermain, 83, Dearly beloved husband of Eileen (Gillespie) Slocum, beloved father of John J. Slocum Jr., Beryl Powell, and Marguerite Quinn, devoted grandfather of John J. Slocum III, Marie-Louise Slocum, Olivia Slocum, Lawrence Louis Gillespie, John B. Trevor IV, Phyllis Trevor Higgerson, Evelyn Trevor Holm, Sophia Brown Trevor, Irene Sherman Trevor, Adam Clayton Powell IV, and Lt. Sherman Scott Powell, and 2 great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Friday, August 15, 1997, at 11:00 am in Trinity Church, Queen Anne Square, Newport, RI. Interment will be held in the Island Cemetery, Newport, RI. A reception following the services will be held at the family's home. For information Hambly Funeral Home, ''Brick House'', 30 Red Cross Avenue, Newport, RI.

title: Evangelist Will Pay Penalty for Assault
description: Accused of assaulting a flight attendant, the Rev. Robert H. Schuller, the television evangelist seen by millions on the ''Hour of Power,'' appeared yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn, apologized and agreed to enter a program that could end the possibility of further prosecution after six months of good behavior.

title: In Prime Minister's Life, A Parable of His Country
description: At 77, Prime Minister I. K. Gujral, who has been buffeted from crisis to crisis since taking over as head of India's 15-party coalition Government four months ago, is by his own account a transitional figure. But he has a vision -- ending decades of enmity with Pakistan -- that would have likely found favor with the leaders who won India's independence 50 years ago.

title: CD Pioneers Decide to Form 2d Standard For Next Disks
description: A new fight has broken out among the companies developing the next generation of digital disks that will replace the audio compact disk, the computer CD-ROM and the TV laser disk.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Oriental Lilies

title: Pension Plan Puts Teamsters' Chief in Tight Spot
description: United Parcel Service officials say that one of the mysteries of the 10-day-old teamsters' strike is the union's opposition to the company's proposal for a new pension plan. According to U.P.S., the plan would increase monthly pension benefits by an average of 50 percent.

title: Hefty Penalties Against a Broker In Initial Issues
description: D. H. Blair Investment Banking, a securities firm that has promoted itself as the top underwriter of new stock issues among small companies, has based its reputation on the performance of its issues after they begin trading. Yesterday, an associated firm agreed to pay a $2 million fine and to reimburse customers $2.4 million for overcharging them during the first few days of trading in such issues.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Toughest Foe At the P.G.A. Is Winged Foot
description: Any golfer who has competed at Winged Foot Golf Club can tell horror stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIN, JOHN THORNE
description: PERKIN-John Thorne, of Fairfield, Conn. and Nantucket, Mass. died peacefully in New York on August 12, 1997 after a brief illness. Loving husband of Elizabeth (Betsy) and devoted father of Christopher, Thorne, and Richard. Also survived by his mother, Mrs. Richard S. Perkin of New Canaan, Conn., brothers Richard T. of New York City, and Robert S. of Darien, Conn., and sister Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, Mass. A graduate of Milton Academy (1955) and Bowdoin College (1959), Mr. Perkin was a stockbroker with A.G. Edwards & Co. At one time, he was an Overseer of Bowdoin College, a Vice President of The Bridgeport Symphony, a Director of Bridgeport Hospital, and a Governor of the Country Club of Fairfield. In addition, he was formerly a Trustee and Treasurer of Fairfield Country Day School and, at the time of his death, a Trustee of the Perkin Fund and an Honorary Trustee of Fairfield Country Day School. A memorial service will be held at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, Conn. at 11:00am, Saturday, August 16, 1997. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions for the planting of trees in John's memory be sent to: Bowdoin College, Office of the Secretary, Station 4100, Brunswick, ME 04011; Colgate University, Gift Records Office, 13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, NY, 13346; Hobart College, Development Office, Geneva, NY 14456; or Westminster School, Office of the Headmaster, 995 Hopmeadow St., Simsbury, Conn. 06070.

title: New Everett Hearing Set for October
description: A Family Court judge ruled yesterday at a hearing in Queens that two children of Mets outfielder Carl Everett would remain in foster care at least until late in October, when another hearing will be held to determine if the children have been abused and, if so, who is responsible.

title: End of Stanley's Exile Provides Sign of Relief
description: The space between the lockers belonging to Paul O'Neill and Wade Boggs has not had a uniformed player use it since 1995. It had belonged to Mike Stanley, and the unspoken message since Stanley was allowed to leave via free agency was that it would be wrong to let the cubicle slip into the hands of someone new.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULLEY, ROGER M. BLOOM
description: HULLEY-Roger M. Bloom. 41, of Gardiner, NY, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, died on Monday Aug. 11th of AIDS-related PML. A graduate of Brown University and Columbia Law School, Roger was an assoc. attorney at Skadden Arps in NYC. As a long-term AIDS survivor, he was active in his community, leading buddy teams for ARCS, a local AIDS organization. Survivors include his partner Jeffrey Bright, mother, Terry Hope Hulley, of Weston, CT, sister, Marcia Hulley, of Brookline, MA, and nephews, Willie and Peter. Donations may be sent to The Roger M. Bloom Hulley Memorial Fund, PO Box 399, Gardiner, NY 12525.

title: Cable Wires Are Tangled As Avalanche Receives Aid
description: Fox Sports and Liberty Media both own a piece of the Rangers. And yet they helped provide the Colorado Avalanche with a cushion of future cash flow to keep Joe Sakic from signing with the Rangers yesterday for $21 million.

title: Educated Patients Create Demand for Smarter Breed of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHE, HENRY J.
description: ROCHE-Henry J. Of Bronxville, N.Y. On August 12, 1997. Twin brother of the late William. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, N.Y. between the hours of 6-8PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday August 15 at 11AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONENFELD, SOL
description: SONENFELD-Sol, died August 12, 1997, at the age of 88. Devoted husband of Bea for 55 years. Cherished father of Roberta and her husband Bob; adored and adoring grandfather of Taryn. Dear Dad, my intense sense of loss is softened only by the rich legacy and wonderful memories you've given me. I will continually strive to do the same for Taryn. You'll always be my hero. Love, Roberta. Contributions may be made to YIVO Institute for Jewish Research or the National Yiddish Book Center.

title: Spano Is Indicted in Texas
description: John Spano, whose failed bid to buy the Islanders prompted a criminal investigation, was indicted in Texas yesterday on Federal charges that he defrauded two lenders of at least $5.1 million.

title: Ontario to Shut 7 Border Nuclear Reactors
description: The province of Ontario is shutting down 7 of its 19 operating nuclear reactors -- all within 100 miles of the United States border -- after an internal report concluded that the province's utility company was so badly managed that it had compromised the safety of its entire nuclear power system.

title: Veiled Threat to Prop Currency Undercuts High-Flying Dollar : Bundesbank Keeps Eye on the Mark
description: FRANKFURT  The Bundesbank gave a clear indication Wednesday that it was prepared to raise German interest rates to defend the value of the Deutsche mark and to keep inflation under control.

title: PHYSICIAN SALES AND SERVICES BUYS RADIOLOGY CONCERN
description: Physician Sales and Services Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held S&W X-Ray Inc. for an undisclosed amount to expand its imaging-distribution business. S&W X-Ray, based in Rochester, distributes radiology and imaging equipment, chemicals and supplies and provides technical service. The company had $73 million in revenue in the year ended March 31. Physician Sales, a distributor of medical supplies based in Jacksonville, Fla., said the transaction made its Diagnostic Imaging Inc. unit a leading imaging distributor, with revenue of $340 million.

title: SM SUMMIT DENIES ALLEGATIONS THAT IT PIRATED SOFTWARE
description: SM Summit Holdings Ltd. denied allegations yesterday by the Microsoft Corporation and two other companies of software copyright violations. SM Summit, which is based in Singapore and makes compact disks and CD-ROM's, said it had been irreparably damaged by the accusations. Microsoft, Adobe Systems Inc. and Autodesk Inc. contended that a unit of SM Summit might have been making counterfeit software. The three United States companies have filed a civil lawsuit against SM Summit, acting through the Business Software Alliance, which fights violations of intellectual property laws. The police raided the SM Summit unit yesterday after a former employee tipped off the software group, Microsoft said.

title: Protest Call: 'Something Has to Be Done'
description: On a typical morning, Radio Soleil D'Haiti, a Haitian cable radio station that broadcasts from a storefront in Brooklyn, offers light entertainment, usually the undulating rhythms of peppery compas music. But yesterday, things were far from normal.

title: 12 Hikers Are Swept Away By Flash Flood in a Canyon
description: A canyon renown for its narrow, twisting limestone walls became a trap for 12 hikers on Tuesday when a flash flood filled it with a wall of water 11 feet high.

title: Trying Target For Size
description: ''DOES it seem like the New York area could use a new kind of shopping experience?''

title: City Opera's Workers Vote to Authorize Strike
description: The singers, dancers, chorus, directors and stage managers of the New York City Opera have voted to authorize a strike if negotiations between the company and their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, do not produce a new labor agreement to replace the one that expired on May 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSON, JEANETTE W.
description: LIFSON-Jeanette W., 93, formerly of Deal, N.J., Aug. 11. Survived by a daughter and six grandchildren. Service Sat. Aug. 16, 1 PM, A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 N. Main St., Cranbury, N.J.

title: Gasoline and Oil Prices Rise After Problems at a Refinery
description: Gasoline and crude oil prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as reports of a shutdown at an Exxon refinery in Texas overshadowed data showing an unexpected rise last week in United States inventories of crude oil.

title: Advocacy Groups Set to Resist Subpoenas From Senate Inquiry
description: Many of the nonprofit advocacy groups subpoenaed by the Senate committee investigating campaign finance, among them some of Washington's most influential lobbies on both the left and the right, are angry at the scope of the demand for documents and are suggesting that they may not fully comply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, ROGER W.
description: SULLIVAN-Roger W. On August 12th, beloved husband of Susan; devoted father of Farley and stepfather of Mark and Warren Dabney; loving brother of Barry. Outstanding educator and principal of Smithtown High School. In lieu of flowers and gifts, donations appreciated in his name to the American Heart Association. Memorial services Friday, August 15th, 6 PM, at Temple Beth Sholom, Edgewood Avenue, Smithtown.

title: Vindication, Not Vengeance
description: For a domestic dispute, the ''alienation of affection'' case of Dorothy Hutelmyer vs. Margie Cox Hutelmyer has attracted a lot of national attention. But this is not a story of greed or vengeance, as the press would have it. It's about the need for vindication.

title: Film Festival Reflects Hong Kong That Was
description: The annual Festival Hong Kong, a monthlong series of films at Cinema Village, is offering a precautionary look back at the Hong Kong that was, just in case the city's new masters clamp down on its prosperous movie industry.

title: Founding Fathers Deceived the People, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Brand-New Recipe For Healthy Bones Adds More Calcium
description: Citing substantial evidence that most Americans do not consume enough calcium to stave off bone loss, a panel of nutrition experts set new standards today that increase the recommended daily allowance of calcium-rich foods by roughly one serving per day for most people.

title: Running Away, Girls Were Lured Into Prostitution, Authorities Say
description: They were young girls fleeing problems at home. A 13-year-old on the run from a local group home. A 14-year-old hiding from her father. A 17-year-old who just walked out the door of her parents' house when things got to be too much and an 11-year-old with a history of family troubles.

title: In Murder Of Firefighter, An Arrest But No Motive
description: After James Halversen, a 30-year-old New York City firefighter, was shot to death on a Friday night last January while jogging with his golden retriever on the track at Centereach High School, detectives were baffled. While the Long Island crime scene clearly showed that Mr. Halversen had been a gunman's intended target, investigators could find no motive, no reason anyone would want him dead.

title: But No 80's Excess at Law Students' Summer Programs
description: The other night at the Pull Cart, a ceramic studio in a Manhattan loft, dozens of men and women in their 20's were staring intently at unpainted pottery bowls, cups and saucers. Paintbrushes poised, they deliberated. Stripe versus swirl? Cornflower blue versus heather green?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMLOCK, ROSE
description: HEMLOCK-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Ann, Michael and Alfred. Grandmother of Doreen, Robyn, Adam, Amy, Brian and Laura. Great-grandmother of Tiana and Raj. Beloved sister of Jennie, Symie and Gussie. Services Thurs., 10:30AM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills (at 76th Road).

title: Pataki Expresses Doubts About a Measure for Early Retirement of Teachers
description: In a signal that he may be prepared to veto a bill that would permit thousands of New York City teachers to retire early, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he had concerns about the bill and suggested that he favored letting such matters be resolved through collective bargaining.

title: Settlement in Baseball Suit
description: A Superior Court judge approved a settlement yesterday that awards $6,500 to a girl who had accused the Galloway Township Athletic Association of discriminating against her by refusing to let her play on a boys' baseball team.

title: BIOMATRIX SHARES SOAR AFTER DRUG IS CLEARED FOR SALE
description: The stock of Biomatrix Inc. rose 13 percent yesterday after the company said that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its Synvisc treatment for marketing. Shares of Biomatrix rose $3, to $25.75. Biomatrix, a biomedical company based in Ridgefield, N.J., said Synvisc was used to treat osteoarthritis of the knee. It will be sold by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories in Radnor, Pa., a pharmaceutical unit of the American Home Products Corporation, and will be available in the United States this fall.

title: Ozawa Orders a Shake-Up in the Venerable Program for Student Musicians
description: To much of the public, Tanglewood is the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Here, amid 500 lushly beautiful acres in the tranquil Berkshire Mountains, the orchestra has been presenting summer concerts in its 5,100-seat, open-air music shed since 1938. It was the first festival of its kind in America and remains the most famous.

title: Deputy Mayor Sworn In
description: Jaime Vazquez, who was Mayor Bret D. Schundler's most vocal critic on the Jersey City Council and who ran against him in May, was sworn in Tuesday night as a deputy mayor for international affairs and economic development.

title: Across U.S., Brush Fires Over Money for the Arts
description: The bitter cultural conflict that reached a showdown over continued financing of the National Endowment for the Arts is starting to spread to towns and cities around the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, PAUL
description: RUDOLPH-Paul. The American Institute of Architects, New York Chapter, mourns the death of Paul Rudolph, FAIA. He was an enthusiastic colleague, rigorous mentor, and impassioned designer. He was devoted to the possibilities of modern architecture. His drawings and buildings, compositions of space, light and structure, enriched us all. Robert Geddes, FAIA, President Carol Clark, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISNER, BENJAMIN
description: EISNER-Benjamin. Loving husband of Rita, devoted father of Dr. Cathey Falvo, cherished grandfather of Jessica Falvo. Service today, 10 am, at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mt Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to New Rochelle Peace Action Committee, PO Box 1735, New Rochelle, NY 10802.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the pianist Sviatoslav Richter on Aug. 2 misspelled the surname of his wife. She is Nina Dorlyak, not Doloyak.

title: 4 in Brazil Cleared of Murder in Burning of Indian
description: A federal judge in Brasilia has dismissed murder charges against four young men accused of dousing an Indian leader with gasoline and setting him on fire, saying they did not intend to kill him.

title: Demonizing China? Beijing Can Blame Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Rewriting Burundi's Brutal Past
description: It is hard to talk to a politician in this Central African country today without the word genocide coming up.

title: U.S. Housing Department to Cut 3,000 Workers Over Five Years
description: Clinton Administration officials and the largest union representing Federal housing agency workers said today that they had agreed on a plan to reduce the work force of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to 7,500, from the current level of 10,500, by 2002.

title: The Irish Way, With Flying Feet and a Champion or Two
description: There is nothing quite like the sight of a stage filled with Irish step dancers, their torsos like taut columns with feet that fly through impossibly complex, subtle moves. There was plenty of that kind of excitement from the Trinity Irish Dance Company of Chicago on Tuesday night when it made its New York debut at the Joyce Theater.

title: OFFICER CHARGED IN MAN'S TORTURE AT STATION HOUSE
description: A 25-year-old police officer was charged last night with assaulting and brutalizing a Haitian immigrant in a Brooklyn station house bathroom after arresting him in a street scuffle, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that other officers might also be arrested.

title: In 2 Extraditions, Drug Officials Sense a Shift in Dominican Policy
description: In a move that United States officials hope will mean a breakthrough in their efforts to combat the international drug trade, the Dominican Republic honored a longstanding request by the United States yesterday and extradited two Dominicans to New York to face drug and murder charges.

title: Differing Views of Policeman Accused of Assaulting Man in Custody
description: Police Officer Justin Volpe, 25, followed his father into police work and landed a job on the midnight tour, patrolling the streets of Flatbush, Brooklyn. Now he stands accused of assault and sexual abuse for allegedly tormenting and critically injuring a man he had taken into custody.

title: Struggling To Wake Up A Lethargic Tour Crowd
description: This summer, saying you run a touring rock festival has become like saying you enjoy burning money. With so many package tours on the road in imitation of Lollapalooza, which started the trend six years ago, audiences are not only dwindling, they're also getting less enthusiastic. Performers at nearly all of the festivals that have come through New York this summer have berated the crowd for its lackluster response, and the Horde tour stop on Tuesday evening at Jones Beach was no exception. The headliner, Neil Young, inserted a lyric into ''Throw Your Hatred Down'' lashing out at the crowd. Beck, who preceded him, stopped the music and spent several minutes imitating the crowd's ho-hum response to his set, which is one of the year's most entertaining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIG, DONALD JOSEPH (DON), M.D., PH.D.
description: SELIG-Donald Joseph (Don), M.D., Ph.D., age 54, of 103-2 Continental Plaza, Elizabeth City, NC, died Tuesday, August 12, 1997, at The Duke University Medical Center in Durham, NC. A native of Jamaica, NY, Dr. Selig was the son of Edith Gordon Selig of New York City and the late George Raymond Selig. Besides his mother, survivors include two daughters, Heather Kwakye of Detroit, MI, and Elizabeth Selig of St. Louis, MO; a son, Kevin Selig of Vancouver, British Columbia; a companion, Bonnie L. Robertson, of the residence; and one grandchild. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Community Prescription Project, 108 N. Road St., Elizabeth City, NC. Blood donations to the American Red Cross will also be greatly appreciated. For further details, please contact Twiford's Memorial Chapel, 405 East Church St., Elizabeth City, NC.

title: Nissan exults over an offbeat campaign, despite flat sales and a debate on ads that 'entertain.'
description: THE Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. is confidently declaring victory for a quirky year-old brand image campaign, despite lackluster sales and a debate still raging over the efficacy of advertising that seeks to peddle products by entertaining.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKINSON, WILLIAM H.
description: JENKINSON-William H., on Aug. 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Carolyn (nee Taylor). Loved by many-family and friends. Private Cremation. Memorial Mass to be held at St. Bede's Episcopal Church, 220 Berry Hill Rd., Syosset, N.Y., date to be announced. Donations in his memory can be made to St. Bede's Church.

title: Fleet Financial Seen Nearing Purchase of Money Manager
description: Fleet Financial Group is close to an agreement to buy the Columbia Management Company, a money manager based in Portland, Ore., for $500 million to $600 million in cash, people familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on May 6 about a North Carolina case in which a drunken driver was convicted of first-degree murder characterized the drug Xanax incorrectly. Several readers pointed out as early as May 6 that it is a tranquilizer, not an antidepressant; this correction was delayed by procedural errors.

title: Skills, Not Abstinence
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYER, HAIM ''SONNY.''
description: BEYER-Haim ''Sonny.'' 94, died in Florida 7/27/97, husband of the late Rose Reichman Beyer. Born and raised in NYC. Graveside memorial service at South Dartmouth Cemetery, South Dartmouth, MA Sunday, 8/17/97, 3:30 PM.

title: Plan Would Ban Ads During Mayoral Race
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent appearances in a series of publicly financed advertisements while he is running for re-election would be sharply curtailed under a proposal made yesterday by Councilman Sal F. Albanese, a Brooklyn Democrat who is also running for mayor.

title: Injuries? Safety First Is the Motto
description: Do not look for sympathy from the Indianapolis Colts over the bushel of preseason player injuries. Do not ask Jim Harbaugh, the Colts' rugged quarterback, if he has shed any tears over the rash of quarterbacks who have fallen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRAFATI, LILLIAN
description: BERRAFATI-Lillian. Beloved wife of Dr. Gerald Berrafati. Devoted mother of Josephine Tice, Linda Moran and Joseph. Proud grandmother of Donald, Holly and Gerald. Loving daughter of Gussie Fauci. Fond sister-in-law and friend of Connie Fauci. Dearest sister of the late Peter Fauci. Mass will be celebrated Saturday, 10:00 a.m., at Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington, New York. Reposing at Sinatra Funeral Home, 601 Yonkers Avenue. Viewing hours: Thursday and Friday 2:00 p.m.-4:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m.-9:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please make all contributions to Calvary Hospital or to St. John Riverside Hospital.

title: Suspended Players to Be Paid
description: Baseball's independent arbitrator has ruled that clubs cannot withhold pay from players during suspensions, even if their contracts have clauses stipulating otherwise.

title: Top Soldier Accused of Harassment Threatens to Name Others
description: The highest-ranking enlisted soldier in the Army issued a threat through his lawyers today that if he was put on trial on sexual misconduct charges, his defense team would show that top-ranking Army officers were not prosecuted for the same crimes.

title: Educated Patients Create Demand for Smarter Breed of Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLATTERY, REV. JAMES M.
description: FLATTERY-Rev. James M., 71 years old, Diocese of Ogdensburg, NY, formerly of the Bronx. Suddenly on August 9, 1997 in Potsdam, NY. Beloved son of the late Michael and Elizabeth. Loving brother of the late Mary E. Dowd, the late Rev. John J. and Sister Kathryn Flattery PBVM-Saint Michael's High School, NYC. Dear brother-in-law of Michael A. Dowd. Loving uncle of Kevin Dowd, Patricia Feeley and Margaret Fitzpatrick and great uncle of nine. Visiting at The Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave., New Hyde Park, NY Thursday and Friday 2-5 and 7-9 p.m. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 a.m. at Saint Gregory the Great RC Church, Bellerose, NY. Burial to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers donations made be made to Mount Saint Joseph's Convent, 88 Jackson Ave. New Windsor, NY 12553.

title: India at 50
description: For a people whose culture was defined two millenniums ago, five decades may seem only the flick of an eyelid. But for modern India, attaining the nervous dignity of 50 is an occasion for celebration and self-examination. Both responses reverberate among nearly a billion Indians at home and abroad, some of whom outspokenly decry the shortcomings of a country they perceive as poor, corrupt and divided. Yet this eloquent dissent, no less than fireworks and parades, suggests that this anniversary is truly worth remarking.

title: Bit of This, Bit of That: Add Light
description: DEZ RYAN walks a thin line between innovation and kitsch. Ms. Ryan, right, a Manhattan sculptor, composes candlesticks, wall sconces and lamps from elegant blown glass, thrift store gleanings like abandoned lamp bases and couture fabric castoffs she uses for lamp shades.

title: Execution to Be Sought in Pizza Killings
description: The New Jersey authorities revealed today that they would seek the death penalty for one of the two teen-agers charged with murdering two pizza deliverymen who were ambushed in April in the hill country in the state's northwestern corner.

title: Whose Life Is It?
description: Freedom of choice in our everyday lives is a treasured right in America. That freedom should, of course, be balanced with a sense of responsibility for our personal well-being and that of others.

title: The precocious Thai economy receives its comeuppance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, ALBERT B., MD.
description: HAAS-Albert B., MD. The entire community of New York University School of Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished and loyal colleague Dr. Albert B. Haas. Over the years, his serivce to NYU as a foremost member of the faculty brought immeasurable knowledge, talent and grace to our academic programs. Dr. Haas graduated from medical school in Budapest. In 1940 after France fell to the Nazi's, Dr. Haas and his wife Sonja joined the French Resistance. The Haases were arrested and transported to separate concentration camps. Dr. Haas was imprisoned in Dachau and other camps where he was ordered to perform surgery even though he was not trained as a surgeon. Dr. Haas was able to acquire basic surgical skills by self study and assistance by other surgeons. These skills enabled him to save many prisoners. His extraodinary personal account-''The Doctor And The Damned''-was published later and received widespread acclaim. Dr. Haas immigrated to the United States and completed a residency in Bellevue Hospital. Thanks to the encouragement of Howard A. Rusk, Albert Haas joined the NYU Faculty. For over forty years Dr. Haas taught, conducted extensive research and co-authored with Dr. Rusk scientific papers on pulmonary diseases. The NYU faculty is greatly diminished by the passing of our dear friend, colleague and hero of WWII, Dr. Albert B. Haas. We are deeply saddened. All of us were fortunate to know him and benefit from his vast expertise and appreciate his kindly manner. We extend our deepest sympathy to Francois Haas, Ph.D., an Associate Professor of Rehabilitation Medicine at NYU Medical Center's Rusk Institute, and to Sheila, his wife, and their two daughters: Ariane and Alex. Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP Dean & Provost, NYU School of Medicine & Medical Center

title: WELLS FARGO PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,200 MORE JOBS
description: Wells Fargo & Company, which has eliminated 12,600 jobs since it bought First Interstate Bancorp in April, said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,200 more. In a document filed with regulators, Wells said it expected to have about 32,000 full-time positions by the fourth quarter, down from 33,216 as of June 30. If it reaches that goal, Wells will have reduced its payroll by 13,800, or 28 percent, since the two banks were combined. The cuts are intended to help Wells afford its $13.2 billion acquisition, one of the biggest mergers ever in banking. Wells stock fell $2.3125 yesterday, to $262.1875.

title: Unlikely Companions Fleeing Down River
description: ''The Delta,'' Ira Sachs's somber portrait of a sexually confused teen-ager growing up in the South, zeroes in on a quality of adolescent life that most youth-oriented movies bend over backward to avoid portraying: its sheer stultifying boredom. Life is difficult enough if you're a footloose teen-ager with grown-up desires living in a religious household under the watchful eye of parents who view you as a child. Throw in the first stirrings of homosexuality and the angst can be suffocating.

title: MacTavish Returns as a Coach
description: When last seen in a Ranger uniform, Craig MacTavish was winning the defensive-zone face-off that clinched victory in the final moments of Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals against Vancouver in June 1994.

title: In $5 Billion Deal, Grace Will Sell Packaging Business
description: The W. R. Grace Company said yesterday that it would divest itself of its packaging business in a complex, two-step transaction that culminates a strategy of focusing on the company's other main business, specialty chemicals.

title: Wall Street Journal To Print TV Listings
description: In an effort to broaden both its readership and advertising base, The Wall Street Journal will publish daily television, cable and theater schedules beginning this fall.

title: TRANSACTIONs
description: BASEBALL

title: Union Again Fails to Win Over Workers at Big Textile Plants
description: For the fourth time in 23 years, a textile workers' union has failed in its effort to unionize a dozen North Carolina plants owned by Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., the Kannapolis, N.C., company that has come to symbolize Southern resistance to organized labor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, LESTER B.
description: GOLDSTEIN-Lester B. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Bruce, Matthew and the late Joel. Cherished grandfather of Abby and Ethan, dear brother of Irwin. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Friday, 10 am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, BERENICE
description: JACOBS-Berenice. On August 13, 1997, at home in Great Neck. Beloved wife of Herman for fifty-three years, loving mother of Judith Huff M.D. and Michael. She also leaves a grandson Ethan, her sister Elaine Shulman and brother - in - law Robert, brother S. Lester Klepper and sister-in-law Anne, many cherished cousins, nieces, and nephews, and countless friends. Born in New York, on August 29, 1917, a graduate of Brooklyn College, with a M.A. from Columbia University, founding member of The League of Women Voters, Great Neck Chapter, she was a brave and beautiful lady, kind and generous to all. Services are at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck at noon on Friday, August 15th. Contributions to Brooklyn College or Columbia University.

title: Professor Faces Dismissal
description: In the first such proceeding at Rutgers University in a decade, hearings are being conducted to determine whether a tenured anthropology professor who has taught at the university for 23 years should be dismissed. He is accused of sexually harassing and assaulting a student whose work he supervised.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PATTI DAVIS, who was not exactly known as an exemplary first daughter when her father, Ronald Reagan, was President, has nothing but admiration for the current first daughter, CHELSEA CLINTON.

title: Svenska Cellulosa Bids For Shares of PWA
description: Svenska Cellulosa A.B. said yesterday that it would bid 550 million Deutsche marks ($300 million) to acquire the 20 percent of the German paper maker PWA Papierwerke Waldhof-Aschaffenburg A.G. it does not already own. Shares of PWA jumped 20 marks, to 332 marks, in trading after SCA, a Swedish forestry company, said it would offer the same price per share to minority PWA shareholders.

title: Mets Games Fading to Black?
description: Fourteen Mets games on SportsChannel will be blacked out by Time Warner's New York City cable systems starting tonight if a payment dispute is not resolved. SportsChannel added 25 Mets games to its original schedule of 75 this season, but it could not negotiate a deal with Time Warner to pay for the extra telecasts. Time Warner has shown 11 of the 25 additional games, leaving 14 that may not be available for 1.1 million local cable subscribers.

title: Officials Say 2 Dominicans May Not Face Death Penalty
description: Federal prosecutors are unlikely to seek the death penalty for either of two Dominicans extradited to the United States this week, even though the men are eligible for capital punishment under Federal law, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNNELL, NANEEN
description: BUNNELL-Naneen. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc. notes with sadness the death of Mrs. C. Sterling Bunnell, a loyal friend of the Orchestra and its dedicated supporter. A member of the board of trustees from 1959 to 1985, Mrs. Bunnell also served as Associate Chairman of the Society's Auxilary Board-precursor to the Volunteer Council. Her guidance helped to safeguard the gift of music for future audiences. We extend our deep condolences to her family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec Director

title: SENSORMATIC POSTS $35 MILLION LOSS AND DISMISSES 1,200
description: The Sensormatic Electronics Corporation took a $34.6 million charge in its fourth quarter and said yesterday that it would dismiss 19 percent of its work force, or 1,200 workers, suspend its quarterly dividend and sell some businesses. The company, a maker of electronic-security systems, said that in the quarter ended June 30 it posted a loss, before the charge, of $800,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with net income of $500,000, or 1 cent, a year earlier. The restructuring charge amounted to 47 cents a share, resulting in a final loss of $35.4 million, or 48 cents. Sensormatic, based in Boca Raton, Fla., said it would take another charge in the first quarter, for a total of $65 million. Sensormatic shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $12.375.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: China Cracks Down On Religious Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-worker Accused in Death
description: An arrest warrant has been issued for a Newark man charged with murdering a co-worker on Tuesday, but the authorities have not offered a motive in the killing.

title: Israel Opens Door a Crack; Arafat Says It's Not Enough
description: A day after the departure of an American special envoy, Israel took its first small steps today toward easing punishing measures against Palestinian areas, but Yasir Arafat called the moves inadequate and said the Israelis remained intent on wrecking the peace agreement.

title: Pataki Criticizes Giuliani for Giving Welfare to New Immigrants
description: The Pataki administration today sharply criticized Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to provide welfare benefits to new immigrants in the aftermath of the state's recent decision to begin denying them such benefits during their first year in the country.

title: Staten Island Bluegrass
description: Bluegrass, banjo music and children's activities are scheduled for Sunday at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, Staten Island. Seven bands and more than 10 banjo players, all amateur musicians, will take part in the outdoor event, the 21st New York City Bluegrass Band and Banjo Contest. Winners will receive cash prizes and performance opportunities. It goes on rain or shine from noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $10; $7 for students, Snug Harbor members and the elderly; free for those under 12. Information: (718) 448-2500.

title: In India's 'Golden Moment,' Voices From Past
description: Exactly 50 years after India became independent at what the new country's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, called ''the midnight hour'' of Aug. 14, 1947, Nehru's successors today commemorated their nation's birth.

title: U.P.S. Hints at Flexibility in Talks With Union
description: Negotiators for the United Parcel Service and the teamsters' union resumed talks today with a Federal mediator as the company hinted at new flexibility in bargaining to end the 11-day-old walkout.

title: Executive of Top Pension Fund Leaving to Head New Travelers Unit
description: The Travelers Group announced yesterday that Thomas W. Jones, a top executive at the world's largest pension system, T.I.A.A.-C.R.E.F., would leave his posts there to join Travelers as a vice chairman. He will oversee the company's efforts to expand its fee-based asset management business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, CARL
description: RAPPAPORT-Carl. The Board of Directors, Staff and Families of the Association for Children with Retarded Mental Development joins the Rappaport family in mourning the passing of Carl Rappaport, an incorporator of the Association and a past President of the Board. An advocate for people with mental retardation since the 1940's. Husband of the late Ida Rappaport, long-time Executive Director and Founder of the Association for C.R.M.D., Inc. He was always an exceedingly generous and willing supporter. We shall miss him. Funeral services will be held at the Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York, Friday, August 15 at 10:30 A.M. Jefferson W. Woodcox, President Lawrence Hirsch, Vice-President Rose Podolsky, Secretary

title: Exquisite Images Wrought in Ivory
description: A THOUSAND years ago, a trade route developed from the interior of South Africa, up the East African coast, across the Red Sea to Europe. Swahili tribesmen carried goods to Muslim sailors who took them to the ports of Naples, Sicily, Genoa and Marseilles. Among the goods were ivory tusks of African elephants, which European artists of the Gothic period carved into statues. Larger than Asian elephant tusks, the African tusks were prized for the thick layer beneath their surface, called dentin. It was malleable, responsive to a carver's tools and fine-grained, with an oily texture that polished to a sheen.

title: To the Least Trap and Tee, Westchester Welcomes Golf
description: Even in Westchester County, which considers itself the cradle of American golf, what you're selling determines whether you think the championship at Winged Foot Golf Course is a burden or a bonanza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AL, JUNDI, AKIL
description: AL-JUNDI-Akil. The staff, including 1199 and the Association of Legal Aid Attorneys, the management and the Board of Directors of the Legal Aid Society mourn the death of Akil Al-Jundi, who devoted the last 20 years of his life to assisting persons caught up in the criminal justice system and was an inmate survivor of the Attica rebellion. He died Wednesday night in New York Downtown Hospital at the age of 56 after a complicated illness. Akil worked as a foresnic services assistant in the Criminial Defense Division, where he assisted clients who had been charged with crimes and recomended alternatives to incarceration. In 1992, Akil received the Society's Marden Award for outstanding service and dedication to clients. His work has been recognized by the Correctional Association of New York and the Osborne Association. Akil, who carried the scars of Attica, was one of the inmates in the Attica prison riots in 1971 and the named plaintiff in the civil liability lawsuit that followed. In 1976, he was parolled after serving fifteen years and emerged from prison as a Muslim. He went to work for the Society and earned a reputation for relentless advocacy. Akil was the senior delegate for 1199 and a strong advocate for his co-workers. Funeral services will be held at 4 PM, Friday, at the Masjid Malcolm Shabazz, 102 West 116 Street, N.Y. Public viewing will be held from 1-3 PM, Friday at Marcus Jackson Funeral Home, 2461 8th Avenue, N.Y. We express our profound sympathies to his wife Evelyn, son Ronald, two daughters Wanda and Monique, two granddaughters Niasia and Daria and three grandsons Brandon, Austin and Ronald.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If all fish were as attractive as those at Estiatorio Milos, I would be a happy woman. There they are, gleaming and shining as they sprawl across their bed of ice. Their eyes are clear, their colors bright. ''This is loup de mer, the most prized fish in Europe,'' our waiter says of a particularly beautiful specimen as he gives us a tour of the open kitchen. ''And this,'' he adds proudly, ''is turbot. Here is an Arctic char, and this one is daurade royale. Aren't they beautiful?'' He introduces each fish as if it were a chorus girl in a Broadway show; I would not be surprised to see him bend over and kiss one on the cheek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, PEARL PHILLIPA GEIGER
description: BARNETT-Pearl Phillipa Geiger, 94. Died in her home on Aug. 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Nathan. Mother of Sally Barnett, Marjorie Barnett, and Barbara and Mark Goldfarb. Grandmother of Patricia Zohn, Norman Pfeiffer, Robert and Anna Zohn, Soozy Goldfarb, Andrew and Aviva Goldfarb, Alexander and Douglas Barnett. May we carry on her sense of spirit, humor and independence. Funeral at Riverside Chapel, NYC, Sunday. Time to be announced.

title: COMFORCE AND UNIFORCE SERVICES IN $135 MILLION DEAL
description: The Comforce Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Uniforce Services Inc. for $135 million in cash, stock and debt assumption. Under the offer made directly to shareholders, Comforce, a staffing company, would pay $28 a share in cash and $4 a share in Comforce common stock. It would assume about $35 million of Uniforce's debt. The combined company, with estimated 1997 revenues of $400 million, is to provide staffing and outsourcing services with a focus on technology markets. Shares of Comforce fell 50 cents yesterday, to $7.50. Shares of Uniforce, rose 27.7 percent, or $6.50, to $29.9375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STACK, MARIE
description: STACK-Marie. Died on August 13, 1997 in St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. She was born in New York City August 16, 1915 to the late Margaret (Brooks) Stack & the late Maurice Stack. She graduated from Mary Mount College and performed a lifetime of service for The Metropolitan Insurance Company as an Actuarial Consultant. She was the sister of Maurice Stack of New York and his wife Catherine. She is also survived by three nieces Mary Jane Platt of Sewickley, PA, Eileen Hennegan of Baltimore, MD., and Clare Richer of Southboro, MA., and one nephew Peter Stack of St. Paul, MN and several grand-nieces & nephews. Visiting hours and Andrett Funeral Home will be on Friday from 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10AM, on Saturday at The Epiphany Church.

title: Columbia/HCA Directors Sued By Pension Fund
description: The trustee for the New York State public pension fund sued 11 current and former executives and directors of the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation yesterday, saying that they had allowed ''pervasive and systemic'' criminal fraud to flourish throughout the company.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about notification of the whereabouts of paroled sex offenders referred incorrectly to the State Attorney General's pending request to a Federal court. The state asked the court to lift an injunction and thus permit such notification about those paroled before the passage of the state's law. The Federal appeals court issued the injunction while considering whether notification amounts to unconstitutional additional punishment. The court has not yet ruled on the question.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about criminal explanations for medical symptoms misidentified the town where Waneta E. Hoyt was convicted of killing five of her children. It was in Owego, N.Y., not Oswego.

title: Orthodox Prelate Creates Rift Over College Move
description: Sited atop a grassy hill with an arresting view of the Boston skyline, Hellenic College appears an inspiring setting to educate students in the only college affiliated with the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America.

title: Been Gone for 20 Years, But Long Live the King
description: Tomorrow is D-Day for Elvisites: the 20th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death. Television is aflame with Presleyana, with VH1 and TNT leading the pack.

title: Company Briefs
description: L. LURIA & SONS INC., Miami Lakes, Fla., a jewelry and housewares retailer, said that because of a decline in sales, it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: No Headline
description: ''If you really are a police officer of the City of New York, if you really understand what it means to be a police officer, if you really understand what it means to protect the lives of other people, then you will be among the most revulsed and repulsed by what happened here. If you don't understand that, then you really should leave the Police Department.''

title: Playing to Whoever In Distant Galaxies
description: THE Chinese-born installation artist Cai Guo-Qiang, who is presenting his first American solo show at the Queens Museum of Art, is known to many New Yorkers only as a dark-horse finalist for the Hugo Boss Prize awarded by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum last season. His profile is higher in Europe and Asia, however, thanks in part to his participation in two successive Venice Biennales, this year's and the 1995 edition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JEAN EHRLICH
description: SCHWARTZ-Jean Ehrlich, of Scarsdale, NY, born June 28, 1912 in Philadelphia, PA. Beloved wife for 59 years of Asher W. Schwartz. Devoted mother of Alec and Joanne, Fred, Sue and Frank Lalle. Loving grandmother of Kyra, David, Erroll, Isaac and Nora. Wonderful aunt, great-aunt and friend. She attended the University of Pennsylvania and Simmons School of Social Work. She was a medical social worker at Mt. Sinai Jewish Memorial Hospital and White Plains Hospital. Funeral to be held at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY, Sunday, August 17, 11:30 AM. Contributions to Scarsdale Family Counseling, Harwood Building, Scarsdale, NY 10583 would be appreciated.

description: CASE DISMISSED -- The Campaign Finance Board dismissed a complaint that city-financed advertisements were little more than Giuliani campaign commercials. B3.

description: After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan.

title: Dreams and Disabilities
description: In the palpitating opening moments of the Australian screwball comedy ''Paperback Romance,'' a woman breathlessly narrates a gauzy sex scene featuring two young women and ''a Greek God'' thrashing about ''like wild animals'' in a candlelit cave.

title: No Charges Against Marine in Border Killing
description: Despite angry calls for an indictment from friends and neighbors of a slain West Texas teen-ager, a grand jury tonight decided not to bring criminal charges against the Marine corporal who shot the youth three months ago in an anti-drug operation along the Texas-Mexico border.

title: Premier Says Pakistan Is at Last On Track
description: Although many Pakistanis have greeted the 50th anniversary of the country's independence with scathing assessments of its failures, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has used the occasion to tell his countrymen that Pakistan has done better than its detractors allow, and in some respects better than India, the country out of which Pakistan was carved.

title: More Companies Shorten Summer Vacation
description: Paolo Viberti, who joined Fiat, the giant Italian auto maker, in 1979, used to get August off. Fiat simply shut its big Mirafiori plant on the edge of this northern Italian industrial city. Last year, though, it kept the plant open to retool for a new sedan, the Marea, and the 40-year-old Mr. Viberti, a logistics specialist, got just two weeks off. This August is a little better. Even though the plant is partly open, he will be off three weeks.

title: U.S. ACTS TO OPEN MINORITY PROGRAM TO WHITE BIDDERS
description: The Clinton Administration today set in motion changes in one of its premier affirmative action programs that would make it easier for white-owned companies to qualify for Government contracts that have been reserved almost exclusively for minorities.

As noted in the article, Seiji Ozawa, the conductor and head of the music center, has asked for the resignation of its administrator, Richard Ortner, not its director, Leon Fleisher.

title: Racism Accusations and Award Is Delayed
description: The American Psychological Association, which had planned to give a lifetime achievement award to a psychologist who has specialized in intelligence measurement and personality theory, has postponed it after protests that some of his writings were racist.
