title: Access to the River
description: Last week an environmentalist and fisherman named John Cronin tried to get himself arrested by the Metro-North Commuter Railroad for trespassing. His plan was to cross the railroad tracks in Cortland, N.Y., alongside the Hudson River, in defiance of Metro-North rules. Then, after the arrest, he would challenge in court the railroad's right to block public access to the river.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a recommendation by a panel of experts that most Americans increase their consumption of calcium misstated the panel's comment on fortified food. It said that one way to increase consumption of the essential mineral is fortifying foods; it did not explicitly recommend this.

title: Jack Delano, 83; Depicted the Depression
description: Jack Delano, one of the few surviving members of the group of photographers who fanned out throughout the United States in the 1930's and 40's on behalf of the New Deal's Farm Security Administration and produced what have become iconic images of the Great Depression, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Puerto Rico. He was 83 and had lived in Puerto Rico since 1946.

title: Tobacco Chiefs Oppose a Plan For Big Penalty
description: Tobacco industry executives expressed concern today at the White House about demands for stiffer penalties if they failed to meet targets for reductions in smoking by teen-agers under the proposed tobacco settlement. They said the $15 billion annual payments under the plan were all they could afford.

It said that one way to increase consumption of the essential mineral is fortifying foods; it did not explicitly recommend this.

title: Housing Board Backs Down
description: Less than a week after it became the first housing authority in the nation to defy a Federal request to surrender control of its public housing, the Camden Housing Authority reversed itself yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Punitive Actions Are Advised In Discrimination at Denny's
description: Acting on a complaint that echoed the huge class-action discrimination lawsuits against Denny's restaurants, an independent civil rights monitor has recommended the dismissal of a manager and other punitive actions against a Denny's restaurant near Syracuse University, where a group of Asian college students said they were denied service last April and beaten in the restaurant parking lot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBAUER, LAWRENCE R.
description: LEBAUER-Lawrence R., August 13. Husband of Ellen (nee Stein). Father of Andrew Lebauer, Robin Lebauer, Marisa (John) Westcott and Ian Lebauer. Brother of Eugene Lebauer. Relatives and friends are invited to funeral services, Sunday, 10:30AM, at Temple Adath Israel, Old Lancaster Road and Highland Avenue, Merion, Pennsylvania. Interment, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York. Shiva will be observed at his late residence. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to your favorite charity. Goldsteins Rosenbergs Raphael Sacks. (215) 927-5800.

title: For a Few Top Giants, Pacts Winding Down
description: When the Giants locked up cornerback Jason Sehorn and fullback Charles Way to long-term contract extensions last weekend, the team secured two important players.

title: Dialectic of the Free and the Focused
description: Tanglewood's regular week of contemporary music is gathering steam this year toward a program devoted to Sofia Gubaidulina, who is in residence as composer and teacher, and a final orchestral concert that will include the Second Symphony of Christopher Rouse, the other guiding spirit present. These two composers exemplify with equal force one of the many polarities in new music, that between the wild and various (in her case) and the strongly focused and traditionally disciplined (in his), between the wanderers and those who drive the freeway. In concerts heard so far, though, the latter have predominated -- even, a bit disappointingly, among the young composers here as student fellows.

title: Sojo Optimistic on Return Despite Breaking His Forearm
description: Even with his fractured left forearm in a sling, the affable Luis Sojo still smiled and signed autographs for a friend who visited him in the Yankee clubhouse last night. It was a revealing display by Sojo, who was hurting both physically and mentally after Ricky Bones's fastball ruined perhaps the best season of his career and most likely sidelined him for the next six weeks.

title: McVeigh Speaks at Last, Fleetingly and Obscurely
description: Moments before a Federal judge imposed the death sentence that a jury had decreed for the Oklahoma City bombing, Timothy J. McVeigh today broke the silence he had maintained throughout his trial.

title: No Slogan, No Glamour
description: Hardly Haydn? Haphazardly Haydn? Halfheartedly Haydn? None of the above, certainly. Handily Haydn? Happily Haydn? Hopefully Haydn? No, it's hard to find just the right modest yet affirmative tone.

title: With the Blessing of Valentine, Everett Takes Another Day Off
description: Bobby Valentine, manager of the Mets, told Carl Everett he was welcome to take another day, if necessary, in coping with his family trouble. Everett did exactly that, informing club officials early today that he intended to rejoin the team in Colorado on Friday.

title: A Father Finds the Charges Against His Son Hard to Believe
description: For Officer Justin A. Volpe's father, a retired detective who was the Police Department's first specialist in cracking cases involving stolen art, the allegations of brutality were the beginning of an impossible nightmare.

title: Hyundai Motor Reports 45% Drop in Profits
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, South Korea's biggest auto maker, said its first-half net profit fell 45 percent as the company offered customers interest-free financing to increase sales. The company earned 28.2 billion won ($31.5 million), or 581 won a share, down from 1,150 won a year earlier, a spokesman said.

title: From Poems That Dance the Bomba
description: For its 31st annual summer tour, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, in collaboration with the Pregones Theater in the Bronx, dramatizes what it calls eight ''Afro-Caribbean'' poems (that's a bit of a stretch; one of the poets is a Peruvian) set to music that often seems to make the words leap in a fantastic dance.

title: 2 utilities try to sell gas and electric along with phones and alarms.
description: AS large-scale deregulation of utilities moves ever closer, Energy One L.L.C., a marketing company begun recently by two utility companies, is running a multimillion-dollar ad campaign to convince consumers to change the way they buy power -- and a lot more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, CELIA (NEE GERBITZ)
description: RUBIN-Celia (nee Gerbitz). Beloved wife of the late Ray Rubin. Loving mother of Gloria and Bert Kessler and Marilyn and Allan Glick. Adored grandmother of Madeleine Glick, Cherise and Robert Bransfield, and Lori Kessler. Great-grandmother of Audrey Claire.

title: Raines Returns To Rev Up Yankees
description: Tim Raines spent almost as much time in Tampa, Fla., as he did in the Bronx during this agonizing season. He rehabilitated his torn left hamstring and waited and wondered whether he would be needed at Yankee Stadium. Last night Raines found out that he is definitely needed, and he provided serious dividends.

title: Mind-Bending Fiend Puts The Warp in Warp Speed
description: In the science-fiction wars to determine who can outdo whom in imagining the improbable, ''Event Horizon'' has come up with a lurid new twist. As the rescue party dispatched to locate the Event Horizon, a spaceship that has mysteriously disappeared in the vicinity of Neptune, discovers, you had better be careful when you're flying around in the void, or your vehicle could end up literally going to hell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALDONADO, ROGER WILLIAM
description: MALDONADO-Roger William. Of New Vernon, NJ on Wednesday, August 13, 1997. Husband of Joan Burwell Maldonado. Father of Andrew R. of Summit, NJ; Matthew B. of New Vernon, NJ and Mark M. of Manhattan. Son of Miguel and Zelphia Maldonado of Spring Hill, Fla. Also survived by a grandson, Michael R. of Summit, NJ. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, Aug. 16, 1997 at the 1st Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, Lee's Hill Rd., New Vernon, NJ at 11:00 a.m. Friends may call on Friday Aug. 15 from 7-9 pm at the Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main Street (Rt. 124) Chatham, NJ 07928. In Lieu of flowers those who wish may contribute in his memory to the Division of Oncology Research-7th floor, 161 Fort Washington Ave., NY, NY 10032, C/O: Dr. Wm. Sherman or to the Carol Simons Memorial Cancer Wing, C/O Morristown Memorial Hospital, 100 Madison Ave., Morristown, NJ 07960.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTON, S. DONALD, M.D.
description: MALTON-S. Donald, M.D. A plastic surgeon who practiced in Morristown and Dover, N.J. since 1959, died of a brain tumor. He graduated from University of Michigan and University of Michigan Medical School. He completed his residency in Plastic Surgery from Columbia Presbyterian Hospital and was a Board Certifed Plastic Surgeon. He was a member of Morris County Medical Society, American Society of Plastic & Reconstructive Surgeons and the Americam College of Surgeons. He served in the Navy during the Korean War and retired as an Air Force Major. He is survived by his wife of 44 years, Nadine, his two children: Rhona Kaplan of Larchmont, N.Y., Mark Malton, M.D. of Charlotte, NC, a sister Sheila Malton, of N.Y. and 4 grandchildren. Services will be private.

title: Episodes From a Transitory World
description: New Yorkers who commute underground day in and day out may feel that the prospect of watching a film called ''Subway Stories'' too closely resembles having to work on the weekend. But the film, an HBO NYC production that links 10 distinct fictional interludes, is a lot like the mass transit system itself: while it occasionally makes you want to scream in irritation, it also is a setting for poignant moments that reveal what the emotional traffic between people should be about, in the big city or not.

title: Home Video
description: Call it the case of the mangled ending. ''We'd watch the movie in film school in the 70's and say there's got to be some mistake,'' said Glenn Erickson, a film editor at MGM. On screen was Robert Aldrich's ''Kiss Me Deadly,'' now a cult noir classic but in 1955 nothing but a menace in the eyes of Congressional watchdogs concerned with the country's moral fiber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKIN, LUCILLE BUNIN
description: ASKIN-Lucille Bunin. Of New York and Westhampton Beach. Died on May 10, 1997 in Boston, MA. Lucille was especially known for her love and dedicated support of the arts. Throughout her career, Lucille was an independent art lecturer at New York museums and galleries with a following of many long-time, devoted students. In the 70s and 80s, Lucille Bunin Askin was the guest curator of contemporary art exhibitions at Lehigh University. Lucille was the beloved mother of daughter, Glenn Askin Schweich and son, Neil Zachary Askin, and the loving sister of Elinor Bunin Munroe and sister-in-law of George B. Munroe. Lucille was cherished by her grandchildren: Parker, Tara and Arden Schweich and her son-inlaw, Peter Schweich. Family and friends are invited to attend a memorial service for Lucille at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, New York on Monday, August 18 at 1:30 PM. The Annual Lucille Bunin Askin Art Award will be established at Boston University Academy. Contribution information will be given at the service or call 617-353-9000.

description: New York City's public schools will be unable to start reducing their most overcrowded elementary-school classes until September 1999, a year later than legislators had proposed, because that is when money to hire additional teachers will first become available.

title: CUC TO ACQUIRE HEBDO MAG FOR $440 MILLION
description: CUC International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Hebdo Mag International Inc., a privately held classified-advertisement magazine company, for $440 million. CUC, based in Stamford, Conn., is a direct marketing concern. The Torstar Corporation, a Canadian publishing concern, has a 57 percent share in Hebdo Mag, which is based in Paris. In April, Torstar, reiterating its determination to focus on newspaper publishing, book publishing and children's educational supplies, said it was reviewing its interest in Hebdo Mag. For the year ended Jan. 31, CUC International earned $164.1 million, or 41 cents a share, on revenue of $2.35 billion. Shares of CUC International were unchanged yesterday at $26.375.

title: 2 Korean Chip Makers Report a Bad 6 Months
description: South Korea's two biggest computer chip manufacturers said yesterday that profits tumbled in the first six months of the year as global semiconductor prices plunged. The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest memory chip manufacturer, said profit tumbled 73 percent from a year earlier to 123.2 billion won ($138 million). Hyundai Electronics Industries, a unit of Hyundai Group, reported a 79 percent profit decline to 14.81 billion won.

title: Creating a Monster In a Very Old Profession
description: Saw in hand, Bertrand Blier climbs out on a limb to tell his latest tale of sexual politics and capricious love. Even for Mr. Blier, the agent provocateur behind ''Going Places'' (1973) and ''Get Out Your Handkerchiefs'' (1977), this is a film that flirts with outrage. In ''Mon Homme,'' a prostitute named Marie proudly defends her profession, then defies expectation by falling in love with a derelict. She eagerly transforms him into her abusive pimp and ecstatically enslaves herself. Many complications ensue.

title: Singing the Course Of Human Events
description: SO maybe it is the squarest thing on Times Square. It's often gratingly corny; it's dotted with the kind of nudging sexual jokes that might be swapped in the boys' room of an elementary school, and its songs feature rhymes that make Madison Avenue jingles seem like models of sophistication. Besides, doesn't the very idea of America's Founding Fathers gamboling to a souped-up minuet give you the willies?

title: Crossing Into a Circle of the Brutal
description: NEW YORK was never meant to have its name uttered in the same breath with notorious human-rights violators like Syria, China and Turkey. Yet for the moment, at least, there the city shockingly stands, alongside places whose uniformed forces are routinely accused of acts as brutal as shoving wooden handles and other objects into the rectums of people in custody.

description: Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, has come up with an ingenious proposal to remedy an old problem at the world organization, the composition of the Security Council. He would expand the Council by adding five permanent members -- Germany, Japan and three from the developing world. Enlargement is long overdue.

Shouting ''Infidels!'' at rows of men and boys prostrated at evening prayer, the intruders leveled Kalashnikov rifles. In the fusillade, 10 worshipers died.

title: Tiny Worms Offer Lessons on Life
description: A barely visible worm that usually lives only two weeks may hold an important secret to longevity. Biologists at Massachusetts General Hospital have found that a gene that can make the worm live longer is closely related to a human gene involved in regulating energy metabolism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERKIN, JOHN THORNE
description: PERKIN-John Thorne, of Fairfield, Conn. and Nantucket, Mass. died peacefully in New York on August 12, 1997 after a brief illness. Loving husband of Elizabeth (Betsy) and devoted father of Christopher, Thorne, and Richard. Also survived by his mother, Mrs. Richard S. Perkin of New Canaan, Conn., brothers Richard T. of New York City, and Robert S. of Darien, Conn., and sister Winifred Perkin Gray of Wenham, Mass. A graduate of Milton Academy (1955) and Bowdoin College (1959), Mr. Perkin was a stockbroker with A.G. Edwards & Co. At one time, he was an Overseer of Bowdoin College, a Vice President of The Bridgeport Symphony, a Director of Bridgeport Hospital, and a Governor of the Country Club of Fairfield. In addition, he was formerly a Trustee and Treasurer of Fairfield Country Day School and, at the time of his death, a Trustee of the Perkin Fund and an Honorary Trustee of Fairfield Country Day School. A memorial service will be held at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road, Fairfield, Conn. at 11:00am, Saturday, August 16, 1997. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions for the planting of trees in John's memory be sent to: Bowdoin College, Office of the Secretary, Station 4100, Brunswick, ME 04011; Colgate University, Gift Records Office, 13 Oak Drive, Hamilton, New York, 13346; Hobart College, Development Office, Geneva, NY 14456; or Westminster School, Office of the Headmaster, 995 Hopmeadow Street, Simsbury, Conn. 06070.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 9 about a visit by Pope John Paul II to Poland referred incorrectly to Queen Jadwiga, who ruled in the 14th century. The Queen and her sole heir died in 1399, shortly after she gave birth to him; she was not the founder of a dynasty. And it was not Queen Jadwiga but a predecessor, King Casimir III, who founded the Jagiellonian University in Cracow.

title: MET LIFE TO ACQUIRE ANNUITY UNIT FROM LONDON INSURANCE
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Security First Group, a unit of Canada's London Insurance Group, for $377 million. Security First Group, of Los Angeles, distributes annuities primarily to public employees and customers of regional and community banks. It had total assets of about $3.1 billion as of Dec. 31. Met Life is a New York-based mutual, or a company owned by its policyholders, with assets of about $300 billion. London Insurance, a London, Ontario, insurance concern, said it would record a one-time pretax gain of $173.3 million from the sale.

title: Humans' Earliest Footprints Discovered

At the time, having been eclipsed by the Beatles, Elvis seemed very much older than his years -- caught, in fact, in an irresolute, premature middle age. But now, looking across the years to Aug. 16, 1977, it becomes clear just how young Elvis was when he died.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES ADDS TO CAR DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy car dealerships in Florida and Nevada in transactions valued at $26 million. A Republic spokesman declined to break out the price for the dealerships, Kenyon Dodge of Clearwater, Fla., and Tom Coward Lincoln-Mercury of Las Vegas. Since December, Republic has bought more than 150 dealerships and created the largest United States new-car-dealer chain. The Toyota Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company have gone to court and regulatory agencies in several states to try to block some Republic purchases. Republic, in turn, has sued Toyota.

title: A Low-Key David Byrne Amid All His Influences

Since first taking a break from the Talking Heads for a solo career in the early 80's, he has lent his support to some of the world's most interesting musicians, from Shoukichi Kina (Japan) to Tom Ze (Brazil) to Terry Allen (Texas), and collaborated across the arts with Brian Eno, Robert Wilson, Bernardo Bertolucci and Twyla Tharp. In concert on Thursday night at Roseland, his varied influences were evident in his informed, low-key music and performance. He even recruited a talented unknown, Christina Wheeler, who can usually be found in the corner of experimental Manhattan dance parties adding vocals to a disk jockey's mix, to perform backing vocals.

description: Professionals Insurance Company Management Group agreed yesterday to acquire Physicians Protective Trust Fund of Coral Gables, Fla., for up to $133.3 million in stock. Physicians Protective Trust provides medical malpractice insurance in Florida. Under the agreement, Professionals Group said it would issue between 3.7 million and 4.3 million shares to Physicians Protective Trust. Based on yesterday's stock price of $31, the deal is valued at $114.7 million to $133.3 million. Professionals Insurance, an Okemos, Mich., insurance holding company, said it would merge Physicians Protective Trust into its Picom Insurance Company unit.

title: Yeltsin Vows To Clean Up Privatization In Russia
description: Wading into one of the country's most bitter financial disputes, the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, criticized in a televised address today the handling of two recent, highly contested sales of state property and vowed to do better in the future.

title: Envirodyne to Seek Assistance in Its Sale
description: Envirodyne Industries said today that it would retain a financial adviser to assist it in possibly selling the food packaging and supplies company or some of its units.

title: U.S. Will Bring No More Criminal Charges Against F.B.I. Officials in Ruby Ridge Siege
description: The Justice Department said today that it would not bring more criminal charges against senior F.B.I. officials in the 1992 siege at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, where a Government sniper killed the wife of a white separatist as she clutched their baby daughter inside a mountain cabin.

title: Sometimes, One Parent Is Better Than Two
description: She was 17 years old, six months pregnant with her second child, and living in public housing in Boston with the 21-year-old man who is the father. She had earned a Graduate Equivalency Degree. Her boyfriend hadn't, nor had he finished high school or secured a job. Did she intend to marry the father of her children?

title: A Troubling Double Standard
description: Days before the Gay Men's Health Crisis held its annual fund-raising party on Fire Island last year, critics expressed concern about the event. Why, they asked, was the nation's biggest and most respected AIDS service organization continuing to sponsor a party that had increasingly gotten out of hand, with incidents of drug use? The beach bash, known as the Morning Party, went on as scheduled. It drew 4,500 people and raised $300,000. But one man had to be flown to a hospital after overdosing on GHB, a popular social drug, among other incidents.

title: Minority Police Recruits Sue Over Grading Changes
description: A dozen former Police Academy recruits who are black and Hispanic have filed a lawsuit challenging the fairness of stricter grade-point requirements that were imposed midway through their training.

title: Steel Pier Accident Explained
description: State inspectors have determined that a faulty sensor and an inattentive employee were responsible for an accident at the Steel Pier on Sunday in which an Elizabeth woman toppled from the Wipeout ride and was injured, officials said yesterday.

title: Rev. Frederick Hill, Episcopal Church Rector, 67
description: The Rev. Frederick Hill, who as the ninth rector of St. Michael's Episcopal Church breathed new life into what had been a moribund parish on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Goshen, N.Y. Father Hill, who retired as rector in 1992, was 67.

description: Just how much Mohammed Khatami can change Iran now that he is installed as President remains unclear. His most progressive instincts on domestic issues may be stifled by Iran's ruling religious leaders, and serious tinkering with foreign policy seems doubtful though not impossible. But Mr. Khatami, who won an overwhelming vote in May on a platform of moderate reform, is making a credible initial effort to give Iranians a less rigid government. His Cabinet appointments are mainly new faces with a reputation for competence and a somewhat less ideological outlook than their predecessors.

Heavy metal, the wider genre, has changed irrevocably, altering to fit into a world dominated by canny, expertly produced pop. The major bands of the 1980's have found the waters of maturity tricky to navigate: many have thrown in the towel, and Metallica's recent post-haircut album, ''Load,'' full of slower tempos and real melodies, was greeted with accusations of selling out.

The expected job cuts by the Denver-based company would affect some of the 200 workers hired earlier this year as the company revamped its product line and needed additional help to build inventories of new hard-side luggage products, said John Murtagh, chief administrative officer. ''We built up beyond what we needed long term in order to get the products introduced,'' Mr. Murtagh said.

title: FULTON FINANCIAL TO BUY KEYSTONE HERITAGE
description: The Fulton Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Keystone Heritage Group Inc. for about $210 million in stock to increase its business in Pennsylvania. The offer is about $52 a share for Keystone, which closed yesterday up $10.75, or 29 percent , at $47.50. Keystone is based in Lebanon, Pa. The acquisition will give Fulton Financial, based in Lancaster, Pa., 24 branches and $640 million in assets in the state. Fulton is the fifth-largest bank in Pennsylvania. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year, will give Fulton more than $5 billion in assets.

title: A Czech Quartet Revels In Its Dark Compatriots
description: In a city with as busy a musical life as New York's, coincidental associations sometimes connect entirely unrelated events. This week, Prague seemed to be the topic of the moment. Just as an exploration of Mozart's ties to that city's musical life was coming to an end at the Mostly Mozart Festival, the Frick Collection presented a concert by the Panocha Quartet, an ensemble from Prague that specializes in the Romantic and early modern Czech repertory.

title: Everett Rejoins the Mets After Hearings on Custody

title: Roche Results Up 9.7% For First Six Months

description: Banco Santander S.A., Spain's biggest bank, said its Banco Geral do Comercio unit would pay $500 million for a controlling stake of Brazil's Banco Noroeste.

title: Long Hours Fail to Budge U.P.S. Talks, Carey Says

title: DOMINION TEXTILE IS PLANNING CUTBACKS
description: Dominion Textile Inc. said yesterday that it would close a fabric plant in Ireland and cut production at a plant in Italy to increase the competitiveness of its Klopman International unit in Europe, eliminating 265 jobs, or 29 percent, of Klopman's work force. Dominion Textile said it will take a charge of $21 million Canadian), or about $15.1 million United States), in its fourth-quarter and year-end earnings, which will be released Tuesday. The Oct. 31 plant shutdown in Tralee, Ireland, and cutbacks at a plant in Frosinone, Italy, are part of a reorganization at Klopman, Europe's largest maker of polyester-cotton, greige and cotton fabrics for workwear and casual clothing.

title: Credit-Data Web Site Suspended
description: A World Wide Web site where consumers could look at their credit histories was shut down today after a technical problem sent some reports to the wrong people.

title: Arrest in Dallas Widens Inquiry Into Immigrant Smuggling

title: Lessons From the 70th Precinct
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir took all the right steps with their forceful response to the horrific allegations about Brooklyn's 70th Precinct. They were particularly impressive in battering at the ''blue wall'' of police silence that traditionally greets any inquiry into wrongdoing by their fellow officers. The Commissioner, in announcing yesterday that an officer had come forth to give information, referred to the blue wall as a myth. But history suggests otherwise, and much of the credit for the swift progress in the case must go to the administration's firm action.

title: A Native Terrorist Speaks
description: When they heard that Timothy J. McVeigh might finally speak about the Oklahoma City bombing, relatives of some of the 168 people who died in the 1995 attack came to Denver for his sentencing. But they heard no words from the heart. Mr. McVeigh recited a brief line from a Supreme Court opinion in a 1928 wiretapping case, perhaps a reference to the deaths of the Branch Davidians in Waco, Tex., as Federal agents moved in on them exactly one year before the bombing.

Your partner is a like-minded computer -- in fact, your partner is your exact clone. Your opponents are the many-times world-champion human bridge partnership known as Meckwell: Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. You are struggling through the first high-level challenge match between human and machine bridge players. The spectators, watching and making wisecracks via the Internet, are impatient, but you don't know this, either. You don't really know much, do you?

title: Learning to Love The Ardent Chaos Of Cassavetes
description: JOHN CASSAVETES'S reputation as a director has undergone a remarkable transformation since his death in 1989 at the age of 59. Once viewed as an amateurish maverick who brokered self-indulgent improvisations by his actor-friends, he has come to be seen, especially abroad, as one of the three or four major American filmmakers of the last 30 years. Books are written about him; retrospectives are devoted to him; young directors from Budapest to Brooklyn imitate his passionate, infuriating dramas about love and character meltdown.

title: Welfare for Broadcasters
description: An obscure piece of news last week should please many television viewers, except when they think about how their tax money is spent. The Sinclair Broadcast Group, which operates 29 television stations, and ABC Television indicated that they would not use the additional space on the broadcast spectrum recently given to all broadcasters by Congress to offer viewers a single channel of high-definition digital TV, or HDTV. HDTV, with its super-clear pictures and sound, would require every bit of each broadcaster's allotment of the new spectrum. Sinclair, ABC and no doubt many more broadcasters will now split up their new spectrum into several channels, with each channel using the standard digital format to provide resolution better than today's broadcasts but inferior to HDTV.

This sprightly cousin benefits from its association with the culinarily stylish Mediterranean, while the plain-Jane turnip still conjures up images of tough winters in Siberia, Sweden and Minnesota.

The dry fountain became a receptacle for used soft-drink bottles.

I have no idea how he got here; for that information you'll have to consult the works of William Faulkner or Billy Bob Thornton. Real life is different, of course, and at times certain kinds of singers seem very nearly extinct. (Thus the present dearth of Wagnerian heldentenors and Verdi sopranos.) But occasionally, perhaps by way of compensation, music lovers enjoy something of a bonanza: several outstanding singers with the same range appear at the same time.

title: BAD BOARD
description: Cornered in lower Manhattan with a load of amphetamines, Evan Jones is in trouble. The police are closing in, so Jones makes a desperate move: he rolls the dice and prays. Welcome to Stash, a board game about the high times of drug dealers in New York City, circa 1978. Players compete to smuggle 28 different drugs, then sell them at socioeconomically adjusted prices in more than 100 neighborhoods, all the while dodging addiction, the mob and the cruel Judge Maximus. Designed by Jones and Jeffrey Lee Simons of Q.E.D. Games in Manhattan, Stash was deliberately set in the 1970's to tap into presumed baby- boomer nostalgia for those groovy times. But is this game designed to glorify drug use? 'No', says Jones.'We also design war games, but we're not advocating that you invade France.'

title: Newark Company is Fined After Worker Dies From Acid
description: A Newark company where a worker was killed by a hydrofluoric acid spill in February agreed last week to pay $80,000 in safety-related fines. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration found that USS Corporation failed to train or outfit its workers adequately for safety and used unsuitable equipment. Victor Camacho, 19, of Newark, was killed when a co-worker who could not see him began pumping the acid from one container to another before Mr. Camacho had secured a hose, the agency said. The acid, used to put a frosting on glass perfume bottles, is no longer used by the company.

title: Ride a MiG -- and Let Yourself Go
description: Need more proof that the cold war is over? Consider this: There's a working MiG-21 fighter jet sitting in Missoula, Mont., and its owners are hoping to rent it out to Hollywood. There aren't any takers yet, so plans are brewing to offer flights to the public. ''It's an uncharted area, but we think it could work,'' says Monte Drake, a local banker who owns a piece of the jet. ''People will pay for fuel, the pilot and maintenance. A ride would run $3,500.'' Is it worth it? Here's a look.

title: When Creativity Runs In the Family
description: ARTISTS MAY WELL BE BORN, BUT THEY are also made. As scientists gain insight into the complexities of the brain, it is tempting to ascribe artistic talent, even creativity, to genetic or neurobiological factors. Yet even if talent and creativity are products of nature, they must still be nurtured, recognized and supported. Nowhere is this more evident than in families of artists, where creativity can seem a form of inheritance and a dynamic legacy.

From 1773 to 1827 it was the state's first prison, the place where burglars and counterfeiters and rapists and horse thieves were sent to live underground, like moles, mining for copper by day, sleeping in the caverns by night.

The fact that more than one of the girls profiled is a cheerleader provides insight into how they see themselves -- smiling little helpers on the sidelines. Adolescent girls who participate in sports score higher on every test of self-esteem, with lower incidences of alcohol and drug use, teen pregnancy, eating disorders and, I would assume, self-mutilation. And the health benefits would be an improvement over what Jill is getting from the cigarette in her hand at the conclusion of the article: ''I'm all cured now -- got a light?''

But Philip Murray Condit's Buck Rogers side is tempered by an aggressiveness that has helped him to make his huge company virtually indomitable. Since assuming the position of C.E.O. 16 months ago, Condit, a 56-year-old aeronautics engineer trained at Berkeley, Princeton and M.I.T., has navigated Boeing's absorption of Rockwell International's defense and aerospace divisions and, two weeks ago, McDonnell Douglas. Now Boeing has only two American rivals in the defense business -- Lockheed Martin and Raytheon -- when just a decade ago there were nine.

Born in England and educated at Christ Church, Oxford University, he later graduated from Columbia University School of Law. A memorial service will be held in Nonquitt, MA., in September. title: Just as They Were
description: Legs crossed and shoulders thrown back, a young dandy wears an air of serene contentment in his double-breasted pinstripe suit; a Berber woman in traditional dress gently leans against her white-robed husband, cheek to cheek, her right hand resting on his thigh, his left arm around her shoulders; lying on a rug while keeping her baby daughter upright, a young woman, resplendent in head scarf, earrings, necklaces and a printed cotton dress, looks almost quizzically at the camera, her eyebrows exaggerated by makeup. Judging from the 206 black-and-white portraits -- all taken between the late 1940's and early 60's -- in SEYDOU KETA (Scalo, $49.95), it is clear that, as an uncle explains in an afterword, the photographer Seydou Keita was ''blessed in three particular ways'': he had talent and energy, his studio (where he still lives) was located at a busy crossroads in Bamako, then the capital of French Sudan, and his city was enjoying a postwar economic and demographic boom. As one of a handful of commercial photographers there, Keita served an elite of government workers, shopkeepers, wealthy travelers, politicians, their wives and children, and strove to ''come up with ideas to please the customer.'' He succeeded. Whether working outside with a backdrop (his own lace bedspread or cottons printed with leaves, flowers or arabesques) or in his studio with props he provided (like a radio, clock, watch) or his subjects' prized possessions (a bicycle, a gendarme's uniform, a particular hairstyle), and whether photographing people in various styles of African dress or in European suits, Keita knew how to elicit confidence, portray intimate or familial ties and capture a person's nature. Unschooled and largely self-taught, Keita (who became the official photographer of the newly independent Mali from 1962 to 1977) obviously relished his subjects' beauty, dignity and diversity. Christine Schwartz Hartley

title: The Client

''If you want to do everything,'' Mouna explained as we were driven to Charles de Gaulle Airport after a Chanel lunch at the Ritz, ''you'd be late, you'd be tired and you'd look awful -- which is exactly what couture is not about. title: What Does Batman Read at the Beach?
description: It's not a bird, it's not a plane -- it's not even Superman in this stylishly written first novel from Herbert Thomas. THE SUPERLATIVE MAN (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22) features a cleverly reimagined superhero who does little, over the course of the book, to earn the name. But what Superlative Man doesn't do, the author does, managing to impress and intrigue us on page after page. A curious hardboiled hybrid of 1940's pulp fiction and 1990's irony, ''The Superlative Man'' has more in common with the recent dark, retro Batman movies than with the wholesome Superman stereotype. Drugs, sex and violent death abound; people even smoke cigarettes with nary a puff of guilt. Thomas likes his noir very black -- his tough guys are sometimes so tough and his femmes so fatale that they border on the campy, but Thomas's reverence for the genre is so absolute and his rendering of it so exact that it's hard not to grant him his excesses. Only three pages in, his woebegone newshound protagonist, Harvey Gander, throws the opening punch: ''The Superlative Man killed my parents.'' Why? How? And who is the Superlative Man, really? All is revealed in good time, but not before Gander's mentor, an old girlfriend and a good chunk of Gander's ear meet unpleasant ends. Not so the novel itself, which (sadly) ends quite pleasantly. Thomas does such a good job simultaneously celebrating and perverting cliches that it's a shame to see him let his characters live happily ever after. Then again, that's good news if it means a superlative sequel isn't far behind. Liam Callanan

description: MOSBACHER-Emil ''Bus'', Jr., 75, died Wednesday, August 13, at home in Greenwich, CT. Devoted husband of Patricia Ryan. Dear father of Emil III, R. Bruce and John. Loving father-in-law of Nancy. Adored grandfather of Jack and Emily. Dear brother of Barbara, brother of Robert. A memorial will be held at 4 PM on September 8th at the New York Yacht Club, where Mr. Mosbacher served as Commodore. Mr. Mosbacher was born in White Plains in 1922, graduated from Dartmouth College and served as an Officer in the Navy. Mr. Mosbacher served as the Chief of Protocol of the United States from 1969 to 1972, and as Chairman of Operation Sail. He served as a director of Chemical Banking Corporation, Chubb Corporation, Avon Products, Inc., United Merchants and Manufacturer's Co., Lily Tulip Cup Corp., Abercrombie & Fitch Corp., Dollar Savings Bank, Amax, Inc., Amax Gold, Inc. and Putnam Trust Company. He was an Honorary Life Trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital, & a former chairman of the Hoover Institute of Stanford University. The family requests contributions be sent to the Elliot W. Strong Endowed Chair, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York, 10022.

title: Mother In a Strange Land
description: COULD there be a journey more fateful than the overseas odyssey to adopt a foreign child? The United States immigration service refers to these prospective new citizens in the preliminary papers as ''unidentified orphans,'' and, after their arrival in this country, as ''resident aliens.'' In the 1990's, what I think of as an adoption excursion has become a more common, and surreal, experience. Every day, hopeful adoptive parents fly off to Asia, Eastern Europe and Latin America on journeys that will forever change their lives. I have taken two such journeys, the first to Romania, the second to China. But that first trip was my introduction to the depth of revelation that such a trip entails.

And in the middle is a pianola, a 1911 Aeolian that looks like a dignified mahogany coffin for a short, thin, wedge-shaped person. The mix of ancient and new technology is jarring: this is definitely a room where something strange happens.

title: Six Degrees of Rogers Hornsby
description: If baseball is no longer the national pastime, maybe the Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon game is. The game that proves every movie star can be connected to Kevin Bacon in six steps or less is all the rage in Hollywood (where, of course, connections are everything) and has piqued the interest of regular Americans who wish they were so connected. Well, the stated national pastime, baseball, can offer the same experience to people who prefer their seating in a stadium instead of a cineplex. And in baseball's game, the center of it all is the greatest right-handed hitter of all time, Rogers Hornsby. To introduce the game, I've connected a current player from each major league team back to the Rajah. And just to make it more challenging, I haven't used any player more than once. The Times' Murray Chass recently wrote, Baseball, more than any other sport, invites, maybe demands, historical perspective. The Six Degrees of Rogers Hornsby may not have the perspective Chass had in mind, but oh, the history.

title: A Circle of Woes
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers last week brought disciplinary actions against GKN Securities and 29 of its brokers and supervisors for overcharging customers who traded the low-priced securities in which the firm specializes. The firm and employees all consented to the penalties -- more than $2 million in fines and restitution -- without admitting or denying the charges. The GKN case illustrates a fact that has long troubled regulators: brokers at firms with disciplinary problems often end up moving on to other firms that get into similar trouble. An effort to tag such brokers was one reason regulators brought charges against so many brokers. The list of the GKN employees' financial alma maters is a who's who of troubled brokerage firms; some had worked at more than one firm that has faced sanctions. Here is a sampling of those firms, and the number of the GKN brokers cited last week who had previously worked at each.

description: For decades, the Rev. Patrick Moloney was known as a compassionate priest who battled drug dealers and sheltered homeless teen-agers on the most blighted streets of New York's Lower East Side.

title: Union and U.P.S. Officials Negotiate Through the Night
description: Representatives of the United Parcel Service and the striking teamsters' union continued negotiations today after holding all-night talks in an effort to end the 13-day-old strike by 185,000 workers.

title: Children's Books
description: CAT MUMMIES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLGATE, FLORENCE MANUEL
description: COLGATE-Florence Manuel, of Locust Valley, NY, peacefully on August 14, 1997, age 92. Beloved wife of the late John K. Mother of Annette Fayard of Paris, France, John K. Jr. of Mill Neck, NY and Mimi Bullock of Greenwich, CT. Grandmother of twelve, greatgrandmother of 16. Memorial service St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, Thursday, September 11, at 4 PM. A gift in her memory may be made to Locust Valley Library, 170 Buckram Rd., Locust Valley, NY 11560 or North Country Garden Club, 3 Chapel Gate Lane, Glen Head, NY 11545.

title: Hopes Turn to Reality in the Bronx Classic
description: Mike Sell is No. 307 on the Association of Tennis Professionals' computer ranking and just another hopeful eking out a living. Or is he?

title: George P. Shultz, Charlotte Swig
description: Charlotte Mailliard Swig, San Francisco's chief of protocol, and George Pratt Shultz, the former Secretary of State, were married Friday evening in San Francisco. Bishop William E. Swing of the Episcopal Diocese of California performed the ceremony at Grace Cathedral.

title: Weather Man
description: ECO HOMO

title: The F.C.C. Isn't Backpedaling On Telecommunications Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Rosemary Feerick, R. J. Cardamone
description: Rosemary Theresa Feerick and Roderick Joseph Cardamone, religion teachers at Our Lady of Good Counsel High School in Wheaton, Md., were married yesterday at the Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Edmond J. Trench, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Moving Force Behind SETI
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Whitfield And Mr. Allen
description: Timberly Noe Whitfield, a film and drama manager for the A & E Television Networks in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Leonard Allen, a lieutenant in the New York City Police Department. Justice Vasilios C. Arniotes of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony in Manhattan at Barocco Restaurant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSONS, PAULINE
description: LEVINSONS-Pauline, on August 14, 1997. Cherished wife of the late Jacob Levinsons, loving mother of Hessy Taft and Noemi Pollack. Adored grandmother of Nina and Alexander Taft, Gregory and Stefan Pollack, and great grandmother of Jacob Pollack and Lily Taft. Services Sunday, 1:15, ''The Riverside'', West 76 St and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey.

title: To Crime Stoppers Chief, Rewards Pay Off
description: IN the aftermath of the murder of the designer Gianni Versace, various groups offered rewards for catching his accused killer, Andrew P. Cunanan. After Mr. Cunanan was found dead, a houseboat caretaker whose phone call accidentally led the police in Florida to the body claimed a total of $65,000 in reward money. One group paid $10,000 immediately, then after the caretaker pressed his case he received most of the rest last week.

title: One Family's Islands In the Sun
description: Scattered across the country the rest of the year, the Grater family descends each summer on two islands in the St. Lawrence River in the Thousand Islands region of New York.

title: Kimberly Ludwig, Kenneth Glinert
description: Kimberly Beth Ludwig, the daughter of Linda Ludwig of Malibu, Calif., and Tony Ludwig of Sherman Oaks, Calif., was married last evening to Kenneth Lawrence Glinert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd S. Glinert of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Little Progress on Child Abuse
description: A court-appointed review panel has found that New York City's child welfare system is still in shambles, failing to perform even routine tasks that would make victims of abuse or neglect less vulnerable. These distressing findings show that the city needs to intensify its efforts to make sure that at-risk children can be kept out of harm's way.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: BLOOD PACT & OTHER STORIES

title: Coward's Elvira Is Still Queen of the Light
description: ''BLITHE SPIRIT'' is spirited, all right, but don't call it blithe, and not just because the play is so very blase about death. Fashioned by Noel Coward in 1941 as a ''very gay superficial comedy about a ghost'' and tossed off in seven days as an antidote to the death fears of wartime (as well as his own financial troubles), the play is sub-titled ''An Improbable Farce in Three Acts.'' Even so, ''Blithe Spirit'' is as suffused with the depths and the darkness of tormented ambivalence as any dramatically intended, somber, reflective contemplation of the human condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALAKIAN, DR. ANNA
description: BALAKIAN-Dr. Anna. The Faculty and Alumni/ae of The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism extend their condolences to Haig and Suzanne Nalbantian and their families on the death of their mother. Dr. Balakian and her sister, Nona, Class of 1943, had a long and abiding friendship with the Journalism School, encouraging and supporting the development of literary journalism. We honor Dr. Balakian for her devotion to literature and to cultural reporting. Friends and colleagues at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism

title: Turkish Leader Wins a Key Vote to Limit Religious Education
description: Seven weeks after he took office, Turkey's new secular leader today scored his first major political victory by winning passage of a hotly debated law to restrict religious education.

title: Tracing the History of Handmade Jewelry
description: ABOUT 100 objects on view at the Katonah Museum of Art represent the history of handmade jewelry, fiber art and glass from the 1950's through the 90's. The works are from the collection of the American Craft Museum in Manhattan, and the labels read like a ''Who's Who'' of contemporary crafts.

title: A Pyrotechnical U.N.
description: Ten tons of explosives are sitting in boxes in a warehouse in Millington waiting to be carted to the waterfront in Jersey City to be detonated this week.

title: Pickin' and Strummin' and Jammin'
description: AFTER a three-year hiatus, the 21st installment of the New York Bluegrass Band and Banjo Contest is back on Staten Island, offering some of the best bluegrass music this side of the Mason-Dixon line. The deadline for entering it has passed, but musicians with instruments may join the many jam sessions that will occur throughout the day.

title: How New York State Walked Into a Veto of Its Medicaid Item
description: Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, learned long ago how to grease the legislative machinery by helping colleagues with provisions of special interest to them.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Outrageous Ideaof Christian ScholarshipBy George M. Marsden.Oxford University, $22.

title: Alison Attia, Andrew Adler
description: Alison Attia, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert Attia of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to Andrew Newton Adler, a son of Dr. Alice Adler of Lexington, Mass., and the late Dr. David Adler. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to perform the ceremony at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.

title: Vying for New York Stories, For Beguiling Announcers And, Yes, for People's Trust
description: JERRY Seinfeld, Rafael Pineda and Liliana Marin have been causing agita for the already ulcer-prone news executives of New York City's local broadcast television stations.

title: $5,000 Rent May Mean Falafel to Go
description: Come October, the Syrian neurologist from St. Vincent's Hospital and the social worker from Jerusalem who works on 13th Street will have to find somewhere other than Mustafa's Jerusalem Falafel shop to buy their Middle Eastern coffee and their hummus platters. The shop, a mainstay of Greenwich Avenue between Charles and Perry Streets, will have to close at the end of September because of a lease dispute.

title: BUBBAPALOOZA
description: If this summer's all-women Lilith tour is testament to the power of women in music, then this summer's Fruit of the Loom Country Comfort Tour and Experience is testament to . . . the power of underwear. We did research, says Deanna Grubbs, the tour's spokeswoman, ''and a lot of country music fans wear Fruit of the Loom.'' To celebrate that fact, the company is sponsoring a roving extravaganza featuring Hank Williams Jr. and Charlie Daniels. The centerpiece is a 35,000-square-foot midway full of ''country life-style attractions'' -- like the Electric Cowboy pavilion, where contestants go head to head at air guitar. Fans take note: the Trading Post does not sell souvenir Loom briefs, though you can get a ''specialty T-shirt.''

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 3 about managing the Union Square Greenmarket referred incorrectly to the crops grown by an Orange County farmer, Keith Stewart. They are 80 varieties of vegetables, including one popular type of garlic, ro cambole, not 80 varieties of garlic.

title: Frank Bertino, 77, Prep Coach
description: Frank Bertino, the former teacher, football coach and athletic director at Riverdale Country School who ranks second in victories among high school coaches in New York State, died last Sunday at his home in Yorktown, N.Y. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAAS, ALBERT
description: HAAS-Albert. The entire Department of Rehabilitation Medicine of the NYU School of Medicine is greatly saddened by the death of this distinguished colleague. Dr. Haas was one of the fathers of the field of Pulmonary Rehabilitation. He headed for many years the Pulmonary Rehabilitation Services, both at Bellevue and the Rusk Institute. His wise counsel will be missed by all of us. The French government has recognized the courageous services that his late wife, Sonia and he have rendered to the resistance movement during World War II by the Legion of Honor. Our deep expression of sympathy to his son, Francois who followed in his footsteps, and his wife Sheila, and their two children, Ariane & Alex. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 17, 1 P.M., Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, between 9th and 10th Streets. Mathew H. M. Lee, M.D., Acting Chairman, Dept. of Rehabilitation Medicine Bruce B. Grynbaum, M.D., Vice Chairman, Dept. of Rehabilitation Medicine

title: Artist's Exhibit On Pain of AIDS Is Not Sacred
description: Barton Benes's latest artwork has riled, inspired or just plain disgusted audiences in England, Europe, North Dakota and New Mexico, yet it is practically unknown in New York, where Mr. Benes has lived most of his life. All that could change soon.

title: Moye Thompson, Douglas Suisman
description: Moye Frances Thompson, who owns Earthworks Pottery, a New York gallery and studio, was married yesterday to Douglas Robert Suisman, an architect in Santa Monica, Calif. The Rev. Ernest D. Pipes Jr., a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's house in Santa Monica.

title: The Original '12 Angry Men,' a Mirror of Its Time With a Moral
description: WHEN ''12 ANGRY MEN'' OPENED AT MOVIE theaters in April 1957, critics knew they were seeing something special. A. H. Weiler wrote in The New York Times that it was ''difficult to recall a more incisively revealing'' depiction of a jury-room drama. In a separate article, Mr. Weiler described the characters as ''the bigot, the sadist, the lucid but uninformed, the wise-guy and the empty-headed types'' and wrote that the film ''clearly mirrors the mind and heart of a variety of citizens in our town.'' Its moral, he said, was that ''man's fate is the problem of every man.''

title: A Little Off the Neck
description: 'Unbeknownst to me, fat had accumulated in my neck,'' says Martin McDermott, a 33-year-old New Yorker (pictured) who recently took advantage of a lesser-known form of plastic surgery: neck reduction. ''It wasn't something I was going to live with for the next 40 years.''

title: D.M.V. Computer Gremlin Slows the Usual Even More
description: Those who must do business with the Division of Motor Vehicles often complain that their encounters are rarely pleasant or brief -- and that's when the agency is running smoothly. But the public had problems than usual this month, when a computer glitch that eluded detection for two weeks caused sporadic shutdowns in service, ranging from minutes to whole days at 45 D.M.V. offices around the state. The problem, which was solved last week, involved a faulty piece of hardware known as a dial backup, through which the data lines to all D.M.V. offices run, said Jack Mozloom, director of communications for the State Treasury Department, which is in charge of the state's computer stuff. STEVE STRUNSKY

title: Not Just Dazzling in Their Time, but Dedicated
description: WITH THE DEATHS THIS YEAR OF Alexandra Danilova, in July, and Leon Danielian, in March, the ballet world has lost two great dancers of enormous flair. Although they appeared with several groups during their long careers, they were especially associated with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, the cosmopolitan touring company that after settling in the United States during World War II delighted countless Americans from the 1940's through the early 60's. The performances of Danilova and Danielian did much to convince newcomers to dancing that ballet could be exhilarating and inspiring -- and fun as well.

title: The Cost of Nice Beaches: Who Should Pay the Price?
description: For generations, the Jersey Shore beach badge has been a rite of summer for beachgoers, with municipalities charging as much as $10 a day or $60 a season to provide access to their stretches of the state's 127 miles of shoreline.

title: Experimental Mood Prevails in Purchase
description: ARTISTS who make their living bending wood, exploring the physics of chairs and carving their visions into headboards met here recently at the first conference of the newly formed Furniture Society.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A costume drama of sexual intrigue, a portrait of a notorious monarch, an episodic Hollywood package and a pioneer sci-fi classic from Britain.

title: Preserving Summer in a Jar
description: PICKLING and preserving have become recreational activities and are no longer necessities to prepare for the coming winter. Many people forgo these kitchen tasks entirely in favor of plucking jars off store shelves.

title: The F.B.I. and the King Both Had Suspicious Minds
description: THE meeting at the White House between President Nixon and Elvis Presley in December 1970 was one of the more bizarre encounters in the annals of American popular culture. An equally odd though much less widely chronicled clash of cultural sensibilities occurred just days later, when Mr. Presley toured F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. The visit on New Years' Eve day is recounted in the F.B.I.'s 663-page file on Elvis, which has been available since June on the agency's Internet site (www.fbi.gov) and is excerpted here.

title: Labor Showdowns: The Effect on Stocks
description: THE United Parcel Service is a private enterprise, but the strike there may lead some investors to wonder whether any public companies might also soon square off with labor -- and if so, what such disputes might do to their stocks.

title: Check, Please. Now Let's Eat.
description: NOT so long ago, the soy-sauce- soaked cardboard containers that topped many an urbanite's trash were a badge of privilege, a statement of priority. But now they're just ordinary garbage. A majority of the restaurant-made meals purchased throughout America are being taken home. Chinese food is not the only portable feast bidding for the mid-American dinner dollar. ''Take-out'' has been renamed ''meal replacement.''

title: The Thin Red Line
description: Jill McArdle evokes the young Sylvia Plath. Plath was a tall, attractive blonde, intent on perfecting herself. Her need for approval was enormous.

title: Marisa A. Kuhn, Stefan M. Rosen
description: Marisa Ann Kuhn, a daughter of Edda B. Kuhn of Southport, Conn., and Robert M. Kuhn of Oak Brook, Ill., was married yesterday to Stefan Marshall Rosen, the son of Donna B. Rosen of Greenwich, Conn. Judge Paul J. Del Nero, who retired from the Rhode Island District Court in Newport, officiated at the New York Yacht Club in Newport.

title: Taking a Chance on Love: Now, a $1.2 Million House
description: ONE day not too long ago a young woman wrote a note and stuck it on the windshield of the young man's red Jeep. She had seen him playing volleyball, and had heard his friends call him John.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, the last line of a front-page article in this section last Sunday about bicycling was omitted. The complete quotation, from Jim Grady, was: ''I keep waiting for the day I slow down. First, I thought it would happen when I turned 50. Now, I'm 58, I'm still keeping up with the younger kids. I love it.''

title: God Is an .800 Hitter
description: If the emphasis on ''values'' and clean living works for the Texas Rangers, I applaud it (''God Is an .800 Hitter,'' by Chris Smith, July 27). At the same time, I grieve for those who think that they have found God in the pious precincts of evangelism.

title: Tenants at 45 Wall St.: Just Folks, Not Firms
description: Expectations had been that the 435 apartments at 45 Wall Street, one of the first office towers converted to residential use as part of the city's Lower Manhattan Revitalization Plan, would be rented in large corporate and institutional blocs.

title: 'Benjamin's Crossing'
description: To the Editor:

title: Just a Typical Farm Wife, but She Kept a Diary
description: WHO -- Sarah Tabitha Appleton Reid.

title: Going Solo
description: To the Editor: Judith Anderson's ''Damsel in Distress: Only One Need Apply,'' (July 20) reminded me of my solo adventures in Italy years ago. I arrived in Venice, at a palazzo on the Grand Canal, only to be informed that there were no rooms; they had received my wire too late to respond. I cried. It was late. I was alone. What could I do? He apologized and told me there was a room, but it was beneath contempt and one they did not usually rent. I took it sight unseen and it was one of the loveliest rooms I had during my entire trip.

title: Elizabeth Wareham, Bernard Holland
description: Elizabeth Ann Wareham, a publicity director in the trade division of Simon & Schuster, the New York publishing company, and Bernard Peabody Holland 3d, the chief music critic of The New York Times, were married on Tuesday at their home in New York. Arnold G. Fraiman, a retired justice of State Supreme Court in New York, officiated.

title: A Shore Road Mansion, Now Obscured From Shore
description: IT'S one of the last of Brooklyn's Shore Road mansions, built with dramatic views of New York Harbor and the Narrows. Today you can't even see the water from the Farrell house at 125 95th Street in Bay Ridge, for it was moved 100 feet back from Shore Road eight decades ago to escape demolition.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH TO PROTEST POLICE
description: Thousands of demonstrators, many waving toilet plungers or Haitian flags, marched through Flatbush, Brooklyn, to the 70th Precinct yesterday, protesting the torture there of a Haitian immigrant and assailing the Giuliani administration's record on police brutality.

title: Sara Paulson, Edward Eigen
description: Sara Lynn Paulson, a daughter of Dr. Sara Friedrichsmeyer of Cincinnati and Joseph H. Paulson of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married in New York on Friday to Edward Andrew Eigen, a son of Natalie Eigen and Dr. Stuart Eigen of New York.

title: Portraits of a Distant People By a Pioneer With a Camera
description: EARLY PHOTOGRAPHIC portraits, no matter how expert the man or woman behind the camera, always seem a little stiff to modern eyes. Not only do the subjects' Victorian costumes lend a faraway, fancy-dress air but the people themselves seem artificial -- pokerfaced, stiffly arranged, life-size dolls rather than human beings. And distance of time often renders that earliest era's most celebratedly beautiful visages strangely unappealing. But John Thomson was that rare being, less a photographer than a fine artist, capturing his subjects, quirks and all, in ways that transform them from historical figures into lively companions.

title: Floating Hospital Is at Sea in the Search for a Pier
description: The Floating Hospital is a New York institution that has provided the city's poor and sick with medical and dental treatment as well as sunshine and fresh air for 130 years. It is also an institution with a problem: Facing eviction from its East River berth, it has nowhere to go.

title: What the President Ordered
description: Presidents have wanted the line item veto for more than a century; President Clinton got it, thanks to Republicans in Congress who made the veto a goal of their 1994 Contract With America. And last week he used the weapon for the first time, striking three items from the balanced budget and tax-cut package.

title: Color Us Invisible
description: Liberal Racism

title: Writings by Iran's New President Due to Be Published in U.S.
description: In a move that is generating unusual excitement among Middle East scholars and policy makers, two American research institutes this week will co-publish the first English-language translation of writings and speeches by Mohammed Khatami, the new President of Iran.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Aug. 3 about motorcyclists who stopped to view the Grossglockner, Austria's highest peak, misidentified the road on which they were traveling. It was the Hochalpenstrasse (or High Alpine Road), not the Hohenstrasse.

title: Selling A Home? Try Bach
description: I SOLD my first house in 1993 after it had been on the market less than a month. Call me cocky, but I knew it was just a matter of the right person stumbling through the front door and falling -- hook, line and sinker -- for my bait.

title: New and Bold Takes on the Humble Bead
description: BEADS, usually strung, to be worn and admired, are given a different spin at the Brookfield Craft Center. ''We invited a curator to create a show that would expand the normal boundaries of a bead's concept,'' said John I. Russell, director of the center.

title: Glasgow
description: If Edinburgh is Scotland's stately dowager, than Glasgow, just 40 miles to the west, is its feisty teen-ager. Friendlier and a bit wilder than Edinburgh, Glasgow is still working to extricate itself from its old image as a has-been, postindustrial city of closed factories and not-so-exciting culture. But even though most visitors are likely to think of Edinburgh first when they think of Scotland, they will find vigor and indeed loveliness in Glasgow, whose name means roughly ''dear green place'' in Celtic.

title: Music of the Spheres
description: Space Is The Place

title: Gregory King and Karen Matsushima
description: Karen Emi Matsushima, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. Kathleen R. Matsushima and Akira P. Matsushima of Inverness, Ill., was married last evening to Gregory McLennan King, a son of Nancy M. King and Douglas L. King, both of New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The bride's mother, who is a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

title: The Mother Connection
description: It rained the day of my grandmother's funeral, a fine drizzle that clung to our dark coats like a silver veil. She died this past December, a few weeks short of her 90th birthday. We buried her in the family plot just behind my mother, who died at 42. The official documents listed my grandmother's cause of death as acute respiratory and coronary failure, backed up by advanced breast cancer -- an absolute calamity of the chest -- but I believe otherwise: that despite all her ailments, she died of loneliness and quite possibly a broken heart. She kept asking for my mother until the very end.

title: Study Links Violence Rate To Cohesion In Community
description: The largest study ever undertaken of the causes of crime and delinquency has found that there are lower rates of violence in urban neighborhoods with a strong sense of community and values, where most adults discipline children for missing school or scrawling graffiti.

title: Evoking the World of Winslow Homer
description: The 1858 Tenth Street Studio Building, which once stood at 51 West 10th Street, had everything an artist could hope for -- cheap rent (about $200 a year), heat, good light, camaraderie, a gallery, soirees and wealthy patrons. It was the world of William Merritt Chase, Frederic Church and Winslow Homer.

title: Book Analyst Failed to See Westchester-Bound Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: Rite Aid Could Prove Too Powerful for Sure
description: The drugstore chain Rite Aid recently began advertising a sophisticated new computer system that will record customers' drug histories and flash warning lights if a pharmacist tries to fill a prescription that could be harmful when combined with another of the customer's medications.

title: Amanda Marks and Bruce McKinlay
description: Amanda Maria Marks, the daughter of Andree and Charles Marks of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Bruce William McKinlay, a son of Irene M. McKinlay of Purdys, N.Y., and the late John D. McKinlay. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Convent of Our Lady of Princeton.

title: Gauging a New Drop In H.M.O.'s Stocks
description: SO far, August hasn't let health maintenance organizations take a vacation. In one week alone, Aetna and United Healthcare reported disappointing earnings, and Stephen F. Wiggins, the founder of Oxford Health Plans, resigned. The Aetna report then pushed down H.M.O. stocks in general, with the Morgan Stanley index of the industry falling 5.3 percent since the beginning of the month.

title: Anne Peracca, Matthew Bijur
description: Anne Humes Peracca, a daughter of Dr. Maryellen Humes of Westport, Conn., and Roland M. Peracca Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Justin Bijur, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Bijur of New York. Val Demong, a justice of the peace in Goshen, Vt., officiated at Blueberry Hill, an inn in Goshen.

title: Pay for Vindication?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Social Changes Revive the False God of Numbers
description: A YEAR ago, after a furious debate within his own party and even among his own advisers, President Clinton signed the most radical revision of the nation's welfare policy in history. Last week the President declared the change an unqualified success.

title: $1 Million Gift for Needles Is a Lifesaver, Financier Says, Not a Ruse to Legalize Drugs
description: In a philanthropic gesture certain to elicit outrage as well as gratitude, the financier George Soros is spending $1 million on sterile needles to be handed out to heroin and cocaine addicts who risk contracting AIDS and other diseases by sharing needles.

title: In TV's Dull Summer Days, Plots Take Wing on the Net
description: On TV this summer, as it does every long, trying season of reruns, time is standing still. Impatient channel surfing doesn't help. Glimpses of fall premieres are only maddening. Months will go by before fans know what happens in the lives -- and deaths -- of characters in their favorite prime-time dramas.

title: In Swoopes's Family, A Merging of Dreams
description: AS the Houston Comets completed their pre-game warm-ups at Madison Square Garden yesterday, Sheryl Swoopes walked toward the Comets' bench and looked over her shoulder at the row of seats behind the basket. After a moment of searching, she made eye contact with her husband, Eric Jackson, who made a motion signaling that everything was fine.

title: Hobbled Woods Unable to Make a Move
description: Tiger Woods had heard the warnings that Winged Foot could humble a player, even a player of his stature. And by the time he completed his final walk up No. 18 today, the shouts from the crowd, urging him to keep his head up, were subtle proof that he had become the most visible victim of the venerable course.

title: A Beat Becomes a Profitable Fashion
description: The doldrums the music business has been in until recently have yielded little in the way of good industry news. Yet at least one exception exists to the tales of stagnant sales and indifferent audiences: music may be doing mediocre business, but music labels are finding new ways to bring in revenue.

title: A Gulf Develops Among Broadcasters on Programming Pledge
description: A gulf is growing among broadcast-television organizations about how they will use the second channels loaned to them for digital broadcasting starting next year. Some broadcasters say they are prepared to abandon the pledges they made to broadcast high-definition programming on those channels -- a promise offered as part of their effort to win the channels in the first place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SAUL DAVID
description: WEINBERG-Saul David. Age 87 of Hallendale Beach, FL. Died Saturday August 16, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Averie. Beloved father of Stephen Weinberg and Karen and Lawrence Peltz. Adored grandfather of Adam Peltz. Enshrined in the hearts of all who knew him, and those who loved him will miss him forever.

title: On the Web, Winning Isn't Everything Isn't Everything but Awards Are Everywhere
description: To W. Edwards Deming, the famed management guru, awards meant that only one person would be a winner, and the rest losers. The on-line community has found a way around that problem: Give out awards for just about anything. The Cool Site of the Moment award alone generates hundreds of winners a day.

title: Jet's Crash In April Still A Mystery To Air Force
description: While American technology explored the surface of Mars this summer, five months of searching has failed to come up with four 500-pound bombs lost in the forbidding high country of Colorado.

title: Stanley Cup Goes for a Jaunt In Red Square
description: In the middle of Red Square today, Yuri Shersnov, a visitor from Belarus, raised the Stanley Cup above his head and let out a triumphant ''I am the champion!'' Shersnov had pushed his way through the crowd for a chance to hold North American hockey's most prestigious trophy and see the Russian hockey stars who brought it to their homeland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, MADALYN
description: WEISSBERG-Madalyn. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Madalyn Weissberg. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Reality of Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Campaign Said To Get Bad Reaction
description: A coming issue of TV Guide describes ''confidential network research'' about an irreverent brand image campaign for the ABC television network that concluded there was an ''overwhelmingly negative reaction'' to the advertising before its introduction.

title: Tomorrow's Gossip Today
description: Matt Drudge freely admits it: sometimes he's dead wrong. ''I have no editor,'' the 30-year-old writer says. ''I can say whatever I want.'' But his on-line gossip sheet, the Drudge Report, is rapidly becoming a must-read for the political and entertainment elites on both coasts. -- Newsweek

title: Among the Horrors of Yugoslavia's Death, the Story of a 'Safe' Enclave
description: ENDGAMEThe Betrayal and Fall of Srebrenica: Europe's Worst Massacre Since World War II By David Rohde 440 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: Largest Denomination to Vote on Closer Ties to 3 Major Churches
description: Leaders of the nation's largest Lutheran denomination began their final debate this morning on a sweeping proposal for closer ties with three major Protestant churches.

title: Even action heroes can find themselves foiled by the gadgets they confront.
description: THE popular success of the movie ''Air Force One'' might seem related to its outrageously appealing and impossible fantasy: Here is an American President who advocates both high moral principle and unabashed use of American power, who is both a family man and a heart-throb, who can hang from a rope dangling from an airplane like a superhero yet loves ordinary football so much he'll watch a game on videotape even after hearing the final score.

title: Eat Greens, Not Dairy, to Increase Calcium
