To a practitioner, this turnabout feels good.

title: In Malaysia, Pressure Builds Over Enforcement of Islamic Laws
description: SHAH ALAM, Malaysia  When Noni Mohamad entered the Miss Malaysia Petite beauty contest, she did not expect to become the focus of a bitter struggle between moderate and conservative Muslims in a country that suddenly seems to be veering away from religious toleration toward extremism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, SIDNEY
description: AARON-Sidney. On August 15, at age 88. Beloved husband of the late Marcia, father of Clifford and Barry, grandfather of David, Rebecca and Samuel, brother and uncle. Lifelong Mason. Services were held.

title: Maggert Earns Spot on Ryder Team
description: For Jeff Maggert, it was the most satisfying third-place finish of his career.

title: Those Gobs on Shore Leave Again, Prowling Wartime New York
description: Big, loud, pushy and intimidating, Hildy Esterhazy has a lot in common with the hell of a town where she works as a taxi driver. That's New York City, or to be more specific, the Manhattan of the 1944 musical classic ''On the Town,'' and whatever their status in other places, these traits are virtues in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Smaller Classes Aren't a Cure-All
description: Eighteen state legislatures have passed, or are considering passing, bills dictating smaller classes as a way to improve the public schools. In New York, the Legislature authorized $142 million solely for the hiring of some 3,600 new teachers by 1999 to relieve overcrowding in New York City schools.

title: Israelis Turn Military Skills Into Software Export Boom
description: Sharon Carmel and his old army buddies used to work on computerized battlefield simulations when they were in the service. Now heading their own software company in this Tel Aviv suburb, they plan a multimedia blitz on the Internet, hoping their software will be the underpinning of a new generation of sites on the World Wide Web.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about a demonstration by a dissident group of Hasidic Jews who oppose the creation of a special public school district for disabled children in the Hasidic village of Kiryas Joel misstated the issue. Organizers of the protest say they object to the district -- created by state legislation at the urging of the village's leaders -- because religion and education should not be separated and Jewish children should not attend secular schools. They do not contend that Hasidic children should not attend school with non-Hasidic children.

title: Yanks Hold Breath as Cone Suffers Shoulder Soreness
description: No one could have known what was going through David Cone's mind when he decided to remove himself from yesterday's 8-0 Yankee victory over the Texas Rangers before the second inning began.

title: Barber Is Surprising the Giants
description: Day by day, you can hear the exasperation rising in Jim Fassel's voice whenever the subject is his top two running backs, Rodney Hampton and Tyrone Wheatley. Finally, after recurring injuries kept Hampton and Wheatley out of Saturday night's loss to the Jets, Fassel acknowledged that he might start the season without either player as his featured running back.

title: U.S. PLAN SHOWS NEW DESIGN WORK ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Although the cold war ended years ago, the United States is hard at work on new or modified designs for nuclear arms, a formerly secret Federal document reveals.

title: William H. Jordy, 79, Architectural Historian
description: William H. Jordy, one of the first historians to chronicle the rise of modern architecture in the United States, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Riverside, R.I. He was 79.

title: Mugged, and Then Hit By a Falling Piece of Stone
description: A man who told firefighters he had been mugged on Saturday had no better luck yesterday: as he sat on a stoop on West 40th Street, a piece of stone on the building above, apparently loosened by illegal renovations inside, fell off and struck him on the head.

title: Comfort and Counsel in Times of Grief
description: After the death of her 25-year-old son, William, Mary Withers found that friends had a limited store of patience for her grief; they soon began urging her to pull herself together and move on. When support groups and counselors also failed to provide the kind of outlet she needed, Ms. Withers turned to the Internet.

title: A Banner Year for Movie Title Tangles
description: Scanning a marquee at a megaplex, moviegoers see clipped titles -- ''Conspiracy,'' ''Nothing'' and ''Free'' -- and are expected to know the rest '' . . . Theory,'' '' . . . to Lose'' and '' . . . Willy.'' It is the business of movie studios to create instant brand identification for their titles (or even parts of them). One way to do that is to make sure that no two titles are that much alike.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce Faster Version Of Popular Minicomputer
description: I.B.M. plans to introduce a new version of its AS/400 minicomputer today that is nearly five times as fast as previous models.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the photojournalist Horace Bristol on Aug. 7 overstated his role as the impetus for ''Grapes of Wrath,'' John Steinbeck's novel about the migration of Oklahomans to California. Mr. Bristol recruited Mr. Steinbeck in the fall of 1937 to work with him on a nonfiction book about the migrants, but Mr. Steinbeck had written magazine and newspaper articles about them in 1936 and was already immersed in turning the material into another form.

title: Seemingly Innocent, Behind the Grand Gestures
description: The International New York Fringe Festival is devoted to cultivating new work by young artists for a new young audience, to judge by two dance programs presented on Sunday afternoon at the University Settlement. Yanira Castro and Rachel Thorne Germond are developing their own styles, but each has already found an individual voice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, RICHARD J.
description: CAMPBELL-Richard J. The faculty and students of New York University's Dept of Psychology mourn the death of Richard J. Campbell, a distinguished colleague and dedicated mentor to NYU students for ten years. We express condolences to his family and sadness for the field of industrial organizational psychology which has lost an important figure.

title: Captain's Call: Couples and Janzen to Complete the Ryder Cup Team
description: Ending months of speculation, Tom Kite named Fred Couples and Lee Janzen to the 1997 United States Ryder Cup team today.

title: Whistle-Blower Lawsuits Aim At Big Provider Of Health Care
description: More than a dozen people associated with the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation have secretly filed separate lawsuits against the company under Federal whistle-blower laws, contending that the company has engaged in a variety of schemes to defraud national health care programs like Medicare, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CASTRO, JOSE SERGIO TAVORA
description: DE CASTRO-Jose Sergio Tavora. June 20, 1933-August 16, 1997. We will all remember the way he embraced life and captivated those around him. He was successful in all his endeavors: academic, professional and personal. Born in Fortaleza, Brazil, he was the son of Sergio de Castro and Idalina Tavora de Castro. He was a loving son, brother, spouse and father. He graduated from law school at the Universidade Federal do Ceara in 1953. His dreams began to unfold when he was awarded both Fulbright and Rotary scholarships to study in the U.S. Accepting the latter, he pursued international law at Yale University, graduating in 1957. He met his first wife, Emilia Faro, while working at Petrobras in NY. His career flourished at Banco Real, where he earned the title of Deputy Regional Director-North America. It was here that he found his second family. Sergio is survived by his children Diana and Nelson, by his fiancee Sumie Ogata, and by his siblings, Jose Valter, Jose Valdomiro, Rita, Helena, Sarah, Regina and Theresa, all of whom were by his side at his time of greatest need. He is now in the company of his loving parents and brother Clemente. There are no words to express just how much we will miss him. Love, Diana and Nelson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZENSTEIN, RICHARD L.
description: KATZENSTEIN-Richard L. Died August 17, 1997 at age 82 in Boca Raton, FL. He was retired from the shipbuilding divisions of Bethlehem Steel and General Dynamics. He is survived by his wife Marian Berliss Katzenstein and seven nieces and nephews.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday citing recent reports of large advances for books misidentified the publisher of ''Behind the Oval Office'' by Dick Morris. It is Random House, not Thorndike, a Random House subsidiary that publishes a large-type edition of the book.

title: SIS BANCORP PLANS PURCHASE OF GLASTONBURY BANK
description: SIS Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Glastonbury Bank and Trust Company of Glastonbury, Conn., for about $40.6 million in stock. Under the agreement, SIS, of Springfield, Mass., would exchange 0.74 share for each of Glastonbury's 1.8 million shares. SIS closed at $29.875 a share yesterday, down 12.5 cents, on the Nasdaq market. Glastonbury closed at $21.25 a share, up $1.25, on the Nasdaq small-cap market. After completion of the deal, the president and chief executive of Glastonbury, J. Gilbert Soucie, would remain in charge of the bank; Glastonbury's board would also be retained. SIS said its earnings would be reduced by $2.5 million in 1997 for expenses related to the merger. The deal is expected to increase earnings in 1998.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deal Is Reached to End Strike Against U.P.S.

title: Leather's Allure for Fall
description: The must-have clothing for the fashion-conscious this fall will be anything in leather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRESHAN, LOUIS
description: TRESHAN-Louis. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Louis Treshan, associated with The Times from 1973, until retiring in 1983.

title: Police Listened In on Bosnian Serb President
description: Once again demonstrating a more assertive stance by Western officials in Bosnia, some 300 British soldiers and United Nations workers searched a police station today for evidence of electronic eavesdropping on the President of the Serbian half of the country by her political rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLMSEN, JERRY
description: SOLMSEN-Jerry. Age 66. On August 9, 1997. Son of Millie Irwig. Father of Bradley and Michael. Brother of Inge. Graveside service today 1 PM, at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: Bill Gates Visits the Grand Canyon
New York Police Trainer Faces Questions in Haiti
description: After 10 years in the New York Police Department, Detective Franz Jerome returned to his native Haiti last year as part of an international team sent to retrain that country's reconstituted police. Recently, he has found himself in an odd position: trying to answer questions from police officers in his hometown of Petionville about reports of a Haitian immigrant being tortured while in New York City police custody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSTENDIG, RHODA
description: ANSTENDIG-Rhoda. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member, and extends its condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz, Rabbi Emeritus Alan S. Roth, President

title: People
description: * Iain Newton and Stacey Lesser, vice presidents and senior brand planners at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, New York, were promoted to head the planning group as planning director and deputy planning director, respectively. They assume duties from Nigel Carr, now general manager of the agency's new office in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOVAKIMIAN, ARAM
description: HOVAKIMIAN-Aram. The patients and staff of the Division of Substance Abuse of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine are saddened to learn of the death of Aram Hovakimian, their recently retired mentor and colleague. Aram worked in our field for almost thirty years, working for Beth Israel Medical Center and the City of New York before he came to Einstein. He served over 10 years as Patient Advocate and always reminded us of why we are here-to help our patients with healthier and happier lives. We will always remember his wisdom and dedication to substance abuse treatment and rehabilitation. Ira J. Marion, Exec Director Constantine Gotsis, MD, Medical Director

title: Outrage on Nazi-era assets has not hurt Swiss banks' business.
description: DESPITE an international black eye for their handling of the accounts of victims of the Nazis, the big three Swiss banks are staging a remarkable recovery from the worst year in their history.

title: As Chechens Free 3, Leader And Yeltsin Discuss Future
description: As three well-known Russian television journalists held hostage in Chechnya were freed, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Aslan Maskhadov of Chechnya met today in Moscow to forge a more workable relationship between their wary and hostile governments.

title: The Cure Is in Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, SOL
description: EISENBERG-Sol. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Sol Eisenberg, associated with The Times from 1953, until retiring in 1981.

title: Opponents Claim the Mets are Stealing Signs Via Video
description: Smile, you're on ''Candid Camera.''

title: Liberty's Losses Erode Confidence
description: A recent stumble by the Liberty -- three losses in four games -- has dropped it out of the lead in the Eastern Conference of the Women's National Basketball Association, and it has severely bruised the team's confidence, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, DORIS
description: GOLD-Doris. In loving memory of my sister and our aunt. We will miss you. Irma, Janet and Karen

title: Profit Is Up 62% At Julius Baer
description: Julius Baer Holding A.G., Switzerland's largest listed private bank and asset manager, said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 62 percent as soaring financial markets helped commission and trading income. Profit rose to 107.5 million Swiss francs ($72 million), from 66.5 million francs a year ago. The company forecast significant earnings improvement for the full year.

title: Disputes develop over the comeback of 'Amos 'n Andy.'
description: ONE of the most contentious television sitcoms ever has unexpectedly returned with commercials selling episodes of the series on videotape. But in keeping with the program's past, its comeback has generated a dispute, too.

title: Costs of 30-Second Spot Rise 6%, to $278,000
description: An annual survey by the American Association of Advertising Agencies reported that the average cost of producing a 30-second national television commercial rose 6 percent in 1996, to $278,000 from $263,000 in 1995. That increase represented a reversal from the previous year's survey, which showed the cost to produce a 30-second spot decreasing 2 percent from 1994 to 1995. The surveys in 1993 and 1994 showed increases in production costs of 11 percent each of those years.

title: Altruism It's Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, M. DEAN
description: WILLIAMS-M. Dean. Died July 12, 1997, in Anchorage, AK. Born in Salt Lake City in 1913. He attended the University of Utah, graduating in 1941 with a Bachelor's Degree in geology and civil engineering. In 1947 he met June Maxwell in New York City where she was working as a registered nurse at New York Hospital. They were married in Lima, Peru, in December that year. Following college and during WWII, he served as a geologist for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in the Panama Canal where he became fluent in Spanish. After two years with the U.S. Geological Survey he began a 23 year career in oil exploration. Dean worked for various exploration subsidiaries of Exxon in Ecuador, Peru, Columbia, Venezuela and Pakistan. He was vice president of Exxon's exploration subsidiary in the Phili ppines at the time of his retirement. For his role in conducting the preliminary geological survey of the Upper Amazon Basin, he was listed in Who's Who of American Geologists. Surviving are his wife of 50 years, June Maxwell Williams, Yuma, AZ; daughter, Tamara, Palmer, AK; son and daughter-in-law, Benjamin and Paula, Draper, UT; and sister-in-law Miriam Maxell Kent of New York City. Burial took place at Mt. Olivet Cemetery, July 17, Salt Lake City.

title: Former Bank Officer Charged
description: A former vice president of National Westminster Bank NJ was indicted yesterday on charges that he misused $350,000 of the institution's funds and issued three forged letters of credit, The Associated Press reported.

title: Removing Half of Brain Improves Young Epileptics' Lives
description: BRAIN-DAMAGED children are actually able to recover some intellectual ground if the entire damaged half of the brain is surgically removed, researchers are finding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, ANTHONY NICHOLAS
description: ROGERS - Anthony Nicholas, passed away August 16, 1997 in Los Angeles, California. He was born March 24, 1953 in Pasadena, CA., and owned a food importing business in Los Angeles and an art gallery in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He is survived by his sister, Maria A. Rogers, his brother, George M. Rogers, and his loving family and friends. He was the eldest child of Mary and George C. Rogers who preceded him in death. A vigil service will be held Tuesday, August 19th at 7:00 PM at Cabot & Sons Chapel, Pasadena and a Funeral Mass will be held on Wednesday, August 20th, at 10:00 A.M., at St. Andrew's Church, Pasadena.

title: Several Companies Change Agencies
description: Several advertisers are making changes on their accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, MABEL
description: MAYER-Mabel of Maspeth on August 18, 1997. Loving wife of Charles. Beloved mother of Joyce Tese (Vincent). Cherished grandmother of Lauren and Andrea. Reposing Tues. and Wed., 2-5 and 7-9PM, at Megiel Funeral Home, 64-18 Flushing Ave., Maspeth (at Grand Avenue and Flushing Ave.), funeral Thursday, 8:15AM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Stanislaus RC Church, 9:15 AM. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Where Exactly Are We? Navigation That Is Hardly Celestial
description: A CERTIFIED technogeek friend was so tickled with the navigational device in his rental car on a recent visit that he called me on his cellular phone to make me listen to it say ''Turn left.'' It did get him to my front door, but not before it had sent him several blocks out of his way.

title: Lutherans Build One Bridge But Vote Down a Second One
description: Leaders of the nation's largest Lutheran denomination voted today to enter into a historic agreement for close cooperation with three other denominations but narrowly rejected establishing similar ties with the Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSSAWIR, ALBERT G.
description: MOSSAWIR-Albert G. On Aug. 18, 1997. Economist at the United Nations for over 20 years. Beloved husband of Morag (nee Gillies), loving father of John Roderick, dear father-in-law of Laura Stinchcom. Proud grandfather of Alexander Clark. Wake Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave, Bklyn, NY. Funeral services Thursday 10 A.M. at Union Church of Bay Ridge. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to Brooklyn Hospice, would be appreciated.

title: Teamsters and Ex-Rival Go After Apple Industry
description: The apples from one of the world's most bounteous fruit-producing regions are nearly ripe. The economy is flush. And an army of low-wage workers who pick and pack the crop is stirring for change. For organized labor, it all adds up to the kind of membership drive that would have been unheard of in previous years.

title: Leo Burnett Wins Additional Dairy Duties
description: Dairy Management Inc., which conducts marketing programs for the American Dairy Association, said yesterday that it had moved the creative advertising duties for cheese products to the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago from Grey Advertising in New York, which has handled that assignment since 1995. Though billings were not disclosed, the association's annual dairy promotional budget is $53 million.

title: CHICAGO MINIATURE LAMP PLANS TO ADD SYLVANIA LIGHTING
description: Chicago Miniature Lamp Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Sylvania Lighting International B.V. for about $165 million in cash, making it one of the world's largest lighting companies. Sylvania, a closely held company based in Geneva, generated about $600 million in revenue last year in 30 countries outside of North America; Chicago Miniature Lamp had 1996 revenue of $94.2 million. The GTE Corporation, the former owner of the Sylvania brand, sold Sylvania's North American operations to Siemens A.G. of Germany in 1993. Chicago Miniature Lamp, of Canton, Mass., said its acquisition of Sylvania Lighting International would increase per-share earnings in 1998. The company's shares fell $2.375 yesterday, to $28.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Orphan Girls of China at Home in New York
description: They have become a common sight in playgrounds from the Upper West Side to Park Slope, the little girls with names like Sabina Jing Wen Gilioli, Sara Mei-Ping Davis and Kerong Christina Kelly, abandoned in China and plucked out of orphanages there to be raised in the doting embrace of middle-aged New York professionals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASTRONARDI, ANGELO J. (ANDY MASTRO)
description: MASTRONARDI-Angelo J. (Andy Mastro). On August 18th, 1997. Owner of Andy's Limo Service. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted brother of Anna Coakley, Emily Schneider and Sophie Petrocelli. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews and grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St, Whitestone. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Luke's, Wednesday 9:30. Entombment St. Michael's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to NYU Medical Center.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Officials of the English National Ballet were not exactly hissing mad. But they did order 60 dancers scheduled for next month's performance of ''Swan Lake'' to stop sunbathing, because they are no longer considered pale enough to play their roles, The Associated Press reported.

title: CORNERSTONE IN $1.06 BILLION PROPERTY DEAL
description: Cornerstone Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust based in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 11 downtown properties in six United States cities from a Dutch pension fund for $1.06 billion in cash and stock. The agreement is the latest in a wave of transactions in which big institutional investors -- in this case, the Dutch Institutional Holding Company of Atlanta -- swap real estate assets for stock in publicly traded real estate companies. Under the agreement, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, Cornerstone will pay the fund $547 million in stock and $508 million in cash, and the fund will lend Cornerstone $250 million, to be paid back over 10 years. Dutch Institutional, an arm of one of the Netherlands' largest pension funds, will become Cornerstone's largest shareholder, holding about 40 percent of its stock and filling two seats on the 12-member board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, GARY MARK
description: GREEN-Gary Mark. Beloved father of David and Gabrielle, Bryan. Dear son of Helen and the late Abner. Dear brother of Bart and Beth, and the late Roger. Adored grandfather of Melissa. Services were held on Thursday.

title: Prisoner to Prisoner
description: Imad Sabi, a 35-year-old Palestinian, has been detained in Israeli prisons for 20 months, one of more than 350 Palestinians being held in ''administrative detention'' by Israel without being charged. He is suspected of political activity in the militant Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine. The open letter excerpted here refers to the case of Yuval Lotem, an Israeli army reserve officer who was recently jailed for a month when he refused to guard a prison holding Palestinians jailed without trial. The letter, written in Arabic, was published in Hebrew earlier this month in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz.

title: Now Turn Back Rising Tide of Paternalism
description: To the Editor:

title: To Argentines, Judges Are Often Biggest Lawbreakers
description: At first, Judge Hernan Bernasconi seemed courageous last year when he jailed the agent of the soccer star Diego Maradona for drug trafficking after the police discovered a large stash of cocaine in his apartment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKAS, RICHARD
description: FARKAS-Richard, August 17, 1997. Devoted husband of Carolyn, loving father of Jeffrey, Craig and Cindy, adored grandfather of Matthew, Victoria, Jason, Michael and Sean. Services Tuesday 11:30am August 19 at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulvard & 76 Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, LAWRENCE
description: MILLER-Lawrence. Suddenly on August 16, 1997. Cherished husband of Louise. Devoted father of Susan. Caring brother of Sonia Grossinger. Adored brother-in-law of Elaine Axel and Muriel Poliakoff. Loving uncle to Stephen, Nancy, Jane, Blair, Carol, Donald and Gloria. ''Goodbye my darling boy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLANDING, BARBARA A.
description: PLANDING-Barbara A., of Brooklyn (former administrative assistant in the rheumatology department Downstate Medical Center) on August 17th. Beloved daughter of the late Andrew and Mary (nee Taylor) Planding. Devoted sister of Andrew Planding. Also survived by 2 nieces and two grand nieces. Funeral from the McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Avenue, Thursday, 9 AM. Funeral Mass St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 9:45 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting 2-5 & 7-9 PM.

title: Sampras And Chang In Davis Lineup
description: Pete Sampras and Michael Chang, the two top players in the world, made the guest list, but the slumping Andre Agassi was snubbed.

title: Court Says College Donors Cannot Sue Over Gifts
description: Donors to colleges in Connecticut who feel their gifts have not been used as intended have no inherent right to sue, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: Hewlett-Packard Reports Mixed Results
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported mixed financial results today for its third fiscal quarter, including strong growth in orders and revenue, but earnings that fell below analysts' expectations. The earnings disappointment prompted a selloff of Hewlett-Packard shares in heavy trading.

title: Advanced Micro In I.B.M. Deal
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said today that the International Business Machines Corporation would use Advanced Micro's latest microprocessor in some of its Aptiva home personal computers, the first of the top five PC vendors to embrace its chips.

title: Israel Releases Some Palestinian Funds, but Sticking Points Remain
description: Rewarding what it called ''partial cooperation'' from the Palestinian Authority, Israel said today that it would pay part of the money owed to Palestinians that was frozen as punishment after the suicide bombing last month in a Jerusalem market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDSTEIN, JACK
description: BRANDSTEIN-Jack. Born 1907, died August 18, 1997. Survived by wife Elena, daughter Eve, grandson Benjamin. Holocaust survivor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VIGDOR, ARTHUR
description: VIGDOR-Arthur. July 5, 1919, to August 19, 1991. Six years have gone by and nothing has changed. Love goes on forever.

title: [No Headline]
description: ''If you want to listen to the Pope, buy his tapes or visit him somewhere else.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEATHERTON, RAY
description: HEATHERTON-Ray. The Episcopal Actor's Guild mourns our past president (1974-1986), and shares fonds memories of a remarkable actor and a gentle man.

title: Pawnshop Chains Grow As They Remake Image
description: When Misty Jones, a 23-year-old mother of three, fell behind on a nagging bill this summer, she knew just what to do. She brought a battery charger for the family car to Cash America, a local pawnshop, to ask for help. ''It rained for, like, two weeks,'' said Ms. Jones, whose husband, a house framer, depends on good weather for his work. ''We knew that if we came to a pawnshop, they would give us a little loan.''

title: A Judge Gets Manhattan's Oldest Divorce Cases Moving
description: Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann leaned over the bench in her wood-paneled Manhattan courtroom yesterday, her face stern as the morning's first case came in by speaker phone from Miami Beach.

title: Life Gets Harder on the Already Mean Streets
description: Carolyn, a prostitute who many years ago abandoned her young son to the care of her churchgoing mother, works a ''crack stroll'' in Harlem, where men come to buy fleeting sex along with their drugs.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Recover a Bit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINDTWORTH, RUTH
description: KLINDTWORTH-Ruth. Leucadia National Corporation announces the passing of their long time and beloved corporate secretary, Ruth Klindtworth. Ms. Klindtworth joined the company in July 1960 and was named corporate secretary in February 1976 and Vice President in 1990. All of us at Leucadia mourn her passing and will deeply miss Ruth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TODD, DAVID
description: TODD-David. On August 12, 1997. In Lebanon, N.H., of injuries following an automobile accident. An inspired teacher of organic chemistry and research chemist for 30 years at Worcester Polytechnic Institute and at other colleges and research centers, graduate of Swarthmore College, B.A. and Harvard Ph.D, public spirited volunteer in many fields. His family, Constance, Rebecca, Laurence, Julia, Jenny, Christopher, Alden, and Mary salute his memory.

title: Sheen of the King Legacy Dims On New, More Profitable Path
description: For more than 25 years after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his widow and four children were Atlanta's royalty.

title: Sedentary Fruit Flies
description: WHEN it comes to eating habits, there are two kinds of fruit flies: the energetic foragers and the couch potatoes, which are less active in finding food.

title: Wanted: A Lifeboat in Space
description: THEY were some of the oddest aircraft ever to fly. People called them ''flying bathtubs,'' ''finned potatoes'' and other strange names.

title: Treasuries Gain Amid Stock Turmoil
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday, amid continued turmoil in the stock market.

title: James Starbuck, 85, TV Dance Innovator
description: James Starbuck, a ballet dancer who became a pioneering television choreographer and also worked on Broadway and in film musicals, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 85.

title: Fresenius Income Nearly Doubles
description: Fresenius A.G. of Germany has indicated that its second-quarter net income almost doubled as the company, the world's largest maker of dialysis equipment and services, profited from its United States buying spree. Profit rose to 65 million marks ($35.9 million) in the three months that ended on June 30, from 33 million a year earlier. Fresenius would not confirm the figure, which was derived from reported first-half earnings and calculated from a first-quarter net of 51 million marks. Fresenius traced the surge in profit in part to its purchase last year of the dialysis activities of W. R. Grace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTIN, LESTER M.
description: ENTIN-Lester M. Beloved husband of Sally and devoted father of Norma Rappaport and Sheila Lenner and brother Horace Entin and six grandchildren and 2 greatgrandchildren. Services are today 1pm at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Rte 4 East, Paramus, N.J.

title: Four Years After the Flames of Waco, a Film Keeps the Doubts Smoldering
description: The questions about what really happened near Waco, Tex., more than four years ago will not go away: not just in the minds of those obsessed with the notion of a Government conspiracy but in the minds of thousands of curious Americans who are turning out to see a documentary, ''Waco: The Rules of Engagement,'' that has been causing a stir at film festivals and in theaters around the nation this summer.

title: Cost of Net Access Estimated
description: Bringing Internet access to all of New Jersey's schools and libraries would cost $2.8 billion over the next five years, according to a report issued yesterday by an agency that is studying the issue.

title: Badgers Relying on Back's Second Effort
description: Ron Dayne's favorite football player when he was small gives you an idea of how long ago he was actually small. More than a decade ago, the young person who would become the most productive freshman running back in the history of college football admired the qualities he would eventually acquire: speed, power, durability. It's just that at the age of 19, as Dayne begins his sophomore season at the University of Wisconsin, his generation seems so far removed from . . . John Riggins?

title: Legh Knowles Is Dead at 78; Trumpeter Headed Winery
description: Legh Knowles, a trumpet player in the Glenn Miller Orchestra who went on to become chairman of Beaulieu Vineyard, one of California's most famous wineries, and a passionate spokesman for all California wines, died on Friday at a convalescent residence near his home in Napa, Calif. He was 78.

title: Whitman to Sign Parole Bills
description: Crime victims in New Jersey will be able to ask parole boards to impose specific conditions before their assailants are released on parole, and terminally ill inmates who were convicted of nonviolent crimes will be eligible for early release under a package of bills to be signed today by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, officials said.

title: Burmah Castrol to Sell Unit
description: The British oil company Burmah Castrol P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to sell Columbia Cement, its United States adhesives unit, to the TACC International Corporation for $:15 million ($24.1 million). TACC International, which is based in Rockland, Mass., is an adhesives, sealants and coatings supplier. The sale is part of Burmah Castrol's recent decision to leave the adhesives business.

title: Exports Help Expand Germany's Economy
description: Germany's economy expanded by ''up to 1 percent'' in the second quarter, as exports continued to fuel growth while domestic recovery remained modest, the Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said yesterday. The annual rate of growth in Germany, Europe's biggest economy, was 2.5 percent to 3 percent in the second three months of the year, he said, putting the economy on course to achieve the full-year growth target of 2.5 percent.

title: Utne Reader Seeks Investors; Sale Is Possible, but Unlikely
description: The Utne Reader, the Reader's Digest of the alternative press of the left, is looking for an investor, according to Eric Utne, its founder and chairman. Mr. Utne said that he would consider selling the publication outright but that such a purchase was unlikely.

title: Macy's Enters Deal For Optical Shops
description: Having emerged from bankruptcy only a few years ago, Macy's is expanding its line of merchandise to include eye glasses and contact lenses. But it is putting the onus of success or failure on someone else's shoulders through an intricate franchising arrangement.

description: Responding to one of the worst allegations of police brutality in recent years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he was ordering every city police officer to spend several hours in loosely organized discussion groups with various critics and supporters of the Police Department.

title: GOLDEN STATE BANCORP BUYING CENFED FINANCIAL
description: Golden State Bancorp said yesterday that its Glendale Federal Bank unit would acquire the Cenfed Financial Corporation for about $210 million in stock. Golden State, based in Glendale, Calif., is a bank holding company with assets of $16.22 billion. Cenfed, based in Pasadena, Calif., has assets of $2.26 billion. Under the agreement, shareholders would receive 1.2 Golden State common shares for each Cenfed common share held. Golden State's shares dropped 50 cents yesterday, to $28.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange, while Cenfed's stock fell 62.5 cents, to $33.375, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition, which would create a combined entity with 193 banking offices, is expected to result in a charge of $30 million before taxes.

title: In Subways, Vandals Etch Old Defiance
description: CABLE television viewers had an opportunity on Sunday night to see a film from HBO NYC Productions called ''Subway Stories,'' said to have been based on true-life tales told by New York City train riders. If you discount the inevitable measure of dramatic license, the film did an admirable job of capturing the feel of the subways.

title: An Itch Torments Many Japanese, but Relief Is Elusive
description: TOSHIHIRO and Masumi Sato tried nearly everything to treat the horribly itchy rash that had afflicted their 4-year-old son, Shota, since he was born. They went to seven or eight hospitals, tried Western and Chinese medicine, fed him garlic and basil and spread lightly acidic water on his skin, all to no avail.

title: Listening for Inner Truths At the Glimmerglass Opera
description: For years now, in the opera house as in the playhouse, directors have used the device of updating as a way to revitalize older works. Take Mozart's bewigged Count and Countess and their retinue of servants and zap them to the Trump Tower. Suddenly, the ''The Marriage of Figaro'' is revealed anew, the theory goes, as a story of power and sexual battles between the classes.

description: The words ''loose bodies'' and ''scope'' usually spell trouble in football, and that was just what they meant to the Giants' running game today. Rodney Hampton had arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today to remove loose cartilage and will miss two to three weeks.

title: Corrections

title: CIRCON SHUNS A FOURTH OFFER BY U.S. SURGICAL
description: The Circon Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected the fourth bid by the U.S. Surgical Corporation, calling the offer of $16.50 a share, or $235 million, too low. U.S. Surgical, based in Norwalk, Conn., first offered to buy Circon last August, for $18 a share, a bid that was lowered to $17 and then $16.33. Each time, Circon rejected the offer. U.S. Surgical owns about 1.96 million shares of Circon, or about 14.8 percent of the company, which makes minimally invasive surgical products. Shares of Circon, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., closed at $15.75 yesterday, up 18.75 cents, on the Nasdaq market.

title: A Poet Knits Together Memories of Armenian Horrors
description: Growing up in Tenafly, N.J., during the ''strange sweetness of a privileged childhood,'' the poet Peter Balakian could feel beneath the membrane of suburban life the intimations of his family's ancient and exotic Armenian culture and a dark and terrifying past. On Sundays, there were the incense-filled, 1,500-year-old rituals of the Armenian church. There were oriental rugs on the floors of his family's house, while other children's houses had shag. There was Mr. Balakian's beloved grandmother, Nafina, who baked choereg, Armenian shortbread, and told him strange parables and fragments of her violent dreams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOWELL, PEGGY
description: McDOWELL-Peggy. Peggy became of counsel to the Family Law Center upon her retirement from the Legal Aid Society, Civil Division. In November 1996, she immediately became actively involved in our Family Law Practice, for working poor people, on a daily basis, while at the same time establishing an immigration practice and assisting foster children to become adopted children. She approched every case with enthusiasm and brought each client a professional confidence that will be unmatched. She was a living law library and a live-in law professor. Although her time with us was short her impact was long. We shall miss her immeasurably. From your Family Law Center family. Pat Fersch, Catherine Cornelius, John Perlich

Has the Police Department's sharper focus on community policing and quality-of-life crimes led officers to abuse their authority and use excessive force? Have we paid too high a price for the remarkable decline in crime that has occurred in the last three and a half years?

title: Judge Orders Health and Safety Items for 5,000 in Workfare

City officials immediately disputed the ruling and said they would appeal.

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS ACQUIRING 70% OF TWEEDY, BROWNE
description: The Affiliated Managers Group of Boston agreed yesterday to buy about 70 percent of the Tweedy, Browne Company, a New York-based money manager with about $5 billion in assets, for more than $100 million. The deal would be Affiliated Managers' ninth investment in a money management firm. Under the agreement, Tweedy, Browne would retain operational autonomy. The firm's three partners, Christopher Browne, William Browne and John Spears, have signed 10-year employment contracts with Affiliated Managers. Tweedy Browne, founded in 1920, has offices in New York and London.

The team has signed a letter of intent with Manhattanville College to use part of a new athletic facility that will have two skating rinks and modern training rooms.

title: AMYLIN PHARMACEUTICALS SLUMPS ON DIABETES DRUG DATA
description: Shares of Amylin Pharmaceuticals Inc. plunged 43 percent yesterday after the company released disappointing data on a drug for diabetes patients. The company's data concerned the compound pramlintide, a synthetic copy of a human hormone that is deficient in diabetics who use insulin. The data showed that pramlintide had only a minor effect on insulin-dependent diabetics and no effect on noninsulin-dependent diabetics, according to Albert Rauch, an analyst at Everen Securities Inc. Shares of Amylin, which is based in San Diego, fell $6.4375, to $8.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

description: CHARET-William A. The Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies expresses our deep sorrow at the passing of our friend and esteemed colleague. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. We will miss this special man. Mary D. Redd, President Phillip A. Saperia, Exec Director

title: Half of Gulf-Illness Panel Now Calls Gas a Possible Factor
description: Nearly half the members of a special White House committee on the illnesses of gulf war veterans say they will urge that the panel reverse itself and conclude that Iraqi chemical weapons may be an important factor in the veterans' health problems.

title: Park Ave. Complex Sold
description: Boston Properties Inc., the real estate company founded by the publisher of The Daily News, Mortimer Zuckerman, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 280 Park Avenue, a complex of two large office towers between 48th Street and 49th Street, from the Bankers Trust Company for $321 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, HELEN
description: MERRILL-Helen. The officers, board of directors and staff of Dramatists Play Service mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and colleague. Helen was a devoted member of the Board of Directors of the Play Service for many years. We will miss her and her incredible theatre knowledge, uncanny instinct for new talent and sly sense of humor, not to mention her memorable accent. We express our deep sympathy to her family, friends and clients. Dramatists Play Service Stephen Sultan, President

title: Remembering Two Boys in a Piper Cub Over America
description: A SIMPLE interview? Sipping civilized tea on some wicker-laden, writerly porch?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, FRANK J. JR
description: LYONS-Frank J. Jr, 71. On August 17, 1997. Of New York, Fort Pierce, Fla. and Long Beach Island, N.J. Retired managing partner of Kwasha Lipton. Husband of Ellen Corbett. Calling Wednesday 6 to 9 & Thursday 9 AM to 10:45. Funeral Mass celebrated 11 AM Thursday. All at St. Ignatius Church, Yardley, PA. Contributions to the Monastery of St. Clare, 142 Hollywood Avenue, Bronx, New York 10465.

title: 'Psycho' at Radio City
description: Alfred Hitchcock's classic thriller ''Psycho,'' starring Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh, will lead off the second annual Radio City Film Festival tonight at 8 at Radio City Music Hall. The five-day festival program, presented by Radio City Productions and Universal Studios, will also include ''Jaws,'' ''American Graffiti,'' ''Fast Times at Richmond High,'' ''National Lampoon's Animal House,'' ''The Blues Brothers'' and ''The Sting.'' All seven films are new prints from the original negatives, and each showing will begin with Woody Woodpecker cartoons and vintage movie trailers. Information: (212) 247-4777.

title: Unfair Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: Presstek comments vaguely about a mysterious settlement.
description: PRESSTEK INC., a company whose stock was one of the fastest climbers in the mid-1990's and is still trading at more than 100 times earnings, disclosed yesterday that it had agreed to settle charges to be brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But it did not say much more than that.

title: New Hospital With 200 Beds Will Replace Queens Center
description: Three crumbling buildings at Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica will be razed next spring to make way for a gleaming, four-wing, five-story building that in about five years will offer two-bed rooms for patients, a sharp departure from the teeming wards now shared by 10 or more people, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GANNETT CO., Arlington, Va., the nationwide news and information company, approved a 2-for-1 stock split and a 5.6 percent increase in its quarterly dividend, to 38 cents.

title: For Victims Of Torture, Hope Can Heal
description: DR. DOUGLAS SHENSON once asked a refugee from the Ivory Coast what was the hardest part about adjusting to life after being tortured by government-sanctioned goons in his homeland. The refugee, who suffered hearing loss and a dislocated shoulder from being whipped and beaten after participating in a pro-democracy demonstration, offered a puzzling reply.

title: Overdue Con Ed Bills May Mean Late Fees
description: Starting this fall, Con Ed customers who let their electric bills go unpaid may pay a price. The Consolidated Edison Company has applied to the New York State Public Service Commission for permission to charge monthly fees of 1.5 percent for late payments by residential customers.

title: No Short Cuts Needed for Polenta
description: Every time I am tempted to buy one of those rolls of ready-made polenta I realize how easy it is to prepare at home. In less than five minutes, I have the finely ground polenta just the way I want it and can stir in any number of ingredients that cannot be added to the ready-cooked roll.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Ameritech's Long-Distance Bid
description: Federal regulators, as expected, today rejected the bid by the Ameritech Corporation to become the first Baby Bell to offer its customers long-distance phone service.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies yesterday about plans to build a hospital in Queens misstated the intentions of the Giuliani administration. Although officials plan to build a new Queens Hospital Center and demolish the existing one, they say they have not given up hope of eventually selling the new building.

title: All Aboard for Previews at Union Pacific
description: THE name of the restaurant is Union Pacific, but do not expect a dining car. Larry Bogdanow, the designer, has opened up the space that was C.T., 111 East 22d Street, with girderlike wooden arches and sweeping vistas. A water curtain defines the entrance, the balcony is more welcoming than before, and a private dining room has been installed upstairs, where there were once offices.

title: Review of GPU Is Ordered
description: Concerned about the number of power failures that GPU Energy's customers have experienced this year, the state Board of Public Utilities ordered a formal review yesterday of the company's ability to cope with destructive storms.

title: Mahwah Mayor Dies, Apparently a Suicide
description: The Mayor of Mahwah, David J. Dwork, was found dead at his desk in Town Hall late Monday night, killed by a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: WASHINGTON

title: 2 Utah Agencies Will Join Forces
description: Two agencies in Salt Lake City -- FJC & N and Williams & Rockwood -- are merging to create what they described as the second-largest shop in Utah, with combined billings of $35 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Once More, Inspired Lunacy
description: The best parts of ''The Unknown Marx Brothers'' are the well-known scenes of the boys doing their shticks in the movies that brought fame to them and laughs to audiences in the 1930's. There's Harpo at the harp, Chico at the piano and Groucho slouching after Margaret Dumont, described here as ''practically the fifth Marx Brother.'' (There's a glimpse of Zeppo, too, but he never counted for much.)

title: A Ceremony in North Korea Breaks More Than Ground
description: In a remote North Korean field surrounded by terraced hillsides, international delegates broke ground today on a remarkable construction project under which Western countries will give North Korea two modern nuclear reactors.

title: Giants' Free Safety Learned the Right Moves From Some Tough Coaches, Like Grandma Wooten
description: When Tito Wooten drives back through his old neighborhood in Goldsboro, N.C., he sees friends who are struggling in harsh 9-to-5 jobs. He sees some still in school. He sees others working on the corner, selling drugs, making a hustle their life's work.

title: Little Change In Bonds as Fed Stays Put
description: Prices of Treasury securities closed mixed yesterday, with a token gain, after the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee decided to keep interest rates unchanged.

title: People
description: * David Henke was named to the new position of executive vice president and creative director on the General Motors corporate account at N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, a unit of MacManus Group. He had been executive vice president and executive creative services director at Temerlin McClain, Irving, Tex., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Trinidad Is All Dressed Up With No One to Fight
description: There isn't much of a future in fighting Felix (Tito) Trinidad Jr. Just ask Maurice Blocker, Hector Camacho, Luis Ramon Campas or Oba Carr. They all met Trinidad's blazing hands. They all went down to defeat.

title: Ordinary People Acting Out Extraordinary Fantasies
description: To describe Jan Svankmajer's film ''Conspirators of Pleasure'' as a live-action cartoon is a little like calling James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' a salty Irish yarn. One of the world's most renowned animators, Mr. Svankmajer, a Czech, is a surrealist visionary whose movies featuring clay figures, marionettes, dolls and eerily life-infused everyday objects have the intensity of fiendishly witty nightmares.

title: Angels Erred on Ban of Phillips
description: In suspending Tony Phillips on Monday after his arrest a week earlier on a charge of cocaine possession, the Anaheim Angels knowingly acted contrary to Major League Baseball's drug policy, an Angels official indicated yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROSLYN
description: LEVY-Roslyn. Beloved wife of the late Morton. Devoted mother of Nancy and Peggy, mother-inlaw of Leonard. Cherished grandmother of Steven and wife Melissa, Elizabeth, David and Darren. She is loved and will be missed by all who knew her. Services 12pm Wednesday 8/20, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Kennedy Killing Made Castro Fear for Cuba, Papers Show
description: Newly released intelligence documents provide evidence that President Fidel Castro of Cuba put his military forces on high alert immediately after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, because he feared that the United States would blame Cuba and launch an invasion in retaliation.

title: A Patisserie and Bistro for Daniel's Pastry Chef
description: WALLS the color of butter. An awning striped in cream. Chocolate mahogany trim. But this is not another antiques shop in a neighborhood filled with them.

title: School Experiment Nears And State Plans for More
description: As the first 13 charter schools prepare to open in New Jersey next month, state education officials are reviewing 37 applications from groups who want to start more of the independent, experimental public schools in 1998.

title: Italian Separatist Picks the Wrong Target: Pope John Paul
description: Umberto Bossi, leader of Italy's separatist Northern League and a past master of the mid-summer, headline-grabbing scandal, has done it again.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE LETS RATES STAND
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, continuing a remarkable economic experiment in which the central bank has kept interest rates low despite shrinking unemployment and unusually strong economic growth.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFTHAL, LEO
description: KAUFTHAL-Leo. The Olive Society extends it heartfelt sympathy to our dear friends, Ilan Kaufthal and his wife, Linda, and to Uri Kaufthal and his wife, Judy, upon the passing of their father. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Edith, and to his grandchildren. His righteousness is reflected in his children and grandchildren, in their achievements and their good deeds. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz, Jack Nash, Chairman Ludwig Bravmann, President

title: Man Indicted in Slaying Of a Jogging Firefighter
description: Eric Calvin, one of two Long Island men charged in the fatal shooting of an off-duty New York City firefighter as he jogged on a high school track near his home in Centereach, was indicted yesterday by a Suffolk County grand jury.

title: Two Say It's Time the Incumbent Left
description: She was the first black woman elected to the City Council, and in her 23 years in office, Mary Pinkett has come to be seen as a political fixture in central Brooklyn and in the Council itself.

title: For the Mets, A Melting Pot Celebration
description: WHEN the Mets started promoting their current homestand as a celebration of various ethnic groups, calling it International Week, it underscored that team's recognition of its residence in America's most diverse urban melting pot.

title: Jeers Sting Mir Mission Control, Which Bemoans a Money Pinch
description: After enduring six months in which Russia's Mir space station has been savaged by folly and tortured by fate, the can-do face of Mission Control finally cracked today.

title: Toyota Said to Have Plan to Bolster Profit
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation plans to almost double its profitability by early next decade by eliminating less-lucrative models in Japan and increasing the efficiency of its overseas plants, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday. Toyota plans to raise operating profit as a percentage of consolidated sales to 9 percent by early in the next decade from 5.4 percent in the year ended March 31, Keith Truelove, a company spokesman, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, MARY JEANNE
description: HARRIS-Mary Jeanne. Of Brookville, L.I. on August 19, 1997. Beloved wife of Henry U. Harris, Jr., mother of Henry U. III (Eleanor M.), Jonathan M. (Cynthia B.) and Peter W. (Harriet R.), sister of Margaret J. Crump, grandmother of nine. Funeral Mass St. Paul the Apostle RC Church, Brookville, on Saturday, August 23, at 11 AM. Interment private. Box 100, Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. 11724 or the Garden Club of America, 596 Madison Avenue, NYC 10022.

description: A COUPLE of characters who once relentlessly mocked all things Canadian are back, selling Canadian beer to Americans.

description: Matt O'Dwyer knows who Wally Pipp was, and he is quickly learning more about Bill Parcells as well. That may be why O'Dwyer, who missed last Saturday's exhibition game against the Giants with a painful sprained ankle, insisted today: ''It's O.K. It's better. I'll play.''

title: Rangers Acquire Purinton
description: The Rangers added a defensemen yesterday when they signed DALE PURINTON to a contract. Terms were not disclosed. Purinton, 20 years old, is 6 feet 2 inches and 195 pounds. He had 6 goals, 26 assists and 254 penalty minutes last season in 51 games with Lethbridge of the Western Canadian Junior Hockey League.

title: Personal Health
description: WOMEN of a certain age are justifiably confused. One day they hear that taking postmenopausal estrogen may cut their risk of Alzheimer's disease by more than 50 percent. The very next day, another study links the long-term use of postmenopausal hormones to a 50 percent decline in deaths from heart disease but also a 43 percent increase in breast-cancer deaths.

description: NOT long ago Dixie Redmond thought every tomato was red and round and hard as a baseball.

description: A week ago, while negotiating with his star center Chris Gratton, Tampa Bay General Manager Phil Esposito compared their dealings to a card game.

title: Wine Talk
description: NOT many years ago, the Far East was a booming market for Cognac and wine was mostly an afterthought. Since then, Asia has become the newest market, and potentially one of the most lucrative, for fine wine, apparently at Cognac's expense. Cognac is in trouble around the world, but particularly in the Far East.

description: To the Editor:

title: Without Surprise, Dell Posts Results That Beat Forecasts
description: The Dell Computer Corporation reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates as it continued to take market share away from other personal computer manufacturers. Dell said its unit shipments had grown at four times the industry average.

title: Love Vs. Truth
description: Is the prospect of a rich, loving relationship with another person so desirable that I will overlook that person's disagreements with me on ideas that are important to me? Or will I stick to my guns, defending my truth, even if the relationship founders as a result?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARNELL, MARGARET
description: DARNELL-Margaret. On August 18, 1997. Loving friend & neighbor. Will be missed by many. Visiting Thursday, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Ridge Chapels, 405 91st Street, Brooklyn, New York. Mass of Christian burial Friday, 10 AM, at St. Charles Borromeo R.C. Church, interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON ELM, H. WALTER
description: Von ELM-H. Walter. Age 82, died peacefully on Sunday August 17 at Calvary Hospital in The Bronx, New York after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn, New York on March 19, 1915, he was the son of the late Margaret and Henry Von Elm, who was former President and Chairman of the Board of The Manufacturers Trust Company. He was graduated from the Choate School and Princeton University, Class of 1937. During World War II he served in the South Pacific as a Captain in the Army Air Corp. He spent his career in banking and retired as a Vice President of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. He was a member of The Everglades Club, The Cap and Gown Club at Princeton, The Princeton Club of New York and the University Club in New York, where he resided for many years. Mr Von Elm is survived by a sister Dorothy Putnam, of East Hampton, New York, a brother Charles Von Elm, of Forest Hills, New York, three nieces and two nephews. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, August 28 at 5:30 P.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Princeton University.

title: Cabdrivers Pass Up Fares in Protest Against Tickets
description: Leaving a trail of confused curbside customers in their wake, several hundred yellow cabs streamed past fares and down Broadway yesterday afternoon, protesting the Giuliani administration's stepped-up enforcement of taxi regulations and demanding health benefits from the city.

title: Safety Board Faults Airline and F.A.A. in Valujet Crash
description: A fire begun and nourished by oxygen generators was the cause of the crash of a Valujet plane in the Everglades 15 months ago, but ultimately the accident, which killed all 110 people aboard, occurred because of supervisory failures by the airline and by the Federal Aviation Administration, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Santa Claus is coming to town today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, KAREN I. (NEE BERNHARD)
description: MEYER-Karen I. (nee Bernhard). Beloved wife of Robert Meyer, daughter of Helen Albert Bernhard and Henry P. Bernhard, sister of Eric, Lisa and David. Passed away August 16, 1997. Karen was a graduate of Union College and Council Member of the Stone Scholastic Academy of Chicago. Memorial services will be held at 11 A.M., Saturday, August 23, at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Save A Life Foundation, 15 Commerce Street, Grays Lake, IL. 60003.

title: Stocks Rise, Continuing A Rebound
description: Stocks continued to recover from their recent slide yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed more than 100 points for the second consecutive session and most major market indexes posted gains of 1.5 percent or more.

title: Guerrillas Rain Rockets on Israel; Injuries Are Minor
description: Islamic guerrillas fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel today to avenge a deadly attack on Monday by militiamen aligned with Israel, but Israel said it was not preparing immediate retaliation.

title: Karros Spoils Bohanon's Big Night
description: In many ways, it was a career night for Brian Bohanon. In a sense, it was kind of a star-crossed one as well.

title: McCrimmon Joins Isles as Aide
description: The Islanders hired a former National Hockey League defenseman, BRAD McCRIMMON, as an assistant coach yesterday, reuniting him with MIKE MILBURY, the Islanders' general manager, who played with McCrimmon in Boston from 1979 through 1982. McCrimmon, 38, will join a fellow assistant, WAYNE FLEMING, on Coach RICK BOWNESS's staff. An 18-year N.H.L. veteran, McCrimmon retired after last season, during which he played 37 games with the Phoenix Coyotes, getting a goal, five assists and 18 penalty minutes. He won a Stanley Cup title with Calgary in 1989.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What's happening to us right now in terms of a downturn we have to deal with is going to happen to colleges in general at some point. Let's face it, bull markets eventually turn into bear markets.''

title: 21 at Repair Shop Arrested in Thefts of Air Bags and Auto Parts
description: After a four-and-a-half-month investigation, the New York Police Department's air bag theft task force raided a Brooklyn automotive shop yesterday morning and arrested 21 people who were charged with possessing stolen property, the police said.

title: U.P.S. SAYS FEARS OF BIGGER LOSSES MADE IT CUT DEAL
description: As 185,000 teamsters prepared to return to work at the United Parcel Service, company officials acknowledged today that fears of hundreds of millions of dollars in additional losses pushed them to back off a long-held demand on pensions during marathon talks on Monday, helping end the 15-day strike.

title: Ray Case Is Delayed by Turf War Between Judges in Tennessee
description: A Tennessee court late Monday night halted all legal proceedings relating to James Earl Ray and scheduled a hearing for next week to clear up legal wrangling over the case by two Shelby County criminal court judges.

title: Task Force Members Appointed by Mayor
description: Here are the people appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to a task force to improve relations between the police and the public.

title: Dollar Rises Again vs. Mark On Bundesbank Rate Decision
description: The dollar rose against the German mark yesterday for a second consecutive day after the Bundesbank, the German central bank, left an interest rate unchanged. The dollar also benefited from a strong recovery in United States stocks.

title: At 89, Hampton Swings On
description: Lionel Hampton's early set at the Blue Note on Monday night, part of the Panasonic Village Jazz Festival, was characterized by tight, swinging arrangements from a 16-piece band. He grabbed every opportunity for humor, despite his recent troubles.

title: Offered Its Own Voice, Wales Clears Its Throat
description: Listen to a British weather report, and ''England and Wales'' merge mellifluously into a single place. Pick up a Government social services document, and the cover will often present the two countries as one.

title: More executives on the road are taking advantage of spas to help relieve stress.
description: UNDER stress and often overweight, businessmen on the road are carving out extra time for visits to spas -- at hotels, resorts and retreats -- in record numbers.

title: Europe Floor Deal Approved by U.S.
description: Tarkett A.G. said today that the Federal Trade Commission had approved its plan to buy the floor-covering business of the French plastics maker, Sommer Allibert S.A., leaving only German antitrust authorities to clear the purchase.

title: The Pop Life
description: Eternal Recurrence

title: Kelly Clings to Slim Hopes for Infant Son
description: Hunter James Kelly was born last Valentine's Day on his famous father's 37th birthday. Jim Kelly heard how lucky he was to have a son so inextricably linked to him. But Hunter was not healthy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, JAMES F.
description: O'DONNELL-James F. Director of Corporate Communications for The Hearst Corporation, died on Saturday, Aug. 16, at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, MA., after a long fight with cancer. The communication plans he developed helped to unify Hearst's 100plus businesses. We appreciate Jim's commitment and contribution to the Company he cared about so much. We will all miss him. Jim was a decorated veteran of the Vietnam War, receiving a Bronze Star and the U.S. Army Commendation Medal. Jim was a native of Boston, MA., a graduate of Boston college (1965), and a longtime resident of Manhattan. He is survived by his parents, a sister, two brothers and nephews and nieces. Private funeral services were held August 19 in West Roxbury, Mass. A remembrance may be donated to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund of New York, 1011 First Avenue, New York, New York 10022, (212) 753-8583. From all his many friends at The Hearst Corporation

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAFFLE, JIMMY
description: WAFFLE-Jimmy. August 19, 1996. No day passes without cherished thoughts of you. I miss you terribly. Until next time, love, Ed.

title: Parolee Is Charged in Rape
description: A New Brunswick man who was recently paroled from prison has been charged with raping a 26-year-old Rutgers University student at knifepoint and nearly choking her to death, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Indonesia Considers Buying Radar Balloon to Patrol Gas Field
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesia is discussing the purchase of a long-range U.S. radar balloon to use with newly acquired reconnaissance aircraft to protect its giant Natuna gas field in the South China Sea.

title: Strained Loyalties Are Likely To Endure
description: For many small businesses, going back to United Parcel Service is a bit like jump-starting a romance. There is a mutual need that never went away, even during the separation, but things may never be quite the same again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MOTHER TERESA and her Missionaries of Charity have distanced themselves from a film about her life that is to be broadcast on the Family Channel on Oct. 5.

title: There's More To Haydn; Much More
description: The music of Haydn that we more or less know -- the many symphonies, string quartets, piano sonatas, oratorios, Masses and operas -- might have been enough to fill even his long career. The music that we know hardly at all or only by repute, to which the second weekend of the Bard Music Festival here on the campus of Bard College was largely devoted, makes the business of having been Haydn seem altogether exhausting.

title: State Will Investigate Power Losses by GPU
description: Concerned about the number of power losses that GPU Energy's customers have experienced this year, the State Board of Public Utilities ordered a formal review yesterday of the company's ability to cope with destructive storms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENTIN, LESTER
description: ENTIN-Lester. The Board of Governors and Members of the Boca Rio Golf Club record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed longtime former member, Lester Entin. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family. Boca Rio Golf Club Norman Ricken, President

title: In Mir's Path: Hard Lesson
description: Big rockets can launch warheads as easily as astronauts and throughout the space age have been used interchangeably for such wildly dissimilar jobs. This fact of technological life is one of the main reasons that Washington puts up with the tragicomedy of the Russian Mir space station.

title: G.E. TAKES A 20% EQUITY STAKE IN ADVANCED NMR SYSTEMS
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had paid $5.1 million to Advanced NMR Systems Inc. for two magnetic-resonance imaging businesses and a 20 percent stake in the company. G.E. has been working with Advanced NMR, which is based in Wilmington, Mass., to develop the systems, which take high-resolution pictures that are used to diagnose cancer and other diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, JACK
description: WHITE-Jack, on August 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Ida. Devoted father of Paula and father-in-law of Jeffrey Gaynor. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Jessica, Scott, David, Ilene and Steven.

title: More on the U.P.S. Deal
description: The tentative accord keeps a pension plan tying benefits to the stock market. Workers could start moving packages today, but many businesses will never again depend on a single deliverer. Articles, pages D18-19.

title: Federal Agents Step Up Pressure in Columbia/HCA Investigation
description: Stepping up the pressure on potential witnesses in the criminal investigation of the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation, Federal agents have been making nighttime visits to the homes of some company employees in Florida, trying to persuade them to cooperate with the inquiry and provide evidence to the Government.

title: Rampage in New Hampshire Kills 4 Before Gunman Dies
description: A 67-year-old gunman apparently intent on settling a grudge killed four people in a remote northern New Hampshire town today and wounded four law-enforcement officials, the authorities said. He then led the police on a chase that ended when he was killed in a shootout with about 20 officers.

title: Rank and File's Verdict: A Walkout Well Waged
description: When money for a baby sitter ran out several days ago, Maria Leon, a striking United Parcel Service worker, stood in the rain on the picket line with her 3-year-old son, Adolfo, and nearly wept at her powerlessness.

title: Texaco Buys 20% Stake In Kazakstan Oilfield
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had bought a 20 percent stake in a giant oilfield in Kazakstan being developed by ENI S.p.A. of Italy and British Gas P.L.C., expanding its reserves of crude oil by as much as one-fifth. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Air Force Acts To Cut Stress Among Pilots
description: Worried by reports that the pilots of its jet fighters and other warplanes were being worked too hard, the Air Force said today that it was sharply curtailing the number of major flight competitions and canceling a large training program.

title: ACCUMED SHARES RISE 41% ON NEWS OF F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: Accumed International Inc. shares rose 41 percent yesterday after the company won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its slide-mapping system for Pap smear tests. Shares of the Chicago-based company rose $1.0625, to close at $3.625, making the company's stock the third-biggest percentage gainer on United States markets and one of the 20 most actively traded stocks. Accumed's Trac Cell 2000 system would allow technicians to see an electronic ''map'' of the cellular material on a Pap smear sample, giving them better focus on parts of the sample useful for diagnosis, the company said.

title: Center of Local Power in Capital Resides With Assertive Economist
description: Over lunch recently, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. got the word from the man who has essentially taken over his job, Andrew F. Brimmer, the chairman of the financial control board. Dr. Brimmer said he would gladly approve Mr. Barry's nominees to head the major city agencies, as long as the Mayor picked the right people.

title: Ward Runs a Girls Camp
description: CHARLIE WARD has been crossing the bridge between the controversial end to the Knicks' season last spring and the team's October training camp by not looking back.

title: F.B.I. CONDUCTS RAID ON J.B. OXFORD SECURITIES FIRM
description: F.B.I.raided the headquarters of the J. B. Oxford Holdings Inc. securities firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. yesterday. The agents, who removed file boxes of documents in shopping carts, declined to say why they raided Oxford, which specializes in discount and electronic brokerage services. Thom Mrozek, a spokesman for the United States Attorney in Los Angeles, said two warrants were served on the firm. Oxford stock fell 21.87 cents, to $1.34375, before trading was halted yesterday afternoon. Shares of some companies for which Oxford is the largest trader fell, including Legacy Software Inc., whose shares plunged 75 cents, to $2. J. B. Oxford, which had total assets of $532.5 million on June 30, had mid-year revenue of $33.8 million.

title: Burnum Burnum, 61, Fighter For Australia's Aborigines
description: Burnum Burnum, a battler for the cause of the Aborigines, died on Sunday in his home in the Sydney suburb of Woronora. He was 61.

title: Festival of Black Filmmakers, With 22 Premieres
description: The Urbanworld Film Festival, featuring the work of black American filmmakers, begins today in New York City. Sixteen dramatic feature films and six documentaries will have their world premieres during the festival, with screenings at the Guild 50th Street Theater at 33 West 50th Street.

title: Mets' Blackout Lifted as Talks Progress
description: The blackout of SportsChannel's Mets games on Time Warner's New York City cable television systems that began last Friday was lifted yesterday as the two sides resumed negotiations to resolve a financial dispute.

title: Police Officer From Yonkers Pleads Guilty In Bias Attack
description: A white Yonkers police officer has pleaded guilty to assault in the bias-related beating of a black man last year in Manhattan. Under the terms of a plea bargain, the officer, Robert Clarke, agreed to quit the Yonkers force and never seek work anywhere as a police officer.

title: At Oxford, Dozens of Fish Stories Add Up to a Symposium
description: SOMETHING was fishy at Oxford, and how! For two days in mid-July, some 175 serious foodniks -- scientists, historians, merchants, journalists and cookbook authors -- gathered at St. Antony's College to talk fish, eat fish and sing fish.

title: Prison for Ex-Mayoral Aide
description: The former chief of staff to Mayor Sharpe James of Newark was ordered yesterday to report to a Federal penitentiary within 60 days to begin serving a sentence for bribery, prosecutors said.

title: Retirement Price Too High?
description: Are small municipalities paying too much for the privilege of showing officials the door? In April, the State Commission of Investigation accused Seaside Heights of doling out nearly $500,000 in excessive retirement benefits. Now, the commission has subpoenaed documents from communities around the state to determine whether other municipalities are also overpaying their retirees, local officials said.

title: Pepsico Buys Stake In Turkish Bottler
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that it had purchased an 11.75 percent stake in its Turkish bottler for $40 million.

description: WEISSBERG-Madalyn. On August 16, 1997. Our sincerest condolences to Michael on the loss of his mother. Your friends in the Class of 2000

title: First, Big Spurt in Business And Then a Probable Drop
description: The heavy cardboard shipping boxes packed with dinnerware and patio bird feeders have piled up for two weeks at Louisville Stoneware, awaiting the end of the strike against United Parcel Service. Now that it is over, John Robertson, Stoneware's president, expects U.P.S. trucks to swoop down on his factory this week and carry off the backlog to the retail stores that sell the company's goods.

title: Study Links Substance Abuse to Violence
description: People who do not use illegal drugs but live in households where such drugs are used are 11 times as likely to be killed as those living in drug-free homes, according to a study reported today in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Korean Car Company Entering New York Region in 33 Stores
description: With automobile customers being wooed by discount prices and low-interest financing in one of the most competitive markets in years, a Korean manufacturer, Kia Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it would open 33 dealerships in the New York region this week.

title: My Son's a Chef in Galicia, of All Places
description: COME back with me to a Sunday morning in 1965, when I was awakened from a sound sleep by the piercing screams of my daughter, then 5. I leapt out of bed, flew down the stairs and found her holding her bottom. Her brother, Michael, then 10, looked crestfallen. And scared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, JOHN, CHRISTOPHE

Services will be held at Temple Beth-El, Roxbury Road, Stamford, Connecticut, 12 noon, on Thursday, August 21.

title: Helen Merrill, Theatrical Agent, Dies at 79
description: Helen Merrill, a strong-willed and influential theatrical agent who advanced the careers of many of the most imaginative playwrights, directors and designers in the American theater, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 79 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Restaurateurs Rediscover the Village: Just Look at Cornelia Street's Revival
description: AS restaurants in many parts of Manhattan have become expensive showcases for star chefs and star customers, Greenwich Village is going its own way, as usual. Culinary entrepreneurs -- often young and richer in talent than money -- are rediscovering the Village, for generations a haven for creative New Yorkers.

title: Corrections
