They are the Shawangunk Mountains, not the Catskills.

title: 51st Birthday Is Carefree For Clinton
description: A year ago thousands of people paid a total of $10 million to the Democrats for the privilege of celebrating President Clinton's 50th birthday with him, or of merely watching the celebration by satellite from remote bashes across the country.

description: CANNO-Irma R. My darling sister Irma has left us. For all of our lifetime we shared our innermost thoughts, our joys and our sorrows. She will be in my thoughts constantly. With deepest love and affection till the end of time. Ricka

title: Four Decades After He Was Blacklisted, A Writer-Producer Finally Gets Credit
description: On a morning in 1953, Alfred Palca's doorman called up to his apartment on East 84th Street in Manhattan and told him that two men were waiting. Mr. Palca, a writer and movie producer, was heading to his set when he stopped in the lobby to meet the men. They turned out to be agents with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and they accused him of being a Communist.

title: National Arts Club Plans Restoration of Its Home
description: Its creatures of stone are turning to dust -- owls and butterflies, turtle doves and bats fallen prey to nearly a dozen decades of city life. But the restoration of the ornate facade of the landmark National Arts Club on Gramercy Park is to begin soon, the first full restoration since the building was designed in the early 1880's as the home of Samuel J. Tilden, a former New York governor and Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: Akil Al-Jundi, Inmate Turned Legal Advocate, Is Dead at 56

He was 56, and the lead plaintiff in the class-action suit to obtain damages for more than 1,200 prisoners beaten, tortured or denied medical care in the aftermath of the inmate uprising of September 1971.

description: Though embarrassed, Washington is bound to the space station, wanting to insure that Moscow does not sell its rockets for warlike uses. Page A11.

description: A woman who was lured to an Inwood apartment with the promise of housecleaning work was instead tortured, sexually abused and starved by her supposed employer, the police said yesterday.

title: Never Mind Literary Quality, or Even Plot: It's the ...
description: Half watching, half dozing, half remembering and three-quarters forgetting, summer after summer we can laze away evenings in the company of great old sleuths like Holmes and Poirot, newer ones from the old country like Dalgleish and Tennison and New York's own up-to-the-minute Simone and Sipowicz. It doesn't much matter that we've already seen most of the episodes, some more than once, on a network, PBS or cable. Whether it's the negligible or unfathomable plots or a case of deteriorating memory, who can recall from one season to the next who did it? Sure, we've definitely been here before, in this English country house or that Lower East Side dump, but the ambiance draws us back.

title: Yanks' Trip Starts Out With a Thud
description: David Wells covered his face with his glove, closed his eyes, then shook his head from side to side. It was only the second inning, but Wells wanted to shake the memories of the first 15 Angel batters out of his mind. It was a performance to forget, but a fiasco that was impossible to forget.

description: In the end, as one of this Caribbean nation's leading intellectuals forlornly put it, ''everything gets framed in terms of race here.''

title: Settlement at U.P.S.
description: Labor leaders exulted yesterday in the settlement of the 15-day strike at United Parcel Service, for understandable reasons. The teamsters won most of their demands -- for wage increases, pension protections and especially for upgrading thousands of jobs from part time to full time. More than that, the union dramatized what it sees as a pernicious trend, the growing reliance of companies on two-tiered work forces in which significant numbers of employees receive lower wages or benefits. It was far from clear, however, that the labor movement will be able to build on its victory to help workers elsewhere who have felt left out by the extraordinary economic boom of recent years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about counterfeiters who use computers reversed the descriptions of the $50 and $100 bills. A portrait of Ulysses S. Grant appears on the $50 bill and of Benjamin Franklin on the $100.

title: Premature Praise for Welfare Reform
description: President Clinton, citing plummeting welfare rolls, has proclaimed last year's controversial reform of the welfare laws a smashing success. The numbers are indeed startling. But as our colleague John Broder noted in Sunday's Times, it is risky to draw categorical conclusions from a single statistic. There may be other reasons for the decline besides the law, and it is far from clear that people have moved from welfare to work in significant numbers. Finally, the rosy numbers tend to hide the law's darker potential.

title: 2 Spanking Studies Indicate Parents Should Be Cautious
description: FOR years, some doctors' organizations have opposed spanking because of research linking it to all sorts of problems in children, including aggressiveness and delinquency. But this line of thinking did not square with reality as many parents saw it. After all, they argued, nearly everyone they knew had been spanked, and most of them turned out all right.

description: Retailers of very different stripes -- Home Depot, Dayton Hudson and Tiffany -- reported second-quarter earnings yesterday that surpassed Wall Street's expectations.

title: Teamsters, Not Company, Will Reap Benefits of Bull Market
description: The teamsters' tentative settlement with the United Parcel Service maintains a pension plan in which the benefits of the rising stock market flow to workers through increased retirement benefits instead of to the company through lower costs.

title: Injuries Add to Call for Safe Infant Walkers
description: DOCTORS and consumer advocates have long sought to ban baby walkers because they cause more injuries than any other children's product. The Government has tried to solve the problem through optional warning labels and public education campaigns, but a new study concludes those efforts are ineffective.

title: Watching the Sweatshops
description: American public concern about offshore apparel factories has swelled to the point where the White House has intervened, and some clothing and sneaker companies are now trying to improve life for their overseas workers. This year Liz Claiborne will begin opening its contractors' factories in Guatemala to local monitors proposed by Guatemalan human rights, church and labor groups. The company has been a leader in efforts to better factory conditions in the third world. Its use of independent local monitors is an unusually serious approach to the problem of assuring that companies deliver.

title: Rarities From Italy And Mozart
description: The Italian chamber ensemble I Musici, now 45 years old, did pioneering work during the Baroque revival of the 1950's and has made a specialty of reviving obscure Italian composers of the 17th through early 19th centuries. Record collectors know this ensemble well, and it has toured the United States many times; but it did not get around to making its Mostly Mozart debut until Monday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. For the occasion, this ensemble of 12 players (11 strings and a harpsichordist) offered a diplomatic compromise, with Italian rarities and more typical Mostly Mozart fare in roughly equal quantity.

title: After Lutherans Vote, Local Ties May Be Strongest
description: If a message can be discerned from a confusing sequence of conflicting votes here this week by the nation's largest Lutheran denomination, it is that Protestants remain inclined to embrace unity but sometimes disagree whether that unity is best pursued, or even necessary, at the national level.

title: INVESTMENT FIRM SAID TO BE IN TALKS WITH LONDON GLOBAL
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, a unit of the Equitable Companies, was in talks to acquire London Global Securities, an international securities lending firm, for about $:100 million ($160 million), British newspapers reported yesterday. Spokesmen for the companies declined to comment on the reports. A takeover of London Global would be the second purchase in Britain for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette this year as the investment bank, traditionally focused on the United States, expands its international operations. In January, the company bought the Phoenix Securities merger advisory firm. London Global is owned by Paloma Partners L.L.C., a New York-based limited partnership.

title: AMOCO AND YPF FORM JOINT U.S. GAS VENTURE
description: The Amoco Corporation and YPF S.A. of Buenos Aires, Argentina's biggest oil company, said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to own and operate 1 trillion cubic feet of natural gas reserves in the Texas panhandle and western Oklahoma. The assets of the new company, known as Crescendo Resources L.P., include about 2,000 gas producing wells and two gas processing plants with a combined capacity of 230 million cubic feet of gas a day. YPF will own 64 percent of Crescendo through Midgard Energy Company, a unit of YPF's Maxus Energy Corporation. Amoco will own 36 percent of Crescendo and have an option to increase its participation through additional asset contributions.

title: Charges of Bank-Loan Fraud
description: A Toms River developer was charged yesterday with defrauding a bank in Somers Point of $7 million in land and construction loans.

title: IMPERIAL OIL TO SELL 3 CANADIAN FIELDS
description: Imperial Oil Ltd. said yesterday that it would sell three of the largest and most prolific oilfields in Canada to the Pengrowth Gas Corporation for $595 million ($426.9 million American). The fields, at Judy Creek and Swan Hills, Alberta, produce 21,000 barrels of oil and 25 million cubic feet of natural gas daily. Imperial will receive a 2.5 percent royalty in future production. Imperial, Canada's largest oil company, is selling many of its conventional oil and gas properties in western Canada to focus on producing heavy oil from its land holdings in northwest Alberta.

title: Defying Israel, Arafat Embraces Islamic Militants

And the official said it was American officials, not specifically C.I.A. aides, who were dismayed that the Palestinians had released some of the suspects from detention.

title: Three Latin Whistle-Blowers
description: For the last three weeks, Gen. Jose Francisco Gallardo has been in solitary confinement in a Mexican military barracks. He is now in his fourth year of prison after accusing soldiers of involvement in killings, torture and drug deals. Senior officers in Peru and Colombia have also been imprisoned or disciplined for blowing the whistle on military abuses. The reprisals against them reveal the true character of three Governments that claim to protect human rights.

title: Lessons of the Valujet Disaster
description: Fifteen months ago a Valujet DC-9 just out of Miami Airport went down in flames in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 people aboard. The crash, followed by the grim search through the swamps for victims' remains, left the public questioning the safety of new low-cost airlines like Valujet and the adequacy of Federal oversight. The final report of the National Transportation Safety Board's inquiry, issued Tuesday, sets forth a disturbing record of sloppiness and complacency involving the airline, its subcontractors and government agencies.

title: Two Colombian Cabinet Ministers Forced Out in New Scandal
description: Two Cabinet ministers have been forced to resign after they were secretly recorded discussing awarding radio frequencies to friends of the administration of President Ernest Samper. The frequencies were supposed to be up for public auction.

title: A Sixth Witness Denounces Sergeant Major
description: The last of six women who have accused the Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier of sexual misconduct angrily pointed her finger at him today as she testified that she had reported his advances because ''he's up at the Pentagon -- he's my superior.''

title: Jets' Starting Lineup Still a Work in Progress
description: After more than a month of training camp and a 3-0 exhibition record, the Jets continue to sort out their starters. Based in part on what happens against Tampa Bay in their final exhibition game on Friday night, the Jets could soon be making changes at six starting positions -- four of them on defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTAGNO, PETTIT, MARION MACDONALD CASTAGNO, PETTIT, M.D.
description: CASTAGNO - PETTIT - Marion Macdonald Castagno-Pettit, M.D., of West Hartford, CT., wife of James G. Pettit, died on Tuesday (August 19, 1997) at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center. She was born in West Somerville, MA, the youngest daughter of the late Angus A. and Catharine Boland Macdonald. She graduated from Boston University and earned her medical degree from Boston University School of Medicine. She completed a rotating internship and residency in ophthalmology at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn, NY, where she also held a teaching fellowship. She practiced ophthalmology in Brooklyn and headed the Eye Clinic at the Metropolitan Insurance Company for several years before moving to Hartford in 1949; she has lived in West Hartford since 1956. Dr. Castagno-Pettit practiced ophthalmology in Hartford from 1949 until April 1997; she held the distinction of being the first female ophthalmologist to practice in Connecticut, and the first woman to perform surgery at both Hartford Hospital and St. Francis Hospital. For many years she served as editor of The Yearbook of Cancer. She regularly volunteered her services at glaucoma clinics throughout the state. Dr. Castagno-Pettit received numerous honors during her career, including the 1988 Woman of the Year Award from the Greater Hartford Business and Professional Women's Club and the 1989 Columbus Day Humanitarian Award. She was an active member of St. Peter Claver Church in West Hartford, and served on the church's Parish Council. She was a member of the Hartford Jazz Society for many years. Besides her husband, Dr. Castagno-Pettit is survived by a sister, Eleanor J. Macdonald, of Houston, TX; a daughter, Frances R. Castagno of New Britain; five sons; Anthony J. Castagno and his wife Karen, of North Stonington; Dr. Paul C. Castagno and his wife Molly, of Tuscaloosa, AL; Charles M. Castagno, of Laguna Niguel, CA; Richard A. Castagno, of West Hartford; Joseph M. Castagno and his wife Doris, of Woodbury; two stepdaughters, Anne Pettit Conway and her husband Jay, and Mary Pettit Orluk and her husband Lawrence, all of West Hartford; and a stepson, James A. Pettit and his wife Christine, also of West Hartford; she is also survived by eight grandchildren and a greatgranddaughter. She was predeceased by her first husband, Rowe A. Castagno, M.D., & two brothers and two sisters. Calling hours will be today from 4 to 8 P.M. at the Sheehan-Hilborn-Breen Funeral Home, 1084 New Britain Avenue, West Hartford. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 AM, Friday at St. Peter Claver Church, 47 Pleasant St., West Hartford. Interment will follow at Fairview Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Peter Claver Church or to the St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center Foundation, 114 Woodland Street, Hartford, CT. 06105.

title: Spikeless Shoe: Soft on Greens
description: The spikeless golf shoe ''revolution'' is just about over, and it has been declared a winner. It has happened rather quickly, in a game slow to accept changes. For as long as anyone cares to remember, golfers have worn shoes with fairly sharp, pointed metal spikes about one-quarter of an inch long -- 12 to a shoe -- for good traction during the swing and when walking between shots. Until seven years ago, their place in the game was as fixed as the wooden tee and the dimpled ball.

title: KOMAG TO CUT 16% OF ITS U.S. WORK FORCE
description: Komag Inc. said yesterday that it would take a charge of $45 million to $60 million to cut 16 percent, or 350 jobs, of its United States work force and close two plants in Milpitas, Calif., to streamline its manufacturing. The disk drive components maker said it expected to report a loss in the third quarter for trimming its worldwide work force to 4,600 people. The San Jose, Calif.-based company also said it expects weak demand for disk products to result in a ''significant sequential decline'' in revenue from in its record sales of $175.1 million in the second quarter. The company expected to report an operating loss for the third quarter before the restructuring charge because of lower sales.

title: All the Colors of the Rainbow Make a School Contract
description: Ruth Lande Shuman, an Upper East Side industrial designer, wanted to do something positive for the New York City schools. So on a day in 1994 when volunteers were invited to spruce up the schools, she armed herself with 500 gallons of donated paint, recruited 285 volunteers and set out to beautify an East Harlem school by splashing stairwells and hallways with a rainbow of 77 colors.

title: Israel Hits Power Lines to Warn Lebanon
description: Israeli warplanes struck back today at targets in southern Lebanon, including power lines feeding the region's largest city, in an attack that Israel said had been intended to send a clear message to Lebanon's Government.

description: For much of the last month, a pall of haze has shrouded Kuala Lumpur and many other parts of peninsular Malaysia, blotting out the sun and prompting official health warnings.

description: Soybean futures prices plunged yesterday after two of the world's largest grain traders, Cargill Inc. and the Continental Grain Company, unexpectedly delivered new supplies against the expiring contract on the Chicago Board of Trade.

description: State utility regulators signaled today that they intend to lower electric rates for residences and small businesses in New York City and Westchester County by as much as 6 to 7 percent, or about double the savings included in a proposed agreement with the Consolidated Edison Company.

description: A recent series of ethnic attacks along the coast has deepened the sense of political crisis in Kenya and derailed early talks between President Daniel arap Moi and opposition leaders.

title: The rising tide of oil strikes lifts a floating-platform maker.
description: BOUYGUES OFFSHORE S.A., one of a handful of oil service companies benefiting from the global quest for new oil supplies through deep-sea drilling, was already starting to catch analysts' attention. Then on Tuesday, when Elf Aquitaine, the French oil concern, announced a major find off the shore of Angola and its shares surged 5.3 percent to a new high of 721 francs, it lifted Bouygues, one of its suppliers, as well.

title: Education Board Approves Contract With Teacher-Training Institute
description: The Board of Education unanimously approved a $600,000, three-year contract last night with a controversial teacher-training organization, a group that argues that the only obstacles keeping all children from meeting high standards are the low expectations of teachers, parents and the children themselves.

title: As Adelphi Stumbled, Hofstra Inched Onward
description: Ten years ago, both Hofstra University here in Hempstead and Adelphi University two miles away in Garden City were in peril. Both were mid-size commuter schools facing a decline in students -- and certain financial trouble.

title: Court Upholds 'Megan's Law' In Split Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court upheld New Jersey's ''Megan's Law'' today, clearing the way for county prosecutors to begin notifying local residents and community groups next month about certain convicted sex offenders in their neighborhoods. It was the highest Federal court to rule on the constitutionality of community-notification laws, enacted in recent years by almost every state in the nation.

title: New York City Jobs Up by 9,100 in July
description: New York City employment surged higher in July, with 9,100 more jobs than in June. It was the biggest monthly gain since January, and it reversed a short-term trend in which city residents were passed over for jobs in favor of people from the suburbs, according to a report by Alan G. Hevesi, the New York City Comptroller.

title: Leo Jaffe, Hollywood Deal Maker, Dies at 88
description: Leo Jaffe, well known for decades as an influential deal maker in Hollywood and as a philanthropist, died yesterday morning at his home in New York City after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRILL, HELEN
description: MERRILL - Helen. Theatrical agent of distinction died on August 18, 1997 of lung cancer after a brief hospitalization. She was born in Cologne Germany in 1918 and came to the United States in 1939. She is survived by her sister Angelica Merrill Wender of New York City; her brother Hervey C. Merrill of Rochester NY and six nephews and nieces. Funeral services will be private and a memorial service will be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: TALBOTS INC. (TLB,N)
description: Talbots Inc. yesterday reported a loss for its second quarter that was wider than expected as it cleared the shelves of sportswear in a return to its best-selling classic business clothes.

title: Underdog In Bronx Is Wielding Fierce Bark
description: When Fernando Ferrer dropped out of the mayoral race earlier this year to run for re-election as Bronx Borough President, many people assumed that he would face an effortless, uneventful campaign and an easy victory for a third term.

description: The News Corporation has reported disappointing earnings for its most recent quarter, as its movie division was hurt by flops like ''Speed 2'' and ''Volcano'' and as it revamped its struggling HarperCollins publishing unit.

title: GOODYEAR UNIT AGREES TO BUY INDOMAX ASSETS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's Engineered Products unit said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the assets of Indomax C.A., an automotive hose maker in Venezuela, and three affiliates, as it continues its expansion in South America. Terms were not disclosed. Engineered Products operates plants in Brazil, Chile and Mexico, in addition to Venezuela. Goodyear shares rose 6.25 cents to $63.

The Dandy Warhols, Polara and Swoon 23 all reach back to the Velvet Underground's primal art-punk fusion of drone, tune and noise. Around simple structures, they gather resonances and dissonances, making songs throb or ripple or screech.

title: INDUSTRY TO ART: Lights That Paint Like Watercolors
description: ''MOST people just don't get it,'' lamented Ruben Cardenas, the manager at Artemide's SoHo showroom, as he watched customers ignore the company's newest lighting development: a series of programmable lighting machines called Metamorfosi, a technology developed for commercial use. It's a light show in a box, able to fill a room with everything from chilly Arctic sunrises to steamy tropical sunsets. (Nine prominent designers conceived the luminaires, or floor and table lamps.) Iride, the weirdest of the models -- four tippy plexiglass tubes with snaky wires -- was on display, but sunlight obscured its effect. ''Wait, I will show you,'' Mr. Cardenas said, leading the way down to a windowless basement. He waved a remote control, and the white room decomposed into moody hazes -- pink, then orange, then yellow, green and blue. Four halogen lamps, backed by reflectors, are topped by glass filters -- red, green, blue, clear -- working like theatrical gels, the colored film clipped onto stage lights. The remote tells a microprocessor what colors to project and how brightly. It's like painting the wall with watercolor washes, but the fuzzy luminosity makes the room feel more like cloud nine. Prices are $3,600 to $6,800. The showroom is at 46 Greene Street. For information: (212) 925-1588.

title: HALTER AND BOLLINGER TO PURSUE CONTRACTS TOGETHER
description: Halter Marine Group Inc. of Gulfport, Miss., and the privately owned Bollinger Shipyards Inc. of Lockport, La., said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to pursue contracts potentially worth $10 billion to upgrade Coast Guard ships and aircraft. Avondale Industries Inc., Litton Industries Inc. and Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. are also looking to pursue the Coast Guard's contracts, the Bollinger vice president, Marc Stanley, said. The project was announced two months ago and should award three contracts worth $5 million each over the next 12 months, Mr. Stanley said. After 18 months, the Coast Guard will then award one fixed-price contract based on the best performance of the three teams. The guidelines for the 15-year improvement program have not yet been fully defined.

description: In a closed-door meeting here today, Russia put the brakes on a proposal to have an international organization supervise elections that the Bosnia Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, has called in her power struggle with her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic.

title: Keep in Mind
description: ''JAZZ REACH,'' a program introducing children to jazz through the Hip Spot, a transportable jazz club with a slide show , a music ensemble and Phil Schaap of WKCR-FM as Master of Ceremonies. Tomorrow at noon at the Tishman Auditorium at The New School, 66 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 929-5149.

title: A Boy Alone, and 2 Adults With a Lot to Learn
description: The dictum ''It takes a village to raise a child,'' popularized by Hillary Rodham Clinton, has quickly fallen into the category of cliche, perhaps, but it will take on new meaning for anyone who tunes in to ''Northern Lights,'' an eccentric and ultimately winning film starring Diane Keaton and Maury Chaykin.

title: Mideast Alarm Button
description: More than three weeks after a suicide bombing shattered a Jerusalem market, the confrontational stances adopted by Israel and the Palestinians have set in motion a dangerous dynamic.

title: New Deadline in Spano Case
description: The deadline for Federal prosecutors on Long Island to present a grand jury with the bank and wire fraud case against JOHN SPANO, the former Islanders owner, has been extended for two weeks, said GARY BROWN, an Assistant United States Attorney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, ADELINE MARTOCCI DEVINE
description: GAMBLE-Adeline Martocci Devine, 92, died on Wednesday at Morris Hall, Lawrenceville. Wife of the late Eugene J. Devine and the late Robert I. Gamble, she is survived by a daughter, Alice Ann D. Connolly of Pennington, NJ and a son, Eugene J. Devine of Arlington, VA, eight grandchildren, six great-grandchildren. She retired after teaching 39 years at P.S. 71, Pelham Bay, the Bronx. Memorial contributions may be made to Morris Hall P.O. Box 6498, Lawrenceville, New Jersey 08648.

title: Comptroller Says Too Many Officers Are Still Doing Civilian Jobs
description: A $1.4 billion program to take New York City police officers out of offices and put them on the streets came under fire yesterday from the state's auditor, Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who said that much of the spirit behind the taxpayer-financed measure had been subverted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Alfred Palca, a film producer and writer who was blacklisted in the 1950's, referred incorrectly to the credit that will be restored to him for the film ''Go, Man, Go!'' While Mr. Palca wrote and produced the film, only the writing credit is expected to be restored, by the Writers Guild of America.

title: A Misinterpretation Of a Buffett Filing Stings Wells Fargo
description: Shares of Wells Fargo & Company, the large California bank, fell sharply yesterday on word that the company run by Warren Buffett had sold its entire holding of almost 8 percent of Wells Fargo stock. Within an hour, $1.3 billion had been shaved from the bank's market value.

title: Hundley Is Shaking Off Remarks Made by Valentine
description: Bobby Valentine may have been seeking to deflect a little attention from his team's recent swoon. He also may have been trying to rattle Todd Hundley's cage.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi, its solo hopes dashed, says no thanks to a role in the Bell Atlantic chorus.
description: IN another surprising shift in how the competitive telecommunications industry pitches products and services, the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York said yesterday that they had agreed to part ways.

title: $20 Million Invested In Internet Company
description: Demonstrating confidence in New York's fledgling new-media industry, Michael Egan, the chairman and former owner of Alamo Rent-a-Car, invested $20 million last week in Web Genesis, a company that runs a popular Internet site.

title: Acquiring Blazers' Dudley May Be in Knicks' Future
description: Charlotte went out and bought a new starting backcourt, signing David Wesley and Bobby Phills. Miami convinced Terry Mills he was part of its future and Detroit spent a bundle on Brian Williams. With their Eastern Conference playoff rivals adding key pieces, the Knicks realize they must get busy.

title: Rangers Sign Lindbom
description: The Rangers yesterday announced the signing of JOHAN LINDBOM, the 26-year-old left wing who was their fifth choice in last June's entry draft. Terms of the contract were not announced.

description: Fila USA Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its account, with billings estimated at $22 million, at Arnell Group in New York.

title: $25 and Under
description: For the Upper West Side, Azure offers an unusual combination: light, creative, ambitious food served in a friendly, informal dining room. It's the kind of place any neighborhood would want, but it is particularly welcome on this stretch of Amsterdam Avenue, where powerful drinks often seem more important than energetic cooking.

title: Take That, You Evil Computer Genius!
description: Roger Christian, who directed ''Masterminds,'' has won Academy Awards for set decoration (''Star Wars'') and art direction (''Alien''), and so it's no surprise that his teen-age action-adventure film ''Masterminds'' has such snazzy computer graphics. The scenes in which Ozzie Paxton (Vincent Kartheiser), a long-haired 16-year-old cyberwhiz, hacks his way into heavily fortified computer systems make such raids look and sound as viscerally exciting as tilting the world's most sophisticated pinball machine.

title: Yes, the Teamsters Did Get, but They Also Gave
description: The new agreement at the United Parcel Service, hailed by many as an unqualified breakthrough victory for organized labor, includes a number of unpublicized concessions by the teamsters that will help the company hold down the cost of the five-year contract.

description: Suburbia

title: Starrett Cancels Sale
description: The Starrett Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled a deal under which it was to be sold to Jacob A. Frydman for $80.4 million, or $12.25 per share.

title: Field of Late Bloomers Gets Its Shot in Travers
description: Eight colts, none of whom ran in the Triple Crown races, were entered in Saturday's 128th Travers Stakes today with a chance to rewrite the story of this season and its 3-year-old casualties.

title: Norris E. Bradbury, 88, Chief Of Los Alamos Atomic Center
description: Norris Edwin Bradbury, the physicist who reluctantly followed J. Robert Oppenheimer as the director of the nation's first atomic weapons research center and then served longer in the job than anyone else, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Alamos, N.M. He was 88.

title: EL PASO ENERGY TO PAY $39 MILLION FOR PIPELINE COMPANY
description: The El Paso Energy Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Gulf States Gas Pipeline Company for $39 million in cash and stock. Gulf States' main asset is a 175-mile natural-gas-gathering and transmission system in northwest Louisiana. The system collects gas from the field and purifies it before it is put into main pipelines. El Paso Energy, based in Houston, has processing plants and a 500-mile transmission system in northern Louisiana.

title: Embezzler Receiving Pension
description: Despite pleading guilty in 1994 to embezzling $173,000 from his business partners and agreeing to step down as a Superior Court judge in Somerset County, Michael R. Imbriani has been collecting an annual pension of $75,000 for three years.

title: A Faulty Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing Teacher Attitudes
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has won enormous support for nearly all of his initiatives. But eyes rolled this week when the Board of Education approved a $600,000 contract with the Efficacy Institute, a teacher-training organization that says it can raise teacher expectations about students and boost student performance in the process. Critics suggest that idea is too vague to be useful. But data from the New York State Department of Education suggest that changing how teachers view their students -- particularly their poorest students -- is critical to turning around failing schools.

title: New Terms Are Expected In MCI Deal
description: Less than a day after announcing that they might renegotiate their $23.4 billion merger, the MCI Communications Corporation and British Telelecommunications P.L.C. are expected to announce new, reduced terms by which the British company will acquire MCI, executives with knowledge of the negotiations said last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDEN, IRVING
description: FIELDEN-Irving. Age 81. Died on August 20, 1997. Attorney and WWII War Crimes Prosecutor. A man of great wisdom, intellect, compassion and integrity. Beloved husband of Natalie. Loving father of Harold & Peggy, Barbara, and Leslie & Jeffry. Cherished brotherin-law of Lionel Martin & Adrienne Hunter. Service today at 11 A.M., Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Free Retailing Advice, Indirectly From Macy's
description: Michael Feder spent 37 years as a manager and executive at Macy's. Now, a year after retiring as a vice president, he has returned to retailing, but at the other end of the industry spectrum: the small, independent shops selling clothing, shoes, electronics or food from dozens of storefronts in midtown Manhattan.

title: Knight-Ridder Near Sale of Unit
description: M.A.I.D. P.L.C., a British on-line provider of business information, said today that it was close to acquiring Knight-Ridder Information Inc. for what analysts said would be as much as $500 million.

title: The White House Turnstile
description: How is the Clinton White House like a subway? According to Johnny Chung, fund-raiser extraordinaire for the Democrats last year, you put in coins to open the gates. That cynical comment was part of a revealing interview this week with Tom Brokaw of NBC News, in which Mr. Chung seemed to live up to his reputation as a ''hustler,'' the term that National Security Council officials used to describe him when they were trying to keep him out. Mr. Chung nonetheless visited the White House nearly 50 times because he arranged for almost $400,000 in party donations, and he told Mr. Brokaw he paid the money because that is how the system worked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, PAUL
description: RUDOLPH-Paul. The Dean, faculty, students, alumni/ae and staff of the Harvard University Graduate School of Design extend their condolences to the family of Paul Rudolph, eminent architect and alumnus. Peter G. Rowe, Dean, Faculty of Design

title: Looking for the Hit Buried in the Beat
description: OMC was too trendy for its own good when it performed on Wednesday night at the Supper Club. Its hit song, ''How Bizarre'' (Mercury), has become ubiquitous on radio stations in the United States, two years after it was released in OMC's native New Zealand.

title: U.S. TELLING RUSSIA TO BAR AID TO IRAN BY ARMS EXPERTS
description: The Clinton Administration has been quietly pressing Russia for most of this year to stop Russian scientists and military institutes from helping Iran develop a new ballistic missile that could reach Israel, Saudi Arabia and American troops in the Persian Gulf, senior Administration officials say.

title: A Little Girl So Perky and Powerful
description: Independent spirit and an unconventional approach to life get a boost in the pleasant new animated film ''Pippi Longstocking.''

title: Celibacy and Infidelity in Conspiracy
description: ''Fire'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: Giants Jockey for Jobs As Packers Polish Up
description: For the Green Bay Packers, undefeated in the preseason and poised for another championship run, tonight's exhibition game against the Giants is a final exercise for a finely tuned machine.

title: The A.M.A.'s Reversal
description: The American Medical Association is wisely trying to back out of a contract to endorse health products made by the Sunbeam Corporation in exchange for fees. Sunbeam is balking, but the A.M.A. is right to break an ill-conceived deal that would have done more to advance the commercial interests of the A.M.A. and Sunbeam than consumer health interests.

title: Low Funds Force Challenger From Public Advocate's Race
description: Citing a severe shortage in campaign contributions, Assemblyman Roger L. Green said yesterday that he would withdraw from the race to be New York City's Public Advocate, leaving the incumbent, Mark J. Green, unopposed in next month's Democratic primary.

title: Everyone's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight Over Car Dealerships Takes a Turn for the Nasty
description: Dishing dirt has turned into throwing mud in the very public spat between the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Honda Motor Company on the one hand and H. Wayne Huizenga's Republic Industries on the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ROBERT
description: CAMPBELL-Robert. On August 19, 1997. Son of Virginia Lee Campbell of Birmingham, Michigan. Brother of Richard Campbell of New York, New York. Services to be announced at a later date. Donations to The American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Reliance Group to Sell Title Insurance Units
description: The Lawyers Title Corporation of Richmond said yesterday that it was buying the title insurance companies of Reliance Group Holdings Inc. for $478 million in cash and stock.

title: Giuliani Details His State Bill For Takeover Of City Airports
description: Stepping up his campaign against the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani unveiled a state bill yesterday to take control of La Guardia and Kennedy Airports away from the agency and give it to the city.

title: INTEGRATED HEALTH SERVICES TO ACQUIRE CORAM UNIT
description: The Coram Healthcare Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its lithotripsy business to Integrated Health Services Inc. for $130 million in cash and the assumption of debt. Under the agreement, Integrated Health, a home health care provider, will buy Coram's interests in lithotripsy partnerships and related assets. Lithotripsy is a noninvasive medical procedure that uses shock waves to dissolve kidney stones. Coram, also a home health care company, said it would use the proceeds to reduce debt. Coram, based in Denver, had 1996 revenue of $522 million. Integrated Health, based in Owings Mills, Md., had 1996 revenue of $1.43 billion.

title: Gene of Mideast Ancestor May Link 4 Disparate Peoples
description: Several thousand years ago, somewhere in the Middle East, there lived a person who bequeathed a particular gene to many present-day descendants. But these millions of now distant relatives could not convincingly be called one big happy family. They include Jews, Arabs, Turks and Armenians.

title: Building a Time Warp With a Birthday Bicycle
description: ''Leave It to Beaver'' is the sort of movie that could be described as good clean fun if it happened to be good or fun.

title: Foster Care Workers Forbidden To Oppose City Agency in Court
description: The Administration for Children's Services has forbidden caseworkers to publicly oppose the city's decisions on foster care cases in Family Court and administrative hearings, city officials said yesterday.

title: Texas Jail Video Puts Transfer Programs in Doubt
description: It started out a few years ago as an unlikely economic development program: parlaying an excess of jail cells into out-of-state payments. Inmates were sent from states as far away as Hawaii and Massachusetts, and 5,500 of them are now lodged in county jails across Texas.

title: TIDEWATER SAYS IT MAY SELL COMPRESSION OPERATION
description: Tidewater Inc. said yesterday that it would consider ways to shed its natural gas compression unit to focus on its primary business of providing vessels for the offshore energy industry. The unit, Tidewater Compression Service, owns about 2,900 natural gas compressors that are used primarily to increase the pressure of gas moving through pipelines. The unit also makes compressor systems and provides related parts to customers. In the year that ended on March 31, the compression unit had operating profit of $12.4 million on revenue of $112.6 million. Tidewater, based in New Orleans, has hired Merrill Lynch & Company and Simmons & Company International to advise it on options for the compression business.

title: Clinton Met Campaign Donor To Discuss a Trade Dispute
description: The White House acknowledged today that President Clinton met last summer with the chairman of the Federal Express Corporation, whose company was a major donor to Democrats and Republicans in last year's campaign and who was seeking a far tougher stance against Japan in a long-running trade dispute involving air cargo.

title: Casino Worker Electrocuted
description: A Turnersville man was electrocuted on Wednesday while working on a casino expansion, The Associated Press reported.

title: Surgery for Abandoned Baby
description: The newborn baby left in a toilet at an Atlantic City bus terminal last month is scheduled to undergo surgery today so that doctors can insert a feeding tube into his stomach.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 11 about the internment of Italians in Montana during World War II referred incorrectly to a 75-year-old Italian citizen who was released from detention on the day officials learned that his son, an Italian-American serviceman, had been killed in a bombing run over Italy. The detainee was not Jerre Mangione, an American writer who described the incident in a history of the period.

title: Strutting Vintage Stuff And Selling It, Too
description: One weekend each August, this beautiful coastal area can lay claim to some of the most desirable and expensive automobiles in the world. Like a three-day summer camp for car fanatics, the Monterey Historic Weekend, held Aug. 15-17 this year, encompasses many types of classic-car activities, from vintage racing at the Laguna Seca race track to wallet racing at the auctions put on by Christie's auction house and the Rick Cole Auction Company.

title: Keeping Pace In a Marathon Of Playgoing
description: WAS a human being meant to be this entertained? One hundred seventy-five plays, monologues, performance pieces, musicals. One hundred seventy-five journeys of self-discovery, contemporary fairy tales, anti-religious screeds, re-examinations of the classics, glib television parodies, irony-laden stand-up acts, abstract movement exhibitions, all performed in museum basements, converted storefronts, second-floor walk-ups, actual theaters and even a car, in every corner of the Lower East Side.

title: Call for a Clean Campaign
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey urged Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to make a pact with him to avoid personal attacks for the remainder of the gubernatorial campaign.

title: Record School Enrollments, Now and Ahead
description: The historic wave of students jamming the nation's classrooms is moving from the elementary schools to the high schools, bringing with it increased costs of new schools, added problems in finding qualified teachers and potentially enormous higher education costs.

title: No Tiny Achievement on the Line for Lopez
description: Don King calls Ricardo Lopez, the World Boxing Council strawweight champion, whom he promotes, the ''terror of the East'' because over the last decade he has dominated a division in boxing that is typically controlled by fighters from the Far East.

title: Despite New AIDS Drugs, Many Still Lose the Battle

description: His name has been invoked by street protesters and mayoral candidates. He has been the focus of outraged editorials and national news coverage. For many immigrant and minority New Yorkers, he is the latest victim of a criminal-justice system that is too often a foe, not a protector.

title: Caffeinated Drinks Catering to Excitable Boys and Girls
description: They can get you ''high'' or give you a quick ''lift.'' Some people just want them for the ''buzz'' or the sheer pleasure of getting a ''rush,'' while others are lured by the possibility of heightening their sexual drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGHT, RUSSELL BACON
description: WIGHT-Russell Bacon, 90, of 125B Heritage Village, Southbury, CT, and Venice, FL, on August 18, 1997. Mr. Wight was born August 14, 1907, in Washington, D.C. Son of Frederick L. & Charlotte L. Bacon Wight. Mr. Wight graduated from the Mount Hermon School in 1931, from Yale College in 1935, and received a Master's of Arts degree in 1951 from Harvard University. He taught history for thirteen years at The Hill School, became director of the Edwin Gould Foundation's Lakeside School, and later became the executive director of the Foundation, retiring in 1969. An army veteran of World War II, he served in the Office of Strategic Services. He and his wife moved to Heritage Village in 1974 from Moorestown, New Jersey. He served as director and trustee of Condo 19, before moving in 1978 to Condo 4, where he served as director and president. Loving husband of 61 years to Jean H. Volk Wight. Father of Russell B. Wight Jr. of Boca Raton, FL., Susan Fabian of Marlborough, CT.; grandfather of two. All services private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Heritage Village Ambulance Association, PO Box 2045, Southbury, CT. 06488.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fall a Bit on the Big Board
description: In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping to profit by buying them back at lower prices. If the share price rises, the short seller faces a loss. Open positions represent shares borrowed and sold but not yet bought back by the seller.

title: More Talk on Radio: Music to Your Ears?
description: Another sports talk radio station is all we need here. One with no game broadcasts. Just 24 hours of nonstop prattling, whining, screaming and babbling.

description: After spending April 10, 1993, buying and testing bullets and silencers, Janusz Walus drove by Chris Hani's house, as he had done at least three times before, just for ''reconnaissance'' purposes. Although he intended eventually to kill Mr. Hani, one of this country's most popular black leaders, he still lacked a special ammunition to be used with the silencer.

title: Serious Politics as Rollicking Fun
description: The new albums by Rage Against the Machine and the Wu-Tang Clan contain vast amounts of information. In Rage's case, anti-establishment positions feed the weight of hip-hop beats and the stun-power of punk guitar; the band strategically uses lyrics and images to support various leftist causes. Wu-Tang has built a cosmology, a millenarian kit bag of kung-fu dialogue, Nation of Islam rhetoric, grim street realism; nine members with individual character traits splinter off from the core philosophy.

title: Ray Hyman, 86, Saxophonist and Inventor
description: Ray Hyman, a musician and inventor, died on Aug. 15 at his home in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. He was 86.

title: GATX WILL BUY SOME PITNEY BOWES ASSETS
description: Pitney Bowes Inc. will sell some of the assets it leases to other companies to the GATX Corporation of Chicago for $460 million in cash as part of the company's plan to raise $1 billion to buy back shares. The companies will also create a joint venture that will get from Pitney Bowes about $800 million in expensive assets like aircraft that are rented to other companies. Pitney Bowes plans to borrow about $600 million against the joint venture's assets. Pitney Bowes, based in Stamford, Conn., also said its board had increased a share-buyback program by 3.2 million shares, to 12.4 million shares. Its shares rose $1.50, to $78.50, while GATX fell 18.75 cents, to $61.125.

title: A Warning to Dr. Karadzic

Cleveland-based Phonetel was to have paid $12.85 a share for Communication Central of Roswell, Ga., and to have assumed $70 million in debt. Communication Central's stock fell $1 a share yesterday, to $8.25. Communications Central operates 26,000 pay telephones and inmate phones. Phonetel owns about 41,000 public pay phones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBUD, MERRIL, MD.
description: EISENBUD-Merril, MD. The trustees, faculty and staff of New York University Medical Center deeply mourn the loss of Merril Eisenbud, age 82, Professor Emeritus of Environmental Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Eisenbud received international attention for his work on atomic radiation. In the 1960s, he pioneered the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission's system for monitoring radioactive fallout from nuclear tests. He was known for his significant work on environmental health. Dr. Eisenbud earned his bachelor's degree in electrical engineering at NYU. In 1968, he led New York City's newly created Environmental Protection Administration, under Mayor John Lindsay. New York's EPA was one of the first agencies of its kind, monitoring air and water resources and waste management. During his tenure at NYU, he was Associate Director of the NYU Institute of Environmental Medicine and Director of the Institute's Laboratory for Environmental Studies. Throughout his career, world leaders sought Dr. Eisenbud's opinions. He served on the United Nations World Health Organization Expert Panel on Radiation, the President's Electromagnetic Radiation Management Council, National Academy of Sciences' National Research Council, National Council on Radiation Protection, and many more international, national, state and city groups. Dr. Eisenbud published more than 200 books and articles, including memoirs called ''An Environmental Odyssey''. He is survived by his wife, Irma; sons, Dr. Elliott, Michael and Frederick; and grandchildren. We express our deep sympathy to his wife and family. E. John Rosenwald, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Medical Center/ School of Medicine Saul J. Farber, M.D., MACP Provost and Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, MIRIAM
description: COOPER-Miriam. Age 67. Beloved mother of Leslie Shapiro Greenberg and the late Howard Shapiro; cherished grandmother of David and Adam Greenberg; loving mother-in-law of Joel Greenberg. Miriam was the recipient of the 1981 Children's Science Book Award for her work, ''Snap Photography.'' She also authored a second, widely-circulated children's book entitled ''How Does It Feel When Your Parents Get Divorced?'' In addition to being an accomplished author, Miriam was a recognized photographer. Her black-and-white photographic displays, ''Goodbye Great Neck'' and ''Women in Bed'', were both exhibited at various galleries throughout Manhattan. In recent years, Miriam re-focused her creative energies and became a playwright. Her play, ''The StarCrossed Lovers,'' was recently performed at Synchroncity Space in Manhattan. Born and raised in Charleston, S.C., Miriam spent her early adult life in Great Neck, L.I. Upon becoming divorced, she moved to TriBeca where she initiated her artistic pursuits as well as a career in advertising. Over the years, Miriam worked in the advertising departments of The West Side Spirit, 7 Days, The American Lawyer and The New York Times. Her vitality, creativity, and youthfulness will inspire us always. Funeral Services at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York City, Friday, August 22, at 11 A.M.

description: Steffi Graf and Boris Becker have announced that they will definitely miss the United States Open this year. But what about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani? Officials of the United States Tennis Association say they would really like to know.

title: Here's a Jane Who's More Like Tarzan
description: LAST year, when Demi Moore turned up to promote ''Striptease'' with a buzz cut and newly bulked-up muscles, the world as one asked a question: Why? Why heighten an already hefty reputation for abrasiveness and physical vanity in such unflattering fashion? Why flaunt this freakish transformation? Why renounce all that preening, big-ticket femininity? As it turns out, Ms. Moore had good reason in ''G.I. Jane.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELSON, ADOLPH
description: ELSON-Adolph, 92, died August 21, 1997 in Neptune, New Jersey. Predeceased by his wife Ruth (Klinger) Sacks, Elson. Beloved father of Sheldon Sacks and Gloria Valenza. Grandfather of six. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral services Sunday at 1:15 pm at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, Inc., 2130 Highway #

title: Vivid Look at a Nation's Ordeal
description: WHATEVER its shattering effect on American lives, the Great Depression of the 1930's was certainly a boon for photographers. With the aim, among others, of helping to promote New Deal social welfare policies, the Federal Government sent professionals all over the country, presumably to register the impact of the disaster.

title: Bisbalense Shows the Way
description: Lonesome Glory, three times the champion steeplechase horse in America, ran third as the beaten favorite today while the Chilean gelding Bisbalense was winning the New York Turf Writers Cup in the rain at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, SHIRLEY
description: HOCHBERG-Shirley. The leadership and staff of Israel Bonds send heartfelt condolences to Irwin Hochberg, Israel Bonds' Greater New York Chairman, and his family on the death of his beloved sister-in-law, Shirley Hochberg, wife of Len Hochberg. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Gideon Patt, President Burton P. Resnick, National Campaign Chairman Jeannie Gerzon, Exec. Dir., Greater New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, HARRIET
description: LEVENSON-Harriet, of Tamarac, on August 20, 1997. Beloved wife of Mickey. Loving mother of David (Ann) Elliot, Ilsa (Gary) Lord and Debbie (Frank) Korowitz. Adored grandmother of Colin, Alissa, Kyle, Rachel and Avery. Dear stepmother of Mark Levenson and Joy (Ray) Teet. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Gilda's Club of South Florida, 4340 Sheridan Street, Suite 102, Hollywood, Florida 33021 would be appreciated. For more information, contact The Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 6701 West Commercial Boulevard, Tamarac, FL. 33319.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, LEO
description: JAFFE-Leo. Our deepest sympathy to our fellow director and friend Stanley R. Jaffe and to the entire Jaffe family. Triarc Companies, Inc. Nelson Peltz, Chairman & CEO Peter W. May, President & COO

description: To the Editor:

title: TEAMSTER VOTING THAT CHOSE CAREY DECLARED INVALID
description: A Federal official yesterday overturned Ron Carey's re-election to the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, ordering a new vote that will again pit Mr. Carey against the man he narrowly defeated, James P. Hoffa, son of the famous teamster leader.

title: New York's Waterways
description: To the Editor:

title: TARRANT APPAREL AGREES TO PAY $23.8 MILLION FOR B.U.M.
description: Tarrant Apparel Group agreed yesterday to pay $23.8 million to acquire the assets of the sportswear maker B.U.M. International, which has filed for bankruptcy protection. Tarrant Apparel, based in Los Angeles, is a women's apparel manufacturer. It said the assets consist primarily of the B.U.M. Equipment trademark, license agreements and related rights. B.U.M. and its affiliate, International Blueprint Inc., filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. Tarrant said a bankruptcy court in California would consider the sale at a Sept. 3 hearing.

title: Private Military School
description: To the Editor:

title: State of Emergency Extended for 5 Counties
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman extended a state of emergency to five southern New Jersey Counties yesterday, and said she would seek Federal disaster relief for flood damage caused by storms that pounded the area on Wednesday night and early Thursday.

title: ECOLAB GETS 14.9% OF GIBSON CHEMICAL OF AUSTRALIA
description: Ecolab Inc. bought a 14.9 percent stake in Gibson Chemical Industries Ltd. of Australia for about $18.7 million and said it was considering buying more. Ecolab, based in St. Paul, makes cleaning and sanitizing chemicals. It said it had bought 3.34 million shares of Melbourne-based Gibson Chemical, which makes similar products, on the open market. Gibson said it suspected that Ecolab, which already has Australian operations, planned to initiate talks with the company. A December 1996 report by the ratings agency Moody's Investor Service said Ecolab had a strategy of buying niche businesses to extend its own product range.

title: Federal Report Describes Teamster Money Scheme
description: In the heat of the tight race for the leadership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters last year, Federal investigators say, two top advisers to Ron Carey's campaign came up with an unusual fund-raising plan.

title: Promise of Good Life Entices Czech Gypsies
description: PRAGUE  The old Czech Gypsy stood in the courtyard of a Toronto motel as she beckoned from the television screen. "Romanies," she said, using the name by which Europe's Gypsies prefer to be called, "if you have any money don't hesitate, and come here. If you stay in the Czech Republic you will suffer and be hungry. Come here, and you'll live like lords."

title: APOLLO GROUP TO BUY COLLEGE FOR FINANCIAL PLANNING
description: Apollo Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the College for Financial Planning for about $35 million in cash and stock to bolster its offerings in the growing market of financial education programs. Apollo Group will pay about $17.5 million in cash and another $17.5 million worth of class A stock to purchase the school from the National Endowment for Financial Education. It will also assume an unspecified amount of liabilities, including deferred tuition income. The College for Financial Planning has an enrollment of more than 20,000 students. Apollo Group owns the University of Phoenix, Institute for Professional Development and Western International University, with more than 53,000 students in its educational programs.

title: Barber Makes His Mark, but Giants Fall Short
description: The Giants nearly brought their preseason to an unexpected close with a victory tonight over the defending Super Bowl champion Green Bay Packers. But when a last, stirring drive stalled deep in Packers territory, the Giants lost, 22-17, ending the exhibition season with a 1-3 record.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Federal Overseer Orders New Teamsters Election

title: DuPont to Buy Ralston Purina Soy Protein Unit
description: In a move that underscores its fervent push into agricultural biotechnology, the DuPont Company announced yesterday that it would acquire Protein Technologies International from the Ralston Purina Company for $1.5 billion in stock.

title: 6 Officers In Serb Police Back on Job In Bosnia
description: Six senior Bosnian Serb police commanders walked into the central police headquarters to work today for the first time since British troops seized the six police facilities in this city and ousted officers loyal to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.

title: Sex Suit Against Clinton Is Trimmed; Trial Date Is Set for Rest
description: A Federal judge in Arkansas dismissed parts of Paula Jones's lawsuit against President Clinton today but scheduled a trial for next May on Ms. Jones's central complaint, that Mr. Clinton sexually harassed her.

title: Law Giving Notice Of Sexual Offenders Upheld in New York
description: Two days after a similar ruling in New Jersey, a Federal appeals court in New York yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a state law that calls for the names and addresses of thousands of sex offenders to be made public. State officials said they would release the names next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, ANNA (NEE GERBER)
description: HOLLAND-Anna (nee Gerber). On August 21, 1997 in Los Angeles, formerly of Brooklyn and Long Beach. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Marion and Ronald Gold and Laura and Jack Starr. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. For service information call the ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York. (516-295-3100).

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday referred erroneously to a report about special bonuses given to nearly 90,000 Federal Express workers. The article was delayed, and appears today, on page 38.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, EDWARD
description: FOX-Edward, in his 90th year. Of Plantation, FL; formerly of Fort Lee, N.J., and Manhattan Beach, Bklyn; orginally of Osweicim, Austria. Devoted husband of 62 years of Lillian (Enoch). Beloved father of Penny Fox Schwartz and Allan Fox. Dear father-in-law of Ronna Taylor Fox. Cherished grandfather of Larry, Freddy, Ricky Schwartz, Tammy and Jeffrey Fox. Loving great-grandfather of Brenden and Taylor Crampton, Amanda & Jason Schwartz, Justin Fox, Hana Schwartz. A treasured source of inspiration to family and friends. Services Sunday, Aug. 24, 9:30 A.M., Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1700 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn.

title: Mercury, Mostly Gone From Bay in Japan, Still Poisons Town's Life
description: When Kazumitsu Hannaga hears that the fish in Minamata Bay are now deemed safe to eat, he grunts and moans, and his gnarled fingers shoot out in all directions to express his disapproval.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL IS ADDED TO S.& P. 500-STOCK INDEX
description: Shares of Clear Channel Communications Inc. got a lift yesterday from news that the company would be added to the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index at the close of trading. The stock gained $2.1875, to close at $62, on the New York Stock Exchange. Clear Channel, a Texas broadcasting company, replaces Tandem Computers Inc., which was acquired by the Compaq Computer Corporation in a deal that closed yesterday.

title: Bonus Pay for Federal Express Workers
description: Nearly 90,000 Federal Express workers have been told that they will share about $20 million in bonuses for their work during the strike against the company's rival, the United Parcel Service.

title: S.E.C. Approves New Nasdaq Listing Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved rules that are intended to improve listing standards on the Nasdaq National Market and the Nasdaq Small Cap Market, the National Association of Securities Dealers said today.

title: School and Lunchroom Duty Begin
description: Back to school time: you'd think I'd be sighing with relief. But, like most parents with children in public school, I'm bracing myself to be more, not less, busy.

title: If You Wish Upon This Team ...
description: NORMALLY, Disney World is the triumphant final destination for the winning Super Bowl quarterback. But here the Jets are, beginning the season at the rainbow's end. Is this some kind of omen?

title: Agriculture Dept. Plans Hunt for Source of Tainted Beef
description: Over the next several days, Agriculture Department officials across the country will pore over mounds of paperwork and interview people in an effort to determine the source of the E. coli bacteria that led to this week's recall of 25 million pounds of ground beef.

title: Drumming Up Business to Survive in a World Without Cold War
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company wanted to predict, without weeks of test drives, how its tires would perform under various conditions. So it went to the Energy Department's Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., for help. ''Their computer models show how a nuclear weapon will react to different conditions, so why shouldn't they show how a tire will react?'' asked William Sharp, president of Goodyear's global support operations.

title: Jean Westwood Is Dead at 73; Led Democrats in Rout of '72
description: Jean Westwood, who was a leader of George McGovern's disastrous Democratic campaign for President in 1972 and was the first woman to be chairman of a major political party, died on Monday in American Fork Hospital in American Fork, Utah, where she had lived for the last two years. She was 73.

title: 120 Reported Killed in Attack On Refugee Camp in Rwanda
description: At least 120 people were killed early this morning at a refugee camp in western Rwanda, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: U.S. Details Its Stance on Bias Remedies
description: In a brief filed today with the Supreme Court, the Clinton Administration argued that although a New Jersey school district was wrong to lay off a white teacher in favor of a black one solely on the basis of race, the Justices should still allow the use of affirmative action in many hiring and promotion decisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUMPHREY, WILLIAM
description: HUMPHREY - William. The trustees, faculty, alumni/ae, and students of Bard College mourn the passing of William Humphrey, whose love of literature and generosity toward students as a member of Bard's faculty left a memorable legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Cuban Visas for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review on Tuesday about four summer productions of the Glimmerglass Opera at Cooperstown, N.Y., misspelled the surname of a set designer for Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri.'' She is Carol Bailey, not Bailer.

title: On the Path to America With Outdoor Raconteurs
description: Artists ought, of course, to be allowed as many mistakes as other mortals. But a program of two pieces by Risa Jaroslow and Dancers at the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors festival was a depressing spectacle, particularly in view of Ms. Jaroslow's proven gifts as a choreographer.

title: British Slice $5 Billion From MCI Bid
description: Saying that a gloomier business outlook makes the MCI Communications Corporation worth 22 percent less than it was just nine months ago, British Telecommunications P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had renegotiated its agreement to acquire the American company.

title: Town Secret Is Uncovered In Birth Quest
description: The day the child was born, to a woman who might have briefly loved her, a small-town doctor in northern Georgia passed her through the back door of his office to a tire maker and his wife from Akron, Ohio, who wanted a baby badly enough to buy one.

title: Actor Isn't Running
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs
description: The American economy may be defying the laws of the business cycle, but American churches are falling on financial hard times, with no relief in sight.

title: U.S. Envoy to Kenya Warns Both Sides to Restore Peace
description: In a hard-hitting speech aimed at slowing the spiraling violence here, the United States Ambassador to Kenya strongly criticized both the Government and opposition leaders today for heading down a path toward more confrontation and suggested that Kenya's foreign aid may hang in the balance if peace is not restored.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKEL, JOE
description: FINKEL-Joe. August 12, 1947August 23, 1996. Remembering this first anniversary of our wonderful, capable, exuberant son-in-law who shared his love of the Alaskan wilderness with us. Harriet and Dick

title: Bridge
description: Some 65 years ago, when the game was young, an ebullient woman named Dorothy Rice Sims made a serendipitous discovery at the bridge table. She bid something she did not have, perhaps accidentally, and prevented the opponents from reaching an easy game. She liked taking risks -- she was one of the earliest women aviators -- and repeated her effort frequently, with mixed results.

title: Drug-Free Event
description: To the Editor:

title: Words of Inspiration, With a New York Feel
description: Jaime Oncins of Brazil had just won his second-round qualifying match at the United States Open. Now, he was standing at the entrance to the players' lounge, staring up at the large words on the wall, and reading aloud: ''I wanna wake up in the city that doesn't sleep, to find I'm king of the hill, top of the heap. If I can make it there, I'd make it anywhere.''

title: A Perky 'Macbeth' With Girlish Witches
description: The witches in the ''Macbeth'' mounted by the Kings County Shakespeare Company for its annual festival in Prospect Park must have learned from rabbits: Shakespeare's three are suddenly seven, and no hags but comely youngsters in dancing tights, hopping around in all sorts of scenes where they have no business. Apparently Michael Oberlander, the director, means to let us know the two Macbeths were more imp-possessed than we thought.

title: GINGRICH PROMISES TO FIGHT CLINTON ON WELFARE LAW
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich accused President Clinton today of caving in to unions on rules that, he said, undermine the welfare law. Mr. Gingrich vowed that his central legislative drive for the fall would be a bill intended to correct those weaknesses.

title: Cities' Concerns Voiced
description: The gubernatorial candidates must address the plight of New Jersey cities if they hope to attract black voters, the executive director of the New Jersey Black Ministries Council said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: INSIDE METRO
description: NOURISHMENT IN HARLEM -- Construction is scheduled to begin next week on a supermarket at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, the first big commercial venture in East Harlem in 20 years. Page 27.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PEGASUS GOLD INC., Spokane, Wash., is reducing its work force by about 9 percent, or 90 employees.

title: A Baroque Keyboardist's Other Side
description: The Scarlattis have never posed a particular problem for the pigeonholers of music history. Domenico, an exact contemporary of Bach and Handel, is best known for his 550 pithy keyboard sonatas; Alessandro, his father, for his operas and cantatas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMMERICH, ALEXANDER L., JR.
description: DOMMERICH-Alexander L., Jr., of Greenwich, CT., aged 86, died at the King Street Nursing Home on Wed., Aug. 20, 1997. Husband of Margaret McCall Dommerich and father of Wilhelmina D. Powell and Alexander L. Dommerich, III. Grandfather of Charlotte G.W. Stutts, Robert Dillon, II, Maria R. M. Dommerich and Amy K.L. Dommerich. Great-grandfather of Zachary Kyle Dillon and Joshua Dillon. Brother of Eleanor D. Schmeltzer and the late Jean D. Lange and Dudley H. Dommerich. Mr. Dommerich attended Brunswick School, the Fessenden School, Lawrenceville School and Wesleyan University. He was Vice President and Secretary of L.F. Dommerich & Co., Inc. & a former member of the Representative Town Meeting of Greenwich, Connecticut. He was also a member of the Riverside Yacht Club and Squadron A. Association, Inc. He served with the Red Barons at the Greenwich Hospital, Meals on Wheels, and many other volunteer activities. There will be a memorial service at 10:45AM, Monday, August 25, 1997 at the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich, Connecticut. It is requested that there be no flowers. Contributions to charities for the blind or to any charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, HELEN A. (NEE EGAN)
description: FITZPATRICK-Helen A. (nee Egan). Peacefully, on August 21, 1997. Devoted wife of Paul P. Beloved mother of the late Helen Marie and Paul Peter. Loving daughter of the late William H. Egan. Dear sister of Rosanne Gilroy, William P., and James J. Egan. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr, Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:45 AM, at St. Francis de Sales Church, Belle Harbor. Interment St. Mary's Star of Sea Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, JAMES ALLAN
description: CAMERON-James Allan. Of Southampton, N.Y., on August 19, 1997. Survived by his loving wife Audrey and by his brother William A. Cameron of East Hampton, N.Y. Visiting hours at the J.M. O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Road, Southampton, N.Y., Thursday from 7-9 PM, and Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. There will be a funeral service on Saturday at 2:00 PM, at the St. Andrew's Dunes Church, Dune Road, Southampton, N.Y. Interment will follow at the Southampton Cemetery, Southhampton, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Good Fellows Club of Suffolk County, P.O. Box 36, Huntington, N.Y. 11743, for local scholarship & charitable organizations would be appreciated.

title: Proposal to Privatize Japanese State Insurer
description: A Japanese Government panel led by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto proposed Thursday night that the 97 trillion yen ($814 billion) postal insurance system, known as Kampo, be turned into a private company by the year 2001. But an industry group warned yesterday that the system should be broken up before being put into private hands.

title: Jets Remain Unsettled, But Unbeaten
description: Imperfectly, but significantly, the Jets completed an undefeated preseason tonight with a theatrical 15-9 overtime victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

description: The Agriculture Department issued an advisory in June about safely cooking ground beef that may have been contaminated with E. coli bacteria. It read in part:

title: Western Wall Prayer
