title: Payoff Inquiry Widens To Daiwa Securities
description: The Daiwa Securities Company, Japan's second-largest brokerage firm, said yesterday that authorities were investigating whether it paid off the same racketeer who extorted millions of dollars from other large financial companies, including the Nomura Securities Company. Daiwa provided records of trades made after 1993 to the Finance Ministry, a company spokesman said.

title: INSIDE
description: No Guarantees on Meat

title: Fassel's Way: Up Close and Personal
description: Reggie White was asked recently what it takes to win. Leaders, was his response. Learning to win is like learning to ride a bike. Someone must be there to guide the handlebars, to lead, to make sure that if there is a fall, the rider knows how to get back up. Leaders are normally the players, veterans like White, who have rings and attitude and status.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPER, DANIEL AND MICHAEL
description: ALPER-Daniel and Michael. With us forever. Our darling sons and brothers. Marcia, Karen and Lawrence

title: Turnstiles: Small Comfort To Wary Subway Riders
description: In recent months, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has quietly installed new ceiling-to-floor turnstiles offering subway riders access to 19 station entrances that had previously been unstaffed and off-limits after hours.

title: Hostage Case Suspect Linked to Other Sex Crimes
description: A man accused of holding a Burmese woman hostage and sexually abusing and torturing her in his Manhattan apartment was denied bail yesterday after prosecutors said he had previously been arrested in three similar cases, and raised the possibility that he was tied to additional crimes.

title: Excerpts from Affirmative Action Brief
description: Following are excerpts from a brief filed with the Supreme Court today by the Clinton Administration in which it argues that the Piscataway, N.J., school board was wrong to lay off a white teacher while keeping a black one, but urging the court to find that it is justifiable to take race into account in hiring and promotions when there is a compelling interest:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Chief of R.J. Reynolds Says Smoking Has Role in Cancer
description: In one of the strongest statements yet by a top tobacco industry executive about smoking and health, the chairman of the company that owns the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company testified yesterday that he believed that cigarettes play a ''role in causing lung cancer.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Pay attention. This is very serious.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, RUTH
description: SHAPIRO-Ruth. On August 22, 1997. Beloved daughter, sister and aunt; wonderful teacher and friend to so many. Memories of your sweet soul will be with us always, you loving family. Funeral service Sunday 12 noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Celtics Sign 2 Free Agents
description: The Boston Celtics yesterday signed the free agents CHRIS MILLS, a forward, and TYUS EDNEY,a guard, players who will most likely fit into Coach RICK PITINO'S up-tempo system.

title: Going Beyond Just Facts To Show a Hollow Soul
description: George Wallace's career is among the most dramatic in American politics, and it is crammed with defining moments. All are recreated with startling veracity and tension in the two-part mini-series called simply ''George Wallace.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIELSON, WILLIAM P.
description: NIELSON-William P. On 8/20/97 of Plandome, NY. Beloved cousin of Mrs. Patricia Simmons. Memorial service on Tuesday, August 26 at 3pm at Christ Episcopal Church, Manhasset. For further information, contact The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, Manhasset.

title: Judge Backs Messinger's Bid For Contested City Documents
description: In a victory for the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that a Borough President has the same right to request city documents under the Freedom of Information Law as any other citizen.

title: Irving Cooperberg, 65; Helped Found Gay Center
description: Irving Cooperberg, a founder and the first president of the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center in Greenwich Village, a hub of gay life in New York City, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: Richard Friedman, Psychiatry Professor, 49
description: Richard Friedman, a professor of psychiatry at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and a pioneer in the study of the mind's effects on physical health, died Tuesday of heart failure after giving a talk at the American Psychological Association meeting in Chicago. He was 49.

title: BANKBOSTON TO EXIT THE INDIRECT AUTO LOAN BUSINESS
description: The BankBoston Corporation said yesterday that it would quit the indirect auto loan business by Oct. 13. BankBoston said the move would eliminate 57 jobs. Employees at the Dedham, Mass., office responsible for the $1.5 billion portfolio can seek other employment within the bank. The bank said it would continue to service the existing loans until they are paid. It will also continue to offer auto loans directly to consumers over the telephone. The Boston company said it would focus on other core businesses including commercial lending to auto dealers.

title: Auto-Test Upgrade Delayed
description: Racing to make a February deadline for enforcing stricter auto emissions standards, the state suffered a setback yesterday when it was forced to reject the only bid submitted for constructing or updating 35 inspection stations, officials said. The lone bidder, Dynamometer Car Inspection, an Israeli company with an office in Glen Rock, failed to meet state specifications, said Jack Mozloom, a spokesman for the Treasurer's Office, which reviewed the bid.

title: A Third Option: Nonprofit Prisons
description: The Justice Department reported recently that the number of adults in American prisons reached an all-time high of 1.1 million in 1996. The penitentiary, unfortunately, remains a popular destination. Yet the question of who ought to run our prisons remains unresolved and urgent -- as shown by the videotape images this week of guards beating inmates in a privately run Texas prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, ROBERT C.
description: DONALDSON-Robert C., of North Babylon, Aug. 22, 1997. Retired Hilton Hotel Executive, served during W.W. II in 4th Armored Division, participated in the Battle of the Bulge. He attended Fordham University. Beloved husband of Loretta. Devoted father of Jacqueline. Dear brother of George of Cazenovia, NY. Friends may visit Saturday 7-9:30 PM & Sunday 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 P.M., at the Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main St., Babylon. Funeral mass, Monday 10:45, St. Joseph's RC Church, Babylon. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: The $2 Billion Stealth Bomber Can't Go Out in the Rain
description: Two years ago, the problem with the Air Force's B-2 Stealth bombers, which cost $2 billion apiece, was that their radar could not tell a rain cloud from a mountainside.

title: Mexico's Privately Run Highways Prove a Costly Failure
description: Over the last decade, as privatization came to be seen almost as a cure-all here, the Government embarked on one of the most sweeping private road-construction programs in the world, licensing scores of companies and banks to build and operate highways.

title: Boxing, With Security, Returns to Garden
description: Felix Trinidad Jr., the International Boxing Federation welterweight champion, will step up in weight tonight as boxing returns to the main arena at Madison Square Garden for the first time in more than a year.

title: SUN HEALTHCARE CUTS OFFER FOR ACQUISITION
description: Sun Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it had reduced the number of shares it will pay in its acquisition of Retirement Care Associates Inc., after the latter said it would restate its financial results for the 1997 fiscal year. Sun agreed in May to buy the rival nursing home operator for about $367 million in stock, cash and debt. Sun said yesterday that the companies agreed to cut the stock swap ratio to 0.520 of a Sun share for each of Retirement Care's 15.7 million shares, from 0.68265 earlier. The change reduces the value of the transaction by about $7.22 million. Shares of Sun Healthcare fell 31.25 cents yesterday, to $21.375, while Retirement Care shares fell $1.6875, to $9.9375.

title: Upset by a Contract, Giuliani Won't Speak at Ashe Stadium
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would not attend the Monday-night opening ceremonies of the new Arthur Ashe Stadium in Flushing Meadows, Queens, to protest a contract with the United States Open that obliges the city to pay fines when aircraft fly over and disrupt tournament matches.

title: Duos and Bandwagons In Staten Island Race
description: While there is an abundance of activity leading up to next month's primaries, few in political circles expect general elections between Democrats and Republicans to heat up until long after Labor Day.

title: Silver and Gold Prices Gain From Stock and Bond Turmoil
description: Silver prices jumped yesterday as investors sought safety from falling stock and bond prices. Gold also rose, but only modestly.

title: USA WASTE SERVICES ADVANCES A $1.5 BILLION BID
description: USA Waste Services Inc. has reached an agreement with regulators that will allow it to complete its $1.5 billion acquisition of United Waste Systems Inc., the companies said yesterday. USA Waste Services, based in Houston, is the nation's No. 3 solid-waste concern. United Waste is based in Greenwich, Conn. Under an agreement with the Department of Justice and the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the companies must sell one landfill. The site accounted for less than $5 million in revenues in 1996, the companies said.

title: Commission Fines Hospital
description: The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission has fined Overlook Hospital in Summit $2,750 for giving incorrect doses of radioactive isotopes of iodine to patients undergoing diagnostic scans, the commission announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAUTHIER, FLORENCE M.
description: GAUTHIER-Florence M. In Brattleboro, Vermont, formerly of New York City. Survived by her daughter Linda Mills MacNiven of Reno, NV and her sister Lillian Berney of New York City. Services Monday, Brattleboro, Vermont.

title: Fair Is Foul. Street Fair, That Is.
Paid Notice: Memorials  TRIPP, MARY
description: TRIPP-Mary. You had beauty. You had courage. And you saved me. The fearful trip is done. Rest peacefully. Norma

description: Call me crazy, but I had a funny feeling that I was never going to be invited to the President's hot tub. Michael McCurry, the White House press secretary, had said it belonged to the American public, so I considered just showing up one night at the northwest gate of the White House with flippers, a sand bucket and a towel.

title: Lyric's Director Retires
description: Bruno Bartoletti, artistic director and principal conductor of the Lyric Opera of Chicago since 1964, will retire in April, the company has announced. His successor will be Matthew Epstein, the company's artistic adviser. Mr. Epstein, 50, has previously served as general director of the Welsh National Opera and artistic director of the BAM Opera, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He is also a vice president of Columbia Artists Management. Mr. Bartoletti, who is 71, will become the company's artistic director emeritus.

title: Still Sheepish in Seattle, Yanks Lose in Kingdome
description: Before Kenny Rogers unleashed his first pitch tonight, he was not comfortable with the mound, so he asked the umpires to modify it. The umpires summoned the grounds crew, and more dirt was spread around the Kingdome mound. If Rogers could have requested and received a new opponent and a new building as simply as he got the dirt, it might not have been such a depressing night for the Yankees.

title: To Buy or Not to Buy?

title: Abe Newborn, Theatrical Agent, 77
description: Abe Newborn, a longtime theatrical agent, died on Aug. 12 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections

Shuart, did help win accreditation in 1982 for the master's degree program in business administration, the undergraduate division was accredited in 1968, eight years before his arrival.

title: Whitman Seeks Flood Aid
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman extended a state of emergency to five southern New Jersey counties yesterday -- Atlantic, Burlington, Cape May, Cumberland and Ocean -- and said she would seek Federal disaster relief for flood damage caused by back-to-back storms that pounded the area on Wednesday night and early Thursday.

title: Lodi Man Is Charged After Body Is Found
description: The body of a Garfield, N.J., woman who had been missing for a week was found buried in a wooded section of Jefferson Township Thursday night, and a man she had dated was charged today with her murder, officials said.

title: A Reckless Performance
description: More than once in his long career, the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat has shown a knack for making exactly the wrong symbolic gesture at exactly the wrong time. This week he did it again, publicly embracing the leaders of militant Islamic organizations that endorse suicide bombing less than a month after a deadly explosion in Jerusalem wrecked a promising American effort to revive the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: U.S. to Let 1,000 Go To Cuba to See Pope
description: The Clinton Administration agreed to let 1,000 Americans and U.S. residents visit Cuba for the Pope's visit in January. The approval went to the Archdiocese of Miami, which plans to arrange the trip. Approvals are likely for other Catholic groups, including the New York Archdiocese.

title: Film Festival Plans Almodovar Premiere
description: The New York Film Festival, which opens Sept. 26 at Avery Fisher Hall with Ang Lee's ''Ice Storm,'' has announced that it will end its 35th annual presentation on Oct. 12 with the world premiere of Pedro Almodovar's ''Live Flesh.'' A thriller set in Madrid, the film involves the police, a diplomat's daughter and the ghosts of Franco's rule.

title: Mets Get Wake-Up Call From Hundley
description: Whether Todd Hundley needs sleep is debatable. But this is beyond dispute: Bobby Valentine needs Todd Hundley.

description: The wily trout were feeding all around Bernie Marois as he stood waist-deep in an ink-black pool on the West Branch of the Farmington River.

description: NEWMAN-Jeannette. Mother, you will remain in our hearts forever. Jeff and Charles and their families

description: In Jackson Hole, Wyo., where elk horn arches grace the town square, some major bull elks of the cultural genus are butting heads over the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a painting contract awarded to the Publicolor company by the New York City Board of Education misstated the estimated cost of supplies. It is 50 cents a square foot, not $50.

title: Trainer Thinks Highly of Awesome Again
description: If the weather is the X factor in Saturday's 128th running of the Travers Stakes, it is not bothering David Hofmans, the trainer of the favorite, Awesome Again. Hofmans pointed out today that his colt won the Jim Dandy in the mud four weeks ago. ''This horse can run through anything,'' he said.

title: Misael Pastrana Borrero, 74, President of Colombia in the 70's
description: Misael Pastrana Borrero, the last of Colombia's National Front Presidents, who governed as part of a coalition between the two main political parties, died at a clinic here today. He was 74.

description: SPRAGUE-Gilbert M. 12/22/57-8/23/96. Remembered, missed, loved.

title: New Model and New Ads As Saab Aims for Revival
description: Think of it as a midlife crisis. At age 50, Saab finds itself at a crossroads: After years of struggling, it has a new management team, a new advertising agency and perhaps most important, a new car on the way.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article cited in the News Summary yesterday about South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which was conducting a hearing on the assassination of a top ally of Nelson Mandela, was omitted from some copies. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal return address.)

title: Obscure Rocket Server Dispatches Ivanisevic
description: A week ago, Julian Alonso of Spain lost in the first round of the G.H.I. Bronx Classic, a lower-level tournament on the Challenger circuit. Today, he shocked the No. 4 player in the world and served notice that his serve will be noticed.

title: A Shabazz Daughter Learns to Cope After Loss
description: Sometimes Ilyasah Shabazz gets the feeling that her mother has let herself into her apartment and is waiting with a meal or is waiting outside her office with something for her to read.

title: An Anxious Scattering of Ashes
description: On a recent bright Sunday, a small group took the ferry from Point Judith to Block Island, R.I. Carrying beach bags, the seven men and women made their way from the harbor to the northward road, and after half a mile or so they crossed the dunes onto the beach.

title: Police Say Tip Received Early In Torture Case Was Mishandled
description: The Police Department ''handled improperly'' an early tip to its Internal Affairs investigators that a Haitian immigrant was brutalized in a Brooklyn station house, Commissioner Howard Safir acknowledged last night.

title: A Dominican In Paris (Almost)
description: THIS was to be a week of pilgrimage for Amin Chaljub, who headed off to World Youth Day in Paris with five of his friends from Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx. They would sing and pray with a half million other Catholic young people, visit shrines and attend a Papal Mass. The festival's theme came from the Gospel of St. John: ''Master, where are you staying?''

title: Prison Continues Lockdown
description: More than three weeks after a guard was killed at Bayside State Prison, the inmates are still being kept locked in their cells most of the day, corrections officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. to Let 1,000 Sail From Miami to Cuba for Pope's Visit
description: The Clinton Administration temporarily eased restrictions on travel to Cuba today, announcing that it would allow the Archdiocese of Miami to sail a cruise ship there with more than 1,000 American Catholics during Pope John Paul II's visit in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSHANSKY, NANCY
description: OLSHANSKY-Nancy. The Board and Staff of the Council of Jewish Federations mourn the sudden loss of Nancy Olshansky, adored wife of Bernard, former Senior Associate Executive Vice President of the Council of Jewish Federations. Born in Boston, Nancy married Bernie in 1952. An avid reader, she persued her own interests wherever his career took them. She was a past President of the Boston Chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women, and a past Vice President of Brandeis University National Women's Committee. Nancy loved learning and passed that passion to their children, to whom she was devoted, and to their grandchildren, the lights of her life. Besides her beloved Bernie, she is survived by their children, Judith Ann and Douglas Gragg, of Boston; Susan and Gary Singer, of Chicago; and Kenneth and Margo Olshansky, of Brooklyn; and their grandchildren, Jason, Sam and Melanie Gragg, Jessica and Hannah Singer, Gideon and Clara Olshansky. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Donations in her blessed memory may be made to either the Brandeis University National Women's Committee Nancy L. Olshansky Book Fund or to the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston. Conrad L. Giles, M.D., Pres., CJF Martin S. Kraar, Exec V.P., CJF

description: To the Editor:

title: With Usual Drama, Mir Crew Makes Risky Repair
description: There were some tense moments in outer space today, but for once the crew of the Mir banished all doubt, carrying out the riskiest and most essential repairs in the Russian space station's long and troubled history.

title: Work to Begin On Pathmark In Harlem After 5 Years
description: Construction is to begin next week on a Pathmark supermarket at 125th Street and Lexington Avenue in what many Harlem residents hope will be the first in a series of business investments in their neighborhood. It will be the first large commercial development in East Harlem in 20 years.

title: Federal Reserve Bank Signs Lease to Expand
description: In one of the largest deals of an already busy year in lower Manhattan, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York signed a lease yesterday for the top 13 floors of 33 Maiden Lane, a 27-story tower near the bank's headquarters at 33 Liberty Street.

title: Mission Viejo Into Final
description: Guadalupe, Mexico, which has not allowed a run in four games, faces a tough test Saturday when it plays Mission Viejo, Calif., for the Little League World Series title.

description: William Cade, a decorated French Resistance fighter and later a travel executive, died on Aug. 8 in a hospital in Naas, Ireland. He was 75 and lived in Kildare, County Kildare.

title: Corrections
description: The Commercial Real Estate column on Wednesday, about the restoration of the National Arts Club building on Gramercy Park, originally the home of Samuel J. Tilden, referred incorrectly to Tilden's defeat in the Electoral College in 1876. He was not the only candidate ever to win the popular vote but lose in the Electoral College; Grover Cleveland did so, losing in 1888 to Benjamin Harrison.

title: A New Vote for the Teamsters
description: After a week of glory as the architect of labor's heady victory over the United Parcel Service, Ron Carey, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, now faces a federally ordered rerun of last year's tainted union leadership election in which he narrowly defeated James P. Hoffa.

title: From Vending Machines, Chips in a Can
description: And now, chips in a soda can.

title: Colleges Beyond Reach
description: A forthcoming report from two university economists asserts that students from affluent families are attending public colleges and universities in ever larger numbers. The report has already commanded considerable media attention and has raised fears that wealthier students may be grabbing places in lower-cost institutions that would normally be occupied by poorer students. It has also inspired some interest in the notion of means-testing public education -- charging higher fees for wealthier students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARGLEBAUGH, HELEN O.
description: BARGLEBAUGH-Helen O., on August 19th, 1997. Loving wife of the late William Medford. Fond sister of William T. Brodnitzki and his wife and family. Her extensive research library on doll costumes and design will be made available for doll research. Family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 103-33 Lefferts Boulevard, Richmond Hill, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, on Monday, at 10:30 AM. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. Donations may be made to Cabrini Hospice.

title: AAMES FINANCIAL IS SAID TO BE CONSIDERING SALE
description: The Aames Financial Corporation is reportedly considering putting itself up for sale. Aames, a Los Angeles-based company that sells mortgages to people with poor credit histories, is said to have hired the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette as an adviser. The shares of Aames slipped 56.25 cents yesterday to close at $22.6875, giving the company a market capitalization of $628 million. Aames's chief financial officer, Gregory Witherspoon, declined to comment on the takeover talk. American Banker, a trade publication, reported on Thursday that the company was for sale.

title: Fragile Peace Taking Root In Bosnia, Albright Says
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that she had seen ''encouraging signs'' of progress toward peace in Bosnia in recent weeks.

title: Emulating the Corporate Role Model
description: While Sandia is becoming the prototype industrial research lab, Oak Ridge National Laboratories is looking more like a corporation.

title: The Puritan's Puritan
description: As Congress hacks away at the Federal endowments for the arts and humanities, we should greet the release of a major early American text with enthusiasm. Richard S. Dunn and Laetitia Yeandle have published a splendid new edition of John Winthrop's ''Journal,'' an account of the founding of New England written between 1630 and 1649. Such works are expressions of a shared national heritage. Expensive to produce, they require years of painful scholarly labor. This edition, from Harvard University Press, is as definitive as projects of this sort are ever likely to be.

title: Boot Camp
description: Hovering just around the ankle, the boot of the moment tapers to a point.

title: 'Talking' To Dogs And Cats
description: THERE is more to your pet than four paws and a happy tail. Pets are as individual as their owners, with personalities and moods we come to predict and grow to love. Anyone owning a pet, however, knows there are limits to what our language can communicate. Were that not the case, a simple ''quiet'' would silence the most bothersome barker, and a ''shoo'' would intimidate the most tenacious counter cat.

title: Bird Calls: Jazz Greats Flock to Parker's Park
description: A DIFFERENT kind of bird will be chirping in Tompkins Square Park today, or at least his songs will. In 1939 a saxophone player from Kansas City, Mo., named Charlie Parker came to New York City and became a dishwasher in Harlem. But by the time of his death in 1955 people called him Bird and he had become one of the most important players in jazz.

title: Carcassonne, City of Stone
description: IN a country so rich in chateaus, palaces, cathedrals and monuments, it may be bordering on hyperbole to suggest that the fortified town of Carcassonne is the most breathtaking sight of all. Suffice it to say that, seen from afar, it offers the extraordinary spectacle of a medieval fortress that seems to have changed little over the centuries. Imposing, impregnable and perfectly preserved, with massive stone ramparts, towers and barbicans adding to its authority, the town dominates a large area from its hilltop position. No wonder the Black Prince took one look and abandoned his plan to attack it.

title: Many Uses of Mirrors in the Home
description: FOR most people, mirrors are indispensable grooming aids, but they can also be decorating tools to create accents, transform space and dematerialize mass. They can also be used to establish mood, to provide more security and even to help babies develop faster.

title: S & M Cafe Sign Too Saucy For Some Neighbors' Palates
description: At La Nouvelle Justine, a new restaurant at 206 West 23d Street that bills itself as the ''world's first S&M cafe,'' it's not the waiters with whips, the diners in high chairs or the calculated sense of depravity inside that has some neighbors complaining. It is what's hanging outside.

title: Paterno Spirit: Like Father, Like Coach
description: JOE PATERNO relaxed over a midsummer's lunch, reminiscing and reflecting on eight decades of living. This was the the calm before the storm: no Penn State football games to play, no practices in Happy Valley to oversee.

title: Digging for Treasure in Their Own Backyards
description: INVESTORS already face a dizzying array of funds that use all kinds of arcane strategies to invest in every corner of the globe. Perhaps that helps explain why more people are choosing funds with the straightforward approach of focusing on companies in their own backyards.

Glowing from its success last year in recruiting young liberals as temporary organizers, the AFL-CIO decided to tap into a virtual gold mine in six cities across the country: retired union members with plenty of time on their hands.

title: Rhoda Alani and Philip Cole
description: Dr. Rhoda Myra Alani, a dermatologist and cancer researcher at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, is to be married today to Dr. Philip Arthur Cole, an internist, endocrinologist and bio-organic chemist at Rockefeller University in New York. title: Making Those Good Causes Do What the Donor Intended
description: BEFORE handing over any money, Larry Kramer, the AIDS activist, tried to square up the terms of his proposed gift to Yale University to endow a gay studies professorship. Although the university ultimately decided that it was unwilling to accept the money on his terms, Mr. Kramer was right to try to set conditions in advance; after making a gift, he would have had considerably less leverage.

title: Decoding Winged Messages From Nature
description: ON Route 1 near New Brunswick, the heavy trucks swoosh past, but Michael Gochfeld and Joanna Burger ignore the rumble above their heads. For minutes they have been staring intently at a patch of shrubbery on the highway's embankment like people who have lost their keys.

description: Katherine Diack Stearns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Stearns of Kent, Conn., was married yesterday to Toby Edgcumbe Symonds, a son of Mrs. Andrew Symonds of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late Dr. Symonds. The Rev. Roger White performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn.

description: FOR about 15 years, Ruth and Bernard Kronyak were your average conscientious homeowners. They mowed and pruned and painted and planted. They observed trash night and recycling night and the annual major trash day. They had no problems with neighbors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, MARIAN G.

title: Making Farmers of City Kids

title: A Folk Album That Awakened A Generation
description: OCCASIONALLY A SINGLE artifact, document or exhibition manages both to recast the way in which artists see their tradition and to reanimate their sense of what is possible within that tradition. Such cultural moments act as prisms, gathering together work from different ends of a genre's spectrum and allowing them to blend in a new way. One such document was Edmund Wilson's 1943 anthology ''The Shock of Recognition,'' which assembled two centuries of American writers talking about one another's work. In the process, it illuminated the grand sweep and vigor of American literature.

title: Panthers' Collins Finds Himself Tangled Up in Racial Barbs
description: Professional football is not exempt from society's racial problems, although the National Football League is one area where blacks and whites cooperate on a daily basis. Consider the recent incident involving the Carolina quarterback Kerry Collins.

title: Why Washington Likes Land Mines
description: THE problem with land mines, for those who would like to banish them, is that they work so well. They are cheap, deadly and durable. They are also indiscriminate. This year in Egypt a girl was killed by a mine apparently buried in the desert by Rommel's Afrika Korps in 1942.

Researchers and farmers came up with an ingenious idea: Why not grow tobacco here under cotton netting to approximate Sumatran conditions, meaning perpetual cloud cover and high heat and humidity.

title: The High Cost of Hope
description: There is a strange new phenomenon in corporate life: the business leader who gets rich by getting fired. A few weeks ago, just nine months into his new job as president of AT&T, John Walter was handed his pink slip with a check for $26 million, which came to $92,300 each day he turned up for work. A few weeks before that, 17 months after he took the helm at Apple Computer, Gilbert Amelio was paid $7 million to clear out his desk, or $13,725 for each of his unprofitable workdays. (Apple lost $1.5 billion during his tenure.) There have been many other similar cases, mostly in the entertainment business, and more are sure to come. Failure at the top of large corporations has come to pay as mysteriously and outrageously well as success.

title: Paradise Not Quite Lost
description: I visited Twin Oaks in 1971 and later helped set up a commune based loosely on its egalitarian format (''Paradise Not Quite Lost,'' by Daniel Pinchbeck, Aug. 3). Twelve of us went to Winding Road Farm with little money, and widely disparate ideals and practical skills, but we tied back our hair, set up work schedules and began to raise food in the vivid green valleys and hills of Wisconsin. Some of my best memories come from that time -- sitting at the long wooden table eating wild greens, garden peas and the inevitable bean dish; learning how to milk a cow; arguing at a later meeting about the place of cows in the ecostructure; washing our hair in rain streaming off the roof; drinking homemade cherry wine and laughing long into the night; working out a policy on nude gardening; baking pies and bread on our wood stove, in shifts, to help pay the $140-a-month mortgage.

title: Columbia Adapts Books to Screen as Works Find Outlet on Line

But, like all university press executives, she was faced with the reality that libraries were buying fewer and fewer books as their budgets shrank. She also knew that universities were less and less willing to absorb big losses from university presses.

title: He Drew Them as He Saw Them
description: Few artists have truly defined an era. George Grosz, the great truth-teller of Weimar Germany and the early Nazi years, came as close as any. His caricatures of headless legislators, dazed prostitutes and bloated war profiteers will always stand in the pantheon of satire. In THE BERLIN OF GEORGE GROSZ: Drawings, Watercolors and Prints, 1912-1930 (Royal Academy of Arts/Yale University, $50), Frank Whitford, the book's editor, makes a good stab at trying to explain Grosz -- not an easy task. Though affiliated at various times with all sorts of political and artistic movements, Grosz (1893-1959) remained independent and full of contradictions. As Whitford points out, at heart Grosz was not interested in causes. He drew and painted simply what he saw, ''the moral collapse of Germany,'' seen through the people around him in Berlin. The book also includes an essay about Grosz's political milieu by the historian Christopher Clark, some very telling comments about the artist from his contemporaries, and excerpts from Grosz's art theories, many of which have never before appeared in English translation. Draftsmanship was where Grosz's true genius lay, and this book excellently displays his trenchant line. Whitford, a former lecturer in art history at the Royal College of Art and at the University of Cambridge, provides opinionated and insightful commentary to accompany the 159 numbered images reproduced, and he helps chart the changes in Grosz's art as his works became somewhat less grotesque. Though full of dark humor, many of the images retain their power to shock. Ted Loos

title: Poland's New Jewish Question
description: The resurgence of Judaism in Poland should be cause for rejoicing, yet Ian Buruma's article ''Poland's New Jewish Question'' (Aug. 3) left me with a sense of loss and rage. He makes the common mistake of trying to separate the Jewish identity from the Jewish religion. He should know better -- there are no half-Jews. With an ethic and body of law that encompass every aspect of daily life, Judaism is not just klezmer orchestras. His reference to nonreligious Western Jews with ''little left of their Jewishness but vague family memories, a taste for Woody Allen and bagels, and a sometimes-morbid preoccupation with the Holocaust'' itself evokes a demeaning stereotype that would be perfectly at home in World War II Poland.

Joe's latest indignity is the product of Andre Charles, a guerrilla graffiti artist who says he was approached by a Camel cigarettes rep about designing an ''urban friendly'' ad campaign. Oops, wrong choice. Charles, who has done more conventional work for places like the Pop Shop, clenched his hipster fists and decided that ''it was time to hang corporate America for a change.'' Paint and a posse of assistants in tow, he headed for Houston Street one sundown -- 12 hours later the mural was finished, showing Joe in a field of gravestones with ''Don't buy the hype'' painted on the side of an abandoned theater. Catch it while you can: at last report, the theater was scheduled for renovation, so the anti-Joe will be short lived.

title: A Series of Wrong Moves

But when the Singhs arrived at their new home, the movers they had hired, Crystal Moving and Storage, demanded $5,000 to unload the truck instead of the $700 price originally quoted, according to the Queens District Attorney's Office. The Singhs balked and instead of paying called the State Department of Transportation, which regulates the moving industry. The next day, four principals in the Brooklyn-based moving company were caught in a sting operation by investigators with the District Attorney's office and the Transportation Department when the foreman came to the Singhs' new house to collect $5,300 (an extra $300 in overnight storage fees).

As a teen-ager in Chicago, she worked in the Braille room of her high school with blind students who were mainstreamed into the school from all over the county. Bothered by the cumbersome slate and noisy cubes her blind classmates used for math problems, she designed a smaller, quieter version. Later, as a student nurse, she created a special method for blind diabetics to measure insulin.

title: In a Test, Snacks Hit the Spot Despite Some Rumblings?
description: RAIN was threatening early this month as a moist wind whipped the Fat Free Pringles tent at the RCA Tennis Championship here in one of America's great test markets. Doggedly, Procter & Gamble workers set out plastic cups of potato chips as they proselytized for olestra, Procter's controversial new fat substitute.

title: Caracas: Beef Today, Thai Tomorrow
description: WHEN oil was king, in the 1970's, money also flowed in Caracas. Today, after a couple of years of stringent and unpopular economic measures intended to curb rampant inflation, the mood in this Venezuelan city that loves to party is rebounding. A bustling metropolis of four million, Caracas offers a cosmopolitan array of dining options, including French, Italian, Spanish, Chinese and even Thai. Argentine and Brazilian-style steakhouses and grills are popular. As for typically Venezuelan food, the focus is strongly on meat.

title: To Catch a Thief
description: The Napoleon of Crime The Life and Times of Adam Worth, Master Thief. By Ben Macintyre. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, HENRY L. JR. (ROY)
description: FINCH-Henry L. Jr. (Roy) 79, died peacefully the evening of Friday, August 22, 1997 at his home. Attended by his wife Maggie and three of his five children, Julie, Marta, Dabney, Annie and Roy. He is also survived by his brother Stephen and five grandchildren Christine, Flavin, Rebecca, Rainer and Julian. He was a professor of philosophy and religion at Sarah Lawrence College and Hunter College and the author of books on Wittgenstein and Simone Weil. Memorial service at Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, NY, Saturday, Sept. 6, 2 PM. Donations in his name to the War Resisters League in NYC or to Restore: The North Woods, Box 440, Concord, MA 01742. A book of his poems is available free on request to Maggie Finch at 106 Liberty Ave, New Rochelle, NY 10805.

title: A Road Strewn With Bouquets
description: EARLY THIS MONTH, just before curtain time at the Music Center, the American Ballet Theater's Julie Kent sat backstage, wearing the raggedy gray dress that is Cinderella's Act I costume. At 28 years old, Miss Kent is the company's only ballerina under the age of 30 whose powers are in full flower. With the eyes of a fawn and limbs that are delicacy made manifest, she has the suppleness and expressiveness essential to a superlative dancer, along with an uncommon ability to dazzle an audience and bewitch it.

title: THE TOP 20
description: You do the math. A panel of football coaches placed eight teams in the No. 1 position on their pre-season ballots. A collection of reporters and broadcasters listed nine schools atop theirs. Coaches who once bristled at questions about high rankings - including JoePa - are smiling and accepting their unearned slots even if they are not convinced they belong. This is smart business, because the unnecessary, but traditional, pre-season pecking order could become decisive in the final major-college season with the Rose Bowl detached from the Bowl Alliance. The plan is for a championship to be determined in the Orange Bowl on Jan. 2. But a season that begins with a grab bag at the top may well develop into a transcontinental food fight with an unfulfilling finish. For now, nobody should even pretend to know.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRAIL, WILLIAM P.
description: McGRAIL-William P. Beloved husband of Mary Emcken McGrail. Dear father of Augusta, Anne, William P. III, Thomas. Loving grandfather of Adrian, Augusta, Peter, Marina and Isabelle. Brother of Jean. Graduate of Lawrenceville School, Dartmouth College, 1944. Lieutenant in U.S. Merchant Marine WWII. President of William P. McGrail Textile Company. Author of The Catch and the Feast. Descendant of Sir William Phipps, First Colonial Governor of Maine/Mass.

title: Shocked!
description: You may remember the scene in ''Casablanca'' when Claude Rains as Captain Renault blows his police whistle and announces that Rick's Cafe must be closed. ''On what grounds?'' asks Humphrey Bogart as Rick. Because ''I'm shocked, shocked to discover that gambling is going on here!'' If you don't remember it, not to worry. Legions of writers are eager to recall it for you. The film came out in 1942; in the 90's, the scene is cited so often that it has turned into a mock shock wave -- and a case study in cliches.

title: Crime
description: For the genteel pleasures of a teatime whodunit, I recommend Margaret Maron's well-mannered Southern mysteries. The stories are served with a buttery regional flavor and Deborah Knott, a North Carolina district court judge, presides over them like a proper hostess, dispensing good judgment in child-custody fights and barbed witticisms in the case of two drunken hunters who have shot up a discarded truck tire, thinking they had bagged an alligator. And she tempers it all with kindness. ''I am always drawn to faces that seem to look on human folly with compassion and amusement,'' she says in KILLER MARKET (Mysterious Press, $22).

title: Saving Those Senior Discounts
description: ''A Senior Discount? I Don't Deserve It,'' by Ted M. Levine (From the Desk Of, July 27), discussed the growing wealth of the 65-and-over age group -- and what he saw as the needless price breaks available to it. His opinions drew many responses from readers.

title: Parks Succeeding in Program To Keep Bears From Humans
description: In the middle of the night on Aug. 13, 1967, two backpackers were killed in their sleep by grizzly bears in the rugged back country here.

title: The Thin Red Line
description: At the end of the article, Egan describes Nancy McArdle's surreptitious visits to Jill's bedroom to search her sleeping daughter's body for fresh wounds. Although treatment has helped Jill stop cutting, it has not allayed her mother's fears or helped Jill and her mother find ways to deal more straightforwardly with each other. Until this is addressed, Jill's unhappiness is likely to continue and her self-injury to recur.

title: Hallie C. Stillwell, a Rancher And Texas Legend, Dies at 99
description: Hallie Crawford Stillwell, who drove a covered wagon into Alpine, Tex., in 1910, worked as a teacher and then settled down and became a Big Bend legend as a sharp-shooting ranch wife on horseback, died on Monday at an Alpine hospital, two months and two days shy of her 100th birthday.

title: Big Shots at Last
description: THE guys started arriving at the seedy little marina on East 68th Street as the sun was setting over Brooklyn. There were around 10 of them and they wore the uniform: flashy shirts, tight slacks, blow-dried hair, pinkie rings and gold bracelets. When they saw each other, they hugged, kissed, passed cigarettes and told war stories.

title: The Height of Emotion
description: For some time now, fashion magazines have been appealing to women's better judgment and preaching the logic of ''investment dressing'': a jacket's versatility, the virtues of seasonless fabrics, the high price of a coat amortized over the course of the next 10 years. Which is all well and good, except that, when it comes to most of the women we know and their thoughts about clothes, the decision-making process is rarely, if ever, a rational one. If anything, it seems to have more in common with falling in love than it does with solving a problem.

title: Able to Carry Families And Faster Than A Speeding V8
description: SO, you've got the money to buy one of those cute little super-roadsters from Mercedes-Benz, BMW or Porsche. But you don't fancy a convertible with the attendant ultraviolet rays. And while you long for the zip of a true sports car, part of you wants to play it safe with four doors and a back seat roomy enough for the in-laws. What to buy?

title: COCKTAIL CULTURE LIVES!
description: While GQ and Esquire battle to control the future of men's magazines, a couple of new publications are flexing muscles for the retro set. Kutie and Hollywood Highball -- based in Seattle and Los Angeles respectively -- take after rock-jawed 50's magazines like Rugged Men and Sir! to revive classic cheesecake. In between are essays on cigars, liquor and ''real men'' like Richard Petty. Kitschy satire motivates both magazines, but only in part. ''We're trying to find a new identity for men,'' explains Jeff Fox, 28, the editor of Hollywood Highball. ''It doesn't work for guys to run around being ashamed of being guys.'' Don't call it porn, though: ''There are probably more bare breasts in Harper's Bazaar than in Kutie,'' says Hank Trotter, Kutie's publisher. Mostly these magazines are about the importance of iconic stuff -- motor scooters, hot cars, cigarette lighters. ''It is not a throw-away product,'' says Hollywood Highball's homage to the timeless Zippo lighter. ''The Zippo is all good.''

However, there was too much focus on the symptom and not enough on the family. I wonder if Jill McArdle would have felt the need to hurt herself had there been an outlet for her anxiety and ''negative'' feelings. title: Poland's New Jewish Question
description: Buruma's report on changes in Jewish life in Poland is interesting, but not terribly relevant in terms of ingrained attitudes of the majority of Polish citizens. To be troubled by the Poles' lack of indignation over anti-Semitic graffiti and the firebombing of synagogues is to refuse to recognize a 1,500-year-old truth. In Europe, Jews have never been accepted by the majority population as true nationals. Jews may have deceived themselves into believing that they were real Germans, Poles, whatever -- but as far as their countrymen were concerned, they were Jews. It makes little difference whether or not they are religious, whether or not they try to assimilate, whether they are accommodating or assertive, they will always be singled out for waves of persecution. If an event as shattering as the Holocaust has not altered this, what right do we have to expect that anything will in the future?

title: An Airport With a Sauna And a Supermarket

title: Sticks and Stones
description: These days, given our mania for large houses, the free-association response to the phrase 620-square-foot house might be tear down. Fortunately for this tiny but beautiful stone and redwood weekend cabin in Sonoma Valley, its current owners decided against bulldozing, or even ripping off the roof and building up. Instead, they opted to preserve the house, which was built in 1960 by Paul Hamilton, an architect based in Santa Rosa, Calif., for his own use. The house owes a considerable formal and spiritual debt to Frank Lloyd Wright, whom Hamilton admired greatly. I certainly vibrate to his organic principles and his sense of space, says Hamilton. He liberated us from the box. Indeed, there is nothing boxlike about this dwelling, with its elegant battered walls made of Sonoma cut stone, laid by Hamilton himself, topped by a narrow ribbon of windows -- a Wrightian gesture to maximize light without compromising privacy.

title: No Need for Better Bombs

Yet the Energy Department and America's nuclear weapons labs are now engaged in a nuclear weapons upgrade program that will make both of these vital arms control objectives harder to achieve.

It happens that H. is just the sort of person who harbors a secret nostalgia for those times when women favored a hat and gloves for town -- but this feeling does not extend to gloves with padded palms and an inflexible thumb. Still, as far as H. is concerned, a person wearing oven mitts on the subway is exercising a constitutionally guaranteed right to accessorize with kitchenware. Who knows? A proposed ''elimination of feral cat colonies'' in Golden Gate Park prompted a campaign to save the strays. * After winning a fight to delete the cat jihad, Supervisor Sue Bierman was rewarded with a newspaper cartoon of a grateful whiskerface hugging her leg. The van rolled over, ending up against a tree with its wheels in the air, like a giant animal pawing at the sky. For a few seconds, all traffic stopped; then most drivers, after taking a good look, drove on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYLE, JOSEPH D.
description: RYLE-Joseph D. A prominent public relations executive died July 25th at his home in New York. He was 86. A Memorial Mass will be held in Lacy Chapel, St. Patrick Cathedral, on September 26, at 10:30 A.M. Memorials may be made to East Side House, 337 Alexander Avenue, Bronx, New York. Mr. Ryle served on the East Side Board for 40 years and was a founder of its Winter Antique Show. His long career in public relations over six decades included such projects and creative efforts for such diverse clients as the New York Racing Association, CocaCola, the Irish Georgian Society, the chanteuse Hildegarde and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Of equal significance were his volunteer efforts on behalf of such organizations as East Side House, Shaker Village in Massachusetts, the Isabel O'Neil Foundation, the Westchester Kennel Club and the Remsenberg Association in the village where he maintained a second home for many years, ''The Academy''. Other celebrations that involved Mr. Ryle included the 40th Anniversary of Time Magazine and the Centennial of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. During WWII he served in the US Air Force rising to the rank of Major. Following the war he was Director of Public Relations for American Overseas Airlines based in London.

title: The Worker Backlash

American workers are now beginning to challenge the very forces that have led to a spectacular resurgence in corporate profitability and competitiveness in the United States. title: Nixon: Still the One
description: What better way to mark the anniversaries of Richard Nixon's resignation (Aug. 9, 1974) and pardon by Gerald Ford (Sept. 8, 1974) than with this never-before-published transcript. The scene: Nixon's Executive Office Building hideaway, May 18, 1973, the day after the Senate Watergate Committee's televised hearings began. John Dean will soon testify that Nixon committed high crimes, and the long slide toward resignation will accelerate. As the final Watergate tapes released by the National Archives reveal, Nixon wanted to give three of his allies -- H.R. (Bob) Haldeman, John Ehrlichman and John Mitchell, who had all resigned by then -- the greatest gift a President can bestow: a blanket pardon. According to Samuel Dash, chief counsel of the Senate Watergate Committee, this exchange, if known to the committee at the time, would have justified a separate article of impeachment all by itself. ''Even Haldeman,'' he says, ''was trying to shut him up.''

title: After the Preaching, the Lure of the Taboo
description: TOWARD THE END OF THIS SUMMER'S hit film comedy ''My Best Friend's Wedding,'' Julia Roberts is hunched on the floor of a hotel hallway, her back propped against the door. The man she wants to marry is in the room getting news of her betrayals. We see her extract -- from her bra, it appears -- a pack of Marlboros. Hesitantly, shakily, she lights a cigarette. The viewer is supposed to see the cigarette and her nervous smoking as a visible counterpart to the panicky feelings of imminent loss that are sweeping over her. She's about to explode, and this cigarette, as it often is in films, is a fuse. Utterly desolate, out in the cold, Ms. Roberts never looked more appealing, huddled around a brief flame and warming cinder, smoke streaming glamorously from her nose.

Plenty of people still purchase bikes this way, but these days hundreds of thousands of cyclists behave like fussy stereophiles, piecing together their bikes using top-quality components made by custom manufacturers. The results can be costly, and it's easy to fall for more technology than you need. In fact, marketers sincerely hope you will. ''Consumer excess has finally reached the bike,'' says Ray Keener, president of Growth Cycle, a Boulder, Colo., marketing company that works with bike retailers and manufacturers. ''People pay $10,000 for stereo speakers or $500 for a golf club. This is just another niche where companies are asking, How high can we go?''

title: Lesbians in Wonderland
description: Change is the one constant in Blanche McCrary Boyd's provocative new novel about sexual identity and the search for the self. Set in the early 1970's, TERMINAL VELOCITY (Knopf, $23) is the story of a prim book editor who works in Boston and the changes that ensue after she tangles with a band of radical lesbians who live in a California commune. Drawn together by their shared affinity for Artemis Foote, an insouciant artist with a convenient trust fund, the denizens of Red Moon Rising are a volatile group, particularly when they're performing their musical feminist version of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' Their ranks include a dentist, a political fugitive, a columnist for Ramparts magazine, an art historian, a drug-peddling witch -- and the unlikely Ellen Burns, seemingly a happily married heterosexual, who will soon take a new lover and a new name. As it crisscrosses the country, Boyd's story moves from comic high jinks through seduction, betrayal and finally violence with a speed that at times feels dizzying. Indeed, before Ellen's reinvention is over, she will have lived the life of a fugitive on the run, witnessed a suicide attempt, received electroshock therapy in a mental ward, tried her hand at skydiving, attended Alcoholics Anonymous and worked on a late-night soap opera about ''a 'Gone With the Wind'-type family and their friendly, happy slaves.'' ''Terminal Velocity'' is not a novel for the squeamish. Despite its excesses, Boyd succeeds in closing the book on a redemptive note that is neither trivial nor saccharine. Hers is a voice that never wavers in its authority or its fierce sexual politics. Andrea Barnet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERBERG, IRVING
description: COOPERBERG - Irving. The Board, Staff and Volunteers of the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center mourn the passing of our Founding President and dear friend and colleague, Irving Cooperberg. Irving had the foresight, determination, humor, and tenacity required to guide the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center through its early years. His generosity and determination played a key role in securing the building which is now the Center's home. Irving led the Center's first critical fund raising campaign, spurring other members of our community to follow his generous lead. Upon completion of his term as President (May 1987), Irving was named President Emeritus by the Center's Board of Director in 1988. Together with Lou Rittmaster, his lover of 25 years, Irving continued his fundraising efforts for the Center. Irving's wisdom and generous spirit were present in his devotion to New York's gay and lesbian synagogue, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah, where he served as Chairman for six of his fifteen years as a member of the Board. His smile and laughter overcame even the darkest hours, and he faced his twelve year struggle with HIV and AIDS with a courage none of us will forget. Through his example we learned about living and not dying with HIV. He was, simply put, a true Mensch. Our deepest sympathy and love go to his devoted lover, Lou Rittmaster. Everyone at the Center will miss Irving more than words can say, and we are forever indebted to him for sharing a vision and spirit that lights our path to a brighter tomorrow for future generations of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people. Judith E. Turkel, Esq President Richard D. Burns, Esq Executive Director Michael Seltzer Board Co-Chair Janet Weinberg Board Co-Chair Lesbian & Gay Community Services Center

The first two-thirds or so of the 90-minute performance-art piece are filled with groaning, trembling, lurching men and women dressed in handsome black-and-white period costumes. Inmates, perhaps, of some mid-19th century lunatic asylum, they act and re-enact fleeting scenes of violence, madness and stylized torture in a world haunted by shadows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIOT, RUTH YOUNG
description: ELIOT-Ruth Young. Died at home on August 23, 1997. A theatre lover all her life. She worked in the New Theatre League in the mid 1930's and The Group Theatre from 1935 to 1941, first as Executive Secretary, then as Associate Publicity Manager, and Associate Business Manager and Assistant to Director Harold Clurman. In 1941, she produced Marc Blitzstein's ''No for an Answer'', co-founded the Dollar Top Theatre and was the General Manager of the Suffern Summer Theatre. During World War II she served as Publicity Director for Russian War Relief. In her later career, she became Publicity Director for Dansk Designs and headed its ''Top-of-the-Table'' Fashion Division. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, Alfred, her children Elizabeth, Margaret and Stephen, and sons-in-law Irwin Sollinger and Mark Solomon, and daughter-in-law Suzanne Hammer Eliot, and by her brother David and sisters-in-law Roslyn and Shirley. The Jewels of her life were her grandchildren Jonathan and his wife Hillary, Jeremy, and Emily Ruth Sollinger, Peter, Andrew and Megan Eliot and Benjamin Joseph Solomon. Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, at 2 PM. Family will receive visitors at her home Tuesday, 5-8 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Avenue of the Americas, NYC 10036-2222.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULLOCK, AUGUSTUS GEORGE, II
description: BULLOCK-Augustus George, II. Age 88, died Friday, August 22, 1997. Mr. Bullock, born in Worcester, MA, was a longtime resident of Grafton, more recently of Dedham, where he lived for the past 15 years with his wife Gertrude (Carter) Bullock. Mr. Bullock leaves in addition to his wife, two sisters, Elizabeth Barton and Mary Johnson, and his brother, the late Francis Bullock, all of Worcester. Mr. Bullock was married to the late Mary (Baugh) Bullock of Philadelphia for 49 years and leaves their children: A.G. Bullock, Jr. of Princeton, MA, the late Rufus Bullock of Greenwich, CT, and Polly Primrose Bullock of Weston, MA, seven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. His extended family included three stepchildren: Katrina Cameron of Palo Alto, CA, Lewis Carter of Lincoln, MA, Rev. John Carter of Norwalk, CT, including numerous grandchildren. Mr. Bullock, the son of Rockwood H. Bullock and Elizabeth (Dewey) Bullock, was educated at Saint Mark's School in Southborough, MA, '27, and graduated from Harvard College in 1931. He remained active in both alumni associations and was Class Treasurer for Saint Mark's School. His professional career spanned 42 years with The State Mutual Life Assurance Company (Allmerica Financial). He joined the company as a securities analyst and retired as Vice-President, Treasurer, and Chief Securities Officer. In 1942 Mr. Bullock joined the Army Air Corps and served in the European Theater of Operations being separated as a Major. He was also Treasurer and Director of the Norwich and Worcester Railroad Co., Director of the Trust Committee, Mechanics Bank, Trustee and Chairman of the Finance Committee of Memorial Hospital, and Trustee of the Morgan Construction Company Pension and Profit Sharing plans. Besides Mr. Bullock's strong fmaily ties, he enjoyed skiing, sailing, woodsman and was an inveterate traveler. Burial will be private and a memorial service will be held at a future date. The Stanley R. Tippett Home, 920 South St, Needham, and the American Cancer Society are the family's choice for donations.

As instructed, quarterback Dave Brown is running Fassel's up-tempo offense faster and faster still. The painstakingly careful Fassel has even tested the sideline communications circuitry, gone over league uniform rules and coached his players on how to run onto the field before a game.

Girl Is Electrocuted on Railroad Tracks
description: An 8-year-old Queens girl on a family fishing trip along the Hudson River was electrocuted over the weekend when she crossed the Metro-North Commuter Railroad tracks in search of a place to go to the bathroom. The third rail that she somehow touched was packed with 600 volts of electricity.

description: It was like the sound a twist-off cap makes on a first turn, that faint release of all that is bottled up. All the uncertainty and self-doubt that had been stirring up inside the once feared and unfazed Liberty was let go last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKMAN, LUCILLE

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today, with the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks down 75.41 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 18,574.76, at the midday break. That followed a big drop on Friday, when the Nikkei fell 506.95 points.

title: Some cable networks keep the programming on during commercials to avoid channel surfing.
description: COMMERCIAL breaks used to be just that -- interruptions in programming to allow advertisers to pitch their products so networks could earn money to pay their bills. But in a day when the remote control is ubiquitous, zapping from station to station -- often during the commercial breaks -- is in vogue. Several cable networks, however, may have found a way to make viewers stay put.

title: Miscellany
description: * Bozell Worldwide, New York, part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, agreed to acquire a majority interest in ADV/Vazquez S.A. de Publicidad, Buenos Aires. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Fake Call to Police Backfires on the Suspect
description: A suspected drug dealer who phoned in a fake report of a police officer needing assistance served only to call attention to himself and the pound and a half of cocaine he had, the police said after arresting him.

title: Redefining Cafe Society, on Line
description: Sometime around early 1995, America's respective infatuations with coffee and cyberspace collided to form an improbable new hybrid called the cybercafe. Suddenly, before you could double-click on a double latte, they were everywhere, from the Octane Interlounge in Rockford, Ill., to the IDT Megabite Cafe in midtown Manhattan, hawking computerized cafeculture for $10-$15 an hour.

title: President's Photo Used in Fraud, Police Say
description: Executives of a jewelry company arranged for a photo opportunity with President Clinton at a fund-raiser in Florida last fall, then used the photographs to help win credibility and court vulnerable investors in what authorities say was a scheme that defrauded 15,000 people of $38 million.

title: Japan Sky Broadcasting and Rival in Deal
description: A fledgling Japanese satellite television venture in which Rupert Murdoch owns a big stake is expected to join forces with a rival, PerfecTV, according to an executive at the company.

title: Mary L. Smith, Only Woman To Lead G.O.P., Dies at 82
description: Mary Louise Smith, a representative of the Republican Party's moderate wing and the only woman ever to serve as chairman of the Republican National Committee, died on Friday at Iowa Methodist Medical Center in Des Moines. She was 82 and a longtime resident of Des Moines.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Laughter may be its own reward, but a public accolade, a figurative pat on the back from one of America's great humorists, a statuette and $5,000 aren't so bad, either.

title: CNN Expands at Airports
description: The Cable News Network plans to double the number of television monitors broadcasting its CNN Airport Network inside the New York area's three major airports by the end of the month.

title: Citified Steps and Stomps to Enliven a Country Evening
description: The 10 dancers and musicians in ''Jazz Tap/Hip-Hop,'' presented on Saturday night at the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here, could probably have done just about anything onstage by the end of the show and still kept drawing cheers from the delirious audience. And the central idea of the show, put together by Dance Umbrella of Boston, was first-rate. Not only did the program offer a savvy mix of tap and hip-hop dancing, but it paired two star performers who were as different as dancers could be.

title: Charged in Girlfriend's Death
description: A 24-year-old Sparta man was arraigned yesterday on a charge of murdering his girlfriend in an Atlantic City casino hotel room late last week.

title: E. F. Shannon Jr., 79, Dies; Forceful Chief of U. of Virginia
description: Edgar F. Shannon Jr., a former president of the University of Virginia who inspired both cheers and scorn for his outspoken opposition to the war in Vietnam in the early 1970's, died on Sunday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 79.

title: Facing the Peril of Earth's Cauldrons
description: PLANET Earth is planning some spectacular volcanic fireworks and millions of people worldwide are going to have ringside seats.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about President Clinton's vacation on Martha's Vineyard misspelled the surname of a writer who was at a birthday party he attended. She is Fran Lebowitz, not Leibowitz. In some editions, a picture caption with the article referred incorrectly to his golfing partner, the chief executive of the General Electric Company. The executive is John F. Welch Jr., not Jack Lynch.

title: Bank Divestiture Threatened
description: The president of the Newark City Council threatened yesterday to pull about $35 million in city funds from accounts at First Union National Bank to protest the bank's new policy of charging noncustomers to cash government checks, The Associated Press reported.

title: Can New Secretary Revive a Beleaguered Department?
description: Once the teamsters strike at United Parcel Service of America was settled last week, it was hard to find Alexis M. Herman. After the initial round of triumphant news conferences on the night of Aug. 18, Ms. Herman, the new Labor Secretary who played a widely praised role in keeping the talks going when both sides seemed ready to quit, just wanted to go on vacation.

title: General Mills Seeks New Creative Ideas
description: General Mills Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking creative ideas from two roster agencies for a cereal brand, Golden Grahams, that is handled by a third roster shop. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: As NATO Grows, Start 2 Shudders
description: The enlargement of NATO, although still in the initial stage, has already revived some traditional misunderstandings and created new misperceptions between Russia and the West.

title: Bosnian Serb Political Rivals Carry Duel to TV Airwaves
description: The signal went dead in the middle of today's episode of the Venezuelan soap opera ''Cassandra,'' the most popular program in this Bosnian Serb enclave.

title: Knicks Seem Close to Claiming Fox as Their Own
description: The Knicks are still in limbo over whether they can obtain the veteran center Chris Dudley, but they have not stopped shopping. Next on the check list is Rick Fox, a bargain-basement scorer who may be headed to New York in the next two days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, JANIS
description: DORFMAN-Janis. The Lord has given and the Lord has taken away, praised be the name of the Lord. As we mourn the untimely passing of Janis Dorfman, we are painfully reminded that life itself is but a loan. And so, as we come to grips with our mortality and the brevity of our lives, we can only look back with gratitude on the fond memories we have-and will always have-of this precious jewel entrusted to us. To our esteemed Board Members, Chai Founders, generous supporters, but most of all, cherished friends, Stanley and Evelyn Marks, and Janis' entire family, we offer our profound sympathy. Janis' incredible courage and determination is a legacy of inspiration for all. And, her family's love, care and devotion brought light where there was darkness, hope where there was despair. We pray that G-d will grant courage and strength to the bereaved family and help them rise above the painful sorrow which has befallen them. May G-d destroy death forever and wipe away tears from every face. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Rabbi Moshe Linchner, V. Chmn. Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. VP

title: New Ashe Stadium Opens With a Big First Serve
description: The weather cooperated, even if the Mayor didn't. Right on schedule, and brimming with the ambition of becoming the most progressive and impressive of the tennis world's four Grand Slam events, the United States Open got under way yesterday in Queens with a combination of glitz and grit.

title: O.W. Riegel, 94, Early Expert on Propaganda
description: O. W. Riegel, a journalist who turned an interest in propaganda acquired in Europe between the world wars into a career as a scholar and expert on the subject, died on Saturday at Stonewall Jackson Hospital in Lexington, Va. He was 94 and lived in Glasgow, Va.

title: After Jets Trim Down, Roster Is More Youthful
description: In a flurry of activity involving nine players, the Jets yesterday cut their payroll as well as the age of their roster and wound up with two rookies to handle the kicking game.

title: INTEGRION FINANCIAL ACQUIRES VISA'S INTERACTIVE UNIT
description: Integrion Financial Network said yesterday that it had acquired the assets and operations of Visa Interactive, the remote banking subsidiary of Visa International, the credit-card organization. Terms were not disclosed, although the companies said Visa International had received stock in Integrion, an interactive banking provider for financial institutions. Integrion, a closely held company, said the deal added more than 60 financial institutions to its customer base.

title: DOW SAYS SENTRACHEM ACCEPTS ITS BID OF $495 MILLION
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that Sentrachem Ltd. of South Africa had accepted a sweetened bid of 11.75 rand a share, or 2.32 billion rand ($495 million), paving the way for Dow to compete against the Monsanto Company's best-selling weed killer, Roundup. Sentrachem, a producer of agricultural and industrial chemicals, had rejected Dow's bid of 10.50 rand a share. The deal would be the largest purchase of a South African company by a United States company since the end of apartheid in 1994. It would allow Dow, which is based in Midland, Mich., to make a generic version of Roundup, the biggest-selling herbicide in the world, after Monsanto's United States patent expires in 2000. The patent has already expired in many parts of the world.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS AGREE TO SETTLE FLORIDA LAWSUIT
description: Faced with a potential legal catastrophe, major cigarette producers agreed yesterday to pay $11.3 billion to settle a smoking-related lawsuit brought by Florida officials and also to undertake a sweeping slate of public health moves there, regardless of the fate of the proposed national tobacco settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIER, LAURABELLE (NEE ROBINSON)
description: GRIER-Laurabelle (nee Robinson). After an extended illness, met with great bravery and courage, had a peaceful death on August 23, 1997. Widow of Robert S. Grier, mother of Lucy Feller and Patricia Weinberg, sister of Constance Wineman of Bloomfield Hills, Mi., sister-in-law of Marjorie Wazer and grandmother of Amy and Wendy Feller, Lisa Tarbox and Neil Weinberg, great grandmother of Haley Elizabeth Tarbox. She was a great inspiriation to us all and will always be remembered for her kindness, warmth and graciousness. We will miss her. Memorial service is private.

Giuliani's education record yesterday, asserting that the Mayor has been slow to address overcrowding in the schools, has cut education spending and has had little success in raising citywide reading scores.

description: The idea that cheap, bountiful energy can be produced by so-called cold fusion suffered another blow today when the Government of Japan said it would terminate its research, which has failed to confirm that the phenomenon exists.

title: Forecasters Begin to See Who Will Feel Effects of El Nino
description: AS the latest version of the powerful weather-maker known as El Nino develops into a giant of its breed in the tropical Pacific, forecasters are beginning to get a clearer idea of how and where its impact will be felt globally in the weeks and months ahead.

title: BIC S.A. RAISES OFFER FOR SHEAFFER GROUP BY $2 MILLION
description: Bic S.A. said yesterday that it had raised its offer for the closely held Sheaffer Group, the United States pen maker, by $2 million after Sheaffer's management made its own takeover bid. Bic, the France-based parent company of the Bic Corporation, signed an agreement on July 31 with Sheaffer's key shareholder, the Luxembourg bank Gefinor S.A., to buy Sheaffer, of Fort Madison, Iowa, for ''significantly less'' than Sheaffer's annual sales of about $50 million. On Aug. 22, Gefinor broke its agreement with Bic in favor of allowing Sheaffer's management to take over the company, Bic said.

title: Hilton Asks U.S. Court to Halt ITT Breakup
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation asked a Federal judge yesterday to block a plan by ITT to split into three companies by Sept. 22.

title: Comedy Wins Film Award At Urban World Festival
description: ''A Woman Like That,'' written and directed by 31-year-old David E. Talbert, was awarded the prize for best dramatic feature at the first Urban World Film Festival, a four-day gathering of mostly black filmmakers in New York that ended on Sunday.

title: Stop Stalling on Land Mines
description: This month the Clinton Administration rightly, though belatedly, decided to join more than 100 other nations working to adopt a draft treaty banning anti-personnel land mines. Regrettably, the Administration still insists on pressing for two Pentagon-sponsored exceptions that are likely not only to delay this Canadian-led initiative but, worse, to undermine the larger goal of drawing holdouts like Russia and China into a worldwide treaty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, HENRY LEROY

title: Mostly Mozart All Over, With Lesser-Known Works
description: The familiar works of the classical music repertory were, in their time, audacious contemporary compositions. But it's easy to forget this when they are performed today with such frequency and standardized competence. The hardest challenge interpretive musicians face is to bring a sense of newness and adventure to a performance of, say, Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique'' Symphony or Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Concerto. Yet this is the challenge that the Mostly Mozart Festival, by its very purpose, takes on every summer.

description: To the Editor:

description: There has long been a lively debate about who is the strongest player of all; prominent candidates are Bobby Fischer, Garry Kasparov, Jose Raul Capablanca, Alexander Alekhine or Emanuel Lasker. But there is no argument about the greatest female player: she is 21-year-old Judit Polgar of Hungary, the youngest of three amazing sisters.

description: Deep personal financial debt led the Mayor of Mahwah, N.J., David J. Dwork, to commit suicide in his township office on the night of Aug. 18, his widow, Johanna, said at a weekend memorial service.

description: The American public, alarmed by the discovery that 25 million pounds of its favorite barbecue food may have been contaminated with potentially lethal E. coli bacteria, can be reassured by Washington's quick action to get the meat recalled. Yet to guard against future episodes, the Federal Government must move as swiftly as it can to put a new regulatory system in place.

title: Half-Year Net Up 47% At German Publisher
description: The German publishing and broadcasting company Axel Springer Verlag A.G. had a 47.2 percent increase in net income for the first half of 1997, the company said yesterday. Profits rose to 118.5 million marks ($65.1 million) from 80.5 million a year earlier, while revenue climbed to 2.22 billion marks ($1.22 billion) from 2.13 billion, a 4.5 percent rise over the first six months of 1996.

description: Israel has decided to build a dam just inside the boundary of land claimed by Syria, officials said today, even though that step is bound to worsen prospects for peace between the two countries.

description: Gasoline prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, pulling crude oil to its lowest level in two months, on signs that domestic refinery output and overseas imports were growing just as summertime driving demand in the United States was expected to wane.
