title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIOT, RUTH YOUNG
description: ELIOT-Ruth Young. Died at home on August 23, 1997. A theatre lover all her life. She worked in the New Theatre League in the mid 1930's and The Group Theatre from 1935 to 1941, first as Executive Secretary, then as Associate Publicity Manager, and Associate Business Manager and Assistant to Director Harold Clurman. In 1941, she produced Marc Blitzstein's ''No for an Answer'', co-founded the Dollar Top Theatre and was the General Manager of the Suffern Summer Theatre. During World War II she served as Publicity Director for Russian War Relief. In her later career, she became Publicity Director for Dansk Designs and headed its ''Top-of-the-Table'' Fashion Division. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, Alfred, her children Elizabeth, Margaret and Stephen, and sons-in-law Irwin Sollinger and Mark Solomon, and daughter-in-law Suzanne Hammer Eliot, and by her brother David and sisters-in-law Roslyn and Shirley. The Jewels of her life were her grandchildren Jonathan and his wife Hillary, Jeremy, and Emily Ruth Sollinger, Peter, Andrew and Megan Eliot and Benjamin Joseph Solomon. Memorial Service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Tuesday, at 2 PM. Family will receive visitors at her home Tuesday, 5-8 PM. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Cancer Care, 1180 Avenue of the Americas, NYC 10036-2222.

He will complete his role as the host of CBS Sports's late-night program from the United States Open Tennis Championships and join ''Access'' on Sept. 8.

Consequently, Wall Street analysts see a potential for growth in the private utility companies that are steadily absorbing a bigger share of the water market by taking on the management of public water systems.

The arrangement's financial terms were not disclosed. U.S. Wireless provides wireless credit-card authorization systems. GTE Wireless said it would aim its data network at two million merchants in the United States, offering a complete system using their existing terminals.

title: Creating No. 1 Drug Wholesaler, Cardinal to Buy Bergen Brunswig
description: With many of their hospital, pharmacy and physician customers forging alliances that enhance their bargaining strength, drug wholesalers have been consolidating, too. In the latest deal, Cardinal Health Inc. agreed late on Sunday to buy the Bergen Brunswig Corporation for $2.41 billion in stock and to assume $386 million of debt. The purchase would create the nation's biggest drug wholesaler, with 31 percent of an annual $64 billion market.

title: What the Louima Case Says

title: NATIONAL CITY TO CLOSE OR REORGANIZE 200 BRANCHES
description: The National City Corporation of Cleveland plans to close or reorganize 200 of its 750 full-service branches in the next three years as it weeds out its least profitable offices. The bank expects to close or sell 30 offices, many in rural areas, that do not generate sufficient return on investment, National City's treasurer, Thomas Richlovsky, said yesterday. National City's plan was reported yesterday in American Banker. The bank will convert 110 full-service branches into ''bank express'' offices that require fewer employees and open 60 supermarket branches to double its in-store sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOKANSON, HANS
description: HOKANSON-Hans, 71. Born 1925, Malmo, Sweden. Died unexpectedly of massive heart attack August 19 at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. Longtime resident of East Hampton, L.I., he was a painter, sculptor, woodworker, furniture designer, with work represented in collections of the Metropolitan Museum in New York; the Brooklyn Museum; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, D.C.; the Smithsonian Institution; Storm King Art Center; Philbrook Art Center in Tulsa, Oklahoma; Guild Hall, East Hampton; The Konsthall in Malmo; Collection of Port Authority of New York and New Jersey; University of New Mexico; as well as many corporate collections such as the Chase Manhattan Collection. Burial was Saturday August 23 in a Zen Buddhist service held at Oakland Cemetery, Sag Harbor, L.I. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Bengt and Sven of East Hampton, in addition to a daughter and two sons, Jan and Hans Olaf from an earlier marriage, and seven grandchildren residing in Sweden.

Stein, Jr., friend and supporter of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. description: BECKMAN-Arthur. On August 23, age 90. Beloved husband of Alma and loving step-father of Randy, brother of Frank and uncle of Norma, Judy, Susan, Denise and Jonathan. We all mourn the passing of this kind and gentle man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, LORETTA
description: BLUM-Loretta, well-known Dallas fashion retailer, passed away August 23 after a brief illness. Loretta was highly respected throughout the fashion industry, both in the United States and Europe, for her innovative sense of style. She attended Ohio State University and Tobe Coburn in New York City. After graduation, she became a buyer for Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman-Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue. In 1975, she returned to Dallas to open her own women's specialty shops featuring many new American and French designers. She was still dressing the fashion-conscious ladies of Dallas at the time of her death. A celebration of her life is planned for a date to be announced.

description: It is one down and one to go for H. Wayne Huizenga's Republic Industries, the nation's largest car dealership owner.

description: The two main systems for producing oxygen on the Mir broke down today, presenting its three-man crew with a fresh setback just days after the crippled space station appeared to be on the road to recovery.

But with the Mets steadily evolving from contenders into mere witnesses to the National League pennant race, the time for the Mets to focus on 1998 is fast approaching.

description: Savannah Foods and Industries received a buyout offer today of $18.75 in cash and stock from the Imperial Holly Corporation, a 24 percent premium over Savannah's closing share price today.

title: Miscellany
description: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said the number of magazine advertising pages in July increased 5 percent from July 1996, to 14,426. For the first seven months of 1997, ad pages rose 5.1 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, to 124,032.

title: Man Who Taped Police Is Arrested on Old Charges
description: For most of the morning yesterday, James Schillaci, a limousine driver and amateur photographer, was appearing on New York City television stations, denouncing the police for what he says is a ticket trap. But the appearances brought him more than celebrity: They brought the police to his door in the early afternoon, a warrant and handcuffs in hand. By 3:15 P.M., he was again a free man, but with a second accusation about the police: harassment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBRIN, SIDNEY
description: KOBRIN-Sidney. On August 25, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Charlotte. Devoted father of Marjory and Dorothy. Dear brother of Selma Gorel. Services Wednesday 10AM at Garlick-Hellman Funeral Home, 1091 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donations to the Leukemia Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a settlement of breast implant litigation proposed by Dow Corning referred incorrectly in some copies to a professor at George Mason University School of Law who commented. He was David Bernstein, not Bernstin.

title: New Democracies, Old Police
description: Honduras's Congress voted last week to name the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop, Oscar Andres Rodriguez, to supervise the transition of its police from military to civilian control. Honduras is trying to demilitarize a police force widely considered to be inefficient, brutal and corrupt. Reaching out to the respected Archbishop -- who did not, in the end, take the job -- was a cry of desperation.

title: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY A HOECHST DRUG UNIT
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Hoechst Marion Roussel Inc.'s Rugby Group unit. Terms were not disclosed, but the companies said the agreement included an initial payment of $70 million, payments on certain products and a payment based on future operating results. Hoechst Marion Roussel, a pharmaceutical unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany, said the sale of Rugby marked its exit from the generic drug business. Watson Pharmaceuticals, based in Corona, Calif., said that Rugby's drugs would complement Watson's existing product line. The sale also includes Rugby's product development group, Chelsea Laboratories.

title: Free Passes Put Reed And Mets In a Hole
description: Bobby Valentine excitedly twirled the rewind button on his videotape machine, showing reporters after last night's game how San Francisco pitcher Wilson Alvarez had balked, how his hands had moved forward and his leg had moved back.

title: High Times In the Kitchens Of the Go-Go 80's
description: ALL in avant-black, razor thin, deadpan, downtown and not about to endanger the fastidious contour of her blood-red lipstick with a superfluous smile, Linda Yablonsky considered the neighboring tables at Restaurant 147 in Chelsea.

title: Tough Journalism
description: When I came to Panama in 1996, I expected to spend a few years engaged in rewarding but essentially peaceful journalism. With the handing over of the Panama Canal, it seemed to be the hour of destiny for Panama. In my view, there were few other places in the hemisphere that offered such rich opportunities for a chronicler of events. But I expected to be an observer, not a protagonist.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 19 about the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misstated the year that Dr. King's convicted killer, James Earl Ray, confessed and then recanted. It was in 1969, not 1968, the year of the killing.

title: Giuliani Is Said to Consider Stronger Police Review Board
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has frequently expressed his disregard for the Civilian Complaint Review Board, a New York City agency created to investigate allegations of police misconduct. Now, in the wake of allegations that police officers brutalized a Haitian immigrant inside a Brooklyn police station, the Mayor is sending a signal that he is willing to consider plans to strengthen the panel.

title: Interested In Islanders? Steinbrenner Won't Say
description: If George Steinbrenner really wants to extend his sports empire from baseball to hockey, that is fine with Charles Dolan, a cable television pioneer who now controls Madison Square Garden and the Rangers.

title: Minor Offenses
description: To the Editor:

title: South Koreans Sign Petitions To Aid North
description: Putting new pressure on the South Korean Government, religious groups here handed officials a huge stack of petitions today calling for increased food aid to North Korea.

title: Hypnotized by Mug Shots That Stare Back: Are They Windows or Mirrors?
description: What, if anything, does a portrait say about a person? The question comes to mind after looking at the mug shots of the Brooklyn police officers charged in the beating and sodomizing of Abner Louima. The images have become fixtures of the news, appearing day after day, as startling in their mundanity as the whole affair is shocking in its brutality.

title: Poor Ranking for Newark
description: Newark falls near the bottom of a list of cities judged for their quality as places to raise children, a survey released yesterday by Zero Population Growth said.

title: Now, That's Really Smoking
description: TAKE a sniff of the smoky aroma from backyards and balconies these days, and you are likely to catch a whiff of hickory or mesquite mingling with the fragrance of anything from shrimp to sausage, corn to rump roast. Across the country, smoke cooking has become a passion with outdoor chefs.

title: Janet Good, 73; Advocated the Right to Die
description: Janet Good, a longtime civil rights worker who cooperated with Dr. Jack Kevorkian to help terminally ill people die, ended her own life yesterday in her home in suburban Detroit. She was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, ADA
description: JAFFE-Ada. Age 101, on August 25, 1997. Wife of the late Berel. Former owner of the popular adult resort Plum Point in New Windsor, New York. Beloved aunt, great aunt, and great-great-aunt and friend to many.

title: Parcells Puts His Faith In Two Rookie Kickers
description: It hasn't happened in the National Football League since 1988. The Jets will be the first team in almost a decade to start the season with a rookie place-kicker and a rookie punter.

title: Thai Food's Brash Trinity Is Bolder When Grown at Home
description: Early in his career as a chef here, Mick Vann realized that it would be a challenge to duplicate the Thai cuisine he'd become infatuated with on visits to Los Angeles.

title: Ocean Dumping Area Closed
description: The Federal Government yesterday closed an ocean dumping area east of Sandy Hook and approved a method to cap the dump and a contaminated region surrounding it, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, PETER J.
description: UNGER-Peter J. On August 24, 1997. Resident of Southampton and New York. Beloved husband of Monica. He is also survived by a son George and two grandchildren of Wellington, Fla. Services private. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Southampton Fresh Air Home. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Father Tells Why He Turned His Son In to Police in Slaying Case
description: The father of the man charged with killing a New York City firefighter for sport said today that he turned his son in after learning that the son's girlfriend suspected him of the murder.

title: How a Family Tale Became a Word-of-Mouth Phenomenon
description: Before he became a novelist, Charles Frazier was a great reader and a man of the outdoors. He had walked the Andes as well as the mountains of his native North Carolina, where he lives on a farm near Raleigh and raises show ponies. In one sweep, his first novel, ''Cold Mountain,'' has won critical acclaim and astonishing popular success. On Sunday the book rises to the No. 1 position on the New York Times best-seller list, replacing Patricia Cornwell's latest Kay Scarpetta mystery.

title: Whitman Camp on the Attack
description: The campaign of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman stepped up attacks on her Democratic gubernatorial opponent yesterday when it began airing a radio advertisement blaming him for high auto insurance rates in the state.

title: Sparks Is Ill, And Sidelined 3 to 6 Games
description: The Giants' left cornerback, Phillippi Sparks, whose play with his fellow cornerback Jason Sehorn is considered a team strength, will miss from three to six games with a noninfectious form of viral hepatitis, the team announced yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: To mention the name CARROLL O'CONNOR is to summon up more than a quarter-century of memories of Mr. O'Connor playing Archie Bunker on ''All in the Family'' and ''Archie Bunker's Place,'' as well as Chief Bill Gillespie on the show ''In the Heat of the Night.''

title: Executive Changes
description: ABC INC., New York, named Peter E. Murphy senior vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Ronald J. Doerfler, who is resigning from the broadcasting company effective Oct. 31. Mr. Murphy was most recently senior vice president for strategic planning and development at Walt Disney Co., which acquired Capital Cities/ABC Inc. last year. Earlier this month, Mr. Doerfler said he was leaving to pursue other opportunities in corporate finance. He will remain at the company through January.

title: New Zealand Papers Buy Pay-TV Stake
description: Independent Newspapers Ltd., which is 49.5 percent-owned by the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, said today that it would buy a 48 percent stake in New Zealand's largest pay-television operator, Sky Network Television Ltd., for $199 million.

title: De Klerk Quits As Party Chief In South Africa
description: Former President F. W. de Klerk, who negotiated an end to apartheid but often seemed a lonely figure in recent years, trying without success to remake his National Party into a multi-racial organization, announced today that he had had enough.

title: Good News for UPN
description: Straining the definition of ''fall,'' UPN began its new fall season on Monday night, the first network to do so. Overnight ratings produced pretty good news for ''Good News,'' a new comedy about a black church and the travails of its new young pastor. Its 5.5 rating (each rating point represents 571,000 homes) was solid, even if earned against reruns on other networks. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: News of Deal With Toyota Sends Republic Shares Higher
description: Shares of Republic Industries surged 7.5 percent today, following the announcement that the company, the nation's largest car dealership owner, had reached an agreement with Toyota. Republic's shares had been in a slump since the spring, when Toyota and Honda began to fight vigorously over Republic's plan to buy car dealerships nationwide.

title: 'Ticking Time Bombs'
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore's Calls To Big Donors Number 86, Papers Show
description: Vice President Al Gore, who has played down his role in making fund-raising calls from the White House, was asked by the Democratic National Committee to make 140 fund-raising telephone calls and made 86, all from his White House office, according to documents that have been turned over to Congressional investigators.

title: Analyst Disputes the Savings Projected in a Hospital Merger
description: The merger of two of Long Island's largest hospitals would produce only $6.2 million a year in savings, not the $92 million in annual savings projected by the hospitals, a witness for the Federal Government testified in Federal court here today.

title: Mexico's Official Embrace of Press Chills as a Publisher Is Fined
description: A Mexican judge, ruling in a case that highlighted the new distance between the Government and the press, has found a prominent newspaper publisher guilty of criminal tax fraud but ordered him to pay only a nominal fine.

title: Mob Link Studied in Slaying of Officer at His Home
description: A New York City housing police officer died yesterday after being shot execution-style in front of his home in Brooklyn, and detectives said they were investigating whether the killing was carried out by members of the Colombo organized crime family.

description: On the hot seat for skipping the United States Open's opening night dedication ceremony Monday night inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, Andre Agassi showed up right on schedule last night and graced the new stadium with his newly pink presence.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A DAY IN A HOT SPOTLIGHT -- A Bronx man who was interviewed on television yesterday about what he says is a ticket trap was suddenly arrested on a 13-year-old warrant and then released, triggering a second complaint: harassment. B3.

title: Odiorne Wilde Adds 'Partners' to Name
description: Odiorne Wilde Narraway Groome in San Francisco has been renamed as a result of several changes in top management.

title: Sara Scranton Linen, Smith College Trustee, 84
description: Sara Scranton Linen, a member of one of Pennsylvania's best-known families who was a trustee of Smith College, died on Sunday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 84.

title: Readers' Patrician Home Celebrates Its 250th Year
description: Not to worry, my dear, said the cuff-linked or flowery-hatted and faintly lock-jawed supporters of the oldest officially chartered lending library in the nation, at their annual garden party here this evening.

title: At a Greek Restaurant, Oil in the Family
description: THE waiter pours olive oil on a little plate. Nothing special there. Olive oil began replacing butter in the 1980's, as Tuscan restaurants rolled in and olive oil won health experts' blessing.

title: Firm Discloses Talks With the S.E.C.
description: Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. is talking with the Securities and Exchange Commission to resolve the agency's possible legal action over its role in the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., in 1994.

title: Whitman Order Allows Some Legal Immigrants to Retain Food Stamps
description: New Jersey will continue to provide food stamp benefits to legal immigrants who are children, elderly or disabled even after the Federal Government stops paying for them next week, Whitman administration officials announced today.

title: Mobsters and Grand Opera (Sound Familiar?)
description: Try as he might to be a likable heroic type, Laurence Fishburne has always conveyed the icy gloom of a man who has gazed into the abyss and come away with a withering sense of disgust. Mr. Fishburne's cold, lidless stare and the hard curl of his lips suggest that while contemplating the void, he whiffed a stench so foul it left him permanently on the brink of nausea.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Korean Won Tumbles To a Record Low
description: The South Korean won tumbled to a record low yesterday as mounting bad loans and turmoil in Asian currency markets prompted banks and companies to buy dollars to insure they can repay foreign debt.

title: Knicks Lose the Bidding War For Fox, Who Heads to Lakers
description: The Knicks' chances of landing Rick Fox vanished yesterday when the free-agent small forward agreed to play with the Los Angeles Lakers instead.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 14 about Nazi influence in prewar and wartime Cologne referred imprecisely to the relationship of a German election and Hitler's rise to power. The election, in March 1933, took place after Hitler was named Chancellor but before he assumed dictatorial powers.

title: Reserve Bank to Make Building Fit Its Name
description: A dozen years after its completion, the building at 33 Maiden Lane will finally live up to its fancy designation -- Two Federal Reserve Plaza -- with the arrival in early 1999 of the first of 800 employees of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUSNER, MAX
description: KLAUSNER-Max. Beloved husband of Rebecca, loving uncle of Judah, Marc, Paul and April, Miriam, Leah and Robert. Adored great uncle, devoted brother-inlaw of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Jacober of London. Passed away this Tuesday, August 26, in N.Y.C. A Rodeph Shalom, he demonstrated great kindness, love and courage throughout his life and in his final days. He will be sorely missed by his entire family. Memorial services are to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 10:45 AM today, Wed. August 27, and Shiva will be observed at 140 Riverside Dr.

title: A Need for Strategic Truces
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was invited to two ceremonies this week, celebrating important milestones for New York City. He accepted one, declined the other, but managed to leave bad feelings at both. While neither action had any profound repercussions, they were reminders of Mr. Giuliani's difficulty in mastering the art of the small, gracious gesture.

title: Israeli Closing of Bethlehem Brings Tensions to a Boil
description: Black smoke billowed from burning tires and the crack of rubber bullets echoed through the streets of Bethlehem today as dozens of Palestinian youths hurled stones at Israeli soldiers to protest Israel's military closing of the town, which has now lasted nearly a month.

title: Firefighters Accused of Delay
description: City officials have scheduled a disciplinary hearing for six firefighters and their supervising lieutenant charged with responding too slowly to the Aug. 11 fire that destroyed an 87-year-old Y.M.C.A. building.

title: Paradise Lost in the Haze
description: For the past 60 years I have vacationed in Maine during the summer. One has only to visit the state to understand why city people like to spend as much time here as possible. The notion of escaping to a beautiful, unspoiled landscape was one of the things that first prompted my annual journey.

title: Food Notes
description: A Labeling Proposal Is Revived

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Earnings listing of Business Day yesterday misspelled the name of a company reporting results. It was Albertson's Inc., not Alertson's.

title: Union for Doctors to Join Forces With Government Workers
description: The Union of American Physicians and Dentists, one of the nation's few independent doctors' unions, plans to announce today that it will join forces with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, more than doubling the federation's physician membership.

title: QWEST PLANS $350 MILLION SYSTEM EXPANSION
description: Continuing the rapid construction of its $2.3 billion advanced fiber optic network, Qwest Communications International Inc. announced a $350 million project yesterday to extend its system deep into Florida and California. Qwest's shares rose $3.86, to $39.98, on the Nasdaq market. The new links should give the aggressive Denver start-up, which is controlled by the billionaire Philip F. Anschutz and run by the former AT&T Corporation executive Joseph P. Nacchio, a broader footprint for supplying its high-powered transmission to Internet service providers and phone companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, ALICE LEINHARDT
description: DEUTSCH-Alice Leinhardt. On August 24, 1997. Retired manager of Wage Administration at R.H. Macy & Co. Beloved wife of Dr. Norman. Loving mother of Dr. James and Mrs. Diana Deutsch, Andrew Deutsch, and Mrs. Nancy and Mr. Andrew Moloff. Devoted daughter of Helen Leinhardt and the late Benjamin R. Leinhardt. Cherished grandmother of Emily and Matthew Deutsch. Loving sister of Walter Leinhardt. Services Wednesday, August 27, 9:45AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: DEFECTING ENVOY FROM NORTH KOREA TO GET U.S. ASYLUM
description: The United States announced today that it would grant political asylum to North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, his brother and their families. Officials said American intelligence agents had spirited them out of Egypt and brought them to this country over the weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER SKLAREW, ROSE
description: ADLER SKLAREW-Rose. On August 24 in Delray Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of the late Harold, mother of Sandy and Barry, mother-in-law of Pat, stepmother of Tony, grandmother of Elissa, Neil and Caitlin. Service Wednesday 2PM at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Delray Beach. Sitting Shiva at the family home until Fri., noon.

title: WITH NO BUYER FOUND, MARK CROSS WILL BE CLOSED
description: The Sara Lee Corporation will shut down its Mark Cross leather-goods business and the unit's seven stores by February after failing to find a buyer for the business. The closing comes four years after Sara Lee bought the 152-year-old maker of handbags and briefcases and six months after the company started seeking a buyer for it. Sara Lee acquired Mark Cross, whose goods are also sold at some department stores, to fill a higher-end market than its Coach line was reaching, the company said. Instead, Coach has increasingly appealed to Mark Cross customers. The Mark Cross and Coach units had combined revenue of more than $500 million last year. Some Mark Cross stores may be converted to Coach stores, the company said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Trash-Devouring Sinks on Tap As City Lifts Ban on Disposals
description: After a short, perfunctory debate that included references to cockroaches, carrot peels, clogged pipes and a convenience long denied to New Yorkers, the City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to lift the ban on garbage disposals, which have been illegal in most city sinks for 26 years because of fears that they would overtax the strained sewer system.

title: Newark Accuses Workers Of Insisting Upon Bribes
description: Nearly two dozen Newark sanitation workers were arrested today and charged with demanding bribes before they would pick up trash from some residents and merchants, officials said. Three businessmen were also arrested, and a fourth was being sought, on charges of paying bribes for illegal pickups, they said.

title: Days of Wine and Neuroses: Woman Under the Influence
description: Blasting out of the past with a rush of crazy exhilaration, ''She's So Lovely'' is a go-for-broke tribute to John Cassavetes's free spirit. In a film made by Nick Cassavetes from a love-struck, stubbornly incorrect screenplay that his father wrote but never lived to direct, there is barely a thought that could survive a present-day opinion poll. That makes the defiance of this boozy romance all the more brazen and rare.

title: Council's G.O.P. Leader Faces Primary Challenge
description: In his six years on the City Council, Thomas V. Ognibene has been widely regarded as one of that body's most conservative members. A lawyer who represents Middle Village and Ridgewood, Queens, Mr. Ognibene has been a stalwart supporter of Ronald Reagan, Alfonse M. D'Amato and a host of other conservative politicians.

title: People
description: * Michael Miller was named manager at the Design Mill, Salisbury, N.C., a new graphic and apparel design division of Jordan Group. He had been president at Miller Designs, Salisbury, which closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHLAND, LOUIS C.
description: OHLAND-Louis C., August 25, 1997, of Jupiter Inlet Colony, Fla.; formerly of Lawrence and Lynbrook. Beloved husband of Harriett E. Dear brother of Elizabeth Karg and Charles Ohland. Longtime resident of East Hampton, L.I., he was a painter, sculptor, woodworker, furniture designer, with work represented in collections of the Metropolitan Museum in New York; the Brooklyn Museum; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, D.C.; the Smithsonian Institution; Storm King Art Center; Philbrook Art Center in Tulsa, Oklahoma; Guild Hall, East Hampton; The Konsthall in Malmo; Collection of Port Authority of New York and New Jersey; University of New Mexico; as well as many corporate collections such as the Chase Manhattan Collection. Burial was Saturday August 23 in a Zen Buddhist service held at Oakland Cemetery, Sag Harbor, L.I. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Bengt and Sven of East Hampton, in addition to a daughter and two sons, Jan and Hans Olaf from an earlier marriage, and seven grandchildren residing in Sweden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YUKER, DR. HAROLD E.
description: YUKER-Dr. Harold E. In sympathy: Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Harold E. Yuker, Distinguished Professor of Psychology, Director of the Center for the Study of Attitudes Towards Persons With Disabilities and former Hofstra Provost and Dean of Faculties. Dr. Yuker died on Monday, August 24, at age 73. For almost five decades, Dr. Yuker had been actively involved in the life of Hofstra University. In 1948 he began his professional career at Hofstra as a teacher in the Department of Psychology, and he became internationally recognized for his research dealing with attitudes toward disabled persons. He graduated cum laude with his DBA degree from the University of Newark, his M.A. degree in psychology from the New School for Social Research, and his Ph.D in social psychology from New York University. In grateful appreciation for his extraordinary service, dedication and generosity to Hofstra, the University named the Harold E. Yuker Reference Library in his honor in 1995. A funeral service will be held Thursday, August 28, 11 AM, at the Monroe Lecture Center at Hofstra University. A memorial service will be held on October 15 at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse. In recognition of Dr. Yuker's accomplishments, donations may be made to the Harold E. Yuker Distinguished Academic Scholarship Fund at Hofstra University. In tribute to the memory of Dr. Yuker, all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: MELAMINE, AN ASHLAND TARGET, SEEKS A BETTER OFFER
description: Melamine Chemicals Inc. is looking for an offer that beats Ashland Inc.'s sweetened bid of $14.75 a share, a company spokesman said. Melamine, a chemicals maker in Donaldsonville, La., let an Ashland deadline pass on Monday. The company said it was reviewing the Ashland offer as well as other options. On Aug. 15, Ashland raised its offer to buy the 77 percent of Melamine Chemicals it does not already own for $61.7 million in cash. The $14.75-a-share bid topped Ashland's initial offer, in June, of $12.50 a share. Ashland had asked Melamine to respond by Monday. Ashland, which makes Valvoline motor oil, has owned shares in Melamine since the company went public in 1987. Shares of Melamine closed at $16.1094 yesterday.

title: A Valuable Space Jalopy

But while prominent in the public eye, the mishaps this year are dwarfed by the benefits the station has yielded both for Russia and its partner in the effort, the United States. When the Russians shut down the station -- as they probably will within a year or so -- they will leave knowing that Mir has substantially advanced what we know about life and work in space and has paved the way for a trip to the nearest planets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON ELM, H. WALTER
description: Von ELM-H. Walter. Age 82, died peacefully on Sunday August 17 at Calvary Hospital in The Bronx, New York after a long illness. Born in Brooklyn, New York on March 19, 1915, he was the son of the late Margaret and Henry Von Elm, who was former President and Chairman of the Board of The Manufacturers Trust Company. He was graduated from the Choate School and Princeton University, Class of 1937. During World War II he served in the South Pacific as a Captain in the Army Air Corp. He spent his career in banking and retired as a Vice President of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. He was a member of The Everglades Club, The Cap and Gown Club at Princeton, The Princeton Club of New York and the University Club in New York, where he resided for many years. Mr Von Elm is survived by a sister Dorothy Putnam, of East Hampton, New York, a brother Charles Von Elm, of Forest Hills, New York, three nieces and two nephews. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, August 28 at 5:30 P.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Princeton University.

title: ALZA ACQUIRING THERAPEUTIC DISCOVERY FOR $100 MILLION

Alza, based in Palo Alto, Calif., is a pharmaceutical company. Therapeutic Discovery, also of Palo Alto, was formed by Alza in 1993 to develop new human pharmaceutical products. Its shareholders of record on Sept. 29 will receive about $12.30 a share. Therapeutic Discovery's class A shares were at $12.19 yesterday on the Nasdaq market, up 18.75 cents. Shares of Alza fell 43.75 cents, to $28.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

In June, Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, agreed to buy Paxson's 46 radio stations, 526 billboards, 2 minor-league teams and other assets for $693 million. It would not say why the changes were made. Clear Channel will also buy the two FM and two AM stations in West Palm Beach, Fla., that Paxson, which is based there, has agreed to buy from the American Radio Systems Corporation for $33 million.

So he chartered a vessel, filled it with his best vintages and crossed the English Channel to London to sell directly from the ship.

title: CUC REDUCES PRICES FOR BOOKS MEMBERS BUY ON LINE
description: CUC International Inc.'s on-line book unit disclosed price cuts yesterday aimed at stealing market share from Amazon.com Inc. and Barnes & Noble Inc. in the fledgling industry of electronic book selling. CUC's Book Stacks Unlimited said it would increase discounts to 40 percent off the suggested retail price for hardcover books and 30 percent off for paperbacks. The discounts apply to members of Net Market, CUC's electronic shopping site, and to members of the Frequent Buyer Club of Book Stacks. Shares of CUC fell 37.5 cents, to $24.375, while Amazon.com stock dropped 31.25 cents, to $27.8125. Barnes & Noble stock fell $1.875, to $45.625.

description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had licensed the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company to offer financial contracts that will enable investors to make bets on the direction of the Dow Jones industrial average.

description: Rick Hartmann, winner of the New York State Open this year, shot a four-under-par 68, the best round of the tournament, to move into first place today after two rounds of the Met Life/Metropolitan Golf Association Open Championship at the Plainfield Country Club.

title: Squeeze on Caddies Eases With Relief From the I.R.S.
description: Club caddies throughout the country didn't need the Internal Revenue Service to remind them of their vulnerability. It's tough enough for bag toters to fend off the threat posed by motorized golf carts. Then along came an I.R.S. field auditor looking into the employment records of a prestigious country club. Before long Congress stepped into the act and the issue became a political golf ball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOKANSON, HANS
description: HOKANSON-Hans, 71. Born 1925, Malmo, Sweden. Died unexpectedly of massive heart attack on August 19 at Southampton (Long Island) Hospital. Longtime resident of East Hampton, Long Island, he was a painter, sculptor, woodworker, furniture designer, with work represented in collections of the Metropolitan Museum in New York; the Brooklyn Museum; Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, D.C.; the Smithsonian Institution; Storm King Art Center; Philbrook Art Center in Tulsa, Oklahoma; Guild Hall, East Hampton; The Konsthall in Malmo; Collection of Port Authority of New York and New Jersey; University of New Mexico; as well as many corporate collections such as the Chase Manhattan Collection. Burial was on Saturday, August 23 in a Zen Buddhist service held at Oakland Cemetery, Sag Harbor, L.I. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sons Bengt and Sven of East Hampton, in addition to a daughter and two sons, Jan and Hans Olaf from an earlier marriage, and seven grandchildren residing in Sweden.

description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the world's largest maker of home electronics products, said today that net income rose 42 percent in the latest quarter, compared with a year earlier, lifted by strong sales of mobile telephones and video cameras as well as overseas sales.

title: Tobacco Pact in Florida Fuels Debate on National Accord
description: The abrupt $11.3 billion settlement of Florida's case against cigarette makers this week has stirred a sharp debate over whether to adopt the proposed nationwide tobacco accord or to continue the state-by-state lawsuits that have been humbling the tobacco industry.

title: Cleaner Gas Still Required

Instead, gas stations in the 13 northern counties will be required under Federal law to continue to sell the fuel for one more winter.

title: Motive Remains Mystery As Officer's Wake Is Held
description: As family, friends and fellow police officers gathered yesterday at a wake for Ralph C. Dols, the off-duty housing police officer who was gunned down execution-style on Monday night outside his apartment in Brooklyn, investigators continued to explore his widow's links to organized crime but said that they had not yet found a motive for the killing.

title: 4 Children Saved From Fire
description: A mother and her adult daughter were charged with child abuse and endangerment yesterday after their four children were rescued from a burning apartment where three of the children had been locked in a bedroom by using bent nails to hold the door shut.

description: Two Haitian organizations are expecting thousands of people to march from Brooklyn to Manhattan tomorrow morning to protest police brutality, and the demonstration has generated support from other civic and minority groups, officials said.

title: Schools Often Turn Bathrooms Into Classrooms

But for years, overcrowded districts throughout the city have used some of the bathrooms in their schools as classrooms and as offices for teachers and guidance counselors.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES AND BASF IN A DEAL TO SWAP BUSINESSES
description: PPG Industries said yesterday that it would acquire the packaging coatings business of BASF A.G. in a swap that would give the German company PPG's activities in surfactants, which are chemicals used to make detergents, cleansers, paper and textiles. Terms of the exchange were not disclosed. The Pittsburgh-based PPG, a maker of automotive and industrial coatings, said annual revenue for each business was about $150 million. BASF's packaging coatings business includes plants in Italy and the Netherlands and a marketing-technical center in Ohio. The PPG surfactants business has about 350 employees.

Services 10AM Friday, at Horne-Danneker. Burial at Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: Malaysia Takes Steps To Strengthen Economy
description: In a bid to shore up the property market and curb the widening trade gap, Malaysia said yesterday that it would end its levy on foreigners' purchases of property and would disclose ''tough measures'' to cut imports. ''I will have a definite plan to deal with the current-account deficit within several weeks,'' said the Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim. Mr. Anwar's statement is the strongest yet in Malaysia's attempts to reduce the widening current-account deficit, which puts pressure on the currency.

title: Valentine The Builder Is Rewarded
description: BOBBY VALENTINE got about as much as possible out of the flawed baseball team he has managed this season, but September is coming, the Mets have been reeling and the argument that they are still seriously in the wild-card race is unconvincing. A team that began the season generating as much expectation as a knock-knock joke thus finds itself fending off criticism for no longer having its shoulder squarely against the post-season door.

title: Miserable and Loving It: It's Just So Very Good to Feel So Very, Very Bad
description: Anhedonia, the inability to have a good time, plagues and exalts Radiohead, the English band that played a sold-out show on Tuesday night at Hammerstein Ballroom. When things are too easy, the songs grow suspicious; when misery arrives, it only confirms expectations. Other people can't be trusted, and the singer doesn't have much use for himself either. Yet the melodies keep reaching upward, searching for the grace that the world denies. ''I'm on a roll this time,'' Thom Yorke sang, facing a crowd that squealed with excitement, but the song could have been an elegy. Radiohead's concert, full of slow songs, minor keys and ominous undercurrents, had a brooding, bittersweet grandeur.

Peter Shelton and Lee Mindel, Manhattan architects, have turned the ship's aft atrium (above) into a soaring three-story entrance to the dining room. They also designed the dining room and lounges.

title: ETHYL TO BUY BACK 35 MILLION SHARES AND HALVE DIVIDEND
description: The Ethyl Corporation's board has approved a plan to buy back as many as 35 million shares, or about 30 percent of its stock in a Dutch auction, for as much as $324 million. The Richmond-based maker of specialty chemicals also said it would reduce its annual dividend by 50 percent, as cash flow from its lead additives declines faster than expected. In a Dutch auction, a holder specifies the minimum price it will accept to sell its shares, and a company determines a price that will allow it to repurchase as many shares as it wants. Ethyl is offering to buy the shares for $7.75 to $9.25 each. The company will reduce the dividend to 25 cents a share from 50 cents a share, beginning in the fourth quarter. The company's shares were unchanged at $9.

title: Jordan To Stay With Bulls
description: Whether it be 30 points or $30 million, Michael Jordan has no problem eclipsing the barrier. He did it again last night, signing on with the Chicago Bulls for at least one more season for what may be the richest annual salary in professional sports history.

title: Yankees' Torre Believes Umpires Are After Irabu
description: With some exasperation and disenchantment in his voice, Joe Torre expressed concern tonight that Hideki Irabu has become a marked man among American League umpires. While the Yankee manager claimed that he was hesitant to even discuss the delicate topic, he initiated the notion after questions about Irabu were broached before the Japanese pitcher took the mound tonight against the Oakland Athletics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARCZ, DEAN ERNEST
description: SCHWARCZ-Dean Ernest. Queens College, its President, Trustees and Alumni celebrate the life and mourn the death of one of the great figures in its sixty year history, our beloved Dean Emeritus Ernest Schwarcz. He died tragically on August 26, 1997 at the age of 76. Born in Hungary, a survivor of the Holocaust and a profound philosopher, he broadcast to the world remembrance, learning and compassion through tireless devotion to education for everyone at any age. As Dean of General Studies, he was a great builder of continuing education, ACE, the Center for Jewish Studies, the Jewish Lecture Series, Ethnic Studies, the Black-Jewish Dialogue, and programs in China and Israel. The respect and affection he commanded in our hearts and in the world at large are boundless. We share deeply in the grief of his wife Marta, always by his side and his true compass. He made Jewish Studies and humane studies at Queens College ''a garden of learning'' that will flourish forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNIGHT, GEORGE WILLIAM

Survived by his beloved wife of 60 years, Adelaide, son George William Jr., grandchildren Jim, Glen, Sara, and Kathryn Knight, brother Ridgeway. He graduated from Sorbonne University and earned an MBA from Harvard. He is the youngest son of Aston Knight, famous landscape artist. He worked as an investment broker and philanthropist. His hobbies included tennis, bridge, stamps, and golf. He served on the Salvation Army Board and as a Trustee of Cornell University. Memorial service will be held Friday, Sept. 5, 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: The Salvation Army, attn: Col. title: Claim Filed On Job Death At Workfare
description: The family of a welfare recipient with a history of heart disease who died last month while on a mandatory work assignment has filed a $10 million claim against New York City, charging that officials administering the workfare program failed to evaluate the woman's health adequately.

title: Looking Back in Central Europe
description: ''When Americans say something is history, that means it's irrelevant,'' the Polish journalist Konstanty Gebert likes to say. ''When we say it, it means just the opposite.'' The Communist past is still very much present in Poland and Germany, which have recently taken controversial measures to punish Communist officials and collaborators. Germany's conviction of three East German leaders for shootings at the Berlin wall and Poland's new law to bar secret-police collaborators from government jobs raise questions about both nations' commitment to the rule of law.

She will also be missed by her many dear friends in NYC & San Diego, CA. She was a graduate of the Sorbonne in Paris and an economist. She was also a permanent consultant at the World Federation of Trade Unions at the United Nations and a social worker. We will miss her greatly. Her courage, intelligence, knowledge and wise counsel will leave a deep void in us all. May her soul rest in peace. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Noranda Puts Mill on Sale
description: Noranda Forest Inc. said today that it was looking for a buyer for its only newsprint mill, which it said was too small to compete against the big newsprint makers. The mill, in Masson-Angers, Quebec, can produce 213,000 metric tons of newsprint a year. It generated the equivalent of $115 million in revenue last year. The Toronto-based Noranda Forest makes a range of specialty papers as well as plywood-substitute and panelboard.

description: Gasoline and crude oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as reports of an operating problem at a large Amerada Hess Corporation refinery in the Caribbean overshadowed data showing an unexpected rise last week in United States gasoline inventories.

title: A Really Old Noise Band Makes a New York Debut
description: In the 1960's the idea that improvised sounds could be music occurred to groups around the world. One was the Nihilist Spasm Band from London, Ontario, which started as a kazoo band in 1965, soon turned to homemade and plugged-in instruments, and has been playing regular Monday night shows for three decades, which probably makes it the oldest continuously operating noise band around. It made its New York debut at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night.

title: Forever Under a Cabin's Magic Spell
description: I LOVED the fireplace as a boy, the sunset glow of its copper hood with the embossed legend, ''If You Be Here a Friend You Needs Must Be'' -- Chaucerian English, my parents said -- and how firelight dappled the cottage's beams, hewn logs, ladder stairs and iron window screens, creating a mood of unreality. We called our cottage the Gatehouse, as it secured the foot of a modest driveway rising to a larger house, our residence, which overlooked the Potomac.

title: Sergeant Major Says Army Investigators Induced Accusers to Lie
description: In sworn statements released today, the Army's top enlisted man offered his most complete response so far to sexual harassment charges, saying each of his six accusers had been encouraged to lie by investigators to support a racist scenario they had concocted in which he, a black man, had lusted after the women because they were white.

title: PHILIP MORRIS PLANS TO CONSERVE CASH FOR SETTLEMENT
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would not increase its quarterly dividend so it could conserve cash for the tobacco industry's proposed national settlement of health-related lawsuits. Philip Morris, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, is expected to pay about half of the settlement, which would cost $368.5 billion over 25 years. The company said in July that it might reconsider its dividend and stock buyback plans because of the agreement currently before Congress. The company's shares were up 12.5 cents, to $45.375. The company said its board had approved a regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share payable Oct. 10 to shareholders of record on Sept. 15.

title: Wal-Mart Picks Kodak Kiosks
description: The battle continues between the Eastman Kodak Company and its archrival, the Fuji Photo Film Company, for the hearts -- and pocketbooks -- of the customers of Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ELLIOT
description: FRIEDMAN-Elliot, 72, Municipal Bond Pioneer. Elliot Friedman of Palm Beach, Florida, formerly of South Orange, N.J. died on August 26, 1997. He fought a twelve year battle with lymphoma. He was the first Chairman of the Board of J.B. Hanauer & Company, one of the oldest municipal bond firms in the country. He retired in 1981. He started at Hanauer as an office boy in 1947, immediately after his graduation from Rutgers University. Mr. Friedman was born and raised in Newark, N.J., and is survived by his wife of fifty years, the former Anita Engber and by two daughters-Deborah of NYC and Shelly of West Palm Beach. Mr. Friedman was active in community and educational organizations serving on the board of the Essex County College and was a past president of Temple Sharey-Tefilo-Israel Men's Club. He was Man of the Year of the Hebrew Youth Academy in Newark, as well as the first appointee of the Essex County Improvement Authority. Mr. Friedman was an original member of High Ridge Country Club in Palm Beach, and had been a member of Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, New Jersey for thirty-five years.

title: Board Bars Strike At U.P.S. Through 1997
description: The National Mediation Board has prohibited United Parcel Service pilots from striking until at least 1998, easing fears of a disruptive holiday walkout. The mediation board said it would not allow the pilots or the company to disrupt U.P.S. operations this year.

title: More Questions About Incentives To Get Those on Welfare to Work
description: It seems like an idea that no one could fault: let welfare recipients keep more of their benefits when they get jobs, and more of them will get jobs. Indeed, the idea has so much appeal that at least 30 states are now trying it as part of their new welfare programs.

description: A man opened fire into a crowd of people in front of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday afternoon, killing a 30-year-old man and wounding five bystanders, the police said.

title: Muster and Majoli Can't Take the Pressure
description: The clay of Paris has been kind to them; it is the reason they are both Grand Slam champions. But these metropolitan hardcourts have been harsher, and yesterday Iva Majoli of Croatia, the 1997 French Open champion, and Thomas Muster of Austria, who ruled the roost at Roland Garros in 1995, were drummed out of contention at the United States Open in back-to-back upsets at the wind-blown Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: A.I.G.-UNIBANCO IN $500 MILLION INSURANCE DEAL
description: American International Group said yesterday that it would pay Uniao de Bancos Brasileiros S.A. about $500 million to form a venture in Brazil, in a bid to tap an insurance market that it expected to grow at double-digit rates in coming years. A.I.G. and Unibanco, Brazil's third-largest non-state bank, will combine their insurance interests in Brazil by exchanging shares of the insurance unit Unibanco Seguros S.A. with shares of A.I.G.'s life and general insurance companies. The $500 million that A.I.G. will pay Unibanco, based in Sao Paulo, represents the difference between the value of 50 percent of Unibanco Seguros and 50 percent of A.I.G.'s Brazilian insurance operations. In trading before the deal was announced, the stock of A.I.G. dropped $1.50, to $96.125.

Taylor Lisk and Kent Rainey Lisk of Westwood, CA., Glenn S. Aston-Reese, Jr. of Washington, PA, David M. Aston-Reese of NYC and Woodstock, NY, Elyse A-R Bertucci of Ishpeming, MI., and William F. title: BANDAG TO PAY $158.5 MILLION FOR 5 RETREAD TIRE DEALERS
description: Bandag Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire five franchised Bandag retread tire dealerships for $158.5 million. Bandag, based in Muscatine, Iowa, makes retreading materials and equipment for independent dealers. The dealerships had 1996 sales of $366 million, or 6 percent of the Bandag dealer network's sales, the company said. Bandag had 1996 sales, exclusive of franchisees, of $756.9 million. The company will form a subsidiary to oversee the dealerships, which are in Nashville; Columbia, Miss.; Wheat Ridge, Colo.; Oklahoma City, and Auburn, Wash.

description: HARVIE-J. Beverly Jr. Of Nyack, NY and Chatham, MA, at home in Chatham on August 26. title: Al Gore Meets the Enemy
description: In legal terms, it does not really matter whether Vice President Al Gore made only a few fund-raising calls from the White House, as he first suggested in March, or the 50 his office later contended, or the 86 now acknowledged. Whatever the number, the calls were repugnant. Witness Mr. Gore's obvious embarrassment during his legendary ''no-controlling-legal-authority'' news conference. Notwithstanding his loophole defense, it still looks to us as if using the White House to make such calls collided with the spirit and the language of the Federal law against fund-raising on Federal property. In any event, the ''controlling legal authority'' to decide the issue ought to be an independent counsel, not Mr. Gore or the nation's oblivious Attorney General, Janet Reno.

title: The Subway to Nowhere, No Time Soon
description: For two grueling decades, in the place where drive-through banking was invented and where people think nothing of driving 45 minutes to see a movie, a convenient, reliable subway system has remained an elusive dream.

title: To Ease Crisis, Israel Lifts Bar To Bethlehem
description: Israel announced an end to a four-week military blockade of the West Bank city of Bethlehem today, removing a small but important irritant in the Israeli-Palestinian partnership.

title: REYNOLDS TO BUY 26% STAKE IN BRITISH COMPUTER SUPPLIER
description: The Reynolds & Reynolds Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 26 percent interest in Kalamazoo Computer Group P.L.C. of Britain for $35 million. Reynolds & Reynolds, based in Dayton, Ohio, provides information-management systems. Kalamazoo supplies computer systems to automotive dealers and software to specialist markets in Britain. Reynolds said two of its executives would be added to the Kalamazoo board. It shares gained 31.25 cents yesterday, to $19.50.

title: CARRAMERICA TO BUY TEMPORARY OFFICE SPACE PROVIDER
description: The CarrAmerica Realty Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Omnioffices Group Inc., a temporary office space provider, for $50 million in cash. The deal comes as real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, expand beyond their traditional business of owning and managing commercial real estate. The Washington-based CarrAmerica is one of the largest United States owners and operators of office properties. The Atlanta-based Omnioffices, with 325 employees, has 28 executive office suites in 14 markets. The suites contain about 20,000 square feet of space in an office building, which Omnioffices slices into as many as 70 individual offices.

title: A Contest Is the Mother Of 16 Inventions
description: IMAGINE a self-locking bicycle, a patio umbrella that won't blow over in high wind and in-line skates with training wheels. These patented designs are among the 16 semifinalists for Hammacher Schlemmer's Search for Invention contest. Hammacher Schlemmer, the purveyor of gadgets (pop-up toaster, 1930; steam iron, 1948; microwave oven, 1968), will show the 16 prototypes on Sept. 10 in its Manhattan store, 147 East 57th Street. Five winners will be named, with the grand-prize winner getting $5,000 and the four others $1,000 each.

title: How Not to Run a Campaign
description: Most campaigns have bumps and smooth spots. So far, Ruth Messinger has demonstrated a self-destructive talent for avoiding the smooth spots. The latest tactical clunk in her race for the Democratic nomination in New York City's mayoral election is a commercial on schools, her signature issue, that manages to be both misleading and depressing. It shows a class of public school students crammed into a bathroom so tiny the students seemed to be sitting on and around a urinal. Filmed from above, with an opening shot of a doleful-eyed little girl who seems to be doing her lessons while hunkered on the floor near the toilet, the scene is arresting. It was also staged -- in a private school, no less. Ms. Messinger's campaign manufactured an illustration of school overcrowding that is worse than anything in the city's system. By exaggerating, she manages to trivialize the horrific reality.

title: Boots of Britain Selling Home-Improvement Unit

Boots, Britain's largest drug retailer, said it would take a one-time charge of $:180 million, about $288 million, on the sale; A. G. Stanley Holdings, a company set up for the acquisition by the London-based venture capital group Alchemy Partners, is paying a nominal sum.

That development created a virtual washout of the day session and turned the Open's already complicated scheduling process into a madcap game of musical courts. Even Pete Sampras, this Grand Slam's defending champion, suffered through a relocation and demotion in order to restore order to the courts.

title: Immigrants Are Detained
description: When 55 illegal immigrants, most of them Mexican, arrived for work at seven Monmouth County businesses on Wednesday morning, agents from the Immigration and Naturalization Service were waiting for them. The immigrants, including 12 women with children, were led away in plastic handcuffs and told they could leave the country voluntarily or plead their case before a Federal immigration judge in the next two weeks, Lynn Durko, a spokeswoman for the agency, said yesterday. So far, 38 have agreed to leave, she said. The mothers were released to be with their children Wednesday, but the rest of the immigrants were still being held yesterday at a detention center in Elizabeth. The businesses involved, which had been under surveillance for several weeks, could face fines of up to $2,000 for each immigrant hired without documentation, Ms. Durko said.

title: Doctors Rush Beating Victim To Surgery

title: Teamsters and Democrats
description: After decades of corruption and mob influence, the teamsters' union has not had an easy time cleaning up its reputation. It would thus be a sickening irony if those involved in the union's latest problems turned out to include the Democratic Party. What has come to light so far suggests that a scheme was at least discussed in which the Democratic National Committee would raise money to help Ron Carey, the teamsters' president, in his re-election campaign last year in return for teamsters' contributions to the Democrats.

title: CRESCENT TO BUY 3 TEXAS PROPERTIES FOR $489 MILLION

Crescent, a Texas-based real estate investment trust, said the properties included Houston Center, which consists of three office buildings, a 399-room Four Seasons Hotel with luxury apartments and 20 acres of undeveloped commercial land. Crescent is buying the property from the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago. Other properties are the United States Home Building, an office building in the West Loop-Galleria suburban office area near Houston, and Fountain Place, a skyscraper in Dallas. Crescent had 1996 revenues of $208.8 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARCZ, ERNEST
description: SCHWARCZ-Ernest. The President and Faculty of Touro College in New York and Jerusalem, deeply mourn the tragic passing of Professor Schwarcz, a devoted and esteemed friend and guide. Dr. Schwarcz was a quintessential religious Jew, a profound student of the Talmud, a unique builder of Jewish Studies in many continents, a pioneer in Black-Jewish dialogue and a specialist in Chinese education. We deeply loved Ernest for his decency and extraordinary readiness to help his friends and all educational institutions in addition to his direct professional responsibilities. We are saddened by the loss of this extraordinary intellectual leader, a most decent human being and the void that he leaves. Our condolences to Martha, his beloved and devoted life partner. Dr. Bernard Lander

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARNEY, NORMAN A.
description: VARNEY-Norman A. Born in Boston in 1922, he attended The Tilton School and Duke University, graduating in 1943. He served as a lieutenant on active duty in the US Navy until 1945, as a member of a minesweeper support group. He then joined the J. Walter Thompson Company, where he spent his professional career. As a Senior Vice President, he had an important role in the establishment of the New York Mets and Toronto Blue Jays Baseball Clubs. He retired in 1987. title: HECHINGER ACCEPTS REDUCED OFFER FROM LEONARD GREEN

The original offer of $3 a share, or $126.6 million, was contingent on the company's meeting certain earnings goals in the second quarter. The offer for all outstanding class A and class B shares was made on July 17. The class A shares closed at $2.125 yesterday, down 50 cents, while the class B shares were at $2.25, down 56.25 cents. Leonard Green plans to combine Hechinger with the Kmart Corporation's Builders Square chain and create the nation's third-largest home improvement chain, after Home Depot and Lowe's Companies.

title: No G.I. Role Seen in Arrests Of Bosnian War Suspects
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, tried to end speculation today that American troops were preparing to join a NATO mission to apprehend major war-crimes suspects in Bosnia, insisting again that American soldiers would be ill-suited for the role.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZLOTNICK, MARTIN
description: ZLOTNICK-Martin. Beloved husband and father and step-father, died August 26, at Georgetown University Medical Center (24th of Av). In his 47 year career he worked in research and development of aircraft, missile defense, energy technology and policy research. At various times he was afflitated with Nichols Research Corp, ABMDA, DOE, AVCO and Hudson Institute. His publications appeared in ''Science,'' ''Omni'' and technical jounals. He is survived by his wife Ruth and children Hila, Cheryl, Adam, Daniel, Naava, Tali and Debra. Donations in his memory may be made to Kesher Israel Congregation, Washington, DC.

title: For Children
description: 'Canada Speaks for Children'

title: INSIDE
description: Economic Growth Jumps

title: Tied Up in a Stupid Scheme To Attract Daddy's Attention
description: Looking a few pounds heavier and wearing more eye makeup in ''Excess Baggage'' than in her star-making hit, ''Clueless,'' Alicia Silverstone suggests an Aubrey Beardsley caricature of a Valley Girl with a touch of Brunnhilde. The petulant curl in her lips has deepened into a sculptured cleft. And the changes are enough to have altered Ms. Silverstone's idealized everyteen image. Now she is a surreal, zaftig everyteen who seems eerily larger than life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, HENRY LEROY JR.
description: FINCH-Henry Leroy Jr. The War Resisters League mourns the death August 22 of Roy Finch, passivist of integrity and courage, W.W. II CO, editor of Liberation and WRL Chair, 1953-59.

title: Judge Says Show May Go On
description: A Superior Court judge refused yesterday to block a rap concert planned for tonight, despite concerns from township officials who said the site was ill-equipped to handle the crowd.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Twenty years after TED TURNER sailed the 12-meter yacht Courageous to victory in the 1977 America's Cup races off Newport, R.I., he will once again take the helm of the sailboat in a reunion with his 10-man crew.

title: Accounts
description: * Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to Richards Group, Dallas, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were not disclosed. Also, Maxfli Golf, Greenville, S.C., part of the Dunlop-Slazenger Sports Corp., to Richards/Shutze, Atlanta, an affiliate of Richards Group, to handle advertising, which had been handled by that agency on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Ex-Employee Pleads Guilty In Taking of Kodak Data
description: A former employee of the Eastman Kodak Company pleaded guilty today to a felony charge of transporting stolen property in a case in which Kodak accused him of taking trade secrets worth millions of dollars and trying to build a business on selling them to Kodak competitors.

title: Robert Switzer, Co-Inventor Of Day-Glo Paint, Dies at 83
description: Because Bob Switzer fell off a loading dock as a teen-ager six decades ago, Allied troops were not accidentally bombed by their own planes during World War II, boxes of Tide detergent glow on supermarket shelves and black light is big at rock concerts.

title: A Plaza In Motion And Alive With Color
description: Shifting pink and orange gauze screens ''parallel the human body as sound source and moving image,'' said the program notes for ''Red Squalls II,'' a dance by Gus Solomons Jr. that was presented by the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival on Wednesday afternoon. The band got its marching orders via the gestures of the conductor and the performers. ''Red Squalls II'' had most of the accouterments of dance chic, but the piece was more than that.

title: The Science Center Keeps Things Buzzing
description: ALMOST every day, from 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., dozens of F-15 jet fighters take off unnoticed from an obscure base in northern New Jersey. Hurtling at speeds as high as Mach 2.5, they often buzz landmarks like the George Washington Bridge and threaten to rattle the torch out of the Statue of Liberty's hand. Occasionally, one of the young pilots has to be reminded that his mission is not to obliterate some unsuspecting town.

title: GENESEE & WYOMING SAYS IT WILL BUY AUSTRALIAN RAILROAD
description: Genesee & Wyoming Inc. said yesterday that a group it was leading would pay $42.3 million for Australia National Railways' S.A. Rail intrastate freight and maintenance business in southern Australia as part of the breakup of the Australian Government-owned railroad. The purchase is Genesee & Wyoming's first foray outside North America. It operates more than 1,500 miles of track in New York and five other states and provides industrial switching services throughout the United States. The company, based in Greenwich, Conn., also operates a railroad in Canada with a joint venture partner.

title: Schools Emerge as Campaign Battleground
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger skirmished yesterday over who was responsible for classroom overcrowding in New York City, issuing their attacks in separate visits to what is becoming the backdrop of choice for this year's campaign: the public schools.

title: Natural Gas Prices Up Sharply On Concerns Over Stockpiles
description: Natural gas prices rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on concerns that supplies of the fuel were not being stockpiled fast enough to prepare for the winter heating season.

title: 2 Top Executives Leaving Valuevision
description: Valuevision International Inc. said today that its top two executives would step down and that the company would consider options including a merger.

title: U.S. Suspects Russia Set Off Nuclear Test
description: The Clinton Administration said today that Russia might have detonated a nuclear weapon on a remote Arctic island less than two weeks ago, in spite of its support for an international moratorium on nuclear tests. The Administration said it was investigating the matter and seeking an explanation from Moscow.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the march today protesting police brutality, which is expected to attract thousands of people, roadways across downtown Brooklyn and near City Hall will be clogged. Traffic delays are expected in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn Bridge from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and around City Hall and the Manhattan side of the bridge between noon and 6 P.M. The march is to begin about 10 A.M. at Grand Army Plaza and head down Flatbush Avenue, turning west on Tillary Street, crossing the Brooklyn Bridge on the pedestrian walkway and moving north on Park Row, west on Chambers Street and south on Broadway. It is to conclude at the southern end of City Hall Park.

title: A Fictional President
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINDLER, ALBERT B.
description: SHINDLER-Albert B. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Beth (Carlos) Marques and Ilene (Barry) German. Cherished grandfather of Jesse, Daniel and Noah. Fond brother of Robert (Elaine). Dear brother-in-law of Florence Goldstein. He taught us all the meaning of courage and the spirit of honor and dignity. He enriched us with his gentle spirit, love and friendship. We will miss him always. Services today 12 noon, ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: In East Village, a Spirited Pace for Rental Project Development
description: With strong demand for rentals in Manhattan continuing, development activity is spreading into the East Village, where a nine-story apartment building is under construction and a seven-story structure has just opened for leasing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFBERG, ROSE
description: HOFFBERG-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Laura Rubin and Eileen Hoffberg. Loving sister of Ann Goldberg, Alex Gerson and Sidney Gerson. Cherished grandmother of Caroline and Jake. Esteemed member of Brighton Beach Jewish Center and Amit Women. Graveside services 11:00 AM, Friday at The New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Drug Companies in Lawsuit
description: A Federal appeals court has reinstated a pharmaceutical joint venture and five drug wholesalers in a class-action lawsuit filed by thousands of the nation's pharmacists, who accused the companies of conspiring to fix prices.

title: Forego, Injured, Is Put Down at 27
description: He as a huge horse who stood 17 hands high and he suffered from a chronic ankle inflammation throughout his career. But he raced 57 times, won 34 times and was voted Horse of the Year 3 times.

title: Clodomiro Almeyda, 74, Ally Of Allende Jailed by Pinochet
description: Clodomiro Almeyda Medina, an important leftist figure in Chile, died on Monday at his home in Santiago, Chile, after a long battle with colon cancer, his family said. He was 74.

title: Parcells Pulls Late Switch on Punters
description: After watching his rookie punter for only two days of practice, Bill Parcells had seen enough. So today he cut Todd Kurz and brought back the incumbent, Brian Hansen, whom he released on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOIES, DAVID
description: BOIES-David. The trustees, administration, physicians and staff of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center note with sadness the passing of David Boies, father of David Boies, a distinguished trustee of the Hospital Center since 1990. Deepest sympathy is extended to the family. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Ronald C. Ablow, MD, President

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day.

title: Divorce And Our National Values
description: How shall we resolve a marital crisis? Consider an example from the advice column of Ann Landers. An ''Iowa Wife'' wrote to ask what she should do about her husband's habit, after 30 years of marriage, of reading magazines at table when the couple dined out. Ann Landers advised the wife to engage her husband by studying subjects of interest to him.

title: New Jersey and New York Plan Harbor Cleanup
description: The Governors of New York and New Jersey joined with Federal environmental officials yesterday to unveil an ambitious plan to help restore and protect New York Harbor, the rivers and streams that empty into it, and the ocean waters stretching from Montauk Point, N.Y., to Cape May, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, HARRY
description: LEVY-Harry. Formerly of Woodmere, New York. Loving husband of the late Estelle (Mayer). Cherished father of Andrea and Dr. Sheldon Greenberg. Beloved Pop-Pop to Matthew and Joshua. Retired President of Louis Levy & Son. Graveside services at Knollwood Cemetery, Queens, New York at 11 AM today. Shiva will be observed at the Greenberg residence, 4 Northfield Drive, Westport, Connecticut. 06880. Contributions may be made in his memory to: AMC Cancer Research in care of Andrea Greenberg at the address above.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUN MICROSYSTEMS INC., Palo Alto, Calif., laid the cornerstone for a computer research and administrative center in Burlington, Mass., that is expected to create 3,000 jobs.

title: Son of Late Commerce Chief Admits Illegal Political Gift
description: The son of Ronald H. Brown, the late Commerce Secretary, pleaded guilty today to a misdemeanor charge that he illegally funneled $4,000 from an Oklahoma company into the Senate campaign of Edward M. Kennedy three years ago.
