title: Crew Says Violence Declined in City's Schools Last Year
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that reports of assault, weapons possession and other serious offenses in New York City's public schools fell during the last school year, but that reports of less serious offenses like disorderly conduct and harassment rose, particularly in elementary schools.

title: Deal Spotlights New Shrewdness in Detective Business
description: Jules B. Kroll has made a career of directing delicate and confidential investigations. Most often his clients have been foreign governments, major Wall Street firms and the biggest corporations.

title: Barnett Banks In Florida Said To Seek Buyer
description: After years of insisting that it wanted to remain independent, Barnett Banks, the largest banking company in Florida, has decided to auction itself off to the highest bidder, merger advisers said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a California doctors' union that is affiliating with a larger labor group misstated the influence of the smaller union. The Union of American Physicians and Dentists represents 7 percent of the state's practicing doctors, not 20 percent, according to the California Medical Association. The article also misstated the total number of unionized doctors. It is 30,000, not 45,000.

title: Marvel Says Its Liquidation Is a Possibility
description: Marvel Entertainment Group may seek liquidation, among other options, if it cannot soon produce a plan to emerge from bankruptcy, the comic book company's lawyers said today.

title: Traffic Deaths Decline
description: In the four months since the state police and the New Jersey Division of Highway Traffic Safety launched a campaign against aggressive drivers, traffic deaths in six target counties have dropped, Peter Verniero, the State Attorney General, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, BROTHER BONIFACE JAMES IBRAIMAH ADAMS
description: ADAMS-Brother Boniface James Ibraimah Adams, OHC, 42, died August 27, 1997 at West Park, New York as a result of cancer. Father Adams, an Anglican Priest, was a 1989 Fordham University graduate. Requiem Mass at Holy Cross Monastery, Route 9W, West Park on Saturday at 10:30 A.M. Burial in Ghana, West Africa. For information Simpson-Gaus Funeral Home, Kingston, NY. Donations to ''Order of the Holy Cross-African Work'', P.O. Box 99, West Park, New York 12493.

title: From Nora to Vreeland, Women Say Goodbye
description: Nothing (except, possibly, ''Cats'') lasts forever in the ephemeral realm of the theater. And three performances that have done much to enrich the past season in New York will no longer be on view here after the Labor Day weekend. They are all, as it happens, from actresses, all portraying women at the crossroads and all doing unexpected and often thrilling things. And for any serious theater lover, missing out on them is close to criminal.

title: With Guidance From Thelonious Monk
description: Misha Mengelberg's early set at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night proceeded in fits and starts, though it was possible that that was the way he wanted it. Of the Dutch jazz improvisers who emerged 30 years ago, Mr. Mengelberg is one of the greatest, and his career has embodied the eccentric humor and structural experimentation associated with Dutch jazz. But in emergency situations he turns to Thelonious Monk, whose music he absorbed in the late 1950's.

title: Ball Fields For Housing: A Trade-Off Is Contested
description: For all its social problems, like drugs, poverty and unemployment, Harlem has always had one asset lacking in other parts of Manhattan: lots of available, unused land. Over the last 30 years, as landlords abandoned properties, the city turned some of them over to youth baseball leagues, leaving the neighborhood with an unusually large number of diamonds compared with other parts of the borough.

description: To the Editor:

description: A major Wall Street firm raised its gauge of New York State's creditworthiness by a notch today, a move that offered a tempered endorsement of Gov. George E. Pataki's fiscal policies.

description: Renault S.A. said yesterday that it had sold its remaining 3 percent stake in A.B. Volvo, ending the last link between two companies that had once hoped to merge. Renault said it had sold nearly 12.7 million class A shares of the Swedish auto maker and would have a capital gain on the sale of more than one billion francs, or $164.5 million.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday 2-5 and 79PM with service Friday, 11:30AM. Interment to follow at Ferncliff, Ardsley, NY. description: California's ban on preferences went haltingly into effect today, almost a year after voters approved a sweeping end to public affirmative action programs in the state.

description: GEORGE-Allan. Born July 31, 1914 to August 28, 1979. Dearest Daddy. Forever missed by all who knew you. Your legacy of love, caring, kindness and lighting up the world of all those around you, lives on in my heart. You were one of a kind, the world was a better place, thanks to you and your beautiful soul.

description: To the Editor:

title: Why Brazilian Complexities Are Fun
description: Gilberto Gil's audience didn't simply clap along when he performed at Irving Plaza on Wednesday night. It clapped in double time, in triple time and in overlapping syncopations, following the increasingly elaborate cues of a drummer who made the musical complexities look like fun. That's part of the pleasure of Mr. Gil's music: true to the esthetics of Brazilian pop, it pretends its ingenuity comes easily, that the songs just arrived spontaneously. And while the tunes are gliding and ambling and bouncing along, they happen to carry big ideas.

title: Keep in Mind
description: THE INTREPID TUGBOAT CHALLENGE, with a tugboat race and a nose-to-nose tugboat pushing competition, a Popeye-style spinach-eating contest, a line-throwing competition and children's games. Sunday, starting at 12:25 P.M., at Pier 86, West 46th Street at 12th Avenue, Clinton. The events are free; admission to the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum is extra: Adults, $10; the elderly and children 12 to 17, $7.50; children 6 to 11, $5; children 5 and under, free. Information: (212) 245-2533.

title: The North Korean Puzzle
description: The defection of North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, Chang Sung Gil, should prove an intelligence bonanza to the United States. But it adds yet another complication to the diplomatic game the Clinton Administration has been playing with North Korea. Despite criticism from South Korea and some Congressional Republicans, the Administration should persevere in its efforts to coax North Korea out of its dangerous isolation and into negotiations on arms control and peace.

title: Diamonds of a Different Kind: The Coverlets in Cooperstown
description: BEDS are where we are born and die, and spend a third of a lifetime dreaming in between. No wonder they've always been centerpieces of domestic life, little havens constructed of pillows and cushions and comforters, retreats from an all too wakeful world.

title: Columbia/HCA Halting Merger and Capital Plans
description: As it endures a huge Federal criminal investigation of its business practices, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation plans to suspend about $750 million in projects to acquire or construct hospitals in the next few months, the company's new chairman and chief executive said today.

title: Pepsico Spinoff Date Set
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that it had received approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to spin off its restaurant business to shareholders and that the spinoff would occur on Oct. 6. Under the spinoff plan, Pepsico shareholders of record as of Sept. 19 will receive one share in the new restaurant company, Tricon Global Restaurants Inc., for every 10 Pepsico shares they hold.

title: Kentucky Doctors Warn Against a Regional Dish: Squirrels' Brains
description: Doctors in Kentucky have issued a warning that people should not eat squirrel brains, a regional delicacy, because squirrels may carry a variant of mad cow disease that can be transmitted to humans and is fatal.

title: Raisio to Build Plant in Carolina
description: Raision Tehtaat Oy A.B., a unit of Raisio Group and the maker of the cholesterol-cutting margarine Benecol, has agreed to build a sterol plant in South Carolina with the Westvaco Corporation.

description: Inventing the Abbotts

title: Rabin Showed Willingness To Give Golan Back to Syria
description: In secret talks in 1994, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel told the American Secretary of State that he could consider a peace with Syria in which Israel would withdraw to a line that divided the two countries at the outset of the 1967 Middle East war, a former Israeli official said today.

title: Kentuckian, 16, Is a Phenom From the Farm
description: Not every man, woman and farm animal tucked between the pastures and corn fields near Possum Trot, Ky., was sure what to make of the girl next door.

A successor to Mr. King in New York is not planned at this time.

title: The N.F.L. pushes its fan development drive into a second phase.
description: AS pro football starts its 1997-98 season this weekend, the National Football League is revamping an aggressive fan development campaign that began last year. The second phase of the multimillion-dollar advertising and marketing blitz is shifting the spotlight from the famous faces on the field to the usually invisible ones behind the scenes.

description: Not much in the manner of Alhaj Maulavi Qalamuddin suggests that he is one of the most feared men in Afghanistan.

description: The singer Kevin Mahogany closed his first set at Birdland on Wednesday night with a version of Percy Mayfield's ''Please Send Me Someone to Love.'' He first repeated something the saxophonist Hank Crawford had once told him: that the song was always meant to be a prayer, not a love song. And Mr. Mahogany's version was a crawling, teasing kind of secular gospel.

description: With a cast of thousands and an I.Q. of 10, ''Kull the Conqueror'' has arrived to assault the patience of moviegoers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOOD, COURTNEY B.
description: WOOD-Courtney B. August 29, 1987. Ten years have not diminished our love and memories of you. Forever will you remain in our hearts. Your wife and daughter, Claire and Candace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASMIR, CYRIL DAVID
description: KASMIR-Cyril David, age 52, left this world on August 28, 1997. He was comfortable and surrounded by his family. He chose to leave us when we were all smiling, laughing and basking in the joy that he had brought to all of us. Cyril's strong will and undying spirit will continue to live on in his children Darren, Justin and Sean, and his memory will perpetually provide comfort and guidance to all whom he touched. In addition to his children, he is survived by his loving wife Brenda, his parents Frank and Celia Kasmir, his brother Sam, sister Susan, extended family and many loving friends. Words fail us at this time of great loss, end of suffering, and start of a peaceful rest. We can honor and celebrate a good life, full of passion during which he loved and was loved completely. His youth never left him. Cyril worked tirelessly to provide for his family and to take care of his friends. He was always there for us. He had something to teach us all. His passing will be deeply mourned, yet those who knew him can take solace in the memory of his laughter and of his expressions, both the smiling ones and the stern. He has earned a peaceful rest, yet we're sure he will revel, as he did in life, in the work and the rapture he has ahead. Funeral services will be at 10:00 A.M., Sunday at Sparkman/ Hillcrest Northwest Highway Chapel, Rabbi Gerald J. Klein officiating. Interment following at Hillcrest Memorial Park. The family will receive friends from 4:00 to 6:00 P.M. Saturday in the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial contributions be made to the American Cancer Society, 8900 John Carpenter Freeway, Dallas, Texas 75247 or to Dallas Visiting Nurse Assoc., 1440 West Mockingbird Lane, Suite 500, Dallas, Texas 75247.

title: 70 Used-Car Dealers Cited After a Sting
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday that four out of five used-car dealers had cheated inspectors posing as customers during a recent undercover operation.

title: TRAVELERS GROUP SELLS HOTEL TO LOWE FOR $330 MILLION
description: Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that it had sold the Hotel del Coronado near San Diego for $330 million to Lowe Enterprises Investment Management Inc., which was acting on behalf of an undisclosed pension fund client. Lowe Enterprises said its Destinations Hotels and Resorts unit would manage the hotel. The unit is to invest more than $50 million in the next five years to improve the hotel, which is on Coronado Island. Travelers Group, a New York financial services company, said its third-quarter earnings would be increased by an unspecified amount as a result of the sale.

title: Farewell to Summer, With Fairs and Fireworks
description: Labor Day is Monday, and holiday celebrations are planned all weekend. The Labor Day Parade in Manhattan will take place on Sept. 6, along Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 72d Street, starting at 11 A.M. Here is a sampling of activities this weekend in the three-state area. Unless noted, admission is free:

title: 2 Officers Are Injured While Arresting Suspects
description: Two police officers were injured yesterday when two men whom they were attempting to place under arrest grabbed the officers' guns and repeatedly bit at least one officer, the police said.

title: $25 and Under
description: A friend of mine is so passionate about spicy food that he carries a bag of chilies with him, especially to Asian restaurants. Dismayed by the reluctance of these restaurants to spice their foods forcefully, he'll take out a Serrano or a Scotch bonnet pepper and serenely nibble away as his companions gasp and shrink back. But on our last visit to Ubol's Kitchen, he never even opened his bag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, CHARLES
description: RAPPAPORT-Charles. On Aug. 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Eva. Loving father of Jay (Judy), Perry (Barbara) and Edith (Joseph) Amorese. Cherished grandfather of Marc, Matthew, Michelle and David and the late Jake and great grandfather of Morgan, Abigail and Maxwell. President of Federation of NY Housing Cooperatives. Former Chairman of the Board of N.A.H.C. Services Friday, 12 noon ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Up on Fifth Ave., a Most Exclusive Club Shows Off Its Members' Virtuosity
description: ONE of the most beautiful houses on Manhattan's Museum Mile is No. 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street. The entrance hall promises much. The staircase delivers. So does the wonderfully varied sequence of rooms -- some large and grand, and another so small as to be almost conspiratorial -- on the second floor. Up above, the great mansion turns into a spacious but relatively informal town house, with glorious glimpses of Central Park and twisty little staircases where we don't expect them.

title: Grand Central Catacombs: How a Century Left Order in Ruins
description: ONCE upon a time, machines looked shiny and sleek for the camera. It seemed that the gears of Charles Sheeler and the bolts of Margaret Bourke-White would last forever. Well, they haven't.

title: Parents: Don't Rush Turning Child Around
description: When is it safe to switch a baby from a rear-facing car seat to a seat that faces forward? The official answer has changed recently, creating problems for parents and car-seat manufacturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYDON, SALLY
description: LYDON-Sally, on August 28, 1997. Beloved sister of James, Edward, Michael, Mary and Annarose. Devoted daughter of the late Patrick and Sarah. Funeral Mass Saturday at St. Cecilia R.C. Church, Brooklyn at 9:30 AM. Interment in Calvary Cemetery. She gave her time and boundless energy as a long time volunteer at St. Patrick's Cathedral. She was an active member of the Catholic Daughters of America and other humanitarian groups which she joined after a long career with the U.S. Army Recruiting Service. Memorial Service on Sat., August 30, at 1:00 PM, The Church of the Intercessor, St. Thomas Place, Malverne, NY.

title: Byron MacNabb, 87, an Atlas Rocket Leader
description: Byron Gordon MacNabb, who directed field operations for the rocket system that launched the United States' space program and sent four astronauts into orbit, died on Monday. He was 87 and lived in Cheyenne, Wyo.

title: Furman Selz is joining ING, as takeover candidates dwindle.
description: COMMERCIAL banks continue to prowl Wall Street for acquisitions, trying to increase their nascent investment banking businesses. In the latest deal, ING Group, the Dutch insurance and banking company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Furman Selz L.L.C., a privately held New York securities firm, for $600 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, BRACHA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, NATALIE

title: Asian Stocks Fall Sharply for a 2d Day
description: Waves of selling battered many Asian stock markets for a second day today after Malaysia introduced restrictions on share trading and more signs of rising interest rates and flagging economic growth were seen elsewhere. Currencies were more modestly lower.

title: TECO ENERGY SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS OIL AND GAS SUBSIDIARY
description: Teco Energy Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell its oil and natural gas subsidiary, Teco Oil and Gas, because of the unit's disappointing results. The energy company, which mainly sells electricity to customers in Florida through its Tampa Electric Company utility, also said it planned to take a third-quarter pretax charge of $7.5 million to write off discontinued operations related to three unsuccessful natural gas wells. Teco Energy formed Teco Oil and Gas in 1995 to participate in exploration projects in the Gulf of Mexico. In the third quarter a year ago, the company had net income of $65.3 million, on revenue of $400.8 million. Shares of Teco Energy fell 56.25 cents yesterday, to $24.0625.

title: Indianapolis Dealer Objects to Ford Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company's plan to streamline its Indianapolis dealerships has suffered a setback because a key dealer rejected the company's buyout offer as inadequate.

title: Lufthansa Says Earnings Nearly Doubled
description: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. said yesterday that its first-half net income had almost doubled to 157 million German marks, or $86.7 million, ahead of the October sale of the Government's remaining 35.7 percent stake in the airline. Lufthansa shares surged as much as 5 percent after the airline said that a weaker mark, an increase in long-haul traffic and cost-cutting measures had combined to increase net from 81 million marks a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, PAUL F.
description: GORMAN-Paul F. Suddenly on August 26, 1997 of Raleigh, North Carolina and Albany, NY. Loving father of Tamara Gorman. Dear brother of Sandra Hoppe, Leslie Boudreau and Pamela Gorman. Dearest friend of Edith Waite. Friends may call at the Roslyn Hts Funeral Home, 75 Mineola Ave., Roslyn Hts, Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. Contributions in his name to The Binghamton Foundation, Binghamton University, Binghamton, NY. would be appreciated. He will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINGERHUT, PAUL MARVIN
description: FINGERHUT-Paul Marvin. On August 28,1997 beloved husband of Lillian, loving father of Carole, David and Richard. Father-in-Law of Alan, Patricia and Haley. Dear brother of Morton, cherished grandfather of Michael, Steven, Lisa, Garrett and Andrew. Funeral Service today, 11:30AM, Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Lobo Sparks Liberty Into Title Game In W.N.B.A.
description: Burdened with high expectations, Rebecca Lobo had trouble shaking the overrated label some fans slapped on her after more than a few unproductive regular-season games.

title: 'Heather, You O.K.?' Uh-Oh
description: For a fine illustration of what ''before'' means, ''Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation'' is being opportunistically re-released. It was way back in 1995 that this schlocky horror farce, then known as ''Return of the Texas Chainsaw Massacre,'' first appeared with the unknown actors Matthew McConaughey and Renee Zellweger in starring roles. But even in a film whose principal props include litter, old pizza slices and a black plastic trash bag, it's clear that these two were going places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADRONE, GEORGE W.
description: PADRONE-George W., 67, of Rancho Mirage, Calif. On August 27. Formerly of Bellerose, Queens. He was the son of Vito and Catherine Jones Padrone and was for 20 years the companion of Robert E. Armstrong of NYC and Rancho Mirage. For thirty-one years Mr. Padrone was on the staff of the IBM Corporation, capping his career as Administrator of the IBM Club of NYC. A memorial is planned for Calif. in the fall.

title: Injured Immigrant Has Turn for Worse
description: The medical condition of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who says he was tortured by the police in a Brooklyn precinct house, considerably worsened yesterday, and he underwent surgery last night. A doctor said the operation went well.

title: Euro RSCG Forms Unified Italy Group
description: Euro RSCG Worldwide, a unit of Havas Advertising, said yesterday that it had reorganized its operations in Italy by forming a group, Euro RSCG Italia, that would oversee agencies specializing in services like advertising, media buying, health care marketing and new media.

title: Home Video
description: With no big films among the newest releases (''Les Voleurs'' and ''Hard Eight'' are certainly estimable smaller ones), several big boxed sets move front and center.

title: Novartis Posts Profit Rise Of 27.4% for First Half
description: Novartis A.G., the world's largest maker of drugs, said yesterday that its first-half net income rose 27.4 percent on a rise in sales and savings from the merger that formed the company. The chief financial officer, Raymund Breu, predicted that the increase in full-year net would exceed the first-half rise.

title: In Japan, a Textbook Case of Truth and History
description: TOKYO  For three decades, Saburo Ienaga and Nobukatsu Fujioka have stood on opposite sides of the barricades in a battle over how much schoolchildren here should learn about Japanese atrocities during World War II, including the slaughter of up to 300,000 Chinese in the Rape of Nanking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLNER, ALFRED
description: WILLNER-Alfred. Devoted father of Amy and Joel Kassiola, loving and beloved grandfather of Beth and Brenda. Services at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Ave (at Prospect Park), Brooklyn, today at 12 noon.

title: Networks and Set Makers In Standoff Over HDTV
description: With the introduction of digital television only about a year away, leaders of the three major television networks are caught in a standoff with television manufacturers.

title: Low Inflation Seen Amid Solid Growth In Economy
description: The economy grew at a 3.6 percent annual pace during the spring, far higher than the 2.2 percent rate estimated a month ago, the Government said today. Even with the more robust growth, inflation remained subdued during the second quarter.

title: Police Link a Stolen Car Found in Brooklyn to an Officer's Murder
description: The police believe that a stolen car they recovered late Wednesday was used two nights before in the gangland-style execution of Ralph C. Dols, the off-duty housing police officer who was shot outside his Brooklyn apartment, a law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Kennedy Quits His Campaign For Governor
description: Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d announced today that he would not run for governor of Massachusetts, ending a campaign that had been engulfed by controversy over his family even before it was officially begun.

title: Smithfield Stock Split
description: The pork processor Smithfield Foods Inc. said yesterday that it would split its stock 2 for 1. The split will double the amount of shares, but halve each share's value. The company, based in Smithfield, Va., said the split is payable Sept. 26 to shareholders of record on Sept. 12. Shares of Smithfield Foods rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $55.875, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: A Country Corner Where the Grass Does Seem Greener
description: HEAT makes people illogical. I got on the uptown subway to go to Brooklyn just two weeks ago. And people who wouldn't be caught dead on the summer-baked sidewalks head to the beach to spit-roast themselves in the sun.

title: Dow Falls 92.90, but the Smaller Stocks Rise
description: Large-company stocks were pummeled yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 100 points. But the stocks of smaller companies managed to rally enough to push that sector's main index to a new high.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL TO PAY $625 MILLION FOR RIVAL
description: Continuing its expansion effort, Equity Residential Properties Trust, a Chicago real estate investment trust controlled by the financier Sam Zell, plans to pay about $625 million in securities to buy a rival apartment company, Evans Withycombe Residential Inc., based in Scottsdale, Ariz. Equity would also assume $432 million in debt. The deal, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, calls for holders of Evans Withycombe common stock to receive a half share of Equity Residential stock for each of their shares and holders of operating partnerships to receive Equity Residential partnership units at the same ratio. Equity's stock fell $1.625, to $48.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Evans was up $1.5625 at $23.625.

title: Tyranny in Belarus
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about prize winners at the Urban World Film Festival in Manhattan misspelled the name of an actor in ''A Woman Like That,'' which won for best dramatic feature. He is N'Bushe Wright, not N'Brush.

title: Pataki Signs Bill to Redraw District Lines
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed a bill today that will, if it is approved by a Federal panel, redraw the lines of the largely Hispanic 12th Congressional District and five neighboring districts in New York City.

title: Speaker Gingrich Mixes Politics and Paleontology
description: Somewhere short of a heat stroke, with a world-class paleontologist coaching him, a Hollywood star squatting nearby mumbling encouragement, anxious aides checking their watches and even more antsy security men on the lookout for rattlesnakes in the scrub brush, Newt Gingrich accomplished his goal: he found a dinosaur bone.

title: Mets May Let Harnisch Go
description: With team officials saying that there does not seem to be a market for Pete Harnisch, the Mets are apparently considering releasing the 30-year-old right-hander.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRANO, ANDREA
description: CARRANO-Andrea, 71, the worldrenowned shoe designer, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. Andrea Carrano is survived by his wife, Elizabeth, their daughters, Valentina and Giada, their son, Andrea, and 3 daughters by his first marriage, Gianna, Maria Grazia and Manuela, and their mother, Carmen. A memorial mass will be held in the Chapel of St. Vincent's Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Saturday, at 10 AM.

title: End of a Dream
description: Martina Diederich was in a German tour group traveling around this country three years ago when she met Baxter Thompson near New Orleans. They fell in love, visited each other's families, got engaged. Finally, a year ago, they were married.

title: Federal Express Won No Trade Favors
description: To the Editor:

title: Plasma Rivers Discovered Around Poles Of the Sun
description: Scientists have discovered immense rivers of hot, electrically charged gas flowing beneath the surface near the polar regions of the Sun, a surprising phenomenon that could help them understand sunspots and other disturbances that often cause electromagnetic storms and power failures on Earth.

title: Bad News Bearers
description: As usual, Joseph Kennedy didn't get it quite right. The Massachusetts Congressman announced yesterday that he had decided against running for governor. All over Washington, spinmasters will be laughing about how Mr. Kennedy blew a chance for a media age triple play. He could have announced bad news on a Friday, in August, just before a national holiday. Instead he marches out on a Thursday, leaving plenty of time for the high-audience news shows and a weekday paper. Duh.

title: Zoo Crew Is Raided
description: They went by the name Zoo Crew and many in the poor sections of Newark saw them as young, community-minded entrepreneurs who donated money for basketball clinics. Yesterday, the authorities said that an 18-month investigation had shown that the Zoo Crew was also a drug gang that used its businesses as fronts for a ''sophisticated and lucrative'' street trade in cocaine and heroin. Agents raided 13 locations and arrested 21 people, seizing cash, weapons and drugs. Page A1.

title: Perhaps Not Pure, but Certainly Entertaining
description: If and when the really threatening economic asteroids hit jazz -- and let's hope it doesn't happen -- perhaps only the most adaptable will survive. They may not always offer undiluted, hard-core jazz, but this superbreed of musicians with an encyclopedic grasp of entertainment ritual will provide one-stop shops of challenge, comfort and commercialism. The alto saxophonist Kenny Garrett and the singer Dianne Reeves, who closed the Panasonic Village Jazz Festival with a crowd-pleasing free concert in Washington Square Park on Monday afternoon, are two such performers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLOPPENBURG, EMILY R. D. TAYLOR
description: KLOPPENBURG-Emily R. D. Taylor, on Saturday, August 23, 1997, after years of illness; of Mount Lebanon (Pgh, PA.), formerly of New York. Wife of the late G. Raymond Kloppenburg. Emily came to Pittsburgh to be cared for. Dearly beloved mother of Ann Rainey Aston-Reese of Mt. Lebanon (Pgh, PA.) and Martha K. Lisk of Westwood, CA; beloved grandmother of A. Taylor Lisk and Kent Rainey Lisk of Westwood, CA., Glenn S. Aston-Reese, Jr. of Washington, PA., David M. Aston-Reese of NYC and Woodstock, NY, Elyse A-R Bertucci of Ishpeming, MI., and William F. Aston-Reese of Staten Island, NY; great-grandmother of Todd B. Aston-Reese of Pgh, PA, Kristen Violet Aston-Reese, William F. AstonReese and Zachery Glen AstonReese, all of Staten Island, NY and Ella Terese Bertucci of Ishpeming, MI. Emily was a graduate of Mt. Holyoke College for Women in MA. and had a degree in Library Science from Columbia University, NYC. She spent her adult life in Volunteer Work, first at Union Settlement in NYC and many other charitable organizations until she came to Pgh., where she volunteered with the Pgh. Symphony Association and tutoring with the Pgh. Public School System. Friends may call Friday, August 29, afternoon and evening at DeWitt Funeral Home, Borden Avenue, Pine Bush, NY, where services will be held Saturday, August 30 at 10:00AM. Interment New Prospect Church Cemetery, Ulster County, New York. For information, call H. Samson, Inc., Funeral Directors, Pittsburgh, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EDITH
description: MILLER-Edith. Devoted wife of Bertram. Adored mother, loving sister, cherished grandmother. Services on Friday, 10:00AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Fassel Points Out Advantage Of Youth
description: There are 10 rookies on the Giants' roster, and the number of them in the starting lineup grew to five today because Derek Engler is going to hold on to the job at center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLKIN, LUCILLE
description: KOLKIN-Lucille. Age 78. Died suddenly, August 27th. Our loss of this vibrant multi-talented woman is mourned by Alfred Kolkin, her loving, devoted husband for 53 years; their daughters, Marjorie Kolkin, and Judy Kaplan and her husband Harry Kaplan; Grandchildren Jesse, & Jill, her brother Paul Gewirtz, nieces and nephews, sister-in-law Mim Kelber & Harry Kelber, and her many friends and associates in the Penn South community and National Opinion Research Center. A Hunter college graduate who was a pioneering ''Rosie The Riveter'' at the Brooklyn Navy Yard during World War II, Lucy's social conscience and activism in progressive causes is a cherished legacy. Memorial service Noon, Wednesday, Sept. 3rd. Riverside Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan.

title: North Koreans Seek Famine's Antidote in U.S.
description: Choe Kang Ryong was a long way from the scorched cornfields, ruined rice paddies and hungry, skeletal children of North Korea. Alone and silent, he stood for a little while today on the edge of hundreds of acres of healthy corn, food for the plump hogs of the Cannon Valley Cooperative. Wading into the dense bumper crop that closed over his head, the slender North Korean reached down to crumble the soil. He felt the girth of a strong green stalk.

title: Lieutenant Governor Attacks Pataki's Lilco Takeover Plan
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross came to Long Island today to denounce Gov. George E. Pataki's plan for a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINHOLM, WILLIAM S.

title: Congo Blocks U.N. Inquiry Into Report of Killings
description: A team sent to investigate reports that Hutu refugees from Rwanda were killed by troops loyal to the Congo's new leader has again been stymied by the Congolese Government, an American investigator said today.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the march today protesting police brutality, which is expected to attract thousands of people, roadways across downtown Brooklyn and near City Hall will be clogged. Traffic delays are expected in Brooklyn near the Brooklyn Bridge from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and around City Hall and the Manhattan side of the bridge between noon and 6 P.M. The march is to begin about 10 A.M. at Grand Army Plaza and head down Flatbush Avenue, turning west on Tillary Street, crossing the Brooklyn Bridge on the pedestrian walkway and moving north on Park Row, west on Chambers Street and south on Broadway. It is to conclude at the southern end of City Hall Park.

description: IT is not enough to go looking for the next Tiger Woods or the next Jackie Joyner-Kersee or the next Alex Rodriguez. You have to start with a talent pool.

title: Bond Prices Surge on Favorable Reports About Inflation
description: Treasury securities rose strongly yesterday, after the Commerce Department reported that inflation pressures were not building in the second quarter. Securities were also bolstered by an afternoon report citing unnamed Federal Reserve economists as saying strong growth was not really a problem as long as inflation remained tame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTTONE, MADELINE
description: BOTTONE-Madeline. Wife of the late Carl. Devoted mother of Anthony C. Bottone M.D. and his wife Betty. Dear grandmother of Paul and his wife, MaryRita. Loving sister of Mary Alvino. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Ann's Church, Saturday, 9:30AM. Visiting Friday 2-5, 7-10 PM.

description: Lawyers for Terry L. Nichols, who will stand trial next month in the Oklahoma City bombing, were rebuffed on two fronts today.

Long gone are its spring hatchery trout, most of which fell victim months ago to well-placed night crawlers or gobs of mealworms dangled from bobbers.

description: Jaw clenched, hands clasped and eyes focused straight ahead, Sgt. Gregory Fors didn't flinch when two marchers in yesterday's protest against police brutality began waving a Jamaican flag an inch from his nose.

description: The Government of Brunei intervened in the foreign-exchange market today to support several of Asia's foundering currencies, and analysts said its action caused stocks in Malaysia and Singapore to rebound from their weakest levels of the day.

description: It sounds like a cruel challenge: Why not put Toyota Camrys and Honda Accords in Buick dealerships and see whether dealers can persuade people to buy the Buicks anyway?

description: A good offensive line has been likened to a clenched fist. Tightly packed, it can strike. It is also good for protection. But one weakened joint and the unit fails.

description: The Manhattan borough president's race generated heat yesterday as the two leading contenders for the Democratic nomination traded accusations of ''push polling,'' a campaign tactic that delivers negative information about an opponent under the guise of opinion research.

title: 98 Die in One of Algerian Civil War's Worst Massacres
description: One of the worst massacres in almost five years of war between the military-backed authorities in Algeria and their militant Muslim opponents took the lives of at least 98 inhabitants south of Algiers overnight, the Algerian Government said today.

title: Williams Comes of Age, Emphatically
description: This was not about the red, white and blue beads sprouting from her head of braids, nor the symbolism surrounding an African-American girl raised around the rough edges of Los Angeles gracing the court that was named for Arthur Ashe.

title: Sale of U.S. Nuclear Fuel Plants Raises Host of Conflicts
description: There is big money in nuclear energy. While most nuclear-power plants in America may be economic albatrosses, the little-known Government-owned enterprise that supplies the bulk of their uranium fuel is highly profitable.

title: REXEL SEEKS FULL OWNERSHIP OF U.S. SUBSIDIARY
description: Rexel S.A. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the remaining 49 percent of its Rexel Inc. unit for $19.50 a share, or about $265 million in cash, as it seeks to remain competitive in the electrical supplies distribution business. The French parent company has been gradually building its stake in the United States operation, which is based in Coral Gables, Fla., since 1992, when it obtained a 30 percent interest in what was then known as Willcox & Gibbs Inc. after selling its Southern Electric Supply unit to Willcox. In May 1995, Rexel S.A. raised its stake to about 46 percent and Willcox & Gibbs changed its named to Rexel Inc. Rexel S.A. is the largest electrical supplies distributor in the world. The stock of Rexel Inc. rose $1.9375, to $20.8125.

title: Two Said to Plot Bombing In a Subway Are Indicted
description: Two men accused of plotting to bomb a major subway station in Brooklyn were indicted yesterday on Federal conspiracy and weapons charges, but investigators said they still had no evidence linking the defendants to any terrorist group.

title: Israeli Urges Pullout From Lebanon After 4 More Soldiers Die
description: The leader of the opposition Labor Party today urged swift negotiations for a gradual withdrawal of Israeli forces from southern Lebanon, a day after four young Israeli soldiers burned to death there in a blaze ignited by artillery shells from their own side.

title: Joyce Ebert, 64, Prolific Actress In Stage Roles Large and Small
description: Joyce Ebert, a versatile character actress for more than 30 years with the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, died on Thursday at Southport Manor, a rest home in Southport, Conn. She was 64.

title: Panic in Stocks Infects Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Foreign investors stampeded out of Hong Kong on Friday in the territory's busiest trading day ever, their confidence in Asia shaken by rising interest rates to ward off currency speculators and aggravated by Malaysian rules that make it harder to sell stocks.

title: 2 Communities Illustrate Debate Over Census
description: One neighborhood is urban, largely black and poor. The other is suburban, virtually all white, and middle and upper class. But they represent two sides of the same coin, the yin and the yang of the problems the Census Bureau experiences in trying to carry out a modern-day count of the nation's population.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, lines were dropped from a front-page article yesterday about unrest in Bosnia. The affected passage should have read, ''A White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, told reporters in Martha's Vineyard, Mass., where President Clinton is on vacation, that the United States 'won't tolerate either side' inciting violence against American troops. He said that 'it's important that all the parties there understand that they should not challenge' the peacekeepers 'and that we will hold the leadership responsible for keeping their people under control.' ''

title: CITY NATIONAL TO PAY $34.1 MILLION FOR HARBOR BANCORP
description: The City National Corporation, the parent company of the City National Bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Harbor Bancorp in a transaction with a total value of $34.1 million. Harbor shareholders will receive cash, City National shares or a combination of cash and stock valued at $24.10 for each Harbor share, subject to several conditions. Harbor's shares jumped $2.75 a share, to $22.375, in Nasdaq trading. City National, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., rose 93.75 cents, to $27.9375. Harbor Bancorp, based in Long Beach, Calif., is the holding company for Harbor Bank and had 6 branches with 98 employees and approximately $213 million in assets as of June 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLKIN, LUCILLE
description: KOLKIN-Lucille. The Assembly of Concerned Cooperators mourns the untimely loss of our Chair, Lucille Kolkin. Her untiring devotion to our organization and to Penn South will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Al and the entire family.

title: Biggest Southeast Bank Buying Florida Giant for $15.5 Billion
description: Spending more for a bank than any company has in history, the Nationsbank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Barnett Banks for $15.5 billion in stock.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: 2 INDICTED IN BOMB PLOT -- Two men accused of plotting to bomb a major subway station in Brooklyn were indicted on Federal conspiracy and weapons charges. Page 27.

title: Mayor May Get Federal Job
description: President Clinton will nominate Mayor Cardell Cooper next week to a top position in the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN MARKETING INDUSTRIES, Kansas City, Mo., said its Dunbrooke division had agreed to buy Westark Garment Manufacturing, Fort Smith, Ark., for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.

title: Countess Diana Produces Another Victory for Byrne
description: It is one thing to win a stakes race or two, even at historic old Saratoga Race Course. It is something else to win a string of them, especially when you are running against D. Wayne Lukas, the king of trainers of 2-year-old horses.

title: Sihanouk, Back Home, Hopes to Be Mediator
description: As a gentle rain fell on the ancient temples of Angkor nearby, King Norodom Sihanouk returned today to the ailing country he left six months ago, voicing a last, faint hope of peace and reconciliation.

title: Student Arrested in Phone Fraud After Wrong Victims Beeped
description: In an era of electronic communication and high-tech fraud, it sounds like an amazingly simple way to make a buck.

title: Carl Jacobi, 89; Wrote Spooky Tales
description: Carl Jacobi, a short-story writer whose tales of the macabre and fantastic filled pulp magazines and books for six decades, died on Monday at a nursing home in suburban Minneapolis. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEN, ESTHER B.
description: GERSTEN-Esther B. Died peacefully on August 28, 1997 at the age of 99. Beloved mother of Louis, devoted sister of Kyver Blumstein, dear mother-in-law of Bess, cherished sister-in-law of Esther, fondly remembered aunt. Wife of her dearest late husband, Alfred, with whom she would wish, in the words of the poet, Robert Browning, to finally: ''O thou sole of my sole/I shall clasp thee again/ and with God be the rest.'' Service on Sunday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mike Espy Is Not Alone
description: It is sad to see a young politician's promising career go down the drain in a personal corruption scandal. But this week's indictment of Mike Espy cannot be dismissed as the petty product of an overreaching Independent Counsel, as Mr. Espy's supporters portray it. Mr. Espy is charged with soliciting and accepting gifts from food companies he regulated as Secretary of Agriculture. The total value of the gifts was small, under $40,000, but the alleged crime itself was a serious breach of public trust.

title: Cathleen Cordell, Actress, Dead at 81

title: Daewoo Plans to Invest In Ukrainian Car Maker
description: The Daewoo Corporation of South Korea has agreed to invest $1.28 billion in a joint venture with the state-owned car maker Avtozaz in Ukraine, the Government said yesterday. According to the preliminary agreement, which both sides still must sign, the venture will produce 150,000 cars within four years, including Daewoo models and General Motors' Opel models, rising to 250,000 cars within seven years.

title: Peel the Peach, Yes, But Hearts Quake Over What Comes Next
description: It seemed a simple thing, really. Conceding that its 26-year-old ban on garbage disposals defied common sense, the New York City Council discarded it on Wednesday and appeared to give New Yorkers access to a kitchen convenience so rudimentary that it is taken for granted almost everywhere else.

description: Call him New Jersey's seafaring Senator. Arriving on a Coast Guard cutter, Robert G. Torricelli docked at Liberty State Park yesterday to wrap up a five-day, multicraft tour of the state's waterways to promote Federal legislation he is introducing, a $30 million bill to help preserve 3 New Jersey estuaries and 25 others across the country. Starting last Monday, the Democratic Senator's travels also included a flat-bottom boat ride through the Delaware Water Gap, canoeing down the Delaware River and sailing off the Atlantic Coast. MICHAEL POLLAK

title: Growth Slows For Incomes; Spending Up
description: Personal income grew at a slower pace in July than it did a month before, while spending rose at the fastest pace since January, suggesting that the economic expansion will continue well into next year.

title: DYLEX OFFERS $72 MILLION FOR MARK'S WORK WEARHOUSE
description: Dylex Ltd. of Toronto said yesterday that it had offered to buy Mark's Work Wearhouse Ltd., a chain of 280 stores, for cash and shares worth almost $100 million (Canadian), or $72 million (United States). The deal would expand Dylex's retail clothing business in Canada to 920 stores. Dylex offered $1.65 (Canadian), equivalent to $1.19 (United States), in cash and one-quarter Dylex share for each Mark's share. It said the offer valued Mark's, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, at $3.76 (Canadian), or $2.70 (United States), a share. But shares of Mark's rose 90 cents a share, to $4.20, indicating that investors believe Dylex or another bidder will have to pay more.

title: John C. Kendrew Dies at 80; Biochemist Won Nobel in '62
description: John Cowdery Kendrew, a British molecular biochemist and 1962 Nobel laureate who decoded part of the mystery of life by revealing the detailed structure of a key protein, died last Saturday in Cambridge, England. He was 80.

title: Setting The Tone For Police Reform
description: In the 25 years since I testified before the Knapp Commission about my odyssey to combat police corruption, I have occasionally been credited with spurring profound changes within the New York Police Department. It's a flattering way to be remembered, but the unfortunate reality -- as recent events in Brooklyn's 70th Precinct confirm -- is that nothing about police culture has significantly changed since I left the force in 1972. The department continues to tolerate unacceptable behavior, making an atrocity like the alleged abuse of Abner Louima virtually inevitable.

description: In a landmark victory for Japanese who have been trying to educate young people about their country's wartime atrocities, the Supreme Court ruled today for the first time that the Government had broken the law by censoring textbooks to remove references to the slaughter of civilians.

description: For the first time since sectarian violence erupted 28 years ago between the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority in Northern Ireland, the British Government today invited representatives of the Irish Republican Army to participate in formal peace talks.

description: A Tennessee appeals court ruled late today that two Memphis judges overstepped their authority in handling James Earl Ray's bid for a trial. The court stopped short of halting proceedings in the case, but clarified its restrictions on how it should be conducted.

description: The Torstar Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its Miles Kimball home and gift product catalogue division to a management-led group for $27 million. Torstar, a Toronto-based publisher of books and newspapers, said it would report a small gain on the sale. Miles Kimball, based in Oshkosh, Wis., is a direct-mail marketer of home and gift products. Torstar said it would purchase a 40 percent equity interest in the new Miles Kimball Company for $4 million. Torstar's holdings include The Toronto Star, Canada's largest daily newspaper; Metroland Printing, Publishing and Distributing, a community newspaper chain, and Harlequin Enterprises, a romance-fiction publisher.

description: The FMC Corporation intends to buy back up to $500 million of its stock. FMC, based in Chicago, produces chemicals and machinery. The buyback, to be completed by the end of 1999, will increase earnings per share by reducing the number of shares outstanding. FMC had 38 million shares outstanding as of June 30 for total market capitalization of $3.2 billion. It closed today at $83.0625, down $1.1875.

title: Wheat Up on Talk of El Nino And Expected Sales to Egypt
description: Wheat prices climbed to their highest level in more than three months yesterday on fears that El Nino would cut overseas crop production and on the expectation that Egypt would buy wheat from the United States.

title: Manhattan
description: The island's tip was sliced by a ship canal that tamed the Spuyten Duyvil shoals, but severed Marble Hill from Inwood. Medieval tapestry unicorns grace the Cloisters; a flag-pole and stockade mark old Fort Tryon. Lofty crags overlook the broad Hudson River as bedrock & history anchor the Heights to the George Washington Bridge. Walk east toward the Bronx across High bridge; gaze to the south from Sugar Hill, where trumpeters and tap dancers stepped up into the sun. Ages ago Iapetus (an older Atlantic Ocean) closed; the kiss with Africa heated a melting pot. Lava was injected in veins of rock and coagulated to form Palisade cliffs. The legacy of Algonquian life is hidden in our place names and our meals. The newcomers (first the Dutch, then English, African, Irish, German, Italian, Jewish, Chinese, Greek, Ukrainian, Armenian, Puerto Rican, Pakistani, Cuban, Dominican, Haitian, Filipino, and all) have shed blood in a thousand places, but millions live. Legends of Gotham: Father Knickerbocker, Boss Tweed, Emma Lazarus, Fiorello, the roar of the el, the blizzard of '47, Giants at the Polo Grounds. Offshore, barges ply swirling brown water near North River sewage pipes, as striped bass and shad swim up ''the river that flows both ways'': a tidal reach of the sea all the way up to Albany. Brownstone, bodega, ball court & bus stop: on warm nights in Harlem, noisy streets and quiet rooftops. Kids splash around a hydrant as lovers embrace on a Riverside Park bench and rush-hour traffic in stalled on the Triborough Bridge. Some uptown options: gospel choir on Sunday, sooty Grant's Tomb, hiphop the Apollo, ribs at Sylvia's, law at Columbia, mangos in El Barrio, peace garden in the Cathedral, rowboat on the Meer, pub-crawl the West Side, listen to poetry at the 92nd St. Y, nosh at Songbirds alight in leafy woods as a turtle lays eggs near a pond in Central Park. Grand museums flank the green with dinosaur bones and Egyptian tombs. When it snows, we ramble out to Sheep Meadow & the Great Lawn; in sunshine, to Strawberry Fields, the Lake, & the Zoo. Buy hot dogs from pushcarts near Madison boutiques, or subways. (Take the A train, ride the Lexington line, or change at 59th Street for the IRT. Catch the F out to Queens.) Gneiss but full of schist, the bedrock sparkles with mica. It bears the weight of midtown; Skyscrapers at Columbus Circle, Fifth Avenue, and Park Avenue. Attend concerts at Carnegie, ice skating shows at Rockefeller Center, Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Our eyes are drawn up to a blue slice of sky as vertical walls enclose us. 100 gridlocked taxis honk at police blockades as Fidel speaks at the U.N. Revelers jam Times Suqare on New Year's Eve, to jostle and sing as the ball drops. Buses come in (the Lincoln Tunnel) to Port Authority, trains to Grand Central. The lion-flanked public library was once a reservoir; we love the Art Deco classic Chrysler spire. From Hell's Kitchen walk to broadway, buy tickets for ''Showboat'' or ''Cats'' - hey, the Knicks won at the buzzer in the Garden! See Macy's flat parade, then gape from atop the Empire State, where mighty Kong took a fall. Diamond jewelers join fur-clad window shoppers as herds of jaywalkers cross against the light in the Garment District. Graffiti-scrawled boards near the Flatiron Building enclose pits of unconsolidated sediment Consolidated Edison must dig. Workers repair Gramercy Park cables, reroute Chelsea steam pipes, plug a burst main flooding streets by Union Square. (Tap water flows down from the Catskills in deep tunnels; garbage is hauled to a landfill at Fresh Kills.) The riverfront was filled for barnacle-crusted piers, and Minetta Brook wetlands became lots in Greenwich Village. A sweatshop horror: 146 locked-in women lost their lives in the Triangle Shirtwaist fire. Watch skateboard demons cavort among panhandlers as old men play chess near the arch in Washington Square, N.Y.U. students, art film fans, coffee drinkers, & East Village poets crowd smoky joints on Saturday night; some cross (the Holland Tunnel) back out to New Jersey. Cheap gallery space is a memory in SoHo; cast-iron lofts rent high, as do TriBeCa warehouses. A bag lady seeks warmth huddled over a sidewalk grate on the Bowery, where Stuyvesant's farm once spread in old New Amsterdam. The original steal (this island, traded for $24 in beads) lies plastered in muth and concrete, obscured like the African Burial Grounds. A Lower East Side delicatessen sells good chicken soup; enjoy zuppa di pesca at the Festival of San Gennaro, or bird's nest soup in Chinatown. Marchers to City Hall cross the Brooklyn Bridge to demonstrate, as tourists at South Street Seaport eat lunch with a view. The Fulton Fish Market is mobbed before dawn. Precambrian stocks bond the upper crust with solid foundations below the Trade Towers, Trinity Church and Wall Street. Ferryboats to Staten Island, Ellis Island, the Statue of Liberty, and Governor's Island depart from wind-swept docks at Battery Park.

description: The concrete pile of Chungking Mansions, its slab sides gnawed black by fungus and past fires, looms over the passing parade on Nathan Road.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook on Aug. 12 about ''The Bible Code'' by Michael Drosnin misstated, in some instances, the theory according to which the book arranges the text of the Bible and other books to make famous names, words and dates appear in crossword puzzle fashion. In the arrangement most fully explained in the book, the letters of the Bible were divided into 64 rows of 4,772 characters, and the name of former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel appeared; other numbers of rows and characters were used with the Bible and with Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment'' to produce other names and dates mentioned in the article.

title: No Reggae Festival
description: The ''Caribbean Music Fest '97'' scheduled for tomorrow at noon at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island was canceled yesterday by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation because of concerns over safety. The department said the promoter of the event, the Caribbean Reggae Institute, was unable to meet minimum safety requirements for security, fire prevention and parking. Ticket refunds can be obtained at the point of purchase; tickets bought through Ticketmaster are to be credited to the purchaser's account.

description: Ralph C. Dols, the off-duty New York City housing police officer who was shot execution style outside his Brooklyn apartment on Monday night, was mourned yesterday with all the cathartic and clannish pageantry of a formal police funeral, as detectives investigated whether his killing was the work of organized crime.

description: The index of prices that farmers receive for grain and livestock was unchanged from a month ago but down 8.5 percent compared with a year earlier, the Government said today.

description: As the designated hitter nears the end of its 25th year of existence, baseball's club owners yesterday made their first official effort to eliminate it.

description: There is no doubt that what has happened over the last 120 years in this half-dead hill town just downslope from the Continental Divide has ranked among the more freakish, tragic and raucous episodes in American history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASMIR, CYRIL DAVID
description: KASMIR-Cyril David, age 52, left this world on August 28, 1997. He was comfortable and surrounded by his family. He chose to leave us when we were all smiling, laughing and basking in the joy that he had brought to all of us. Cyril's strong will and undying spirit will continue to live on in his children Darren, Justin and Sean, and his memory will perpetually provide comfort and guidance to all whom he touched. In addition to his children, he is survived by his loving wife Brenda, his parents Frank and Celia Kasmir, his brother Sam, sister Susan, extended family and many loving friends. Words fail us at this time of great loss, end of suffering, and start of a peaceful rest. We can honor and celebrate a good life, full of passion during which he loved and was loved completely. His youth never left him. Cyril worked tirelessly to provide for his family and to take care of his friends. He was always there for us. He had something to teach us all. His passing will be deeply mourned, yet those who knew him can take solace in the memory of his laughter and of his expressions, both the smiling ones and the stern. He has earned a peaceful rest, yet we're sure he will revel, as he did in life, in the work and the rapture he has ahead. Funeral services will be at 10:00 A.M., Sunday at Sparkman/ Hillcrest Northwest Highway Chapel, Rabbi Gerald J. Klein officiating. Interment following at Hillcrest Memorial Park. The family will receive friends from 4:00 to 6:00 P.M. Saturday in the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial contributions be made to the American Cancer Society, 8900 John Carpenter Freeway, Dallas, Texas 75247 or to Dallas Visiting Nurse Assoc., 1440 West Mockingbird Lane, Suite 500, Dallas, Texas 75247.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, lines were dropped from a front-page article yesterday about a conference in Switzerland commemorating the centenary of the Zionist movement. The affected passage should have read, ''Of course, the letters are chiefly the work of a lunatic fringe. Nonetheless, they reflect a deterioration in Switzerland's relationship with the Jews, Israel and America since questions of money -- specifically the Swiss handling of Nazi plunder and the money of Holocaust victims -- erupted into broader disputes that have left the land of neutrality and probity wondering what its true self-image should be.''

title: Haunted By the Ghost Of an S.R.O.
description: A FENCED-IN patch of red and tan brick, smooth and flat, doesn't look like much of an attraction, but it's enough to draw some visitors who peer past the chain link. The dilapidated, city-owned single-room-occupancy hotel that used to stand on this corner of East First Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan was never much to behold, and the city declared it unsafe and demolished it in early July. Yet even in its absence, it exerts a hold on its former tenants, like an aching phantom limb.

title: Bridge
description: In World War II, Chungking in western China was the capital of the Chinese Nationalists under Chiang Kai-shek. Hardly any Westerners visited the area, nor have they since. Next week, however, the nearby city of Chongdu will be the bridge center of the planet. World stars from Europe and North America will compete in the Marlboro China tournament, beginning tomorrow.

title: METAL MANAGEMENT TO ACQUIRE AEROSPACE METALS
description: Metal Management Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Aerospace Metals Inc., based in Hartford, for $18 million in cash and $6.5 million in stock. Metal Management, a Chicago scrap-metal recycling company, said the closely held Aerospace produced materials from recycled scrap metal and had estimated annual revenue of $50 million. Under the terms of the deal, Metal Management will lease Aerospace's property. Metal Management had sales of $65.1 million for the year ended March 31. Its stock dropped 75 cents a share yesterday, to $21.625.

title: Clothes Shoppers Waiting on the Brink of a Break
description: On the eve of New York's second tax-free holiday on clothing this year, Lisa Leonard is taking stock of her 4-year-old son's wardrobe. Winter jacket? Last year's is a little tight. Pants? He needs more. Turtlenecks? Those, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTOR, SHEPARD
description: KANTOR-Shepard. The Trustees, Administration, Physicians and Staff of Gracie Square Hospital mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Dr. Kantor, beloved physician, coworker and friend for more than 20 years. Dr. Kantor was the founder and Medical Director of Gracie Square's Managed Care Unit, a unit that became a model for other psychiatric programs in the city, and led to much of the hospital's success in the last decade. Dr. Kantor was a man of great compassion and character, and will be deeply missed by his staff and patients. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, September 2, at 1:30 pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St, NYC Eleanor T. Elliott, Chair, Board of Trustees Frank Bruno, President Robert J. Campbell, MD, Medical Director

title: Republic to Buy Five Florida Auto Dealers
description: Republic Industries has agreed to buy five car dealerships in Florida for $47.3 million, seeking to cluster dealerships in its home state.

title: Woman Attacked in the Village; Neighbors Fear a Serial Rapist
description: A 25-year-old woman was raped in her Greenwich Village apartment yesterday morning by a man who had apparently followed her home from the subway, the police said.

title: Four Companies Taking 25% Stakes in J Sky B
description: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, and executives from the Sony Corporation and two other Japanese companies agreed at a meeting yesterday to take 25 percent stakes each in the Japan Sky Broadcasting Company. J Sky B, which is scheduled to begin 150-channel service in April, is the latest entrant in a race to deliver satellite television to Japan's 50 million households.

title: Dow Concludes Rough Month By Dropping 72.01 Points
description: July giveth and August taketh away.

title: U.S. Proposing Greater Powers On Food Safety
description: One week after the biggest meat recall in the nation's history, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman today proposed legislation that would broadly strengthen his department's powers over companies found to have produced tainted meat and poultry.

title: A Fighter Pilot Who Aimed for Novels but Lives on Film
description: In the universe of James Salter's novels, men are men and women don't have jobs. The characters drink Chateau Margaux and kirs and Calvados. The women give the men long, narrow looks and say wry things, and when they make love, the earth does not just move. It quakes.

title: Thyssen Sells Its Stake In Mobile Phone Concern
description: The German industrial giant Thyssen A.G. said yesterday that it had sold its stake in the mobile phone operator E-Plus Mobilfunk G.m.b.H. for 2.26 billion marks, or $1.25 billion. The 30.1 percent stake was sold to O.tel.o, a joint venture between the German utilities Veba A.G. and RWE A.G.

description: SCHUBIN-Edith. The officers, Board of Trustees, and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services extend sincere condolences to our colleague and fellow trustee, Milton J. title: Swedish Scandal
description: Sweden's self-image is built around its humane social welfare system at home and its promotion of racial harmony and economic development in the third world. That makes the revelation of a decades-long Swedish policy of coercing welfare recipients into racially motivated sterilizations all the more jarring, to Swedes and Americans as well. Nothing can undo the human damage already inflicted. But Swedish authorities must move swiftly to uncover the full story, acknowledge official responsibility and decently compensate the surviving victims.

title: PANTRY AND LIL' CHAMP CONVENIENCE CHAINS TO MERGE
description: Pantry Inc. will buy Lil' Champ Food Stores Inc., a convenience store chain, for cash and stock to expand Pantry's operations in the Southeastern United States. Terms were not disclosed. Pantry, based in Sanford, N.C., will acquire Lil' Champ from the closely held Docks U.S.A. Inc. Lil' Champ, based in Jacksonville, Fla., has 489 stores in Florida and Georgia and annual sales of about $500 million. The combined company will have 880 convenience stores and annual revenue of more than $900 million. Pantry is owned by the private investment firm Freeman Spogli & Company, which has an 84 percent stake, and Chase Capital Partners, with 16 percent.

description: SILVERMAN-Jane Dobrow (nee Haber) on August 29, at 97 after a lengthy and courageous struggle. Beloved wife of the late Sam Silverman and Oscar Dobrow. Devoted mother of the late Roslyn and Ellen. Survived by son Lawrence, brother Joseph, sisters Edna, Rae and Ann. Grandchildren Leslie, Olivia, Owen, Lauren, Pamela, Elizabeth, Goffrey and Tiffany and numerous greatgrandchildren. A woman of extraordinary accomplishment. Jane will be long and lovingly remembered. Graveside services Sunday, 12:30 PM, Mount Hebron Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Alzheimer research.

title: Teamsters Election Monitor Is Reported Planning to Quit
description: The Federal election overseer who recently annulled Ron Carey's re-election as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has said privately that she intends to resign, officials involved in monitoring the union said today.

title: Continental's Flight to Rio
description: Continental Airlines Inc. said today that it would begin a daily nonstop flight to Rio de Janeiro from Newark on Sunday. The airline began service to Brazil on July 10 with a flight from Newark to Sao Paulo and continuing on to Rio de Janeiro. The company said the Sao Paulo flight would continue daily. Continental, based in Houston, had 1996 revenues of $6.63 billion.

title: Beyond Yoga, Curry and Nehru Jackets Into Film, Publishing and Body Painting
description: Ever since the Beatles popularized Hinduism and Nehru jackets in the late 1960's, Indian cultural artifacts have had a vague currency in the American imagination. But lately, India and its inhabitants are indisputably chic.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday about a takeover offer by Union Pacific Resources Group Inc. for the Pennzoil Company misstated the ownership of Union Pacific Resources. It is independent; it is no longer a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation.

title: Jan Sejna, 70, Ex-Czech General and Defector
description: Jan Sejna, a former major general in the Czechoslovak Army who defected to the United States in 1968 and provided valuable intelligence on Communist military activities, died at his home in Bethesda, Md., on Saturday. He was 70.

title: Liberty's Last Stop: Championship Game
description: Teresa Weatherspoon's swagger. Kym Hampton's determination. Rebecca Lobo's intense stare. They all returned Thursday night.

title: Chinese Songs, So Open Yet So Lyrically Opaque
description: The high profile of Chinese composers in this country at the moment has several explanations. One must be the sheer quality of the work that many of them have been producing. Another has to do with the recent history of China, since most of these composers belong to the generation trained during the period of relief immediately after the Cultural Revolution.

title: A Durable Operation On Too Solid Ground
description: For years, even as rivals like First Union and Nationsbank gobbled up banks across the country and moved into Barnett Banks Inc.'s backyard, Barnett prided itself as being ''Florida's bank.''

title: 3 Versions of Ex-Lax Are Recalled After F.D.A. Proposes Ban on Ingredient
description: The maker of Ex-Lax, the nation's top-selling overnight laxative, pulled three versions of the product off store shelves today after the Food and Drug Administration proposed a ban on the main ingredient, which has been linked to cancer in rats and mice.

title: Candidates Take to the Shore

The Governor will hop on her bike this morning for a two-day, 74-mile ride from Long Branch to Ocean City, with 17 stops along the way, Tom Wilson, her campaign manager, said. Mr. McGreevey began a stroll down the beach yesterday morning in Sandy Hook that will end tomorrow 40 miles south in Atlantic City, Rich McGrath, a campaign spokesman, said. title: Sampras vs. History
description: To judge from most of the predictions on this year's U.S. Open, Pete Sampras isn't competing against the field but against tennis history and the greats of previous generations. Is Sampras really the best tennis player ever? The question is harder to answer in tennis than in some other sports. Few modern fans, for example, would hesitate to call Michael Jordan the best basketball player ever. title: Tradegy at Sea         n    By Suzanne O'Connor     SEA TALES: INFERNO ON THE MORRO CASTLE looks at the tragedy as an unsolved mystery, with re-enactments, archival film and survivor interviews. The luxury liner burst into explosive flames in 1934, on her 174th cruise between Havana and New York, killing 134 people. Was this an accident or a madman's plot? The narrator Patrick Tull relates the intrigues of that night: a captain found dead in his stateroom; a radioman intitially hailed as a hero who ended his life in prison (for arson); an acting captain who failed to sound the general alarm or order an SOS call. The Morro Castle washed ashore off Asbury Park, N.J., where she lay for three months before being sold as scrap. - THURS. at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M. on A&E.       Photo. (Associated Press)

title: Hip-Hopping Onto the Late-Night Scene         n    BY LISA W. FODERARO     FOR more than three years, television executives have bemoaned the void left by Arsenio Hall, the first successful black host of a late-night talk show. They have waited patiently for someone who had the power to enthrall young African-American viewers while crossing over to a wider audience, someone capable of delivering a high-energy show that would make the two reigning princes of late night, Jay Leno and David Letterman, look downright dowdy.              Well, they may have found him, in stereo.     Earlier this month, on the same night, at the same time (11 in New York City), Keenen Ivory Wayans and Chris Spencer, both Black comedians with neat goatees and neon smiles, made their debuts from Los Angeles. In a droll nod to their syndication showdown, Mr. Spencer, whose show, ''Vibe,'' is seen in New York City on WWOR, Channel 9, pulled out a congratulatory fruit basket sent him by Mr. Wayans. As he began his monologue, chomping on a plum, he collapsed as though poisoned.     There is another new show in the wings with the potential to draw a young, multiracial audience. The basketball legend Earvin (Magic) Johnson is now taping pilots for a late-night talk show he is developing with Twenthieth Television, the syndication division of Fox Studios. Called ''The Magic Hour,'' it is scheduled to begin early next year, ideally after either Mr. Wayans or Mr. Spencer has called it a night, those involved in the production whisper.     Of the two new hosts already on the air, 39-year-old Mr. Wayans, whose show is on WNYW, Channel 5, in New York, has the edge in terms of name recognition. He was the creator and star of the Emmy Award-winning comedy series ''In Living Color'' and has also had success in films, as a star of ''Hollywood Shuffle'' and as writer, director and star of ''A Low Down Dirty Shame.''     The set of his new show is a pastiche of shape and color: no desk, just a couple of modernist couches, a coffee table resembling a giant peanut and a sprawling fish tank that glows lavender. Mr. Wayans's sartorial tastes range from Flashy to bizarre. One night he sported a shiny black jumpsuit, another night a slinky chartreuse shirt, all topped off with clunky jewelry.     Despite the trappings, Mr. Wayans has an easy way about him. He seemed preternaturally calm on opening night in contrast to one of his guests, the actor Brendan Fraser, who nearly gulped with nervousness. And Mr. Wayans loves to coax his guests into talking about sex. Pamela Anderson Lee, the former star of ''Baywatch,'' volunteered that her libido knew no bounds now that she was pregnant.     ''Has pregnancy slowed you down?'' Mr. Wayans asked.     ''Your sex drive is through the roof,'' she exclaimed. ''There are no sharp corners on any of the furniture at home.''     Then there are the off-the-wall comedy sketches and mock commercials. A public-service announcement with the message ''Smoke: because holes in throats are pretty cool'' showed a nicotine-addicted grandmother blowing out birthday candles and playing a saxophone through her neck. Another, a takeoff on commercials for exercise contraptions, advertised the ''Sexerciser'' for $29.95, with vigorous demonstrations.     ''Keenen has a big following that loves and adores him, which is a great help,'' said Charlie Parsons, a British television producer who is collaborating on the show as an executive producer with Mr. Wayans and Eric L. Gold. '' 'In Living Color' was universal in its comedic appeal. This new show has a generational appeal. The target audience is younger and hipper. Everyone is welcome.''     Mr. Parsons said that while Mr. Leno's and Mr. Letterman's shows were ''incredibly well produced,'' he believed there was ''definitely an audience that isn't being serviced by them.''     The star of ''Vibe,'' 29-year-old Mr. Spencer, is after the same audience. ''We're just trying to add some flavor to the milk,'' he said in an interview. Many viewers ''left the whole late-night arena after Arsenio,'' he added. ''There are a bunch of artists who don't get the opportunities because of the style of music they play or the kinds of jokes they tell.''     While Mr. Spencer may not have a household name, the creator of his show, Quincy Jones, does. A musician, composer, and record and film producer who has won 26 Grammy Awards, Mr. Jones has styled the show on his three-year-old magazine, ''Vibe.''     His connections have given the scenes and on the screen. An executive producer, Daniel Kellison, helped start ''The Rosie O'Donnell Show'' and before that spent eight years with Mr. Letterman. The director, Sandra Fullerton, held the same job with Mr. Hall from 1989 to 1994.     Mr. Jones appeared for 10 minutes at the start of the first show before handing it over to Mr. Spencer. in those few minutes, he schmoozed with President Clinton about America's youth in an appearance taped at the White House. Then Mr. Jones told viewers, ''No matter what your age or race or sex, 'Vibe,' will be an equal opportunity entertainer.''     The guests that night included Whoopi Goldberg, Brandy, Anthony Edwards of ''E.R.,'' the female rap group Salt-n-Pepa and, by satellite, Denzel Washington and Spike Lee.     The choice of the relatively unknown Mr. Spencer is not as odd as it seems. He is, after all, young, handsome and very funny. ''How often is a brother given an opportunity to go into a million homes and not be arrested?'' he quipped upon first taking the stage.     A peripatetic stand-up comic, Mr. Spencer, who favors expensive-looking, trendy jackets, has appeared on MTV, ''In Living Color'' and Mr. Hall's show. He also has close ties to the Wayans family. He had a starring role in the film ''Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood,'' which Keenen Wayans produced. And in the publicity kit for ''Vibe,'' Mr. Spencer named Mr. Wayans's brother, Damon, the comedian and actor, as one of his role models, along with Jack Paar and Mohammed Ali.     Like ''The Keenan Ivory Wayans Show,'' ''Vibe'' strives for an integrated guest list. A recent show included the actress Demi Moore and the model Naomi Campbell. The studio audience is also integrated, roughly half white and half black. Only the musical guests seem one-dimensional, with the focus on rap and soul. But Mr. Spencer said he saw nothing wrong with that.     ''Hip-hop is now pop,'' he said. ''When you see Japanese kids getting their hair fried so it looks like an Afro and wearing pants falling off, that's not about acting black. That's about pop culture.'' His guests on the first show included the rap group Salt-n-Pepa (from left, Pepa, Salt and Spinderella). Quincy Jones, Below, is the show's creater and executive producer. (Vibe)(pg. 3); The hip trailblazer, Arsenio Hall, right, interviewing Robert De Niro. (pg. 41); David Letterman, right, on his show, with Grant Hill of the Detroit Pistons.
