title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDRIDGE, RUTH WILLIAMSON
description: ELDRIDGE - Ruth Williamson. Died August 27, 1997, at age 92, in Gwynedd, PA. She and her late husband were early residents of Foulkeways, the first Quaker retirement community. She was graduated from Schoharie High School, age 16, and Albany School of Nursing, age 20. She was a nurse with the Henry Street Settlement House on NYC's lower eastside at the time of her marriage to Lewis A. Eldridge Jr., in 1928. The defining period in her life covered the next three years in Berlin, Germany. There she heard Richard Strauss conduct ''Solome,'' Furtwangler conducting Beethoven and Schnabel playing Schubert and Mozart. This lead to a life-long love of classical music and the German people. On return to Great Neck, NY, she studied voice with Alda Astori and later in Rensselaerville, NY, organized summer concerts. Deeply disturbed by the Second World War, she was lead to the Quaker faith. She was secretary of the New York Yearly Meeting, and the library at the Albany Friends Meeting was named in her honor. Survivors include a son Roswell Eldridge of Rensselaerville, NY, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Her husband died in 1977, and her oldest son, Lewis A. Eldridge III, of Oyster Bay, NY, died in 1982. A memorial service will take place in September in Rensselaerville, NY. Contributions to American Friends Service Committee, Philadelphia, and the Metropolitan Opera.

title: LABOR OF LOVE
description: Robert Short, whose ''Gospel According to Peanuts'' topped the nonfiction best-seller lists 32 years ago, has long wanted to do another book of comic-strips-as-devotional-tool using ''Calvin and Hobbes.'' ''You could make a case for the tiger, Hobbes, being a kind of Christ,'' Short says. ''Calvin, like humanity, can be selfish and mean, but Hobbes's attitude is complete love for him.'' Sadly, Bill Watterson won't play ball -- a devout recluse who shut down the strip in 1995, he steadfastly refuses to license the images. Undaunted, Short has gone bootleg, packing churches and college auditoriums with a lecture called ''Short Meditations on Calvin and Hobbes and Christ.'' Is it legal to do this without permission? ''If they tell me to quit it, I'll quit,'' Short says. But what strip would work instead? ''I'm also interested in 'B.C.' ''

title: Science Fiction
description: The Inquisition is back. This is the animating premise of THE RISE OF ENDYMION (Spectra/Bantam, $23.95), the fourth book of Dan Simmons's galaxy-spanning series that began in 1989 with ''Hyperion.'' For vastness of scope, clarity of detail and seriousness of purpose, Simmons's epic narrative is on a par with Isaac Asimov's Foundation series, Frank Herbert's ''Dune'' books, Gene Wolfe's multipart ''Book of the New Sun'' and Brian Aldiss's Helliconia trilogy. No one in modern science fiction, not even Wolfe, has dealt more sensitively with the interface between religion and science. Yet ''The Rise of Endymion,'' like its three predecessors, is also a full-blooded action novel, replete with personal combats and battles in space that are distinguished from formulaic space opera by the magnitude of what is at stake -- which is nothing less than the salvation of the human soul.

But then his team stepped up the defense and mastered the full-court press. Instead of being traded last season, the Kid closed out his opponents. Though critics accuse him of not having a master game plan, his coaches say he is playing for the history books now. He'd just like to score a couple of decisive slam dunks.

description: JUST as every garden has perennials and annuals, the Hamptons' restaurant scene is a mix of brightly colored beauties that fade with winter's first cold blasts and sturdy blooms that have put down roots and blossom every season. The Annex in Wainscott is a hardy one.

title: Billion-Dollar Plan to Clean New York City Water at Its Source
description: The flow of drinking water to New York City begins as far away as a damp spot under some leaves on a mountainside 120 miles north of Times Square. For 155 years, the city has maintained a complicated network of reservoirs and aqueducts to carry rain and melted snow from distant hills to bathtubs in Brooklyn and sinks on Staten Island.

title: S.A.T. Scores in State Up in Verbal, Stable in Math
description: S.A.T. scores among New Jersey students mirrored a nationwide trend this year, with performance on the verbal part of the test roughly stable and with a three-point gain in math, the College Board reported last week. New Jersey scores continue to lag behind those in the rest of the country, however.

title: Epitome of Needy Nerdiness
description: TO SITCOM WONKS STEEPED IN the lofty pedagogy of Archie Bunker, Mary Richards, Heathcliff Huxtable, Ralph Kramden and Lucy Ricardo, the name Steve Urkel arouses serious heebie-jeebies. Highbrows easily dismiss Urkel (played by Ja leel White) as the high-I.Q. geek in ABC's ''Family Matters'' who speaks in a falsetto that has grown falser as Mr. White has aged from 12 to 20 during the series' run and wears oversize red-framed glasses, plaid shirts, saddle shoes and denims hiked to his nipples to reveal long expanses of white socks. Elitists are appalled that his name evokes the oral historian Studs Terkel, whose oeuvre rarely crosses into Urkel's demographic.

title: Harnisch-Valentine Dispute Overshadows Victory
description: The Mets have already surpassed their victory total from 1996, with four weeks and a day remaining in this season. Bobby Valentine, their manager, has a new three-year contract and speaks of a new and improved direction for a team in a downward spiral for most of this decade.

description: JANES-Frank. 54, died suddenly in Houston, TX, August 28, 1997 of a heart attack. description: THREE weeks of sliding stock prices have reminded many investors how unwise it can be to put all their eggs in one basket (or one market). In addition to the mattress, money market funds and bond funds, there is a new place Americans can shelter a chunk of their nest eggs: commodity mutual funds.

This beautiful man-beloved father of Leland, Andrew and the late Kenneth, Gregory and Barry and adored husband of Stella-will, until we meet again, be held precious in our memory and very deeply missed. description: Two young lovers lay flared out on the crushed velvet couch, strung out on their own hipness. He stared at a fan, contemplating infinity. She picked the polish off her nails. A typical night in the Village. Except this was Astoria, Queens. Archie Bunker land. First stop U.S.A.

title: Keeping a Bullet-Torn Music Alive
description: GANGSTA RAP DIDN'T DIE with Tupac Shakur and the Notorious B.I.G. -- not as long as Bone Thugs-n-Harmony are around. Krayzie Bone, Layzie Bone, Bizzy Bone and Wish Bone are still following the strategy announced by the group's name on ''The Art of War,'' their third collection since 1994. Bone Thugs-n-Harmony got together in Cleveland and were groomed in Los Angeles by Eazy-E, who learned how to push the hot buttons of sex and violence with N.W.A. Bone Thugs-n-Harmony blend tales of mayhem with smooth, unhurried backing tracks; though the Bones don't actually harmonize much, they do sing their choruses. They also have some distinctive rap cadences: a singsong two-note style derived from Jamaican dancehall toasting, along with double-time rapping and even faster triplets.

title: Holiday? What Holiday?
description: WITH 3,000 guests staying in the 1,624 hotel rooms at the Tropicana Casino and Resort this weekend, Roseann Gotta's only hope is that she'll be able to go home and tend her roses after a shift that can last 12 hours. Ms. Gotta, a garde-manger chef, is one of 120 employees in the Tropicana's room service operation. ''Just about all of us work Labor Day weekend,'' she said. ''It's the last hurrah of the summer, so everybody wants to be here.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELAND, WARREN HANAN, ESQ.
description: LELAND-Warren Hanan, Esq., an engineering-construction company executive, of Juno Beach, Florida and formerly of Duxbury & Boston, MA., died at his family's home in Wilton, CT. on July 28. Mr. Leland was born in New York City, NY on August 7, 1915. He was the son of the late Lewis and Rose (Eichman) Leland. He was married to the late Jeanne Mary Frith on December 12, 1959. Mr. Leland was educated at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where he received his B.A. in 1939 and his L.L.B. in 1941. He served in the USAAF as a pilot and Intelligence Officer in WWII, participating in numerous battles and campaigns in Tunisia, Rhineland, India/Burma and China. He was honorably discharged at the rank of Major in 1946. Mr. Leland was admitted to the Bar in New York in 1946. Mr. Leland was Vice President and General Counsel, Kellogg International Corporation, London, England, 1959-1965; Vice President and General Counsel, M.W. Kellogg & Co., New York City, New York, 1965-1970; Vice President and General Counsel, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp., Boston, MA, 1970-1978; Sr Executive Vice President and Director, Stone & Webster Engineering Corp., Boston, MA, 1978-1992; Director, Stone & Webster Overseas Corp., 1978-1992; Chairman of the Board and Director, Solid Circulation Systems, Inc., Boston, MA, 1982-1992; Chairman of the Board and Director, Multifuel Boilers, Inc., Boston, MA, 1982-1992; Private Investor, 1992-1997; wonderful grandfather, 1993-1997. Mr. Leland leaves his daughter, Susan L. Safko of Connecticut; his son, Colin W. Leland of Connecticut; and his two granddaughters, Christen Frith Safko and Lauren Leland Safko of Connecticut.

title: For a Projector Maker, Multiplexes Are a Ticket to Growth

title: Bookshelf

It was such a mess that he left the woods and went to the city to find new materials and techniques. Rescued by a little girl who offers him spaghetti, ribbons and shoelaces, he finally learns from her to weave and goes home. Now his nests look like baskets. The tangles are very funny.

description: WESTCHESTER'S stock of affluent, well-motivated students would seem to be the type who would do well in college. Instead, many are leaving school after their freshman year, a trend that is alarming school officials and compelling them to try to staunch the flow.

title: Curtain Up         n    By Howard Thompson     Though Hitchcock acknowledged that STAGE FRIGHT (1950) missed the target, it does score on backstage atmosphere. The main weakness is the meandering whodunit, as a veteran sleuth's daughter (Jane Wyman) endeavors to shield the main suspect, a handsome young actor (Richard Todd, above). At the center fo the case, a musical star (Marlene Dietrich) flutters flirtatiously. Ms. Wyman is natural as ever, Todd looks desperate and Dietrich adds gauzy allure. The fringe rewards include the veterans Alastair Sim and Sybil Thorndike as Ms. Wyman's parents. But the best performance comes from Kay Walsh in a cameo as a slatternly maid. - THURS. at 2 P.M. on AMC.          Photo: Richard Todd (Warner Brothers)

title: Robert McNamara And the Ghosts Of Vietnam
description: As a former United Nations official who worked in Cambodia and, more recently, Bosnia, I was hoping to find some sage insight into conflict avoidance or resolution. Instead, I was startled to find that McNamara comes away from all his experience with the realization that you must ''understand your opponent.'' As an example of real or imagined ''opponents,'' he includes ''the Bosnians.'' This is the first time I've heard that the warring factions in the former Yugoslavia are or were ''opponents'' of the United States. In traditional peace-keeping missions, parties to a conflict are treated somewhat differently than as ''opponents.''

They all fled Congress in the last few years, joining a virtual riptide of legislators who've decided that the Hill just isn't cool anymore. (''I feel like I got out of an elevator before they cut the cord,'' says Schroeder, now president of the Association of American Publishers.) While it's hard to believe that any job offering power and cheap haircuts could be unpopular, one hypothesis -- to be aired at this weekend's convention of the American Political Science Association in Washington -- has it that negative perceptions about Congress are even tainting the applicant pool.

title: Industrial Strength Bleakness
description: The only thing wrong with the title of Jeff Torrington's new novel, THE DEVIL'S CAROUSEL (Harcourt Brace, $23), is that it turns out to be too upbeat. If there's a bleaker, grimier, more desperate existence than that of a Scottish auto worker yoked to the Centaur Car Company's assembly line (otherwise known as ''the Widow'' or ''the Devil's Carousel''), it would have to be hell itself - and even there, it couldn't possibly rain as much. The Centaur Car Company is clearly on its last legs, and so too are its employees. After receiving a rare sick-leave pass, one of them staggers home, only to lose his shoes and his life in the gutter outside a fishmonger's shop; a collection taken up for his widow nets a pitiful amount because there have been so many similar appeals. Another worker teeters into insanity upon learning that his years-old employee ID number has changed; a third fakes his own death, with disastrous results. Torrington (who won the Whitbread Prize for his first novel, ''Swing Hammer Swing!'') uses unapologetically blunt prose, painting the world of the factory floor in vivid, lurid detail. Occasional bouts of dark humor - frequently delivered via typescript facsimiles of the plant's renegade employee newsletter - do more to underscore the bitterness of the characters than lighten the relentlessly despairing mood. More a series of loosely connected short stories than a single narrative, the novel progresses in fits and starts, much like the factory's beleaguered assembly line. The effect perfectly echoes the fragmented lives of its subjects, making ''The Devil's Carousel'' a jolting ride. Liam Callanan

I wondered what the cave must feel like from inside, and briefly considered the idea of trying to scale the almost vertical cliff in order to find out. Prudence prevailed, however, and I decided to appreciate it from below.

title: For 125 Years, a Big Industry That Produces Delicate Lace

But 125 years after the first hand-embroidery shops opened across the Hudson from Manhattan's garment industry and a century since the arrival of embroidery machines, foreign competition has weakened the $300 million industry. In the last 15 years, 20 percent of its business has been lost, as have many jobs that traditionally employed the area's Swiss, German, Hispanic and Indian immigrants. Computer automation of the massive embroidery machines that turn out meticulously delicate patterns has improved efficiency for those who can afford it. But many of the industry's 400 mostly family-run businesses cannot.

title: THE BEAT GOES ON
description: *Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road'' was published 40 years ago this week, and though the Beats themselves are all dying off, their popularity isn't. *The novel sold 110,000 copies last year alone -- a figure most contemporary novelists can only dream about. *Viking, the original publisher, is capitalizing on the anniversary by releasing ''Some of the Dharma,'' a 420-page book of Kerouac's unpublished Buddhist prayers, journal entries, poems and scattershotiana. *Sample: ''It's five minutes/after/Eleven -- puff.'' (Page 385.) *Sample: ''Once I was a bug/And I died in a rose.'' (Page 319.) *How will fans approach the new work? ''I won't look for logic or rationality,'' says Levi Asher, creator of Literary Kicks, a Beat-oriented Web site. ''I'll just try to hop onto whatever wavelength Jack seems to be riding and see if I like it there.''

title: Seeing Themselves
description: The collective identity of the French people during the world wars and the forging of that identity are the subjects of the ambitious book THE FRENCH IN LOVE AND WAR: Popular Culture in the Eras of the World Wars (Yale University, $35). Charles Rearick, a professor of history at the University of Massachusetts, focuses on the little people, frequently setting one of them off against an Other - the rich man, the foreigner or the cosmopolitan. The ''myth of the people,'' Rearick writes, ''has had a long history and a changing cast of characters.'' In France that cast has traditionally included such figures as Joan of Arc and Marianne, the mythical symbol of the Republic; Rearick extends the cast to include entertainers like Maurice Chevalier, Mistinguett, Jean Gabin and Edith Piaf, all of whom, for one reason or another, served as representations of the French people in the years from World War I to the end of World War II. These became important during that period as a result of dramatic changes in French society, in which workers and the lower middle classes gained political and economic strength, thus becoming important voters as well as consumers of mass culture. Therefore they determined which images would be provided for them as much as they served as models for those images. While ''The French in Love and War'' is well researched, well documented and full of interesting details (plus more than 125 illustrations), it is annoyingly redundant. Moreover, Rearick's narrative drive frequently stalls as he devotes large chunks of space and time to explicating the stories of popular songs and films of the day. Despite these quibbles, this is a valuable and informative book that goes a long way toward proving one of Rearick's central theses, that ''inexact or distortional, the myths and symbols of popular culture still matter historically for the part they played in organizing experience and representing identity.'' Robin Lippincott

He studied at Harvard Divinity and graduated from The Episcopal Theological Seminary, Cambridge, MA, in 1935. He was ordained to the deaconate in June 1935, by the Right Reverend Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church of America. He was assigned to St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Bridgeport, CT, in 1942, and held that position for over 30 years. Rev. Morgan retired but remained active within the ministry of St. John's Episcopal Church until 1991. He was a member of Masonic Temple of America, St. John's Lodge No. 8, A.F. and A.M., Stratford, CT, and was past Grand Chaplain of the Masonic Order of CT. Rev. Morgan was a direct descendant of Miles Morgan, founder of Springfield, MA, and also of William Janes, a found of New Haven, CT. He is survived by his wife Marcia Childs Morgan, his children Marcia M. Fish, Edward C. Morgan, Kingsley Morgan, Sarah M. Orefice, Margaret M. Blanda, a sister Olive M. Turner and 13 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. The body of Rev. Morgan will be received into St. John's Episcopal Church, Bridgeport, and lie in state. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASMIR, CYRIL DAVID
description: KASMIR-Cyril David, age 52, left this world on August 28, 1997. He was comfortable and surrounded by his family. He chose to leave us when we were all smiling, laughing and basking in the joy that he had brought to all of us. Cyril's strong will and undying spirit will continue to live on in his children Darren, Justin and Sean, and his memory will perpetually provide comfort and guidance to all whom he touched. In addition to his children, he is survived by his loving wife Brenda, his parents Frank and Celia Kasmir, his brother Sam, sister Susan, extended family and many loving friends. Words fail us at this time of great loss, end of suffering, and start of a peaceful rest. We can honor and celebrate a good life, full of passion during which he loved and was loved completely. His youth never left him. Cyril worked tirelessly to provide for his family and to take care of his friends. He was always there for us. He had something to teach us all. His passing will be deeply mourned, yet those who knew him can take solace in the memory of his laughter and of his expressions, both the smiling ones and the stern. He has earned a peaceful rest, yet we're sure he will revel, as he did in life, in the work and the rapture he has ahead. Funeral services will be at 10:00 A.M., Sunday at Sparkman/ Hillcrest Northwest Highway Chapel, Rabbi Gerald J. Klein officiating. Interment following at Hillcrest Memorial Park. The family will receive friends from 4:00 to 6:00 P.M. Saturday in the Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial contributions be made to the American Cancer Society, 8900 John Carpenter Freeway, Dallas, Texas 75247 or to Dallas Visiting Nurse Assoc., 1440 West Mockingbird Lane, Suite 500, Dallas, Texas 75247.

But the many other and welcome distractions made the studied cuteness of the place easy to ignore. And nothing was out of date with the creative fare nor with the kitchen, which does not miss a beat even when playing to only a handful of diners on a slow weekday night.

title: Wrap Star
description: Once upon a time, there was a princess with an idea. The idea was a dress. Not a taffeta ball gown like the ones fairy-tale heroines usually wear -- this was a drip-dry, cotton jersey dress that wrapped in front and tied at the waist. The princess devised cunning prints in vivid colors and arranged for the dress to be manufactured and sold. In no time, women all across the land were buying the dresses -- five million of them -- and wearing them. And even though the princess was a member of the jet set, famous far and wide as a glamorous party girl, her dress was seen as evidence of an uncanny knack for identifying with her customers: they felt that she must have understood them to have invented something so comfortable and practical, so suitable to their own everyday adventures and to their newfound sense of independence.

Movement often played a part, as did music and, eventually, video, in pieces that played generally to audiences of peers.

title: Train-Safety Inspections Follow Fatal Wrecks at Union Pacific
description: Scores of Federal inspectors arrived unannounced this week at the offices, rail yards and dispatching centers of Union Pacific, the nation's largest railroad, to determine why it has had a series of fatal train wrecks.

title: Healing a Disfigured Rembrandt's Wounds
description: UNTIL IT WAS IRREVERSIBLY damaged by a vandal in the summer of 1985, Rembrandt's ''Danae'' was by common consent one of the most beautiful of all European paintings. Though at first believed to have been damaged beyond any hope of recovery, it is to go back on view in the Hermitage here on Oct. 13 after 12 years of close and often perilous work on its restoration.

title: At Arthur Ashe Stadium, Most Find Something to Love
description: Pat and Jeanne Hurd had been prepared to resist the charms of the new Arthur Ashe Stadium. For more than a decade, the sisters had been watching the tennis matches of the United States Open inside the old, time-tested arena, and they felt an understandable fidelity to it. Perhaps it wasn't young and stylish, but it had shown them the best of times.

title: Midwestern Idea, New York Twist
description: LIGHTLY more than two years ago, a group of high-powered and well-connected New York women formed their own investment club. Inspired by the Beards town Ladies, the successful Midwestern women's club that described its homespun style of picking stocks in a best-selling book, the New Yorkers set out to learn more about finance. Despite impressive jobs in fashion and real estate, and marriages to men who run huge enterprises, these women discovered that they, too, had been woefully ignorant when it came to money.

title: When Opera Singers Mattered, These Mattered More Than Most
description: BABY-BOOMERS MAY HIT the millennium without stars. There are super-successes, these days, but no legends. To get a hint of what is missing, one need only turn to recent video and audio releases: two silent movies starring the astounding soprano Geraldine Farrar and the first of two phases of EMI's huge CD reissue of recordings by the sainted Maria Callas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERKIN, DEWITT, JR.
description: PETERKIN-DeWitt, Jr., of Noroton, CT. Died August 29, 1997 of heart failure and complications related to Parkinsons Disease. He was 84. Mr. Peterkin is survived and missed by his wife Katharine Urban, two daughters Clare and Kate, three sons DeWitt III, George, and Patrick and his wife Jennifer and three grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister Jane Gurney and his brother John Peterkin. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 5 at 11am at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Rd., Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to The American Parkinson's Association, 1250 Hyland Blvd., Staten Island, NY 10305-1946 or to Waveny Care Center Employee Fund, 3 Farm Rd., New Canaan, CT 06840.

description: IN Louisiana, if a person tries to steal another person's car while that person is sitting in it, then the driver has the legal right to pull a pistol, squirrel gun or assault rifle and shoot the suspected carjacker in any part of the anatomy he can hit, by chance or skill.

title: Where Even Cops Get Robbed
description: Crime, or more precisely a rising fear of crime, has become the most serious threat to the success of South Africa's fledgling democratic government. Even a short-time visitor to the nation's chief commercial city is struck by its beleaguered atmosphere. Tour guides warn you not to venture out alone unless you know where you are going. Hotels have ramped down their operations, and many businesses have fled to the suburbs. Whole blocks of apartments have been taken over by drug dealers. Residents of the tonier suburbs live behind walls topped with barbed wire and protected by private security firms, their bedrooms sealed off by internal rape-prevention gates.

title: The Vallone Hearings
description: The Louima brutality case is an ugly reminder that New York City has yet to establish a strong, independent body to monitor and investigate police misconduct. The City Council created such an agency in 1994, but Mayor Rudolph Giuliani vetoed the bill. When the Council overrode the veto, the Mayor successfully challenged the bill in court on the grounds that it infringed on executive authority.

title: Asking Fairness For Mount Kisco
description: After reading your interview with Graciela Heymann (Westchester Q&A, July 6), I have to question why the town of Mount Kisco is being unfairly depicted as a racist town and how the rights of day workers have anything to do with racism. It is unethical for employers to exploit the day workers, and it is an issue that must be dealt with.
